DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan begins promotion of digital content industry

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) formally opened its Digital Content Industry Promotion Office Tuesday as a first step in an ambitious plan to develop Taiwan as a global digital publication center.

Presiding over the inauguration ceremony, Chou Neng-chuan, deputy director- general of the MOEA Industrial Development Bureau, described the office as a hub from which efforts will be made to promote and expand the digital content industry in Taiwan.

The bureau has decided to spend NT$3.885 billion (US$121 million) over the next five years to develop the digital content sector, a goal that is listed as one of the government's flagship projects within the cultural creative industry, Chou said.

He said one of the office's first tasks will be to establish at least two trading centers for Chinese-language electronic books by the year 2013. It will also seek to develop at least 10 creative technology applications related to reading and will aim for local content on electronic reading devices to be increased to at least 80 percent of the total, he added.

Meanwhile, Chou said, over the next five years, the center will make efforts to publish and market 100,000 copies of Chinese-language e-books, attract NT$10 billion-worth investment in the digital publishing industry, increase the digital reading population to 1 million, and expand the production value of the digital publishing sector to NT$100 billion by 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan university to launch master's credit program in Shanghai

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Shih Hsin University will launch a master's credit cohort program in Shanghai at the end of October, targeting Taiwanese businessmen in China, the university's representative in Shanghai said Wednesday.

The program is aimed at providing an opportunity for Taiwanese investors and employees in China to pursue advanced studies in communication management, according to Shen Tsung-nan, deputy head of the Shanghai-based Shih Hsin Extension Education Institute which will host the classes.
In the initial stage, the program will be offered to 30 students and the classes will be held one weekend a month starting Oct. 31, Shen said.
The purpose of the program is to provide a fast track for China-based Taiwanese to obtain a master's degree from the university, according to Shen.

He said the university will apply to the Ministry of Education (MOE) at the end of October to allow graduate credit hours earned in Shanghai to be counted toward a master's degree. The MOE's decision will be released around late January, he added.
Currently, under Taiwan's education regulations, credits earned outside the country cannot be counted towards a graduate degree in Taiwan schools, Shen noted.

The courses to be offered at the institute are those for which credits are most commonly transferred, he said. They include organization theory and management, communication theory, media marketing and management, and human resource management in the media.
At the start of the program, the Taiwanese students will be enrolled in two classes -- organization and management, and communication theory, according to Shen.

According to Peng Si-zhou, head of the Department of International Business, Taipei College of Maritime Technology, there is high demand among Taiwanese businessmen in China for further study opportunities to enhance their knowledge, particularly in the areas of cultural and creative industry and the service sector.

Besides, in the short term, offering classes to Taiwanese across the strait is a good way for private universities to expand business, Peng said, noting that there are about 1 million Taiwanese based in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF will not be represented at China national day celebrations

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday that it will not send any representative to attend China's 60th national day celebrations or other relevant activities in Beijing.

Ma Shao-chang, SEF deputy secretary general, was responding to questions on whether SEF Vice Chairman Rock Hsu is among the some 150 Taiwan figures who have accepted Beijing's invitation to attend China's 60th national day celebrations on Oct. 1.

The SEF is a semi-official agency authorized by the government to handle exchanges with China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) in the absence of official contact between the two sides.
Ma said that Hsu, chairman of the Kinpo Group, will take part in the event in a personal capacity, and his planned participation has nothing to do with the SEF or any other official agency in Taiwan.
Ma added that Hsu is one of the private sector representatives on the SEF's board of directors and is therefore not obliged to obtain SEF approval for travel to Beijing for any purpose.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said while the government has no legal power to forbid any private individual from attending the Beijing celebrations, Hsu, who is now in Beijing, should think twice before he decides to do so and should "keep public sentiment in mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: THSRC sacks one employee, disciplines 24 for profiteering

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) fired one its station superintendents Wednesday after it was found that the person had been engaged in profiteering at the expense of the company, officials said.

In addition, 24 employees were disciplined for using insider knowledge to snag personal profits, THRSC officials said, adding that this was the company's first round of disciplinary action against dishonest workers.

The debt-ridden high speed railway company confirmed earlier in the day that 98 employees, mostly station staff, were suspected of hurting the company's interests by taking advantage of their position to make profits.

The 25 employees were found to have stocked up on "buy four get one free" group tickets, based on insider knowledge that the company would cancel train services during Typhoon Morakot in early August.
Those employees cashed in on the company's refund policy and its compensatory free voucher offers to ticket holders when services were canceled during the storm, the THSRC disclosed.
Meanwhile, another 73 employees are still being questioned about their suspected attempts to make money from a promotional Father's Day offer last month.

Under the "88 program" launched Aug. 8 on Father's Day, holders of tickets with serial numbers ending with 88 were entitled to vouchers for half-price tickets valid for Aug. 7-9. But because trains were canceled on those two day due to Typhoon Morakot, only a few people eventually got the half-price coupons.

It was found that a large number of THSRC employees had kept the tickets with the '88' serial numbers for themselves, officials of the company said, adding that a second round of punishment will be handed out when the interrogation process is completed.
The supervisors of those dishonest employees will also be disciplined for poor management, the officials added.
Earlier in the day, THSRC Chairman Ou Chin-der expressed regret over the incidents, saying that he considers honor and discipline among employees as top priority.
The cases have prompted the company to review its ticketing system, said Ou, who assumed chairmanship of the THRSC last week after Nita Ing resigned from the position.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pregnant A(H1N1) patient who lost her baby recovers

TEXT.P: A woman who was discharged from hospital Wednesday after recovering from a serious case of influenza A(H1N1) said "it is good to be alive", although she lost her baby in her sixth month of pregnancy.

The 25-year-old woman, surnamed Chen, was the first pregnant A(H1N1) patient recorded in Taiwan. She was transferred from Pingtung County to Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital (KVGH) in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, on Aug. 13 after she developed symptoms of pneumonia.

KVGH Vice President Huang Jung-ching said that when the patient arrived at the hospital she was having difficulty breathing. She was given the antiviral drug Tamiflu and placed on the extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) system, he said, adding that they were the key treatments that saved the woman's life.
However, it is regrettable that she lost the baby, Huang said.

Chen said she had no idea of how she contracted the H1N1 virus. She advised that pregnant women who contract A(H1N1), also known as swine flu, should stick to the doctors' treatment, despite concerns over Tamiflu's side effects.

The Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) reported Wednesday that seven more patients had been hospitalized in Taiwan for severe H1N1 symptoms in the previous 24 hours, bringing the total number of hospitalized cases since the outbreak began to 305.
Of that number, 18 had died, 30 were still being treated in hospitals, while the other 257 had been discharged.
The fatalities included one woman who died two days after giving birth to a baby boy and another who was pregnant and declined to take Tamiflu.
A CECC official said Sunday that the swine flu outbreak is on the downswing in Taiwan and the percentage of people being hospitalized with the virus had clearly declined.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 1, or the 13th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia, " and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies. 1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
2001: A six-day conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concludes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approves the opening of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."
