DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Preserving traditional art form, old master keeps 'em laughing

TEXT.P: Donning the costume of a clown and employing vulgar yet vivid Taiwanese dialect, 78-year-old Shih Chao-yang leads his family in performing a local wordplay act known asChe-gu Changthat always has the audience holding their sides with laughter.

Che-gu Chang meanscart and drums arrayin Chinese.No one can explain why it is so named, but it is one of the earliest forms of folk entertainment in Taiwan, usually performed by at least two men, one dressed up in drag as a young lady, and the other as a clown.
Accompanied by a band of three to nine stringed instruments, they act out folk tales, historical legends and stories from literature.
Theyoung ladycatches the audience's eyes during the play, but it is the clown whose funny acting and interesting dialogue with the young lady makes people burst into laughter.
The plays can be staged anywhere from a lobby to an outdoor square in front of a temple and sometimes even on a makeshift stage made from an ox cart.
Having been involved in this form of entertainment for more than six decades, Shih, who comes from Homei in Changhua County, has been dubbed a national treasure.
In the past, farmers learned to perform Che-gu Chang simply for recreation after the harvest, when they did not have to tend their crops,Shih said.
Shih's troupe was at its busiest during the Chinese New Year holiday, and especially during the Lantern Festival, as local temples would invite the group to perform along with other similar troupes.
In order to attract the biggest audiences, each troupe would call all their skills into play and would sometimes even send people to disrupt the pitches of the other troupes.
The competition among the different troupes was so intense that it often prompted squabbles and police or local officials would have to be called in to keep order,Shih recalled.
Shih learned his craft as a teenager from his father, who was a Che-gu Chang performer in his village.

The young Shih's performances became well-known around Homei by the time he was 15, and he was often asked to perform at local theaters as a professional entertainer, where he took great enjoyment in making his audiences roll in the aisles.

Public address systems were unheard of at that time, so the players would have to pitch their voices to allow the audiences to hear them.This took its toll on Shih, as his voice had not yet broken, so his father sent him to work in Taipei so that he would not damage his throat.

Rather that dousing his enthusiasm for his craft, however, absence made him even more passionate about it, and when he returned to Homei several years later, he performed Che-gu Chang as a hobby while working on his inherited farmland.
It was at that time that Shih began to realize his routines had to keep abreast with the changing times to attract audiences.
I began to write new plays with new scripts that were more relevant to people's daily lives and more appealing to audiences,he said.
Following the old tradition, Shih's scripts were written in phrases of either four or seven words, with amusing lines and rhymes designed to rouse the audience's interest.
The writing process was quite difficult for him, because he only attended elementary school for a few years when Taiwan was ruled by Japan and could hardly read or write Chinese characters.

Because of this, he had to work out the plots in his mind and dictate them to a transcriber who would write them, polish them and then read them back to him.If he thought the dialogues were not appropriate, he would suggest changes until they were perfect.
Finally, he would then have to commit them to memory so that he could rattle them off on stage without thinking.

Although his plays are represented in simple language because of his virtual illiteracy, they provide in-depth descriptions of the common people's ordinary lives, thanks to his insightful observations and rich life experience.

According to Shih, a perfect Che-gu Chang performance combines a good script, including an entertaining epilogue and dialogue, funny yet graceful acting, and beautiful voices that are capable of expressing various human emotions.

His marvelous performances and unique skills brought him to the attention of the Changhua County government, which invited him to teach his trade at local elementary schools -- which he has done since 1983 -- to introduce the folk art to young people.
In 1988, Shih formed his own troupe, consisting of his two sons, two daughters- in-law and several female relatives.
At its peak, Shih's troupe gave 30 to 40 performances a month at local temples, weddings and funerals.
However, Che-gu Chang can no longer rival modern entertainment forms, and Shih is satisfied these days if his troupe can give 10 performances a month.
Without audiences, no form of art can thrive,Shih said.

I do feel sorry for the fading away of this aspect of life, but Iam thankful that I have been able to make a living for 18 years with this hobby and that I have been able to entertain so many people by sharing with them what I really love,he said.
It would be an unexpected windfall for me if any student to whom I introduced Che-gu Chang is motivated enough to carry the torch and revive the art.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County reports its first swine flu fatality

TEXT.P: Swine flu, officially known as influenza A (H1N1), has claimed the life of a woman in Taoyuan County, the first fatality in the northern county since the outbreak began, the Taoyuan Public Health Bureau reported Thursday.

The victim, the 19th in Taiwan, was a 24-year-old woman who suffered from funnel chest, a congenital deformity that causes cardiac and respiratory problems and requires the administration of oxygen when the patient is asleep.

The woman was hospitalized Sept. 26 with asthma and other flu symptoms and on Sept. 28 she tested positive for the A(H1N1) virus. She received intubation and ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) treatment Sept. 29, but died later that day, according to the Taoyuan Health Bureau.

Meanwhile, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) reported Thursday that one more patient had been hospitalized with the H1N1 virus as the new flu strain continued to spread throughout the country.
The newly hospitalized patient was a 19-year-old male from Taipei County.
The case brought the total number of H1N1 hospitalized patients to 306 since the outbreak began, the CECC said.
Nineteen of these patients have died, while 261 have recovered and 26 others remain in hospital, the CECC said.

A CECC official said Thursday that the swine flu outbreak is on the downswing in Taiwan as the rate of people being hospitalized with the H1N1 virus had clearly declined and the number has remained under 30 over the past week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 10,000 Chinese to visit Taiwan during National Day holiday

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 Chinese tourists are expected to visit Taiwan during China's week-long National Day holiday, according to statistics released Thursday by the Tourism Bureau.
During the Oct. 1-8 period, some 11,100 Chinese tourists will visit Taiwan in 511 groups, 103 of which are scheduled to arrive on Thursday, the statistics showed.

According to travel agents, while tourist arrivals from China declined last month as a result of the influenza A(H1N1) outbreak, the holiday effect has given an obvious boost to the sluggish inbound tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first 'living price index' to be published Oct. 5

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first "living price index", which will measure fluctuations in the price of consumer goods and factor in people's opinions of such changes, will be published on Oct. 5, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

The new cost-of-living index will reflect the price of water, electricity, domestic gas, food and transportation services, among other items. It will be published on a monthly basis to serve as a reference for administrative policies, said DGBAS Minister Shih Su-mei while answering questions in the legislature's Finance Committee.

Explaining the difference between the existing consumer price index (CPI) and the new living price index, Shih said that the CPI is an average weighted index comprised of 424 items in seven categories, and it measures differences in the price of goods and services. However, the new living price index will place a higher value on peoples' feelings about commodity price fluctuations, Shih said.

The new so-called "CPI-living necessaries" will be divided into three categories, with food, housing (water, electricity and gas) and transportation (fuel) in category A, and education and entertainment in category B, Shih said.

Category C will be more extensive, covering the prices of food and clothing as well as other items that fall under the housing segment such as water, electricity, domestic gas, transportation, household maintenance services, daily cleaning supplies, and cable TV fees, Shih added.

Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu instructed the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) earlier in September to work out a "living price index" that would reflect people's feelings about commodity price fluctuations. Chu said the government should talk about economic performance "in a way that most people can understand."

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Led by strong gains in banking and financial shares, Taiwan's share prices closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 36.12 points, or 0.48 percent, to close at 7,545.29.

With the hope that Taiwan and mainland China will soon sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cross-strait banking, the local bourse opened higher at 7,581.38 and reached a new 2009 high of 7,599.62. However, it failed to break the 7,600 level as electronics shares consolidated recent gains, causing the index to reverse gains at one point and reach the day's low of 7,492.62.
A total of 49.6 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$135.33 billion (US$4.2 billion), up from NT$125.24 billion the previous day.

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 2.32 percent. Textile stocks advanced 1.92 percent, cement stocks gained 1.77 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares added 0.98 percent.
Food shares dropped 1.01 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 0.8 percent, constructions issues were down 0.29 percent, and machinery and electronics shares pared 0.08 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,288 to 1,178, with 207 stocks remaining unchanged.

Foreign institutional investors, the major driving force behind the recent market gains, were net buyers of NT$10.08 billion-worth of shares for the day, compared with NT$12.58 billion the previous day. The net worth of shares bought by foreign institutional investors in September was NT$144.2 billion, which pushed the local share index up more than 10 percent for the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Long lines as Taiwan kicks off 2009 vaccinations for seasonal flu

TEXT.P: Hundreds of people lined up outside a hospital in Taipei to be vaccinated for seasonal flu Thursday as Taiwan kicked off the year's flu-prevention campaign amid fears of the spread of the flu, as well as swine flu.

As of 11: 30 a.m., 900 people had received a number from the Taipei Veterans General Hospital to get a vaccination for the seasonal flu as the peak flu season is setting in for seasonal flu, as well as swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1) , according to hospital authorities.
In the southern port city of Kaohsiung, residents also began to receive seasonal flu vaccinations Thursday at over 200 health institutions contracted with the city government.
Long lines were also formed at hospitals in central Taiwan's Taichung City.
A total of 245 hospitals and clinics in Taichung were opened to vaccine receivers. An estimated 120,000 people in the central city are expected to benefit from the flu-prevention drive.
Health officials attributed the "booming business" mainly to mounting threats posed by not just seasonal flu, but also the new A(H1N1) flu.

As of Thursday, the number of people hospitalized for H1N1 had reached 306 in Taiwan, since the outbreak began earlier this year. Nineteen of these patients have died, while 261 have recovered and 26 others remain in hospital. But health officials said the outbreak is on the downswing as the rate of people being hospitalized had declined.

Across Taiwan, the seasonal flu vaccines will be given nationwide in order of priority to elderly people aged 65 and above, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, poultry breeders, and patients with rare or serious diseases, followed by children aged between 6 to 10 months, and Typhoon Morakot victims living in temporary houses or shelters.
Vaccines for H1N1 flu are expected to be distributed to Taiwan's public in early November at the earliest, according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).

The H1N1 vaccines will be distributed according to a different order of priority -- with typhoon-affected people and medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention first in line, then pregnant women, followed by pre- school children, seriously ill patients, and elementary, junior high and senior high school students, CDC officials said.

Further down on the priority list will be individuals aged between 50 and 64, healthy people in the 25-49 age group, those aged over 25 at high risk of cardiopulmonary disease, and those in the 19-24 age bracket.

On Thursday, entertainer-turned-lifetime anti-smoking volunteer campaigner Sun Yueh was one of the first citizens in the country to receive the inoculation for the seasonal flu on the first day of the drive.

Sun urged citizens who are on a priority list for free inoculations against seasonal flu to waste no time to receive the vaccine at hospitals or their local health offices as autumn draws near. The flu season starts in autumn and continues throughout the winter till early next year.
Sun also advised people to wear face masks in public places, wash their hands often and refrain from shaking hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier suggests broadening cross-strait economic ties on trial basis

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said at a Cabinet meeting Thursday that cross-strait economic cooperation should be expanded on a trial basis.

Wu made the comment after listening to a Ministry of Economic Affairs report on "the bridging project -- current and future industrial cooperation between Taiwan and the mainland," according to Su Jun-pin, minister in charge of the Government Information Office, at a press briefing after the Cabinet meeting.

Wu said that as Taiwan has the advantage in R&D, production and business management, the current one-way investments in China by Taiwan businessmen should be gradually addressed after the normalization of cross-strait economic exchanges and cooperation.

To make Taiwan more attractive to investors from mainland China and the rest of the world, the relevant government agencies should redouble their efforts to improve Taiwan's investment climate, as this would help to boost economic growth and employment, Wu said.

Su said the MOEA, under its "bridging project," listed Chinese herbal medicine, solar power, automotive communications, information, LED and wind-power generation as the areas in which Taiwan and China could pursue joint development.
He added that 18 letters of intent involving some 80 enterprises, mostly in the above-mentioned industries on both sides of the strait, have been signed to facilitate future cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hydrogen battery chargers for cell phones unveiled

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) unveiled Thursday new types of hydrogen powered battery chargers for cell phones, that their inventor said will set a new trend in battery use across the world.

Speaking at a news conference marking the release of the highly -efficient and energy-effective new devices, Yeh Hui-ching, director of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, announced the arrival of a new era of hydrogen energy and gave the government's full endorsement for the local hydrogen fuel cell sector.

"The government hopes to acquire a slot in the global green energy industry's production chain with the hydrogen fuel cell technologies, and it seeks to make the sector's key expertise a local content by 2012 and begin commercial production as soon as possible," Yeh said.

One eye-catching item among the newly created devices displayed in the news conference was an electricity ball, which is capable of releasing hydrogen after charging water into it, and the hydrogen powered device can serve as a battery charger for cell phones.

The electricity ball can be fully charged with hydrogen power in only two hours, allowing cell phones to get electricity unplugged, said Shueh Chan-li, a researcher at the ITRI's Energy and Environment Research Laboratories.

According to Shueh, the institute has led other countries in using hydrogen power to develop battery chargers for cell phones. He expressed the belief that the hydrogen powered electricity ball could be popularized following its mass production that is set to reduce its cost. Currently, a handset of such a fuel battery charger costs NT$500 (US$15.52).

Two other new kinds of hydrogen powered fuel batteries were also on display in the news conference. One can allow vehicles to be driven faster than a motorcycle with a speed of more than 80 kilometers per hour, while the other can serve as an uninterrupted power supply equipment for companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday:
Apple Daily:
Debunking the myths surrounding Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp.
We have to debunk the myths about the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp (THRSC).
Myth one, the railway system was built under the Build-Operate-Transfer model. The fact is 92 percent of the project's funding came from the government.

Myth two, the railway system is not profitable. The fact is it recorded a pre- tax profit of NT$11.6 billion, or 50.4 percent of its revenue, in 2008. But the profit was wiped out by debt servicing and depreciation.
Myth three, the government has no legal power to regulate the corporation. The fact is the government has been closely involved in the management of the corporation from its inception.
We hope the company will be managed in the following ways:
First, the government should not force the consortium of banks to give the company extraordinary concessions in the rescheduling of its debts.
Second, THRSC should be operated as a quasi-state company now that the government has stepped in to reschedule its debts.
Third, an ad hoc committee comprised of members of the the general public should be set up to monitor the company's operations.
Fourth, the owners of the company should not be permitted to lease the rights to develop property adjacent to the company's stations.
United Daily News:
Was 1949 a blessing or a disaster for Taiwan?

Taiwan and mainland China have been ruled by different regimes since 1949. That year was considered by some as a disaster for Taiwan because it catapulted the island into the hands of alien rulers. But for others, it was seen as a blessing because it sheltered Taiwan from the rule of the Chinese Communists.

As a result, Taiwan developed into the first democracy among Chinese communities worldwide and it has become a prosperous society, which has enabled it to negotiate on equal terms with Beijing for peaceful co-existence.
Although Taiwan's development has not been smooth -- having
undergone the ordeal of the 228 Incident and the white terror era
-- its challenges pale in comparison with the ordeals the Chinese
people have experienced in the last six decades.
Our view is that 1949 was more a blessing than a disaster for Taiwan, as the island developed from that point into a political model that Beijing can emulate.
Liberty Times:
Are the authorities trying to sell out Taiwan?

Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang told the Legislative Yuan Tuesday that his ministry is trying to work out a plan by the end of this year to ease restrictions on investments in China by local flat panel manufacturers and wafer foundries.
The flat panel and wafer industries in Taiwan were both developed with special aid from the government, and if they are allowed to invest in China, this will sap Taiwan's economic strength.

The Ma administration is negotiating with China on an economic cooperation framework agreement which will open Taiwan's market to Chinese products at the expense of local industries, and the administration's decision to allow the flat panel and wafer industries to invest in China is nothing less than a sell out that will cost Taiwan its economic lifeline.
China Times:
President has no right to choose losing over winning for fear of owing the devil

The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) losses in the referendum on gambling in Penghu County and in the legislative by-election in Yunlin County had prompted some of President Ma Ying-jeou's followers to claim that he would opt for losses rather than rub elbows with political villains.
But we have to say that the president has no right to make such a decision.
Sticking to principle is not always a virtue in politics. All great leaders in history know how to get down in the dirt while struggling to realize their goals step by step.
Who else can the people rely on for reform if Ma, as head of state and of the ruling party, cannot help them realize their hopes for a better future?

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: Lifted by importers and local central bank's buying, the U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, rising NT$0.119 to close at NT$32.319.

The U.S. currency opened unchanged at the previous day's closing of NT$32.2, and reached a low of NT$31.995 in the afternoon, but recovered to close at the day's high of 32.319, reversing its downtrend in the past two days.
A total of US$2.3 billion changed hands during the day's trading, up from the previous day's US$2.21 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA expresses condolences to Indonesia, Samoa over disasters

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it has expressed condolences to Indonesia and Samoa, which suffered heavy loss of life in two separate major earthquakes the previous day.

"We contacted our representative offices in those two countries immediately after learning about the quakes and asked them to convey our condolences and sympathy to the respective governments," said MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang at a regular press briefing.
"The two offices are also trying to determine what the needs are in the disaster zones, and our medical teams are ready to help if necessary," he added.
So far, no Taiwanese citizens have been reported injured or killed in the two quakes, according to Chang.

A magnitude 8.0 quake struck Samoa Tuesday morning local time, triggering tsunamis that engulfed American Samoa, Samoa and Tonga, killing at least 113 people in Samoa and 31 in U.S. Samoa and leaving many others missing.
On the Indonesian island of Sumatra, a 7.6-magnitude earthquake stuck the north- west city of Padang Wednesday and a second one of magnitude 6.8 rattled the island Thursday.
The first quake killed hundreds of people and Indonesian officials said they fear the death toll could soar to thousands.

Meanwhile, the MOFA said that it has contacted the Philippines and Vietnam governments to express concern over the losses caused by Typhoon Ketsana, which hit the Philippines last weekend killing more than 240 people there before moving on to Vietnam where 23 people have died in the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTA with China will need legislature's approval: MAC head

TEXT.P: A proposed free-trade agreement Taiwan's government hopes the island will sign with China will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation before being implemented, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday, in an attempt to appease widespread concerns that the administration will reach agreement with Beijing without first seeking legislative or public approval.

Lai said at a legislative session that the government will soon complete negotiations with China on the signing of the pact, known as the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) . The government has said it hopes to sign the agreement by next year.
According to Lai, the administration will be supervised by the Legislative Yuan through communications and consultations on issues pertaining to the agreement.

Aside from giving reports to and listening to suggestions from the legislature before engaging in negotiations with China, Lai said the MAC and government agencies will keep it informed of the progress of negotiations.
"The ECFA will become effective and be implemented after negotiations with China have been completed and the pact is approved by the legislature," Lai told legislators.

Lai added that her agency, which is in charge of developing Taiwan's policies regarding mainland China, will continue to push for cross-strait negotiations and economic and trade cooperation with China, as the stable and peaceful development of relations between the two sides is not only important to Taiwan's national existence, but also to peace and security in the Asia Pacific region.
She said the government will further ease bans on Chinese investments in Taiwan's securities market and other cross-strait banking and financial exchanges.

According to the MAC chairwoman, as of mid-September, a total of 3,081 outlets operated by 44 banks in Taiwan have been approved to offer Chinese currency exchange services, and up to 150 outlets have been allowed to accept Chinese bank notes since Taiwan lifted restrictions on transactions of Chinese currency in June 2008.

In face of a rising China, Lai said, Taiwan should seek to improve cross-strait ties. She added that her office will work to deepen cultural and educational exchanges and strengthen information sharing across the Taiwan Strait.
Lai said that over the past year, improved relations with China has indeed brought substantial benefits for Taiwan and has helped improve Taiwan's relations with the international community.

Relations between the two sides have dramatically improved in the past year. Regular direct flights and shipping links have been launched, both have regular high level meetings, Taiwan has decided to allow Chinese investment in about 100 sectors and many more Chinese tourists are traveling to Taiwan.

Lai added that the MAC will continue to work to promote cross-strait exchanges and dialogue based on the rational principle of "facing reality, creating a better future, shelving disputes, seeking a win-win situation" and the principles of "equity, dignity, reciprocity" in order to realize the eventual goal of permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait.
The two sides have yet to sign a peace treaty since the end of a civil war in 1949, the 60th anniversary of which is this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry to close down Johannesburg office by end of October

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it is scheduled to close down its representative office in Johannesburg by the end of October.

"The process of closing down our representative office in Johannesburg is still in progress and is expected to be completed by Oct. 31," said Samuel S.M. Kuo, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs, at a regular press briefing.

Since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008, the MOFA has been reviewing the functions and performance of its foreign representative offices as part of an effort to maximize use of the country's diplomatic resources.

It has since closed down overseas offices in Bangladesh, Bolivia, Venezuela and Colon in Panama on grounds that they were under performing or were in close proximity to other Taiwan representative offices.
The MOFA is scheduled to open a new office in Sapporo, Japan later this year, and is planning to establish one in Istanbul, Turkey.
Taiwan currently has 117 embassies and representative offices around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs to participate in UNFCCC, ICAO: Premier Wu
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/09 18:18:48 (By Y.F. Low and Hwang Jaw-pyng)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih on Thursday requested his Cabinet to work out substantive steps Thursday to promote Taiwan's participation in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) to further expand the country's international involvement.

Following Taiwan's success in its bid to attend the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's decision-making body -- as an observer for the first time in May this year, the government has recently announced that the UNFCCC and ICAO will be the country's next targets for "meaningful participation" in U.N. specialized agencies.

Raising the issue during a weekly Cabinet meeting, Wu noted it is in line with a "pragmatic and flexible" diplomatic approach that instead of pushing for a bid for U.N. membership, the government is now trying to promote broader participation for Taiwan in affiliated organizations of the world body.

In previous years, under the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian, Taiwan had sought to join the U.N. each year. But such attempts had always failed due to opposition from China, a U.N. Security Council permanent member. Beginning last year, after President Ma Ying-jeou was elected, Taiwan no longer made such attempts.
Nonetheless, Wu asserted Thursday that Taiwan needed to be involved in U.N. affiliated agencies.
Wu said the serious disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot in August has highlighted the need for the government to pay closer attention to the possible impact of global warming on Taiwan.

Under this circumstances, it is necessary for Taiwan to seek to take part in the UNFCCC and the World Meteorological Organization to strengthen Taiwan's access to advanced climate technologies and data, Wu said.
The premier instructed relevant agencies to make proper preparations prior to the United Nations Climate Change Conference slated for Dec. 7-18 in Copenhagen.

On the significance of Taiwan's bid to take part in the civil aviation group ICAO, Wu said the Taipei flight information region occupies a pivotal position in East Asian air traffic and that it is important for Taiwan to obtain immediate flight information to ensure flight safety.

Meanwhile, officials at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York said the office has requested the country's diplomatic allies to help send a joint letter to the U.N. missions of UNFCCC signatories and ICAO members to push the U.N. members to agree to grant Taiwan's request to join the two organizations.
The allies are expected to complete signing the letter within a week, the officials said.

Kao Jen-chuan, director of TECO-New York, who concurrently serves as chief of a U.N. affairs task force, may also write to the U.N. missions of the diplomatic allies to explain the purpose of Taiwan's bids.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers voice opposition to health insurance premium hike

TEXT.P: Legislators from across the political spectrum unanimously voiced opposition Thursday to a government plan to raise the national health insurance premium rate from next year, saying the time is not right for such a move.

Their comments came a day after Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih- liang said his agency has almost completed a plan to raise health insurance premiums to help prop up the nation's financially shaky health insurance program.
Under the plan, Yaung said, the insurance premium rate will be increased from the current 4.55 percent to 5 percent of the monthly insured amount.

"The planned adjustment should be affordable to most people. The average citizens will need to pay only an additional NT$60 (US$1.86) to NT$70 per month -- which is equivalent to the cost of a lunch box, " Yaung explained. "For the wealthy, the increase will be equivalent to the price of five or six lunch boxes."

People in low-income groups may not be required to pay higher premiums or may even see a drop in their rates, he said. For those in the lower income bracket who will be required to pay more, the increase will only be equivalent to the price of a small pack of instant noodles, he added.
"In any case, the premium adjustment plan will not increase the financial burden on economically disadvantaged groups, " Yaung stressed.

Acknowledging that some lawmakers had lobbied him to give the assurance that the health insurance premiums would not be increased during his tenure, Yaung said he could not make such a promise because he has to fulfill his duty to keep the health insurance program afloat and sustainable.
The program's deficit will hit NT$50 billion by the end of this year, Yaung noted, adding that the planned premium hike would only help to prevent growth of that figure.
Yaung said his agency will do its utmost to persuade lawmakers to support the premium hike plan.
Commenting on Yaung's remarks, ruling Kuomintang legislative whip Lu Hsueh-chang said his caucus' stance on the issue is crystal clear -- now is not the time to raise health insurance premiums.

Lu cited Premier Wu Den-yih's recent statement to back the KMT legislative caucus' stance. "The premier has said premium hikes should be a last resort and should only be considered after all other options have been exhausted," Lu said.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislative whip Wang Sing-nan echoed Lu's view, saying that the party would not like to see an upward adjustment of insurance premiums at this time as the domestic economy has yet to bottom out in the country's worst-ever recession.
Wang further said the proposed premium hike should not be introduced until the Taipei City government repays its debts to the DOH's Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI).

As of the end of last year, the municipal governments of Taipei and Kaohsiung -- the country's two largest cities -- had defaulted on NT$25 billion in health insurance subsidies that they should have paid for people who work in the two cites but have their household registrations outside the cities.
Many opposition lawmakers have been pushing the DOH to recover the debts owed by the municipal governments before considering any increase in health insurance premiums.

But DOH officials have been leaning toward a plan for the Legislative Yuan to revise the central and local governments tax revenue allocation law to resolve the insurance premium subsidy issues once and for all.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan scientists visit Canada for digital content technology
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, Sept. 30 (CNA) 10/01/09 18:27:05 (By Paul Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of researchers and scientists from Taiwan are currently visiting Canada for academic exchanges, particularly on digital content development and related technologies.

Dr. Pen-Chung Yew, director of the Institute of Information Science under Taiwan's top research institution, Academia Sinica, delivered a speech on digital content technology at the University of Toronto Wednesday.

Yew and other group members -- who also included Dr. Der-Tsai Lee, an academic with Academia Sinica, and Dr. Liao Hong-yuan, an Academia Sinica fellow researcher -- discussed with faculty at the University of Toronto, about the feasibility of developing closer science and technological cooperation between the two countries through collaborative research.
Leading the group of faculty from the Toronto university was Paul Young, a vice president for research.

Liao, who doubles as a convenor of the information technology research and development program under the National Science Council, also delivered a speech on digital learning in Taiwan and a national digital archives program.
The national digital archives program aims to build an environment for creating digital collections as well as preserving and presenting national treasures, Liao said.
For his part, Lee said Taiwanese scientists have made commendable performances in digital content development and research on related technologies.
"They have also pushed their research achievements onto the world stage through winning recognition at international competitions, including a big prize from Museum International, UNESCO," Lee said.
The Taiwan sci-tech delegation is also scheduled to visit the University of Waterloo in Ontario and Ryerson University in Toronto in the following days for similar purposes.

Other delegation members included Liu Pang-feng, a National Taiwan University professor; Lee Han-ming, a professor with National Taiwan University of Science and Technology; and Kuo Yao-huang, a professor with National Cheng Kung University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayor outlines vision for new municipality

TEXT.P: The first five years of the new municipality that will incorporate Taichung City and Taichung County might be characterized by chaos, but its situation will then improve substantially and swiftly, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu forecast Thursday.
Addressing a forum on the new Taichung municipality's development prospects, Hu said residents of the central Taiwan area have high expectations of the merger and upgrading of their region.

"But the merging of the two administrative districts involves many complex tasks that will be more difficult to address than many could imagine, " Hu said, adding that transport infrastructure construction and urban design will be most important tasks after the integration of the two administrative areas.
The Executive Yuan has approved a proposal that Taichung City and Taichung County should be merged into a single special municipality, to be called Taichung City, in late 2010.
Noting that broad vision is needed in planning the new municipality infrastructure, Hu said it will also take time for the city to change and evolve.

Pointing to a mass rapid transit (MRT) system project for the city, construction of which is scheduled to officially begin later this month, Hu said the project should be carried out in several phases and should be given financial support from the central government.

"At present, the city government can only plan the first and second phases of the MRT construction. In the long run, the line should be extended to cover Taichung Harbor and Taichung Airport to increase its viability, " Hu said, adding that such expansion will become easier after the merger into a single administrative body.
"One plus one could equal more than two, " Hu said, referring to the development potential and capacity of the merger of Taichung city and county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fubon securities to set up joint venture with China soon: chairman

TEXT.P: Taiwan's No. 2 brokerage - Fubon Securities - has reached an agreement with specific partners and will soon set up a joint-venture company in mainland China once Taiwan and China sign a financial memorandum of understanding (MOU), the chairman of the company said Thursday.

However, after signing the MOU on cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation on financial supervision, Taiwanese-owned brokerage firms still will not be permitted to operate A-shares businesses. In China, yuan-denominated A shares are for domestic Chinese investors only, while foreign investors are allowed to invest in B shares.

But David Chang, chairman of Fubon Securities, said he hopes that Fubon will be allowed to underwrite A shares and establish a wholly-owned China subsidiary in the special economic zone that China has set up on its eastern coast, by the Taiwan Strait.

The development of the economic zone got a nod from China's government in May. The zone covers a large area spanning from the Pearl River Delta in southern China to the Yangtze River Delta in northeast China, two of mainland China's economic powerhouse regions. Southeastern China's Fujian province will serve as the hub.

"As long as we acquire one percent market share in China's A shares brokerage market, we can duplicate another Fubon Securities which occupies 6.25 percent market share in Taiwan, " Chang said, pointing out the importance of getting access to underwrite A shares for Taiwanese brokerages in China.
Chang added that the overall brokerage fee income of A shares in China reached 90 billion yuan in 2008, and is expected to top 100 billion yuan with 30 percent growth every year.

"The brokerage business is expected to be the first to score profits among banking, insurance and brokerage businesses, " he said, explaining that most Chinese brokerages lack experience on financial derivatives and innovation, so Taiwanese brokerages can better use their strengths on electronic trading, risk management and product innovation.

According to mainland China's laws, foreign brokerage firms need to form joint ventures with Chinese partners to get market access, with a minimum capital requirement of 1.2 billion yuan and foreign ownership less than 33 percent. The JVs also need to operate B share business for at least five years before underwriting A shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural artistry raises northern Taiwanese county's profile

TEXT.P: Farmers in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County have created a piece of "agricultural artwork" by planting different color crops in a rice paddy - potentially opening a new trend of using crop planting to advertise, officials said Thursday.
The artwork in Taoyuan shows the Chinese words "Taoyuan, Take Off" in swaths of farmland along a section of the Sun Yat-sen Freeway.

Featuring the words and the colored images of airplanes and high-rise buildings, the work was created by members of the Taoyuan City Farmers' Association by planting purple and green-leafed rice on two hectares of farmland.
The creation has become a new landmark in Taoyuan County.

Officials of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency said Thursday that the work is part of a project launched by the agency in 2002 to encourage farmers to gradually reduce the amount of land under cultivation by converting unprofitable farmland to other uses.

Since then, the Miaoli District Agricultural Research and Extension Station, has begun providing technology transfers of colored crop art work creations to farmers, with the aim of boosting the value of farmland, according to the officials.
Farmland can not only be used for rice cultivation and landscaping, it can also be used as an environmentally friendly tool for advertising, according to Chang Su-chen, a researcher at the station.

This is the first time that a rice-paddy art work has been created in so vast swathes of paddy fields in Taiwan, according to Chang, who added she hopes more works can be made along the runways of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to allow more people from other countries to get a bird's eye view of Taiwan's rural farmland landscape.

DOC.HEADLINE: Photovoltaic industry to be theme of Taipei Summit: BOFT head

TEXT.P: The Taipei Summit 2009 has chosen the photovoltaic industry as its theme this year, with the aim of enhancing technical exchanges and economic cooperation with the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the head of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Thursday.

BOFT Director-General Huang Chih-peng made the remarks at a news conference to promote the upcoming conference, which will be jointly sponsored by Taipei Summit 2009 and Photovoltaic Taiwan Forum 2009, and will take place Oct. 7, bringing together more than 80 officials and business representatives from the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand.

He noted that the development of the photovoltaic industry in Southeast Asia is comparatively lagging behind that of Taiwan's and said the choice of the photovoltaic industry as the theme of the summit will help local companies to build partnerships with the photovoltaic industry in Southeast Asia and make inroads into those markets.
Lee Chun-li, an official of the Energy Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, also said Taiwan's photovoltaic industry benefits from its booming semiconductor industry.
The output of Taiwan's solar cells is presently number four in the world, with the goal of reaching the number three position next year.

Lee said Taiwan's promotion of the photovoltaic industry should target overseas markets, noting that Southeast Asia is also developing the industry, which will provide Taiwan manufacturers with good opportunities.
"Taiwanese manufacturers could tap the Southeast Asian market by forming technology cooperation or transfer agreements with their counterparts there," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expert urges sustained efforts to understand China's military
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/09 20:32:42 (By Stanley Cheung and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: China showcased its military hardware in a parade in Beijing Thursday to celebrate its 60th national day, but a U.S. expert said sustained efforts are needed to detect and understand China's military approach.
The wide range of home-developed weaponry on display in the largest-ever parade included nuclear-capable missiles, fighter jets, aerial drones and other advanced arms.
Dean Chang, a research fellow with the U.S.-based Heritage Foundation, said in an article delivered to the CNA that in some respects, the big guns displayed were a distraction.

Lower-profile command, control and communications systems, such as airborne early-warning and control aircraft and satellite- communications devices, more accurately reflect the comprehensive challenge of China's expanding military capabilities, he said.
These systems might not look particularly special in a parade, but they evince the increasing sophistication of China's strategic thinking and technology, he added.

China is not aiming to match the U.S. weapon-for-weapon. Instead, China is pursuing an "asymmetric" approach. It is a view of future warfare, expounded in PLA analyses, that focuses more on enabling the PLA to gather, transmit and exploit information while denying an opponent that same ability, Chang said.

Less noticeable, but arguably even more important and worrisome, Chang continued, is a coherent doctrine and improved training regimens. PLA training efforts include extensive exercising of command-and-control capabilities, employing forces that cross military region boundaries, and "conducting training in complex electromagnetic environments," a reference to both electronic warfare and cyberwarfare.
He said the U.S. needs long-term, in-depth analyses of Chinese capabilities that go beyond the "bean counting" of new systems to look at logistical capabilities and training regimens.

This will require extensive examination of Chinese-language materials such as PLA reference volumes, textbooks and other official publications, because much of this will involve reshaped doctrine and adjusted metrics rather than physical systems, and this entails expanding the ranks of analysts familiar with Chinese military publications and capable of assessing their authoritativeness.

Addressing changes to Chinese strategy will also require maintaining a substantial U.S. force in the East Asian region, and conventional capabilities in the area -- long the American strong suit -- must be maintained, both to reassure American allies and to signal to China that the U.S. has continued commitment to the region, he added.

The most difficult challenge for U.S. policy makers, however, will be interacting with members of the PLA itself. There is arguably no better means of learning about changes within a military than by talking with its members, observing its exercises, and even going to its academies and institutions of higher military education.

He said the U.S. is clearly the dominant military power in the Asia-Pacific region today, but China is gaining fast, and China's expanding range of national interests and military capabilities suggest there will be greater likelihood of brushing up against the U.S., both inside and outside Asia.

Chang said it is important that the two sides reduce the opportunity for misunderstanding or miscalculation -- be it of capability or intention. This is impossible unless U.S. analysts can get focus on China's growing operational capabilities, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dance company to perform at arts festival in Rhode Island

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first all-male dance company "Horse" will stage its highly acclaimed production "Velocity" at the FirstWorks Festival in Providence, Rhode Island on Oct. 24, company manager Fred Chuang said Thursday.

While visiting Taiwan early this year, the festival's artistic director Kathleen Pletcher invited "Horse" to present "Velocity" at the Providence festival, an annual cultural event which was first launched in 2004, Chuang said.

In the production "Velocity", the dance group explores how the frenetic nature of contemporary society pulls people and things apart. The production synthesizes elements of experimental theater, drama and mime.
The choreography reflects the observations of the young "Horse" members on evolution, progress and loss in the speed of movements, according to Chuang.
In April 2008, the overseas premiere of "Velocity" in New York's Joyce Theater won the young company a review in the New York Times.

On April 18, 2008, Art critic Jennifer Dunning said in the New York Times: "The evening-length work that Horse presented in this American debut, looked essentially like a series of favorite bits, set to well-chosen music by composers ranging from Mozart and Bach to John Cage and Michael Gordon. The piece ran out of steam toward the end, but until then it was a feast of evocative, playful small dances showcasing the supple physicality and subtle dramatic gifts of its performers."

The visit to Providence will be "Horse" dance company's third visit to the U.S. since it was founded in 2007. After its well acclaimed performance in April 2007 at the Mandance Project at Joyce Theater, the five-man troupe was again invited to present their new production "Bones" at the 2009 Mandance Project at the Joyce Theater in April.

FirstWorks is a multidimensional arts organization recognized with eight national endowment of the arts grants in the U.S. Since 2004, the organization has collaborated with the City of Providence's Department of Art, Culture and Tourism to present an annual art festival. The 2009 festival, Sept. 24VNov. 15, features dance, music, theater and interactive installations.
Upon returning from the U.S., the group will be preparing for the premiere of a new production "Growing Up", according to Chuang.
Four performances of "Growing Up" are scheduled from Dec. 4-6 at the Taipei National University of the Arts.
"Velocity" is a joint production of choreographers/dancers Chen Wu-kang, Wu Wei- chia, Yang Yu-min, Huang Yi, Chang Tzu-ling and Kao Yung-yu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister does U-turn on insurance rate hike

TEXT.P: In an about-face, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday that the national health insurance premium rate will not be hiked for the moment, although the insured amount of rich people will be raised.

The "no hike" statement came just a day after Yaung said the DOH had almost completed a plan to increase the insurance premium rate from the current 4.55 percent to 5 percent of the monthly insured amount from next year to help prop up the country's cash-strapped health insurance program.
The proposed premium adjustment plan immediately drew fire from legislators from across the political spectrum who said the time was not right for such a move.

Lawmakers from both the ruling and opposition camps also cited a recent statement by Premier Wu Den-yih to back their stance. Wu said the previous week that health insurance premium hikes should be a last resort and should only be considered after all other options have been exhausted.
In an apparent response to the lawmakers' opposition, Yaung said the rate hike plan will be shelved for the time being.
But he added that the insured amount of the wealthy will be raised so that they have to pay more for the health insurance program.
"The gap between the insured monthly salary amounts of the lowest- and highest- income groups of people will be widened from the current 7.6 times to between 10 and 15 times," Yaung said.
According to Yaung, the health insurance program's deficit will hit NT$50 billion by the end of this year.
Many opposition lawmakers have been pushing the DOH to recover the debts owed by the Taipei city government before considering any increase in health insurance premiums.

The Taipei city government has so far defaulted on NT$30 billion in health insurance subsidies that they should have paid for people who work in the city but have their household registrations outside the city.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Thursday the city government plan to repay all of its debts to the DOH's Bureau of National Health Insurance in five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: 55 aged industrial compounds set to become eco-friendly

TEXT.P: In line with a government policy to make Taiwan a low-carbon society, plans are being drawn up to transform 55 of the country's old industrial compounds into eco-friendly facilities, with three of them selected to serve as "flagship depots" in the initial stage, officials said Thursday.

According to officials of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the bureau is considering installing solar panels and some 1,800 LED lamps in these aging industrial compounds -- which cover a combined total of more than 10,000 square meters -- as part of its efforts to realize the renovation plan.
"All the solar panels and LED equipment will be products manufactured by Taiwanese companies," the official noted.

Juifang Industrial District in northern Taiwan, Chushan Industrial District in central Taiwan and Kuantien Industrial District in the south are being targeted as the "flagship" versions of the planned eco-friendly facilities that will focus on ecology, culture and health-related concepts, the officials said.
The upgrading plan is expected to create over 8,700 jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rainfall, mudslides to be major factors in typhoon disaster control

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said Thursday that rainfall and mudslides will be major considerations factored in along with wind strength in typhoon-induced disaster prevention and control measures.
Chu made the remarks when presiding over a meeting to step up preparations against two typhoons that forecasters said could affect Taiwan over the weekend.

In the past, the government has used wind strength to gauge the strength of typhoons when preparing for major disasters and has used it as basis for whether to announce class or office closures, Chu said.

"But we have learned a lesson from past experience and most recently from Typhoon Morakot, " he went on, adding that "wind strength is not the only factor, as damage from rainfall and mudslides can be much more serious."

Typhoon Morakot swept across the country in early August, triggering the worst flooding and mudslides in half a century. Nearly 700 people died, including around 400 victims from Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County who were buried alive when their village was inundated by mud.

Chu said that in future, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) , the National Police Administration and National Fire Agency will work closely with their local counterparts, while the military will also be prepared to provide emergency rescue services, support and resettlement.

The government will also join forces with civic organizations such as the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and volunteer groups to carry out disaster relief work.

Those areas that are prone to flooding will be divided into two categories -- more serious and less serious areas. But whether the residents in these two categories will be evacuated during flooding will be decided by the CEOC.

The CEOC will study the information provided by related government agencies such as the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , the Department of Agriculture and the Water Resources Agency when making such decisions.
Earlier, Premier Wu Den-yih said that flood prevention and dredging will be given priority.
He also said the Cabinet will propose a white paper on disaster prevention every year to underscore the Executive Yuan's determination to shoulder its responsibilities in this regard.
In this way, the public can learn about the land conservation and rehabilitation, as well as disaster-fighting mechanisms.
The white paper will also list the annual budget for disaster prevention and control in a transparent way, he added.
Meanwhile, The CWB said the strength of the two typhoons -- Parma and Melor -- which were southeast of Taiwan -- had increased and that both were moving in a west-northwesterly trajectory.
CWB Director Shin Tsai-chin predicted that the two storms would be east of the Philippines and southeast of Taiwan by Sunday.

He warned the public to be on guard, noting that the outer edges of the typhoons could join forces with the northeasterly monsoon to produce torrential rain in northern and eastern parts of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former health minister awarded French order

TEXT.P: Former Health Minister Chen Chien-jen was awarded a top-level French order Thursday in Taipei in recognition of his excellence in research in the field of genomics and molecular epidemiology and his contributions to promoting France- Taiwan scientific cooperation.

Patrick Bonneville, France's top representative to Taiwan, hosted a ceremony at his residence to award Chen the Officer of the Order of the Academic Palms, describing him as an outstanding scientist who has played a significant role in bilateral research cooperation between the two countries.
The function was attended by Wong Chi-huey, president of Academia Sinica, as well as other experts from the local academic and medical sectors.
Chen said he was honored to receive the medal on behalf of all the scientists who have contributed over the years to the many bilateral research projects between Taiwan and France.

According to Chen, bilateral cooperation between Taiwan and France lies not only in the field of science and high technology, but also in helping broaden the international perspective of young scientists from both countries.
"Science and technology have no borders and the passion demonstrated by both Taiwanese and French scientists in their research goes beyond the language barrier," said Chen.
"I hope that in the future, our work in medical, communication and nanotechnology will benefit not only people in Taiwan and France, but also the rest of the world," he added.

Thanks to Chen's dynamism and personal involvement, France is now ranked as the second scientific partner of Taiwan in terms of the number of joint research projects, following the United States, according to the French Institute.

Chen, who visited France many times during his term as National Science Council (NSC) minister, helped launch several important cooperation schemes between Taiwan and France, including the "Orchid partnership, " which supports new joint research projects, and the "Frontiers of Science" symposia, which promotes exchanges among young French and Taiwanese scientists, according to the institute.

Chen also helped establish a multi-thematic cooperative program between the NSC and the French National Agency for Research in January 2007 -- a program that was at that time the first institutional partnership of the French agency with a foreign agency outside Europe, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Main Stadium management likely to face financial woes

TEXT.P: With the high maintenance fees for the World Games Main Stadium in Kaohsiung City, several legislators questioned Thursday whether the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) , which has taken over management of the stadium, can afford to operate it.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiang Nai-hsin said during a legislative session that the SAC has set up a management division in charge of the stadium's operations and that personnel expenses and maintenance fees are estimated to reach up to NT$250 million, while the SAC has been granted a budget of just NT$70 million.
The legislative session was held to discuss issues related to the Kaohsiung World Games in July and the Taipei Deaflympics in September, as well as baseball revitalization plans.

KMT Legislator Cheng Chin-ling suggested that the SAC, the highest authority in Taiwan for physical fitness and sports, should hand the operating rights of the stadium over to the Kaohsiung city government.

In response, SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said the council will spare no efforts to host large-scale international events to make good use of the equipment and facilities and the experience of hosting the World Games. At present, the SAC is seeking to host the 2017 East Asian Games.

Tai added that the SAC is also planning to arrange for national sports events and training sessions, as well as other community and cultural activities, to be held at the stadium. A portion of the space will also be used for commercial purposes.
She also asked legislators to help out while reviewing budget bills for the stadium's operations in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to seek improved ties with China, enhanced defenses

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that while seeking to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the government will try to ensure it maintains strong enough forces to defend the sovereignty and safety of the nation.
The premier was responding to remarks by People's Republic of China (PRC) President Hu Jintao earlier in the day in Beijing.

In a speech delivered after reviewing troops in a parade in celebration of the PRC's 60th national day, Hu pledged to "push forward the peaceful development of relations across the Taiwan Strait" amid a historic thaw between the two sides.
"We will continue to strive for the complete reunification of our motherland, which is the common aspiration of the Chinese nation," Hu added.

At a tea party for the press, Wu urged China to face the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been under different jurisdictions since 1949. "Only by doing so can a peaceful development of cross-strait relations be assured," he said.

Citing a proverb that says that "any nation that does not face difficulties or enemies is doomed to fail, " Wu said Taiwan must "prepare for the worst (in dealing with China) " at the same time that it tries to increase contacts.

Since cross-strait tension has been greatly relieved, Wu said, both Taiwan and China should shelve those disputes that cannot be solved in a short period of time so as to create a "win-win" situation between the two sides.

Saying that Taiwan respects "whatever forms of celebrations China chooses to mark its 60th national day, " Wu added that while pursing closer ties with China, Taiwan will also try to enhance bilateral relations with the United States, Japan and other friendly nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan helps Salvadoran farmers grow organic papayas
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Sept. 30 (CNA) 10/01/09 22:32:55 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to El Salvador Carlos Liao presented US$200,000 Wednesday in loans to farmers in northern El Salvador to allow them to plant high-end fruit strains bred by Taiwanese experts, according to a statement from the ROC embassy.
Liao and Salvadoran Minister of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry Manuel Sevilla jointly presided over the presentation ceremony.

Addressing the ceremony, Liao said Taiwan has maintained a technological mission in El Salvador for more than 38 years, during which time it has launched many educational programs to help Salvadorans develop high-end agriculture and aquaculture by offering loans and technological know-how.
In addition to vegetable and fruit cultivation, Liao went on, experts from Taiwan have also succeeded in teaching Salvadorans how to raise tilapia and shrimp.

Since 2000, the mission has been sending its members to Chalatenango Province in the country's northwest to teach local farmers how to raise high-end fruit strains provided by Taiwan, including papayas, guavas, star fruit, bell fruit and dates.
Taiwan-developed papaya and guava strains grow especially well in Chalatenango, Liao noted.

With the assistance of Taiwanese experts, he went on, local farmers have planted 65 hectares of papayas and 12 hectares of guavas in the province over the past three years, generating more than US$1.6 million in revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan scheduled to reopen to tourists in late October

TEXT.P: The Alishan Forest Recreation Area, one of Taiwan's most popular tourist attractions, may re-open to tourists late this month, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Thursday.

Delivering a report on rehabilitation and reconstruction in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Mao said Highway No. 18, the main road serving the mountain resort area that was washed out in several places by the storm, will be repaired.
In the initial stage, large coaches will not be permitted to use the road, and tourists will be carried in by vehicles seating a maximum of nine passengers.
Mao also said that there was still no timetable for a possible re-opening of the famous Alishan Mountain Railway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military to be deployed upon typhoon warnings

TEXT.P: The military will deploy troops in potential danger zones on a standby basis upon the issuance of a typhoon warning, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday.
Vice Defense Minister Huang Yi-ping said the number of deployed forces will exceed 6,000 personnel.

In Hualien and Taitung counties, the military will deploy about 400 servicemen, as well as generators and water pumps, while in northern Taiwan, around 3,000 servicemen equipped with amphibious vehicles and rubber boats will be placed on standby, he said.
In southern Taiwan, around 2,000 soldiers will be deployed, along with pumps and diggers, while in central Taiwan, 1,700 will be deployed with various heavy equipment.
Similar measures will be taken on the outlying islands of Penghu, Matsu and Kinmen, he added.

"The remaining troops will be divided into a first contingency group, which will be ready to depart for affected areas 10 minutes after a disaster is reported, while a second contingency group will depart for the areas three hours later," he added.

The military has also investigated the status of idle and still usable military barracks in various cities and counties, and has planned 34 shelters in 22 cities and counties able to accommodate around 14,000 disaster victims.
Huang said the military "has reviewed its rescue operations during Typhoon Morakot in early August and has made major changes in its disaster prevention and rescue methods."

He added that in future, the ranks of military personnel stationed at the Central Emergency Operation Center will be upgraded and that additional staff will be stationed there to be in charge of coordination with government agencies, equipment, personnel dispatch and news dissemination.

Meanwhile, the Central Weather Bureau said that whether two approaching typhoons -- Parma and Melor -- will make a direct hit on Taiwan was not yet certain, but it predicted heavy rain for northern and eastern parts of Taiwan due to the combined effect of the two typhoons and the northeasterly monsoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Photovoltaic industry to be theme of Taipei Summit: BOFT head

TEXT.P: The Taipei Summit 2009 has chosen the photovoltaic industry as its theme this year, with the aim of enhancing technical exchanges and economic cooperation with the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the head of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Thursday.

BOFT Director-General Huang Chih-peng made the remarks at a news conference to promote the upcoming conference, which will be jointly sponsored by Taipei Summit 2009 and Photovoltaic Taiwan Forum 2009, and will take place Oct. 7, bringing together more than 80 officials and business representatives from the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand.

He noted that the development of the photovoltaic industry in Southeast Asia is comparatively lagging behind that of Taiwan's and said the choice of the photovoltaic industry as the theme of the summit will help local companies to build partnerships with the photovoltaic industry in Southeast Asia and make inroads into those markets.
Lee Chun-li, an official of the Energy Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, also said Taiwan's photovoltaic industry benefits from its booming semiconductor industry.
The output of Taiwan's solar cells is presently number four in the world, with the goal of reaching the number three position next year.

Lee said Taiwan's promotion of the photovoltaic industry should target overseas markets, noting that Southeast Asia is also developing the industry, which will provide Taiwan manufacturers with good opportunities.
"Taiwanese manufacturers could tap the Southeast Asian market by forming technology cooperation or transfer agreements with their counterparts there," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expert urges sustained efforts to understand China's military
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/09 20:32:42 (By Stanley Cheung and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: China showcased its military hardware in a parade in Beijing Thursday to celebrate its 60th national day, but a U.S. expert said sustained efforts are needed to detect and understand China's military approach.
The wide range of home-developed weaponry on display in the largest-ever parade included nuclear-capable missiles, fighter jets, aerial drones and other advanced arms.
Dean Chang, a research fellow with the U.S.-based Heritage Foundation, said in an article delivered to the CNA that in some respects, the big guns displayed were a distraction.

Lower-profile command, control and communications systems, such as airborne early-warning and control aircraft and satellite- communications devices, more accurately reflect the comprehensive challenge of China's expanding military capabilities, he said.
These systems might not look particularly special in a parade, but they evince the increasing sophistication of China's strategic thinking and technology, he added.

China is not aiming to match the U.S. weapon-for-weapon. Instead, China is pursuing an "asymmetric" approach. It is a view of future warfare, expounded in PLA analyses, that focuses more on enabling the PLA to gather, transmit and exploit information while denying an opponent that same ability, Chang said.

Less noticeable, but arguably even more important and worrisome, Chang continued, is a coherent doctrine and improved training regimens. PLA training efforts include extensive exercising of command-and-control capabilities, employing forces that cross military region boundaries, and "conducting training in complex electromagnetic environments," a reference to both electronic warfare and cyberwarfare.
He said the U.S. needs long-term, in-depth analyses of Chinese capabilities that go beyond the "bean counting" of new systems to look at logistical capabilities and training regimens.

This will require extensive examination of Chinese-language materials such as PLA reference volumes, textbooks and other official publications, because much of this will involve reshaped doctrine and adjusted metrics rather than physical systems, and this entails expanding the ranks of analysts familiar with Chinese military publications and capable of assessing their authoritativeness.

Addressing changes to Chinese strategy will also require maintaining a substantial U.S. force in the East Asian region, and conventional capabilities in the area -- long the American strong suit -- must be maintained, both to reassure American allies and to signal to China that the U.S. has continued commitment to the region, he added.

The most difficult challenge for U.S. policy makers, however, will be interacting with members of the PLA itself. There is arguably no better means of learning about changes within a military than by talking with its members, observing its exercises, and even going to its academies and institutions of higher military education.

He said the U.S. is clearly the dominant military power in the Asia-Pacific region today, but China is gaining fast, and China's expanding range of national interests and military capabilities suggest there will be greater likelihood of brushing up against the U.S., both inside and outside Asia.

Chang said it is important that the two sides reduce the opportunity for misunderstanding or miscalculation -- be it of capability or intention. This is impossible unless U.S. analysts can get focus on China's growing operational capabilities, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dance company to perform at arts festival in Rhode Island

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first all-male dance company "Horse" will stage its highly acclaimed production "Velocity" at the FirstWorks Festival in Providence, Rhode Island on Oct. 24, company manager Fred Chuang said Thursday.

While visiting Taiwan early this year, the festival's artistic director Kathleen Pletcher invited "Horse" to present "Velocity" at the Providence festival, an annual cultural event which was first launched in 2004, Chuang said.

In the production "Velocity", the dance group explores how the frenetic nature of contemporary society pulls people and things apart. The production synthesizes elements of experimental theater, drama and mime.
The choreography reflects the observations of the young "Horse" members on evolution, progress and loss in the speed of movements, according to Chuang.
In April 2008, the overseas premiere of "Velocity" in New York's Joyce Theater won the young company a review in the New York Times.

On April 18, 2008, Art critic Jennifer Dunning said in the New York Times: "The evening-length work that Horse presented in this American debut, looked essentially like a series of favorite bits, set to well-chosen music by composers ranging from Mozart and Bach to John Cage and Michael Gordon. The piece ran out of steam toward the end, but until then it was a feast of evocative, playful small dances showcasing the supple physicality and subtle dramatic gifts of its performers."

The visit to Providence will be "Horse" dance company's third visit to the U.S. since it was founded in 2007. After its well acclaimed performance in April 2007 at the Mandance Project at Joyce Theater, the five-man troupe was again invited to present their new production "Bones" at the 2009 Mandance Project at the Joyce Theater in April.

FirstWorks is a multidimensional arts organization recognized with eight national endowment of the arts grants in the U.S. Since 2004, the organization has collaborated with the City of Providence's Department of Art, Culture and Tourism to present an annual art festival. The 2009 festival, Sept. 24VNov. 15, features dance, music, theater and interactive installations.
Upon returning from the U.S., the group will be preparing for the premiere of a new production "Growing Up", according to Chuang.
Four performances of "Growing Up" are scheduled from Dec. 4-6 at the Taipei National University of the Arts.
"Velocity" is a joint production of choreographers/dancers Chen Wu-kang, Wu Wei- chia, Yang Yu-min, Huang Yi, Chang Tzu-ling and Kao Yung-yu.
