TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to El Salvador Carlos Liao presented US$200,000 Wednesday in loans to farmers in northern El Salvador to allow them to plant high-end fruit strains bred by Taiwanese experts, according to a statement from the ROC embassy.
Liao and Salvadoran Minister of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry Manuel Sevilla jointly presided over the presentation ceremony.

Addressing the ceremony, Liao said Taiwan has maintained a technological mission in El Salvador for more than 38 years, during which time it has launched many educational programs to help Salvadorans develop high-end agriculture and aquaculture by offering loans and technological know-how.
In addition to vegetable and fruit cultivation, Liao went on, experts from Taiwan have also succeeded in teaching Salvadorans how to raise tilapia and shrimp.

Since 2000, the mission has been sending its members to Chalatenango Province in the country's northwest to teach local farmers how to raise high-end fruit strains provided by Taiwan, including papayas, guavas, star fruit, bell fruit and dates.
Taiwan-developed papaya and guava strains grow especially well in Chalatenango, Liao noted.

With the assistance of Taiwanese experts, he went on, local farmers have planted 65 hectares of papayas and 12 hectares of guavas in the province over the past three years, generating more than US$1.6 million in revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan scheduled to reopen to tourists in late October

TEXT.P: The Alishan Forest Recreation Area, one of Taiwan's most popular tourist attractions, may re-open to tourists late this month, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Thursday.

Delivering a report on rehabilitation and reconstruction in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Mao said Highway No. 18, the main road serving the mountain resort area that was washed out in several places by the storm, will be repaired.
In the initial stage, large coaches will not be permitted to use the road, and tourists will be carried in by vehicles seating a maximum of nine passengers.
Mao also said that there was still no timetable for a possible re-opening of the famous Alishan Mountain Railway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military to be deployed upon typhoon warnings

TEXT.P: The military will deploy troops in potential danger zones on a standby basis upon the issuance of a typhoon warning, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday.
Vice Defense Minister Huang Yi-ping said the number of deployed forces will exceed 6,000 personnel.

In Hualien and Taitung counties, the military will deploy about 400 servicemen, as well as generators and water pumps, while in northern Taiwan, around 3,000 servicemen equipped with amphibious vehicles and rubber boats will be placed on standby, he said.
In southern Taiwan, around 2,000 soldiers will be deployed, along with pumps and diggers, while in central Taiwan, 1,700 will be deployed with various heavy equipment.
Similar measures will be taken on the outlying islands of Penghu, Matsu and Kinmen, he added.

"The remaining troops will be divided into a first contingency group, which will be ready to depart for affected areas 10 minutes after a disaster is reported, while a second contingency group will depart for the areas three hours later," he added.

The military has also investigated the status of idle and still usable military barracks in various cities and counties, and has planned 34 shelters in 22 cities and counties able to accommodate around 14,000 disaster victims.
Huang said the military "has reviewed its rescue operations during Typhoon Morakot in early August and has made major changes in its disaster prevention and rescue methods."

He added that in future, the ranks of military personnel stationed at the Central Emergency Operation Center will be upgraded and that additional staff will be stationed there to be in charge of coordination with government agencies, equipment, personnel dispatch and news dissemination.

Meanwhile, the Central Weather Bureau said that whether two approaching typhoons -- Parma and Melor -- will make a direct hit on Taiwan was not yet certain, but it predicted heavy rain for northern and eastern parts of Taiwan due to the combined effect of the two typhoons and the northeasterly monsoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former health minister awarded French order

TEXT.P: Former Health Minister Chen Chien-jen was awarded a top-level French order Thursday in Taipei in recognition of his excellence in research in the field of genomics and molecular epidemiology and his contributions to promoting France- Taiwan scientific cooperation.

Patrick Bonneville, France's top representative to Taiwan, hosted a ceremony at his residence to award Chen the Officer of the Order of the Academic Palms, describing him as an outstanding scientist who has played a significant role in bilateral research cooperation between the two countries.
The function was attended by Wong Chi-huey, president of Academia Sinica, as well as other experts from the local academic and medical sectors.
Chen said he was honored to receive the medal on behalf of all the scientists who have contributed over the years to the many bilateral research projects between Taiwan and France.

According to Chen, bilateral cooperation between Taiwan and France lies not only in the field of science and high technology, but also in helping broaden the international perspective of young scientists from both countries.
"Science and technology have no borders and the passion demonstrated by both Taiwanese and French scientists in their research goes beyond the language barrier," said Chen.
"I hope that in the future, our work in medical, communication and nanotechnology will benefit not only people in Taiwan and France, but also the rest of the world," he added.

Thanks to Chen's dynamism and personal involvement, France is now ranked as the second scientific partner of Taiwan in terms of the number of joint research projects, following the United States, according to the French Institute.

Chen, who visited France many times during his term as National Science Council (NSC) minister, helped launch several important cooperation schemes between Taiwan and France, including the "Orchid partnership, " which supports new joint research projects, and the "Frontiers of Science" symposia, which promotes exchanges among young French and Taiwanese scientists, according to the institute.

Chen also helped establish a multi-thematic cooperative program between the NSC and the French National Agency for Research in January 2007 -- a program that was at that time the first institutional partnership of the French agency with a foreign agency outside Europe, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Main Stadium management likely to face financial woes

TEXT.P: With the high maintenance fees for the World Games Main Stadium in Kaohsiung City, several legislators questioned Thursday whether the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) , which has taken over management of the stadium, can afford to operate it.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiang Nai-hsin said during a legislative session that the SAC has set up a management division in charge of the stadium's operations and that personnel expenses and maintenance fees are estimated to reach up to NT$250 million, while the SAC has been granted a budget of just NT$70 million.
The legislative session was held to discuss issues related to the Kaohsiung World Games in July and the Taipei Deaflympics in September, as well as baseball revitalization plans.

KMT Legislator Cheng Chin-ling suggested that the SAC, the highest authority in Taiwan for physical fitness and sports, should hand the operating rights of the stadium over to the Kaohsiung city government.

In response, SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said the council will spare no efforts to host large-scale international events to make good use of the equipment and facilities and the experience of hosting the World Games. At present, the SAC is seeking to host the 2017 East Asian Games.

Tai added that the SAC is also planning to arrange for national sports events and training sessions, as well as other community and cultural activities, to be held at the stadium. A portion of the space will also be used for commercial purposes.
She also asked legislators to help out while reviewing budget bills for the stadium's operations in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 2, or the 14th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 B.C.: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, located 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
2001: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is studying the feasibility of using undercover agents in its battle against organized crime.
2004: Iraqi insurgents shoot down a U.S. military helicopter near Baghdad, killing 36 soldiers and crewmen aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Typhoon-related torrential rain forecast

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecast Friday that torrential rain will affect northern and eastern Taiwan for a few days from Oct. 5 due to the combined effect of two typhoons and the northeasterly monsoon.
According to the weather bureau, Typhoon Parma was centered some 1,200 km southeast of Taiwan as of 11 a.m. Friday, moving in a west-northwesterly direction toward the island at a speed of 20 kph.

The typhoon could move over the north of Luzon Island in the Philippines or could sweep through the Bashi Channel over the next few days, depending on atmospheric pressure changes over the Pacific, the CWB meteorologists forecast.
Another typhoon, Melor, was even farther away from Taiwan as of news time, moving also in a west-northwesterly direction but at a slower pace of 15 kph.
"The typhoon could take a northerly direction and sweep toward Japan if the Pacific high pressure system weakens further over the following several days, " the meteorologists forecast.

Whether either makes landfall in Taiwan will depend on changes in the Pacific high pressure system, they said, although they forecast heavy rain for northern and eastern parts of Taiwan due to the combined effect of the two typhoons and the seasonal northeasterly monsoon.
For central and southern Taiwan, they forecast cloudy weather but only a low chance of torrential rain.

Friday saw temperatures drop to a comfortable 26 degrees - 29 degrees Celsius with sporadic showers under the impact of the northeasterly monsoon. Temperatures ranged between 26 degrees and 32 degrees Celsius for central and southern Taiwan, where there were sunny skies, with afternoon showers in mountainous areas, the forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2011 U.S. immigrant visa program to kick off Oct. 3

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Friday that the 2011 U.S. Diversity Immigrant Visa (DV) lottery will run from Oct. 3 to Dec. 1.
"Due to anticipated high demand for the online application system, AIT encourages participants to submit applications well before the lottery ends," the AIT said in a press release.

According to the AIT, system delays in the past caused by extremely heavy demand in the final days of the registration period have resulted in the failure of some applicants to register for the program.

While the system is being upgraded, overwhelming demand could cause delays and therefore it is very important to apply early, as no entries will be accepted after 1 a.m. Dec. 1, Taiwan time, regardless of whether there are system delays during the registration period, it added.

The only source for complete and authoritative information on eligibility requirements and application procedures is available at www.dvlottery.state.gov, according to the press release, adding that all applications must be submitted online according to the instructions on the Web site and that this year, entrants are required to submit an e-mail address with their applications.
People born on the islands of Taiwan and Penghu are eligible to participate in the DV program, while those born elsewhere should check the link www.dvlottery.state.gov, according to the AIT.
There is no fee for participating in the lottery and the U.S. Government employs no outside consultants or private services to operate the program, the AIT said.

Any intermediaries or others who offer assistance to prepare DV entries do so without the authority or consent of the U.S. Government, and use of any outside intermediary or assistance to prepare a DV entry is entirely at the entrant's discretion, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central, local governments can enforce mandatory evacuation

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said Friday that governments at both central and local levels can enforce mandatory evacuations in the event of massive rainfall and mudslides triggered by typhoons.

Speaking on the possible threats posed by two approaching typhoons -- Parma and Melor -- expected to begin affecting Taiwan late this weekend, Chu said evacuations should be carried out immediately if the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) issues instructions in that regard.

The evacuation of residents from areas threatened by typhoons and floods should also be executed immediately if the local city or county government decides such a course of action is necessary, Chu added.
He also noted that weather forecasts by the Central Weather Bureau should not be the only standard based on which the central and local governments make decisions concerning emergency evacuations.

On the possibility of conflicting opinions, such as if the CEOC calls for an evacuation but the local government says it is unnecessary, Chu said the evacuation will be mandatory so long as one government administration, whether it be central or local, gives an evacuation order.
"If the local government decides to issue an evacuation order, the central government will support the local decision, " Chu stressed.
Meanwhile, he went on, in addition to wind strength, rainfall and mudslide forecasts will also be used as a basis for whether to announce class or office closures in the event of a serious typhoon.

The vice premier made the remarks as a follow-up to remarks he made a day earlier at a meeting on typhoon-induced disaster prevention and control measures in the wake of the massive devastation caused by Typhoon Morakot in August.

Morakot swept across the country in early August, triggering the worst flooding and mudslides in half a century. Nearly 700 people died, including around 400 victims from Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County who were buried alive when their village was inundated by mud.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan appreciates European Union's goodwill: official
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/02/09 14:04:14 (By Lin Yu-li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The European Union's recent reiteration of support for Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in international organizations demonstrates the organization's goodwill toward the country, Republic of China Representative to the European Union Shen Lyushun said in a phone call from Brussels Thursday.

In particular, it would greatly improve Taiwan's ability to deal with natural disasters if the country were to be admitted to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) , Shen told a CNA reporter based in Berlin.

In a European Parliament session held Sept. 17, pro-Taiwan members of parliament proposed that Taiwan -- which experienced the worst flooding in 50 years during Typhoon Morakot in August -- should be allowed to take part in the WMO to enhance the country's preparedness for extreme climate change as a result of global warming.

In response to the proposal, European Commission Commissioner Meglena Kuneva said it remains the European Union's policy to support Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in international organizations under "appropriate circumstances."
Kuneva also promised that the European Union will consider Taiwan's request to be included in the European Union's visa waiver program.
Taiwan has not been represented at the United Nations since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China.
Since 1993, Taiwan has been trying -- unsuccessfully, due to Beijing's objections -- to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation.

In 2008, the country shifted its strategy to promoting a bid to "participate meaningfully in the activities of specialized U.N. agencies, " in line with President Ma Ying-jeou's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy that favors a moderate and pragmatic approach.

Following Taiwan's success in its bid to attend the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's decision-making arm -- as an observer for the first time in May this year, the government has recently announced that the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) will be the country's next targets for such "meaningful participation."

Explaining Taiwan's UNFCCC bid during a Cabinet meeting a day earlier, Premier Wu Den-yih said the country's participation in the UNFCCC and the WMO is crucial to strengthening its access to advanced climate technology and data.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tunnel concert to mark 60th anniversary of Kinmen battle

TEXT.P: A rare concert performed in a tunnel will be staged Oct. 18 on the outlying island of Kinmen to mark the 60th anniversary of the battle of Kuningtou, in which Kuomintang forces fought off attacking Chinese communists to maintain control of the island, officials at the Kinmen National Park Headquarters said Friday.

The concert, which will take place inside the island's Chaishan Tunnel, will be one of two "prayer for peace" shows organized by the park headquarters to commemorate the anniversary. The other is scheduled for a day earlier at the Kinmen County Stadium and will feature the Taipei Symphony Orchestra.

The tunnel concert will feature cellist Chang Cheng-chieh, who will play his 319 -year-old Rugieri cello, soprano Mewas Lin, flautist Wu Tzung-hsien, violinist Roger Chiang and harpist Hong Chi-mei, the officials said.
A floating stage will move the musicians around an A-shaped waterway inside the tunnel, the officials went on.
In light of the unique characteristics of the venue, the concert will be open to only 300 audience members aged 10 and older, they added.
Those interested in attending are required to register in advance by calling the park headquarters at (082) 313182 or by visiting its Web site at www.kmnp.gov.tw.
The battle of Kuningtou took place Oct. 25-27, 1949, when nearly 10,000 Communist troops in 200 ships invaded Kinmen as a prelude to seizing Taiwan.
In the fierce three-day battle, the invaders were repulsed, losing nearly 4,000 soldiers, with another 5,200 captured.

The defeat of the communists brought a 10-year halt to Beijing's attempts to take Taiwan by force. In 1958, they bombarded Kinmen, situated just kilometers off China's southeastern coast, but were unable to seize any part of the Taiwan- held island on that occasion either.

DOC.HEADLINE: Better to evacuate even if nothing happens later: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that he would rather see residents in mudslide- prone areas evacuated before a typhoon hits even if nothing happens later, rather than risk disaster because people did not move.
"It's like taking out an insurance policy against accidents, although the last thing one would want is to become a claimant, " Wu said at the Legislative Yuan.
He called for residents in areas that are under threat from typhoons and floods to comply with any evacuation order issued either by the central or local governments.

The premier made the remarks in response to a question by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chen Chieh on the government's state of preparedness as two approaching typhoons -- Parma and Melor -- are expected to begin affecting Taiwan late this weekend or early next week.

Wu said that in addition to wind velocity warnings by the Central Weather Bureau, rainfall and mudslide forecasts will also be used to determine whether schools and offices should be closed during a typhoon.

In the future, the Central Weather Bureau, the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture, the National Science Council's Disaster Research Center and the Air Force Weather Wing will work closely to monitor storm situations and related information, he added.

In response to a question by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsueh Ling, the premier said that if there is any repeat of the mudslide casualties and heavy infrastructure damage that occurred in early August when Typhoon Morakot struck, officials found guilty of negligence will be penalized.

According to the Central Weather Bureau, Parma and Melor -- which were still far southeast of Taiwan as of Friday -- had both increased in strength and were moving in a west-northwesterly direction toward the island.

The weather bureau warned the Taiwan public to be on the alert, saying that the outer bands of the typhoons could converge with the northeasterly monsoon, bringing torrential rain to northern and eastern parts of the country from late this weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: NBA players to coach children affected by Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: National Basketball Association (NBA) players in Taipei next week for an exhibition game will coach children affected by Typhoon Morakot for a day, the Taiwan chapter of the Christian charity organization World Vision announced Friday.

"As the first ever NBA game in Taipei is creating excitement across Taiwan, a group of children currently facing adversity but still embracing their basketball dreams will be given a once in a lifetime opportunity to learn from professional basketball players in an NBA basketball clinic in Taipei on Oct. 7, " World Vision Taiwan said in a press release.

Retired San Antonio Spurs defensive star Bruce Bowen, Indiana Pacers star Danny Granger, and his Pacers teammates will pass on their shooting, passing and dribbling skills to 82 World Vision sponsored children, according to the charity organization.

The children, aged 12-14, are from indigenous communities in typhoon-stricken Chiayi County and other areas that have struggled against poverty or suffered severe property losses during Typhoon Morakot, which devastated southern Taiwan Aug. 7-10.

The basketball clinic is part of the NBA Cares program that promotes social responsibility and community charity. NBA Cares chose to work with World Vision Taiwan because the two share a concern for child welfare.

Taiwan will host an NBA game for the first time when the Denver Nuggets and Indiana Pacers play an exhibition game at Taipei Arena Oct. 8, a breakthrough for a country in which the NBA has a devoted following.

Taipei will become the 8th Asian city to host an NBA exhibition or regular season game. Japan's Tokyo, Yokohama and Saitama hosted six regular season two- game series between 1990 and 2003, while exhibitions have been held in recent years in Beijing, Guangzhou, Macau, and Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop on local bourse

TEXT.P: Ending a three-day rally, Taiwan's share prices tumbled Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 133.41 points, or 1.76 percent, to close at 7,411.88.
Following a fall on Wall Street overnight, the local bourse opened lower at 7,415.16 but then rose to the day's high of 7,483.43 as investors picked up bargains.
Dragged down by the weak showings of plastics, tourism, textile and paper shares, the market later retreated to 7,391.63 before rebounding slightly at the end of the session.
A total of 4.03 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$116.04 billion (US$3.59 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals stocks falling the most at 2.57 percent. Textile shares fell 2.39 percent, paper and pulp issues dropped 2.33 percent, machinery and electronics shares declined 1.77 percent, foodstuff issues shed 1.29 percent, banking and financial stocks dropped 1.22 percent, construction shares lost 0.93 percent, and cement stocks were down 0.81 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,905 to 550, with 190 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$13.13 billion worth of shares.
They had bought a net NT$144.2 billion in shares in September, helping drive up the Taiex by more than 10 percent for the month, but followed the bearish mood in the market Friday.
One analyst predicted that following the market's recent gains, the Taiex may head lower and is likely to fluctuate between 7,384 and 7,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
Apple Daily:
A flip-flopping government
Flip-flops are a bane to policymakers, but the Taiwan government made an about- face on two projects recently, causing public uproar.
The first was the Presidential Office's plan to tighten regulations pertaining to the height of buildings in the area adjacent to the presidential residence in downtown Taipei.
The plan was opposed by estate developers and was later scrapped by the Presidential Office.
The second was a proposal to add three stops to the Taiwan High Speed Railway service. Premier Wu Den-yih said that the plan had to be shelved because the railway company was in financial straits.

However, the minister of transportation and telecommunications reversed the decision after politicians from the areas close to the proposed stops protested. The three additional stations will be built before next January, the minister said.

The government is obviously been held hostage by local governments which are controlled by businessmen who have set their sights on big profits from the development of property near the proposed station sites.
How can such a flip-flopping government not cause chaos?
United Daily News:
When would China get rid of the red sea of giant pictures and
slogans?

Beijing is inundated by a red sea of giant pictures and slogans in celebration of its national day. Beijing's celebrations stress collectivism and discipline, which is in sharp contrast to Taiwan's focus on individualism and freedom in its celebrations at the opening of the Kaoshsiung World Games and Taipei Deaflympics.

Chinese President Hu Jintao repeated Mao Zedong's declaration that "the Chinese people have stood up." However, we have to point out that while China may have stood up, its people have not, as they are still far from being fully liberated.
Hu said his country will stick to the "Chinese version of socialism." Everyone knows this is a lie. China has already deviated from socialism and is on the path of capitalism.
"The Chinese version of socialism" is only a pretext used by China to justify its Communist dictatorship.
From the perspective of Mao Zedong's teachings, China's 1.3 billion people are all capitalists and should don tall paper hats and parade on the streets.

Hu's calls for liberation of thought is what really makes the point. If China had stuck to the dogma of communism, it could not have risen to the glory it has today. The Chinese people would never enjoy freedom and democracy unless they're liberated from the shackles of the Chinese version of socialism.
Taiwan may not be China's match in terms of national power, but its people enjoy far greater liberty and democracy than the Chinese.
Liberty Times:
How could voters give their mandate to these people?
China's celebration of its national day has nothing to do with Taiwan, but some Taiwanese bigwigs scrambled to angle an invitation to join the celebration in Beijing.
Those people include some of President Ma Ying-jeou's national policy advisers and business tycoons.
They have forgotten that China has never given up its designs on Taiwan and is threatening to take over the island using force.
By retaining those pro-China advisers, President Ma has showed that his administration is skewed toward Beijing.
As to those business tycoons who visited Beijing to show their friendship toward China, they have betrayed the island that fosters them.
How can we trust our country to these people? We can change this by denying them our votes in forthcoming elections.
China Times:
Administration's bane is shooting itself in the foot
The ruling team is always the target of fault-finding by the opposition, but President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is lucky because it rules while the opposition's strength is at its lowest ebb.
Unfortunately Ma's ruling team often digs holes for itself, making controversies out of nothing. This could be an indication of Ma's defective decision-making ability.
Following are two recent examples of Ma's ability to create a fuss over nothing:

The first is the choice of the CNA chairman. This was a decision of little significance, but the authorities nonetheless managed to flip-flop over a decision for 24 hours, first naming an unknown 42-year-old writer to head the agency, only to change their minds and replace him with a 77-year-old.
The ruling team offered no explanation for the abrupt change.

Another more notable example was a plan to tighten height restrictions on buildings in the area adjacent to the president's official residence, as the administration believes a skyscraper erected near the residence poses a security threat.
The plan, initiated by the Presidential Office, was eventually scrapped after causing discord between the office and the Taipei city government.
Although the Presidential Office claimed that it and City Hall were at cross purposes, everybody knows that City Hall is not in a position to recommend such changes.
Furthermore, permission to build the skyscraper in question was granted by Ma himself during his term as mayor of Taipei.

If the skyscraper really poses a security risk, why not just relocate the residence. No-one will believe the flip-flop was caused by anyone other than Ma's ruling team, which should be blamed for this bungle.
Ma should improve his decision-making procedure and stop causing such storms in a tea cup.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expresses appreciation for allies' support at U.N.

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed appreciation Thursday for the support of Taiwan's diplomatic allies for the country's efforts to seek meaningful participation in United Nations specialized agencies.

According to a MOFA press release, a total 15 head of states or representatives of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies spoke in favor of Taiwan at the Sept. 23-30 General Debate of the 64th U.N. General Assembly.

They are Palau, the Marshall Islands, Kiribati, Nauru, Burkina Faso, Sao Tome and Principe, Gambia, Tuvalu, St. Christopher and Nevis, Swaziland, the Solomon Islands, Belize, Nicaragua, St. Lucia, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

Samuel S.M. Kuo, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs, said at a regular press briefing Thursday that Fradique de Menezes, president of Sao Tome and Principe; Yahya Jammeh, president of Gambia; Blaise Compaore, president of Burkina Faso; and King Mswati III of Swaziland voiced support on Sept. 24 and 25 for Taiwan's U.N. bid.
They said that Taiwan will make significant contributions to the U.N. specialized agencies, which at the same time will also benefit from Taiwan's participation, according to Kuo.
The also called on the world to consider Taiwan's legitimate right to participate in international organizations, he added.
The MOFA announced Sept. 21 that Taiwan will strive for membership in U.N. specialized agencies, rather than direct participation in the U.N. as it had been pursuing in previous years.

Taiwan will seek meaningful participation in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) , the MOFA said, calling for the two agencies to give favorable consideration to the needs of Taiwan's people and what they could contribute if admitted.
Taiwan has not been represented in the U.N. since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the Peoples Republic of China.
Since 1993, it has been trying to have the world body consider the issue of its representation, but has made little progress largely due to China's obstruction.

Taiwan's allies and supporters have been trying to get the General Assembly to list Taiwan's application for admission on the U.N. agenda, but Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.
This year, the Taiwan government has come up with a more flexible and pragmatic approach that it hopes will allow it to better negotiate the complex situation.
It is hoped that Taiwan will first enter the ICAO as an observer this fall, and then gain admission to the UNFCCC after December this year, according to the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier questioned on CAL chairman's presence at parade in Beijing

TEXT.P: The attendance of Philip Wei, the chairman of Taiwan's national carrier China Airlines (CAL) , at China's National Day parade Thursday was inappropriate, Premier Wu Den-yih said on Friday.

If an incumbent official or the leader of a state-run company attended the parade, "I would see such an act as inappropriate," but things would be different if it's a retired government servant, Wu said.
He added, however, that he wanted to understand what really happened before commenting further.

Wu's remarks were made in response to a question from opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsueh Ling on whether the Cabinet should remove Wei after he answered Beijing's invitation to attend its national day parade in his capacity as the chairman of Taiwan's state-controlled carrier.
Taiwan and China have been bitter rivals since the end of China's civil war in 1949 when the Kuomintang-led Republic of China regime lost the war to the Communists and retreated to Taiwan.

Under President Ma Ying-jeou, relations between the two countries have improved, but many in Taiwan are uneasy over the rapid pace of the rapprochement, with some criticizing the government for surrendering Taiwan's sovereignty.
Those raw nerves were touched when it was learned that three of the president's national policy advisers planned to attend China's Oct. 1 parade, and Wei's presence has also been questioned.
Asked what he thought of China's militaristic national day celebration, the premier said "we don't have any reason to interfere" in how a country celebrates its national festivals.
He urged, however, that the development of peaceful relations between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait, which people of the two sides had make great efforts to achieve, be preserved.

Meanwhile, Wei, who returned to Taiwan earlier Friday, told the Central News Agency that he participated in China's celebration as a matter of courtesy after receiving an invitation from the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office.
"CAL is a private company, and I am not a civil servant, so there is no need for me to inform the government in advance of my activities," Wei argued.
He said that through the opening of direct trade, postal, and transportation cross-strait links, the carrier's planes have flown to China and business with the mainland has grown.
"With good interactions between the two sides, answering the invitation was based on courtesy," Wei said.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum pieces will not be loaned to China: director

TEXT.P: National treasures at the Taipei-based National Palace Museum (NPM) will not be exhibited in China because that country does not have a law to prevent the seizure of artworks, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said Friday.
The NPM collections are national assets and if they are to be exhibited abroad, it will be only in countries that have laws that guarantee the return of the exhibits, Chou said.
"As long as there are no such legal protections in China, the NPM will not consider loaning the national treasures to that country, " Chou said.

The NPM director made the remarks at a news conference held at the museum Friday to mark the arrival of 37 pieces of art that are on loan from the Palace Museum in Beijing. The pieces will be included in an exhibition on Emperor Yongzheng -- the fourth ruler of the Manchu Qing Dynasty -- which will held at the NPM from Oct. 7 to Jan. 10, 2010.

The exhibition will feature 246 artworks related to Yongzheng, including 203 items from the NPM's Qing Dynasty collections, two from the Shanghai Museum, three from Academia Sinica and one owned by a Taipei-based pharmaceutical company.
Of the artworks from China is a seal that was used by Emperor Yongzheng, which bears three Chinese characters that read, "It's hard to be a king."

Yongzheng ruled China for 13 years from 1722 to 1735. He was known as a tough and hard-working emperor who opposed corruption and was bent on clean, effective government. During his reign, the Manchu Empire became a great and peaceful power.

Yongzheng's private life was a sad one. He had nine children but only three survived. He died mysteriously at the age of 58. He was succeeded by his son, Prince Hong Li, who became the fifth emperor of the Qing dynasty under the name Emperor Qianlong.

At Friday's press conference, Chou said the joint exhibition was made possible after her "ice-breaking" visit to China's Palace Museum in Beijing in February -- the first of its kind in 60 years -- and a reciprocal visit in March by Zheng Xinmiao, director of the Beijing museum.
During the visits, Chou said, they discussed matters regarding cross-strait cooperation on a joint Yongzheng exhibition.
The exhibition was also possible because of Taiwan's legislation in 1992 of the Statute on Encouraging and Rewarding Cultural and Art Enterprises, Chou said.
"Under that statute, the exhibits from the museums in Beijing and Shanghai will be exempt from seizure or any legal entanglements over ownership," she added.
"Taiwan's art and cultural objects could also be displayed in China once a similar statute is put in place there to grant them the same protection," she said.
The NPM has the world's largest collection of Chinese historical artifacts, totaling more than 700,000 pieces.

Most of the items were removed from the Beijing Palace Museum in the 1930s to prevent the collection from falling into the hands of the invading Japanese army. They were later shipped to Taiwan when the Kuomintang-led Nationalist troops lost the civil war in China to the Communists in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Brainy volunteer worker offers service with gadget

TEXT.P: A volunteer worker with the Hualien-based Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation not only has a kind heart but also a clever mind that has allowed him to create a smart gadget to help disaster victims, among others, maintain their oral health.

Chou Chin-yuan, who was a truck driver before becoming a volunteer for the Tzu Chi Foundation after retiring, has invented a portable dental equipment case dubbed the "Tzu Chi 007" due to its similarity to the 007 briefcase seen in the famous James Bond films.
"The health care environment in disaster zones is really bad. I hope that this 'Tzu Chi 007' can help those affected by disasters benefit from more efficient medical services," he said.

Chou made the original version of his case in 2001, capitalizing on his expertise in machinery and rich volunteer experience to develop a dental equipment case based on a model originally invented by a dentist in Tzu Chi's U.S. headquarters.

After modifying the case throughout the decade, Chou recently developed the fourth generation of the portable product that weighs 12.2 kilograms and measures 45 centimeters long, 33 cm wide and no more than 20 cm deep.

This latest version, resulting from intensive consultations with dentists and manufacturers over the past three years, has wheels and can be carried aboard a plane or conveniently brought to disaster zones.

"As a volunteer worker who travels around with a group to offer charitable health care to underprivileged people, I find that normal dental equipment occupies nearly two-thirds of a cargo truck's space and decided to work out a solution to the problem, " he said.
The portable dental kit contains a set of miniature dental instruments and equipment, including a dental handpiece, dental scaler, dental light, and dental halogen lamp.
"With 1,250 cc of water, a dentist can immediately start to work by simply stepping on the kit's motor," Chou explained.

Due to its portability and convenience, more than 80 kits have been used by charitable organizations providing free dental services in countries such as China, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and the Dominican Republic.
"I am happy to be able to use what I know to do something for people in need," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China trying to monopolize say in Taiwan issue: scholar

TEXT.P: An expert on Taiwan-China relations said Friday that China has been trying to monopolize say in the Taiwan issue despite the fact that the issue has become one of international concern.

Director Tsai Ming-yen of the National Chung Hsing University's Graduate Institute of International Politics said at a Taipei seminar that Taiwan, China and the United States all clearly understand that bilateral relations among any two of them are deeply related to the third party, but China has been trying very hard to dominate say on the Taiwan issue.

While the world witnessed the stable development of Taiwan-China- U.S. triangular relations, there are still uncertain factors that may impact the future development of relations among the three parties, Tsai said at a seminar on peace in the Asia-Pacific region, co-sponsored by the Academia Sinica's Center for Humanities and Social Sciences and the Center for Asia-Pacific Area Studies.

Those factors include how the United States and China would manage their "cooperative and competitive" relations, the military imbalance in the Taiwan Straits which favors China, and China's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

Tsai pointed out that after cross-strait relations improved and U.S.-China cooperation increased, the sensitivity of the Taiwan issue has been reducing, and is no longer a "political bargaining chip" for either Beijing or Washington as far as U.S.-China relations are concerned.

However, Tsai said although the Taiwan issue was not on the agenda of a U.S-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue in July, Chinese State Councilor Dai Bingguo stated in the meeting that " it's the core interests of China in maintaining the integration of national territory."
Dai's remarks, according to Tsai, indicate that Beijing continues to regard the Taiwan issue as its core interest and will not yield any ground on this matter while dealing with the United States.

Liu Faitao, an associate research fellow with China Institute of International Studies, said at the seminar that the United States has become less capable of utilizing the Taiwan issue as a means to prevent or deter China as it had done before, as a result of China's economic rise and the recent thaw in cross-strait relations.

Tsai urged Taiwan to pay greater attention to the change in the triangular relations, especially how the U.S. would react to China's intent to monopolize decision-making in the Taiwan issue and cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central government debt nearly NT$4 trillion: Finance Ministry

TEXT.P: The central government's outstanding debt totaled NT$3.887 trillion (US$120.3 billion) as of the end of August, a figure that was relatively low based on the country's gross domestic product (GDP), the Ministry of Finance said Friday.

"The total debt as a percentage of GDP is 32.21 percent, making Taiwan's financial status relatively healthy if compared to those of the United States. Japan, and other countries, " the ministry said in a statement apparently issued in response to a less flattering assessment by a lawmaker.

Citing figures from the Ministry of Audit earlier in the day, Legislator Lu Shiow-yen of the ruling Kuomintang said that if liabilities such as pension and insurance obligations are factored in, then the government's overall debt actually stood at NT$19.722 trillion at the end of 2008, or NT$860,000 per capita.

Focusing strictly on the current national debt without commenting directly on future liabilities, the ministry said it had been accumulated as aresult of borrowing to finance major infrastructure projects to advance national development.

These infrastructure projects, however, now represent NT$7.661 trillion, or NT$333,000 per capita, in public assets, not to mention the increased employment and economic growth to which the projects have contributed.

In the 16 months since President Ma Ying-jeou was inaugurated, the government has borrowed NT$222.5 billion to finance stimulus measures to increase economic growth in the face of the global financial crisis, the ministry added.

Taiwan's financial status remains relatively "healthy" since its total debt as a percentage of GDP was still lower than 170.5 percent in Japan (2008) , 47.1 percent in the United State (2007) , 66.6 percent in France (2007) , 40.8 percent in Germany (2007) and 86.7 percent in Singapore (2007), the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Release of life' religious practice spurs big business: group

TEXT.P: In Taiwan, religious groups spend more than NT$200 million (US$6.19 million) annually to engage in "release of life" rituals, which they practice 750 times on average each year, according to the Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan (EAST) Friday.

People usually practice "fangsheng, " or "release of life, " when they fall ill, have a miserable marriage or want to pray for wealth in their next life, the EAST said in a statement on a recent survey on the practice in Taiwan.

Some Buddhism followers believe that setting animals free increases their own merit, which translates into a better rebirth. This has sparked a new profit- making business in the religious market in Taiwan, the EAST said.

The business is supported by a complete demand and supply system that operates on the "symbiosis" between religious believers and hunters, breeders and vendors, it added. However, this business not only hurts the animals that are hunted or bred for sale to fangsheng adherents, but also causes damage to the ecological system, it added.
In the 2009 survey, EAST interviewed operators and staff of 484 local Buddhist and Taoist temples and other groups that follow the teachings of esoteric Buddhism.
It found that 256 of the 388 respondent groups maintain the fangsheng practice, while 98 have given it up, and 34 have not practiced it in a long time and are not sure whether they will do so again.
Seven of the groups that still practice fangsheng said they do so in foreign countries, including China, Hong Kong, the United States, Canada, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Nepal and India.

Notably, an organization run by a Buddhist monk named Hai Tao was found to have engaged in a total of 89 instances of fangsheng in Taiwan and 35 abroad in 2008, according to the survey. This year, it has so far engaged in ritual freeing of animals 75 times in Taiwan and 22 times overseas, the survey found.
On average, it organized 10 rounds of activities a month for its members to free animals, the EAST said, describing the Hai Tao group as a"super fangsheng organization."
Based on the survey, the EAST estimated that more than 200 million creatures are used in Taiwan each year in the religious ritual and at least NT$200 million is spent annually on such activities.
Birds, fish, frogs, turtles and snakes are the most commonly used animals, according to the survey.

Turtledoves, sparrows, scaly-breasted munia, and Japanese white-eye are the most popular birds in the "release of life" activities because they are cheap and can be easily caught in large numbers in the wild in Taiwan, the EAST said.
It noted that the birds are often kept in tiny wooden cages before being transferred to bird shops and that some of them usually die from shock in captivity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students urged to stretch in the morning

TEXT.P: Based on research showing that "exercise makes people smart," the Ministry of Education (MOE) suggested Friday that elementary and junior high schools should reinforce requirements that students stretch before starting their classes in the morning.

MOE Physical Education Department Director Wang Chun-chuan stated that many scientific studies have shown that exercise helps boost the brain's vitality, including one published in the Journal of Physiology by a team of researchers at National Cheng Kung University in May.

The team found that the spatial or aversive learning and memory of laboratory mice significantly improved after they were pushed to run on a treadmill or wheel for one month. The conclusion was cited in a New York Times article published Sept. 16 and triggered heated debate on the Internet.
Citing the report, Wang suggested teachers lead students in doing stretching exercises 30 minutes every morning, saying he believes such a practice will enhance students' ability to learn.

DOC.HEADLINE: As health insurance shortfall mounts, Yaung searches for funds

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Friday that Taiwan's National Health Insurance system would face a deficit even bigger in 2010 than the NT$55.4 billion expected this year and insisted that premiums had to go up.

Yaung, answering questions at a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, said raising premiums was not a question of whether he agreed with the idea or not but simply something that was unavoidable, and he suggested raising premiums on high income earners.
The DOH chief was responding to criticism from opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsueh Ling, who accused the DOH of waffling on the issue of whether premiums would be raised.

Citing the conclusions made at a recent citizen's conference, Hsueh insisted that "the national health insurance system must be maintained, " that "government subsidies must not be slashed" and that "national health insurance premiums cannot be hiked."
Yaung disagreed with Hsueh's charge and made it clear that "the DOH has been very clear in its stance on the issue."

Although the DOH head acknowledged that the financially strapped National Health Insurance system needs to be reformed to make it more cost-effective, Yaung argued that the goal cannot be achieved if premiums are maintained at current levels.

According to Yaung, government subsidies have not only not fallen in the past decade, they have gone up markedly for senior citizens as Taiwan's elderly population has grown by 30 percent. The cost of caring for the elderly, he said, is three times higher than for younger people.
He also pointed to premium reductions or exemptions for low-income or slightly above low-income households that affect 2.41 million people, or one-tenth of Taiwan's population.

Under such circumstances, Yaung told Hsueh, it was only natural that higher income earners pay a little more to help the disadvantaged based on the health insurance system's fundamental concept of having those with means assist those less well off.

Yaung said on Thursday that the health insurance premium rate, currently set at 4.55 percent of insurers' monthly salary up to a ceiling of NT$131,700 (US$4,052) per month would not be increased for the moment, but that the premiums paid by high income earners would be hiked.

Chu Tong-kuang, a deputy convener of a DOH task force on insurance premiums, said Friday that the DOH intends to increase the income ceiling (NT$131,700) on which premiums are calculated, as early as next week.
The existing ceiling is 7.62 times higher than the minimum income basis, NT$17,280, on which premiums are calculated, and the DOH would like to increase the cap to 10-15 times the minimum.

If a factor of 15 is adopted, the new ceiling would be set at around NT$260,000 per month and would increase monthly premium revenues by about NT$1 billion. Moving the income ceiling higher would affect between 80,000-90,000 people, Chu estimated.

Among those affected would be doctors, accountants, lawyers, and business executives, he said. The plan to raise the ceiling could be implemented at any time and would not require legislative approval.
Other legislators urged Yaung to recover premiums that Taipei and Kaohsiung cities owe the Bureau of National Health Insurance to bridge the system's shortfall.

Yaung explained that recovering the money would not help the system financially because money had already been borrowed from local banks to cover the amounts owed, but he pledged that the money would be collected nonetheless.
Taipei owes approximately NT$36.7 billion and Kaohsiung around NT$18.7 billion in premium contributions they were supposed to make on behalf of people working but not residing in their cities.

The two municipalities argued that they were only liable to make premium payments on behalf of city residents and took the case to court, but the courts eventually rejected their argument and ordered them to pay the premiums due.
Taipei in particular has dragged its feet in responding to the court order.

Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng said Friday, however, that arrangements have already been worked out with the two cities to repay the balance owed. Taipei and Kaohsiung have agreed to repay what they owe over eight years and six years, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu claims one more life in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Influenza A (H1N1) , has claimed one more life in Taiwan, the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) reported Friday.

The victim, the 20th in Taiwan and the fourth in Taipei County, was a 10-year- old girl with epilepsy who was hospitalized Tuesday after having a sudden bout of seizures and developing a fever at school, according to Taipei County health officials.

The hospital tried to control her seizures by giving her emergency treatment but did not give her the anti-viral drug Tamiflu for the swine flu. The girl was declared dead on Wednesday because of cardiorespiratory failure, the officials said.
Only Thursday did a test report by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reveal that a specimen taken showed she had the H1N1 virus, and her case was identified as severe.

According to the health officials, the girl had had seizures since she was five months old. She was diagnosed with epilepsy at the age of two and took medicine to control the problem, and medical experts believe that the swine flu retriggered her seizures.

The officials noted that the girl's older brother showed flu symptoms on Sept. 28 and tested positive for the H1N1 virus after seeking medical attention at a clinic. He recovered, however, after taking Tamiflu.
None of the girl's 30 classmates and teachers have shown swine flu symptoms, the officials added.

As of Thursday night, five more people were hospitalized with the H1N1 virus, bringing the total number of patients hospitalized with the new flu strain to 311 since the outbreak began, including 19 fatalities, according to the CECC.
Of that number, only 28 are still being treated in local hospitals, while the other 264 have been discharged.
Meanwhile, 249 classes in 173 schools around the country remained suspended because of H1N1 infections among students.
The number of affected classes dropped to 0.16 percent of the total, from 0.32 percent a week ago, according to the CECC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet must work with locals on disaster prevention: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Friday urged Cabinet members to work with local governments over the weekend on disaster prevention and control.

The president asked the premier, the vice premier, and heads of related government agencies to travel to cities and counties as the nation is on high alert against two approaching typhoons -- Parma and Melor -- even if the weekend is the Mid-Autumn holiday.
He made the remarks while presiding over a meeting at the Presidential Office amid reports that two typhoons could bring heavy rains.

He reminded the participants that when disaster strikes, the number of people in the affected areas and people will usually be greater than the number of rescuers. If that is the case, it will be impossible to provide satisfactory assistance to every one.

If the emergency hotline 119 is inundated, the people will call the media and if the media air their calls for help, then the public would ask "whether is our government? Why isn't it engaged in rescue efforts?"

"If that is the case, it will be a repeat of what took place in Typhoon Morakot, " Ma said, adding that "the best way is a well-prepared disaster-fighting team, which will deploy forces in the risk-prone areas immediately."
If the public, especially those in the remote areas, can see military forces and firefighters in the vicinity, they will be more at ease, he said.
He pointed out that the tremendous property damages and nearly 700 lives lost during Morakot resulted in the resignation of former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.
"This is for the government a very serious matter, which will not be allowed to be repeated again," he affirmed.

Meanwhile. the Central Weather Bureau said that although the strength of Parma has been downgraded from a super typhoon, there will be heavy rains starting Sunday, especially in northern and eastern parts of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000 Chinese tourists to spend Moon Festival in Sun Moon Lake

TEXT.P: Over 1,000 tourists from China are expected to spend their Moon Festival in Sun Moon Lake Saturday, an official with the Beijing-based China Travel Service (CTS) said.
Sun Moon Lake, located in the central Taiwan county of Nantou, has long been one of the Taiwan scenic spots most favored by Chinese tourists.
CTS Vice President Si Laishun told the Central News Agency that CTS is organizing the special tourist program in cooperation with 14 travel agents in various Chinese provinces.
The 1,000 tourists, in some 40 groups, have already arrived in Taiwan, and will gather in Sun Moon Lake for a special Moon Festival Saturday.

The Moon Festival, the 15th day of the eighth month in the Chinese lunar calendar year, along with the Dragon Festival and Lunar New Year, are the three most important traditional festivals for Chinese around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Electronic shackles considered in detention system change

TEXT.P: Judicial authorities are considering allowing criminal defendants to wear electronic shackles instead of having to be held in detention centers after they have been indicted, the Judicial Yuan said Friday.

The change in the nation's detention system would be made possible by an amendment to the Criminal Procedure Law, which has yet to be enacted, said Liu Ling-chi, director of the Judicial Yuan's Criminal Department.
The new system is aimed at safeguarding defendants' human rights while preventing them from fleeing before courts have the chance to deliver their verdicts.

According to the Criminal Procedure Law, judges have only two options for people indicted for crimes carrying minimum sentences of five years -- to either detain the defendant or release the individul on bail.
Under the new system, electronic devices monitoring the movement of shackle- wearing suspects will be installed in the police bureaus of counties and cities to prevent defendants from escaping.
There have been several cases in which indicted individuals who were released on bail fled abroad, triggering public outcries for the government to consider a change in the detention system.

Meanwhile, under the planned amendment to the Criminal Procedure Law, the length of detention would also be shortened to fewer than two months for persons of interest being investigated by prosecutors, and to no more than 15 months for those on trial in the district and higher courts.
The current Criminal Procedure Law gives prosecutors the right to detain suspected criminals for four months at most before they decide whether or not to hand down indictments.

During trials in district and high courts, the indicted are subject to an initial detention of three months, and their detention can be extended three times for an additional total of six months. Detention periods are unlimited for those, who if found guilty, are sentenced to death or to jail terms of over 10 years.

Judicial authorities have been accused of abusing their power in detaining former President Chen Shui-bian, who was sentenced to life in jail by the Taipei District Court on Sept. 11 on charges of corruption, forgery and money- laundering.
The ex-president, who has appealed his case to the higher court, was first detained Nov. 12 last year and was released Dec. 13 following his indictment by prosecutors.
He was detained again Dec. 30 the same year after the Taipei District Court approved a request by prosecutors to take him back into custody, and has not been released since then.
