DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 3, or the 15th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
2001: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet- level National Science Council (NSC), is elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).
2001: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opens, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."

DOC.HEADLINE: As health insurance shortfall mounts, Yaung searches for funds

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Friday that Taiwan's National Health Insurance system would face a deficit even bigger in 2010 than the NT$55.4 billion expected this year and insisted that premiums had to go up.

Yaung, answering questions at a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, said raising premiums was not a question of whether he agreed with the idea or not but simply something that was unavoidable, and he suggested raising premiums on high income earners.
The DOH chief was responding to criticism from opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsueh Ling, who accused the DOH of waffling on the issue of whether premiums would be raised.

Citing the conclusions made at a recent citizen's conference, Hsueh insisted that "the national health insurance system must be maintained, " that "government subsidies must not be slashed" and that "national health insurance premiums cannot be hiked."
Yaung disagreed with Hsueh's charge and made it clear that "the DOH has been very clear in its stance on the issue."

Although the DOH head acknowledged that the financially strapped National Health Insurance system needs to be reformed to make it more cost-effective, Yaung argued that the goal cannot be achieved if premiums are maintained at current levels.

According to Yaung, government subsidies have not only not fallen in the past decade, they have gone up markedly for senior citizens as Taiwan's elderly population has grown by 30 percent. The cost of caring for the elderly, he said, is three times higher than for younger people.
He also pointed to premium reductions or exemptions for low-income or slightly above low-income households that affect 2.41 million people, or one-tenth of Taiwan's population.

Under such circumstances, Yaung told Hsueh, it was only natural that higher income earners pay a little more to help the disadvantaged based on the health insurance system's fundamental concept of having those with means assist those less well off.

Yaung said on Thursday that the health insurance premium rate, currently set at 4.55 percent of insurers' monthly salary up to a ceiling of NT$131,700 (US$4,052) per month would not be increased for the moment, but that the premiums paid by high income earners would be hiked.

Chu Tong-kuang, a deputy convener of a DOH task force on insurance premiums, said Friday that the DOH intends to increase the income ceiling (NT$131,700) on which premiums are calculated, as early as next week.
The existing ceiling is 7.62 times higher than the minimum income basis, NT$17,280, on which premiums are calculated, and the DOH would like to increase the cap to 10-15 times the minimum.

If a factor of 15 is adopted, the new ceiling would be set at around NT$260,000 per month and would increase monthly premium revenues by about NT$1 billion. Moving the income ceiling higher would affect between 80,000-90,000 people, Chu estimated.

Among those affected would be doctors, accountants, lawyers, and business executives, he said. The plan to raise the ceiling could be implemented at any time and would not require legislative approval.
Other legislators urged Yaung to recover premiums that Taipei and Kaohsiung cities owe the Bureau of National Health Insurance to bridge the system's shortfall.

Yaung explained that recovering the money would not help the system financially because money had already been borrowed from local banks to cover the amounts owed, but he pledged that the money would be collected nonetheless.
Taipei owes approximately NT$36.7 billion and Kaohsiung around NT$18.7 billion in premium contributions they were supposed to make on behalf of people working but not residing in their cities.

The two municipalities argued that they were only liable to make premium payments on behalf of city residents and took the case to court, but the courts eventually rejected their argument and ordered them to pay the premiums due.
Taipei in particular has dragged its feet in responding to the court order.

Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng said Friday, however, that arrangements have already been worked out with the two cities to repay the balance owed. Taipei and Kaohsiung have agreed to repay what they owe over eight years and six years, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu claims one more life in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Influenza A (H1N1) , has claimed one more life in Taiwan, the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) reported Friday.

The victim, the 20th in Taiwan and the fourth in Taipei County, was a 10-year- old girl with epilepsy who was hospitalized Tuesday after having a sudden bout of seizures and developing a fever at school, according to Taipei County health officials.

The hospital tried to control her seizures by giving her emergency treatment but did not give her the anti-viral drug Tamiflu for the swine flu. The girl was declared dead on Wednesday because of cardiorespiratory failure, the officials said.
Only Thursday did a test report by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reveal that a specimen taken showed she had the H1N1 virus, and her case was identified as severe.

According to the health officials, the girl had had seizures since she was five months old. She was diagnosed with epilepsy at the age of two and took medicine to control the problem, and medical experts believe that the swine flu retriggered her seizures.

The officials noted that the girl's older brother showed flu symptoms on Sept. 28 and tested positive for the H1N1 virus after seeking medical attention at a clinic. He recovered, however, after taking Tamiflu.
None of the girl's 30 classmates and teachers have shown swine flu symptoms, the officials added.

As of Thursday night, five more people were hospitalized with the H1N1 virus, bringing the total number of patients hospitalized with the new flu strain to 311 since the outbreak began, including 19 fatalities, according to the CECC.
Of that number, only 28 are still being treated in local hospitals, while the other 264 have been discharged.
Meanwhile, 249 classes in 173 schools around the country remained suspended because of H1N1 infections among students.
The number of affected classes dropped to 0.16 percent of the total, from 0.32 percent a week ago, according to the CECC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet must work with locals on disaster prevention: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Friday urged Cabinet members to work with local governments over the weekend on disaster prevention and control.

The president asked the premier, the vice premier, and heads of related government agencies to travel to cities and counties as the nation is on high alert against two approaching typhoons -- Parma and Melor -- even if the weekend is the Mid-Autumn holiday.
He made the remarks while presiding over a meeting at the Presidential Office amid reports that two typhoons could bring heavy rains.

He reminded the participants that when disaster strikes, the number of people in the affected areas will be greater than the number of rescuers. If that is the case, it will be impossible to provide satisfactory assistance to every one.

If the emergency hotline 119 is inundated, the people will call the media and if the media air their calls for help, then the public would ask "where is our government? Why isn't it engaged in rescue efforts?"

"If that is the case, it will be a repeat of what took place in Typhoon Morakot, " Ma said, adding that "the best way is a well-prepared disaster-fighting team, which will deploy forces in the risk-prone areas immediately."
If the public, especially those in the remote areas, can see military forces and firefighters in the vicinity, they will be more at ease, he said.
He pointed out that the tremendous property damages and nearly 700 lives lost during Morakot resulted in the resignation of former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.
"This is for the government a very serious matter, which will not be allowed to be repeated again," he affirmed.

Meanwhile. the Central Weather Bureau said that although the strength of Parma has been downgraded from a super typhoon, there will be heavy rains starting Sunday, especially in northern and eastern parts of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000 Chinese tourists to spend Moon Festival in Sun Moon Lake

TEXT.P: Over 1,000 tourists from China are expected to spend their Moon Festival in Sun Moon Lake Saturday, an official with the Beijing-based China Travel Service (CTS) said.
Sun Moon Lake, located in the central Taiwan county of Nantou, has long been one of the Taiwan scenic spots most favored by Chinese tourists.
CTS Vice President Si Laishun told the Central News Agency that CTS is organizing the special tourist program in cooperation with 14 travel agents in various Chinese provinces.
The 1,000 tourists, in some 40 groups, have already arrived in Taiwan, and will gather in Sun Moon Lake for a special Moon Festival Saturday.

The Moon Festival, the 15th day of the eighth month in the Chinese lunar calendar year, along with the Dragon Festival and Lunar New Year, are the three most important traditional festivals for Chinese around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Electronic shackles considered in detention system change

TEXT.P: Judicial authorities are considering allowing criminal defendants to wear electronic shackles instead of having to be held in detention centers after they have been indicted, the Judicial Yuan said Friday.

The change in the nation's detention system would be made possible by an amendment to the Criminal Procedure Law, which has yet to be enacted, said Liu Ling-chi, director of the Judicial Yuan's Criminal Department.
The new system is aimed at safeguarding defendants' human rights while preventing them from fleeing before courts have the chance to deliver their verdicts.

According to the Criminal Procedure Law, judges have only two options for people indicted for crimes carrying minimum sentences of five years -- to either detain the defendant or release the individul on bail.
Under the new system, electronic devices monitoring the movement of shackle- wearing suspects will be installed in the police bureaus of counties and cities to prevent defendants from escaping.
There have been several cases in which indicted individuals who were released on bail fled abroad, triggering public outcries for the government to consider a change in the detention system.

Meanwhile, under the planned amendment to the Criminal Procedure Law, the length of detention would also be shortened to fewer than two months for persons of interest being investigated by prosecutors, and to no more than 15 months for those on trial in the district and higher courts.
The current Criminal Procedure Law gives prosecutors the right to detain suspected criminals for four months at most before they decide whether or not to hand down indictments.

During trials in district and high courts, the indicted are subject to an initial detention of three months, and their detention can be extended three times for an additional total of six months. Detention periods are unlimited for those, who if found guilty, are sentenced to death or to jail terms of over 10 years.

Judicial authorities have been accused of abusing their power in detaining former President Chen Shui-bian, who was sentenced to life in jail by the Taipei District Court on Sept. 11 on charges of corruption, forgery and money- laundering.
The ex-president, who has appealed his case to the higher court, was first detained Nov. 12 last year and was released Dec. 13 following his indictment by prosecutors.
He was detained again Dec. 30 the same year after the Taipei District Court approved a request by prosecutors to take him back into custody, and has not been released since then.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Relations with China, U.S. challenge for new Taiwan Cabinet: AmCham

TEXT.P: Skillful managing of cross-Taiwan Strait economic relations and continuing to strengthen relations with the United States are among the challenges for Taiwan's new Cabinet, according to a Taipei-based U.S. trade group.

The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei made the remarks in the September issue of its monthly publication, Topics, saying that the new government of Premier Wu Den-yih will face a host of challenges, starting with the need to prove its competence and efficiency in carrying out reconstruction in the areas hard-hit by Typhoon Morakot in early August.

"The former Cabinet was replaced because it evidently did not meet the high demands and expectations of the Taiwan public. It will now be up to Premier Wu and his ministers to show that they are up to the task," according to a Topics editorial.

In moving ahead on a proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China, the government will need to make the case more clearly to the public on why such a pact is so crucial to preserving and protecting Taiwan's export markets in China and the region, according to the editorial.

It adds that other topics that deserve to be high on the new Cabinet's priority list include balancing the advances in cross-strait ties with further strengthening of relations with the U.S. -- Taiwan's most important source of international support -- continuing to pursue the aspiration of developing Taiwan into a regional financial center, tackling the problem of insufficient funding for the national health care system, and shoring up Taiwan's international economic competitiveness.

While the political environment in Washington makes it currently unfeasible for the U.S. to begin negotiating a free trade agreement with any country, including Taiwan, and discussion of a bilateral investment agreement has been stalled because of procedural complications, Taiwan and the U.S. could explore various other mechanisms for broadening and deepening the economic relationship, according to the editorial.
"If that can be done, Taiwan would feel a greater sense of confidence and security as it engages China," it says.
On the financial aspect, the editorial contends that several proposed lows and regulations threaten to undermine Taiwan's competitiveness in the banking, insurance and assets management industries.

It says the Executive Yuan, by liaising with the legislature and coordinating between the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Ministry of Finance, is in a position to ensure that Taiwan's attractiveness in the financial services sector is not eroded.

The editorial also warns that as long as hospitals in Taiwan are reliant for their financial soundness on ever-larger discounts from the pharmaceutical and medical device manufacturers, Taiwanese patients' access to new and innovative treatments will be restricted and Taiwan will be unable to draw the investment needed to build a flourishing biotech industry.

In terms of improving Taiwan's international economic competitiveness, the editorial says this could be accomplished by improving the fairness, transparency and consistency of the regulatory process, and by adhering to international practices rather than trying to devise Taiwan-unique solutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. trade group welcomes trade policy changes in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) has welcomed recent policy changes made by the Taiwanese government on the retail, tax and transport sectors, saying that the decisions have effectively resolved the protracted issues covering a broad swathe of concerns.

"Getting solutions to three issues for three different committees was a nice way to end the summer, " AmCham President Andrea Wu was quoted as saying in the September issue of the AmCham monthly publication, Topics.
"Let's hope we can maintain a similar momentum through the rest of the year," she adds.

Wu was referring to Taiwan's recent liberalization of imports from China by removing tableware from the banned list, the clarification of the scope of "Taiwan-sourced income" for income tax purposes, and allowing the use of electronic invoices to help expedite express cargo shipments.
The government's prohibition on imports of made-in-China porcelain and china tableware and kitchenware has been one of the priority items of the AmCham Retail Committee for the past several years.

According to the article, it was a particularly frustrating issue for the committee because the rationale for the ruling appeared to be "nebulous, " since although the local ceramics industry is not even equipped to produce Western- style tableware in large quantities, the ceramics manufacturers association kept objecting to any relaxation of the ban on Chinese imports.
The Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs decided in August to release the category as permissible for import.

Regarding"Taiwan-sourced income," AmCham's Tax Committee has long appealed to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to clear up confusion over the tax treatment of payments to overseas entities for services performed entirely offshore.

In September, the MOF issued a ruling titled Guidelines for Determining Taiwan- sourced Income as Defined under Article 8 of the Income Tax Law, that provides just such clarification along the lines that the Chamber suggested, the article says.

For example, income earned by foreign enterprises that render services outside Taiwan will not be considered Taiwan-sourced if the foreign enterprise has no fixed location of business or agent in Taiwan -- or if there is a fixed location or agent but they were not involved in providing the particular service rendered.
The third recent change, also announced in September by the MOF, came in the form of revised Regulations Governing Customs Clearance Procedures for Express Consignments.

It states that paper invoices will no longer have to be attached to express export shipments as long as the express cargo company possesses digital invoice storage and retrieval systems and can provide Customs with immediate perusal and printout of the relevant files when required.

The revision was requested by AmCham's Transportation Committee, which noted that it would enhance Taiwan's trade competitiveness and is also in line with a paperless clearance project being promoted by the World Customs Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: New life quality index to be published: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Friday that in order to better reflect people's feelings about their quality of life, a new table of economic indicators that are more relevant to the public will soon be published.

The table will compile 13 existing economic indicators related to the lives of ordinary people in four aspects -- income, production, consumption and finance. It will be published on a monthly basis on the CEPD Web site so that people can access the statistics easily, said CEPD Deputy Minister Hu Chung-ying.
" The statistics will reflect people's feelings about their lives, and the government will review its policies if the data shows they are not performing well," Hu said.
He also noted that the CEPD's definition of so-called "ordinary people" is civilians not including low-income individuals, and not specific to gender or age.

The aspect of income covers average wage and salary adjustments, jobless claims and the number of jobs on offer, while the production aspect covers container traffic through commercial ports, international shipping, trailer traffic on freeways, and the number of foreign visitors, he said.

The consumption aspect includes retail sales, food service sales, category A of the living price index and consumer confidence index, while the aspect of finance covers the weighted stock index and the trading volume of the stock market, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO to hold workshop on creative industry

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said Saturday that it has invited Andrew Cahn, chief executive of U.K. Trade and Investment -- a British government organization responsible for marketing the U.K. overseas -- to share the experiences of Britain's creative industry.

According to a BTCO newsletter, Cahn will attend an Oct. 7 workshop titled "Going for Gold: London 2012 and U.K. Creative Industries" in Taipei and provide opening remarks titled "London 2012 Olympics: Springboard for the U.K. Economy".
Admission to the workshop is free and open to all.

The workshop is part of the BTCO's efforts to showcase the development of the creative industry in Britain over the past 50 years, and is being held to correspond with an exhibition it is hosting in the Taiwan Design Expo, which opened a day earlier in the central city of Taichung.
The exhibition, titled "Love and Money -- 50 Years of Creative Britain", is being held in the International Design Pavilion at the 2009 Taiwan Design Expo, slated to run through Oct. 18.

The BTCO said the content of the exhibition was chosen specifically to showcase the diversity of the creative sector in the United Kingdom and to highlight creative projects that have been commercially successful without compromising on creativity.
"The originality and professionalism of U.K. creativity inspires the world, providing business with the creative imagination that drives commercial success," the BTCO said in the newsletter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's life expectancy averages 78.57

TEXT.P: The life expectancy at birth of the people of Taiwan averaged 78.57 years in 2008, up by 0.19 years from the 2007 average, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced Saturday.
Over the past 13 years, life expectancy has increased 4.04 years, the ministry said after publishing the 2008 life expectancy chart.

By comparison, Taiwan's 2008 life expectancy was three years shorter than Japan's, two years less than those of Singapore and France and one year shorter than Canada's, but longer than those of the United States, China, Malaysia and the Philippines, while on par with South Korea, Britain and Germany.
In 2008, Taiwanese males and females lived 75.59 years and 81.94 years, respectively, on average, it said.

In terms of administrative areas, residents of Taipei City lived the longest at 81.87 years last year, followed by Kaohsiung City residents with an average of 78.21 years of life expectancy, according to MOI statistics.
In both cities, as well as in other localities, females lived longer than their male counterparts, with the female population in Taipei City taking the lead.

In terms of geographic regions, northern Taiwan residents, regardless of gender, enjoyed the longest life expectancy of 80 years, ahead of their counterparts in central Taiwan with 78.03 years and those in southern Taiwan with an average life expectancy of 77.41 years. Eastern Taiwan residents had the shortest life expectancy of 74.09 years.
The figures reflect a noticeable gap between urban and rural areas, as well as regional differences, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-risk villagers evacuated as Typhoon Parma approaches

TEXT.P: Military personnel and police began evacuating villagers in several regions deemed to be high-risk areas of Kaohsiung County Saturday, with approaching Typhoon Parma forecast to bring torrential rain, creating the danger of mudslides.

Having learned a bitter lesson from the tragic incidents of villages buried under mudslides and human lives and property lost in floods incurred by Typhoon Morakot and accompanying heavy rain in early August, central and local governments were taking all possible precautionary measures to ensure the safety of people living in mountainous regions considered the most vulnerable.

More than 1,000 residents, mostly from aboriginal tribal communities in Liuguei township, Kaohsiung County, had been evacuated with military assistance. Meanwhile, 700 military officers and soldiers had been dispatched to the most risky regions for disaster prevention and rescue action should the need arise.

In the southernmost county Pingtung, residents of tribal communities in three mountain villages that were hard hit by Typhoon Morakot were evacuated, while residents of Shengmu village in central Taiwan's Nantou County, which also suffered serious damage by Morakot, were also evacuated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese companies visit Africa to expand trade opportunities

TEXT.P: Twenty-one Taiwanese companies led by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) were scheduled to leave on a trip to four African countries Saturday, targeting business opportunities in markets with a total combined population of 300 million, according to TAITRA officials.

According to TAITRA, a total of 1,000 meetings between the Taiwanese representatives and African buyers have been scheduled during a number of Taiwanese trade fairs be held in Nigeria, Kenya, Uganda and Egypt that are expected to attract 500 foreign buyers. Taiwan's mini-notebooks and office stationery are so popular that meetings featuring those products have been fully booked, the officials said.

To meet the characteristics of emerging economies in Africa, Taiwanese companies manufacturing auto parts, food machinery, notebooks, lighting equipment and solar energy-related products have been chosen to be represented on the trip, the officials added.

According to TAITRA, 15 of the world's top 20 fastest-growing economies are located in Africa. Nigeria is the continent's most populous country, with a population of 142.3 million and an annual per capita income of US$2,000.

Egypt has 77.1 million, with an average per capita income of US$5,500, while Kenya's population is 39 million with an average per capita income of US$1,700, and Uganda has 32.71 million people and an average per capita income of US$900, TAITRA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Multi-function orchid park opens in Tainan County

TEXT.P: A multi-function park called Orchid Exploration World opened Saturday in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, with management vowing to make it a world-class leisure and tourism facility.

Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih and Taiwan Orchid Professional Co. Chairman Chang Teh-ning jointly presided over the opening of the park, which previously was an orchid biotechnology production center.

Su hailed the local orchid industry as one of Taiwan's greatest prides and voiced his hope that the park will further help advance the local industry's brands in the world market by presenting its diverse facets to the local public and foreign visitors.

Taiwan Orchid Professional Co., commissioned by the county government, is in charge of operating the multi-function leisure-oriented park for 12 years starting from this year. The facility features four sub-theme parks -- the Orchid Castle, the Orchid Dream Work, the Crystal Palace and the Orchid Gallery.
Along with the park's inauguration, the company is also sponsoring a fair of cosmetics made from extracts from locally grown orchids.
Chang said the company is set to embrace the many challenges ahead by making the local orchid industry even more robust in the face of international competition.

With changes in management direction, the park will also become a tourism center open to general visitors, making better use of the compound's large area, much of which used to lie idle as a result of lacking adequate development acumen.

DOC.HEADLINE: President lauds housing units for homeless typhoon victims

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou lauded Saturday the temporary housing units being constructed for victims in Taitung County who were rendered homeless by Typhoon Morakot.
"The housing units are marvelously built, " said Ma upon entering one of the units in Chinfeng township to observe the interior.

He expressed appreciation for World Vision Taiwan, the charity organization that solicited the money for the housing, as well as for High Tech Computer CEO Cho Ho-tu for a generous donation his company made.

The president, accompanied by Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo, visited the eastern county to learn about the progress of post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction. Nearly 700 people died and thousands lost their homes and property when the typhoon swept past Taiwan Aug. 7-9.

Turning to the possible onslaught of approaching Typhoon Parma, Ma said that disaster prevention comes before rescue and that the central government will work closely with local governments to reduce the possibility of disaster.
Earlier, he had visited workers of the Taiwan Railway Administration to thank them for their speedy work to repair the Taimali section of the Southern Link line.
A 1-kilometer stretch of the line's foundations were swept away by the storm and the repair work, originally estimated to take two months because of its difficulty, was completed in half that time.
Meanwhile, Mao and Taitung Magistrate Kuang Li-chen held the first meeting at the county's emergency operations center, which was opened earlier that same day.
Mao instructed the military and firefighters to step up inspections in order to provide speedy assistance in the case of emergencies.

Satellite phone systems and other notification systems should be tested, he went on, adding that monitoring of a mudslide-formed lake above Chialan village in Chinfeng township should also be strengthened.
The previous day, Ma had called a high-alert disaster prevention meeting during which he assigned government officials to various areas to oversee disaster prevention and control work.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pingtung biotech park to reach NT$18 billion output by 2013

TEXT.P: The first stage of construction of the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park (PABP) has been fully completed and is expected to have reached an annual output value of NT$18 billion (US$557.3 million), with more than 6,000 employees upon completion of the third stage of construction in 2013, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Saturday.

According to the CEPD, 20 factories and one incubation center have already set up operations at the park. Among them, the Hokuto Corp., a Japan-listed company that produces mushrooms, has the largest investment at NT$430 million.

Total investment in the first-stage construction area has reached NT$3.86 billion, the CEPD said, adding that the second stage will be completed by March 2010, with the third scheduled for completion by the end of 2013.

The CEPD said Advanced Green Biotechnology -- the biggest bio pesticide company in Asia -- has already received orders from Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia since entering the PABP recently, and is planning to submit a stock listing plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traditional arts center in Yilan presents Mekong art

TEXT.P: Since 2003, the center has presented the art festival every autumn, each year basing its theme on a different part of the Asia-Pacific region, according to a spokesman. Dozens of groups and artists from Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Burma and Thailand have been invited to present folk music, dance and theater at this year's nine-day festival that runs Oct. 3-11, he added.

Among the folk artists are the Tre Viet Band from Vietnam, Samarm and his Folk Art Ensemble from Laos, shadow puppet troupe Sovanna Phum from Cambodia, Burmese puppet troupe Mandalay Marionettes, and Thailand's famous palace mask dance group of Srinakharinwirot University.

During the festival, a series of complementary exhibitions, demonstrations of making handicrafts and lectures will be held at the center, which is located near the county's scenic Dong Shan Water Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd Taiwan-Saint Lucia trade fair opens
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/03/09 19:55:09 (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Saint Lucia trade fair, the second of its kind, opened Friday in the Caribbean country, with dignitaries from the two countries taking part in the opening ceremony.

Lenard Montoute, acting premier of Saint Lucia, Minister of Commerce, Industry and Consumer Affairs Tessa Mangel and Foreign Minister Rufus Bousquet, as well as Republic of China Ambassador to Saint Lucia Tom Chou, attended the event.
Montoute and Mangel both hailed the resumption of formal diplomatic ties in 2007 after a hiatus of 10 years, saying that the decision has benefited both countries.

Over the past two years, Taiwan has rekindled many cooperative projects with Saint Lucia, some of which have already borne fruit and have benefited the people of the Caribbean island nation, they said.
Chou for his part expressed hope that the fair will help provide more business opportunities between the two countries and strengthen trade ties between Taiwan and other countries in the region.

Six Taiwanese firms and 20 Saint Lucia companies are participating in the three-day trade fair that is being co-sponsored by the ROC embassy and Saint Lucia's Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Consumer Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: International conference on China to be held: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and National Chengchi University will co- sponsor an international conference on China Oct 5-6, in which MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan is scheduled to make a keynote speech on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the country's China policies, the MAC said in a news release Saturday.

The conference, titled International Conference On China: Six Decades and After, will invite various scholars and experts to discuss and evaluate cross-strait relations, China's political, social and regional development, and a variety of other issues, according to the press release.

The attendees will include Professor Brantly Womack of the University of Virginia, Associate Professor Scott L. Kastner of the University of Maryland, Professor Zhao Ding-xin of the University of Chicago, Professor Yang Zhong of the University of Tennessee, and Professor You Ji of the University of New South Wales in Australia.

The MAC said the opinions and views collected at the conference will help the government further understand China's evolution and will serve as a reference for setting future China policies and managing cross-strait issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese companies visit Africa to expand trade opportunities

TEXT.P: Twenty-one Taiwanese companies led by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) were scheduled to leave on a trip to four African countries Saturday, targeting business opportunities in markets with a total combined population of 300 million, according to TAITRA officials.

According to TAITRA, a total of 1,000 meetings between the Taiwanese representatives and African buyers have been scheduled during a number of Taiwanese trade fairs be held in Nigeria, Kenya, Uganda and Egypt that are expected to attract 500 foreign buyers. Taiwan's mini-notebooks and office stationery are so popular that meetings featuring those products have been fully booked, the officials said.

To meet the characteristics of emerging economies in Africa, Taiwanese companies manufacturing auto parts, food machinery, notebooks, lighting equipment and solar energy-related products have been chosen to be represented on the trip, the officials added.

According to TAITRA, 15 of the world's top 20 fastest-growing economies are located in Africa. Nigeria is the continent's most populous country, with a population of 142.3 million and an annual per capita income of US$2,000.

Egypt has 77.1 million, with an average per capita income of US$5,500, while Kenya's population is 39 million with an average per capita income of US$1,700, and Uganda has 32.71 million people and an average per capita income of US$900, TAITRA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Multi-function orchid park opens in Tainan County

TEXT.P: A multi-function park called Orchid Exploration World opened Saturday in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, with management vowing to make it a world-class leisure and tourism facility.

Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih and Taiwan Orchid Professional Co. Chairman Chang Teh-ning jointly presided over the opening of the park, which previously was an orchid biotechnology production center.

Su hailed the local orchid industry as one of Taiwan's greatest prides and voiced his hope that the park will further help advance the local industry's brands in the world market by presenting its diverse facets to the local public and foreign visitors.

Taiwan Orchid Professional Co., commissioned by the county government, is in charge of operating the multi-function leisure-oriented park for 12 years starting from this year. The facility features four sub-theme parks -- the Orchid Castle, the Orchid Dream Work, the Crystal Palace and the Orchid Gallery.
Along with the park's inauguration, the company is also sponsoring a fair of cosmetics made from extracts from locally grown orchids.
Chang said the company is set to embrace the many challenges ahead by making the local orchid industry even more robust in the face of international competition.

With changes in management direction, the park will also become a tourism center open to general visitors, making better use of the compound's large area, much of which used to lie idle as a result of lacking adequate development acumen.

DOC.HEADLINE: President lauds housing units for homeless typhoon victims

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou lauded Saturday the temporary housing units being constructed for victims in Taitung County who were rendered homeless by Typhoon Morakot.
"The housing units are marvelously built, " said Ma upon entering one of the units in Chinfeng township to observe the interior.

He expressed appreciation for World Vision Taiwan, the charity organization that solicited the money for the housing, as well as for High Tech Computer CEO Cho Ho-tu for a generous donation his company made.

The president, accompanied by Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo, visited the eastern county to learn about the progress of post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction. Nearly 700 people died and thousands lost their homes and property when the typhoon swept past Taiwan Aug. 7-9.

Turning to the possible onslaught of approaching Typhoon Parma, Ma said that disaster prevention comes before rescue and that the central government will work closely with local governments to reduce the possibility of disaster.
Earlier, he had visited workers of the Taiwan Railway Administration to thank them for their speedy work to repair the Taimali section of the Southern Link line.
A 1-kilometer stretch of the line's foundations were swept away by the storm and the repair work, originally estimated to take two months because of its difficulty, was completed in half that time.
Meanwhile, Mao and Taitung Magistrate Kuang Li-chen held the first meeting at the county's emergency operations center, which was opened earlier that same day.
Mao instructed the military and firefighters to step up inspections in order to provide speedy assistance in the case of emergencies.

Satellite phone systems and other notification systems should be tested, he went on, adding that monitoring of a mudslide-formed lake above Chialan village in Chinfeng township should also be strengthened.
The previous day, Ma had called a high-alert disaster prevention meeting during which he assigned government officials to various areas to oversee disaster prevention and control work.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pingtung biotech park to reach NT$18 billion output by 2013

TEXT.P: The first stage of construction of the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park (PABP) has been fully completed and is expected to have reached an annual output value of NT$18 billion (US$557.3 million), with more than 6,000 employees upon completion of the third stage of construction in 2013, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Saturday.

According to the CEPD, 20 factories and one incubation center have already set up operations at the park. Among them, the Hokuto Corp., a Japan-listed company that produces mushrooms, has the largest investment at NT$430 million.

Total investment in the first-stage construction area has reached NT$3.86 billion, the CEPD said, adding that the second stage will be completed by March 2010, with the third scheduled for completion by the end of 2013.

The CEPD said Advanced Green Biotechnology -- the biggest bio pesticide company in Asia -- has already received orders from Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia since entering the PABP recently, and is planning to submit a stock listing plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traditional arts center in Yilan presents Mekong art

TEXT.P: Since 2003, the center has presented the art festival every autumn, each year basing its theme on a different part of the Asia-Pacific region, according to a spokesman. Dozens of groups and artists from Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Burma and Thailand have been invited to present folk music, dance and theater at this year's nine-day festival that runs Oct. 3-11, he added.

Among the folk artists are the Tre Viet Band from Vietnam, Samarm and his Folk Art Ensemble from Laos, shadow puppet troupe Sovanna Phum from Cambodia, Burmese puppet troupe Mandalay Marionettes, and Thailand's famous palace mask dance group of Srinakharinwirot University.

During the festival, a series of complementary exhibitions, demonstrations of making handicrafts and lectures will be held at the center, which is located near the county's scenic Dong Shan Water Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd Taiwan-Saint Lucia trade fair opens
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/03/09 19:55:09 (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Saint Lucia trade fair, the second of its kind, opened Friday in the Caribbean country, with dignitaries from the two countries taking part in the opening ceremony.

Lenard Montoute, acting premier of Saint Lucia, Minister of Commerce, Industry and Consumer Affairs Tessa Mangel and Foreign Minister Rufus Bousquet, as well as Republic of China Ambassador to Saint Lucia Tom Chou, attended the event.
Montoute and Mangel both hailed the resumption of formal diplomatic ties in 2007 after a hiatus of 10 years, saying that the decision has benefited both countries.

Over the past two years, Taiwan has rekindled many cooperative projects with Saint Lucia, some of which have already borne fruit and have benefited the people of the Caribbean island nation, they said.
Chou for his part expressed hope that the fair will help provide more business opportunities between the two countries and strengthen trade ties between Taiwan and other countries in the region.

Six Taiwanese firms and 20 Saint Lucia companies are participating in the three-day trade fair that is being co-sponsored by the ROC embassy and Saint Lucia's Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Consumer Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: International conference on China to be held: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and National Chengchi University will co- sponsor an international conference on China Oct 5-6, in which MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan is scheduled to make a keynote speech on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the country's China policies, the MAC said in a news release Saturday.

The conference, titled International Conference On China: Six Decades and After, will invite various scholars and experts to discuss and evaluate cross-strait relations, China's political, social and regional development, and a variety of other issues, according to the press release.

The attendees will include Professor Brantly Womack of the University of Virginia, Associate Professor Scott L. Kastner of the University of Maryland, Professor Zhao Ding-xin of the University of Chicago, Professor Yang Zhong of the University of Tennessee, and Professor You Ji of the University of New South Wales in Australia.

The MAC said the opinions and views collected at the conference will help the government further understand China's evolution and will serve as a reference for setting future China policies and managing cross-strait issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Earthquake rattles Taiwan

TEXT.P: An earthquake measured 6.3 on Richter scale rattled Taiwan at 1:36 a.m. Sunday (1736 GMT Saturday), no immediate reports of damage or casualties.

The temblor, the second with a magnitude above 6 this year, took place at 22.8 km (14.33 miles) southeast of Hualien, eastern Taiwan, with a depth of 15.3 km (9.4 miles), and was felt around the island according to the Central Weather Bureau.
Straddling on the boundaries of the Eurasian Plate and the Philippine Sea Plate, Taiwan is prone to earthquakes. A magnitute-7.3 earthquake hit the island in 1999 killed 2400 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 4, or the 16th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
2001: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announces that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.
2001: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presents the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China government spokesman expresses welcome for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Weather bureau issues land warning for Typhoon Parma

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for the Hengchun peninsula in southern Taiwan Sunday as medium Typhoon Parma continued its approach to the country.

Parma, with winds gusting up to 162 kilometers per hour, was 340 km south of Oluanpi on the southernmost tip of Taiwan as of 5:30 a.m., moving in a north- northwesterly direction at 7 kph, the bureau said.
The typhoon slammed into the northern Philippines a day earlier, killing at least three people there, according to foreign wire service reports.
"Right now, Parma seems to be swirling in the Bashi Channel that separates Taiwan and the Philippines and its speed is likely to slow down to 4 kph," said Hsiao Chia-sen, a CWB forecaster.
Over the next two or three days, Hsiao went on, the typhoon may move slowly and hover around the Bashi Channel, but he added that further observation will be needed to predict its course after that.
He urged residents in the Hengchun area to take precautions against powerful wind and heavy downpours.
Residents in northern and eastern parts of Taiwan should also be on guard against torrential rain brought by the typhoon, Hsiao added.

The approaching typhoon comes less than two months after Typhoon Morakot, the worst storm to hit the island in half a century, killed more than 600 and led to a major Cabinet reshuffle due to lackluster government response in the initial stages.

DOC.HEADLINE: H1N1 vaccinations to be free: health official

TEXT.P: Local citizens will not be required to pay for vaccination against swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1), a health official said Sunday.

"The free-of-charge policy is aimed at encouraging people to receive inoculations as soon as possible once the vaccination program is launched next month, " said Chou Chih-hau, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health (DOH).
According to Chou, the DOH will offer NT$150 (US$4.63) per head in subsidies to local health care institutions that offer H1N1 vaccinations.
"The amount is enough to pay for registration fees and medical examination fees for each citizen who receives H1N1 inoculation at designated hospitals, clinics or health centers," Chou said.

As more than 10 million people will be involved in various kinds of vaccinations in the coming months, Chou said, the subsidy program for H1N1 vaccination is expected to help speed up completion of the program.

According to the DOH's plan, 5 million doses of H1N1 vaccine imported from Switzerland-based pharmaceutical firm Novartis will be available for high-risk individuals in late October, while 10 million doses to be supplied by local manufacturer Adimmune Corp. will be ready in early November.
As the two suppliers will deliver the doses in staggered shipments, the vaccines will be administered simultaneously.
The DOH-initiated priority list for H1N1 vaccination is led by typhoon-affected victims, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, and pregnant women.

They will be followed on the priority list by pre-school children, seriously ill patients, elementary, junior and senior high school students, individuals in the 19-24 age bracket and those over 25 at high risk of cardiopulmonary disease, healthy people in the 25-49 age bracket, and those aged between 50 and 64.

Meanwhile, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) reported Sunday that five more patients had been hospitalized for severe H1N1 symptoms in the previous 24 hours, bringing the total hospitalization cases to 319 since the outbreak began.
Of that number, 21 had died, 28 were still being treated in local hospitals, while the other 270 had been discharged after making complete recoveries.
The five newly hospitalized patients include one male and four females, aged between 4 and 42.
A CECC official said the center is keeping a close watch on the developments in the H1N1 situation in the wake of the Mid-Autumn Festival.

"The weather has been cooling off significantly in recent days and human interaction has increased over the Mid-Autumn Festival, so we are monitoring whether the two developments will have any impact on the H1N1 situation," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tremor does not predispose Taiwan to landslides: expert

TEXT.P: An earthquake that jolted Taiwan early Sunday has not predisposed the island to more landslides, even if Typhoon Parma hits the island in the next few days, an expert said later that day.

Yen Hong-yuan, a professor of earth science at Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County, said the precipitation brought by Parma to eastern Taiwan had not yet exceeded safety limits and was therefore unlikely to trigger landslides.
He said the 6.3-magnitude temblor 23 km southeast of Hualien at 1: 36 a.m. was "not abnormal."
"Although it is the second temblor with a magnitude over 6 this year, the number of earthquakes this year is within the normal range," he said.

Furthermore, Yen said, the precipitation caused by Typhoon Parma so far was less than one-third of the nearly 3,000 mm of rainfall brought by Typhoon Morakot and there were few slopes in eastern Taiwan predisposed to mudslides.
"The fear that soil softened up by the temblor is more likely to slide after sucking up water from rainfall is groundless, " Yen pointed out.

As Typhoon Morakot, which triggered widespread landslides and killed more than 600 people in early August, has rammed home the importance of evacuating people from mudslide-prone areas before torrential rain, Yen said he was confident that the Morakot tragedy will not be repeated.

Typhoon Parma was centered 310 km south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanpi as of Sunday afternoon, moving slowly on a north-northwesterly trajectory, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 1,200 evacuated as Typhoon Parma nears

TEXT.P: More than 1,200 residents in mudslide-prone areas of four counties around the nation had been evacuated as of 1 p.m. Sunday amid the threat of Typhoon Parma, which was forecast to hit Taiwan after slamming into the Philippines the previous day.

"As of 1 p.m. Sunday, 1,241 residents in 10 townships and villages in four counties -- Nantou, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Pingtung -- had been evacuated over mudslide concerns, " the Central Emergency Operations Center said in a statement.

The evacuation was part of the government's efforts to avoid a repeat of the tragedy caused by Typhoon Morakot in early August, when the storm triggered massive flooding and devastating landslides in southern Taiwan that buried various mountain villages and left more than 700 people dead or missing.
According to the center, rainfall spawned by Typhoon Parma was concentrated in the mountains of northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County and the northern county of Taipei.

From Saturday midnight through 1 p.m. Sunday, 129.5 mm of precipitation had been recorded in Juifang, Taipei County, with 124.5 mm in Yilan's Tatung township and 112 m.m. in the county's Tungshan township, center officials said.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) originally predicted that Parma could bring up to 1,100 mm of rainfall to Taiwan's mountainous regions, but later lowered the forecast to 800 mm, with the mountains of northern and eastern Taiwan receiving the worst of it.
The bureau issued a land warning for Typhoon Parma for the Hengchun peninsula in southern Taiwan at 5:30 a.m. Sunday.
Since then, however, the storm had been swirling around in the Bashi Channel that separates Taiwan from the Philippines and its speed had slowed to 4 kph.

The CWB's typhoon report had not mentioned Parma's speed since 8: 30 a.m. that day, with all follow-up reports saying only that the typhoon was in the Bashi Channel and moving slowly on a west-northwesterly trajectory.

CWB meteorologists said it was difficult to predict whether Typhoon Parma would move east or west because several factors -- a high pressure system in South Asia, a cold front from the north, a high pressure system in the Pacific Ocean and another typhoon, Melor -- could affect its movement.

Noting that Typhoon Melor was moving fast from southeast of Taiwan in a west- northwesterly direction, the weathermen said Melor was likely to come closer than 1,500 km to Parma over the next two days.
By then, they said, a drag effect will appear between the two typhoons, although they added that it remained to be seen whether Melor would drag Parma northeast or southwest.
Lee Ching-sheng, a meteorology professor at National Taiwan University, echoed the CWB weathermen's views on Parma's unpredictability, saying many factors could affect its course.
Whatever course the typhoon takes, however, the government was determined to make every possible effort to minimize the chances of disaster.

It had been taking precautionary measures since Saturday, with President Ma Ying-jeou, Premier Wu Den-yih and other Cabinet members inspecting disaster prevention and response preparations in coastal and mountainous areas and the military assisting in evacuating mountain villagers.

Typhoon Morakot caused heavy human casualties and property damage in Taiwan and led to a major Cabinet reshuffle, with Wu replacing Liu Chao-shiuan as premier. Political analysts said Typhoon Parma will test the new Cabinet's competence and operational efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emergency Operations Center sets up help hotline

TEXT.P: The Central Emergency Operations Center, which was opened the previous day to brace for approaching Typhoon Parma, set up a hotline for emergency calls Sunday.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah, who serves as commander of the center, announced the six-line (02) 8196-6999 hotline to the press that same day.
However, he said members of the public who require help should first dial the regular 119 emergency call and use the center's hotline only when the 119 line is engaged or disconnected.
"We will relay the calls for help to the relevant local authorities, so calls for help might not be dealt with as fast as if people call 119 directly," said Jiang.

In order to avoid jamming the emergency lines, the minister suggested that the public report disasters to local borough or village chiefs, who will compile the information and relay it all together to the emergency centers operated by local governments.

The extra hotline was set up after people were reduced to calling local TV channels to report disasters during the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot in early August, complaining that the 119 line was always busy.
The image of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration was tarnished by these complaints, which was part of the reason for a Cabinet reshuffle in which former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan stepped down.

As of Sunday afternoon, Typhoon Parma was located 310 km south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanpi, moving slowly on a north-northwesterly trajectory, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military servicemen brace for post-storm relief operations

TEXT.P: More than 34,584 military servicemen around Taiwan and on several outlaying islands were ready to respond to calls for rescue and relief operations during the onslaught of Typhoon Parma, the Ministry of National Defense said Sunday.
In a press release, the ministry said it believed the deployments would meet any local government demand for help.
The forces were divided into five groups, with each of them responsible for an operational area under the command of an ad hoc Armed Forces Emergency Operations Center.
The center will keep abreast of the latest developments of the storm, and will order the servicemen to take action without waiting for approval from their superiors, according to the press release.

In anticipation of the approach of the typhoon, the ministry said it had canceled leave for some servicemen 36 hours before the Central Weather Bureau issued a land warning for southern Taiwan Sunday morning.
Noting that it has made rescue and relief operations one of its main priorities, the ministry said it will engage in the disaster relief operation as actively as it would in a battle situation.
The Defense Ministry was criticised for its slow response to local government calls for help in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, which ravaged parts of the south of the island in early August.
The poor response meant that former Defense Minister Chen Chao-min had to step down in an ensuing Cabinet reshuffle.
The armed forces efforts earned praise from Premier Wu Den-yih that day when he made an inspection tour of a military command in Taoyuan County.
The premier noted that the armed forces have a lot of personnel and fleets of excavators on standby and are ready to deploy them to diaster-prone areas as soon as possible.
"It will be a perfect anti-disaster drill even if Typhoon Parma doesn't prompt any disaster," he said.
"With the readiness of the people and the armed forces, I am certain that whatever havoc Typhoon Parma may wreak, it will not be as serious as that caused by Typhoon Morakot," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dog parade in Taipei to mark World Animal Day

TEXT.P: Braving windy and rainy weather, a dazzling dog parade took place in Taipei Sunday as part of celebrations to mark World Animal Day.
It was the first time that the Oct. 4 World Animal Day had been celebrated in Taiwan with such fanfare.
Although the approach of Typhoon Parma brought wind and rain to Taipei, many animal rights activists took part in the one-kilometer-long parade that ended in front of Taipei City Hall.
Many of the marchers were dogs decked out in colorful raincoats, head scalves and other decorations.
With a theme of opposing the abandoning of pets, gin traps and animal abuse, the parade was complemented by a trade fair, with about 60 booths selling pet foods and pet-care products.
Organizers said 20 percent of proceeds from the sales would be donated to animal protection groups in southern Taiwan that were hard-hit by Typhoon Morakot in early August.
Many animal protection and rescue groups as well as pet veterinaries and clinics and stray dog centers also put up booths at the site to promote their cause.

As the event was organized by Animals Taiwan, a protection and rescue group founded by British expatriates in Taiwan, many foreign residents took part in the event to throw their support for animal rights protection.
The World Animal Day was started in 1931 at a convention of ecologists in Florence, Italy as a way of highlighting the plight of endangered species.

It was also the feast day of Saint Francis of Assisi, a Catholic deacon and the founder of the Order of Friars Minor, more commonly known as the Franciscans. He is known as the patron saint of animals and the environment, and it is customary for Catholic churches to hold ceremonies honoring animals around his feast day of Oct.4.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidacy registration for year-end elections to start Monday

TEXT.P: Candidacy registration for the Dec.5 elections for new local government chiefs and members of local councils will start Monday.

All those who intend to run for mayoral or magisterial posts in most cities and counties around the country and for seats in city or county councils must register their candidacy before the Oct.9 deadline, according to a work schedule unveiled by the Central Election Commission Oct.1.

No elections will be held in Taipei County, Kaohsiung County, Taichung County, Taichung City, Tainan City and Tainan County as they will either be directly upgraded to the status of a special municipality or be mutually integrated into a special municipality next year.
New heads of these new special municipalities will be held simultaneously with heads of the two existing special municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- in late 2010.

Meanwhile, the tenure of the mayors and magistrates to be elected in December will be extended for one year and five days until late 2014 if a Cabinet-propsed amendment to the Law on Local Government Systems to that effect clears the legislative floor later this year.

The proposed tenure extention is aimed at streamlining local elections, CEC officials said, adding that the tenure extension will allow for simultaneous elections of future heads of all special municipalities as well as cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5.0-magnitude earthquake jolts Taiwan

TEXT.P: The temblor, centered at 24.7 km east by north to Suao, in eastern Taiwan county of Yilan, was caused by the movement of the Eurasian Plate against the Philippine Sea Plate, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
It is a natural release of strain and has nothing to do with a 6.3-magnitude tremor which shaken the island at 1:36 a.m. Sunday, the bureau said.
