1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
2001: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announces that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.
2001: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presents the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China government spokesman expresses welcome for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Weather bureau issues land warning for Typhoon Parma

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for the Hengchun peninsula in southern Taiwan Sunday as medium Typhoon Parma continued its approach to the country.

Parma, with winds gusting up to 162 kilometers per hour, was 340 km south of Oluanpi on the southernmost tip of Taiwan as of 5:30 a.m., moving in a north- northwesterly direction at 7 kph, the bureau said.
The typhoon slammed into the northern Philippines a day earlier, killing at least three people there, according to foreign wire service reports.
"Right now, Parma seems to be swirling in the Bashi Channel that separates Taiwan and the Philippines and its speed is likely to slow down to 4 kph," said Hsiao Chia-sen, a CWB forecaster.
Over the next two or three days, Hsiao went on, the typhoon may move slowly and hover around the Bashi Channel, but he added that further observation will be needed to predict its course after that.
He urged residents in the Hengchun area to take precautions against powerful wind and heavy downpours.
Residents in northern and eastern parts of Taiwan should also be on guard against torrential rain brought by the typhoon, Hsiao added.

The approaching typhoon comes less than two months after Typhoon Morakot, the worst storm to hit the island in half a century, killed more than 600 and led to a major Cabinet reshuffle due to lackluster government response in the initial stages.

DOC.HEADLINE: H1N1 vaccinations to be free: health official

TEXT.P: Local citizens will not be required to pay for vaccination against swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1), a health official said Sunday.

"The free-of-charge policy is aimed at encouraging people to receive inoculations as soon as possible once the vaccination program is launched next month, " said Chou Chih-hau, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health (DOH).
According to Chou, the DOH will offer NT$150 (US$4.63) per head in subsidies to local health care institutions that offer H1N1 vaccinations.
"The amount is enough to pay for registration fees and medical examination fees for each citizen who receives H1N1 inoculation at designated hospitals, clinics or health centers," Chou said.

As more than 10 million people will be involved in various kinds of vaccinations in the coming months, Chou said, the subsidy program for H1N1 vaccination is expected to help speed up completion of the program.

According to the DOH's plan, 5 million doses of H1N1 vaccine imported from Switzerland-based pharmaceutical firm Novartis will be available for high-risk individuals in late October, while 10 million doses to be supplied by local manufacturer Adimmune Corp. will be ready in early November.
As the two suppliers will deliver the doses in staggered shipments, the vaccines will be administered simultaneously.
The DOH-initiated priority list for H1N1 vaccination is led by typhoon-affected victims, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, and pregnant women.

They will be followed on the priority list by pre-school children, seriously ill patients, elementary, junior and senior high school students, individuals in the 19-24 age bracket and those over 25 at high risk of cardiopulmonary disease, healthy people in the 25-49 age bracket, and those aged between 50 and 64.

Meanwhile, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) reported Sunday that five more patients had been hospitalized for severe H1N1 symptoms in the previous 24 hours, bringing the total hospitalization cases to 319 since the outbreak began.
Of that number, 21 had died, 28 were still being treated in local hospitals, while the other 270 had been discharged after making complete recoveries.
The five newly hospitalized patients include one male and four females, aged between 4 and 42.
A CECC official said the center is keeping a close watch on the developments in the H1N1 situation in the wake of the Mid-Autumn Festival.

"The weather has been cooling off significantly in recent days and human interaction has increased over the Mid-Autumn Festival, so we are monitoring whether the two developments will have any impact on the H1N1 situation," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tremor does not predispose Taiwan to landslides: expert

TEXT.P: An earthquake that jolted Taiwan early Sunday has not predisposed the island to more landslides, even if Typhoon Parma hits the island in the next few days, an expert said later that day.

Yen Hong-yuan, a professor of earth science at Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County, said the precipitation brought by Parma to eastern Taiwan had not yet exceeded safety limits and was therefore unlikely to trigger landslides.
He said the 6.3-magnitude temblor 23 km southeast of Hualien at 1: 36 a.m. was "not abnormal."
"Although it is the second temblor with a magnitude over 6 this year, the number of earthquakes this year is within the normal range," he said.

Furthermore, Yen said, the precipitation caused by Typhoon Parma so far was less than one-third of the nearly 3,000 mm of rainfall brought by Typhoon Morakot and there were few slopes in eastern Taiwan predisposed to mudslides.
"The fear that soil softened up by the temblor is more likely to slide after sucking up water from rainfall is groundless, " Yen pointed out.

As Typhoon Morakot, which triggered widespread landslides and killed more than 600 people in early August, has rammed home the importance of evacuating people from mudslide-prone areas before torrential rain, Yen said he was confident that the Morakot tragedy will not be repeated.

Typhoon Parma was centered 310 km south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanpi as of Sunday afternoon, moving slowly on a north-northwesterly trajectory, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 1,200 evacuated as Typhoon Parma nears

TEXT.P: More than 1,200 residents in mudslide-prone areas of four counties around the nation had been evacuated as of 1 p.m. Sunday amid the threat of Typhoon Parma, which was forecast to hit Taiwan after slamming into the Philippines the previous day.

"As of 1 p.m. Sunday, 1,241 residents in 10 townships and villages in four counties -- Nantou, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Pingtung -- had been evacuated over mudslide concerns, " the Central Emergency Operations Center said in a statement.

The evacuation was part of the government's efforts to avoid a repeat of the tragedy caused by Typhoon Morakot in early August, when the storm triggered massive flooding and devastating landslides in southern Taiwan that buried various mountain villages and left more than 700 people dead or missing.
According to the center, rainfall spawned by Typhoon Parma was concentrated in the mountains of northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County and the northern county of Taipei.

From Saturday midnight through 1 p.m. Sunday, 129.5 mm of precipitation had been recorded in Juifang, Taipei County, with 124.5 mm in Yilan's Tatung township and 112 m.m. in the county's Tungshan township, center officials said.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) originally predicted that Parma could bring up to 1,100 mm of rainfall to Taiwan's mountainous regions, but later lowered the forecast to 800 mm, with the mountains of northern and eastern Taiwan receiving the worst of it.
The bureau issued a land warning for Typhoon Parma for the Hengchun peninsula in southern Taiwan at 5:30 a.m. Sunday.
Since then, however, the storm had been swirling around in the Bashi Channel that separates Taiwan from the Philippines and its speed had slowed to 4 kph.

The CWB's typhoon report had not mentioned Parma's speed since 8: 30 a.m. that day, with all follow-up reports saying only that the typhoon was in the Bashi Channel and moving slowly on a west-northwesterly trajectory.

CWB meteorologists said it was difficult to predict whether Typhoon Parma would move east or west because several factors -- a high pressure system in South Asia, a cold front from the north, a high pressure system in the Pacific Ocean and another typhoon, Melor -- could affect its movement.

Noting that Typhoon Melor was moving fast from southeast of Taiwan in a west- northwesterly direction, the weathermen said Melor was likely to come closer than 1,500 km to Parma over the next two days.
By then, they said, a drag effect will appear between the two typhoons, although they added that it remained to be seen whether Melor would drag Parma northeast or southwest.
Lee Ching-sheng, a meteorology professor at National Taiwan University, echoed the CWB weathermen's views on Parma's unpredictability, saying many factors could affect its course.
Whatever course the typhoon takes, however, the government was determined to make every possible effort to minimize the chances of disaster.

It had been taking precautionary measures since Saturday, with President Ma Ying-jeou, Premier Wu Den-yih and other Cabinet members inspecting disaster prevention and response preparations in coastal and mountainous areas and the military assisting in evacuating mountain villagers.

Typhoon Morakot caused heavy human casualties and property damage in Taiwan and led to a major Cabinet reshuffle, with Wu replacing Liu Chao-shiuan as premier. Political analysts said Typhoon Parma will test the new Cabinet's competence and operational efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emergency Operations Center sets up help hotline

TEXT.P: The Central Emergency Operations Center, which was opened the previous day to brace for approaching Typhoon Parma, set up a hotline for emergency calls Sunday.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah, who serves as commander of the center, announced the six-line (02) 8196-6999 hotline to the press that same day.
However, he said members of the public who require help should first dial the regular 119 emergency call and use the center's hotline only when the 119 line is engaged or disconnected.
"We will relay the calls for help to the relevant local authorities, so calls for help might not be dealt with as fast as if people call 119 directly," said Jiang.

In order to avoid jamming the emergency lines, the minister suggested that the public report disasters to local borough or village chiefs, who will compile the information and relay it all together to the emergency centers operated by local governments.

The extra hotline was set up after people were reduced to calling local TV channels to report disasters during the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot in early August, complaining that the 119 line was always busy.
The image of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration was tarnished by these complaints, which was part of the reason for a Cabinet reshuffle in which former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan stepped down.

As of Sunday afternoon, Typhoon Parma was located 310 km south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanpi, moving slowly on a north-northwesterly trajectory, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military servicemen brace for post-storm relief operations

TEXT.P: More than 34,584 military servicemen around Taiwan and on several outlaying islands were ready to respond to calls for rescue and relief operations during the onslaught of Typhoon Parma, the Ministry of National Defense said Sunday.
In a press release, the ministry said it believed the deployments would meet any local government demand for help.
The forces were divided into five groups, with each of them responsible for an operational area under the command of an ad hoc Armed Forces Emergency Operations Center.
The center will keep abreast of the latest developments of the storm, and will order the servicemen to take action without waiting for approval from their superiors, according to the press release.

In anticipation of the approach of the typhoon, the ministry said it had canceled leave for some servicemen 36 hours before the Central Weather Bureau issued a land warning for southern Taiwan Sunday morning.
Noting that it has made rescue and relief operations one of its main priorities, the ministry said it will engage in the disaster relief operation as actively as it would in a battle situation.
The Defense Ministry was criticised for its slow response to local government calls for help in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, which ravaged parts of the south of the island in early August.
The poor response meant that former Defense Minister Chen Chao-min had to step down in an ensuing Cabinet reshuffle.
The armed forces efforts earned praise from Premier Wu Den-yih that day when he made an inspection tour of a military command in Taoyuan County.
The premier noted that the armed forces have a lot of personnel and fleets of excavators on standby and are ready to deploy them to diaster-prone areas as soon as possible.
"It will be a perfect anti-disaster drill even if Typhoon Parma doesn't prompt any disaster," he said.
"With the readiness of the people and the armed forces, I am certain that whatever havoc Typhoon Parma may wreak, it will not be as serious as that caused by Typhoon Morakot," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dog parade in Taipei to mark World Animal Day

TEXT.P: Braving windy and rainy weather, a dazzling dog parade took place in Taipei Sunday as part of celebrations to mark World Animal Day.
It was the first time that the Oct. 4 World Animal Day had been celebrated in Taiwan with such fanfare.
Although the approach of Typhoon Parma brought wind and rain to Taipei, many animal rights activists took part in the one-kilometer-long parade that ended in front of Taipei City Hall.
Many of the marchers were dogs decked out in colorful raincoats, head scalves and other decorations.
With a theme of opposing the abandoning of pets, gin traps and animal abuse, the parade was complemented by a trade fair, with about 60 booths selling pet foods and pet-care products.
Organizers said 20 percent of proceeds from the sales would be donated to animal protection groups in southern Taiwan that were hard-hit by Typhoon Morakot in early August.
Many animal protection and rescue groups as well as pet veterinaries and clinics and stray dog centers also put up booths at the site to promote their cause.

As the event was organized by Animals Taiwan, a protection and rescue group founded by British expatriates in Taiwan, many foreign residents took part in the event to throw their support for animal rights protection.
The World Animal Day was started in 1931 at a convention of ecologists in Florence, Italy as a way of highlighting the plight of endangered species.

It was also the feast day of Saint Francis of Assisi, a Catholic deacon and the founder of the Order of Friars Minor, more commonly known as the Franciscans. He is known as the patron saint of animals and the environment, and it is customary for Catholic churches to hold ceremonies honoring animals around his feast day of Oct.4.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidacy registration for year-end elections to start Monday

TEXT.P: Candidacy registration for the Dec.5 elections for new local government chiefs and members of local councils will start Monday.

All those who intend to run for mayoral or magisterial posts in most cities and counties around the country and for seats in city or county councils must register their candidacy before the Oct.9 deadline, according to a work schedule unveiled by the Central Election Commission Oct.1.

No elections will be held in Taipei County, Kaohsiung County, Taichung County, Taichung City, Tainan City and Tainan County as they will either be directly upgraded to the status of a special municipality or be mutually integrated into a special municipality next year.
New heads of these new special municipalities will be held simultaneously with heads of the two existing special municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- in late 2010.

Meanwhile, the tenure of the mayors and magistrates to be elected in December will be extended for one year and five days until late 2014 if a Cabinet-propsed amendment to the Law on Local Government Systems to that effect clears the legislative floor later this year.

The proposed tenure extention is aimed at streamlining local elections, CEC officials said, adding that the tenure extension will allow for simultaneous elections of future heads of all special municipalities as well as cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5.0-magnitude earthquake jolts Taiwan

TEXT.P: The temblor, centered at 24.7 km east by north to Suao, in eastern Taiwan county of Yilan, was caused by the movement of the Eurasian Plate against the Philippine Sea Plate, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
It is a natural release of strain and has nothing to do with a 6.3-magnitude tremor which shaken the island at 1:36 a.m. Sunday, the bureau said.

The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 5, or the 17th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Hunan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch an eight-day series of camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
2000: Hung Chien-hsiung, a 27-year-old man, donates 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that is the only way to save the older man's life.
2001: Gao Xingjian, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 2000 -- the first Chinese writer to win the prestigious award, shows his other talent by opening an exhibition of his paintings in Taipei.
2001: Republic of China Presdient Chen Shui-bian receives visiting U.S. economist Lester Thurow, exchanging views with him on the economic problems faced by Taiwan and the rest of the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."

U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.272 at 9:45 a.m. Monday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.078 from Friday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Monday, moving up 12.36 points at 7,424.24 on a turnover of NT$2.19 billion (US$68 million).
The weighted price index lost 133.41 points, or 1.76 percent, to close at 7,411.88 last Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Land typhoon warning expected to be lifted soon

TEXT.P: The land warning in southern Taiwan against Typhoon Parma could be lifted later Monday as the system has weakened and was downgraded to a tropical storm earlier in the day, the Central Weather Bureau said.

Parma has weakened significantly since it swept through the Philippines late last week and it continued to lose strength over the weekend, with maximum winds near the center dropping to 101 kilometers per hour, according to weather forecasters.
The CWB said that as Parma is also getting smaller in terms of the radius of its typhoon-force winds, the land warning issued for Taiwan's southernmost Hengchun Peninsular could be lifted soon.
As of noon Monday, Parma was located at 250 kilometers southwest of Eluanbi on Taiwan's southern tip, the CWB said.

Forecasters warned that Parma is expected to linger southwest of Taiwan for one or two days, and that its outer bands, coupled with the prevailing northeasterly monsoon in the region, could continue to bring heavy rains in eastern and northern Taiwan.

People in mountainous areas should guard against landslides and falling rocks that could be triggered by heavy rains, while those in low-lying areas should be on the alert against floods, the CWB said.

Although Parma has not made landfall on Taiwan, the island has experienced heavy rains in the last two days. Sansing in Yilan, eastern Taiwan has borne the brunt, having been drenched with 700 mm of rain in the last 36 hours.
Governments at various levels in Taiwan have been put on high alert as the island has not yet fully recovered from the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot on Aug. 8.
Typhoon Morakot, which brought precipitation of nearly 3,000 mm in a couple of days, wreaked havoc on southern Taiwan, taking 600 lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government plans to set up disaster prevention administration

TEXT.P: The government is planning to set up a Cabinet-level disaster prevention and relief administration to integrate and streamline its disaster relief mechanism, the Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Monday.
The administration will focus on improving disaster response and speeding up recovery in disaster areas, Jiang told the Legislative Yuan.

Regarding the government's reconstruction work in the wake of Typhoon Morakot's destruction in August, Jiang said the Cabinet will launch four programs under the broad headings of regional planning, infrastructure repair, home rehabilitation, and industrial reconstruction.

The regional planning program will include soil conservation and watershed management, while the infrastructure aspect will cover the repair and rebuilding of roads, bridges and tunnels, he said. Under the home rehabilitation program, people will receive assistance to rebuild their homes, and the industrial reconstruction program will provide relief loans and other forms of assistance to industries, he added.

Speaking on the disbursement of relief funds since the Typhoon Morakot disaster, Jiang said that as of Oct. 1, some 99.84 percent of the subsidies for death, injury or missing relatives had been distributed, while 85.94 percent of the funds for housing damage and 89.8 percent of that for flood damage had been disbursed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 6,600 evacuated as Typhoon Parma approaches

TEXT.P: More than 6,600 residents in mudslide-prone areas of six counties around the country had been evacuated as of 8 a.m. Monday as Typhoon Parma lingered southwest of Taiwan, the Central Emergency Operations Center said Monday.

In order to protect people's lives and safety, the government will issue compulsory evacuation orders in danger zones, and will not accept written statements of self-responsibility from residents who choose not to move, said Premier Wu Den-yih while responding to media questions at the Legislative Yuan Monday.

A local newspaper reported Monday that some villagers in Pingtung County wanted to sign written statements that they had chosen not to leave and would be responsible for their own safety. But the local authorities refused their requests and forced them to evacuate the area, according to the report.

The evacuation order was part of the government's efforts to avoid a repeat of the tragedy caused by Typhoon Morakot in early August when the storm triggered massive flooding and devastating landslides in southern Taiwan, burying mountain villages and leaving more than 700 people dead or missing.

According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , rainfall from Typhoon Parma was concentrated in the mountains of northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County. As of midday Monday, six areas in Yilan County had recorded the highest levels of precipitation in the country.
The county's Tungshan's township was drenched with 114 mm of rain in one hour, from 11 a.m. to noon Monday, the CWB said.

In addition, the Council of Agriculture (COA) on Monday updated the number of rivers on its red alert list for mudflows. The 28 rivers on the list are all located in 14 villages and townships in Yilan county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese donation could be used for bridge reconstruction: premier

TEXT.P: Some of the donations from China for relief aid in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot will probably be used in the reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge, which was destroyed by massive flooding triggered by the typhoon, Premier Wu Den-yih said Monday.
Wu made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to questions by lawmakers after reporting on a planned special government budget for post- typhoon reconstruction.

Legislator Pan Meng-an of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party questioned the premier about China's promise of NT$5.1 billion (US$158.14 million) to support relief aid and restoration in Morakot-affected areas of southern Taiwan.
Pan had questioned the actual amount that had been received, pointing out that there had been discrepancies as to how much had in fact arrived.

Wu told the lawmaker that the government has so far received only some NT$900 million of China's promised donation and that it hopes the rest of the funds can be allocated to major post-Morakot reconstruction projects.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, along with other relevant authorities, is studying a plan to spend the Chinese funds on the reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge over the Gaoping River, which connected Kaohsiung County's Linyuan township and Sinyuan township of Pingtung County until it collapsed Aug. 9, Wu said.
It has been assessed that the reconstruction will cost over NT$3 billion, including the cost of building a temporary bridge until the 2.8-km bridge is rebuilt, according to the Executive Yuan.
The bridge reconstruction project is scheduled to begin February 2010 and to be completed by December 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Women's labor force participation rate on rise: CEPD

TEXT.P: The domestic women's labor force participation rate has been rising steadily in recent years and is expected to exceed 50 percent for the first time next year, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.

As the number of jobs in the labor market has not increased substantially, CEPD officials said, rising women's labor participation rate could squeeze men's employment opportunities, with men aged over 40 being most vulnerable.
The labor force participation rate is the percentage of working-age persons -- those aged 16-64 -- in an economy who are employed or are unemployed but looking for a job.
According to CEPD statistics, men's labor participation rate has shown a downward trend in the past seven years, falling from 68.22 percent in 2002 to 67 percent in 2008.

In contrast, women's labor participation rate has been on the upswing. In the past, the rate tended to hover around 46 percent as many local women could not seek work outside the home because of household and child rearing responsibilities.
However, the situation has changed since 2002 when the women's labor participation rate began its uninterrupted upward streak, rising from 46.59 percent that year to 49.67 percent in 2008.
Globally, women generally lag behind men in terms of labor force participation, CEPD officials said.

However, except for Taiwan, women's labor participation rates in most advanced economies tend to be over 50 percent. In the United States and many European countries, the rate is higher than 70 percent. In 2008, Japan's women's labor participation rate reached 67 percent and South Korea's 59 percent,
According to the officials, marriage has been one of the most important factors affecting local women's labor participation.

CEPD statistics show that labor participation rates are almost the same among unmarried males and females, approaching 60 percent in both categories. But the rate tends to fall below 50 percent for married women, the figures show.
In 2008, single women's labor participation rate was 9 percentage points higher than that of married women, according to CEPD tallies.
But over the past seven years, the married women's labor participation rate has risen by more than 3 percent due to a combination of factors, CEPD officials said.
One of the factors might be related to the fact that married women have been forced to enter the job market because their husbands are earning less than before.
Another factor might be the influx of single young women into the job market, the official said, adding that higher levels of education among women has made it easier for them to land jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise on local bourse

TEXT.P: Led by gains in construction shares amid a strong local currency, Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 26.1 points, or 0.35 percent, to close at the day's high of 7,437.98.

Despite losses on Wall Street last Friday and weak showings in stock markets in Asia, the local bourse opened slightly higher at 7,424.24 and dropped to the day's low of 7,381.02 before closing at the day's high.
A total of 3.27 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.78 billion (US$2.94 billion) , down from NT$116.04 billion the previous trading day.
Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.42 percent.

Plastics and chemicals issues rose 1.31 percent, textile shares advanced 0.91 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 0.66 percent, banking and financial shares were up 0.45 percent, machinery and electronics stocks advanced 0.24 percent, and food stuff shares added 0.01 percent.
Only one of the major stock categories -- cement shares -- dropped 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,167 to 1,162, with 216 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$10.24 billion-worth of shares for the day, compared with NT$13.13 billion the previous trading day.
They had bought a net NT$144.2 billion in shares in September, helping drive up the Taiex by more than 10 percent for the month.
One analyst said that with the market volume continuing to shrink as the Taiex hovers around the monthly moving average of 7,380, the market is likely to fluctuate between 7,200 and 7,600.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: Driven down by exporters and foreign bank's selling, the U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.095 to close at NT$32.255.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.35 before reaching a low of NT$32.242 following the intervention of Taiwan's central bank.
A total of US$1.00 billion changed hands during the day's trading, down from the previous day's US$1.35 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel Prize-winning Japanese writer arrives for first visit

TEXT.P: Kenzaburo Oe, the renowned Japanese writer who won the 1994 Nobel Prize for Literature for creating "an imagined world where life and myth condense to form a disconcerting picture of the human predicament today, " arrived in Taiwan Monday for his first-ever visit to the country.
Oe is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the Institute of Chinese Literature and Philosophy (ICLP) under Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's most prestigious academic institution.
In addition to attending a symposium on his literature scheduled for Oct. 6-7, Oe will also give lectures and autograph copies of his books for local readers.
Oe, 74, has been described as "Japan's social conscience" for his resolute opposition to Japanese militarism and the deep sense of critical self- examination that pervades his work.

"Oe has condemned Japan's invasion of other Asian countries for many years now, and regards his trip to Taiwan as a journey of atonement for Japan's past atrocities, " said Peng Hsiao-yen, an ICLP research fellow.

According to Peng, Oe has visited China seven times, where he has been heartily received. During one of his visits there, he conveyed his wish to visit Taiwan to Xu Jinlong, a research fellow at the Beijing-based Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.

"This eventually led the ICLP and the Chinese academy to cooperate in organizing the Oct. 6-7 symposium in Taipei that will review Oe's literature from an international perspective," Peng said, adding that Oe's visit also represents his wish for a cross-Taiwan Strait academic exchange focusing on his work.

The symposium will open with a speech by Oe, to be titled "Late Work, " an allusion to the work by late Palestinian American cultural giant Edward Said, one of his literary bosom friends, Peng said, adding that in the speech, Oe will relate what he hopes to do for Asian society in the remainder of his life.

A total of 13 papers will be presented at the seminar, with topics ranging from Oe's literary imagination, the influence of Chinese writer Lu Xun on his work, the position of music in his work and his leftist ideas, according to Peng.

The ICLP will also organize an exhibition of Oe's literature, dubbed "From Shikoku Forest to the World, " which will be accompanied by musical works produced by his brain-damaged son and literary muse, Hikari.
The Oct. 6-9 exhibition will display Oe's literary works, manuscripts and 40 photos featuring his acceptance of the Nobel Prize and other relevant activities, as well as paintings by his wife.

Oe was born in a forest-hemmed village in Ehirne Prefecture on the island of Shikoku. In his Nobel Prize acceptance speech, he described himself as "a son of forests, " as forests have been a limitless source of his literary inspiration.

During his childhood, Oe lived through World War II, an experience that left a deep life-long imprint on his writings. The ferocity of war, post-war trauma and the melancholia of death infuse his early works, which are heavily influenced by Western modernism, according to Peng.
"As an author, Oe has been engaged in various social and political issues from an anti-war, humanitarian and liberal perspective," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday:
Liberty Times:
Anti-storm measures should not be taken as political show
We are glad that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is taking unprecedented drastic measures to brace for the attacks of Typhoon Parma.
As extreme weather conditions are becoming more of a rule than an exception, anti-disaster measures should be considered a routine practice by the government.
However, we are worried that the country's politicians from President Ma on down are putting on a show to get public praise rather than to avoid the disaster.
Our concerns were stoked by Premier Wu Den-yih's claims that his administration would prefer to let the public take an unnecessary day off for the typhoon rather than risk their lives to go to work.

Whether the day should be taken off during a typhoon is a question which can be easily determined according to the weather conditions, and an unnecessary holiday might cost the country NT$2 billion worth of production.
United Daily News:
KMT's problem is not factionism, but the nature of factions.
The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lost lawmaker by-elections in Miaoli and Yulin counties in tandem, and was defeated in a referendum on whether to allow gambling in Penghu County.

Political pundits have blamed factionism within the party for its defeats and they seem to be right, as local factions in many other counties are threatening the party's chances for success in their areas in the year-end elections of local government chiefs.

But factionism is not endemic to the KMT, as the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is also rife with factions. But unlike the DPP factions, the KMT factions are more interested in snapping up benefits than pursuing the party's goals.
In order to win elections with local faction support, the party authorities have to distribute benefits evenly among them.
The party lost its control of these factions when it could not meet their greed for benefits.
This problem may not be solved in the near future, but the KMT will not be able to thrive if it does not address the issue.
China Times:
Chinese parade is not what we should be worried about, censorship
is

A spokesman for the Democratic Progressive Party criticized several local TV channels for broadcasting the whole process of China's National Day military parade in Beijing, claiming that it hurt local people's feelings, national security and constitutes a violation of the law.
The Government Information Office promised to look into this and to mete out punishment if any run-ins with the law were found.
We have to congratulate the DPP for its eventual learning of censorship from its arch rival Chiang Kai-shek and its eventual forsaking of its founders' cause of pushing for press freedom.
Chiang would laugh in his tomb for having the DPP as his followers.

However, we have to urge the Government Information Office, and President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to pause and think. Is this a political taboo that a government which claims to be a follower of liberalism dare to break?
Don't dismiss the punishment to be meted out by the Government Information Office as a little wrong step, it will become the beginning of a huge setback for the country's freedom and democracy.

The opposition is willing to betray its cause and to debase itself, but the ruling party should resist the temptation of abusing power and ignore the sirens of nationalism. It should not forsake the country's hard-earned press freedom and plunge the nation into the abyss of dictatorship.
China's military parade is a public event before the eyes of people around the world. Anyone who is interested in it may watch it via the Internet.
By the same token, any local TV channel which considers it news-worth may broadcast it.
We are not alarmed by TV broadcasts of China's military parade, but we will be alarmed if the government punishes these channels because it means the revival of censorship. Apple Daily:
Government's incompetence will result in problems for the elderly
The government's latest statistics show that the average life expectancy in Taiwan is 76 for men and 82 for women.
Those figures mean that there will be an average of 6.4 years for every man and 8.2 years for every woman when they will need caretakers.
The cost of taking care of the elderly will be a heavy financial burden both on their family members and society as a whole.
Unfortunately, we have not seen any attempts on the part of current government to come to grips with this looming problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panamanian ship's captain, 2 crew member rescued

TEXT.P: The captain and two crew members of a Panama-registered cargo ship that sank off Taiwan's outlying Penghu Island group were rescued one day later by marine search and rescue personnel from Taiwan and China, but 11 other crew members remained missing, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said Monday.
The 1,375-ton Silver Sea sank some 86 nautical miles southwest of Penghu archipelago Sunday afternoon, while transporting 53 containers from Taiwan to the Philippines.
It departed the Kaohsiung port for Manila around noon Saturday.

The bureau said it received calls for help from the ship at 5: 25 p.m. Sunday and immediately asked the search command center under the Executive Yuan to launch rescue operations on the sea and from the air.

The center swiftly dispatched military rescue helicopters to the area, while rescue helicopters and two patrol boats were also sent by the Ministry of the Interior and the Coast Guard Administration to the scene, the bureau said.

The ship's captain, who is from Myanmar, was rescued by a Chinese ship around 9 a.m. Monday, while two crew members from Indonesia were saved by Taiwan's vessels and were sent to a hospital in Chiayi County later Monday.

The Chinese vessel went to the scene after learning of the accident. Taiwan also sent rescue ships to the area where the ship sank, which is close to the imaginary middle line separating Taiwan and China in the Taiwan Strait. A Hong Kong cargo ship also sailed to the spot to help with rescues.
As of 5: 00 p. m. Monday, the remaining 11 crew members were still missing.

Although several rescue helicopters were sent to search for the victims, pilots only saw some containers, the wreckage of the ship and an empty life-saving boat floating on the sea, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau added.
Meanwhile, the Tsoying marine base in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, has sent several ships to the area to continue searching for survivors, the center noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly encouraged to get vaccinated against flu, pneumonia

TEXT.P: Senior citizens aged 75 and over were advised Monday to get vaccinated against seasonal influenza and streptococcus pneumonia -- a frequent killer of the elderly -- with the approach of the flu season.

Lin Hung-chuan, a specialist in lung disease and diseases of the immune system at Chang-Gung Memorial Hospital (CGMH) issued the advice after a national inoculation program against seasonal flu began Oct. 1.
The elderly are also entitled to free pneumonia inoculations, offered by the Wang Chan-yang social welfare and charity foundation run by the Formosa Plastics Group, which owns CGMH.
Lin said both the flu and the streptococcus vaccines are safe to take together.
Lin said that while seasonal flu is not particularly dangerous in itself, it can cause complications such as pneumonia, which can be fatal.
Streptococcus pneumonia is the most frequently seen pneumonia killer, Lin continued, pointing out that the fatality rate among the elderly infected by the virulent bacteria is 42.5 percent.
Moreover, the chance of being attacked by the bacteria again is five times higher than that of contracting the disease for the first time, he said.

It was streptococcus pneumonia that prompted the late founder of the Formosa Plastics Group, Wang Yung-ching, to donate 578,000 doses of streptococcus pneumonia vaccine in 2007 for people over 75 after he caught the disease but recovered, according to Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director- General Chou Chih-hao.

The free vaccination was designed to be carried out over three years starting from 2007, and there are still about 40,000 doses left for this year, Chou said, revealing that Wang's foundation has also donated another 57,000 doses to increase the stock for this year.

According to CDC statistics, Taiwan has a population of 1.01 million people aged 75 and over, 470,000 of whom have not yet been inoculated with the pneumonia vaccine, which offers protection for five years.

Meanwhile, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) reported that day that one more patient, aged 12, had been hospitalized with severe influenza A(H1N1) symptoms in the previous 24 hours, bringing the total hospitalization cases to 320 since the outbreak began.
Of that number, 21 had died, 28 were still being treated in local hospitals, while the other 270 had been discharged after making complete recoveries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan forex reserves rise to new high

TEXT.P: Taiwan was holding US$332.24 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of the end of September, a record high amount that was US$6.82 billion more than the August figure, the Central Bank of the Republic of China reported Monday.

Lin Sun-yuan, director-general of the bank's Department of Foreign Exchange, attributed the increase to earnings from foreign exchange reserve investments, as well as the strong appreciation of major currencies that it held, such as the euro and Japanese yen, against the U.S. dollar.
Taiwan was still ranked as the world's fourth-largest holder of forex reserves, after China, Japan and Russia and ahead of India, in September.

China held US$2.13 trillion in forex reserves as of the end of June, increasing some US$177.9 billion over that posted in March, Lin said. Japan had US$995.7 billion as of the end of August, up US$3.8 billion over that posted in July.
Russia, the world's third-largest forex reserve holder, had US$367.5 billion as of the end of August, up by US$15.2 billion from July.
India, meanwhile, had US$263.5 billion in forex reserves as of September 25, up US$3 billion from August.
South Korea's forex reserves as of September is not yet available. It held US$240.9 billion at the end of August, up US$4.4 billion from July.

Besides Taiwan and South Korea, the other two of "Asia's dragons" - Singapore and Hong Kong - Singapore had US$176.6 billion in forex reserves at the end of August, up US$1.5 billion from July. Hong Kong held US$218.2 billion in foreign reserves, up US$8.7 billion from July.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Oct. 5

TEXT.P: Taiwan: MOEA 12. Chinese donations will not be used to reconstruct bridge

DOC.HEADLINE: Everything to be bigger for visiting NBA athletes

TEXT.P: National Basketball Association (NBA) players in Taiwan to play in an exhibition game Oct. 8 will be treated to super-sized services, such as enlarged beds and steaks more than double the standard size during their three-day stay.

The Denver Nuggets and Indiana Pacers will play the first ever NBA game in Taiwan on Thursday, and Crystal Liu, marketing and public relations manager at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel where the NBA players will stay, said the hotel is ready for their arrival Oct. 6.

It has prepared 270 "special" rooms for the group of over 300 NBA players, family members, executives and staffers coming to Taiwan, with each room being equipped with 170-centimeter bathrobes (instead of the standard 120 cm) , 30.5 cm slippers, 183 cm bath towels and 2.43-meter-long beds, Liu said.

The room service menu will also offer expanded portions, with the standard 200-gram steak becoming 500 gms. and the standard bowl of beef noodles doubling in size. Gigantic U.S.-styled hamburgers and mountains of fresh fruit will also be available, Liu said.
Taipei will become the eighth Asian city to host either an NBA regular season or exhibition game, following Tokyo, Yokohama, and Saitama in Japan, Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou in China, and Macau.
After the Pacers and Nuggets play their exhibition game on Oct. 8, they will fly directly to Beijing for another exhibition in the Chinese capital's Wukesong Arena on Oct. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rebuilding of major southern bridge not to rely on Chinese funds

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih ruled out the possibility Monday of using China-donated funds to rebuild a major bridge in southern Taiwan that was destroyed during the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot in early August.

"We have politely rejected the proposal of using Chinese donations to finance reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge over the Gaoping River, " Wu said at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting Monday afternoon.

He was responding to a question from opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Huang Wei-cher on how China's pledge of NT$5.1 billion in funds for post-typhoon rehabilitation will be used.
Wu said the government has so far received only about NT$900 million (US$27.86 million) of the amount promised by Beijing.
"China intends to have the remaining funds used to finance selected infrastructure reconstruction projects, with the names of Chinese donors engraved on them," Wu said.

After China's Sichuan province was rattled by a devastating earthquake in May 2008, Taiwanese companies donated funds for the reconstruction of certain major infrastructure projects, and China wants to follow that example, Wu said.

In response to a question from DPP Legislator Pan Men-an, Wu had suggested in the morning session of the committee hearing that funds from China might be used to finance reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge, which connected Kaohsiung County's Linyuan township and Pingtung County's Sinyuan township until it collapsed Aug. 9.
In the afternoon session, however, Wu ruled out that possibility.
"After a careful assessment, we think it is inappropriate to have the bridge financed with Chinese funds, " Wu said, without further explanation.
The Executive Yuan will consider allocating Chinese donations to other projects and will exercise prudence in selecting the most suitable ones, Wu added.

The Shuangyuan Bridge reconstruction project will cost an estimated NT$3 billion, including the cost of building a temporary bridge until the 2.8 km bridge is rebuilt, according to an Executive Yuan assessment.
The project is scheduled to begin in February 2010 and be completed by December 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flat panel, chip fab China policy to be decided by year's end

TEXT.P: The government will decide by the end of the year whether local flat panel and chip manufacturers can invest in facilities or buy stakes in other companies in China, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday.
"Relevant government agencies will conduct a cross-ministerial meeting on the issue later this year to set a clear course for the future development of the two local sectors," MOEA officials said.

Apart from the key condition that it must be beneficial to Taiwan's people, a clear policy that helps the two local industries get a foothold in China's market without leading to the hollowing out of Taiwan will be adopted by the end of this year, they said.

Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang said at the end of September that companies in the two sectors would be allowed to invest in China to help them secure China's market and prevent it from looking toward partners from other countries such as South Korea to acquire related technologies.
At present, Taiwanese chipmakers are limited to investing in plants in China that use the older 8-inch wafer technology.

A local newspaper reported on Monday that workers at some flat panel and chip companies headquartered in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park are worried about losing their jobs if their employers were allowed to invest in advanced technology processes in China.

In response to the report, the Industrial Development Bureau made it clear Monday that the policy will fully heed public concern that such relations with China must not affect the interests of Taiwan's people.

Even if high-tech companies are permitted to invest in China on a case-by-case basis, government policy will still take into consideration the Wassenaar Agreement to mitigate adverse effects on Taiwanese enterprises, bureau officials said.
The agreement is signed by some 40 countries to prevent exports of sensitive technology with potential military uses to certain countries, including China, North Korea and Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's Palace Museum director arrives for joint exhibition

TEXT.P: The director of China's Palace Museum, Zheng Xinmiao, arrived in Taiwan Monday to attend a press conference for an upcoming joint exhibition with Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM).

Zheng will take part in the press conference together with his Taiwanese counterpart, Chou Kung-shin, and the two are expected to reveal the concrete results of exchanges between the two museums over the past six months and their planned exchanges next year.

The exchanges between the two state-run museums began formally in February when Chou made an "ice-breaking" visit to the Palace Museum in Beijing, the first time the heads of the two museums had ever met.

The visit concretized their cooperation in putting together an exhibition on the Yongzheng Emperor -- the fourth emperor of the Qing dynasty -- scheduled to open at the National Palace Museum on Oct. 7.

The Palace Museum in Beijing loaned 37 pieces from its collection on the Chinese emperor while the Shanghai Museum contributed two others to the exhibition titled "Harmony and Integrity: The Yongzheng Emperor and His Times."
In all, 246 pieces from the Yongzheng period of 1722-1735 will be featured in the exhibition, which runs until Jan 10, 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government will mark, not cerebrate Double Tenth Day

TEXT.P: The government will mark Double Ten Day Friday but will not cerebrate the Republic of China's founding anniversary as it has in the past, the spokesman of the Presidential Office said Monday.

Wang Yu-chi said President Ma Ying-jeou will preside over a ceremony for the country's national day at the Presidential Office, with the heads of the five branches of government and Cabinet members attending.
Ma will also deliver a major speech, which he is now working on, Wang added.

After nearly 700 citizens lost their lives during Typhoon Morakot in early August, President Ma and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who serves as the chairman of the organizing committee for the Double Ten celebration, decided that the festivities normally held for the founding anniversary would be canceled.
The money saved would instead be used for post-disaster reconstruction, according to the consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cost-of-living indexes down in September

TEXT.P: The government's statistical agency unveiled cost-of-living indexes for the first time Monday in line with Premier Wu Den-yih's pledge to make economic indicators more relevant to the everyday lives of ordinary people.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) prepared three cost-of-living indexes to more precisely reflect the fluctuation of prices for goods and services in three categories.

The first cost-of-living index was figured out mainly based on the costs of food, fuel and electricity while the second index covers a basket of 244 items, including food, education and entertainment, such as travel, extra schooling fees and electronic products and computers.
The third index covers 239 items, including food and other daily necessities, such as clothing, toilet paper and shampoo.
According to the DGBAS tallies, September's first cost-of-living index stood at 113.97, down 1.23 percent from the month-earlier level.
The second cost-of-living index stood at 109.26 in September, falling 1.14 percent from the August level, while the third cost-of-living index stood at 110.36, down 1.11 percent from August.

"Compared with the traditional consumer price index (CPI) , all three cost-of- living indexes registered bigger falls than the CPI, " said Wu Chao-ming, a DGBAS section chief in charge of calculating and monitoring consumer price fluctuations.
The CPI stood at 105.49 in September, down only 0.65 percent from August, Wu said.

The larger drops in the three cost-of-living indexes mainly resulted from substantial declines in vegetable, egg and electricity prices during the period, down 12.54 percent, 5.64 percent and 11.62 percent, respectively.
"These three items account for a larger weight in the first cost-of-living index than in the CPI, thus resulting in a larger decline in the cost-of-living index," Wu explained.
In preparing the CPI index, Wu said, the agency covers 424 items.

"With a view to make the index better reflect the average person's feelings and their everyday lives, the first cost-of-living index selected only 190 items from those gauged in the CPI, with food prices accounting for 80 percent of the index," Wu elaborated.
The first index also includes the costs of natural gas and electricity as well as fuel costs, Wu said.
The second cost-of-living index covers 244 items -- the 190 items calculated in the first index plus 54 others in the education and entertainment categories.
Meanwhile, Wu said the consumer price index dropped 0.86 percent in September from the year-earlier level. It marked the eighth consecutive monthly decline since Feburary.
The price decline was slightly larger than August's 0.8 percent, but Wu said the figure did not signal any risk of further economic contraction as the economic recession has gradually bottomed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Push made to lure investment from China-based Taiwanese firms

TEXT.P: The government intends to lure more investment from Taiwanese firms based in China by touting six new star industries, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Monday.

Yu Chi-cheng, deputy director of the MOEA's Department of Industrial Services, touted the benefits of investing in Taiwan at a gathering of China-based Taiwanese businessmen in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City to celebrate the Mid- Autumn Festival.

Yu was trying to solicit investment in six star industries that Taiwan's government has pushed aggressively as future growth engines -- specialty agriculture, green energy, health care, tourism, cultural innovation and biotechnology,

Among the 200 attendees were Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and over 100 representatives of Taiwanese businessmen's associations in China.
At the gathering, Yu also noted that total investment in Taiwan by local businessmen operating in China had already beat the target set by the MOEA for 2009.

The amount of capital injected by overseas Taiwan businessmen into the domestic market between September 2006 and September this year totaled NT$71.7 billion (US$2.26 billion), with NT$67.4 billion in 245 projects invested by those with operations in China, Yu said.
The balance of the investment was made by Taiwanese businessmen in the United States, Canada and Southeast Asian countries.

China-based Taiwanese businessmen launched 110 investment projects in Taiwan worth a total of NT$18.6 billion in 2008, and another 79 projects worth NT$35 billion in the first nine months of 2009, MOEA statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to act on 'fat cat' CEOs: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih demanded Monday that government agencies act swiftly against so-called fat cat CEOs in affiliated organizations or foundations, especially those who are earning two monthly salaries.

Wu was responding to questions during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, during which ruling Kuomintang lawmaker Lin Teh-fu said these overpaid executives had triggered negative sentiment among the public.

"Some retired government officials now hired in government-run spin-offs or nonprofit organizations not only are earning two salaries every month -- one from their previous post in the government and one from their current job -- but also enjoy a high interest rate of 18 percent on their bank deposits," Lin said.
"That has provoked strong criticism from society."

Wu promised to fully weed out all such personnel in government-affiliated enterprises and organizations based on relevant laws and regulations. "But we cannot recklessly attack people, because there will be trouble if we're wrong," he stressed.
It was reported that the Ministry of Economics Affairs has the largest number of such enterprises or nonprofit organizations under its jurisdiction.
Some of the top executives in these businesses get two salaries totaling over NT$300,000 (US$9,300) per month -- more than a government minister makes, the report said.

Liu Ming-chung, director of the MOEA's Commission of National Corporations, dismissed the report, however, and said that monthly salaries for ranking CEOs and full-time advisers at 15 MOEA-affiliated businesses are set at NT$80,000 or lower, in line with regulations which were already revised in July.
"All of them get only one salary from their present posts, and no one continues receiving another salary from their previous posts in the government," he explained.
"All newly employed CEOs and advisers will be compensated in compliance with the new regulations."
According to Liu, the MOEA runs 35 such companies and organizations such as Taiwan Power Company, Aerospace Industrial Development Corp and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (Taiwan).
The ministry currently hires 89 part-time and full-time advisers at these businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red Cross Society donates US$200,000 for Indonesian quake relief

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China announced Monday that it will donate US$200,000 to Indonesia for rescue and relief efforts there following a powerful earthquake.

Chen Shih-kuei, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society, said that 535 people were killed and another 2,400 injured in a magnitude 7.6 temblor that struck the Indonesian island of Sumatra Sept. 30.
It is believed that around 3,000 to 4,000 people are still trapped in buildings that collapsed in the quake.
Chen urged the public to donate money for the Indonesian mission through his or other organizations to show their support for international humanitarian aid efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government plans to set up disaster prevention administration

TEXT.P: The government is planning to set up a Cabinet-level disaster prevention and relief administration to integrate and streamline its disaster relief mechanism, the Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Monday.
The administration will focus on improving disaster response and speeding up recovery in disaster areas, Jiang told the Legislative Yuan.

Regarding the government's reconstruction work in the wake of Typhoon Morakot's destruction in August, Jiang said the Cabinet will launch four programs under the broad headings of regional planning, infrastructure repair, home rehabilitation, and industrial reconstruction.

The regional planning program will include soil conservation and watershed management, while the infrastructure aspect will cover the repair and rebuilding of roads, bridges and tunnels, he said. Under the home rehabilitation program, people will receive assistance to rebuild their homes, and the industrial reconstruction program will provide relief loans and other forms of assistance to industries, he added.

Speaking on the disbursement of relief funds since the Typhoon Morakot disaster, Jiang said that as of Oct. 1, some 99.84 percent of the subsidies for death, injury or missing relatives had been distributed, while 85.94 percent of the funds for housing damage and 89.8 percent of that for flood damage had been disbursed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 6,600 evacuated as Typhoon Parma approaches

TEXT.P: More than 6,600 residents in mudslide-prone areas of six counties around the country had been evacuated as of 8 a.m. Monday as Typhoon Parma lingered southwest of Taiwan, the Central Emergency Operations Center said Monday.

In order to protect people's lives and safety, the government will issue compulsory evacuation orders in danger zones, and will not accept written statements of self-responsibility from residents who choose not to move, said Premier Wu Den-yih while responding to media questions at the Legislative Yuan Monday.

A local newspaper reported Monday that some villagers in Pingtung County wanted to sign written statements that they had chosen not to leave and would be responsible for their own safety. But the local authorities refused their requests and forced them to evacuate the area, according to the report.

The evacuation order was part of the government's efforts to avoid a repeat of the tragedy caused by Typhoon Morakot in early August when the storm triggered massive flooding and devastating landslides in southern Taiwan, burying mountain villages and leaving more than 700 people dead or missing.

According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , rainfall from Typhoon Parma was concentrated in the mountains of northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County. As of midday Monday, six areas in Yilan County had recorded the highest levels of precipitation in the country.
The county's Tungshan's township was drenched with 114 mm of rain in one hour, from 11 a.m. to noon Monday, the CWB said.

In addition, the Council of Agriculture (COA) on Monday updated the number of rivers on its red alert list for mudflows. The 28 rivers on the list are all located in 14 villages and townships in Yilan county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese donation could be used for bridge reconstruction: premier

TEXT.P: Some of the donations from China for relief aid in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot will probably be used in the reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge, which was destroyed by massive flooding triggered by the typhoon, Premier Wu Den-yih said Monday.
Wu made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to questions by lawmakers after reporting on a planned special government budget for post- typhoon reconstruction.

Legislator Pan Meng-an of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party questioned the premier about China's promise of NT$5.1 billion (US$158.14 million) to support relief aid and restoration in Morakot-affected areas of southern Taiwan.
Pan had questioned the actual amount that had been received, pointing out that there had been discrepancies as to how much had in fact arrived.

Wu told the lawmaker that the government has so far received only some NT$900 million of China's promised donation and that it hopes the rest of the funds can be allocated to major post-Morakot reconstruction projects.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, along with other relevant authorities, is studying a plan to spend the Chinese funds on the reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge over the Gaoping River, which connected Kaohsiung County's Linyuan township and Sinyuan township of Pingtung County until it collapsed Aug. 9, Wu said.
It has been assessed that the reconstruction will cost over NT$3 billion, including the cost of building a temporary bridge until the 2.8-km bridge is rebuilt, according to the Executive Yuan.
The bridge reconstruction project is scheduled to begin February 2010 and to be completed by December 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Women's labor force participation rate on rise: CEPD

TEXT.P: The domestic women's labor force participation rate has been rising steadily in recent years and is expected to exceed 50 percent for the first time next year, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.

As the number of jobs in the labor market has not increased substantially, CEPD officials said, rising women's labor participation rate could squeeze men's employment opportunities, with men aged over 40 being most vulnerable.
The labor force participation rate is the percentage of working-age persons -- those aged 16-64 -- in an economy who are employed or are unemployed but looking for a job.
According to CEPD statistics, men's labor participation rate has shown a downward trend in the past seven years, falling from 68.22 percent in 2002 to 67 percent in 2008.

In contrast, women's labor participation rate has been on the upswing. In the past, the rate tended to hover around 46 percent as many local women could not seek work outside the home because of household and child rearing responsibilities.
However, the situation has changed since 2002 when the women's labor participation rate began its uninterrupted upward streak, rising from 46.59 percent that year to 49.67 percent in 2008.
Globally, women generally lag behind men in terms of labor force participation, CEPD officials said.

However, except for Taiwan, women's labor participation rates in most advanced economies tend to be over 50 percent. In the United States and many European countries, the rate is higher than 70 percent. In 2008, Japan's women's labor participation rate reached 67 percent and South Korea's 59 percent,
According to the officials, marriage has been one of the most important factors affecting local women's labor participation.

CEPD statistics show that labor participation rates are almost the same among unmarried males and females, approaching 60 percent in both categories. But the rate tends to fall below 50 percent for married women, the figures show.
In 2008, single women's labor participation rate was 9 percentage points higher than that of married women, according to CEPD tallies.
But over the past seven years, the married women's labor participation rate has risen by more than 3 percent due to a combination of factors, CEPD officials said.
One of the factors might be related to the fact that married women have been forced to enter the job market because their husbands are earning less than before.
Another factor might be the influx of single young women into the job market, the official said, adding that higher levels of education among women has made it easier for them to land jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise on local bourse

TEXT.P: Led by gains in construction shares amid a strong local currency, Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 26.1 points, or 0.35 percent, to close at the day's high of 7,437.98.

Despite losses on Wall Street last Friday and weak showings in stock markets in Asia, the local bourse opened slightly higher at 7,424.24 and dropped to the day's low of 7,381.02 before closing at the day's high.
A total of 3.27 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.78 billion (US$2.94 billion) , down from NT$116.04 billion the previous trading day.
Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.42 percent.

Plastics and chemicals issues rose 1.31 percent, textile shares advanced 0.91 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 0.66 percent, banking and financial shares were up 0.45 percent, machinery and electronics stocks advanced 0.24 percent, and food stuff shares added 0.01 percent.
Only one of the major stock categories -- cement shares -- dropped 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,167 to 1,162, with 216 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$10.24 billion-worth of shares for the day, compared with NT$13.13 billion the previous trading day.
They had bought a net NT$144.2 billion in shares in September, helping drive up the Taiex by more than 10 percent for the month.
One analyst said that with the market volume continuing to shrink as the Taiex hovers around the monthly moving average of 7,380, the market is likely to fluctuate between 7,200 and 7,600.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: Driven down by exporters and foreign bank's selling, the U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.095 to close at NT$32.255.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.35 before reaching a low of NT$32.242 following the intervention of Taiwan's central bank.
A total of US$1.00 billion changed hands during the day's trading, down from the previous day's US$1.35 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel Prize-winning Japanese writer arrives for first visit

TEXT.P: Kenzaburo Oe, the renowned Japanese writer who won the 1994 Nobel Prize for Literature for creating "an imagined world where life and myth condense to form a disconcerting picture of the human predicament today, " arrived in Taiwan Monday for his first-ever visit to the country.
Oe is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the Institute of Chinese Literature and Philosophy (ICLP) under Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's most prestigious academic institution.
In addition to attending a symposium on his literature scheduled for Oct. 6-7, Oe will also give lectures and autograph copies of his books for local readers.
Oe, 74, has been described as "Japan's social conscience" for his resolute opposition to Japanese militarism and the deep sense of critical self- examination that pervades his work.

"Oe has condemned Japan's invasion of other Asian countries for many years now, and regards his trip to Taiwan as a journey of atonement for Japan's past atrocities, " said Peng Hsiao-yen, an ICLP research fellow.

According to Peng, Oe has visited China seven times, where he has been heartily received. During one of his visits there, he conveyed his wish to visit Taiwan to Xu Jinlong, a research fellow at the Beijing-based Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.

"This eventually led the ICLP and the Chinese academy to cooperate in organizing the Oct. 6-7 symposium in Taipei that will review Oe's literature from an international perspective," Peng said, adding that Oe's visit also represents his wish for a cross-Taiwan Strait academic exchange focusing on his work.

The symposium will open with a speech by Oe, to be titled "Late Work, " an allusion to the work by late Palestinian American cultural giant Edward Said, one of his literary bosom friends, Peng said, adding that in the speech, Oe will relate what he hopes to do for Asian society in the remainder of his life.

A total of 13 papers will be presented at the seminar, with topics ranging from Oe's literary imagination, the influence of Chinese writer Lu Xun on his work, the position of music in his work and his leftist ideas, according to Peng.

The ICLP will also organize an exhibition of Oe's literature, dubbed "From Shikoku Forest to the World, " which will be accompanied by musical works produced by his brain-damaged son and literary muse, Hikari.
