The Oct. 6-9 exhibition will display Oe's literary works, manuscripts and 40 photos featuring his acceptance of the Nobel Prize and other relevant activities, as well as paintings by his wife.

Oe was born in a forest-hemmed village in Ehirne Prefecture on the island of Shikoku. In his Nobel Prize acceptance speech, he described himself as "a son of forests, " as forests have been a limitless source of his literary inspiration.

During his childhood, Oe lived through World War II, an experience that left a deep life-long imprint on his writings. The ferocity of war, post-war trauma and the melancholia of death infuse his early works, which are heavily influenced by Western modernism, according to Peng.
"As an author, Oe has been engaged in various social and political issues from an anti-war, humanitarian and liberal perspective," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday:
Liberty Times:
Anti-storm measures should not be taken as political show
We are glad that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is taking unprecedented drastic measures to brace for the attacks of Typhoon Parma.
As extreme weather conditions are becoming more of a rule than an exception, anti-disaster measures should be considered a routine practice by the government.
However, we are worried that the country's politicians from President Ma on down are putting on a show to get public praise rather than to avoid the disaster.
Our concerns were stoked by Premier Wu Den-yih's claims that his administration would prefer to let the public take an unnecessary day off for the typhoon rather than risk their lives to go to work.

Whether the day should be taken off during a typhoon is a question which can be easily determined according to the weather conditions, and an unnecessary holiday might cost the country NT$2 billion worth of production.
United Daily News:
KMT's problem is not factionism, but the nature of factions.
The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lost lawmaker by-elections in Miaoli and Yulin counties in tandem, and was defeated in a referendum on whether to allow gambling in Penghu County.

Political pundits have blamed factionism within the party for its defeats and they seem to be right, as local factions in many other counties are threatening the party's chances for success in their areas in the year-end elections of local government chiefs.

But factionism is not endemic to the KMT, as the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is also rife with factions. But unlike the DPP factions, the KMT factions are more interested in snapping up benefits than pursuing the party's goals.
In order to win elections with local faction support, the party authorities have to distribute benefits evenly among them.
The party lost its control of these factions when it could not meet their greed for benefits.
This problem may not be solved in the near future, but the KMT will not be able to thrive if it does not address the issue.
China Times:
Chinese parade is not what we should be worried about, censorship
is

A spokesman for the Democratic Progressive Party criticized several local TV channels for broadcasting the whole process of China's National Day military parade in Beijing, claiming that it hurt local people's feelings, national security and constitutes a violation of the law.
The Government Information Office promised to look into this and to mete out punishment if any run-ins with the law were found.
We have to congratulate the DPP for its eventual learning of censorship from its arch rival Chiang Kai-shek and its eventual forsaking of its founders' cause of pushing for press freedom.
Chiang would laugh in his tomb for having the DPP as his followers.

However, we have to urge the Government Information Office, and President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to pause and think. Is this a political taboo that a government which claims to be a follower of liberalism dare to break?
Don't dismiss the punishment to be meted out by the Government Information Office as a little wrong step, it will become the beginning of a huge setback for the country's freedom and democracy.

The opposition is willing to betray its cause and to debase itself, but the ruling party should resist the temptation of abusing power and ignore the sirens of nationalism. It should not forsake the country's hard-earned press freedom and plunge the nation into the abyss of dictatorship.
China's military parade is a public event before the eyes of people around the world. Anyone who is interested in it may watch it via the Internet.
By the same token, any local TV channel which considers it news-worth may broadcast it.
We are not alarmed by TV broadcasts of China's military parade, but we will be alarmed if the government punishes these channels because it means the revival of censorship. Apple Daily:
Government's incompetence will result in problems for the elderly
The government's latest statistics show that the average life expectancy in Taiwan is 76 for men and 82 for women.
Those figures mean that there will be an average of 6.4 years for every man and 8.2 years for every woman when they will need caretakers.
The cost of taking care of the elderly will be a heavy financial burden both on their family members and society as a whole.
Unfortunately, we have not seen any attempts on the part of current government to come to grips with this looming problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panamanian ship's captain, 2 crew member rescued

TEXT.P: The captain and two crew members of a Panama-registered cargo ship that sank off Taiwan's outlying Penghu Island group were rescued one day later by marine search and rescue personnel from Taiwan and China, but 11 other crew members remained missing, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said Monday.
The 1,375-ton Silver Sea sank some 86 nautical miles southwest of Penghu archipelago Sunday afternoon, while transporting 53 containers from Taiwan to the Philippines.
It departed the Kaohsiung port for Manila around noon Saturday.

The bureau said it received calls for help from the ship at 5: 25 p.m. Sunday and immediately asked the search command center under the Executive Yuan to launch rescue operations on the sea and from the air.

The center swiftly dispatched military rescue helicopters to the area, while rescue helicopters and two patrol boats were also sent by the Ministry of the Interior and the Coast Guard Administration to the scene, the bureau said.

The ship's captain, who is from Myanmar, was rescued by a Chinese ship around 9 a.m. Monday, while two crew members from Indonesia were saved by Taiwan's vessels and were sent to a hospital in Chiayi County later Monday.

The Chinese vessel went to the scene after learning of the accident. Taiwan also sent rescue ships to the area where the ship sank, which is close to the imaginary middle line separating Taiwan and China in the Taiwan Strait. A Hong Kong cargo ship also sailed to the spot to help with rescues.
As of 5: 00 p. m. Monday, the remaining 11 crew members were still missing.

Although several rescue helicopters were sent to search for the victims, pilots only saw some containers, the wreckage of the ship and an empty life-saving boat floating on the sea, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau added.
Meanwhile, the Tsoying marine base in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, has sent several ships to the area to continue searching for survivors, the center noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly encouraged to get vaccinated against flu, pneumonia

TEXT.P: Senior citizens aged 75 and over were advised Monday to get vaccinated against seasonal influenza and streptococcus pneumonia -- a frequent killer of the elderly -- with the approach of the flu season.

Lin Hung-chuan, a specialist in lung disease and diseases of the immune system at Chang-Gung Memorial Hospital (CGMH) issued the advice after a national inoculation program against seasonal flu began Oct. 1.
The elderly are also entitled to free pneumonia inoculations, offered by the Wang Chan-yang social welfare and charity foundation run by the Formosa Plastics Group, which owns CGMH.
Lin said both the flu and the streptococcus vaccines are safe to take together.
Lin said that while seasonal flu is not particularly dangerous in itself, it can cause complications such as pneumonia, which can be fatal.
Streptococcus pneumonia is the most frequently seen pneumonia killer, Lin continued, pointing out that the fatality rate among the elderly infected by the virulent bacteria is 42.5 percent.
Moreover, the chance of being attacked by the bacteria again is five times higher than that of contracting the disease for the first time, he said.

It was streptococcus pneumonia that prompted the late founder of the Formosa Plastics Group, Wang Yung-ching, to donate 578,000 doses of streptococcus pneumonia vaccine in 2007 for people over 75 after he caught the disease but recovered, according to Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director- General Chou Chih-hao.

The free vaccination was designed to be carried out over three years starting from 2007, and there are still about 40,000 doses left for this year, Chou said, revealing that Wang's foundation has also donated another 57,000 doses to increase the stock for this year.

According to CDC statistics, Taiwan has a population of 1.01 million people aged 75 and over, 470,000 of whom have not yet been inoculated with the pneumonia vaccine, which offers protection for five years.

Meanwhile, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) reported that day that one more patient, aged 12, had been hospitalized with severe influenza A(H1N1) symptoms in the previous 24 hours, bringing the total hospitalization cases to 320 since the outbreak began.
Of that number, 21 had died, 28 were still being treated in local hospitals, while the other 270 had been discharged after making complete recoveries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan forex reserves rise to new high

TEXT.P: Taiwan was holding US$332.24 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of the end of September, a record high amount that was US$6.82 billion more than the August figure, the Central Bank of the Republic of China reported Monday.

Lin Sun-yuan, director-general of the bank's Department of Foreign Exchange, attributed the increase to earnings from foreign exchange reserve investments, as well as the strong appreciation of major currencies that it held, such as the euro and Japanese yen, against the U.S. dollar.
Taiwan was still ranked as the world's fourth-largest holder of forex reserves, after China, Japan and Russia and ahead of India, in September.

China held US$2.13 trillion in forex reserves as of the end of June, increasing some US$177.9 billion over that posted in March, Lin said. Japan had US$995.7 billion as of the end of August, up US$3.8 billion over that posted in July.
Russia, the world's third-largest forex reserve holder, had US$367.5 billion as of the end of August, up by US$15.2 billion from July.
India, meanwhile, had US$263.5 billion in forex reserves as of September 25, up US$3 billion from August.
South Korea's forex reserves as of September is not yet available. It held US$240.9 billion at the end of August, up US$4.4 billion from July.

Besides Taiwan and South Korea, the other two of "Asia's dragons" - Singapore and Hong Kong - Singapore had US$176.6 billion in forex reserves at the end of August, up US$1.5 billion from July. Hong Kong held US$218.2 billion in foreign reserves, up US$8.7 billion from July.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Oct. 5

TEXT.P: Taiwan: MOEA 12. Chinese donations will not be used to reconstruct bridge

DOC.HEADLINE: Everything to be bigger for visiting NBA athletes

TEXT.P: National Basketball Association (NBA) players in Taiwan to play in an exhibition game Oct. 8 will be treated to super-sized services, such as enlarged beds and steaks more than double the standard size during their three-day stay.

The Denver Nuggets and Indiana Pacers will play the first ever NBA game in Taiwan on Thursday, and Crystal Liu, marketing and public relations manager at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel where the NBA players will stay, said the hotel is ready for their arrival Oct. 6.

It has prepared 270 "special" rooms for the group of over 300 NBA players, family members, executives and staffers coming to Taiwan, with each room being equipped with 170-centimeter bathrobes (instead of the standard 120 cm) , 30.5 cm slippers, 183 cm bath towels and 2.43-meter-long beds, Liu said.

The room service menu will also offer expanded portions, with the standard 200-gram steak becoming 500 gms. and the standard bowl of beef noodles doubling in size. Gigantic U.S.-styled hamburgers and mountains of fresh fruit will also be available, Liu said.
Taipei will become the eighth Asian city to host either an NBA regular season or exhibition game, following Tokyo, Yokohama, and Saitama in Japan, Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou in China, and Macau.
After the Pacers and Nuggets play their exhibition game on Oct. 8, they will fly directly to Beijing for another exhibition in the Chinese capital's Wukesong Arena on Oct. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rebuilding of major southern bridge not to rely on Chinese funds

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih ruled out the possibility Monday of using China-donated funds to rebuild a major bridge in southern Taiwan that was destroyed during the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot in early August.

"We have politely rejected the proposal of using Chinese donations to finance reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge over the Gaoping River, " Wu said at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting Monday afternoon.

He was responding to a question from opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Huang Wei-cher on how China's pledge of NT$5.1 billion in funds for post-typhoon rehabilitation will be used.
Wu said the government has so far received only about NT$900 million (US$27.86 million) of the amount promised by Beijing.
"China intends to have the remaining funds used to finance selected infrastructure reconstruction projects, with the names of Chinese donors engraved on them," Wu said.

After China's Sichuan province was rattled by a devastating earthquake in May 2008, Taiwanese companies donated funds for the reconstruction of certain major infrastructure projects, and China wants to follow that example, Wu said.

In response to a question from DPP Legislator Pan Men-an, Wu had suggested in the morning session of the committee hearing that funds from China might be used to finance reconstruction of the Shuangyuan Bridge, which connected Kaohsiung County's Linyuan township and Pingtung County's Sinyuan township until it collapsed Aug. 9.
In the afternoon session, however, Wu ruled out that possibility.
"After a careful assessment, we think it is inappropriate to have the bridge financed with Chinese funds, " Wu said, without further explanation.
The Executive Yuan will consider allocating Chinese donations to other projects and will exercise prudence in selecting the most suitable ones, Wu added.

The Shuangyuan Bridge reconstruction project will cost an estimated NT$3 billion, including the cost of building a temporary bridge until the 2.8 km bridge is rebuilt, according to an Executive Yuan assessment.
The project is scheduled to begin in February 2010 and be completed by December 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flat panel, chip fab China policy to be decided by year's end

TEXT.P: The government will decide by the end of the year whether local flat panel and chip manufacturers can invest in facilities or buy stakes in other companies in China, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday.
"Relevant government agencies will conduct a cross-ministerial meeting on the issue later this year to set a clear course for the future development of the two local sectors," MOEA officials said.

Apart from the key condition that it must be beneficial to Taiwan's people, a clear policy that helps the two local industries get a foothold in China's market without leading to the hollowing out of Taiwan will be adopted by the end of this year, they said.

Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang said at the end of September that companies in the two sectors would be allowed to invest in China to help them secure China's market and prevent it from looking toward partners from other countries such as South Korea to acquire related technologies.
At present, Taiwanese chipmakers are limited to investing in plants in China that use the older 8-inch wafer technology.

A local newspaper reported on Monday that workers at some flat panel and chip companies headquartered in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park are worried about losing their jobs if their employers were allowed to invest in advanced technology processes in China.

In response to the report, the Industrial Development Bureau made it clear Monday that the policy will fully heed public concern that such relations with China must not affect the interests of Taiwan's people.

Even if high-tech companies are permitted to invest in China on a case-by-case basis, government policy will still take into consideration the Wassenaar Agreement to mitigate adverse effects on Taiwanese enterprises, bureau officials said.
The agreement is signed by some 40 countries to prevent exports of sensitive technology with potential military uses to certain countries, including China, North Korea and Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's Palace Museum director arrives for joint exhibition

TEXT.P: The director of China's Palace Museum, Zheng Xinmiao, arrived in Taiwan Monday to attend a press conference for an upcoming joint exhibition with Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM).

Zheng will take part in the press conference together with his Taiwanese counterpart, Chou Kung-shin, and the two are expected to reveal the concrete results of exchanges between the two museums over the past six months and their planned exchanges next year.

The exchanges between the two state-run museums began formally in February when Chou made an "ice-breaking" visit to the Palace Museum in Beijing, the first time the heads of the two museums had ever met.

The visit concretized their cooperation in putting together an exhibition on the Yongzheng Emperor -- the fourth emperor of the Qing dynasty -- scheduled to open at the National Palace Museum on Oct. 7.

The Palace Museum in Beijing loaned 37 pieces from its collection on the Chinese emperor while the Shanghai Museum contributed two others to the exhibition titled "Harmony and Integrity: The Yongzheng Emperor and His Times."
In all, 246 pieces from the Yongzheng period of 1722-1735 will be featured in the exhibition, which runs until Jan 10, 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government will mark, not cerebrate Double Tenth Day

TEXT.P: The government will mark Double Ten Day Friday but will not cerebrate the Republic of China's founding anniversary as it has in the past, the spokesman of the Presidential Office said Monday.

Wang Yu-chi said President Ma Ying-jeou will preside over a ceremony for the country's national day at the Presidential Office, with the heads of the five branches of government and Cabinet members attending.
Ma will also deliver a major speech, which he is now working on, Wang added.

After nearly 700 citizens lost their lives during Typhoon Morakot in early August, President Ma and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who serves as the chairman of the organizing committee for the Double Ten celebration, decided that the festivities normally held for the founding anniversary would be canceled.
The money saved would instead be used for post-disaster reconstruction, according to the consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cost-of-living indexes down in September

TEXT.P: The government's statistical agency unveiled cost-of-living indexes for the first time Monday in line with Premier Wu Den-yih's pledge to make economic indicators more relevant to the everyday lives of ordinary people.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) prepared three cost-of-living indexes to more precisely reflect the fluctuation of prices for goods and services in three categories.

The first cost-of-living index was figured out mainly based on the costs of food, fuel and electricity while the second index covers a basket of 244 items, including food, education and entertainment, such as travel, extra schooling fees and electronic products and computers.
The third index covers 239 items, including food and other daily necessities, such as clothing, toilet paper and shampoo.
According to the DGBAS tallies, September's first cost-of-living index stood at 113.97, down 1.23 percent from the month-earlier level.
The second cost-of-living index stood at 109.26 in September, falling 1.14 percent from the August level, while the third cost-of-living index stood at 110.36, down 1.11 percent from August.

"Compared with the traditional consumer price index (CPI) , all three cost-of- living indexes registered bigger falls than the CPI, " said Wu Chao-ming, a DGBAS section chief in charge of calculating and monitoring consumer price fluctuations.
The CPI stood at 105.49 in September, down only 0.65 percent from August, Wu said.

The larger drops in the three cost-of-living indexes mainly resulted from substantial declines in vegetable, egg and electricity prices during the period, down 12.54 percent, 5.64 percent and 11.62 percent, respectively.
"These three items account for a larger weight in the first cost-of-living index than in the CPI, thus resulting in a larger decline in the cost-of-living index," Wu explained.
In preparing the CPI index, Wu said, the agency covers 424 items.

"With a view to make the index better reflect the average person's feelings and their everyday lives, the first cost-of-living index selected only 190 items from those gauged in the CPI, with food prices accounting for 80 percent of the index," Wu elaborated.
The first index also includes the costs of natural gas and electricity as well as fuel costs, Wu said.
The second cost-of-living index covers 244 items -- the 190 items calculated in the first index plus 54 others in the education and entertainment categories.
Meanwhile, Wu said the consumer price index dropped 0.86 percent in September from the year-earlier level. It marked the eighth consecutive monthly decline since Feburary.
The price decline was slightly larger than August's 0.8 percent, but Wu said the figure did not signal any risk of further economic contraction as the economic recession has gradually bottomed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Push made to lure investment from China-based Taiwanese firms

TEXT.P: The government intends to lure more investment from Taiwanese firms based in China by touting six new star industries, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Monday.

Yu Chi-cheng, deputy director of the MOEA's Department of Industrial Services, touted the benefits of investing in Taiwan at a gathering of China-based Taiwanese businessmen in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City to celebrate the Mid- Autumn Festival.

Yu was trying to solicit investment in six star industries that Taiwan's government has pushed aggressively as future growth engines -- specialty agriculture, green energy, health care, tourism, cultural innovation and biotechnology,

Among the 200 attendees were Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and over 100 representatives of Taiwanese businessmen's associations in China.
At the gathering, Yu also noted that total investment in Taiwan by local businessmen operating in China had already beat the target set by the MOEA for 2009.

The amount of capital injected by overseas Taiwan businessmen into the domestic market between September 2006 and September this year totaled NT$71.7 billion (US$2.26 billion), with NT$67.4 billion in 245 projects invested by those with operations in China, Yu said.
The balance of the investment was made by Taiwanese businessmen in the United States, Canada and Southeast Asian countries.

China-based Taiwanese businessmen launched 110 investment projects in Taiwan worth a total of NT$18.6 billion in 2008, and another 79 projects worth NT$35 billion in the first nine months of 2009, MOEA statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to act on 'fat cat' CEOs: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih demanded Monday that government agencies act swiftly against so-called fat cat CEOs in affiliated organizations or foundations, especially those who are earning two monthly salaries.

Wu was responding to questions during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, during which ruling Kuomintang lawmaker Lin Teh-fu said these overpaid executives had triggered negative sentiment among the public.

"Some retired government officials now hired in government-run spin-offs or nonprofit organizations not only are earning two salaries every month -- one from their previous post in the government and one from their current job -- but also enjoy a high interest rate of 18 percent on their bank deposits," Lin said.
"That has provoked strong criticism from society."

Wu promised to fully weed out all such personnel in government-affiliated enterprises and organizations based on relevant laws and regulations. "But we cannot recklessly attack people, because there will be trouble if we're wrong," he stressed.
It was reported that the Ministry of Economics Affairs has the largest number of such enterprises or nonprofit organizations under its jurisdiction.
Some of the top executives in these businesses get two salaries totaling over NT$300,000 (US$9,300) per month -- more than a government minister makes, the report said.

Liu Ming-chung, director of the MOEA's Commission of National Corporations, dismissed the report, however, and said that monthly salaries for ranking CEOs and full-time advisers at 15 MOEA-affiliated businesses are set at NT$80,000 or lower, in line with regulations which were already revised in July.
"All of them get only one salary from their present posts, and no one continues receiving another salary from their previous posts in the government," he explained.
"All newly employed CEOs and advisers will be compensated in compliance with the new regulations."
According to Liu, the MOEA runs 35 such companies and organizations such as Taiwan Power Company, Aerospace Industrial Development Corp and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (Taiwan).
The ministry currently hires 89 part-time and full-time advisers at these businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red Cross Society donates US$200,000 for Indonesian quake relief

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China announced Monday that it will donate US$200,000 to Indonesia for rescue and relief efforts there following a powerful earthquake.

Chen Shih-kuei, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society, said that 535 people were killed and another 2,400 injured in a magnitude 7.6 temblor that struck the Indonesian island of Sumatra Sept. 30.
It is believed that around 3,000 to 4,000 people are still trapped in buildings that collapsed in the quake.
Chen urged the public to donate money for the Indonesian mission through his or other organizations to show their support for international humanitarian aid efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Land warning for Typhoon Parma lifted

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted the land warning for Typhoon Parma at 11: 30 p.m. Monday after the eye of the typhoon headed south, but CWB meteorologists warned that heavy rains could continue for at least another day.

The CWB said that the combined effects of peripheral currents and a northeasterly monsoon are expected to bring heavy rains to northern and eastern Taiwan and mountainous areas in central and southern Taiwan.
The Hengchun Peninsula, which is no longer directly threatened by the typhoon, is also expected to be hit by torrential rain for at least another day, the CWB predicted.
On whether the CWB will lift the sea warning for the typhoon, meteorologists said they will wait to see the impact of Typhoon Melor on Parma before making a decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cost-of-living indexes down in September

TEXT.P: The government's statistical agency unveiled cost-of-living indexes for the first time Monday in line with Premier Wu Den-yih's pledge to make economic indicators more relevant to the everyday lives of ordinary people.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) prepared three cost-of-living indexes to more precisely reflect the fluctuation of prices for goods and services in three categories.

The first cost-of-living index was figured out mainly based on the costs of food, fuel and electricity while the second index covers a basket of 244 items, including food, education and entertainment, such as travel, extra schooling fees and electronic products and computers.
The third index covers 239 items, including food and other daily necessities, such as clothing, toilet paper and shampoo.
According to the DGBAS tallies, September's first cost-of-living index stood at 113.97, down 1.23 percent from the month-earlier level.
The second cost-of-living index stood at 109.26 in September, falling 1.14 percent from the August level, while the third cost-of-living index stood at 110.36, down 1.11 percent from August.

"Compared with the traditional consumer price index (CPI) , all three cost-of- living indexes registered bigger falls than the CPI, " said Wu Chao-ming, a DGBAS section chief in charge of calculating and monitoring consumer price fluctuations.
The CPI stood at 105.49 in September, down only 0.65 percent from August, Wu said.

The larger drops in the three cost-of-living indexes mainly resulted from substantial declines in vegetable, egg and electricity prices during the period, down 12.54 percent, 5.64 percent and 11.62 percent, respectively.
"These three items account for a larger weight in the first cost-of-living index than in the CPI, thus resulting in a larger decline in the cost-of-living index," Wu explained.
In preparing the CPI index, Wu said, the agency covers 424 items.

"With a view to make the index better reflect the average person's feelings and their everyday lives, the first cost-of-living index selected only 190 items from those gauged in the CPI, with food prices accounting for 80 percent of the index," Wu elaborated.
The first index also includes the costs of natural gas and electricity as well as fuel costs, Wu said.
The second cost-of-living index covers 244 items -- the 190 items calculated in the first index plus 54 others in the education and entertainment categories.
Meanwhile, Wu said the consumer price index dropped 0.86 percent in September from the year-earlier level. It marked the eighth consecutive monthly decline since Feburary.
The price decline was slightly larger than August's 0.8 percent, but Wu said the figure did not signal any risk of further economic contraction as the economic recession has gradually bottomed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to act on 'fat cat' CEOs: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih demanded Monday that government agencies act swiftly against so-called fat cat CEOs in affiliated organizations or foundations, especially those who are earning two monthly salaries.

Wu was responding to questions during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, during which ruling Kuomintang lawmaker Lin Teh-fu said these overpaid executives had triggered negative sentiment among the public.

"Some retired government officials now hired in government-run spin-offs or nonprofit organizations not only are earning two salaries every month -- one from their previous post in the government and one from their current job -- but also enjoy a high interest rate of 18 percent on their bank deposits," Lin said.
"That has provoked strong criticism from society."

Wu promised to fully weed out all such personnel in government-affiliated enterprises and organizations based on relevant laws and regulations. "But we cannot recklessly attack people, because there will be trouble if we're wrong," he stressed.
It was reported that the Ministry of Economics Affairs has the largest number of such enterprises or nonprofit organizations under its jurisdiction.
Some of the top executives in these businesses get two salaries totaling over NT$300,000 (US$9,300) per month -- more than a government minister makes, the report said.

Liu Ming-chung, director of the MOEA's Commission of National Corporations, dismissed the report, however, and said that monthly salaries for ranking CEOs and full-time advisers at 15 MOEA-affiliated businesses are set at NT$80,000 or lower, in line with regulations which were already revised in July.
"All of them get only one salary from their present posts, and no one continues receiving another salary from their previous posts in the government," he explained.
"All newly employed CEOs and advisers will be compensated in compliance with the new regulations."
According to Liu, the MOEA runs 35 such companies and organizations such as Taiwan Power Company, Aerospace Industrial Development Corp and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (Taiwan).
The ministry currently hires 89 part-time and full-time advisers at these businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red Cross Society donates US$200,000 for Indonesian quake relief

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China announced Monday that it will donate US$200,000 to Indonesia for rescue and relief efforts there following a powerful earthquake.

Chen Shih-kuei, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society, said that 535 people were killed and another 2,400 injured in a magnitude 7.6 temblor that struck the Indonesian island of Sumatra Sept. 30.
It is believed that around 3,000 to 4,000 people are still trapped in buildings that collapsed in the quake.
Chen urged the public to donate money for the Indonesian mission through his or other organizations to show their support for international humanitarian aid efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 6, or the 18th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
2001: A local banker urges Taiwan consumers to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
2001: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participates in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: Miaoli County to hold activities for elderly on traditional festival

TEXT.P: A variety of activities for the elderly will be held in the central county of Miaoli in October to celebrate the "Chong Yang Festival," county government officials said Monday.

The activities include gate ball matches and an achievement show for elderly people attending classes, the officials said at a press conference. The traditional festival -- also known as the "Old Men Festival" -- is celebrated on the ninth day of the ninth lunar month, and the elderly are especially encouraged to take part in the activities.
The county is home to 52 people aged 100 or above, and has more than 18,000 people over 80 years of age, according to data provided by the county government.
One couple that has been married for 61 years was invited to attend the press conference, one of 1,895 couples in the county who have celebrated their 60th wedding anniversaries.
Asked about the secret of a happy marriage, the diamond wedding couple said tolerance is the essential ingredient of any successful union.

"You need to see your partner's strengths, not just weaknesses. Any problem can be solved as long as you are able to tolerate your partner, " said Fan Fa-jin, an 83-year-old whose wife is 82 and who has five children and four grandchildren.

Fan also noted that he makes all the decisions outside the home, while everything inside the home is left to his wife for decision-making. "That is always the key to avoiding conflict, " he said with a twinkle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
One death, flooding in Yilan because of Typhoon Parma

TEXT.P: As Typhoon Parma veers away from Taiwan, it has left one person dead, caused flooding in 30 areas in Yilan County, and forced 6,831 people to be evacuated from their homes as of Monday night, the Central Emergency Operation Center (CEOC) reported Tuesday.
A 43-year-old man living in Beinan township in southeastern Taiwan's Taitung County, surnamed Wei, drowned after falling in a flooded river, the center said.

Heavy rains from the typhoon triggered serious flooding in Yilan in northeastern Taiwan, submerging Yilan City and townships including Sansing, Wujie, Dongshan, Jhuangwei, Datong, Toucheng and Luodong in waters ranging between 10-50 centimeters high.

The CEOC said that between Sunday dawn and 9 p.m. Monday, Hansi in Dongshan township received 1,121 mm of rainfall, the most of anywhere in Taiwan, followed by 1,046 mm in Sansing, and 949 mm in Datong township's Niudou.

Other areas affected by the storm were Hejhong in Hualien County's Sioulin township, which received 671 mm of rain, and Rueifang town in Taipei County, which recorded rainfall of 444 mm, the center said.
Meanwhile, 74 rivers on the island were given red alerts for flooding, including 56 in Yilan County and 18 in Hualien County.

Another 227 rivers had yellow alerts, indicating that nearby residents should be aware of possible flooding, the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Tuesday.
In addition, the COA issued landslide red alerts for 109 areas -- all in Yilan and Hualien counties, suggesting local governments to "forcibly" evacuate residents to safe places.
Typhoon Parma has weakened to a tropical storm after its periphery swept over the southern tip of Taiwan Monday.

The Central Weather Bureau reported that as of 8:30 a.m. Tuesday, the storm was centered 310 km south-southwest of Eluanbi, at Taiwan's southernmost tip, moving in a south-southwesterly direction at a speed of 10 km per hour.
The bureau maintained its sea warning for the storm after lifting its land warning the previous night.

Under the joint influence of the storm's outer rim and the northeast monsoon, the weather bureau predicted Tuesday that rainfall in Hualien County will increase to 800-1,200 mm in mountainous areas and 500-700 mm in lowland areas.
It warned people in the northeastern and eastern areas of Taiwan to remain on the alert for torrential rains.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students bag award at Rotterdam Architecture Biennale

TEXT.P: Students from Tamkang University won a special award at the 4th International Architecture Biennale Rotterdam (IABR) with a collective design called "Spatial Limbo," the Danshuei, Taipei County-based university said Tuesday.

"Spatial Limbo" -- designed by six postgraduate and undergraduate students from Tamkang's Department of Architecture -- won a Special Mention Award at the Parallel Cases exhibition for offering an inventive and creative approach to the biennale's theme, "Open City: Designing Coexistence."
This marked the first time that a student group from Taiwan has won an award at the prestigious IABR.

The Parallel Cases exhibition, which displayed 44 entries chosen from 280 works submitted by universities around the world, allowed teams to imagine how architectural and urban development projects can help contribute to social cohesion in future cities.
"Spatial Limbo" uses words, drawings, photos and models to describe four peripheral urban areas in Taiwan that have not come to terms with urban development in the fast process of social change.
The four areas included a naval fuel plant, a commercial complex with beehive- like units, a cluster of shanty homes on the edge of a big city and a seaside residential hill.

"We didn't want to let our design fall into a stereotyped framework, which promotes the idea that old or defunct spaces must be renewed or rejuvenated, " said Chen Yung-yu, one of the six student designers.
"The existence of peripheral spaces also serve as a medium to reflect the absurdities of cities, " Chen said.
Another design by another group of architecture students from Tamkang, called "Zhongxin, " also made it into the Parallel Cases exhibition.

"Zhongxin" is a park design based on a now defunct village for dependents of military personnel, more commonly known in Taiwan as "juancun." The design turned space in Taipei City's Beitou district into a "juancun" park.
"We studied the lifestyle of military dependents in a bid to preserve the unique 'juancun' culture and history, " said Chang Wei-ju, one of the work's seven student designers.
The 4th IABR, being held in Rotterdam and Amsterdam, opened Sept. 25 and is scheduled to run until Jan. 10, 2010.
Tamkang and Harvard Graduate School of Design are the only two schools from around the world to have two entries in the Parallel Cases exhibition, university officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier prefers local governments deciding whether to suspend class

TEXT.P: Local governments should retain the power to decide whether to close schools and offices as a threatening typhoon approaches, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday amid calls for the central government to take over the job.

Yilan County residents have criticized the county government for repeatedly changing its mind on whether to call for school and office closings as Typhoon Parma approached, leading to suggestions that the central government get involved in the decision-making process.

Wu said local governments have had the authority to decide on suspending class and work over the past two to three decades and that he believes the judgment of local governments can better reflect the actual situation on the ground.
He also defended the Yilan County government, saying it did not believe it had vacillated in deciding school and office closings as Parma dumped heavy rain in the northeastern Taiwan county.
Wu admitted, however, that the central government should reinforce its data analysis so that it can offer more accurate information to local governments to help them make their decisions.
On the call for the Executive Yuan to take the authority to decide closings, the premier said he "is willing to carefully weigh whether to have different authorities hold the power."

The Yilan County government announced at 8 a.m. Monday that schools would be closed beginning noon that day after the Central Weather Bureau updated its rainfall prediction to a higher level of alert.
Its decision, however, to authorize local township chiefs to decide whether or not to close offices plunged the county into chaos, as some townships worked while others did not.

Only at 11: 30 a.m. did the county government announce that all offices in the county would be closed, too late for some parents to take their children home from school, according to a local newspaper report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Authorities set rainfall level for school, office closures

TEXT.P: The minimum level of precipitation to prompt school and office closures has been set tentatively at 350 mm per day, the head of the Central Personnel Administration said Tuesday.

"Basically, local city or county governments can announce class or office closures in the event that 350 mm of precipitation is recorded in a single day in their areas of jurisdiction, " Wu Tai-cheng said at aquestion and answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Wu made the remarks in response to a suggestion by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lu Shiow-yen that the Executive Yuan include precipitation as one of the factors used by local governments to decide whether to close schools and workplaces in the event of a typhoon or floods.
Later, Premier Wu Den-yih said he seconded Lu's suggestion, adding that mudslide predictions should also be another factor, in addition to wind strength.

He said that particularly in remote areas, disaster prevention can be more effective if the relevant orders are issued by local governments rather than the Executive Yuan because time and distance could impact on the Cabinet's response.

Around noon Tuesday, the Central Personnel Administration announced that it will convene a meeting of the relevant Cabinet-level agencies and local governments around the country Wednesday to work out a new mechanism under which the local governments could have autonomy regarding class and office closures and could simultaneously inform the central government of their decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'National Day' birds to make annual stop by Kenting

TEXT.P: Gray-faced buzzard eagles, also known as the "National Day Bird," will soon pass through southern Taiwan's Kenting for about 20 days, the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior (CPAMI) said in a statement Tuesday.

To welcome this rare species of migratory bird, listed in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) , the Kenting National Park will hold an annual eagle-watching event that will include various bird-watching and environmental education activities.
Appendix II includes species for which trade must be controlled to "avoid utilization incompatible with their survival."

The gray-faced buzzard may be the most famous of 200 bird species that transit through Kenting National Park every year as they migrate, and because its migration period usually comes around Oct. 10, Taiwan's national day, it is nicknamed the "National Day Bird."
Gray-faced buzzards usually rest in Kenting for about 20 days from early to mid- October and can be seen flying in groups above the ocean.
The best place to see the birds, according to the CPAMI statement, is in the rural township of Manjhou, where the eagles gather in "columns" and fly around before diving to the ground before sunset.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 98.07 points, or 1.31 percent, to close at 7,536.05.
The local bourse opened at 7,479.51 and fluctuated between 7,566.88 and 7,447.54 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.92 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$146.02 billion (US$4.54 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 1.66 percent. Textile stocks advanced 1.61 percent, banking and financial shares rose 1.47 percent, machinery and electronics shares increased 1.41 percent, foodstuff issues gained 1.23 percent, cement stocks were up 0.88 percent, paper and pulp issues added 0.84 percent, and construction issues rose 0.37 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,783 to 748, with 238 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$9.57 billion-worth of shares for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday:
Apple Daily:
Education myth
The Kuomintang has vowed to choose a highly educated candidate to compete in the race for magistrate in Yunlin County, after its original nominee dropped out of the race.
In the party's view, people with higher education degrees always have a clean image and are not linked to local factions.
This is a myth that originated in Confucianism, which asserts that education improves character. This myth has persisted not only in Taiwan's political circles but also in its business circles.
Actually there is no evidence that people with high education have more integrity or capability than ordinary people.
United Daily News:
Our two cents on health insurance premium hikes

Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang announced last week a new formula for calculating National Health Insurance premiums under which the maximum income basis on which premiums are calculated will be raised from NT$131,000 to NT$259,000.
Therefore, people with salaries of NT$260,000 or higher per month will see their premiums increase from NT$6,000 to NT$12,000 per month.
Former Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan had proposed to raise premiums by calculating them based on the insured's total income rather than simply salary.

Since the income of many wealthy people consists of capital gains and dividens rather than salaries, we believe Yeh's proposal is more reasonable and will inject life into the cash-strapped insurance program for a longer period.
Yuang should explain why he chose an option which doesn't seem to be the best way out.
Liberty Times:
Local political factions should refuse to serve Kuomintang
In the wake of the Kuomintang's defeat in the legislative by-election in Yunlin County, President Ma Ying-jeou said he prefers to lose than to cooperate with dirty local faction leaders.

He has shown his contempt for local factions just as did the late President Chiang Kai-shek, who was described by late Shanghai gangster kingpin Du Yueh- sheng as considering Du his chamber pot, which he "puts under the bed after using it."
The KMT repeated its trick in Taiwan by colluding with local factions to control the island, and that now constitutes the party's major vulnerability.
President Ma also considers factions as chamber pots, so he blamed them for his party's loss in Yunlin County while playing down his poor performance on the job.
Local factions are not endemic to Taiwan. They have played significant roles in other democratic countries.

We will be glad if the ruling party is determined to sever ties with local factions, and we urge local factions to stop serving as the KMT's chamber pots and give Taiwan a chance for the development of a healthy democracy.
China Times:
Taiwan survives Typhoon Parma, but will it survive future storms?

Typhoon Parma has not caused serious damage to Taiwan, thanks to the all-out efforts of President Ma's administration, but the governments of several counties where typhoon warnings were in effect barely escaped major damage.
Parma was erratic, with an unpredictable course and influence on Taiwan, complicated by the movement of the nearby Typhoon Melor and a prevailing monsoon in northern Taiwan.

Scientists have warned that the earth is entering into a peak storm period in a thousand-year cycle because of global warming. Taiwan must improve the accuracy of its weather forecasting to enable it to be adequately prepared if it wants to survive future storms.
The general public's awareness of disasters should also be raised.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drive launched to teach senior citizens about medication use

TEXT.P: An integrated drive has been launched to teach elderly citizens the correct way to take medicines to avoid side effects and waste of medical resources, the Taiwan Health Care Reform Foundation said Tuesday.

A total of 455 health-care related facilities, including 17 university hospitals, 43 regional hospitals, 53 community hospitals, 54 sanitation offices and outpatient service centers, and 288 drug stores, had joined the foundation's campaign as of Oct. 2, and have jointly created a Web site dedicated to the effort, a foundation spokesman said.

These health-care enterprises, which are voluntarily participating in the campaign, will teach elderly patients how to take medicine and will offer free consultations on the Web site -- www.thrf.org.tw/elder/, he added.

Citing information provided by the Taipei Veterans General Hospital, the spokesman said one elderly patient was found to have taken in one month more than 200 pills that were prescribed by several different departments of the same hospital.

According to the hospital, senior patients have an average of 1.3 to 1.8 chronic diseases and may have to take more than 10 tablets daily as prescribed by various doctors, if the patients attend 1.65 to 3.31 clinics a day on average.

The foundation also cited the case of a 75-year-old man who was taking more than 10 different kinds of medication a day, which were prescribed by doctors from different hospital departments to treat his benign prostatic hiperplasia, constipation and insomnia. However, that led to him having excessive doses of tranquillizers, the foundation added.

As this is common senario among elderly patients, the Bureau of National Health Insurance has been encouraging hospitals to open special outpatient clinics as a one-stop service for elderly people with multiple chronic diseases.

Some local governments, such as Taipei County, have been collaborating with local pharmacist associations to set up a home visit service for senior patients, which would include keeping track of medication use and dosage.

DOC.HEADLINE: University, private company sign agreement to produce aluminum nitride

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University in the southern city of Tainan signed a joint venture agreement with the privately owned Taiwan Nitride Material Inc. Tuesday for the production of aluminum nitride (AlN), a synthesized material used in electronics applications.
The agreement was formally signed at NCKU by Hwang Hwang-hweng, a senior executive vice president at the university, and H.H. Chang, chairman of Taiwan Nitride Material.

Under the joint venture plan, the two sides will jointly invest a total of NT$30 million (US$932,000) initially for research and development of AlN, a semiconductor material widely used for heat radiation and insulation in applications in the ultraviolet optoelectronics industry.

The project -- one of many initiated by the National Science Council to foster cross-discipline innovation -- is expected to yield profits totaling at least NT$100 million in the first 10 years, according to NCKU.

The joint venture is also one of NCKU's six investment projects, which include aquaculture oral bacterial vaccine preparation, development of healthy herbs, copper resources recycling, bio-surfactant products, and AlN electronic substrate metallization, according to Hwung.

AlN is stable at high temperatures in inert atmospheres and melts at 2800 degrees Celsius. In the air, surface oxidation occurs above 700 degrees and even at room temperature, and surface oxide layers of 5-10 nm have been detected. This oxide layer protects the material at temperatures of up to 1370 degrees Celsius.

It dissolves slowly in mineral acids through grain boundary attack, and in strong alkalies through attack on the aluminum nitride grains. The material hydrolyzes slowly in water. AlN is resistant to attack from most molten salts, including chlorides and cryolite.
Among the applications of AlN are optoelectronics, dielectric layers in optical storage media, electronic substrates and chip carriers where high thermal conductivity is essential.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan can help accelerate democratic development in China: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's democratic politics is believed to be able to help speed up the development of democracy in China as the Beijing turns increasingly strong on the international political stage thanks to its big economic power, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Tuesday.
Lai made the remarks while making a keynote speech at an annual gathering of overseas Chinese who live in Europe. The group had gathered in Taipei for an annual visit.

In her speech, Lai underlined the gradual reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, describing the improved cross-strait ties as the greatest change in Taiwan over the past 16 months.
Taiwan has been promoting the development of cross-strait relations based on the principles of not seeking unification, independence or military invasion.

The improvement in cross-strait relations from the hostile stand-off that existed between the two sides in the past has won Taiwan the title of a "peace maker" instead of "trouble maker "in the Asia-Pacific region, Lai said.

Speaking of Taiwan's strategies in pushing for the development of cross-strait ties under the leadership of President Ma Ying-jeou, the official in charge of Taiwan's affairs with the mainland said the first step was recovering the long- frozen dialogues and negotiations between the two sides.
Thanks to the resumption in talks, the two sides reached agreements with each other on many economic and trade problems over the past year, Lai said.

She noted that now Taiwan is making efforts to push for the signing of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), a type of free-trade agreement, with China in the hope that Taiwan can recover its international economic competitiveness.

Ma argues the agreement is necessary in order for Taiwan not to lose out to China's other trade partners, who will enjoy low tariffs or tariff-free access to the Chinese market once they sign free-trade agreements with Beijing.
Such an agreement, however, has stirred debate in Taiwan, with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and others expressing fears it could make Taiwan's economy too dependent on China.

Lai on Tuesday also said that the time is not yet ripe for the Taiwan and China to begin discussing political issues or issues concerning the establishment of a military mutual-trust mechanism between Taiwan and China.
