DOC.HEADLINE: Umbilical cord blood transplant effective in stroke treatment: trials

TEXT.P: Umbilical cord blood transplants have shown good results in the treatment of strokes, spinal cord injuries and brain injuries, according to trials conducted on animals recently by the Chi Mei Medical Center (CMMC) in Tainan County.
The findings indicate that umbilical cord blood transplants, which have been used in the treatment of childhood leukemia and severe thalassemia, may have broader applications.

Chen Sheng-hsien, director of CMMC's department of obstetrics and gynecology, said researchers at the medical center have used mice to test the effectiveness of umbilical cord blood transplants in treating paralysis, a common post-stroke symptom, and it was found that a transplant helped improve the mice's conditions.
Researchers have also launched experiments on the use of umbilical cord blood transplants in the treatment of dementia, Chen said.
Meanwhile, the experiments on the use of umbilical cord blood in treating diabetes have entered human trials, he said.
In the experiments, stem cells obtained from umbilical cord blood were cultured and separated to produce insulin-producing cells, before the cells were transplanted to diabetes patients, he said.

According to Chen, umbilical cord blood transplants may also be used to improve chronic allograft rejection in patients who have undergone organ transplants, so as to prolong the life of the transplanted organs.

DOC.HEADLINE: After suffering a mutiny, Taiwanese fishing boat heads home

TEXT.P: The Japanese government did not refuse to help the Taiwanese fishing boat that suffered a minor mutiny, but there were differences among Japanese agencies on how to handle the crew and the boat, which is currently on its way back to Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

"Based on humanitarian concerns, the Japanese government agreed to let the boat enter its harbor, but it was still negotiating with us on the details of how to deal with the crew, " MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang said at a regular press briefing.
According to media reports, a mutiny broke out on the Pintung-based "Yu Chun No. 166" fishing vessel while it was operating in the Pacific Ocean.

The reports said that the Taiwanese captain Shih Chin-shing called his family Oct. 2 via satellite phone and said he and his chief engineer had locked themselves in the navigation room after two of eight Indonesian crew members threatened their lives with knives.

The captain turned the boat toward Japan's Bonin Islands -- known in Japan as the Ogasawara Group -- some 1,000 kilometers south of Tokyo and asked the Japanese government for permission to dock but the request was refused, the reports said.

According to Chang, after learning about the captain's request, the MOFA started negotiating with Tokyo. Japan's Fisheries Agency agreed to let the fishing boat pull into shore, but its Immigration Bureau had concerns on how to handle the boat and its crew, he added.

While Taiwan and Japan were still negotiating on the details of the matter, the captain of the Taiwanese fishing boat decided to head back to Taiwan, as weather conditions had improved with Typhoon Melor's movement away from the area, Chang said.

"Humanitarian aid is a universal value, and the Japanese government promised to protect the safety of the Taiwanese captain and his chief engineer, but it was concerned about how to handle the eight Indonesian crew members and the boat," Chang said.
With the boat now heading back to Taiwan, the Coast Guard Administration embarked on a mission later Tuesday afternoon to escort it home, which would take 8-9 days, he added.
The MOFA has also asked Japan to send a coast guard vessel to protect the Taiwanese boat on its way back, but the Japanese government has yet to respond to that request, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air Force fully compensated for damage to missiles: ministry

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Air Force has received full insurance reimbursement in the amount of NT$6.1 million (US$189,765) for the repairs to eight sparrow missiles that were damaged in 2007 during delivery by Taiwan Railways, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday.

Due to poor handling by Taiwan Railways, the missiles fell against each other while being transported in March 2007 and the rocket propulsion systems on eight of them were damaged, MND spokesman Yu Si-zu said at a press conference Tuesday.
Replacement of the damaged propulsion systems cost NT$6.1 million and was fully reimbursed by Mingtai Insurance Company, which provided coverage of the delivery in 2007, the spokesman said.
All eight systems have been replaced by Air Force technician teams and the damaged ones were disposed by Chung-shan Institute of Science and Technology, he added.

Addressing the safety issue, Director of Air Force Logistics Division Hsu Guo- lan said that all the relevant rules and procedures were followed during the delivery process, with Air Force personnel providing escort all the way.
Hsu said Mingtai Insurance Company, which agreed in 2007 to pay the full damage claim, was seeking compensation from Taiwan Railways.

DOC.HEADLINE: 67 percent of Taiwan's enterprises to hire employees in Q4: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly 67 percent of Taiwan's enterprises plan to recruit employees in the fourth quarter of this year, in a sign that its economic climate is taking a turn for the better, the results of a survey showed Tuesday.
According to the 104 Job Bank survey, salesmen are most wanted by the enterprises planning to hire new workers in the current quarter.

Sales representatives accounted for 37.3 percent of all the talent to be hunted, followed by marketing personnel which made up 15.6 percent of sought-after talent, and engineering R&D personnel at 12.2 percent, the survey showed.

Enterprises in the monetary and insurance sectors topped the list of local companies which want to hire new staff, followed by those in the health care and environmental protection, IT, construction and real estate, and manufacturing sectors, in that order, according to the survey.
The enterprises cited a need to have more salesmen to cope with the growth in business.

The survey also found that 35.6 percent of the people who are currently employed and whose salaries have remained unchanged for the past two years, plan to look for another job, mostly as salesmen, in a bid to get higher pay and to expand their public connections.

Employees in the health care and environmental protection sectors get the highest pay, with average annual salaries reaching NT$758,000 (US$22,830), followed by those in the IT sector with NT$650,000 in salary, the mass communications sector with NT$634,000, and the transportation and manufacturing sectors, both at NT$600,000.

Chiu Wen-jen, director general of marketing for the 104 Job Bank, said that on average, college graduates who serve as salesmen earned NT$2,000 more monthly than their counterparts working in administrative jobs in the beginning, but the gap in pay may expand to 23 percent three years later and even to 34 percent after five years.

Huang Wen-yao, head of the bank's China Man Hunt Department, said that Taiwan's sales talents have been welcomed in the mainland's job market because of their high sense of loyalty, responsibility and flexibility.
The survey conducted between Sept. 8-14, had 4,998 valid respondents, and a margin of error of 1.39 percentage point.
The 104 Job Bank is one of the largest human resources service Web sites in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daily folic acid intake helps reduce cancer risk: local research

TEXT.P: Adequate folic acid intake can help reduce cancer risk, particularly the risk of incurring breast cancer, a local researcher said Tuesday.

"Eating a plate of dark green vegetables daily could help lower the risk of breast cancer by 20 percent to 40 percent, " said Sun Chien-an, a professor at Fujen Catholic University's Department of Public Health.
"Eating a bit of pork liver occasionally is also helpful in reducing cancer risk," he added.

Sun made the comments based on the findings of a research project that he has been conducting over the past 10 years at the request of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) on the correlation between local people's folic acid intake and the risk of cancer.

Sun said his research team analyzed the findings of the 1992-1996 national nutrition surveys, conducted blood tests on residents in two townships -- Hsinchu County's Jhudong and Chiayi County's Putzih -- and tracked the changes for more than 10 years.
Moreover, the team factored in information from databanks that recorded the condition of local cancer patients and causes of death, Sun said.

According to the findings of the research project, the incidence of breast cancer among the group of people who took more than 415 micrograms (mg) of folic acid daily was 25 percent lower than among those whose daily intake of folic acid was less than 260 mg.

The research also found that the incidence of breast cancer was 44 percent lower among those who had folic acid concentrations of more than 17.2 nanogram (ng) per 100 milliliters (ml) in their blood than among those who recorded folic acid concentrations of 7.2 ng or less per 100 ml.

A further analysis of the data collected in the study showed that the incidence of various forms of cancer among those whose daily folic acid intake exceeded 415 mg over the past 15 years was only 8 percent, as compared to 9.7 percent among those whose daily intake fell below the daily minimum.
"These findings indicate that foods rich in folic acid can help ward off cancer," Sun said.
Speaking on the same occasion, Lin Hsueh-jung, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, said people's daily folic acid intake should increase with age.

"For those younger than 4, the daily intake of folic acid should be no less than 200 mg, and for those aged 13 and over it should be more than 400 mg," Lin said, adding that the minimum daily intake for pregnant women should be at least 600 mg.

Noting that folic acid is a water-soluble vitamin necessary for human cell division and growth, Lin said it is found widely in natural foods, including dark green vegetables such as asparagus, broccoli and cabbage, as well as in whole grains, beans, animal livers and foods containing yeast.

"One can get 400 mg of folic acid by eating 17 small stems of asparagus or 2.25 bowls of broccoli, " Lin said, adding that people who eat out often can get adequate amounts of folic acid from vegetable salads and yeast.

According to the results of national nutrition surveys, the intake of folic acid among local people tends to be less than half of the suggested amount and the deficiency is most serious in the 13-18 age group.

Lin said foreign researchers have also found that adequate folic acid intake can significantly lower the risk of colorectal cancer and can also help prevent many other forms of cancer, including cervical cancer, liver cancer, lung cancer, colon cancer and gastric cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai Cultural Week to open in Taipei Oct. 15
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/09 19:42:15 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Shanghai Cultural Week is slated to kick off in Taipei City Oct. 15, a top Shanghai official in charge of cultural and publicity affairs said Tuesday.

The event will feature 15 kunqu (a form of Chinese opera) performances, acrobatics and other artistic performances at Zhongshan Hall in downtown Taipei Oct. 15-22, said Ying Mingda, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the Shanghai Administration of Culture, Radio, Film and TV.
Ying said he will travel to Taiwan with five colleagues Oct. 11 to make arrangements for the staging of the promotional event.

A group of officials in charge of cultural affairs from Shanghai and Beijing, including Zhu Yonglei, director of the Shanghai Administration of Culture, Radio, Film and TV who is also deputy director-general of the Bureau of Shanghai World Expo Coordination, are expected to arrive in Taiwan Oct. 14, Ying said.
Other prominent members of the official group will include Ai Qingchun, a former vice minister of China's Ministry of Culture, according to Ying.
The cultural week, which is part of efforts to promote the Shanghai Expo in Taiwan, will also feature a four-week exhibition of art works from the Shanghai Art Museum.
More than 170 performers and officials are expected to arrive in Taiwan in groups for the cultural week, Ying said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan creates new teaching material to turn kids on to literature

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government released Tuesday a set of supplementary teaching material for elementary school students to help them learn modern Chinese literature in a fun way.

To raise the children's interests in reading, the new reading material - which are geared towards students in the third to sixth grades - contain poems, fairy tales, short stories and articles, county Education Bureau officials said.
Some of the material were recommended by school children, who shared with the education bureau the kind of things they enjoy reading.

The articles feature various topics, including a modern life the children are familiar with, a fantasy kung fu world created by Chin Yung, a famous Chinese kun fu novel writer, and a world of celebrities including Taiwanese pitcher for the Yankees Chien-Ming Wang and popular pop singer Jay Chou, the officials said.

The new teaching material, which took over 20 scholars and teachers a year to compile, contain 96 articles of contemporary writers, which are packed in four volumes of books, according to the county government.
County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said he hopes students can learn in an easy and amusing way with the new Chinese-language literature supplementary material.
The material will be distributed to each elementary school in the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plans to trim budget for next fiscal year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government plans to cut its projected expenditures for next year by NT$4.8 billion to improve efficiency in the utilization of government funds, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday, while giving a report to the legislature on the central government's budget for the next fiscal year.

The NT$4.8 billion had originally been earmarked for the purchase of helicopters by the Ministry of the Interior for disaster relief work, the implementation of several transportation infrastructure projects and the construction of the Hushan Reservoir in Yunlin County. These planned expenditures have now been canceled.

The revised budget for next year will be NT$1.735 trillion, which will be used mainly to boost economic development and to pay for disaster reconstruction and prevention in light of Typhoon Morakot, which caused widespread destruction in Taiwan in August, killing more than 600 people.
The new Cabinet made the budgetary adjustments after withdrawing the general budget bill drawn up by the previous premier's Cabinet and resubmitting it to the Legislative Yuan for further review.
According to the new general budget bill, the projected expenditures of NT$1.735 trillion will be down NT$74.7 billion from the current fiscal year.
If projected revenues of NT$1.552 trillion, down NT$121.2 billion from the current fiscal year, are realized, there would be a deficit of NT$183 billion, Wu said.
The government will have to take out a loan of NT$249 billion to plug the deficit and meet the NT$66 billion in its debt repayments, according to Wu.

The new budget plan calls for a special budget for infrastructure construction projects aimed at stimulating the economy. That portion of the budget will be the biggest expenditure, totalling NT$192.2 billion, up NT$43 billion from the current fiscal year.

Some NT$84.5 billion will be used for landslide and flood prevention and control, up NT$9.6 billion from fiscal year 2009, with the aim of preventing flood damage and disasters and safeguarding the life and property of the country's people, Wu said.
Also on the priority list are: strengthening anti-epidemic work, promoting industrial and economic development, and establishing an efficient national social safety net, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Parma total NT$29.5 million

TEXT.P: Losses in the agricultural sector from Typhoon Parma totaled NT$29.53 million, with Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan suffering the heaviest damage, the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Tuesday.

Torrential rain brought by Typhoon Parma Sunday and Monday in eastern Taiwan's Yilan and Hualien counties caused NT$11.43 million in damage to farms and local agriculture, while related facilities sustained damage of NT$18.1 million, according to the latest COA statistics.

Some 80 percent of the high-end Sanhsing green shallot grown in Yilan was destroyed in the flooding caused by the typhoon, a situation that is expected to push up the price of the crop in retail markets.

The Sanhsing farmer's association said that in 10 days time the output of locally grown green shallot might be only half of the normal level. The COA forecast that the production will return to normal in at least one month.
Yilan's green shallot crops account for 15 percent of the total amount grown nationwide.

Although Typhoon Parma did not make landfall on Taiwan, its outer bands brought as much as 1,500 mm of rainfall to Yilan, causing flooding in some 30 locations and triggering mudslides in several townships.
More than 800 residents in danger zones were evacuated between Sunday night and Monday morning. There were sporadic reports of accidents in the area, but no reports of deaths.

As of Tuesday morning, the floods in most of the inundated townships had receded. Across the country, traffic at 22 locations on highways and bridges was either closed or suspended as a result of the typhoon.

Meanwhile, traffic on the Suhua Highway, which links Yilan and Hualien, remained closed due to rockfalls and mudslides at six places along the road. The highway is expected to be fully reopened by Wednesday.
On Tuesday morning, the Northern Link Railway, which was damaged on Monday, was repaired and two-way traffic had resumed.

As Typhoon Parma moved away from Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau lifted its sea warning against the storm Tuesday afternoon, but warned that the south eastern regions of the country and the Hengchun Peninsula on the southern tip should expect torrential rain.

DOC.HEADLINE: 29 overseas businesses prepared for Taiwan listing

TEXT.P: Recent efforts by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) to encourage overseas businesses to be listed in Taiwan have borne fruit, with 29 overseas companies having applied with the TWSE for guidance on how to do so, TWSE officials said Tuesday.
Since the start of this year, TWSE executives have visited China, Hong Kong and various countries in Southeast Asia in a bid to persuade Taiwanese businesses there to list their stocks on the TWSE.

Most of the 29 companies that have expressed interest in doing so are Taiwanese businesses based in China and Hong Kong, while U.S. hi-tech companies from Silicon Valley form the second-largest group, the officials said.

Among the Taiwanese businesses are the 85 C cafe chain, Tingyi Holding Corp., which owns the instant noodle brand Master Kong, IC designers Himax Technologies and Silicon Motion Technology Corp., and monitor manufacturer TPV Technology, they said.
Meanwhile, Mill Con Steel Industries PLC of Thailand has recently applied with the TWSE to offer Taiwan Depositary Receipts (TDR).
Yorkey Optical International and New Focus Auto Tech Holdings, whose TDRs have been approved for trading, will officially list their shares on the TWSE within the fourth quarter, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Museum to cooperate with Chinese counterpart, will not loan pieces

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) will continue to cooperate with Beijing's Palace Museum, but will not loan its treasures to its Chinese counterpart, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said Tuesday.
According to Chou, such loans do not fall into the category of cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation.

She made the remarks at a news conference to promote an exhibition of 246 artifacts from the period of the Qing Dynasty Emperor Yongzheng at the NPM scheduled to open the following day and featuring artworks on loan from Beijing's Palace Museum.

Both Chou and Beijing's Palace Museum Director Zheng Xinmiao, who arrived in Taiwan Monday for the exhibition, said the show will be the culmination of cross-strait exchanges and cooperation over the past six months.

Asked whether, since Beijing has loaned pieces to the NPM for the show, it will in turn ask the NPM to loan parts of its collection to the Beijing museum, Zheng said that "we are still discussing and planning the matter."
Chou said that under a consensus reached between the two museums Feb. 15, they have "put aside name designation and law in favor of substantive cooperation at the present stage."
"After deep and wide cultural exchanges, it will be only natural for further exchanges and cooperation," she added.
The cooperative and exchange programs announced by Zheng and Chou include the establishment of a video conference system and linkage by the end of this year.
The two museums will also continue with cross-strait cooperation to work on future exhibitions.
Zheng noted that his museum will sponsor a seminar on the resumption of a Palace Museum publication this November and will invite NPM Deputy Director Fung Ming- chu to attend.
In addition, Chou will be invited to attend an academic symposium sponsored by Beijing's Palace Museum in October 2010, Zheng said.
The museums will also discuss cooperation on developing cultural creative products and combating copyright infringement problems, as well as new cooperative projects and museum file exchanges.

Chou made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing's Palace Museum in February -- the first of its kind in 60 years -- and Zheng made a reciprocal visit to Taiwan in March, during which matters regarding cross-strait cooperation on a joint Yongzheng exhibition were discussed.
Chou said earlier that Taiwan's legislation in 1992 of the Statute on Encouraging and Rewarding Cultural and Art Enterprises had made the exhibition possible.
"Under the statute, exhibits from museums in Beijing and Shanghai are exempt from seizure or any legal entanglement over ownership, " she said.
"Taiwan's art and cultural objects could also be displayed in China once a similar statute is put in place there to grant them the same protection," she added.
The Yongzheng exhibition, featuring the life, culture and art of his 13 years in power from 1722 to 1735, will be held at the NPM from Oct. 7 through Jan. 10 next year.

A total of 246 artworks related to Yongzheng, including 203 items from the NPM's Qing Dynasty collection, 37 from Beijing, two from the Shanghai Museum, three from Academia Sinica and one owned by a Taipei-based pharmaceutical company, will be on show at the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to strengthen ties with EU after Lisbon Treaty takes effect

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) vowed Tuesday to work even harder than before to strengthen ties with the European Union, as the EU Parliament will gain power and significance after the Lisbon Treaty takes effect.
Prominent changes in EU structure and politics will take place once the treaty comes into effect in January, as it aims to streamline decision-making and reform the blocs structures.
These changes include more qualified majority voting in the Council of Ministers and increased involvement of the European Parliament in the legislative process.

"The integration within the EU will march a step further when the Lisbon Treaty takes effect, and we will have to put more value on the EU and strive to strengthen bilateral relations with the European body and its member states,said Chiu Jong-jen, director-general of the MOFAs Department of European Affairs, at a regular press briefing.
According to Chiu, while Taiwan will continue to consolidate its friendship with EU member states, the MOFA will also work harder to increase contacts within the European Parliament.
Doing so will help to broaden the Taiwan-friendly atmosphere in Europe, the MOFA believes.

The Lisbon Treaty will lead to the creation of a president of the European Council with a term of two and half years and a High Representative for Foreign Affairs to present a united position on EU policies.
So far, the Czech Republic and Poland are the only two EU member countries yet to ratify the treaty, which is expected to enter into force Jan. 1, 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open representative office in Sapporo
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/06/09 20:37:49 (By Mike Chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: In a move aimed at further cementing relations with Japan, Taiwan is opening an additional representative office in the Hokkaido Prefecture capital of Sapporo, officials at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) in Japan said Tuesday.

With the official opening of TECRO's Sapporo branch Oct. 24, to be presided over by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin- pyng, the number of Taiwan's representative offices in Japan will increase to six -- in Tokyo, Yokahama, Naha, Sapporo, Osaka and Fukuoka.

The officials said the Sapporo branch aims especially to serve the 300,000 Taiwanese tourists who visit Hokkaido each year, as well as to provide assistance to Taiwanese fishing vessels and fishermen who operate in northern Pacific waters and use the port of Kurhiro in Hokkaido as a major operations base.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top coffee chain plans stock listing by Q2 next year

TEXT.P: The overseas holding company of Taiwan's top coffee chain 85 degree C Cafe is planning to list the stock on the Taiwan market by the second quarter of 2010, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.
The 85 degree C Cafe chain, which is named after the ideal temperature at which to brew coffee, will be the first Taiwanese coffee house to seek local stock listing.

The coffee chain is also expected to be selected by MOEA later this month as one of the top Taiwan global brands in 2009, the official said, but declined to provide further details on grounds that the company was planning to list on the local market.

In addition to its Taiwan business, the holding company Gourmet Master Co. has expanded the coffee shop chain into China, Australia and the U.S., with total revenue from business in the four countries reaching NT$3.4 billion in 2008 and profits close to NT$500 million, the company reported.

The chain, which sells a cup of house coffee at NT$35 (US$1.08), opened a new store in central Taiwan's Taichung City last month -- its 400th shop worldwide. It plans to increase that number to 500 by the end of this year, according to a report on the company's Web site.
The 85 degree C Cafe opened its first U.S. chain in September 2008, and has since recorded the highest monthly revenues worldwide from business in that country.
It entered the China market in 2007, taking substantial market shares in the big cities. It has opened 46 shops in Shanghai in just 19 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tough talk from premier on illegal wiretapping by authorities

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih had some tough words on illegal wiretapping by law enforcement officials Tuesday, saying that agency heads will be sacked if any government official is found to have conducted illegal wiretapping in violation of human rights protection principles.
Wu made the remarks while fielding questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao at a Legislative Yuan plenary session.

Lai asked why two law enforcement agencies' 2009 budgets will only be slightly less than their 2008 amounts even though the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) announced recently that the number of wiretaps has declined by 70 percent.

According to Lai, the 2009 budgets for the Investigation Bureau and the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the Interior Ministry will only be 1.97 percent and 10 percent less than their 2008 figures, respectively, as listed in the central government's budget plan.
"It seems to me that the two agencies are still procuring wiretapping equipment, " Lai said, adding that the premier should do something in this regard.
He demanded that Wu make a commitment on eliminating unwarranted wiretapping by law enforcement agencies.
Under the existing law, Wu pointed out, wiretapping in criminal investigations requires prior approval by judges.

"Without judicial endorsement, no wiretapping is allowed. If any official dares to conduct unauthorized wiretaps in violation of President Ma Ying-jeou's order and human rights protection principles, their superiors will be dismissed," Wu said.
"Like the members of the public, the government also hates illegal eavesdropping," he added.

Meanwhile, Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng told Lai that the 2009 budget plans for law enforcement agencies cannot be used as a gauge of the accuracy of her announcement of a 70 percent decrease in the number of illegal wiretaps.

"The 70 percent decrease was referring to comparison between the numbers of warranted wiretaps recorded in 2008 and 2007. In the past, wiretapping just needed the sanction of prosecutors, but the rules have changed and it now requires the approval of judges, " Wang pointed out.
She further noted that law enforcement officers who conduct illegal or unsanctioned wiretaps will be subject to prison terms ranging between six months and five years.

Stressing that prosecutors offices around the country have conducted regular checks on whether law enforcement officials have engaged in illegal eavesdropping and provide up with quarterly reports for the ministry, Wang said she will order a feasibility study on whether to set up a special hotline for the public to report suspected illegal wiretaps.

DOC.HEADLINE: New AIT deputy director assumes office

TEXT.P: Eric H. Madison assumed his duties as deputy director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Oct. 2, according to an AIT press release Tuesday.
Madison, who is a career foreign service officer, served most recently as economic counselor at the American Embassy in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia during the past year, the AIT said.
Prior to that, he served as deputy counselor in the Economic Section at the American embassy in Beijing, China, it added.
This is Madison's second stint with the AIT, having served as deputy chief in the AIT's Economic Section from 1992 to 1995, after two years of Chinese language training, the AIT stated.

A Washington, D.C. native, Madison is a French literature graduate from Dartmouth College and was a Fulbright Scholar at the University of Constance in Germany where he earned a diploma in German literature, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three government-run funds report gains

TEXT.P: Thanks to strong showings in the global stock markets and on the local bourse, three major government-run funds have registered profits over the past few months, according to figures released Tuesday by various government agencies.

As of Sept. 29, the net value of the retirement fund for public functionaries had amounted to NT$422.9 billion (US$13.16 billion) , compared with NT$409.4 billion in 2007 and NT$349.5 billion in 2008, when the financial crisis began to take hold, according to statistics compiled by the Management Board of the Civil Service Pension Fund.

Some 56 percent of the fund's total amount was used for fixed income investments, down from 63 percent at the end of June. About 44 percent was used for securities investments, up from 37 percent at the end of June, the statistics reveal.

As of the end of August, meanwhile, realized and unrealized gains from the civil service pension fund had reached NT$51.26 billion, which translated into an annual rate of return of 20.56 percent. The fund is expected to deliver even more brilliant performance in September, as the local stock market rose by around 10 percent for that month.

Taiwan's labor pension fund, with a total capital scale of NT$908.6 billion, had made a total of NT$75.98 billion as of the end of August, which translated into an annual rate of return on investment of 8.88 percent, the fund's administrator said Tuesday.
The gains were sufficient to offset NT$60.5 billion in losses incurred last year and netted NT$15.4 billion in surplus.
Around 25 percent of the fund's total amount was used for equity portfolio investments, according to the administrator.

Since the second quarter of this year, the economies in the United States and Europe have shown signs of bottoming out and local and foreign stock markets have staged a strong rebound, leading to gains for the labor pension fund over the past few months.

The labor insurance fund, which suffered NT$50 billion in losses last year due to the negative impact of the global financial crunch, also had made NT$28.8 billion in gains as of the end of August, according to the fund's manager.
The gains were not yet enough to offset the significant losses of NT$50 billion incurred last year, the manager added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Revenue increasing in Central Taiwan Science Park

TEXT.P: The revenue of the Central Taiwan Science Park (CTSP) has continued to increase, reaching NT$46.9 billion (US$1.46 billion) for the July-August period, a sign that the local economy is steadily recovering from the global financial crisis, officials at the CTSP Administration said Tuesday.
The amount represents a growth of 21 percent from the May-June period, 59 percent from the March-April period and 147 percent from the January-February period, the officials said.
Contributing the largest share to the July-August period was the photonic industry, which generated NT$36.8 billion in revenue, accounting for 78.49 percent of the total, they said.
Revenue from the semiconductor sector accounted for 19 percent, while the precision machinery sector accounted for 2.07 percent, they added.
The CTSP Administration expressed optimism that the park's revenue for 2009 will achieve its target amount of NT$216.4 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese trade group visits Argentina
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 5 (CNA) 10/06/09 21:35:29 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A trade delegation organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) received an enthusiastic response during a visit Monday to the Argentine capital of Buenos Aires.
According to the Taiwan representative office in Argentina, it has arranged 230 meetings between delegation members and over 100 local manufacturers.

The delegation is comprised of 33 representatives from 22 Taiwanese manufacturers, who are promoting products that include metal valves, plastic products, textiles, auto and motorcycle parts and components, and machine tools and facilities, as well as electronic products.

Taiwan's representative to Argentina, Li Hsin-ying, wished every success to the trade group, saying that Taiwanese and Argentine industries can complement one another and that there is room for further development.

He noted that Argentina has recently facilitated the issuing of visas for Taiwanese people wishing to enter the South American country, and he encouraged Taiwanese, especially businessmen, to take the opportunity to tour or do business there.
The trade group, which arrived in Argentina Saturday, was scheduled to travel to the second leg of its South America visit -- Brazil -- after winding up its Argentina visit Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 22nd swine flu death reported

TEXT.P: A 42-year-old farmer from Cishan township in Kaohsiung County died Sunday from influenza A(HIN1) , becoming the 22nd victim of the epidemic in Taiwan, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reported Tuesday.

The death was the first in Kaohsiung County out of a total of 25 confirmed cases of the disease, according to the health bureau of the county in southern Taiwan. Six of the patients remained hospitalized as of Tuesday.

The man, who suffered from hypertension, diabetes and lung disease, died Oct. 4 at a Kaohsiung university hospital after his condition rapidly deteriorated despite being given the anti-viral Tamiflu and placed on life support.
He was admitted to the hospital Sept. 30 after developing fever and a cough -- typical symptoms of swine flu.
The man lived with his parents, as well as the family of his older brother. His brother was discharged from hospital Tuesday after being treated for a cold.
The health bureau urged the public to stay on high alert against influenza A(HIN1) as the peak seasonal flu period approaches.
Meanwhile, a free inoculation program is slated to kick off next month to encourage the public to get vaccinated against H1N1, according to Chou Chih-hau, CDC deputy director-general.
Chou said the DOH will offer NT$150 (US$4.63) per head in subsidies to local health care institutions that offer the H1N1 vaccinations.
"The amount is enough to pay for registration fees and medical examination fees for each citizen who receives H1N1 inoculation at designated hospitals, clinics or health centers," he noted.
The priority list designated by the DOH for H1N1 vaccination is led by typhoon- affected victims, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, and pregnant women.

They are followed by pre-school children, seriously ill patients, elementary, junior and senior high school students, individuals in the 19-24 age bracket and those over 25 at high risk of cardiopulmonary disease, healthy people in the 25-49 age bracket, and those aged between 50 and 64.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. visa applications in Taiwan moved to Manila: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that a recent decision by the British government to move visa applications in Taiwan to be processed in Manila from Oct. 5 was made because the number of visa applications has decreased significantly since March 3, when Taiwanese passport holders were granted 6-month visa-free entry to the United Kingdom.

Chiu Jong-jen, director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, made the remarks at a regular press briefing, saying that "the decision might sound bad to us, but it is certainly not the case."

The U.K. Border Agency recently announced changes to the processing of visa applications in Taiwan, saying that Taiwanese passport holders who still require a U.K. visa will continue to make their applications in Taiwan in the usual way, but from Oct. 5, the applications will be sent for processing at the agency's new regional center in Manila, according to a recent press release from the Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO).

"The change is to consolidate the U.K.'s immigration expertise in visa centers of excellence such as Manila, to enhance the quality of decision-making. Visas from Japan, Republic of Korea, and Hong Kong are already being processed in Manila," the press release noted.

Since March 3 this year, the U.K. has waived visa requirements for Taiwanese passport holders traveling to the U.K. for less than six months, and from March to July, the number of Taiwanese visitors to the U.K. was up by 30 percent compared with same period of last year, according to statistics published by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau.

According to the BTCO, there will be no change in the visa application process for people who still need a visa for the U.K. and no additional costs will be incurred, although there might be an increase in the turnaround time.

"To ensure that travelers have a smooth trip to the U.K., we encourage everyone to make their applications well in advance of any planned journey to the U.K. Applications can be accepted up to three months in advance of the proposed date of travel, " BTCO Director David Campbell was quoted as saying in the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agencies with low rates of budget execution to be penalized

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will unveil within one month a set of criteria for punishing government agencies with low rates of execution of major infrastructure construction projects that are part of an economic stimulus plan, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday.

Wu made the promise during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session after ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lo Shu-lei suggested that the Executive Yuan penalize public agencies failing to execute the special budget plan in a prompt and efficient manner.
Lo especially pointed finger at the Ministry of Economic Affairs, saying that 99 percent of the special construction projects with which it has been tasked have not been executed.

In response, Wu said that he will direct two Cabinet-level bodies -- the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission and the Public Construction Commission -- to step up supervision of progress in major infrastructure construction projects and to work out criteria within one month for the punishment of agencies with low rates of budget execution.
Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang rebutted Lo's accusation, saying that his ministry was "not as slow" in carrying out budget plans as Lo claimed.

"The 99 percent rate was for June, when the special public construction budget plan had been in force for just two months. By the end of September, 53.5 percent of major infrastructure construction projects under the charge of my ministry had been implemented," Shih said.

During the same legislative session, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators grilled Wu about what they described as the government's exaggeration of the economic benefits of closer engagement with China.

DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said China's imports increased 25.6 percent last year, but its imports from Taiwan only rose 7.8 percent, indicating that the KMT administration's eased trade and economic policy toward China has not generated as many benefits as touted by the government.

In response, Wu said trade should be based on reasonable and mutually beneficial terms. "We cannot unilaterally ask China to procure our products, " he pointed out, adding that Taiwan should endeavor to sharpen its competitive edge in order to export more products to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to treat all typhoons as if they were Morakot: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the government will make the best preparations possible against future typhoons as if they were as devastating as Morakot, which lashed Taiwan in early August.
Morakot swept past Taiwan Aug. 7-9, causing flooding and landslides unseen for 50 years, which killed nearly 700 people and left thousands homeless.
Ma made the remarks during a visit to the Central Emergency Operations Center after sea warning for Typhoon Parma was lifted earlier in the day.
He said that the center will continue to operate and provide necessary assistance to local emergency centers before returning to situation normal.
According to the center's estimate, one person died in flooding caused by Parma, while 33 areas were inundated, with agricultural losses totaling NT$38.38 million (US$1.19 million).
"The number of people evacuated was 7,863 this time, compared with around 6,400 evacuated from the affected areas during Typhoon Morakot," he noted.
During Typhoon Parma, the number of people evacuated from heavy rainfall areas of Taipei, Yilan and Hualien counties was 1,300.
He said that this time, the number of people evacuated in non-flood areas was five times those in flood areas, showing that residents were much more alert to the potential for danger.

Even before Parma hit Taiwan, relevant Cabinet officials visited different areas of the country to communicate with local governments on evacuation, while the military also deployed servicemen on standby in potential disaster areas.
"The disaster prevention measures this time will be used for reference in preparations against future typhoons," the president said.
The government was harshly criticized for its slow response to Typhoon Morakot, which led to the resignation of then-Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMBA alliance plans to launch cross-strait business leaders forum

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese universities that provide Executive MBAs (EMBAs) announced Tuesday the formation of an alliance to promote intercampus course exchange.

The alliance will also seek cooperation with Chinese universities -- including Xiamen University, Fudan University, Peking University and Nanjing University -- to launch a cross-Taiwan Strait business leaders forum, said Yang Chien-min, CEO of National Chengchi University's (NCCU's) EMBA program.

Other members of the EMBA Education Alliance are National Sun Yat-sen University, National Chiao Tung University, National Tsing Hua University, National Cheng Kung University, National Central University, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, and National Chung Cheng University.

According to Yang, hi-tech management, management of small- and medium-sized businesses, "refined living, " digital content and cultural creativity are areas in which Taiwan holds an advantage, and integration of the existing resources is essential to enhancing their value.

With this in mind, NCCU will launch a high-level business leader program in October that will offer three sub groups -- global entrepreneurship; cultural creativity, hi-tech management and information application; and international finance -- Yang said.
A total of 78 openings will be available, open to people with at least 12 years of work experience, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 250 overseas compatriots meeting in Taipei

TEXT.P: Some 250 overseas compatriots from 12 European countries and the United States are attending an Oct. 4-10 program in Taiwan in which they have met with Cabinet officials and will make sight-seeing trips to various parts of the country.

Since 1975, representatives of overseas Chinese associations and academic societies in Europe have met annually in leading European cities, in assemblies organized by overseas communities in the host cities. The organizer of the 35th assembly, the Chinese Association in Hamburg, decided early this year to meet in Taipei during the Double Ten national day festivities.

On Oct. 4-6, the attendants heard a series of briefings from Cabinet officials on the nation's policies regarding foreign affairs, China affairs, overseas Chinese affairs and economic development, and in the next few days, sight-seeing trips to the outlying island of Kinmen and various scenic spots on the east coast have been arranged.

While no national day celebrations will be held Oct. 10, the overseas compatriots will visit the mausoleum of the late President Chiang Kai-shek at Tzuhu and the mausoleum of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo at Touliao, both in Taoyuan County, on that day.

There are approximately 1 million overseas Chinese in Europe, mostly living in Britain, France and the Netherlands, according to statistics compiled by the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission under the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's academia hails scientist's Nobel Prize

TEXT.P: Taiwan's academia was jubilant Tuesday over Academia Sinica Academician Charles K. Kao's winning of the 2009 Nobel Prize in physics.

Kao, a Chinese American who was awarded the Nobel for breakthroughs in fiber optics research, has been an academician at Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's most prestigious research institution -- since 1992.
Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong, who was attending a conference in Japan, said in a telephone interview that he was very happy to learn that Kao had won the top academic honor.
The institution also issued a press statement expressing its gratification at Kao's securing of the Nobel accolade.

Kao, 75, shares half of the US$1.4 million prize "for ground-breaking achievements concerning the transmission of light in fibers for optical communication, " the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, which awards the prize, said in a statement.

The other half of the prize is shared between two other American scientists -- Willard S. Boyle and George E. Smith -- "for the invention of an imaging semiconductor circuit -- the CCD sensor, " the Swedish academy said.
According to Academia Sinica Vice President Liu Chao-han, Kao is one of the pioneers of fiber optic communication.
"His greatest contribution has been a discovery that led to a breakthrough in fiber optics and facilitated the communications revolution," Liu said in the Academia Sinica statement.

"His calculation about how to transmit light over long distances via optical glass fibers essentially taught us how electrical cables can be changed to optical fibers for communication and was nothing less than a revolution. Even now, most of the communications industry relies on fiber optics, " Liu said, adding that Kao's discovery inspired the communications industry more than any other.
"When he was President of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, he cultivated many talented young people. On behalf of the Academia Sinica I would like to congratulate him heartily, " added Liu.
Kao was born in Shanghai. He received his Bachelor of Science degree from the University of London in 1957 and his Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from the same university in 1965.
He was President of The Chinese University of Hong Kong from 1987 to 1996 and later served as director of engineering at Standard Telecommunication Laboratories in Harlow in the U.K.
While Kao used to travel to Taiwan to attend Academia Sinica's annual conference after he was elected an academician in 1992, he has not visited for several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT to voice opposition to tax on investment-linked insurance

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) will call on Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu to voice its opposition to Taiwan's decision to tax income from investment- linked insurance products, an ECCT official said Tuesday.

Chris James, chairman of ECCT's insurance committee and president of Allianz Insurance Taiwan, said at a press conference that it would be a mistake for Taiwan's government to levy tax on income from investment-linked insurance products, as doing so will simply increase insurers' operating costs and impact the public's confidence in long-term investment.
As a result, he added, the government's tax revenue will not necessarily grow.

Defending investment-linked insurance policies, James said that these kinds of insurance products, which are transparent, flexible and offer higher returns, can meet the needs of the insured in taking out insurance policies while giving them the benefits of long-term investment and thus complementing the shortcomings on the part of Taiwan's existing social security system.

On July 24, the Tax Reform Committee under the Executive Yuan adopted a resolution to treat earnings from unit- linked insurance products as taxable income. Gains of up to NT$270,000 are tax-exempt under the existing exemption for interest income, but amounts beyond that would be subject to taxation.
The committee also suggested that proceeds from policies where the policy holder and beneficiary are not the same person be subject to a 10 percent gift tax on benefits of over NT$2.2 million.
The proposal met immediate objections from both the American Chamber of Commerce Taipei (AmCham) and the ECCT.

The ECCT, founded in 1988, is the foremost organization championing the business interests of European companies in Taiwan. It now has around 650 individuals and 370 firms from more than 25 industries as members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 7, or the 19th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build the model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1958: Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the Republic of China government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but adds that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of the society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday, moving up 81.74 points at 7,617.79 on a turnover of NT$5.04 billion (US$156.62 million).
The weighted price index gained 98.07 points, or 1.31 percent, to close at 7,536.05 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT to voice opposition to tax on investment-linked insurance

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) will call on Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu to voice its opposition to Taiwan's decision to tax income from investment- linked insurance products, an ECCT official said Tuesday.

Chris James, chairman of ECCT's insurance committee and president of Allianz Insurance Taiwan, said at a press conference that it would be a mistake for Taiwan's government to levy tax on income from investment-linked insurance products, as doing so will simply increase insurers' operating costs and impact the public's confidence in long-term investment.
As a result, he added, the government's tax revenue will not necessarily grow.

Defending investment-linked insurance policies, James said that these kinds of insurance products, which are transparent, flexible and offer higher returns, can meet the needs of the insured in taking out insurance policies while giving them the benefits of long-term investment and thus complementing the shortcomings on the part of Taiwan's existing social security system.

On July 24, the Tax Reform Committee under the Executive Yuan adopted a resolution to treat earnings from unit- linked insurance products as taxable income. Gains of up to NT$270,000 are tax-exempt under the existing exemption for interest income, but amounts beyond that would be subject to taxation.
The committee also suggested that proceeds from policies where the policy holder and beneficiary are not the same person be subject to a 10 percent gift tax on benefits of over NT$2.2 million.
The proposal met immediate objections from both the American Chamber of Commerce Taipei (AmCham) and the ECCT.

The ECCT, founded in 1988, is the foremost organization championing the business interests of European companies in Taiwan. It now has around 650 individuals and 370 firms from more than 25 industries as members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's academia hails scientist's Nobel Prize

TEXT.P: Taiwan's academia was jubilant Tuesday over Academia Sinica Academician Charles K. Kao's winning of the 2009 Nobel Prize in physics.

Kao, a Chinese American who was awarded the Nobel for breakthroughs in fiber optics research, has been an academician at Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's most prestigious research institution -- since 1992.
Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong, who was attending a conference in Japan, said in a telephone interview that he was very happy to learn that Kao had won the top academic honor.
The institution also issued a press statement expressing its gratification at Kao's securing of the Nobel accolade.

Kao, 75, shares half of the US$1.4 million prize "for ground-breaking achievements concerning the transmission of light in fibers for optical communication, " the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, which awards the prize, said in a statement.

The other half of the prize is shared between two other American scientists -- Willard S. Boyle and George E. Smith -- "for the invention of an imaging semiconductor circuit -- the CCD sensor, " the Swedish academy said.
According to Academia Sinica Vice President Liu Chao-han, Kao is one of the pioneers of fiber optic communication.
"His greatest contribution has been a discovery that led to a breakthrough in fiber optics and facilitated the communications revolution," Liu said in the Academia Sinica statement.

"His calculation about how to transmit light over long distances via optical glass fibers essentially taught us how electrical cables can be changed to optical fibers for communication and was nothing less than a revolution. Even now, most of the communications industry relies on fiber optics, " Liu said, adding that Kao's discovery inspired the communications industry more than any other.
"When he was President of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, he cultivated many talented young people. On behalf of the Academia Sinica I would like to congratulate him heartily, " added Liu.
Kao was born in Shanghai. He received his Bachelor of Science degree from the University of London in 1957 and his Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from the same university in 1965.
He was President of The Chinese University of Hong Kong from 1987 to 1996 and later served as director of engineering at Standard Telecommunication Laboratories in Harlow in the U.K.
While Kao used to travel to Taiwan to attend Academia Sinica's annual conference after he was elected an academician in 1992, he has not visited for several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMBA alliance plans to launch cross-strait business leaders forum

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese universities that provide Executive MBAs (EMBAs) announced Tuesday the formation of an alliance to promote intercampus course exchange.

The alliance will also seek cooperation with Chinese universities -- including Xiamen University, Fudan University, Peking University and Nanjing University -- to launch a cross-Taiwan Strait business leaders forum, said Yang Chien-min, CEO of National Chengchi University's (NCCU's) EMBA program.

Other members of the EMBA Education Alliance are National Sun Yat-sen University, National Chiao Tung University, National Tsing Hua University, National Cheng Kung University, National Central University, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, and National Chung Cheng University.

According to Yang, hi-tech management, management of small- and medium-sized businesses, "refined living, " digital content and cultural creativity are areas in which Taiwan holds an advantage, and integration of the existing resources is essential to enhancing their value.

With this in mind, NCCU will launch a high-level business leader program in October that will offer three sub groups -- global entrepreneurship; cultural creativity, hi-tech management and information application; and international finance -- Yang said.
A total of 78 openings will be available, open to people with at least 12 years of work experience, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agencies with low rates of budget execution to be penalized

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will unveil within one month a set of criteria for punishing government agencies with low rates of execution of major infrastructure construction projects that are part of an economic stimulus plan, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday.

Wu made the promise during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session after ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lo Shu-lei suggested that the Executive Yuan penalize public agencies failing to execute the special budget plan in a prompt and efficient manner.
Lo especially pointed finger at the Ministry of Economic Affairs, saying that 99 percent of the special construction projects with which it has been tasked have not been executed.

In response, Wu said that he will direct two Cabinet-level bodies -- the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission and the Public Construction Commission -- to step up supervision of progress in major infrastructure construction projects and to work out criteria within one month for the punishment of agencies with low rates of budget execution.
Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang rebutted Lo's accusation, saying that his ministry was "not as slow" in carrying out budget plans as Lo claimed.

"The 99 percent rate was for June, when the special public construction budget plan had been in force for just two months. By the end of September, 53.5 percent of major infrastructure construction projects under the charge of my ministry had been implemented," Shih said.

During the same legislative session, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators grilled Wu about what they described as the government's exaggeration of the economic benefits of closer engagement with China.

DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said China's imports increased 25.6 percent last year, but its imports from Taiwan only rose 7.8 percent, indicating that the KMT administration's eased trade and economic policy toward China has not generated as many benefits as touted by the government.

In response, Wu said trade should be based on reasonable and mutually beneficial terms. "We cannot unilaterally ask China to procure our products, " he pointed out, adding that Taiwan should endeavor to sharpen its competitive edge in order to export more products to China.
