DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Shaolin disciple dreams up a kung fu school

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer
When Chang Ching-kuo dropped out of school and occasionally ran away from home at the age of nine, his future looked bleak.

Then, inspired by the films of Ashton Chen, a child kung fu star of the early 1990s, the Keelung native successfully begged his father to send him to the Songshan Shaolin Temple Film and TV Kungfu Academy in China's Henan province.
The move saved Chang's life, and now he harbors the dream of using martial arts training to help troubled youths, just as the Shaolin academy helped him.
"My biggest dream is to set up a nine-year martial arts school to help kids and teenagers who have lost their way to lead normal lives and build up their moral integrity," Chang says.
The idea crosses the 27-year-old's mind every time he sees children or teenage wasting their times in the streets or in Internet cafes.
"Seeing this always makes me feel that a kung fu school would be good for helping those kids get back on the right life path, " he says.

"Learning martial arts such as kung fu is really tiring and requires single- mindedness, but my personal experience is that kids like to spend some time studying after completing their kung fu practice for the day."

Chang speaks from experience. His parents were divorced when he was only two years old, leaving his grandmother to look after him. But she was too old to properly care for him, and he started running away from home and regularly missing classes after entering elementary school.
"Every member of my family thought I was hopeless, " he recalls ruefully.

In 1990, he entered the Songshan Shaolin Temple Film and TV Kungfu Academy -- an umbrella facility authorized by the Chinese government to teach children basic martial arts. There, Chang studied kung fu for five years.
"Those days were beset with difficulties, and it took me several years to adapt to the extremely restrictive and disciplined environment," he recalls.

"Apart from getting only bland meals, we had to get up at 4: 50 a.m. every day and start our training routine by running around the base of two nearby mountains. With senior students chasing us with whips, we had to run faster than rabbits," Chang says.
The students were also subjected to physical discipline by older students when their kung fu movements did not measure up.
"Our thighs often bore bruises, " Chang remembers, and resting in the dormitory often provided little respite from the daily hardships.

"During the night, more than 20 people would sleep on a two-level bed in a dormitory of about 100 square meters, " Chang says. "During the summer, we had to endure temperatures of 40 degrees Celsius without air conditioners or fans, while in the winter, we faced temperatures below zero while meditating."

After five years of basic training at the academy, it was recommended that Chang attend the Songshan Shaolin Temple Monks Training Base Mission in 1994 and he became the first disciple from Taiwan of the Shaolin Temple at a time when relations across the Taiwan Strait were still sensitive.
He then was allowed to take part in a warrior monk group and performed around China in the following years until he returned to Taiwan in 2000 to serve his mandatory military service.

That, however, marked the start of a fresh setback in his private life. With just an elementary school education, he had trouble finding a well-paid job in Taiwan despite his martial arts mastery and ended up working in odd jobs as a construction worker, private security guard and waiter.
Not until he appeared on a local TV show in 2007 did he achieve some level of recognition, but even then, he was criticized for "fishing for fame."
In the face of the mounting criticism, Hua Lin, secretary-general of the Taiwan Zen Buddhist Association, came to Chang's defense, praising his martial arts skills as a genuine accomplishment.

"Chang's hard qigong, such as punching, flying kicks, swordplay, iron head and weapon wielding, is really amazing and is evidence that Chang has mastered the techniques of the so-called 18 types of Chinese martial arts," Hua said.

The association now frequently invites Chang to teach Shaolin martial arts in different regions of the country. He also returns to the Songshan Shaolin Temple every year or two to perfect his techniques.
Speaking of the years he spent mastering kung fu in China, Chang attributes everything to destiny.
"I do not regret all the years I spent learning kung fu in China, even if I missed the chance to go to college in Taiwan, because it taught me to be a righteous man."

Passionate about contributing to society, Chang regularly shows his concern for the underprivileged, visiting the Taichung Drug Abuse Treatment Center in central Taiwan to help addicts with their rehabilitation.
He also stages qigong performances for charity at nursery schools and institutions for the mentally challenged.
Establishing a kung fu school, though, remains Chang's major pursuit.

"Learning kung fu can help kids achieve a healthy state, both mentally and physically," he says. "As Abbot Shi Yan Zhang told me, a kung fu practitioner is nothing without a strong sense of morals. The main tenet of kung fu is to cultivate one's moral character."

Hearing that the Miaoli County government is planning to establish a kung fu school next year, Chang wonders when his chance will come, acknowledging that his goal remains no more than a distant dream hindered by stiff challenges.
"Lacking support from the government or the private sector, it is a very difficult task," he laments.
Chang says, however, that he will not be deterred from his goal because he really wants to do something for troubled and temperamental children.

"My experience in Shaolin Temple made me aware that adults must find an appropriate method to educate this kind of hyperactive child, who can easily become a good for nothing by missing school or running away from home."

DOC.HEADLINE: 100 Chinese couples to get married in Taiwan by year-end

TEXT.P: One hundred Chinese couples are expected to visit Taiwan by the end of this year to get married and go on their honeymoon, an emerging trend in cross-Taiwan Strait tourism, a travel agent said Wednesday.

The first group of 15 couples from Jiangsu province arrived in Taiwan Monday. They were offered a mass wedding ceremony at the Taipei 101 skyscraper Tuesday before setting off on an around-the-island honeymoon tour.

According to Yao Yingjun, general manager of the VIP department of Jiangsu-based China Travel Service, having their wedding overseas is becoming increasingly popular among young Chinese, with the Indonesian island resort of Bali and Boracay Island in the Philippines being the hottest picks.
The wedding-honeymoon packages to Taiwan also appeal to Chinese couples because more wedding traditions have been preserved in Taiwan than in China, Yao said.
The fact that mass Taiwanese weddings are often witnessed by government officials is also fascinating, he said.

Couples taking part in the wedding-moneymoon packages can choose from two themes: "trendy Taipei" and "romantic Kenting, " and they can also choose whether to travel around Taiwan or just part of the island, Yao said.
As such packages require a month of preparation, the next group of couples is not expected to come until early November, he said.
An around-the-island wedding-moneymoon package costs 16,000 Chinese yuan, or NT$77,000, per couple, including the costs of a wedding banquet, bridal gown and wedding photo services.

Zhu Jianfeng and Shen Jing, one of the couples who participated in the first wedding-moneymoon tour to Taiwan, said they decided to join the tour because they were attracted to the idea of having a wedding at Taipei 101 and thought the price charged was very reasonable.

Another couple, Yuan Hui and Chen Qi, said their first impressions of Taiwan were passionate and romantic, and that getting married at the world's tallest building was a very special experience that they will remember for the rest of their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to commemorate 60th anniversary of Kuningtou battle

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will invite former Kinmen commanders and veterans of the Battle of Kuningtou to a ceremony in Kinmen on Oct. 25 to commemorate the battle that kept the outlying island out of the communists' hands.

As part of its campaign to mark the battle, the MND has also launched essay competitions, art exhibitions, and seminars leading up to the main event, the opening ceremony for the Peace Memorial Square on Oct. 25, Deputy Defense Minister Huang Yi-bing said Wednesday.
Huang explained that the battle is being commemorated so that people will remember historical lessons and create a peaceful environment for future generations.
The Battle of Kuningtou began on Oct. 25, 1949, when Chinese communist warships carrying over 10,000 troops landed on Kuningtou, located on the northwestern tip of the main island of Kinmen.
After three days of battle, on Oct. 27, the nationalist army defeated the communists after forcing the surrender of thousands of communist troops.

The victory, which boosted the sagging morale of the nationalist forces, which were on the retreat after losing the Chinese civil war, frustrated the communist attempt to take control of Kinmen and its advance toward Taiwan.

Kinmen County Magistrate Li Zhu-Feng also suggested Wednesday that the MND consider establishing a military museum in Kinmen to preserve discarded weapons, an idea that the MND's Huang said the military would fully support.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday:
UNITED DAILY NEWS:
Should portrait of Deng Xiaoping hang on Tiananmen Square gate?

As China marked its 60th founding anniversary, most worth celebrating was its good fortune that the Communist Party of China (CPC) has been transformed from Mao Zedong's communism to Deng Xiaoping's communism.

After over 30 years of openness and reforms spearheaded by Deng, the present CPC has in fact dismissed Mao, even though it still upholds Marxism and Maoism and hangs Mao's portrait on the Tiananmen Square gate.

That's because if Chinese leaders openly criticize Mao, the party's legitimacy could be questioned. Yet though Mao's portrait still hangs in Tiananmen, China is in practice moving away from and rejecting Mao's thought.

There is a long way to go for China's transformation. The day the portrait of Mao is removed from the gate, it may be the day when its transformation is nearly complete. LIBERTY TIMES: People will not sit idly by as entertainers ingratiate China and officials sell out Taiwan
One entertainer said in his blog recently that China will definitely become powerful, while another expressed his congratulations on the birthday of the great motherland.
These entertainers, eying the potential market in China, are despicable because of their ingratiating manners.
But what's more abominable is the blatant tilt toward China by Taiwan's political and business leaders.

President Ma Ying-jeou accepts the so-called "one China" consensus to denigrate Taiwan into a region under China. Even though he claims "no unification, " he is following the approach of pursuing closer cross-strait economic ties to promote unification.

When China resorts to canceling the visits of Chinese tourists to Kaohsiung to pressure it not to screen a documentary on a Tibetan political activist, Premier Wu Den-yih was in league with China when he said "you want me to shop more in your place, but you do things that make me uncomfortable, then I'd better not shop there."
These officials are abominable as well as horrible. President Ma is counting on the sugar-coated drug of China for a better economy, which will lead to the eventual swallowing of Taiwan by China.

These political and business leaders who sell out Taiwan may lead a prosperous life because their pay from China, but the future generations will suffer and lead miserable lives. CHINA TIMES: Time to solve the overdue health insurance payment problem
Over the past six months, the pro-DPP media has doggedly pursued the issue of the Taipei City government owing billions in back health insurance premiums.

The reason, of course, is that the issue involves President Ma Ying-jeou from his time as Taipei mayor. As mayor, Ma filed suit against making the overdue payments and asked for a constitutional interpretation because he believed it was unreasonable for Taipei to contribute to the premiums of those who worked but did not reside in the city.
Even though the administrative court and the grand justices ruled that the Taipei City government should pay, this problem is still not solved.

Local governments around Taiwan owe more than NT$60 billion in health insurance premium payments. The government has already borrowed over NT$90 billion from the banks to tide over the health insurance system's difficulties, so the actual book loss is only around NT$30 billion.

If the Department of Health (DOH) wants to raise health insurance premiums mainly because of financial shortfalls caused by the large sums owed by local governments, then it will be hard to convince the public that health insurance premiums have to be hiked.

A total of nine cities and counties owe back health insurance premiums. The biggest debtor is Taipei City, which owes approximately NT$36.7 billion, followed by Kaohsiung City, which owes around NT$18.7 billion.

At the same time that the government considers raising premiums, it must also resolve the local government debt problem rather than focusing on the NT$30 billion deficit. But to solve the problem, President Ma must make his views on the issue clear. Otherwise, nobody in the Cabinet will dare deal with Taipei's debts. APPLE DAILY: (A) Bureau of Military Intelligence only good at internal strife
The bitter internal strife within the Bureau of Military Intelligence and its involvement in corruption cases has led to indictments and personnel changes.

The bureau is the most secretive within the intelligence community and has strong factions. In recent years, it has been infiltrated by China, seriously debilitating its counter-intelligence capability.
This, coupled with warmer cross-strait relations, has left the unit with nothing to do but to engage in internal strife.

It is worrisome because the unit is responsible for gathering military information from the enemy. If it is demoralized, it will be at the mercy of the enemy, damaging national interests. (B) A buck-passing government

The fickle attitude of the Yilan County government has drawn the ire of its residents, as the government changed its mind several times on whether or not to close schools and offices because of Typhoon Parma.
Premier Wu Den-yih was right when he said that the matter should be left for local governments to decide because it is more aware of the situation on the frontline.
During Typhoon Morakot, both the central and local governments were criticized. That's why this time, the officials thought of only passing the buck to evade their responsibility.
This shows how blurred the lines of responsibility are and how weak-minded these officials can be.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 72.61 points, or 0.96 percent, to close at 7,608.66.
The local bourse opened at 7,617.79 and fluctuated between 7,619.03 and 7,562.9 during the day's trading session.
A total of 5.54 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$160.94 billion (US$5 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 3.81 percent. Banking and financial shares advanced 2.58 percent, cement stocks rose 2.23 percent, construction issues gained 2.19 percent, foodstuff issues were up 2.04 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 1.69 percent, plastics and chemicals shares advanced 0.95 percent, and machinery and electronics shares increased 0.12 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,560 to 1,089, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$9.63 billion-worth of shares for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bolder cross-strait investment policy to be put in place: official

TEXT.P: Instead of a "bird cage" policy, the government will adopt a bolder cross-Taiwan Strait investment policy to avoid Taiwan's marginalization in East Asia, in an attempt to mitigate the effects of a regional trade bloc to be formed by China and Southeast Asian countries in 2010, a government official said Wednesday.

San Gee, vice chairman of the Cabinet level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , outlined the government's stance concerning cross-strait trade and economic links while giving a speech on Taiwan's challenges and opportunities in an emerging Asia-Pacific market at the 2009 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference being held Oct. 7-8 in Taipei.
"The government is set to put forth more opening measures to allow greater Chinese investment to enter Taiwan, " he said, without detailing a timetable.

"To ward off the negative impact of an economic integration in the region on Taiwan, which is excluded from the regional trade bloc, the government is poised to adopt a more open and bolder cross-strait investment policy to help Taiwanese companies secure their market shares in the Chinese market," San said.

"Asian emerging economies, particularly China, will be markets full of business opportunities in the future," he went on. "China has recovered rapidly after the global economic crisis broke out a year ago, and is expected to have become the world's largest economy by 2030, with a middle class population of about 44 million," he said.

In the face of Taiwan's exclusion from regional trade blocs, the government should seek to break the isolation through setting up cross- border partnerships such as free trade agreements under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), he contended.
"Cross-strait economic activities must be normalized so as to help Taiwan offset its absence from regional trade organizations through two-way cooperation with China," San added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two newcomers make Taiwan's top 20 global brand name list

TEXT.P: Two companies and their brands have vaulted into the Taiwan Top 20 Global Brand list for the first time in 2009 with their high brand values and good business prospects, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Wednesday.

The two new entries are Want Want Group, a food processing company from Taiwan that operates over 100 factories in China, and CyberLink Corp., a multimedia software company that produces DVD playback, digital home, television and burning software, according to a TAITRA statement.
Want Want, which had sales of US$1.55 billion in 2008, was selected because of its dominance in the Chinese market, where 93 percent of its sales were generated last year, the statement said.
CyberLink was recognized for outperforming others because of the global momentum of multimedia applications.
The two firms were among 20 companies that have been selected in leading global brand consultancy Interbrand's Taiwan Top 20 Global Brands survey for 2009.

Other brand names making the list this year are, in alphabetical order, Acer, Advantech, Asus, Depo, D-Link, Genius, Giant, HTC, Johnson, Master Kong, Maxxis, Merida, MSI, Synnex, Transcend, Trend Micro, Uni-President and Zyxel.

According to TAITRA figures, this year's top 20 brands in Taiwan are worth US$8.67 billion, a 5.1 percent drop compared to the previous year, which Interbrand said is because of the global economic crisis last year that caused the value of the world's top 100 brands to fall by 4.6 percent.

"Great visions and investment in technology innovations are reasons why these companies create such impressive brand values, " Interbrand noted, but it suggested that the brands explore markets other than the United States and China to diversify risk.
This is the seventh year that Interbrand has collaborated with TAITRA and BusinessNext magazine to identify Taiwan's 20 most valuable brands by brand value.

To rank the brands, Interbrand uses a combination of analysts' projections, company financial documents, and its own qualitative and quantitative analysis to arrive at a net present value of the brands' earnings.
The final ranking and brand values of this year's Taiwan Top 20 Global Brand survey will be revealed Oct. 16 in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA promotes farm animal welfare in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) is holding the 2009 Farm Animal Welfare Forum in Taiwan Oct. 6-7, with an aim to help the local livestock industry understand the development trends in animal husbandry worldwide.

In an effort to improve livestock welfare in Taiwan, the COA has invited five keynote speakers -- animal welfare experts from the United States, Great Britain, Belgium and Canada -- to speak on matters relating to farm animal welfare, humane transport and slaughter management.

The five keynote speakers are John Webster, emeritus professor of animal husbandry at the University of Bristol; Donald M. Broom, a professor of animal welfare at the University of Cambridge who has served on the committees of the Council of Europe and The World Organization for Animal Health; Ian J.H. Duncan, a professor at the univgersity of Guelph in Canada; Stephen Wotton, a senior lecturer in food animal science at the University of Bristol; and William Benjy Mikel, professor and head of the department of food science, nutrition and health promotion, and director of the Food Science Institute at Mississippi State University.

According to the COA, Taiwan has implemented and executed legislation on animal welfare and in the future, the best international practice and developments in humanely raised farm animals will be implemented here.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science parks' performance signals economic recovery: NSC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy seems to have bottomed out and is now in recovery, judging from the sharp decline in the number of furloughed workers, increase in revenues, new investment projects and increased water and electricity consumption at three major science parks in the country over the past few months, the National Science Council (NSC) reported Wednesday.

The assessment was part of a report delivered by NSC Deputy Minister Chen Lih- juann on the performance of the Hsinchu Science Park, Southern Taiwan Science Park, and Central Taiwan Science Park for the period January to August this year.

The number of workers on unpaid leave at the three major science parks had dropped sharply to 2,377 as of the end of September, down 98 percent compared to the record high of about 130,000 in January, according to Chen.
In January, employees on unpaid leave accounted for 66 percent of the total work force at the three parks, but as of Sept. 30, the percentage was only 1.2, Chen said.
Meanwhile, business turnover at the parks between January and August totaled NT$930.3 billion (US$28.91 billion), which represented a monthly growth rate of 11.7 percent, he reported.
In August alone, business turnover was NT$154 billion, about 94 percent of the year-earlier level, he said.

After the global financial crisis broke in September last year, turnover at the parks dropped significantly, hitting a low of NT$71.9 billion in January, less than half of the year-earlier level, according to figures compiled by the NSC.
Monthly turnover at the parks in the first half of 2008 was around NT$160 billion to NT$170 billion, the statistics showed.
Overall business turnover at the three parks is expected to rebound in September to the level before the global financial crisis erupted, Chen predicted.
The NSC also adjusted upward its forecast for business turnover at the three parks this year to NT$1.59 trillion from the NT$1.41 trillion it had projected in August.

The total investment in new projects at the three parks during the first eight months of this year was 96.6 percent of the amount for the same period last year, while the capital increase in existing projects during the period was in excess of last year's level, the tallies show.

Between January and August this year, Chen said, 40 new investment projects worth NT$41.45 billion were approved for the three parks, while 37 companies increased their investment capital in existing projects by a total of NT$87.74 billion.

In July and August, 20 newly approved companies became operational at the three parks, while 17 companies increased their investment capital, Chen reported. The value of all the new investment and capital increase in existing projects was NT$114.58 billion, 24 times the amount for January and February, he added.
In addition, in August, electricity and water usage at the parks increased by 26 percent and 63 percent, respectively, compared to January, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC to fund hospital costs for compulsorily isolated H1N1 patients

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) will foot the hospital bills of patients who are compulsorily isolated with influenza A(H1N1) infection, an official said Wednesday.

According to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Jih-haw, the new flu strain is categorized as a Category 4 notifiable disease, for which local health authorities may decide at their discretion whether to enforce compulsory isolation of infected patients.
In the event that patients are isolated against their will, their hospital costs will be funded by the CDC, Chou said.

Chou made the explanation following a complaint by the Consumers' Foundation that many hospitals require private room accommodation -- which is covered only partially by the National Health Insurance -- for influenza A(H1N1) patients, leaving the patients to foot the expensive bills themselves.
The findings were obtained through a survey of 14 hospitals in Taipei City and Taipei County conducted Sept. 21-23, according to Consumers' Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen.
The results show that five, or 35.7 percent, of the hospitals do not allow such patients to stay in three- or four-bed wards, which are fully covered by National Health Insurance.
Among the five hospitals, Taipei City Hospital Yang Ming Branch, Chung Shan Hospital and Wang Fang Hospital strictly require such patients to stay in private rooms.

While Chang Gung Memorial Hospital only allows swine flu patients to share a three- or four-bed ward with other patients suffering from the same disease, Cathay General Hospital requires patients to be separated from each other if they are accommodated in three- or four-bed wards.
The survey also found that eight, or 57 percent, of the hospitals will make the patients pay for the cost of private accommodation.

These hospitals are Taipei City Hospital Yang Ming Branch, National Taiwan University Hospital, Cathay General Hospital, Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Far Eastern Memorial Hospital, Tri-Service General Hospital, Chung Shan Hospital and Taiwan Adventist Hospital.
To better prevent the spread of the disease, the foundation demanded that the CDC make hospitals set up special isolation areas for swine flu patients and pay for related costs.

Also responding to the foundation's complaint, Tsai Shu-ling, manager of the Medical Affairs Section under the Bureau of National Health Insurance, said the bureau will launch an investigation into the situation.
If any hospitals are found to have charged any compulsorily isolated patients, they will be asked to provide refunds, Tsai said.

Statistics released that day by the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) show that there were 11 more patients hospitalized with the H1N1 flu strain than a day earlier, bringing to 332 the total number of such cases since the outbreak began.
While 26 of the patients remained in hospital, 284 had recovered and had been discharged, and 22 others had died, the CECC said.

As of 4 p.m. Tuesday, 351 classes in 252 schools around the country remained suspended because of H1N1 infections among students. The number of affected classes accounted for 0.23 percent of the total, according to the CECC.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar remains unchanged on Taipei Forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, closing at NT$32.180.
A total of US$1.05 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.200 and reached a low of NT$32.050.

DOC.HEADLINE: NBA star meets fans in Taipei ahead of pre-season game

TEXT.P: On the day before the first ever pre-season National Basketball Association (NBA) game in Taiwan, Chauncey Billups, a point guard for the Denver Nuggets, met with more than 300 fans at Taipei Gymnasium Wednesday.
Billups, a three-time All Star, said in Chinese, "I support my team, " adding that basketball is a team sport and everyone needs to play their part well.

Billups said he is very honored to be part of the first team to play a pre- season game in Taiwan, and promised to do his best in Thursday's game. The Denver Nuggets will play the Indiana Pacers at 7:30 p.m. Thursday at Taipei Arena.
Several players from the local Super Basketball League (SBL) were also at Wednesday's event, at which Billups gave young basketball players some tips on how to move on the court.
The NBA star also gave a demonstration of his shooting skills, winning a "three- point shootout" against Lee Xue-lin, a point guard for Taiwan's Yu Long.
During a practice session at noon on Thursday, Denver Nuggets forward Carmelo Anthony said he is looking forward to seeing how crazy Taiwanese fans will get at Thursday's game.

The 4,000 available open tickets for the NBA pre-season game were sold out 15 minutes after they went on sale, despite the fact that the prices, ranging from NT$800 (US$25) to NT$12,800, were the highest ever for any basketball game in Taiwan.
After their game on Thursday, the Pacers and Nuggets will move on to China for another pre-season game in Beijing on Sunday.
Taipei is the eighth Asian city to host either an NBA regular season or pre- season game, along with Tokyo, Yokohama, and Saitama in Japan; Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou in China; and Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Morgan Securities optimistic about Taiwan's economic growth next year

TEXT.P: The J.P. Morgan Securities Ltd. on Wednesday forecast a 5.5 percent growth for Taiwan's economy next year.
Taiwan's 2010 gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to grow higher than that of the United States' 3.2 percent and the European Union's 2.7 percent, according to the forecast.

Nick Lai, a research supervisor for the Taiwan area in J.P. Morgan Securities, said that the Taiwanese stock market's return rate will reach 120 percent next year, giving it the highest rate of return among all Asian markets.
Lai predicted that almost all of the technology-related stocks in the Taiwan market, with the exception of those of parts and components, will have better- than- expected profits.
He said that the rest of the shares listed in the Taiwan market will have a generally satisfactory performance except those in the plastics and chemicals sectors.

J.P. Morgan suggested that traders increase their investments in technology- related and financial shares, and reduce their holdings of communications shares, but said it would maintain a moderate stance on natural materials shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals up during China's National Day holiday

TEXT.P: Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan are expected to average 1,800 per day for the whole of the eight-day National Day holiday of China that will end Oct. 8, approximately 1.8 times the number that came last year, according to initial tallies released Wednesday by the Tourism Bureau.

However, representatives of local travel agencies noted that the number of Chinese visitors has been on the decline in recent days as the long holiday draws to an end, and is likely to fall below 1,000 per day after the holiday.

Despite visits by Chinese tourists to various scenic spots around Taiwan during the national holiday, the overall willingness of such tourists to visit Taiwan could have been affected by the influenza A(H1N1) epidemic on the island, bureau officials said.
Fewer than 40,000 Chinese tourists visited Taiwan in September -- about 1,200 a day, according to the travel agency representatives.

During the first two days of China's National Day holiday this year, the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan hit a peak of about 3,000 a day. After the holiday ends, however, arrivals are expected to dip to September's figure, or even fall to below 1,000 a day, the representatives predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NBA players coach Taiwanese children affected by Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: National Basketball Association (NBA) players, who are currently visiting Taipei for an exhibition game, on Wednesday coached Taiwanese children affected by Typhoon Morakot to help them recover from psychological trauma.

The participating children, aged 12-15, are from indigenous communities in Chiayi county and other areas that have struggled against poverty or suffered severe property losses during Typhoon Morakot, which devastated southern Taiwan from Aug. 7-10, killing more than 600 people.
The "basketball clinic" is part of the NBA Cares program that promotes social responsibility and community charity.

All of the children are sponsored by the Taiwan chapter of the Christian charity organization World Vision. NBA Cares chose to work with World Vision Taiwan because the two share a concern for children welfare.

The charity and the NBA are hoping that through playing sports, the children can begin to heal scars left behind by the trauma of the typhoon, including having to flee their homes or losing their homes, family, friends and neighbors.
"We always go through periods in life when we are down and everything has gone bad, but you always can come back. There is always a brighter tomorrow," Indiana Pacers star Danny Granger told the CNA.
Granger believes that playing sports is definitely a good way to help with the healing process for children who survived natural disasters.

"When you play basketball or whether it's baseball, you are not thinking about the problems that you're having at that given moment, so it definitely is an outlet just by an event like this," he said.
Describing himself and his teammates as big kids at heart, the 26-year-old NBA star said that playing with the children was a lot of fun.
Granger added that he is excited about sightseeing in Taipei during the visit and said he has often heard that the NBA is popular in Taiwan.
Xiao Hau, a 15-year-old boy who participated in the basketball clinic, said that he was really looking forward to the event because he is a fan of the NBA and he plays for his school team.

Taiwan will host an NBA game for the first time when the Denver Nuggets and Indiana Pacers play an exhibition game at the Taipei Arena on Oct. 8, a breakthrough for a country in which the NBA has a devoted following.

Taipei will become the 8th Asian city to host an NBA exhibition or regular season game. Japan's Tokyo, Yokohama and Saitama hosted six regular season two- game series between 1990 and 2003, while exhibitions have been held in recent years in Beijing, Guangzhou, Macau, and Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier suggests amending laws on `fat cats'

TEXT.P: If regulations governing civil servant retirement and the retirement and consolation payments for political appointee were to be amended, there would be no possible way for retired civil servants to become "fat cats, " Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday.

Wu made the remarks while responding to lawmakers' questions at the Legislative Yuan on the widely discussed matter of "political fat cats, " a term used to describe retired government officials and military officers who are hired to work in government-run companies or non-profit organizations.

Thanks to these post-retirement jobs, some of those retirees are drawing two salaries every month -- one from their previous post in the government and one from their current job, while some also enjoy a high interest rate of 18 percent on their bank deposits.
The existance of "fat cats" has recently incured increased negative sentiment in society, since many people have seen their incomes decline due to the economic downturn.

Wu said a clear law can deter retired public servants who are hired by government-affiliated enterprises and organizations as advisors or chief executive officers because of their abundant work experience and professional knowledge.

Under the existing regulations, the double salary payment is not allowed in state-owned enterprises and non-profit organizations, but is permissible in enterprises in which the government controls less than 50 percent of the shares.
Wu revealed that two draft bills have been formed to lower the government share ceiling to 20 percent, adding that they have been delivered to the Legislative Yuan for screening.

The controversy over "fat cats" arose last month after lawmakers accused the management of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) of allowing some executives to suck financial resources from the company while leaving it with heavy losses.

Though operating the high speed railway as a private concern under a 35-year BOT (build-operate-transfer) contract, THSRC appealed to the government for financial support to help defray its losses, leading many to question the compensation paid to its executives.

On Wednesday, a local tabloid newspaper pinpointed 236 "fat cats" who are retired military officers. In response to the report, Minister of National Defense Kao Hua-chu said that none of those who have retired from the ministry are receiving two salaries.
Not even those who are hired by the Veterans Affairs Commissions under the Executive Yuan after their retirement receive a double salary, Kao said.
Wu said the government has found in its probe that there are not so many "fat cats" as the media have reported. "Many have been wronged, " he said, pledging the government will deal with the issue.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) stated that it will not rule out the possibility of cutting the budget for partially government-owned institutions that "feed the fat cats with high payments."

Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang, a whip of the KMT caucus, said at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan that a resolution the legislature passed early this year rules that the government pensioners should not be offered a monthly wage of over NT$31,200 (US$970) if they are hired by an institution in which the government has at least a 20 percent stake.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet reserved about compensation for hot spring operators

TEXT.P: The Cabinet expressed reservations Wednesday over a request by hot spring resort operators in Kaohsiung County for government compensation for losses from the flooding caused by Typhoon Morakot in early August.

Lo Shih-hsiung, chief secretary of the post-Typhoon Morakot Reconstruction Committee under the Executive Yuan, said that any request for state compensation can only be achieved through the court system.

Lo also urged resort operators in the Baolai hot spring area in the county's Liouguei township to reconsider their plans to rebuild their damaged facilities on the original sites, pointing out that the increased probability of extreme flooding as a result of global warming has made the area unsafe for development projects.

The Tourism Bureau is expected to meet with the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Kaohsiung county government in the near future to discuss whether to restrict development projects there or help them obtain bailout loans from the government, Lo said.

The official made the remarks during a meeting with the Baolai hot spring resort operators, many of whom operate without business licenses and are seeking to be legalized. They include the Hsin Pao Lai Hot Spring Resort, which suffered losses of NT$670 million, and the Fun Chen Resort Hotel, which suffered losses of NT$65.6 million due to the typhoon.

Lin Kuo-bao, chairman of Hsin Pao Lai, argued that the operators should be entitled to state compensation because the flooding that devastated the hot spring areas could have been caused by improper work on a water channeling project at the Tsengwen Reservoir.

Meanwhile, Wu Chiu-lin, chairman of Fun Chen, said the unlicensed operators have received government guidance for more than six years in preparation for their legalization, and therefore should be made eligible for the government's post- Morakot bailout program for the tourism sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Palace Museum will not acquire any disputed artifacts: curator

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) will not collect any cultural relics or objects d'art whose origins are controversial or in dispute, the museum's top curator said Wednesday.

NPM Director Chou Kung-shin made the remarks while fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan session where ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-hua asked why the museum had rejected an offer by the French collector to give it two bronze sculptures of Chinese zodiac animals that date back to China's Qing Dynasty (1644-1911).
Lee was referring to two bronze heads -- one of a rabbit and the other of rat -- that were illegally seized in 1860 from Beijing's summer palace Yuanmingyuan by invading French and British forces.

The two statues later became part of the collection of the late French fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent. When they were put up for auction by the designer's partner Pierre Berge late last year, it aroused great anger in China, which demanded their return.
China's Lost Cultural Relics Recovery Fund, an activist group, filed a petition in France in an attempt to stop the auction, but the Paris tribunal rejected the petition.

The two zodiac animal heads were sold in the Paris auction in February this year for 15.7 million euros each to a telephone buyer who at the time remained anonymous. A few days later, a Chinese collector, Cai Mingchao, said that he was the successful bidder but would refuse to pay for the statues. He claimed his bid was a "patriotic act" to sabotage the auction.
The two statues have since been sitting in a safe room at Christie's auction house.

According to a Reuters report, Berge had considered donating them to a museum either in France or Taiwan. However, he said neither country wanted to exacerbate tensions with China, and added that in the end he would probably find a "brave" buyer.

Responding to Lee's questioning, Chou said she was invited by the French government to visit Paris in June. During the visit, she indeed met with Berge, who said at the time that he "would neither sell nor donate" the two pieces, she recalled.
From the perspective of professional ethics, Chou said, the Palace Museum should not collect any artworks or cultural relics whose origins are controversial or in dispute.
In response to Lee's continued grilling on the issue, Chou maintained that "as they were taken illegally... we cannot accept them, because of professional ethical principles."
During the same session, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chen Ting-fei asked Premier Wu Den-yih whether he agreed with Chou's views.
In response, Wu said he will ask the Palace Museum to clarify whether the French collector intends to sell or donate the bronze animal head to Taiwan.
"Even if the collector wants to donate the items, we should still consider the relevant ethical problems, including whether the Paris court's ruling is final," the premier added.
The National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei is home to the cream of the 1,000-year Chinese art collection held by various Chinese emperors.

Wu said all of the the museum's articles were legally transported to Taiwan during the Chinese civil war. As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been separately ruled for the past six decades, the National Palace Museum's legal status is undisputable.

Meanwhile, KMT legislative whip Lu Hsueh-chang said he agrees with Chou's stance that it is not appropriate for the Palace Museum to accept the two bronze pieces, which he said are more suitable for outdoor display.
"The KMT legislative caucus would not oppose the idea if the French collector donates the pieces to some other local museum for outdoor display," he added.

According to the Reuters report, Berge has said he would return the two pieces to China only if the country guaranteed human rights and allowed the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, to return home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Firm sees 10-15 percent rise in Taipei real estate prices

TEXT.P: The Debenham Tie Leung Property Management (DTZ) on Wednesday said that it foresees a 10 to 15 percent rise in real estate prices in the Taipei area in the fourth quarter.

Billy Yen, general manager of DTZ's Taiwan unit, one of the largest property services companies in Taiwan, said that the prices of real estate in the Taipei area can only move upward, thanks to the continuous decrease in the amount of usable land and a possible mass inflow of capital from mainland China.
Yen said that sales of the highest-priced office buildings registered negative growth in the first two quarters, but sales began to grow in the third quarter.
Yen said that Taiwan's real estate prices are lower than those of Hong Kong, and under no circumstance would Taiwan's property prices remain at the current low level.
Regarding how people should cope with the market trend, Yen suggested: "Do not sell your (real estate) easily, and buy whatever you like as long as prices are reasonable."

Taiwan on June 30 gazetted two sets of legal regulations with immediate effect governing Chinese investments in Taiwan and applications by Chinese businesses to open subsidiaries or branch offices here, paving the way for mainland capital to enter the island.
The move is widely regarded as being favorable to Taiwan's industries, especially the real estate sector.

However, people who cannot afford to buy a home - including many young Taiwanese singles or married couples living at home with their parents or in-laws - fear that an influx of Chinese investment in the sector could drive up prices to even more unaffordable levels.
Taipei's property prices, especially in centrally located areas, are already considered beyond the reach of many working professionals , even with a mortgage.
Government efforts to encourage home buying by young people has only seen minimal success.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diplomatic draftees to start service in Taiwan's allies

TEXT.P: Ninety-nine diplomatic draftees are slated to head for Taiwan's diplomatic allies around the world from late November to provide voluntary services, according to the government-funded Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund (Taiwan ICDF).

The draftees, divided into 27 technical and medical service missions, will be dispatched to the country's diplomatic allies in Asia, Central and South America, the Caribbean and Africa after completing an eight-week training program in mid-November, said a press release issued Oct. 5 by the fund, which is overseen by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The young male adults, from a diverse variety of backgrounds ranging from the high-tech sector to traditional businesses, will be performing their diplomatic service as an alternative to mandatory military conscription.

In line with international trends and in order to better serve the underprivileged people in Taiwan's diplomatic partners, college graduates majoring in financial management and industrial design have been recruited in this year's program, the press release said.
The program provides intensive training in foreign languages, cultural differences and living skills to help the draftees quickly adapt to life in the countries to which they are sent.

The Taiwan ICDF started offering the overseas volunteer service by diplomatic conscripts to its diplomatic allies in 2000, and this year's diplomatic draftees are from more than 20 different educational backgrounds -- the biggest range ever, it noted.
To date, a total of 618 young males have participated in the program, gaining practical experience in overseas volunteer work and opening a window on the world for themselves, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hosts photovoltaic exhibition

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum & Exhibition (2009 PV Taiwan), which opened in Taipei Tuesday, has drawn record participation this year, one of the organizers said.
According to Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), 236 exhibitors are displaying their products at 500 booths, as compared to 300 booths in 2008.
The exhibition, the foremost of its kind in Asia, underscores the robust industrial capabilities and R&D technologies in Taiwan, TAITRA said, adding that 1,200 buyers are expected to attend the show.

The output value of Taiwan's PV industry in 2008 was NT$101.1 billion (US$3.1 billion) and the export of PV cells was more than 900MW (megawatt), which meant that Taiwan was 4th largest production base worldwide for PV cells, TIATRA said.

The 2009 exhibition, which is being held Oct.7-9 at the Taipei World Trade Center, is expected to offer an ideal marketing platform for suppliers on every link of the supply chain, said Hong Ming-chin of TAITRA Exhibition Department.
For the first time, an HCPV (High efficiency Concentration Photovoltaics) area and a German pavilion have been set up at the annual PV show.
Some 54 foreign companies are among the 236 exhibitors at the show, TAITRA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Licensed artisans in Tainan to launch business at job fair

TEXT.P: A total of 23 artisans who have received permits from the Tainan County Cultural Affairs Department to open street booths will launch their business at a job fair Oct. 17

The artisans first had to undergo three months of vocational training offered by the Tainan County Labor Affairs Department, after which they took a licensing test, which was required for the first time in the county and which they all passed.

The county government granted certificates of qualification to the 23 artisans, which allows them to operate stalls on streets, in markets, or at government sponsored fairs, said Chen Ya-feng, an official of the county's Labor Affairs Department.
They have already created a wide variety of innovative handicraft items such as dolls made from children's socks and colored salt art works made from sea salt from Cigu in Yunlin County, Chen added.
The 23 artisans are now not only equipped with the skills to make art and craft items, but have also been trained to attract customers and market their products, according to Chen.
The employment fair will be held at Nan Jeon Institute of Technology in the southern county.

Two other local governments, Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, have been administering similar tests every year for the licensing of street artists specializing in the performing arts, visual arts and creative artifacts.
Licensed performers and artists are allowed to display their work or perform in designated public areas and accept cash contributions from the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, U.K. should strengthen partnership: British trade official

TEXT.P: Andrew Cahn, chief executive of the U.K. Trade and Investment (UKTI) -- a British government organization responsible for marketing the U.K. overseas -- said Wednesday that Taiwan and the United Kingdom should work to build a closer partnership, as it will bring mutual benefits for the two countries.

Noting that Taiwan has enormous strength in consumer electronics, and Britain is strong on creativity and design, Cahn said: "There is a natural marriage between our two economies there and I would like to see us building on that link.

Cahn made the remarks in a meeting with local media during his visit to Taiwan to share the development of the creative industry in Britain over the past 50 years, and to promote business opportunities for Taiwanese companies in the 2012 London Olympics.

According to Cahn, the UKTI is looking to partner with Taiwan because after British companies helped Taiwan host the World Games in Kaohsiung in July and Deaflympics in Taipei in September, the U.K. is hoping that in return, Taiwanese companies will use the experience developed in holding these sporting events to help London stage a very effective Games.

More business opportunities will also be created for Taiwanese companies if Taiwanese firms take part in the London Olympics, as the U.K. has close links with places that are scheduled to host other big games, Cahn said.
He was referring to South Africa, which will host the 2012 World Cup and Rio de Janeiro, which was recently awarded the rights to host the 2016 Olympic Games.
It isnt just one game, the skills which Taiwanese companies developed from the games you held, you really can go out and sell, Cahn said.

Also at the press conference Wednesday, Cahn announced the biggest single new investment to the U.K. from Taiwan, with Kenmark Industrial -- a Taiwanese firm that specializes in manufacturing liquid crystal display televisions -- having set up a factory in Corby, East Midlands in the U.K.

This investment is a great boost for the region and is very welcome. It comes at a time when manufacturers have been struggling. This vote of confidence in the U.K. and its manufacturing base will give people great confidence,Cahn said.

Kenmark recognizes that the U.K. is the best place to establish a European operation. We have a great business culture and we are the springboard from which companies can move into markets around the world,he added.

Kenmark Industrial has invested US$30 million and leased the 150,000 square-foot facility for a LCD TV manufacturing plant, which has already started operating, creating around 500 jobs over the next three years, according to the Taipei- based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO).
This new investment is one of the biggest investments to the U.K. from Asia in recent years, the BTCO said.

DOC.HEADLINE: September exports hit 11-month high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports hit an 11-month high in September, totaling US$19.07 billion, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) Wednesday.
Although the amount was 12.7 percent lower than the year-earlier level, the decline rate was the smallest for the past 11 months, said Lin Li-chen, head of the MOF's Department of Statistics.
Lin predicted that the drop in exports will slow further this month and positive growth will resume in November.
"The export growth rate will pick up even more in December, " Lin forecast.

Taiwan's exports began a steep downward streak in the fourth quarter of last year amid a global financial crisis and economic recession, but they have been spiking gradually since the beginning of this year.
"As the fourth quarter is traditionally an export boom season, we believe that the downward spiral of exports will soon bottom out, " Lin said.

Taiwan's external trade records for September also showed that its sales to major trading partners have gradually rebounded. "For instance, our shipments to China and Hong Kong posted the first positive growth after declining for 12 months," Lin noted.

While optical equipment sales to China and Hong Kong posted the first increase after a year-long slump, Lin said, the rate of decline for other major export items to the two markets has slowed over the past month.

Meanwhile, imports of capital equipment and consumer goods have also been rising steadily in recent months, indicating that private investment and consumption have gradually regained momentum, Lin added.
Compared with August, September's exports registered a marginal increase of 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, imports for September amounted to US$16.52 billion, down 3.1 percent from August and marking a 21.1 percent year-on-year decrease, which was the smallest decline in 10 months.
In September, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$2.55 billion, according to customs statistics.

Accumulated exports for the first nine months of this year amounted to US$143.82 billion, down 29.6 percent from the same period last year, while imports totaled UD$121.78 billion, down 37.8 percent year-on-year.
As a result, Taiwan enjoyed a combined trade surplus of US$22.04 billion for the nine-month period, marking a growth of 1.5 times the year-earlier level.
In September, Taiwan's shipments to its major export markets, such as the United States, Europe and Japan, all posted growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most college students need part-time jobs to meet expenses: poll

TEXT.P: The majority of college and university students in Taiwan want to find part-time jobs to help defray living expenses, according to the results of a recent survey.
The results of the 1111 Job Bank survey, released Wednesday, showed that living expenses for college students in the country average NT$64,000 (US$1,990) per semester.
Tuition and food costs are the major expenses, and 70 percent of students have to come up with some of the funds themselves, according to the online poll that was conducted Sept. 23-Oct. 6.
Some 80 percent of the students said they need to earn money to meet their expenses, and 92.52 percent said they would like find part-time jobs.

Ho Chi-sheng, the executive in charge of public relations affairs at the online employment consultant company, attributed the increasing need for part-time works among college students to tuition hikes, as well as salary cuts among working people due to the global economic downturn.
In addition, more and more students are choosing to remain in school longer to pursue advanced degrees, which has contributed to the rising demand for part- time jobs, Ho said.
The survey also found that 46.92 percent of the respondents needed to work so that they can pay their student loans.

Fubon Bank, a student loan provider in Taiwan, said it granted student loans to 57,000 people in the first half of the 2009 school year, marking a 6 percent growth compared with the same period last year.
The survey found that most students, 44.52 percent, lean towards part-time work in the food service sector because there are plenty of offers and no special vocational skills are required.
The second most popular choice was office work, favored by 34.92 percent of the respondents, followed by data entry, which was the choice of 25.79 percent of the students.
A total of 1,362 valid samples were collected for the survey, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.7 percentage point.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF delegation to visit China to promote judicial cooperation

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will visit China Oct. 18-24 to exchange views with judicial authorities there on cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in crime prevention, an SEF spokesman said Wednesday.

The group, to be led by Director of the SEF Legal Department Wu mei-hung, will comprise 10-odd officials from the Judicial Yuan, the Coast Guard Administration, the Bureau of Investigation under the Justice Ministry and the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior, said SEF Deputy Secretary Ma Shao-chang.

The group will visit the Supreme People's Procuratorate and the Supreme Court in Beijing and the Zhejiang People's Procuratorate and Provincial Higher People's Court in Hangzhou, to exchange views with judicial authorities there on ways and means of enhancing cross-strait cooperation in fighting crime.

The trip was postponed for nearly two months because of the Typhoon Morakot disaster in southern Taiwan in early August and a subsequent visit to Taiwan by the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama from Aug. 30-Sept. 4 to comfort typhoon victims.
Beijing, which sees the Dalai Lama as a separatist, had suspended several scheduled cross-strait exchange programs in a show of displeasure over the Dalai Lama's visit to Taiwan.

On behalf of the governments of the two sides, SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) signed an agreement April 26 in Nanjing on cross-strait judicial assistance and cooperation in fighting crime.

The two sides agreed to help each other in serving judicial documents and probing and collecting evidence, to confirm each other's civil judgments and arbitration awards, and most significantly, to repatriate criminals and suspected criminals. The agreement was hailed as a milestone because China has long been considered a haven for Taiwan criminals, mainly because of the absence of a repatriation agreement.
Ma also said that the SEF will go ahead with a plan to organize a delegation of Taiwan media executives to visit China to help strengthen exchanges between media enterprises on the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improving cross-strait ties will not affect relations with allies

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Wednesday that his administration's efforts to improve relations with China will by no means affect Taiwan's ties with its diplomatic allies.

Ma made the remarks while meeting with 18 senior military and police officers from five diplomatic allies in Central and South America and the Caribbean -- the Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Paraguay -- who are attending advanced study courses in Taiwan.
The president explained that his administration has been working hard to improve relations with China over the past 17 months with specific goals in mind.

"The main purpose of such efforts is to reduce tensions in the Taiwan Strait and to seek the possibility of normalizing bilateral trade and economic relations, " Ma said, adding that the drive will not affect Taiwan's long-term relationship with its diplomatic allies.
Moreover, Ma said Taiwan is willing to discuss with its allies the feasibility of extending or expanding various bilateral cooperative projects.

Over the past decades, Taiwan has organized special classes for military officers from its diplomatic allies. During the Cold War in the 1960s, it sponsored training classes for grassroots military personnel for countries in Latin America, Middle East and Africa for the anti-communist cause. Many of those students later emerged as top leaders or prominent politicians in their countries.

In recent years, the courses have focused on topics related to political and economic developments. Since the 1980s, Taiwan has also been hosting special classes for senior military and law enforcement officers from its diplomatic allies.

Ma said that during his three state visits to Central and South America since his inauguration in May 2008, he has met with many "graduates" of various training classes organized by Taiwan in past years.

"It was a special feeling to meet them in their home countries and I believe that all those training classes have helped to forge significant friendships between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hosts photovoltaic exhibition

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum & Exhibition (2009 PV Taiwan), which opened in Taipei Tuesday, has drawn record participation this year, one of the organizers said.
According to Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), 236 exhibitors are displaying their products at 500 booths, as compared to 300 booths in 2008.
The exhibition, the foremost of its kind in Asia, underscores the robust industrial capabilities and R&D technologies in Taiwan, TAITRA said, adding that 1,200 buyers are expected to attend the show.

The output value of Taiwan's PV industry in 2008 was NT$101.1 billion (US$3.1 billion) and the export of PV cells was more than 900MW (megawatt), which meant that Taiwan was 4th largest production base worldwide for PV cells, TIATRA said.

The 2009 exhibition, which is being held Oct.7-9 at the Taipei World Trade Center, is expected to offer an ideal marketing platform for suppliers on every link of the supply chain, said Hong Ming-chin of TAITRA Exhibition Department.
For the first time, an HCPV (High efficiency Concentration Photovoltaics) area and a German pavilion have been set up at the annual PV show.
Some 54 foreign companies are among the 236 exhibitors at the show, TAITRA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Licensed artisans in Tainan to launch business at job fair

TEXT.P: A total of 23 artisans who have received permits from the Tainan County Cultural Affairs Department to open street booths will launch their business at a job fair Oct. 17

The artisans first had to undergo three months of vocational training offered by the Tainan County Labor Affairs Department, after which they took a licensing test, which was required for the first time in the county and which they all passed.

The county government granted certificates of qualification to the 23 artisans, which allows them to operate stalls on streets, in markets, or at government sponsored fairs, said Chen Ya-feng, an official of the county's Labor Affairs Department.
They have already created a wide variety of innovative handicraft items such as dolls made from children's socks and colored salt art works made from sea salt from Cigu in Yunlin County, Chen added.
The 23 artisans are now not only equipped with the skills to make art and craft items, but have also been trained to attract customers and market their products, according to Chen.
The employment fair will be held at Nan Jeon Institute of Technology in the southern county.

Two other local governments, Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, have been administering similar tests every year for the licensing of street artists specializing in the performing arts, visual arts and creative artifacts.
Licensed performers and artists are allowed to display their work or perform in designated public areas and accept cash contributions from the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, U.K. should strengthen partnership: British trade official

TEXT.P: Andrew Cahn, chief executive of the U.K. Trade and Investment (UKTI) -- a British government organization responsible for marketing the U.K. overseas -- said Wednesday that Taiwan and the United Kingdom should work to build a closer partnership, as it will bring mutual benefits for the two countries.

Noting that Taiwan has enormous strength in consumer electronics, and Britain is strong on creativity and design, Cahn said: "There is a natural marriage between our two economies there and I would like to see us building on that link.

Cahn made the remarks in a meeting with local media during his visit to Taiwan to share the development of the creative industry in Britain over the past 50 years, and to promote business opportunities for Taiwanese companies in the 2012 London Olympics.

According to Cahn, the UKTI is looking to partner with Taiwan because after British companies helped Taiwan host the World Games in Kaohsiung in July and Deaflympics in Taipei in September, the U.K. is hoping that in return, Taiwanese companies will use the experience developed in holding these sporting events to help London stage a very effective Games.

More business opportunities will also be created for Taiwanese companies if Taiwanese firms take part in the London Olympics, as the U.K. has close links with places that are scheduled to host other big games, Cahn said.
He was referring to South Africa, which will host the 2012 World Cup and Rio de Janeiro, which was recently awarded the rights to host the 2016 Olympic Games.
It isnt just one game, the skills which Taiwanese companies developed from the games you held, you really can go out and sell, Cahn said.

Also at the press conference Wednesday, Cahn announced the biggest single new investment to the U.K. from Taiwan, with Kenmark Industrial -- a Taiwanese firm that specializes in manufacturing liquid crystal display televisions -- having set up a factory in Corby, East Midlands in the U.K.

This investment is a great boost for the region and is very welcome. It comes at a time when manufacturers have been struggling. This vote of confidence in the U.K. and its manufacturing base will give people great confidence,Cahn said.

Kenmark recognizes that the U.K. is the best place to establish a European operation. We have a great business culture and we are the springboard from which companies can move into markets around the world,he added.

Kenmark Industrial has invested US$30 million and leased the 150,000 square-foot facility for a LCD TV manufacturing plant, which has already started operating, creating around 500 jobs over the next three years, according to the Taipei- based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO).
This new investment is one of the biggest investments to the U.K. from Asia in recent years, the BTCO said.

DOC.HEADLINE: September exports hit 11-month high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports hit an 11-month high in September, totaling US$19.07 billion, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) Wednesday.
Although the amount was 12.7 percent lower than the year-earlier level, the decline rate was the smallest for the past 11 months, said Lin Li-chen, head of the MOF's Department of Statistics.
Lin predicted that the drop in exports will slow further this month and positive growth will resume in November.
"The export growth rate will pick up even more in December, " Lin forecast.

Taiwan's exports began a steep downward streak in the fourth quarter of last year amid a global financial crisis and economic recession, but they have been spiking gradually since the beginning of this year.
"As the fourth quarter is traditionally an export boom season, we believe that the downward spiral of exports will soon bottom out, " Lin said.

Taiwan's external trade records for September also showed that its sales to major trading partners have gradually rebounded. "For instance, our shipments to China and Hong Kong posted the first positive growth after declining for 12 months," Lin noted.

While optical equipment sales to China and Hong Kong posted the first increase after a year-long slump, Lin said, the rate of decline for other major export items to the two markets has slowed over the past month.

Meanwhile, imports of capital equipment and consumer goods have also been rising steadily in recent months, indicating that private investment and consumption have gradually regained momentum, Lin added.
Compared with August, September's exports registered a marginal increase of 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, imports for September amounted to US$16.52 billion, down 3.1 percent from August and marking a 21.1 percent year-on-year decrease, which was the smallest decline in 10 months.
In September, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$2.55 billion, according to customs statistics.

Accumulated exports for the first nine months of this year amounted to US$143.82 billion, down 29.6 percent from the same period last year, while imports totaled UD$121.78 billion, down 37.8 percent year-on-year.
As a result, Taiwan enjoyed a combined trade surplus of US$22.04 billion for the nine-month period, marking a growth of 1.5 times the year-earlier level.
In September, Taiwan's shipments to its major export markets, such as the United States, Europe and Japan, all posted growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most college students need part-time jobs to meet expenses: poll

TEXT.P: The majority of college and university students in Taiwan want to find part-time jobs to help defray living expenses, according to the results of a recent survey.
The results of the 1111 Job Bank survey, released Wednesday, showed that living expenses for college students in the country average NT$64,000 (US$1,990) per semester.
Tuition and food costs are the major expenses, and 70 percent of students have to come up with some of the funds themselves, according to the online poll that was conducted Sept. 23-Oct. 6.
Some 80 percent of the students said they need to earn money to meet their expenses, and 92.52 percent said they would like find part-time jobs.

Ho Chi-sheng, the executive in charge of public relations affairs at the online employment consultant company, attributed the increasing need for part-time works among college students to tuition hikes, as well as salary cuts among working people due to the global economic downturn.
In addition, more and more students are choosing to remain in school longer to pursue advanced degrees, which has contributed to the rising demand for part- time jobs, Ho said.
The survey also found that 46.92 percent of the respondents needed to work so that they can pay their student loans.

Fubon Bank, a student loan provider in Taiwan, said it granted student loans to 57,000 people in the first half of the 2009 school year, marking a 6 percent growth compared with the same period last year.
The survey found that most students, 44.52 percent, lean towards part-time work in the food service sector because there are plenty of offers and no special vocational skills are required.
The second most popular choice was office work, favored by 34.92 percent of the respondents, followed by data entry, which was the choice of 25.79 percent of the students.
A total of 1,362 valid samples were collected for the survey, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.7 percentage point.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF delegation to visit China to promote judicial cooperation

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will visit China Oct. 18-24 to exchange views with judicial authorities there on cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in crime prevention, an SEF spokesman said Wednesday.

The group, to be led by Director of the SEF Legal Department Wu mei-hung, will comprise 10-odd officials from the Judicial Yuan, the Coast Guard Administration, the Bureau of Investigation under the Justice Ministry and the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior, said SEF Deputy Secretary Ma Shao-chang.

The group will visit the Supreme People's Procuratorate and the Supreme Court in Beijing and the Zhejiang People's Procuratorate and Provincial Higher People's Court in Hangzhou, to exchange views with judicial authorities there on ways and means of enhancing cross-strait cooperation in fighting crime.

The trip was postponed for nearly two months because of the Typhoon Morakot disaster in southern Taiwan in early August and a subsequent visit to Taiwan by the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama from Aug. 30-Sept. 4 to comfort typhoon victims.
Beijing, which sees the Dalai Lama as a separatist, had suspended several scheduled cross-strait exchange programs in a show of displeasure over the Dalai Lama's visit to Taiwan.

On behalf of the governments of the two sides, SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) signed an agreement April 26 in Nanjing on cross-strait judicial assistance and cooperation in fighting crime.

The two sides agreed to help each other in serving judicial documents and probing and collecting evidence, to confirm each other's civil judgments and arbitration awards, and most significantly, to repatriate criminals and suspected criminals. The agreement was hailed as a milestone because China has long been considered a haven for Taiwan criminals, mainly because of the absence of a repatriation agreement.
Ma also said that the SEF will go ahead with a plan to organize a delegation of Taiwan media executives to visit China to help strengthen exchanges between media enterprises on the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improving cross-strait ties will not affect relations with allies

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Wednesday that his administration's efforts to improve relations with China will by no means affect Taiwan's ties with its diplomatic allies.

Ma made the remarks while meeting with 18 senior military and police officers from five diplomatic allies in Central and South America and the Caribbean -- the Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Paraguay -- who are attending advanced study courses in Taiwan.
The president explained that his administration has been working hard to improve relations with China over the past 17 months with specific goals in mind.

"The main purpose of such efforts is to reduce tensions in the Taiwan Strait and to seek the possibility of normalizing bilateral trade and economic relations, " Ma said, adding that the drive will not affect Taiwan's long-term relationship with its diplomatic allies.
Moreover, Ma said Taiwan is willing to discuss with its allies the feasibility of extending or expanding various bilateral cooperative projects.

Over the past decades, Taiwan has organized special classes for military officers from its diplomatic allies. During the Cold War in the 1960s, it sponsored training classes for grassroots military personnel for countries in Latin America, Middle East and Africa for the anti-communist cause. Many of those students later emerged as top leaders or prominent politicians in their countries.

In recent years, the courses have focused on topics related to political and economic developments. Since the 1980s, Taiwan has also been hosting special classes for senior military and law enforcement officers from its diplomatic allies.

Ma said that during his three state visits to Central and South America since his inauguration in May 2008, he has met with many "graduates" of various training classes organized by Taiwan in past years.

"It was a special feeling to meet them in their home countries and I believe that all those training classes have helped to forge significant friendships between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies," Ma said.
