DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 8, or the 20th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
2001: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirms that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
2001: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructs police to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
NTU makes world's top 100 university list
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/09 11:48:07 (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top school, National Taiwan University (NTU) , has made the top 100 list of the Times Higher Education--QS World University Rankings for 2009, with a ranking of 95.
It is the first time that NTU has been listed in QS' top 100 university rankings since QS Intelligence Unit began to compile the list six years ago. NTU ranked 124 in 2008.

The overall QS rankings were compiled based on six distinct indicators -- academic peer review, employer review, faculty student ratio, citations per faculty, international faculty and international students.
A total of 9,386 academics and 3,281 employers responded to the 2009 survey, an increase of 40 percent in both groups from a year ago, QS researchers said.
They attributed NTU's rise in the prestigious rankings to the fact that its scores in most of the indicators improved this year.

Nevertheless, the QS researchers suggested, if NTU and other leading universities in Taiwan intend to stand higher in the rankings or enter the top 100 list, they should make improvements in areas like international faculty and international students.
NTU and other Taiwan universities could also do better in the areas of faculty student ratio and citations, the researchers said.
Sixteen Asian universities made the QS top 100 list for 2009, with Japan's University of Tokyo ranking the highest at 22.

Further down the list were the University of Hong Kong at 24, the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology at 35, the Chinese University of Hong Kong at 46, China's Qinghua University at 49, and Peking University at 52, according to the QS rankings.

Worldwide, Harvard University held the top ranking, followed by the University of Cambridge, Yale University, University College London, Imperial College London, the University of Oxford, the University of Chicago, Princeton University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the California Institute of Technology, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kao's Nobel win shows increasing focus on applied sciences: physicist
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/09 11:53:02 (By Mandy Wong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The award of the 2009 Nobel Prize for Physics to Chinese American Charles Kao is an indication that applied sciences are receiving more and more attention, a 1957 Nobel physics laureate said Wednesday.
Yang Chen-ning, a distinguished professor at large at Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) , made the remarks when asked by the media to comment on the award to Kao, a former president of CUHK.
Both Kao and Yang are members of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious research institution.

Kao, 75, was named one of three winners of the 2009 Nobel Prize for Physics for his ground-breaking discoveries which led to the development of modern fiber- optic communication networks that transmit voice, video and high-speed Internet data around the world.

On the topic of competitive scientific research, Yang said although China still lags far behind Western countries in this field, many Chinese scientists are likely to win Nobel prizes within the next 20 years as China is gradually catching up.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mudslides risks will be factor in deciding school, office closures

TEXT.P: Mudslide risks will be taken into consideration when deciding whether to close school and offices in the event of a natural disaster, the head of the Central Personnel Administration said Thursday.

City and county governments have the authority to announce school and office closures if mudslide warnings are issued as part of disaster preparedness for typhoons, floods or earthquakes, Wu Tai-cheng said during a question and answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Wu said that in addition to wind strength, precipitation and earthquake intensity, mudslide predictions will also be used by local governments to decide whether to close schools and workplaces in the event of natural disasters.
"Within the next two weeks, the government will put forth regulations for school and office closures pertaining to mudslide risks," Wu promised.

Such announcements should be made by local governments as early as 7 p.m. and no later than 10 p.m. for the following day, and under special circumstances, no later than 5 a.m. on the day when schools and offices should be closed, he said.

He said this was one of the decisions made at a meeting of the Central Personnel Administration, relevant Cabinet-level agencies and local governments around the country Wednesday to work out a new mechanism under which the local governments could have autonomy regarding class and office closures and could simultaneously inform the central government of their decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Luxembourg sets up representative office in Taipei to strengthen ties

TEXT.P: Luxembourg's decision to open an official representative office in Taipei this week is an indication of the value it places on relations with Taiwan, the head of the office said Thursday.

"This is a part of the overall strategic economic positioning of Luxembourg in Asia, which includes setting up offices in Seoul, Shanghai, India, Dubai, Tokyo and Taipei," Hugues Mignot, the executive director of the Luxembourg Trade and Investment Office, Taipei, told CNA in a telephone interview.

"Because of the improving relations at all levels with China, the world is even more attracted to Taiwan than before, as it looks at Taiwan as a hub for improving and developing additional relations with China," he added.

Chiu Jong-jen, director-general of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) Department of European Affairs, told CNA that the Foreign Ministry welcomes the establishment of the Luxembourg office, as it will help the Western European country to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's economic and political situation and boost bilateral exchanges.
Luxembourg, one the founders of the European Union, was the 17th European entity to open an office in Taiwan.
According to Mignot, the opening of the Luxembourg Trade and Investment Office in Taipei follows a series of successful bilateral contacts between the two countries.
Mignot said there are already very strong economic links between the two sides but Luxembourg wants to develop new kinds of relationships with Taiwan.

He said he will work to reinforce the substance of the existing relations in such fields as air cargo, logistics, financial and investments funds management, Web hosting, radio and TV satellite management and shipping registration.
Taiwan and Luxembourg can also cooperate in areas of high-technology such as photovoltaic and healthcare research, he added.

Mignot, a Belgian who has served as director of the Belgium Office in Taipei over the past two decades, said that he was appointed to head the Luxembourg office because of his experience. The appointment demonstrates the diversity and openness of Luxembourg, which has three official languages and over 300,000 migrant workers from other European countries, he said.
Mignots efforts to advance substantive bilateral relations between Taiwan and Europe have been highly recognized and lauded.

In 1987, Mignot was the first to propose the establishment of a European Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan. In 2002, he started pushing for the establishment of a European Economic and Trade Office in Taipei, which was finally established in March 2003.

Other efforts of his led to the signing of the Taiwan-Belgium Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement. Furthermore, he has spared no effort in promoting cooperation agreements between the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and National Science Council, and their Belgian counterparts.
As the top Luxembourg representative to Taiwan, Mignot vowed to work on a treaty between Taiwan and Luxembourg to avoid double taxation, and to promote academic and cultural exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Weather Bureau plans to launch weather channel

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) unveiled a plan Thursday to launch a dedicated weather channel to provide the public with direct access to meteorological information.

The bureau is currently working on a joint project with Chunghwa Telecom in the hope that the proposed free TV channel would be included in the company's multimedia-on-demand (MOD) service, said CWB Director-General Shin Tzay-chyn.

According to Shin, the CWB hopes to use the TV channel not only to provide weather forecasts and information on earthquakes and typhoons, but also to educate the public about natural phenomena in a fun and lively manner.
However, it is unlikely that the channel will be launched soon, as the CWB's existing workforce cannot yet produce enough programs to maintain the operation, Shin said.
As a warm-up to its TV venture, the CWB will strengthen its video cast service on its official Web site, he said.
The video cast will presented more frequently and it will be expanded to include earthquake reports, in the addition to the weather forecasts that it currently streams online, he added.
Meanwhile, Chunghwa Telecom officials proposed that the CWB try to increase its product variety to meet public demand.
They said the company will hold further discussions with the CWB to hammer out the details of the proposed cooperation project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Conductor spreads music from world stage to rural communities

TEXT.P: "I would like to donate the proceeds from the auction to the Eden Social Welfare Foundation as a tribute to the physically disabled," he said.

"Little Henry was chosen among my many batons because it reflects many very significant moments in my life and because the twice damaged baton signifies the possibility that beautiful things, such as music, can be created out of imperfection," he explained.

The music career of the 39-year-old Chiang began long before he won the Georg Solti competition. He started as a violinist, and by the age of 15 he was already a chamber musician performing at the Munich Gasteig in Germany.

In 1990, at the invitation of Professor Alice Schoenfeld, he attended the University of Southern California (USC) where he met the man who would become his mentor, Professor Daniel Lewis. Lewis encouraged him to develop his potential to be an orchestra leader.

As a college student, Chiang performed with the USC Chamber Orchestra, YMF Debut Orchestra, Antelope Valley Symphony Orchestra, and Grand Teton Festival Orchestra. He also had the opportunity to interact with several notable teachers, including Gustav Meier, Robert Spano, John Nelson, Oliver Knussen, and Seiji Osawas at Tanglewood in Massachusetts.
Tanglewood has been the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra since 1937 and the New England resort is considered a cradle of musical talent.

Chiang, who became a Tanglewood fellow in 1995, had opportunities to pursue a music career in the United States, but the young conductor had more ambitious plans. His goal was to form an orchestra of Taiwanese musicians, take them to see the world and let the world see them.

In 1996, Chiang returned to Taiwan and soon grew busy teaching at Soochow University and collaborating with ensembles on their productions. However, he held on to his creed that "high art has a social responsibility to enlighten, to reconcile, to challenge, and to entertain the souls and minds of the people of its community."
In 1998, he founded the Philharmonia Moment Musical, a symphony orchestra of young Taiwanese musicians.

"Unlike other genres, classical music allows a good performer to work alone in his or her artistic pursuits, and consequently, musicians very often give the impression that they are not keen on team work," Chiang said.
"I believe all this can change if someone takes the lead and makes consistent and continuous efforts to coordinate the progress," he added.

The number of Taiwanese students at prominent music schools in Europe and the United States is impressive, and many of these top students have returned to Taiwan over the past two decades. In addition, classical music concerts have been drawing increasingly larger audiences of all generations.
Against this backdrop, Chiang, as musical director of Philharmonia Moment Musical, has been seeking greater international exposure for himself and the orchestra.

In 2003, he contacted Claudio Abbado, the music director and principal conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, London Symphony Orchestra and the Berlin Philharmonic orchestra, hoping to audition for the summer music festival of the Lucerne Festival Orchestra, which was founded by Abbado in 2003.

A video audition of Chiang conducting an orchestra won him the valuable opportunity to spend summer 2003 in Lucerne. In the next three years, he also took some members of the Philharmonia Moment Musical to the festival in Switzerland.

In the last two years, Chiang and Philharmonia Moment Musical have made great strides toward his goal of taking his orchestra to see the world and showing the world the standard of classical music in Taiwan.

On June 19, 2007, Chiang made a highly acclaimed New York debut at Carnegie Hall, conducting the New England Symphonic Ensemble in a program that featured Beethoven and Mozart. In August 2007, he led his orchestra on a five-performance tour of Italy and Germany.

"The invitation to the prestigious Young Euro Classic Festival in Berlin in August 2008 was a great honor for our 99-member orchestra," Chiang said. "We impressed audiences there with our interpretation of Gustav Mahler's Symphony No. 5 and with the Germany premiere of Taiwanese composer Lai Deh-ho's Concerto for pipa, bamboo flute, xiao and chamber orchestra." The highly regarded German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine gave Chiang and the orchestra a good review, saying it was no surprise that Mahler's Symphony No. 5 was performed in a Berlin concert hall, but it was impressive to see a Taiwanese orchestra established in 1998 dare to perform such a symphony, which is traditionally dubbed "an ironclad tank".
Even as he strives to make his mark internationally, Chiang has set himself the task of bringing music to local communities around Taiwan.
In addition to its performances at metropolitan concert halls, Philharmonia Moment Musical has given open-air concerts at parks and schools and played chamber music at reform schools and prisons.
"After our performances in local communities, many of our musicians have said that they found the interactive responses from people who had never sat in a concert hall very rewarding, " Chiang said.

The orchestra has given particular attention to aboriginal tribal communities, holding dozens of concerts in remote areas of southern Taiwan prior to the recent devastation that was wrought in those regions by floods and mudslides from Typhoon Morakot in August.
In the wake of the typhoon, Chiang said that he and his orchestra were especially concerned about post-disaster rehabilitation in those remote regions.
In an effort to help raise funds for typhoon victims in the affected communities, the orchestra staged a charity concert at Huashan Culture Park in Taipei on Sept 11.
The orchestra has also scheduled performance tours of southern Taiwan with the aim of brightening the lives of the people there.

"The feedback we've had from ordinary people in rural communities has invigorated our young musicians who are as convinced as I am that music can enlighten, challenge and entertain souls and minds," Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children under 9 to get two-dose H1N1 vaccine

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday that children under the age of 9 and below third grade in elementary school will be given a two-dose vaccine against influenza A(H1N1), better-known as swine flu.
The Cabinet-level DOH will determine later whether the vaccine should be administered in one or two doses to citizens over 9 years of age, the minister said at the Legislative Yuan.
The DOH has purchased 15 million doses of A(H1N1) vaccine from the Swiss pharmaceutical firm Novartis and from Taiwan's sole human vaccine manufacturer Adimmune Corp.

The minister said the H1N1 vaccine imported from Novartis will be available earlier and will be more suitable for children, therefore, it will be given to babies between 6 months and two year old, as well as to victims of Typhoon Morakot.
Medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention will receive the vaccine supplied by Adimmune Corp., he added.

Yaung added it has been a global trend for children under 9 to be put on a two- dose vaccination schedule, although effective single-dose vaccination in this age group has been reported in clinical trials in the U.K. and Australia.
The DOH has placed typhoon victims, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, and pregnant women at the top of its priority list for H1N1 vaccination.

Next on the list are pre-school children, seriously ill patients, elementary, junior and senior high school students, individuals in the 19-24 age bracket and those over 25 at high risk of cardiopulmonary disease, healthy people in the 25-49 age bracket, and people between 50 and 64 years old, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan higher education faculties underpaid: NTU

TEXT.P: Taiwan's higher education faculties are generally underpaid as compared to their counterparts in top notch universities in the world, a National Taiwan University (NTU) official said Thursday.
The relatively lower salaries offered to NTU faculty is one of the reasons why the university has not been able to hire good teachers from abroad, NTU Secretary-General Liao Hsien-hao said.
"NTU should consider adjusting its salary structure so as to entice talented professors from overseas," Liao said.

He was speaking at a news conference to publicize a report from London earlier in the day that NTU has made the top 100 list of the Times Higher Education-QS World University Rankings for 2009, with a ranking of 95.
It is the first time that NTU has been listed in QS' top 100 university rankings since the global company began to compile the list in 2004. NTU ranked 124 in 2008.

Noting that on average university faculty salaries in Taiwan are the lowest among the four "Asian dragons," Liao said he is worried that even China will surpass Taiwan soon in terms of recruiting top notch professors from abroad.
"The salary issue has also led many outstanding Taiwanese professors to seek employment in the wider academic marketplace, including the United States, Canada and Singapore," Liao added.

He praised a government initiative that was launched in 2006 to make available "NT$50 billion in five years" to boost higher education in Taiwan, saying that it has been validated by NTU's entry to the world's top 100 university rankings.
However, the allocation this year of NT$7.5 billion instead of the originally scheduled NT$10 billion under the plan has dealt a blow to the development of higher education in the country, he said.
The allocation for 2009 was reduced as a result of the global economic crunch, the outbreak of A(H1N1) influenza, and the Typhoon Morakot disaster in August.

Regarding new worries that NTU will lose its momentum now that it has entered the top-100 rankings after years of effort, Liao said the ranking is not the only index that NTU uses to assess itself, nor is it the only goal of the university.
"NTU's motto is 'duty, honor, country' and its top goals are to help students develop good character and morals in their pursuit of knowledge, " he said.

Commenting NTU's entry to the world top-100 university rankings, members of the NTU Student Association said they feel honored, but must ask themselves whether the achievement has any substantive meaning for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Distributor fined for adding hazardous substance to its domestic gas

TEXT.P: Lee Chang Yung Chemical Industry Corp. (LCY) has been slapped with a fine of NT$2 million (US$62,220) for unauthorized addition of a hazardous substance to its bottled gas, the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.
LCY imports liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and also distributes LPG produced by the local state-owned oil refiner CPC Corp.
LCY's bottled gas was recently found to contain dimethyl ether, a hazardous chemical that can cause headaches, dizziness, lightheadedness and even loss of consciousness.
According to a statement released by the Bureau of Energy, the addition of the substance is a violation of the Petroleum Administration Law.
LCY is not permitted to add dimethyl ether or any other substance to its LPG, as the company does not have an oil refining licence, the bureau said.
The bureau said the MOEA has asked CPC to review its distribution contract with LCY and consider whether to terminate the agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to look into South African visa treatment: foreign minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will look into whether Taiwanese nationals were treated unjustly when they applied for South African visas, and decide whether to request changes, Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang said Thursday.

Yang made the remarks at the Legislative Yuans Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee in response to opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-langs questions about how the ministry was dealing with the problem involving Taiwanese passport holders, being treated like mainland Chinese nationals, when they apply for South African visas.

The Taiwanese applicants have been required to present a certificate of account balance showing they have savings of over NT$80,000 (US$2,490) and were given visas which are only valid for 10 days, according to Tsai. This is the type of treatment of Chinese nationals by many countries which fear they will overstay their visit.
This is indeed a matter of concern so the foreign ministry will look into it and reason with the South African government,Yang said.
Yang said his ministry will also carry out an overall review of how Taiwanese nationals are treated when they travel abroad.
"If there is any injustice or inconvenience, the ministry will request countries concerned make improvements,Yang added.

Making his first appearance at the Legislative Yuan after assuming office last month, Yang told the committee that he will continue to promote President Ma Ying-jeous policy of flexible diplomacy, which he said has achieved several positive results, such as the admission of Taiwan as an observer in the World Health Assembly for the first time this year.

Yang acknowledged, however, that although such a policy has brought about many opportunities and positive results for Taiwan, challenges remain in the future, as it is difficult to make fundamental changes in international realities that Taiwan has faced over the past decades.

Moreover, Yang said that despite the fact that Taiwan and mainland China no longer compete for allies under President Ma Ying-jeous policy of flexible diplomacy, which favors a diplomatic truce with Beijing, the foreign ministry will not take this arrangement for granted and let down its guard.

Through active actions and concrete results, the Foreign Ministry will work hard to prove that flexible diplomacy is the most accurate diplomatic strategy, and that diplomatic truce is the most rational tactic for Taiwan to take,Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to commend the 2009 Ten Best Classic Rice award winners

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has announced the winners of the 2009 Ten Best Classic Rice Award after a fair, just and open selection process was conducted on Sept. 29, according to the COA.
COA Vice Minister Huang Yu-tsai revealed the list of winners at the Agriculture and Food Agency (AFA).
The 10 winners are: Hsu Neng-fa, Chen Lung-an, Tseng Chung-nung, Chang Mao- sheng, Tsai Sheng-ping, Chuang Yu-chih, Cheng Shu-lin, Wu Tsung-wen, Tseng Ming- pao and Wu Chang-cheng .

Since 2004, the COA has been conducting the annual "National Quality Rice Competition" to select the best brands of rice in Taiwan. In an effort to attract more outstanding farmers to join the competition, the contest was renamed the Ten Classic Rice Award in 2007.
This year, the seventh annual competition has 1,493 participants from 47 townships and cities, the highest numbers ever. The competition itself has become the common interests of the rice industry.

The COA stressed that the event has succeeded in introducing the idea of high- quality production to farmers, recognizing the hard work farmers have done, and increasing farmers' revenues. In addition, it helps to promote the popularity of the rice-producing areas and boost local development.

The Council will grant the 2009 Ten Classic Rice Awards to the 10 winners at the Taipei World Trade Center Hall 2 on Oct. 17. In the meantime, the High-Quality Taiwan Rice Expo 2009 will be held along with the awarding ceremony.
The 10 award-wining rice brands will be on display and for sale at the expo, the Council said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister optimistic about Taiwan joining U.N. agencies

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang on Thursday expressed confidence in Taiwan's efforts to seek meaningful participation in two United Nations specialized agencies, saying that he believes it will not take as long as it did to gain observer status in the World Health Assembly (WHA).

Taiwan will seek meaningful participation in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

"After 13 years of effort, Taiwan was finally admitted to the WHA as an observer in May, " Yang said. "I believe we can do it much faster in the case of these two agencies, but I cannot project a timetable."

Yang made the remarks in response to legislators' questions on the issue, while reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee for the first time since he took office last month.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Sept. 21 that Taiwan will strive for membership in U.N. specialized agencies, rather than direct participation in the U.N. as it had been pursuing in previous years.
The ministry called for the UNFCCC and the ICAO to give favorable consideration to the needs of the Taiwan people and what they could contribute if admitted.

Paul Chang, director-general of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said at Thursday's committee meeting that as of Wednesday, 14 of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies had co-signed a resolution in support of Taiwan's bid to participate in the UNFCC, while 13 of them had expressed support in the case of the ICAO.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-lang raised the issue of Taiwan's designation in its efforts to join the agencies, noting that some U.N.-related Web sites still refer to Taiwan as "Taipei, China, " a name that he said is unacceptable and belittles the country.
Yang said that although Taiwan is seeking pragmatic participation in the U.N. specialized agencies, the MOFA will try to come up with a designation that would uphold Taiwan's dignity.
Taiwan has not been represented in the U.N. since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the Peoples Republic of China.
Since 1993, it has been trying to have the world body consider the issue of its representation, but has made little progress largely due to China's obstruction.

Taiwan's allies and supporters have been trying to get the General Assembly to list Taiwan's application for admission on the U.N. agenda, but Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.
This year, Taiwan has come up with a more flexible and pragmatic approach that it hopes will allow it to better negotiate the complex situation.

Meanwhile, on the question of who will represent Taiwan at this year's unofficial leaders summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum Nov. 12-14 in Singapore, Yang said that he cannot comment on the issue, as the arrangements with leaders of other countries are still in progress.

Because of Beijing's opposition, presidents of the Republic of China have been barred from APEC unofficial leadership summits since the country became a member of the regional grouping in 1991 under the name "Chinese Taipei."

As cross-strait relations began to thaw after President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008, China did not oppose his choice of former Vice President Lien Chan to represent Taiwan at the APEC summit in Peru last year.
Lien was the most senior former Taiwanese official to ever stand in for the country's president at an APEC summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday:
Apple Daily:
Charles Kao became the ninth ethnic Chinese to have ever won the Nobel Prize.
This raises a question: whether he or the eight others would ever have won the laureate if they had stayed in China or Taiwan. The answer is astoundingly no.

This is not only because of their less developed scientific levels and fewer research communities, but also because of too much political meddling. Gao Xingjian who was exiled into France after winning the laureate is a notable example.
Unfortunately, Chinese are so much longing for this honor that they seem to consider Nobel the only measurement of value.

We are glad that Kao won the laureate, a fact that proves that Chinese are not inferior to other people, but we should not be obsessed with winning it. A watched pot never boils. Chinese will have a better chance to get the honor if they devote themselves to their work and forget about winning the prize.
United Daily News:
Testing ECFA with China on China's west of Strait special economic district.
Taiwan is seeking to conclude an economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
It has claimed however that the agreement will be separated from China's west of Strait special economic district in the provinces of Fujian, Guangdong, and Zhejiang and Jiangxi.
However, we would like to suggest the authorities test ECFA on this district because it would give Taiwan the opportunity to mitigate the impacts of opening itself to the whole China abruptly.
Furthermore, the west of Strait district is less developed compared to central China, and opening Taiwan to it will not seriously harm Taiwan's economy.
Liberty Times:
China and Taiwan, who is whose automatic teller machine ?

When a lawmaker questioned the government's policy of opening Taiwan to Chinese investment, citing that only a few Chinese have invested in Taiwan, Premier Wu Den-yih said Taiwan has to improve its competitiveness to attract Chinese investment rather than consider China as its automatic teller machine.

Taiwan and China are competing against each other for overseas markets, they could hardly cooperate with each other without undermining their own benefits, and President Ma Ying-jeou's policy of seeking closer economic ties with China is giving China a chance to learn Taiwan's skills to compete against Taiwan.

Instead of realizing that President Ma has made Taiwan China's automatic teller machine, Premier Wu Den-yih warned the lawmakers against esteeming China as the island's automatic teller machine. How can this person make sensible economic decisions for the country?
China Times:
Two parties have come full circle

One and a half years after it won three fourths of the legislative seats, the Kuomintang is faced with a situation of internal divisions caused by local factions. The reason for the splits is that the local factions have sensed the unpopularity of the KMT central government brought about by its poor performance.

The KMT's loss in the legislative by-election in Yunlin is evidence of the party's sliding popularity. In the election, a former ally ran against the KMT candidate in the race, but they received far fewer combined votes than the winning Democratic Progressive Party candidate.
Is the DPP's victory in Yunlin an isolated incident or an indication of a shift away from the KMT?
Even Tsai Ing-wen, the leader of the DPP, is not sure that her party will win resoundingly in the year-end elections for magistrates and mayors.
If the opposition party wins the magistracy in Yilan and Nantou counties as expected, it would only be recovering political turf that it lost in 2005.
It means that the two parties have come full circle and they should know that what really counts is their policy and their performance in office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outgoing KMT chairman to host farewell dinner

TEXT.P: Outgoing chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), Wu Poh-hsiung, will host a dinner Thursday for ranking party officials, some 10 days before he hands over the post, according to a KMT source.
Lee Chien-jung, director of the KMT Cultural and Communications Affairs Committee, confirmed that Wu will host the KMT officials at a dinner at the Fullon Hotel Taipei.

The invited guests include KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, Premier Wu Den-yih and Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu -- two incumbent KMT vice chairmen -- as well as other KMT vice chairmen and heads of various KMT committees and departments.

The premier's office could not confirm whether he would make it back to Taipei in time for the dinner, as he is on an inspection tour of flood-affected areas in the northeastern county of Yilan in the wake of Typhoon Parma.
Wu Poh-hsiung will be replaced as KMT chairman by President Ma Ying-jeou on Oct. 17, following Ma's unopposed election to the post July 26.
Wu Poh-hsiung assumed chairmanship of the party on April 11, 2007 after a landslide by-election win.

The by-election became necessary when Ma resigned as party chairman Feb. 13, 2007 immediately after he was indicted on corruption charges for alleged misuse of a special allowance fund during his two terms as Taipei City mayor between 1998 and 2006. Ma also announced his bid for the 2008 presidential election at that time.

Wu Poh-hsiung, a KMT stalwart, has served as Taoyuan County magistrate, Taipei mayor, Minister without portfolio, minister of the interior, secretary-general of the Presidential Office and vice chairman of the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: Finance minister promises decreasing gov't debt from 2016

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said Thursday that the level of public borrowing and government debt as a ratio of gross domestic product (GDP) will gradually decline in the coming years in line with a mandatory debt-repayment mechanism.
Lee made the remarks while attending a legislative committee hearing on the allocation of a special budget on post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction work for the period from 2009-2012.
He was responding to questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Sun Ta-chien.
Sun voiced grave concerns over the government finances, noting that it was estimated government debt would hit around 37 percent of GDP by the end of 2010 -- nearing the highest level allowed by law.
Sun questioned Lee on whether the government has worked out any measures to improve its financial situation and repay its snowballing debt.

Although Lee stressed that drastic measures are necessary at a drastic time to address thorny issues, the minister, however, said government borrowing is not necessarily bad if it is used to boost national development.

In conjunction with a middle- and long-term debt repaying project, Lee said that government borrowing will be reduced every year from 2016. Its level as a percentage of GDP will also slide in tandem, he said.

Officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said late last month that government debt was estimated to account for 40.1 percent of the country's GDP for fiscal year 2009, up from 35.5 percent in 2008, and 34 percent in 2007.

The debt growth is attributable to the damage in infrastructure caused by several typhoons -- including Typhoon Morakot, which caused widespread destruction in early August -- and the global economic downturn, CEPD officials said.

They said that although the ratio is much lower than the average of 91.6 percent among member nations of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , the government should not underestimate the situation, because the government has posted a fiscal deficit for three consecutive years.
The deficit for fiscal 2009 is equivalent to 4 percent of GDP, up from 0.9 percent in 2008 and 0.4 percent in 2007, the officials noted.
Meanwhile, the latest Finance Ministry statistics showed that the central government's outstanding debt totaled NT$3.887 trillion (US$120.3 billion) as of the end of August.

After President Ma Ying-jeou was inaugurated 16 months ago, the government has borrowed NT$222.5 billion to finance stimulus measures to boost economic growth due to the global financial crisis, the ministry added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Supreme Court instructs reconsideration of ruling on Chen's detention

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court on Thursday instructed a lower court to reconsider its ruling that former President Chen Shui-bian should be held in custody for another three months, a Supreme Court spokesman said.

Both Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen were sentenced Sept. 11 to life in prison and fined NT$200 million (US$6.13 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, on several counts of corruption, including embezzling from a presidential fund for state affairs, taking bribes from local businessmen and money laundering.

The Taiwan High Court panel took charge of Chen's case on Sept. 24 after he appealed the judgment, and it ruled later that day that Chen should remain in custody for another three months. It citied the reasons that "there is evidence showing that Chen has tried to hide his ill-gotten gains abroad and, as a former president, he is more familiar with ways to flee than ordinary people, and thus the possibility exists that he would do so. "
However, the Supreme Court said that the High Court ruling cannot stand because it "failed to clearly identify the facts that it cited as evidence to support Chen's continued detention."
On Sept. 25, Chen appealed to the Supreme Court against the High Court's ruling on his continued detention.
The former president was first detained Nov. 12 last year and was released Dec. 13 following his indictment on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering.
He was detained again Dec. 30 after the Taipei District Court approved a request by prosecutors to take him back into custody and he has not been released since.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan proposes bill to restrict land use following Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet approved Thursday a bill that aims to prevent structures and development projects from being built in environmentally-sensitive areas, in a move driven by the major loss of lives and property during Typhoon Morakot.

If the draft law on national land planning clears the legislature, people who illegally build in areas designated unsuitable for development will face fines and even criminal charges Premier Wu Den-yih told reporters.
Wu made the remarks after the Cabinet approved at its weekly meeting the long- talked-about bill aimed at better regulating the use of Taiwan's land.
During Typhoon Morakot, which struck in early August, more than 600 people were killed, most of whom buried by landslides in areas that had suffered from deforestation and abusive development.

In the past few decades, economic development in Taiwan has resulted in many homes, hotels and other businesses being built in mountainous areas or by rivers or coastal areas, especially as local residents or governments try to take advantage of natural scenic attractions to lure tourists.

It is unclear, however, how effective and well-enforced such a law would be if passed, as historically in Taiwan, development has been given higher priority than environmental protection. For instance, even at Sun Moon Lake - one of the scenic treasures of Taiwan - hotels are allowed right up against the lake and not long ago, the government approved a huge five-star hotel to be built nearby.

The draft statute divides the country into four areas in terms of their functions -- land conservation area, agricultural development area, urban and township development area, and marine resources area.

Each area will be subdivided into several types in terms of features of environmental sensitivity, such as ecology, cultural and natural landscape, water resources, natural disaster vulnerability and other resources conservation. Each of them will also be classified into several grades based on the importance of protected targets.

Areas designated for land conservation will be publicly owned - meaning no private ownership will be allowed - because it is either ecologically sensitive or critical to land conservation or landscape maintenance, according to the Ministry of the Interior-drafted bill.

If necessary, the government can impose bans on development, restrict human habitation, or even force people to relocate in order to facilitate land conservation or restoration, according to the bill.
Violators of the law may be slapped with fines ranging between NT$1 million (US$31,250) and NT$5 million.
If their unlawful land use leads to damage or disasters, perpetrators may be given a maximum seven-year prison term plus a fine of up to NT$5 million.
If their illegal actions cause human fatality, the prison term could range between five years and 12 years, plus a maximum fine of NT$10 million.

For emergency environmental or ecological protection needs, the government will be authorized to acquire land, buildings and facilities located those restricted areas, according to the bill. The acquisition prices can be negotiated among relevant parties. If no agreement is reached, the government can forcibly acquire the land at prices prescribed in existing laws.

Indigenous people - whose ancestors have lived in certain parts of Taiwan for thousands of years - however, are not subject to forced relocation without prior consultations and their final consent, even if their settlements or communities are located in disaster-prone regions, according to the bill.
The number of indigenous people in Taiwan is relatively small, at more than 450,000 people.
According to the bill, the government must complete a national survey and unveil a comprehensive land classification blueprint within two years after the legislation is enacted.
And the new land classification system will be implemented within two years after the blueprint is promulgated.
According to the draft statute, a national land sustainable development fund will be established to facilitate land conservation and ecological protection.
"Although the bill doest not specify the amount of the planned fund, we hope the figure can reach at least NT$100 billion (US$3.1 billion)," Wu said.
The fund will come from several sources, including government budget, private donations, contributions by state-owned water and electricity companies and other incomes.
Money from the fund will pay for such things as compensations, in forced relocations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop on local bourse

TEXT.P: Ending a three-day rally, Taiwan's share prices finished lower across the board Thursday due mainly to the impact of an appreciation of local currency against foreign currency.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropped 105.35 points, or 1.38 percent, to close at 7,503.31.

The local bourse opened at 7,615.61 and rose to the day's high of 7,635.66 at one point but then failed to stand above 7,600 as the strong local currency was weighing on the export-reliant electronics sector.
The market later retreated to the day's low of 7,500.32 because of profit taking by investors after the index set a new high Wednesday.
A total of 5.66 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$160.78 billion (US$5.00 billion).
All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile shares falling the most at 2.37 percent.

Machinery and electronics shares declined 1.9 percent, banking and financial stocks dropped 1.47 percent, foodstuff issues lost 1.26 percent, cement shares dropped 1.04 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks fell 0.83 percent, paper and pulp issues dropped 0.14 percent, and construction shares lost 0.04 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,677 to 950, with 193 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$4 million worth of shares. They bought a net NT$19.21 billion in shares the previous two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pledges to promote 'soft power diplomacy'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that his administration is planning to send 10,000 Taiwanese students abroad for study or goodwill visits every year as part of the government's "soft power diplomacy."

The government also hopes to see 20,000 foreign students come to Taiwan to study every year so as to allow the international community to get to know and support Taiwan through such exchanges, Ma said.
The president made the remarks during an event held to present the results of the International Youth Ambassadors project launched by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) this past summer.

Under the initiative, students from three Taiwanese universities were sent overseas to participate in camps in six South Pacific countries that are diplomatic allies of Taiwan: Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, the Solomon Islands and Tuvalu.
Ma told the students that international exchanges are "the best way to discover oneself."

While consolidating the relations with its diplomatic allies will remain a focus of Taiwan's foreign policy, the government will achieve the goal not only through interaction between diplomats, but also through deeper contact between the peoples, Ma said.
He encouraged the students to visit as many foreign countries as possible to expand their international experience.

The MOFA and the Ministry of Education are now studying the possibility of launching courses that are given entirely in English under the Taiwan Scholarship program, and many foreign students have expressed interest in the courses, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Groups ordered to publish use of donations for typhoon victims

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah demanded Thursday that each charity group authorized to receive donations for the Typhoon Morakot victims publish a list on the Internet within a month about how they used the monetary contributions that they have received from the public.
Jiang made the announcement while giving a speech on the issue at a legislative committee meeting.

According to Jiang, as of Oct. 6, 24 government agencies had received cash donations by private individuals or enterprises worth a total of US$6.62 billion (US$205 million) , while 44 private groups got NT$11.21 billion in monetary contribution.
Donations from China are managed by the Mainland Affairs Council, he added.
Some local governments have already published the donated contribution that they received from all walks of life over the Internet, he noted.

The typhoon hit Taiwan in early August, causing the worst damage to southern Taiwan in 50 years. More than 600 people were killed and many people, especially those living in mountainous areas, were made homeless by mudslides and flooding triggered by the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.037 to close at NT$32.143.
A total of US$864 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.190 and reached a low of NT$32.095.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government mulling health tax on betel nuts: DOH

TEXT.P: The government might levy a health tax on betel nuts with the aim of reducing consumption and generating tax revenue, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang announced Thursday.

The Cabinet-level DOH will levy the tax once all technical problems have been resolved and implementation details are ready, the minister said at the Legislative Yuan, without mentioning a specific timetable.

The minister agreed with a proposal by KMT Legislator Lin Hung-chih that a tax of NT$0.13 per betel nut should be levied as a health tax, but said implementing the measure would not be easy "as betel nuts are not sold in packs like cigarettes."
"Cigarettes are mostly imported by tobacco companies, but betel nuts are planted by farmers around the country, so it would be very difficult to implement such a health tax on betel nuts, " he said.

A Bureau of Health Promotion official added that selling agricultural products like betel nuts does not require a business license, and said it would be unlikely that betel nut vendors would be told to count the nuts they sell and tax them individually.

Taiwan raised the health surcharge on tobacco products from NT$10 (US$0.3) to NT$20 earlier this year and the increase in cost for a pack of cigarettes has been seen to discourage smoking, according to a health official.

The move was not welcomed by those who make their living from selling cigarettes and betel nuts, with one vendor complaining that since the increase in price of cigarettes, the number of customers has dropped 30 percent. He said the impact of a betel nut tax would be even more severe.

The health tax issue has also worried betel nut farmers, who are already suffering from shrinking business. One angry farmer in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan told a local newspaper that they might protest against the proposed tax.

With millions of Taiwanese chewing the carcinogenic nut, oral cancer has become the cancer with the fastest increase in mortality rate among male cancer patients. The betel plantations are also largely responsible for mudslides during rainy weather, as the root system of the betel palm is very shallow and provides little anchorage for topsoil.

However, betel nuts are nevertheless the country's biggest cash crop, with over 50,000 hectares under cultivation and NT$8.6 billion-worth of production value in 2008, more than double the production value of rice, according to the Council of Agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: Palace Museum reaffirms stance on rejecting controversial bronzes

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) will never accept artifacts that are controversial, stolen or of unknown origin, the museum's curator reiterated Thursday at a Legislative Yuan session.

It was the second consecutive day that NPM Director Chou Kung-shin had expounded on the museum's stance as lawmakers across the political spectrum continued to question the museum's rejection of a reported offer by a French owner to give it two bronze statues stolen from China some 150 years ago.

Pierre Berge, partner of the late French fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, reportedly has offered to donate the two bronzes -- a rat head and a rabbit head -- to a Taiwanese museum, but the offer was rejected because the museum feared angering China.

During a legislative session a day earlier, Chou said she was invited by the French government to visit Paris in June. During the visit, she met with Berge, who said at the time that he "would neither sell nor donate" the two pieces, she recalled.
Chou further said that even if the owner offered to donate the two pieces, the NPM would not accept them from the perspective of professional ethics.
On Thursday, lawmakers continued grilling Chou over the issue at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Education and Cultural Affairs Committee.
In response, Chou once again stressed the museum's stance, saying that the NPM, as one of the world's most famous museums, should follow professional ethics and uphold its international image.

According to a declaration issued by the International Council of Museums (ICOM) and the United Nations Economic, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) in 1970, Chou said, museums should not procure, accept or exchange artifacts of illegal origin.
She also noted that Gary F. Edson, a senior member of the ICOM's ethics committee, was very positive toward her museum's rejection of the reported offer.
The NPM in suburban Taipei is home to the cream of the 1,000-year Chinese art collection originally stored at the Forbidden City in Beijing and transported to Taiwan during the Chinese civil war.
The two controversial bronzes of the Chinese zodiac animals were illegally seized in 1860 from Beijing's imperial summer palace, Yuanmingyuan, by invading French and British forces.
The two items later became part of the Yves Saint Laurent collection. When they were put up for auction by Berge early this year, it aroused great anger in China, which demanded their return.
China's Lost Cultural Relics Recovery Fund, an activist group, filed a petition in France in an attempt to stop the auction, but a Paris tribunal rejected the petition.

The two pieces were sold in the Paris auction in February this year for 15.7 million euros each to a telephone buyer who at the time remained anonymous. A few days later, Chinese collector Cai Mingchao said that he was the successful bidder but would refuse to pay for the statues, claiming that his bid was a "patriotic act" to sabotage the auction.
The two statues have since been sitting in a safe room at Christie's auction house.

According to a Reuters report, Berge has said he will return the two pieces to China only if the country guarantees human rights and allows the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, to return home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan ties advancing: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou hailed advancing Japan-Taiwan ties Thursday and expressed hope that a "special partnership" relationship can help further two-way ties on the back of the major breakthroughs achieved since his inauguration in May 2008.
Ma made the remarks when receiving a delegation at the Presidential Office of dietmen from Japan's lower house led by Nakatsugawa Hirosato of the Democratic Party of Japan.
The group was the first of its kind to visit Taiwan since Japan's power transfer in September.

Describing overall relations between the two countries as having become even closer and stronger since he took office, Ma said Taiwan and Japan must seek to more effectively reinforce and enhance their exchanges due to their geographic proximity and historical links.
Following his inauguration, Ma designated Taiwan-Japan ties as a "special partnership" and concrete improvement in bilateral relations has been made over the past 17 months.

Apart from an implementation of a reciprocal working holiday program for students of the two countries from June last year, the president said, Taiwan is set to open a cultural center in Tokyo and an office in Sapporo late this month, while four daily direct Taipei-Tokyo flights will be resumed next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense Ministry denies vacillation on arms procurement policy

TEXT.P: The government has never vacillated over its arms procurement policy but has remained firm and consistent on the issue, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday in a statement.

The ministry issued the statement after Mei Fu-hsing, a local military analyst, said in an article published in the Apple Daily that same day that the government was inconsistent in its bids to procure weapons from the United States.

The MND statement said the criticism was unfair because the government has never wavered on its stance with regard to purchasing defensive weapons from the United States, including F-16 C/D jet fighters.

President Ma Ying-jeou has reiterated his administration's desire to acquire U.S.-built F-16 C/Ds and other weapons on many public occasions, including an April 22 teleconference with the Center for Strategic and International Studies to mark the 30th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act and a statement issued during a May 26 transit stop in the United States on his way to Central America for a diplomatic visit, the statement said.
Moreover, it went on, Ma has taken advantage of meetings with visiting U.S. politicians and academics to express the government's arms procurement stance.

In addition, the statement said, government and military authorities, as well as the legislative branch, have through various channels asked the U.S. government to provide Taiwan with the defensive weapons it needs to protect its security in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act, the U.S. law that regulates relations with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

In speeches to military personnel at various levels, the statement continued, Ma has also repeatedly reminded them that despite the government's efforts to improve relations with China and reduce tension in the Taiwan Strait, China has not changed its position on the use of force against Taiwan. Therefore, he said, the military should never relax its combat preparedness and should continue to hone its combat skills to safeguard national security.
"This indicates that our government's policy on arms procurement has not changed," the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition on Chinese animal paintings to open at U.S. museum

TEXT.P: An exhibition featuring some 100 Chinese animal paintings and objects from museums in Taiwan, China and the United States will open Oct. 9 and run through Jan. 3, 2010 at the Cincinnati Art Museum, museum director Aaron Betsky announced Wednesday at an opening ceremony.

Of the exhibits, 20 original animal paintings has been loaned by the National Palace Museum in Taipei, said Lee Wen-chi, press chief of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago (TECO-Chicago), who attended the ceremony.
Describing the exhibition as the research results of Sung Hou-mei, the curator of Asian art at the museum, over the past 20 years, Betsky said the exhibition took five years to prepare.
The exhibition examines the evolution of the symbolic language of Chinese animal imagery and highlights paintings, from the Song, Yuan, Ming and Qing dynasties, Lee said.
TECO-Chicago Director Perry Pei-hwang Shen note that the National Palace Museum rarely lends the national treasures in its collection to other countries.

However, to show the importance Taiwan attaches to enhancing comprehensive exchanges with the United States, particularly in the area of culture and arts, the museum agreed to lend the treasures for the exhibition, according to Shen.

The exhibition will showcase 86 paintings and dozens of objects, with 15 paintings selected from the Palace Museum in Beijing and the Shanghai Museum, and many other artifacts from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, Princeton University Art Museum, and the Nelso-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas.
One of the oldest arts institutions in the United States, the Cincinnati Art Museum has a rich collection of more than 60,000 works of art spanning 6,000 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC will not rule out possibility of political dialogue with China

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not rule out the possibility of holding negotiations with China on political issues, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday.
Lai made the remarks while meeting an 11-member delegation from the Center for a New American Security (CNAS) led by its CEO, Nathaniel Fick.
She noted, however, that the government does not have a timetable for this kind of cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue.

In dealing with China, Lai went on, priority will be given to the "easier, urgent and economic issues, and those issues deemed as difficult, not urgent and politics-related" will only be touched upon when the time is right.
Lai said that at the moment, the time is not ripe for Taiwan and China to establish a confidence-building mechanism (CBM) and sign a bilateral peace agreement.
"This is because public opinion is divergent on Taiwan's policy toward China, and consensus in this regard has yet to be reached, " she said.
Lai expressed hope that both Taiwan and China will seek to resolve problems resulting from cross-strait exchanges by shelving their disputes rather than confronting each other.

She noted that the present thaw in cross-strait relations and maintaining the cross-strait status quo are in the interest of not only Taiwan and China but also the entire Asia-Pacific region and the world.
Since President Ma Ying-jeou was inaugurated in May last year, Taiwan has signed several agreements with China on promoting cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China ready to exchange ECFA `early harvest' list

TEXT.P: Officials from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are scheduled to meet in mid- October to exchange "early harvest" lists to be included in a much-anticipated bilateral economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , an official said Thursday.

"The two sides have held three rounds of informal talks on ECFA issues and are likely to begin formal talks late this month, " said the official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Before a round of formal talks begins, officials from the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade and China's Ministry of Commerce will hold one more informal round of talks in the middle of this month, the official went on.

"The venue for the informal talks could be determined Friday, " the official said, adding that the most important thing during the mid-October meeting will be for the two sides to exchange their "early harvest" lists.
When that happens, the official said, the lists of industries or services that each side will open for tariff concessions or more liberal trade terms will become clear.
Nevertheless, the official went on, the ministry has already outlined major principles that guided the selection of the targeted items, but said that no details would be revealed at present.

In the service sector, the MOEA has targeted areas that China agreed to open when it was seeking accession to the World Trade Organization but which still remain inaccessible to Taiwan, the official said.
Other targeted areas are services for which China has granted preferential tariffs to other countries, and those that are favorable to Taiwan, he added.

According to an ECFA impact assessment report released recently by the MOEA, the government might request China to open up its market to financial, computer- related, R&D, logistics, civil aircraft maintenance, and freight forwarding services from Taiwan.
On the merchandise trade front, the official continued, Taiwan expects China to open its market to export items that are favorable to Taiwan but are subject to high Chinese tariffs.
Others are those for which China has granted preferential duties to its free trade agreement partners, and sensitive goods that Taiwan hopes can be opened up flexibly, he added.

Meanwhile, President Ma Ying-jeou has said that Taiwan hopes an "early harvest" clause can be included in the proposed ECFA to reduce the impact of the new China-Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) free trade area on Taiwanese businesses.

After the China-ASEAN economic integration, which begins Jan. 1, 2010, petrochemical products, textiles, automobile parts and machinery exports from ASEAN members to China will enjoy tariff-free treatment, which will seriously undermine the competitiveness of similar products from Taiwan, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan High Court rules former President Chen remains in custody

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ruled at wee hours Friday that former President Chen Shui- bian should remain in custody, after six hours of debate between prosecutor and three lawyers representing Chen.
The Supreme Court on Thursday instructed the high court to reconsider its ruling that former President Chen should be held in custody for another three months.

Both Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen were sentenced Sept. 11 to life in prison and fined NT$200 million (US$6.13 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, on several counts of corruption, including embezzling from a presidential fund for state affairs, taking bribes from local businessmen and money laundering.

TECO-Chicago Director Perry Pei-hwang Shen note that the National Palace Museum rarely lends the national treasures in its collection to other countries.

However, to show the importance Taiwan attaches to enhancing comprehensive exchanges with the United States, particularly in the area of culture and arts, the museum agreed to lend the treasures for the exhibition, according to Shen.

The exhibition will showcase 86 paintings and dozens of objects, with 15 paintings selected from the Palace Museum in Beijing and the Shanghai Museum, and many other artifacts from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, Princeton University Art Museum, and the Nelso-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas.
One of the oldest arts institutions in the United States, the Cincinnati Art Museum has a rich collection of more than 60,000 works of art spanning 6,000 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 9, or the 21st day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro gain power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
2000: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrive in Taipei to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double-Ten National Day.
2001: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taiwan holds a party to mark the 50th anniversary of its founding.
2001: The five-day 2001 Taipei International Electronics Show kicks off with the number of international buyers in the first day down significantly compared with the previous year's figures.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self- respect."
