DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
High court rules former president should remain in custody

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ruled early Friday that former President Chen Shui-bian should remain in custody, on the grounds that he might abscond if released from detention.

A three-judge panel arrived at the ruling after six hours of debate between prosecutors and three lawyers representing Chen. The session was held after the Supreme Court revoked the panel's Sept. 24 ruling to keep the former president in custody for another three months and ordered another hearing.
The Supreme Court said the earlier high court ruling could not stand because it failed to clearly identify the facts that it cited as evidence to support Chen's continued detention.
In its fresh ruling, however, the judges said that "chances are extremely high" that Chen might flee and that there are also facts to support their opinion.

The judges said that Chen, who was president for eight years and took part in many secret diplomatic missions, has had the chance to come into contact with foreign governments and members of the private sector, making him "more familiar than ordinary people with ways to flee overseas."
With Chen's influence and the assets stashed overseas by his family, he could live a comfortable life if he were to run away to evade the severe sentence that he could face, the judges said.

They noted that Chen still attempted to hide his overseas assets even after the family's money-laundering activities were uncovered by the international anti- money laundering organization Egmont Group in early 2008.

On the Supreme Court's claim that a 24-hour security service for the former president would bar him from absconding, the judges pointed out that the security officers have only been assigned to protect him and have no responsibility to report his whereabouts to the judicial authorities.

Both Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen were sentenced Sept. 11 by the Taipei District Court to life in prison, in addition to receiving fines of NT$200 million (US$6.13 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, on several counts of corruption, including embezzling from a presidential fund for state affairs, taking bribes from local businessmen and money laundering.
The high court panel took charge of Chen's case Sept. 24 after he appealed the judgment. The panel ruled that same day that Chen should remain in custody for another three months.
The former president was first detained Nov. 12, 2008 and was released Dec. 13 following his indictment.
He was detained again Dec. 30 after the Taipei District Court approved a request by prosecutors to take him back into custody and he has not been released since.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese trade mission exploring Brazilian market
DOC.DATELINE: Sao Paulo, Brazil, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/09/09 12:47:03 (By Tang Ya-lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An ongoing Taiwanese trade mission to Latin America visited Sao Paulo, Brazil's commercial and industrial center, Thursday to seek trade opportunities and promote Taiwanese brands.

The mission, organized by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , includes representatives of 23 Taiwanese companies involved in auto and motorcycle parts, machinery, textiles and eight other industries, according to Chu Chien-tsai, a TAITRA official in charge of market exploration.

It is the second time this year that TAITRA has organized a Taiwanese trade mission to visit Brazil, on the grounds that Brazil is not only one of the newly emerging markets dubbed the BRIC (Brazil, Russia, India and China) but also the largest market in South America.

Chu said that although two-way trade between Taiwan and Brazil slid over the past year due to the global economic crunch, business exchanges between the two countries are expected to pick up steam in the latter months of the year.
"I anticipate that today's trade talks will pick up new orders and consequently give a boost to two-way business, " Chu told CNA.

According to official Brazilian trade figures, Taiwan's exports to Brazil amounted to US$1.31 billion in the first eight months of this year, representing a year-on-year decline of 42.04 percent, while imports from Brazil totaled US$664 million, down 49.34 percent.

Mission leader Sun Cheng-tah, chairman of Sungreat General Supply Co., which is one of Taiwan's top five suppliers of auto parts and accessories, said Taiwanese businesses should grasp the golden opportunities presented by Brazil's economic takeoff to explore their overseas markets.

In general, he said, South America is a huge but volatile and unstable market. "The only way to survive the South American market and thrive there is to incessantly explore new markets and get new customers," Sun said.
In addition to promoting auto and motorcycle parts, Sun said, his company is also expected to seek Brazilian partners to start a joint venture in which parts can be assembled locally.

Meanwhile, Chiu Ju-chun, director of the TAITRA trade center in Brazil, said that after a series of downturns since late last year, the Brazilian currency began to appreciate in April this year and that currently, the Brazil real stands at about 1.8 to the U.S. dollar, a value that is conducive to imports.

With its gross domestic product (GDP) edging up 1.9 percent in the second quarter of this year, the Brazilian government is confident that Brazil's GDP will grow at least 1 percent for the whole of 2009, Chiu said.

The mission, which has visited Argentina's capital Buenos Aires, where it secured orders worth a total of US$3.18 million, is scheduled to visit Ecuador and Mexico on the last legs of its Latin America tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT to hold American BBQ, blues month

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said in a recent press release that it will host a series of activities to "introduce American style BBQ and blues music to the people of Taiwan."

"This is the first time AIT has taken the initiative to link an American food promotion with live American blues music. Blues and BBQ go hand in hand in the United States, " Keith Schneller, the director of AIT's Agricultural Trade Office (ATO), was quoted as saying.

In cooperation with the Taichung city government, the U.S. Meat Export Federation, and various other sponsors, the ATO is bringing Joey Gilmore, champion of the 2006 International Blues Challenge, to Taiwan to perform and promote American-style BBQ at venues around the island, according to the AIT press release.

This will include the opening weekend of the 2009 Taichung Jazz Festival Oct. 17-18, and an American BBQ and Blues Pavilion at the J1 stage on Jingkuo Boulevard at the Taichung Jazz Festival, which will offer an enticing array of American BBQ products, beer and spirits, it added.
In addition, the ATO, along with Shangri-La's Far Eastern Hotel Taipei and Hotel ONE Taichung will also launch special menu promotions to celebrate American BBQ and Blues Month.

Chef David Ansted from Shangri-La's Far Eastern Hotel Taipei has selected Texas and Memphis, Tennessee barbecue styles for his menu, while Chef Nick Alvarez from Hotel ONE Taichung will prepare a Memphis-style smoked barbecued beef using a Tennessee whiskey-glazed BBQ sauce with a touch of coffee, according to the press release.

During the promotion, any consumer who orders from an American BBQ special menu can participate in a lucky draw for a chance to win Delta/Northwest Airline tickets and gift certificates from participating hotels and restaurants.

DOC.HEADLINE: President renews call for signing of Taiwan-U.S. extradition pact

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou renewed Friday a call for the United States to sign an extradition agreement with Taiwan to facilitate the repatriation of fugitives from justice.

Raising the issue while receiving a delegation of the U.S. National Association of Attorneys General (NAAG), Ma pointed out that he put forth a similar proposal when the NAAG last visited Taiwan in 2008.

While there had been no progress in Taiwan's efforts to establish judicial cooperation with China back then, the two sides signed an agreement on the issue in April this year to allow for the repatriation of criminals and suspects, Ma pointed out.
"Our American friends all feel that the United States should speed up its pace in this regard," he said.

Ma told the NAAG delegates that his administration officially ratified in May this year the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights that the country signed in 1967.

Although the Republic of China is no longer a member of the United Nations, which makes it unlikely that the country would be allowed to deposit the ratification instruments with the world body, its support for the two covenants remains unchanged, the president said.
He said the Ministry of Justice has drafted legislation to allow for the covenants' implementation in Taiwan and that the bills are pending approval by the Legislative Yuan for enactment into law.
Ma pledged that the government will strictly comply with the standards of the two covenants to enhance Taiwan's human rights protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung high court invalidates lawmaker's election

TEXT.P: The Taichung High Court rejected an appeal filed by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiang Lien-fu from Taichung County and invalidated his election Friday on the grounds that he engaged in vote buying.
Chiang appealed soon after the Taichung District Court ruled on Feb. 27 to invalidate his election on the same grounds.

The district court ruled that Chiang, who was caught on a video tape offering NT$50,000 (US$1,550) to a local voter, Chen Lien-ji, before the legislative election on Jan. 12, 2008, intended to buy Chen's vote with money.

The court dismissed Chiang's argument that he was set up by his political rivals and the money was meant for Chen to organize campaign rallies for him, rather than as a reward for his personal ballot.
The court's ruling was made in a case initiated by Chiang's Democratic Progressive Party rival in that election, Chien Chao-dung.
Chiang then appealed the court's decision.

A by-election will be scheduled within three months after the Central Election Commission (CEC) receives a notification from the Taichung High Court about the invalidation of Chiang's election, according to the CEC office in Taichung County.

That by-election will be the third of its kind this year after one was held in March involving KMT Legislator Lee Yi-ting from Miaoli County and the second held in September involving KMT Legislator Chang Sho-wen representing Yunlin County, both for vote-buying.
Now that Chiang's election has been mullified, the KMT holds 78 seats in the 113-seat legislature, with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party holding 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wiretapping practices decline under KMT government: NSB

TEXT.P: The practice of wiretapping criminal organizations or suspected criminals as well as intelligence targets has been on the decline since President Ma Ying- jeou assumed office on May 20, 2008, the National Security Bureau (NSB) said in a statement Friday.

According to the statement, the frequency of wiretaps on criminal targets fell 65.46 percent in Ma's first 15 months in office, while the frequency of wiretaps aimed at obtaining national security-related intelligence has fallen 56.99 percent.
The rate of change was obtained by comparing the numbers during Ma's time in office to those in the final 15 months of the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration.
None of the wiretaps were conducted unlawfully, the NSB said.

The NSB report on intelligence monitoring was compiled after Ma ordered a thorough investigation into wiretapping by government intelligence units after a local newspaper reported Sept. 28 that the practice has increased in the Ma administration.
The report, citing an anonymous official responsible for intelligence affairs, raised the concerns of lawmakers in both the ruling and opposition parties as well as the administration.
NSB officials are scheduled to brief lawmakers on their investigation at the Legislative Yuan Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Strong business at electronics show a sign of recovery: TAITRA

TEXT.P: Buyers placed substantial orders on the first day of the 35th Taipei International Electronic Show (TAITRONICS) Thursday, an indication that the electronics industry is on the road to recovery, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Friday.

On the opening day of the show that attracted more than 10,000 domestic and foreign buyers, US$150 million in orders were given to local suppliers in private face-to-face meetings, a TAITRA statement said.

The one-day total nearly matched the US$170 million in orders placed in the three days of private meetings at last year's show, continuing a run of promising news in an industry that has been battered by the global economic downturn.

According to local customs statistics, electronics has been one of Taiwan's three fastest growing export sectors in recent months. Electronics shipments in August were US$550 million higher than in July.
August electronics shipments were still 32 percent lower than in August 2008, but the rate of decline was more than 10 percentage points lower than for July.

Jointly hosted by TAITRA and the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, the electronics show will run from Oct. 8-11. at the Taiwan World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall in Taipei.

Electronic components, manufacturing and testing equipment, LEDs and lighting, and safety and security products, are among some of the products being highlighted at TAITRONICS 2009, according to TAITRA.

Top caliber Taiwanese suppliers, such as Tektronix, Agilent, Taiwan Alpha Electronic, OasisTek, GWinstek, TYNTEK, GKB are among the show's 850 exhibitors occupying 1,700 booths who are hoping to meet the sourcing needs of buyers from around the globe.

"The combination of China's enormous production capability and Taiwan's strict quality control and R&D offers worldwide buyers more product variety and greater flexibility at a competitive price, " TAITRA said in the statement.
Aside from the star lineup of Taiwanese suppliers, the show also features a "China Pavilion" comprised of about 100 Chinese vendors packed into a 1,080 -square-meter display area.
TAITRA said a total of 850 one-on-one meetings will be organized during the exhibition to broker business opportunities between Taiwanese suppliers and foreign buyers.
It is expecting 5,000 buyers from abroad and 70,000 professionals from Taiwan to visit the show.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP denies plan to invite Falun Gong founder to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday denied a report that it was planning to invite Li Hongzhi, the founder of the Falun Gong movement that has been banned in China, to visit Taiwan.
Responding to a report in the China Times, DPP acting spokesman Chuang Suo-hang said he had not heard about the idea and denied that the party had any plans to invite Li.
Asked if the invitation would be made by civic groups, Chuang said it would be within the scope of freedom of speech and religion and that the DPP would respect their decision.
The government of President Ma Ying-jeou should make its intentions clear, however, if it were to reject Li's visit based on national security considerations or other grounds.
An invitation to Li to visit Taiwan would be the third to individuals considered anathema by China's government in recent months.

The DPP invited exiled Tibetan leader the Dalai Lama in late August to comfort victims of Typhoon Morakot, and a pro-independence group invited exiled Uighur rights activist Rebiya Kadeer last month to visit Taiwan in conjunction with the screening of a documentary about her life at a local film festival.

While the DPP and civic groups contended the moves were not political, critics saw them as attempts to create politically awkward situations for the president, who has pushed to improve ties with China.
The Ma administration allowed the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan, to the surprise of some, but it rejected Kadeer's application for a visa.

Chuang panned the government's snub of the Uighur activist, accused by Beijing of fomenting violence in Xinjiang province, as a move to please China that not only runs counter to Taiwan's principles as a free and democratic nation but also contravenes the universal value of human rights.

Touching on a ruling handed down by the Taiwan High Court early Friday that former President Chen Shui-bian should remain in custody, on the grounds that he might abscond if released from detention, Chuang said that the DPP regretted the verdict and would discuss with Chen's lawyers how to protect his judicial human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse

Textile stocks rose 2.26 percent, banking and financial shares were up 2.02 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 1.5 percent, cement stocks added 1.45 percent, foodstuff issues advanced 1.25 percent, construction issues rose 1.04 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were up 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City resident selected as Lienchiang magistrate for a day

TEXT.P: A Taipei City resident has won the chance to serve as the magistrate of the outlying Lienchiang County for a day after winning a lucky drawing, the county government announced Friday.

Wen Chia-su, who lives in Taipei City, was selected from some 67,000 people who applied to serve as the county's "magistrate for a day" in an online drawing, said Chen Shu-fu, the head of the county's Project Planning Office.
This year, the number of applicants for the temporary post hit a record high in recent years -- about seven times that of the total population in the county, according to the officials.
Global Vision magazine was commissioned by the county government to conduct the random draw using a computer program.
As part of the application process, Wen obtained a perfect score by answering correctly the 10 questions on the application related to county's main island of Matsu correctly, Chen said.

The county government said it welcomes Wen to serve as its magistrate on a yet- to-be-determined day, during which he will be briefed on policy implementation results and tour the county's major construction sites.
Other prize winners have also been picked and the county government will inform winners via telephone and begin to send out their prizes on Oct. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ang Lee hopes for greater continuity in government's movie arm

TEXT.P: Oscar-winning director Ang Lee said Friday he looks forward to seeing the head of Taiwan's Government Information Office (GIO) stay on the job for a longer time than his predecessors to better contribute to the development of the country's film industry.
The Taiwan-born, New York-based director, who returned to Taipei recently to promote his new film "Taking Woodstock, " expressed his hope while meeting with GIO Minister Su Jun-pin.
Lee said that whenever he returns to Taiwan, he invariably pays a visit to the GIO, which is responsible for administering the country's film sector.
"It seems to me that I tend to be received by a different minister each time," Lee said.
As each minister usually has his or her own policy direction for the film industry, Lee said he is afraid that none of their policy proposals can be implemented fully.

"You are still young. I'm hopeful that you will stay longer so that you will have enough time to put your policy ideas into practice and thus contribute to Taiwan's movie industry development, " Lee told Su.
In response, Su said he is a passionate supporter of the film industry, as the movie world is full of human interest.

Noting that Lee's films have consistently drawn large crowds of filmmaking professionals in Taipei, Su said Lee's films tend to help instill new spirit, new inspiration and new strength in Taiwan's film sector.
Lee's achievements have also helped encourage many young Taiwanese film directors to confidently continue their pursuit of professional excellence, Su said.
"We also hope that our filmmakers and directors can find a niche for development so that one day Taiwan can emerge as a new mecca for the Chinese-language moviedom," he added.

Lee, who traveled to the United States for advanced study after graduating from the National Taiwan University of Arts, made his directorial debut in 1992 with Pushing Hands, a dramedy highlighting the tension between tradition and modernity, which arises when a retired Tai Chi master moves to the U.S. to live with his Westernized son.
His next two offerings, The Wedding Banquet (1993) and Eat Drink Man Woman (1994), each landed an Oscar nomination in the Best Foreign Film category.

Since then, the versatile director has successfully tackled an impressive variety of genres, reflected in a resume which includes a literary classic (Sense and Sensibility) , a dysfunctional family drama (The Ice Storm), a Western (Ride with the Devil), a gay-themed romance (Brokeback Mountain) , an erotic, espionage thriller (Lust, Caution), a comic book adaptation (Hulk) and a martial arts fairytale (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon).
Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon won an Oscar for Best Foreign Film, while Lee himself won the best director award in 2006 for Brokeback Mountain.
Lee's new film, Taking Woodstock, is a comedy about the 1969 concert that helped define the Hippie Generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heritage arts to be staged during the National Day holiday

TEXT.P: Several types of performing arts that have been recognized as cultural heritages will be staged in Taiwan during the National Day holiday, organizers of the events said Friday.

One of them will be kabuki, a type of classical Japanese dance-drama that integrates song, dance and skills that was proclaimed by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) in 2005 as one of the masterpieces of the oral and intangible heritage of humanity.

A kabuki lecture and demonstration presented by Shochiku Company Limited is scheduled for Oct. 10-11 at the Recital Hall of the National Theater and Concert Hall in Taipei, officials at the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center said.
The event, which includes a short performance and a lecture, will take the audience into the mysterious and breathtaking world of kabuki, the officials said.

Meanwhile, the 2009 Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival being held at the National Headquarters of Taiwan Traditional Arts in Yilan County will feature Khmer shadow theater and Khmer classical dance by Cambodia's Sovanna Phum Art Association Oct. 10-11.
Khmer shadow theater, also known as the royal ballet of Cambodia, was proclaimed a cultural heritage by UNESCO in 2003.

The art form, which narrowly escaped extinction in the 1970s, has been closely associated with the Khmer court for more than 1,000 years. Performances would traditionally accompany royal ceremonies and observances such as coronations, marriages, funerals or Khmer holidays.
Khmer shadow theater, or the sbek thom, was added to the UNESCO list of cultural heritages in 2005.

The sbek thom features two-meter tall, non-articulated puppets made of leather openwork. The performances traditionally take place at night outdoors. The shadows of the puppets' silhouettes are projected onto a white screen set up in front of a large fire or, nowadays, projectors.
Also taking part in the arts festival is the Mandalay Marionettes Theater from Myanmar, which will perform Burmese string puppet shows that are rarely seen in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT legislative caucus nixes betel nut plan

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Friday nixed a proposal by the Department of Health (DOH) to impose a health tax on betel nut, saying it would hurt the livelihoods of grassroots residents.
KMT legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang praised the DOH's tax proposal, aimed at protecting the public's health over the long run, as a good idea.
But he said that the livelihood of the public, particularly those at the grassroots level, should be taken into consideration when a new law is being initiated.
"Currently it is imappropriate and unnecessary to impose a betel nut tax," Lu argued.
There are approximately 1.37 million betel nut chewers in Taiwan, according to the latest DOH survey.

Betel nuts, grown on over 50,000 hectares of land around the country, are currently the country's biggest cash crop. In 2008, betel nut production was worth NT$8.6 billion, more than double the production value of rice, according to the Council of Agriculture.
DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said at the Legislative Yuan Thursday that the DOH was studying the feasibility of levying a health tax on betel nuts to reduce consumption and generate tax revenue.
The minister supported the idea of imposing a tax of NT$0.13 per betel nut, or NT$2-3 for each pack of 20 nuts on average.
"We've been collecting cigarette taxes with success, " Yaung said to legislators. "Why not levy a tax or surtax on betel nut consumption?"
He acknowledged at the time, however, that it would be very difficult to collect such a tax, as betel nuts are not sold in packs like cigarettes.

Chao Kun-yu, a Bureau of Health Promotion deputy director, added that selling agricultural products like betel nuts does not require a business license, and he said it would be unlikely that betel nut vendors would be told to count the nuts they sell and tax them individually.
Chao said that before the betel nut tax plan matures, the DOH will accelerate its oral cancer screening campaign, as 90 percent of Taiwan's oral and esophageal cancer patients have chewed betel nuts.

Citing foreign medical reports indicating that effective oral cancer screening contributes to lowering fatalities by 43 percent, Chao said efforts to screen for oral cancer should take precedence over the tax legislation.
Some 5,000 new oral cancer cases are reported in the country each year, with 2,300 people losing their lives to the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former top Chinese aide says fighting corruption easier in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A former aide to the late Communist Party of China (CPC) boss Zhao Ziyang recently spoke highly of the current form of democracy in Taiwan.

Bao Tong, who was expelled by the Communist Party after the Tiananmen Massacre on June 4, 1989, and was sentenced to seven years in jail for "leaking national secrets, " praised Taiwan's system in an essay marking Taiwan's National Day celebration.
In Taiwan, where there is no socialism, it is possible to ferret out corruption openly, Bao said in his essay posted on Free Radio Asia's Web site.
Bao said that while Taiwan had long since reversed the official verdict on a massacre of demonstrators by Kuomintang (KMT) troops in 1947, in China to this day, no one dares mention "June 4, 1989."
"Courts in Taiwan have the power to pass judgment on high-ranking officials, " wrote Bao.

In contrast, "on the mainland, where we enjoy the benefits of the dictatorship of the proletariat, masses of people who turn out to protest at corruption are suppressed as troublemakers, " he wrote, referring to the 1989 military crackdown on student-led protests on Tiananmen Square.
While China on Oct. 1 held the largest-ever parade in Beijing to celebrate its 60th founding anniversary, Bao said the last 60 years of glorious Communist rule contained "a big lie."

"In the first 30 years, tens of millions either died of starvation or were 'harrassed' to death under the banner of revolution, " said Bao, who has been kept under house arrest in Beijing since his release from jail on May 1996.

"In the second 30 years, anyone standing up for civil and constitutional rights, for religious freedom, or for ethnic autonomy has been declared an enemy of the people en masse, all in the name of stability."

In an interview with the Hong Kong Apple Daily, Bao said the power struggle within the Communist Party continues to this day. He argued that former Chinese President Jiang Zemin, who retired in late 2002 as CPC general secretary, continues to hold great influence in the party and is "bullying" incumbent President Hu Jintao.
He said this was evidenced by the appearance of Jiang alongside his successor Hu atop the Tiananmen Squre rostrum to review the military parade marking China's 60th founding anniversary.
According to Bao, Jiang got much more attention from China's state-run media during the parade and the ensuing party in the evening than any other Chinese leader except for Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
Apple Daily:

The chief of Taiwan's National Palace Museum Chou Kung-shin rejected a French art collector's donation of two bronze sculptures seized from a Beijing palace in 1860 by invading French and British forces, citing the "museum's professional ethics" as the reason.
We have to point out that Chou rejected the donated pieces more out of fear of offending China than on ethical grounds.
The bronze sculptures, the heads of a rat and a rabbit, are neither the Dalai Lama nor Rabiya Kadeer, so why should Chou be so afraid of them?

They were brought out of China long before the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization declared that museums should not acquire artwork with unclear origins, and the two pieces should therefore not be governed by it.

Furthermore, China should be glad if Taiwan accepts the donations as it has always claimed Taiwan is part of its territory. Isn't it better to have them in its territory than overseas? Chou should be more considerate of China's leaders.
Liberty Times: ECFA is padlock to shut Taiwan into China's fold
President Ma Ying-jeou made a pitch for an ECFA trade pact with China yesterday while receiving a group of American visitors.

Ma told visitors that Taiwan's ties with China are thawing and economic exchanges are increasing, adding that he hopes the amicable atmosphere will end the two sides' cutthroat competition for allies on the international stage.

The closer economic exchanges across the strait only hands China leverage against Taiwan. Just as it tried to bend Kaohsiung City to its will by having its tourists stay away from that city, Beijing can easily force Taiwan's authorities to toe the line by flexing its economic muscle.
Ma's diplomatic truce with China is actually making Beijing the country's suzerain.
We welcome peace with China but if the peace is obtained at the cost of Taiwan's sovereignty and economic prosperity, it is nothing but surrender.
China Times:
Dealing with China with confidence

In response to questions from an opposition Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker, Premier Wu Den-yih said his administration has refused a request from Chinese donors that their donations should be used to rebuild the broken Shuangyuan bridge in Pingtung County, because it would be "inappropriate."
The premier's remarks were aimed at pleasing the DPP by showing that his administration is not servile to China.

We do not know whether the opposition will buy his trick, but it has exposed that the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou is too cautious in its dealing with China, looking for the catch in every move made by Beijing.
China's request to chip in with a donation to rebuild the Shuangyuan bridge is understandable, as every donor would prefer to see his donation put to use in the place it is most-needed.
It has also exposed the administration's self-imposed restraint in dealing with China for fear of drawing fire from the DPP.
However, the more cautious the KMT is in its engagement with China, the more aggressive the DPP will be in checking it.
This only bears out the administration's low confidence in itself while associating with China.
We hope the government will shed this cowardly image and face China with greater confidence.
United Daily News: Chaotic Year-end Elections

The year-end election of magistrates and mayors is doomed to be chaotic as the ruling Kuomintang has proven incapable of dealing with rebellious factions and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party has failed to come up with any vision that appeals to voters and can only hope that the KMT will self-destruct.
President Ma's administration has a big head but feeble feet because Ma can lead the country out of a political impasse with China but cannot tame local factions.
Meanwhile the DPP is a party with feet but no head because it can only fish in muddy political waters but cannot lead the country with a clear vision for the future.
So the KMT is incapable of governing at the local level while the DPP is incapable of ruling the country.
Unless the two parties can reform themselves and alter this situation, the year- end elections will be meaningless for local voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICT can help create LOHAS economy: seminar participants

TEXT.P: Information and communication technology (ICT) can facilitate lives in urban and rural areas and help create a lifestyle of health and sustainability (LOHAS), participants at a seminar on ICT applications said Friday.

Pundits and experts from Taiwan and Europe discussed how to use ICT to promote urban renewal and industrial development at the conference, called The International Seminar on ICT Utilisation for Regional Revitalization.

Ke Jyh-sheng, the CEO of event co-sponsor the Institute for Information Technology (III) , said ICT plays a key role in regional development, local business development, niche industries and leisure farms.

Hsiao Mei-li, another III official in charge of research to support industry, said if good use is made of ICT, the gap between urban and rural areas can be narrowed, enticing young men to return to their hometowns and helping preserve niche industries.
She noted that in Japan, South Korea and Thailand, governments have used ICT to engage in regional renewal.
Yeh Yun-lung, director-general of the Department of Commerce under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the ministry has already begun to promote the concept of LOHAS in Sinshe, Taichung County.

The ministry will next target Taipei's Ximending, Lugang in Changhua County, and Hengchun in Pingtung County, hoping to achieve sustainable development in the three areas and maintain their local features.

Sascha Haselmayer, the CEO of the seminar's other co-sponsor, the nonprofit Living Labs Global, lauded Taipei City's hotline 1999 as a unique example of using ICT to improve the lives of Taipei's residents.
Haselmayer also introduced to participants ICT used in urban life and regional development, such as using mobile phones to inquire about available parking spaces and pay for parking fees.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gene explaining rice's flood tolerant properties discovered

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese scientist at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious research institute, announced Friday that her research team has identified the gene -- CIPK15 (CBL-interacting protein kinase) -- that explains why rice can germinate and grow under water.

"The CIPK15 gene has been found as the key that guarantees rice's flood tolerant qualities, " said Yu Shu-may, a researcher at Academia Sinica's Institute of Molecular Biology, at a news conference to introduce the new finding.
The gene is the reason why 80 percent of the world's rice is traditionally planted in submerged fields, saving the need to kill weeds and use pesticides, Yu noted.

She expressed the hope that the discovery behind rice's growth can help human beings cultivate more crops that are resistant to floods, drought, salt, and hot or cold temperatures at a time when extreme weather conditions resulting from global climate change have become common and often lead to diminished crop yields.
Yu's study was selected as the cover story in the current issue of the journal Science Signaling.

Lee Kuo-wei, the first author of the paper and the prime contributor to the rice genomics study, said the team's research found that rice is the only crop that can survive in flooded fields thanks to the CIPK15 gene.
Most plants die when submerged in water because the diffusion of oxygen is limited, restricting aerobic metabolism and energy production.

But rice seeds, when plunged under water, signal to the CIPK15 gene that an oxygen shortage exists, triggering SnRKIA, a multiple functional protein, to produce amylolytic enzymes that are then transformed into sugar.
This gives the plants the energy they need to grow under water, Lee explained.
After the rice seedlings emerge from the water, they can take in more oxygen, allowing their roots to generate carbohydrates and energy under water based on the same principles, he said.
Other crops, such as barley, wheat and corn, or even weeds, cannot grow in water through this mechanism because they lack the specific gene, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: National flood control conference to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: A national flood control conference will open Oct. 11 in Taipei that will bring together the heads of 21 cities and counties and a number of flood-control experts to offer suggestions on how to improve disaster prevention and relief measures.

The conference was originally scheduled for Oct. 4 but was postponed for a week as Taiwan braced for Typhoon Parma, which approached the island that day, the Water Resources Agency (WRA) said in a statement Friday.

Torrential rains brought by seasonal typhoons and a powerful earthquake in September 1999 have left soil layers on mountain slopes in Taiwan loose and unstable, and, as a result, sloping hills around Taiwan are vulnerable to disastrous landslides at any time.

To counter that vulnerability, the agency decided to convene the meeting to gather opinions on viable mudslide control and flood prevention mechanisms in order to build a safer and more sustainable homeland, the statement said.

The four main topics for the meeting will be post-Typhoon Morakot drainage and reconstruction, measures to handle soil and sand buildups and disasters in catchment areas, flood control and water usage strategies to cope with abnormal weather conditions, and the overall management of catchment areas.

Expected to attend are the chiefs and council speakers of 21 cities and counties, members of flood control committees, representatives of disaster affected areas, legislators, Control Yuan members, academics and experts, and student representatives, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen to hold seminar to mark 60th anniversary of Guningtou Battle

TEXT.P: A seminar will be held Oct. 14 to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Guningtou -- which stemmed the advance of Chinese Communists on Taiwan -- with 90 experts, scholars and war veterans participating.

The Kinmen National Park Administration said the seminar will be part of a series of activities marking the battle prior to culminating in the main event, the opening ceremony of the Peace Memorial Park on Oct. 25.
The park administration said the seminar will be held to pay tribute to the veterans.

Analysts and experts will also analyze and evaluate the successes and failures of the battle to serve as a lesson for the pursuit of peace for peoples on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to the park administration.
The administration's presentation of a new book commemorating the battle's 60th anniversary will kick off the seminar.
Former Veterans Affairs Commission official Lo You-fang will give akeynote speech while scholars will present papers.
The Battle of Guningtou began on Oct. 25, 1949, when Chinese communist warships carrying over 10,000 troops landed on Guningtou, located on the northwestern tip of the main island of Kinmen.
After three days of battle, on Oct. 27, the nationalist army defeated the communists after forcing the surrender of thousands of communist troops.

The victory allowed the demoralized Kuomintang Army to maintain control of the island just miles off China's southeastern coast and effectively thwarted Communist China's designs on Kinmen and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady of Israeli cinema ready to move Taiwanese audiences

TEXT.P: Gila Almagor, an Israeli actress known as the "First Lady of Israeli Cinema," said Friday in Taipei that she is looking forward to bringing her autobiographical stage play to local audiences, whom she believes will be touched by her story despite linguistic and cultural barriers.

"I've been traveling with the play for over 20 years now, performing either in English or in Hebrew with translation. The response is always the same. People are crying in the same place and laughing in the same place, " Almagor told the Central News Agency in an interview.
"If I can touch some people with my private story, it means a lot to me."

Almagor was invited by the Taipei-based Israel Economic and Cultural Office (ISECO) and Taipei National University of the Arts (TNUA) to take part in the 2009 Kuandu Arts Festival, which will feature an Israel Week Oct. 9-12.
She will perform the one-woman play "The Summer of Avia" on Oct. 10 and 11 and attend some of the screenings of her movies.

The play, which is based on Almagor's autobiographical novel of the same title, reprises her own stories as a Holocaust survivor looking for new life in Israel and her relationship with her psychologically-troubled mother.
While acting has been Almagor's main avocation, she also enjoys writing and describes it as something she does to find her inner self.
"Writing is something very intimate. It's between me and myself. I don't need an audience or inspiration. This is fantastic, " she said.

Visiting Taiwan for a second consecutive year, Algamor said that she was eager to come again because after meeting Taiwanese audiences last year, she felt their warmth and appreciation for her movies despite the language barrier.

Describing Almagor as one of Israel's best ambassadors, ISECO Representative Raphael Gamzou, said at a press conference Friday afternoon dedicated to Almagor that her visit is also part of an Israeli cultural season that has been organized by his office.
The office, he said, attaches a great deal of importance to cultural exchanges, among other activities, between Israel and Taiwan.

"It's very important for us to let Taiwanese friends to feel that our representative office here is active in a multifaceted and multidimensional way. We are definitely interested in developing exchanges and relationships at all levels and all areas of potential progression," Gamzou said.
"It is (also) very important to lay foundations for developing future dialogues and future relationships with the future generations between Israel and Taiwan," he added.

The Israeli cultural season, which kicked off Sept. 26 to mark Tel Aviv's centennial, will continue through the rest of the year and features a series of art and cultural activities such as movie screenings, contemporary dance performances, and concerts by noted Israeli artists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top weather forecaster determined to retire early: official

TEXT.P: Weather Forecast Center Director Daniel Wu is determined to retire early despite being repeatedly asked to stay on, his boss, Central Weather Bureau (CWB) Director-General Shin Tzay-chyn, said on Friday.
Shin said he tried to talk his colleague out of retiring early on a number of occasions, but Wu, citing his new career plans, refused to budge from his position.
Shin added that Wu's post will be filled from within the CWB and said the new appointee would be named in the next few days.

Wu, acclaimed by Shin and his deputy Lin Hsiu-wen as "Taiwan's top weather forecaster, " applied for retirement at the end of August after Typhoon Morakot devastated southern Taiwan, nine years before the 56-year-old meteorologist's legal retirement age.
After serving at the CWB as a weather forecaster for 30 years, Wu said he could no longer tolerate his professionalism being abused.

He said he could not accept "the media's distortions of the bureau's weather forecasts" and blamed television weathermen for often not clearly conveying CWB information or making their own "exaggerated" comments.
"Eventually, the weather bureau was blamed for all the mistakes," he complained.

Wu was also frustrated by local TV reports that said CNN's weather forecasts during Typhoon Morakot in early August were more accurate than the CWB's, and he lamented that the public would rather trust foreign media than CWB's professionalism.

Severe public criticism over CWB's forecasts on Typhoon Morakot, which dumped far more rainfall on Taiwan than the bureau predicted, as well as the Control Yuan's launch of an investigation into its allegedly inaccurate forecasts, were seen as triggering Wu's determination to retire early.
The storm caused the worst flooding in Taiwan in 50 years and left more than 600 people dead and thousands homeless.

"The public has often accused the bureau of not providing accurate forecasts after Taiwan suffered serious damage from several typhoons in the past two years. This kind of atmosphere can be frustrating for forecasters, " Shin said, calling Wu's retirement "a loss for the country."

Premier Wu Den-yih said Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo would try to persuade the experienced meteorologist to remain on the job, but he acknowledged it would be difficult to persuade the retiring forecaster to stay when he is determined to leave.

Daniel Wu graduated from the Department of Atmospheric Sciences of National Central University (NCU) and holds a master's degree in atmospheric science from National Taiwan University. NCU has said it will invite Wu to return the school to teach after he retires.

DOC.HEADLINE: Proximity to MRT biggest draw to prospective home buyers: survey

TEXT.P: Conveniently located mass rapid transit lines, shopping districts and urban parks are the three biggest draws to prospective home buyers, according to the results of a market survey released Friday.

In contrast, houses close to electrical substations, cemeteries and funeral homes, and garbage dumps, are the biggest turnoffs when consumers look for a new place to live, the survey's results showed.

The survey, conducted by Taiwan Realty from Oct. 1-8, asked visitors to the company's 200 outlets around Taiwan what they found to be the most attractive neighborhood features in selecting a new house. A total of 653 valid samples were collected in the poll.
The results showed that 86 percent of the respondents cited proximity to mass rapid transit lines as having the most appeal in choosing a new home's location.
Some 76 percent of those surveyed mentioned being close to shopping districts with famous department stores, such as the upscale Xinyi and Tienmu shopping districts, as being a major draw.
Urban parks are also attractive to potential home buyers, with 72 percent of the respondents citing them as an important prerequisite in deciding where to live.
"The figure indicates that local people have become more health conscious, as urban parks are good places for recreation and exercise, " said Jhally Chiu, a Taiwan Realty executive.
In the same survey, 92 percent cited electrical substations or power transmission pylons as structures that would deter them from buying homes nearby.
Cemeteries and funeral parlors were the second least appealing feature on the list, with 80 percent saying they would not buy a home near such facilities.
They were followed by garbage dumps, which 75 percent of respondents cited as something they would not want in their new neighborhood.
