DOC.HEADLINE: EP member backs drive for Taiwan to join U.N. agencies

TEXT.P: Graham Watson, a member of the European Parliament (EP), said that he fully backs an EP campaign for Taiwan to join specialized U.N. agencies, such as the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), according to The Parliament Website.

Watson, the former leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE) from 2002-2009, told the website that he "wholeheartedly" supports a growing European Parliament campaign calling for Taiwan's "meaningful" participation in international organizations.
"Given that Taiwan is still recovering from a devastating typhoon then, yes, of course it should be allowed to participate in organizations like this," he said.

In a Sept. 17 parliament debate, pro-Taiwan parliamentarian members proposed that Taiwan should be allowed to take part in the WMO so as to help it better deal with natural disasters at time of extreme climate change due to global warming. Taiwan suffered the worst devastation in 50 years when Typhoon Morakot hit the country in early August.

Responding to the proposal, EU Commissioner Meglena Kuneva said the European Union (EU) remains firm on its policy that it supports Taiwan's "meaningful" participation in international organizations under "appropriate circumstances."
Kuneva also promised that the EU will consider Taiwan's request to be covered in the EU's visa waiver program, which would allow Taiwanese people visa free entry into EU countries.

Taiwanese authorities have recently announced that Taiwan would seek to enter the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICA0).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday:
Apple Daily:
Buying votes in front of Ma's very eyes
Allegations of vote-buying are rife in the just concluded elections of members of the KMT Central Standing Committee.
Although the elections have nothing to do with the country, it may serve as a straw in the wind from which one can see what tactics the party will use in the forthcoming national elections.
The role of the KMT Central Standing Committee is expected to be downgraded into a rubberstamp of Ma's administration after Ma takes the helm of the party on Oct. 17.

Why there are still so many people vying for a seat on the committee? Probably they hope to win favorable treatment from China when they do business in China which mistakes the committee for the country's supreme policy-making body.

Ma has vowed to push for reforms within the party, but if he turns a blind eye to the widespread vote-buying in the elections of the Central Standing Committee members, we won't take much stock in his promise.
China Times:
Are the offenders too powerful or the party too feeble ?
Both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have difficulty controlling the local factions that are rife within them.
One day after the deadline for candidacy registration for the local government elections, the KMT expelled eight members who entered the races without the party's approval.
The two parties' problems bear out the fact that elections are seen more as a way to seize political resources and power than as a way to serve society.
Both the KMT and DPP prefer to field candidates with the best chance of winning rather than individuals they intend to groom as future leaders.
So they cooperate with local factions simply for the purpose of winning without regard for serving the people.
Liberty Times:
Without shame, President Ma pitches trade pact with China.
President Ma made a pitch for trade pact with China while presiding over the government's lowest-profile celebration of National Day in history.
Ma's administration has never told people what the trade pact with China is for other than claiming that it is inevitable.
On the other hand, Beijing is trying to close a noose around the neck of Taiwan through a trade pact similar to that it signed with Hong Kong and Macau.
So Taiwan is set to follow in the footsteps of Hong Kong and Macau and be annexed by China.

We believe the public should have a say in the matter via referendum and the people should deny Ma's party their votes in the year-end elections to show their disapproval of the proposed trade pact with China.
United Daily News:
From malicious politics to hatred democracy
A Taipei City councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party has destroyed a door of a Maokong Gondola station to demonstrate what he claimed to be the station's lax security.
His false claims showed the seamy side of the country's democracy, that is the opposition go all out to oppose whatever the ruling party does, without regard to the impact of its opposition.
Notable examples are the opposition's invitations to Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, Uighur activist Rebiya Kadeer and Falun Gong founder Li Zhihong to visit Taiwan.

Another example is the disaster caused by Typhoon Morakot, with DPP accused the ruling party of incompetency in dealing with it while the ruling KMT accused the DPP local chiefs of failing to do their duties.
We wonder where this form malicious politics and hatred democracy will lead the country to?

DOC.HEADLINE: Far Eastern New Century reports growth in Jan.-Sept. turnover
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 18:22:20 (By Wei Su and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The total business turnover of Far Eastern New Century in the first three quarters of this year was NT$13.65 billion (US$423 million), which represented a growth of 2.12 percent year-on-year, company chairman Douglas Tong Hsu said Tuesday.
In addition, investments by the corporation in the cement, retail, and telecommunication sectors in Taiwan and China are growing steadily, Hsu said at a provisional shareholders' meeting.
Since changing its name from Far Eastern Textile Co., the corporation has made diversified investment one of its three principal business activities, he said.

The corporation owns 244 affiliated companies, including nine listed companies in Taiwan and Hong Kong, with a combined value of NT$94.4 billion, up from NT$79.7 billion at the end of last year, according to Hsu.

Regarding the subsidiary Asia Cement, Hsu said its annual output in China has reached 20 million tons in the past, but with China's recent introduction of total quantity management and control, its factory expansion plan has hit a snag.
However, the cement company's annual output could amount to 28 million tons in 2011, once it is operating at full capacity, he said.

Asia Cement China is located in the central Yangtze River region and the Sichuan region where demand for cement has grown substantially because of the many post- disaster infrastructure projects that were launched in the wake of a powerful earthquake in Sichuan in 2008.

In the retail sector, Far East New Century has 43 operating outlets at present and another six that are under construction and are expected to be completed within two years, Hsu said. The six new retail operations will include department stores in Chengdu in Sichuan, Wukesong in Beijing, Wuxi in Jiangsu on the mainland, and Taichung and Hualien, and a 50-story office building in Banciao in Taiwan, Hsu said.

Its affiliated Far Eastern International Bank, since acquiring American International Group's (AIG's) Taiwan credit card business earlier in the year, has begun making profits and is planning to venture into the massive Chinese market once Taiwan signs a financial memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervisory cooperation with China, according to Hsu.

Noting that it has been more than a year since the global financial crisis began and that the worst of the economic recession may be over, Hsu expressed optimism about Taiwan's economic outlook based on the stability of country's financial system, its abundant liquidity and record low interest rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pushing for endorsement of its bid to join U.N. agencies

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it is still pushing for the endorsement of Taiwan's diplomatic allies of its efforts to participate in two United Nations specialized agencies.

Taiwan is seeking meaningful participation in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Joseph Y.L. Kuo, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, said at a regular press briefing Tuesday that Taiwan's embassies and representative offices abroad are working hard to encourage diplomatic allies to sign two position papers to be submitted to the ratifying countries of the UNFCCC and member countries of the ICAO.
"We have to maintain the momentum and the zeal, and continue to push (the bid)," Kuo said.
The MOFA announced Sept. 21 that Taiwan will strive for membership in U.N. specialized agencies, rather than direct participation in the U.N. as it had been pursuing in previous years.
The ministry called for the UNFCCC and ICAO to give favorable consideration to the needs of the Taiwan people and what they could contribute if admitted.

According to the MOFA, as of Tuesday, 15 of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies had signed a position paper in support of Taiwan's bid to participate in the UNFCC, while 14 of them had expressed support in the case of the ICAO.

Asked whether Taiwan should be concerned about the fact that some of the allies have not come forward in support of its U.N. bid, Kuo said that it does not reflect any change in diplomatic relations between Taiwan and those allies, some of which have different political and economic concerns.

Panama, for example, has not endorsed Taiwan's U.N. bid for years, as it has said many times that while it maintains diplomatic relations with Taiwan, it continues to develop closer economic relations with China.
Taiwan has not been represented in the U.N. since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China.
Since 1993, it has been trying to have the world body consider the issue of its representation, but has made little progress largely due to China's obstruction.

Taiwan's allies and supporters have been trying to get the General Assembly to list Taiwan's application for admission on the U.N. agenda, but Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.
This year, Taiwan has come up with a more flexible and pragmatic approach that it hopes will allow it to better negotiate the complex situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica finds new approach to vaccine design

TEXT.P: A research team at Academia Sinica has discovered that the size of the sugar molecules on the hemagglutinin (HA) protein in influenza viruses play an important role in immune responses, findings that may lead to a new strategy for the development of influenza, hepatitis C and HIV vaccines, officials said Tuesday.
The results have been published in the latest online issue of U.S.-based Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
The study was conducted by injecting mice with different versions of H5N1 vaccines and exposing them to the bird flu virus strain, the officials said.
The result revealed that mice immunized with vaccines obtained from the sugar- modified HA had a survival rate more than double those that had been given the non-modified version, the officials said.

Also, the study found that the binding force between HA and human cell receptors became stronger when the sugar molecules were reduced in size, and mono- glycosylated hemagglutinin as a vaccine showed a stronger immune response.

Che Alex Ma, an assistant research fellow at the Academia Sinica's Genomics Research Center, explained that as conventional influenza vaccines are made from oligosaccharide HA molecules resembling those on human cell surfaces, they could easily fool the immune system into becoming unguarded when intruded.
By using the modified HA molecule as the vaccine, the immune system can fully recognize the HA protein and trigger an alerting system that will not be confused by the sugar disguise, Ma said.

The study demonstrated that the removal of structurally nonessential glycans on viral surface glycopreoteins may be a very effective approach to vaccine design against influenza and other human viruses, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's education ministry to subsidize top single-field research
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 19:17:31 (By Fanny Liu and Lin Szu-yu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Education Minister Wu Ching-chi said Tuesday that the country's second five-year NT$50 billion program to upgrade the nation's universities into top academic research centers, will focus on subsidizing top-notch, single-field academic research.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan committee, Wu said details of the program were being discussed by a group of professors and experts led by Wong Chi-Huey, President of Academia Sinica, the most preeminent academic institution in Taiwan.

Wu said the program will mostly focus on subsidizing single-field research, such as the cognitive neuroscience research at National Yang-ming University and the photonics research at National Chiao Tung University.
Each year, the program will provide NT$ 10 billion in subsidies, Wu added.
Wong, the president of the Academia Sinica, has invited academicians and other experts to discuss the subsidy allocation details.

Wu said the first five-year NT$50 billion program to boost academic institutions' quality will expire at the end of 2010. The program has already met its targets, given the fact that National Taiwan University (NTU) ranked among the world's top 100 universities for the first time this year.
NTU took 95th place in the Higher Education league table of The Times of London, compared to 124th in 2008.
Ministry of Education Department of Higher Education Deputy Director Yang Yu-hui has made clear last week that the second 5-year program will not just subsidize NTU.
If the government does so, there will only be one university in Taiwan that can enter the top 100 universities list, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT announces launching of 2010 democracy video challenge

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Tuesday announced the launch of the 2010 Democracy Video Challenge (DVC), a worldwide contest aimed at enhancing the global dialogue on democracy.

Now in its second year, the contests asks budding filmmakers, democracy advocates, and the general public to create video shorts that complete the phrase "Democracy isK, " according to an AIT press release.
The 2009 DVC attracted over 900 submissions worldwide, including nine from Taiwan. The winning film for the East Asia and the Pacific Region was from the Philippines.

"We appreciated the compelling entries submitted to the challenge last year by filmmakers from Taiwan. We hope that this year's competition will attract an even greater number of participants, " Scott Robinson, the director of AIT's American Cultural Center, was quoted as saying.
"Given Taiwan's vibrant democracy and creativity in filmmaking, it would be nice to see a film from Taiwan among the finalists, " he added.

According to the press release, seven winning videos will be chosen -- one each from Sub-Saharan Africa, East Asia and the Pacific, Europe, the Near East and North Africa, South ad Central Asia, and the Western Hemisphere, as well as one anonymous video.

Using YouTube as the video platform for the challenge, the winners will be granted an all-expenses paid trip to Washington D.C., New York, and Hollywood, where gala screenings of the winning videos will be held, it added.
They will also meet with film directors, public officials and democracy advocates from non-governmental organizations in the U.S., and visit film and television program sets.
The AIT said that it will hold a screening to evaluate submissions in Taiwan.

Taiwan partners of the challenge include the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, Council for Cultural Affairs, Chinese Taipei Film Archive, Taiwan Film and Culture Association, SPOT Taipei Film House, National Taipei University of the Arts and National Taiwan University of the Arts.
The deadline for submissions to the 2010 DVC is Jan. 31, 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's gov't to discuss taxing overseas compatriots

TEXT.P: Government agencies in Taiwan will discuss next week how overseas Taiwanese compatriots should be taxed, the head of the Cabinet-level Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) said Tuesday.

OCAC Minister Wu Ying-yih said at a Legislative Yuan session that OCAC officials will meet with officials from the Ministry of Finance next week to discuss technical details of a statute which stipulates that Republic of China citizens will have to pay a minimum tax rate on annual overseas income in excess of NT$1 million (US$31,000), starting Jan. 1, 2010.
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced in September that starting next year, Taiwanese nationals will have to pay a minimum tax rate on annual overseas income in excess of NT$1 million.

The new regulation will apply to Taiwanese citizens who live in Taiwan or overseas and who have an annual overseas income of more than NT$1 million and consolidated personal income of over NT$6 million.
Wu said the OCAC will seek to address the issue of equity involving the citizens' rights and duties.

He made the remarks in response to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ming-hsing, who said the new MOF tax law would legitimize the government to tax overseas- residing ROC citizens, prompting some of them to think about renouncing their ROC citizenship.

Wu said he understands that it is unacceptable to some of the Taiwanese businessmen operating overseas, including the Chinese mainland, that their incomes derived from overseas are duty-free, but that they will soon be taxed in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Wu said, Taiwanese young men who had gone overseas to reside prior to age 18 used to have to be conscripted into compulsory military services once they returned to Taiwan after they were 18 years old or older, but such a law had been changed and only those who return to live in Taiwan longer than 183 days a year will have to be conscripted.
"Some of the overseas-residing ROC citizens hope that they be taxed only if they return to Taiwan to live in their own homes in the country for longer than 183 days a year," Wu noted.
The new MOF tax law defines overseas income as salaries and wages, interest, rent, royalties, business profits, capital gains, professional fees, gambling winnings, pensions and other income.
Vice Finance Minister Chang Sheng-ford said that starting Jan. 1, a 20 percent minimum income tax will be imposed on those who fall within the specified income category.
Only those whose personal income exceeds NT$6 million will be subject to the tax, Chang said.

For example, if the overseas income is NT$3.5 million and the consolidated personal income is NT$2 million, the total amount will be NT$5.5 million and therefore that person will not be subject to the new tax because their income is less than NT$6 million, Chang explained.
If people fall within the income bracket but are already paying income taxes of more than 20 percent, they will be exempt from the new tax, he added.
People who have been paying taxes in other countries on their overseas income can file that as deductible amount on their taxes in Taiwan, he said.

He said the new regulation is not expected to affect many people and will not have any impact on capital repatriation. The new tax will be introduced next January, and will not be applied retroactively, he added.
Under the Act Governing Relations Between Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, income derived in China will not be considered "foreign."
However, earnings from Hong Kong, Macau and the rest of the world will be subject to the minimum 20 percent rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH moves ahead with E-medical record plan

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved Monday a plan that will allow about 80 percent of the country's hospitals to use an integrated system of electronic medical records for patients, starting in 2012.

Under the plan proposed by the Department of Health (DOH), about 60 percent of the nation's hospitals will be able to share electronically stored medical records by that time, a DOH official said Tuesday.

The plan, to be implemented between 2010 and 2012, is aimed at shortening patient waiting times at clinics, avoiding unneeded duplication of medical tests and prescriptions, and avoiding the unnecessary waste of medical resources.
The project will cost NT$6.04 billion, with the money provided from the budget for a project to stimulate the economy and expand public infrastructure.

There has been a legal basis for the establishment of an e-medical record system since 2005, but for a variety of reasons, including inadequate incentives and a lack of funds, the practice of computerizing patient records is not prevalent, according to the official.
The DOH hopes that up to 400 hospitals, or 80 percent of the total in the country, as well as 14,000 clinics, or 70 percent of the total, will be using e-medical records by 2012.
Once the e-medical records system becomes popular, patients will be able to get their medical records anywhere in the country simply by providing their National Health Insurance IC cards.
The DOH also hopes the country's hospitals and medical institutions will agree to shift to such a national system for providing and sharing e-medical records, the official said.

The e-medical records will include medical examination reports, imaging pictures, blood test results and prescription records, as well as results of examinations involving radiation, such as computer tomography scans and magnetic resonance imaging scans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Serving Wangyeh generation to generation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 20:41:41 (By Kuo Chi-hsuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: For many Donggang residents, the 300-year-old Wangyeh festival, held every three years, is an event passed on from one generation to the next, with many of the official positions in the eight-day temple activity passed down from father to son.

For this reason, many children and teenagers can be observed serving in the blessing procession of the deity Wen Wangyeh, which began Sunday in the Donggang fishing port in Pingtung County, southwestern Taiwan, dressed either as "Bantou" -- public officials responsible for maintaining order -- or "Jiaoban" -- sedan carriers.

Unlike the youth who take part in other temple activities, the young Bantou and Jiaoban have inherited the "man-only" positions from their fathers or the elders in their families, and are recognized by the god through a ritual, said 41-year -old Su Po-wen, who has taken part in the festival with his Bantou father since he was 5 years old.

Su stated that if a Bantou has no son, he can pass on the post to the children of his sisters, but the succession must be approved by Wangyeh. Applicants for the position, or those who want to quit, have to ask for the god's permission through the ritual of throwing two divining crescents on the ground, he said.
In order to acquire the permission, the applicants must promise to serve in the post and hand the position down from generation to generation, Su added.

Asked why would he promise to be a Bantou in this way, Su said that "it is a kind of drive to serve Wangyeh whenever the festival is held. Particularly at the time of greeting and bidding farewell to the god, I would feel bad if I did not come."
The traditional temple ceremony to honor Wen Wangyeh began at Jhenhai Park in Donggang last Saturday with a complicated welcoming ritual before the launch of a four-day blessing procession.
The ceremony culminates on the last day of sumptuous rituals with the ceremonial burning of an elaborately carved wooden boat.
More than 10,000 Wangyeh believers from outside the township, as well as curious tourists, have flocked in Donggang to observe the largest and most complex festival of its kind in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai Culture Week opens with acrobatic shows
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 20:46:37 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Shanghai Culture Week opened in Taipei Tuesday with shows presented by teenage performers from the Shanghai Acrobatic Troupe and the Shanghai Circus School.
Among the performers were 17-year-old Cai Yong and 15-year-old Jin Ying.
According to Jiang Zhengping, deputy chief of the Shanghai Acrobatic Troupe, Cai and Jin are two of the leading acrobats in China, and Cai has won an Italian presidential prize.
Cai, who is visiting Taiwan for the first time, said his ambition is to become a professional artistic performer and that he looks forward to opportunities to perform in other countries.
The acrobatic shows are scheduled for Oct. 13-14 at Taipei's Zhongshan Hall.
The 12-day culture week will also feature Kungqu opera and art works and films from Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 50% of students in Taipei eat unhealthy snacks: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 20:52:26 (By Chen Li-ting and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Some 52.5 percent of elementary and junior high school students in Taipei have a habit of buying snacks after school on their way home, and their favorite choices are fried chicken and shake drinks, the results of a survey released Tuesday showed.

This means that one in every two students aged 11-15 in the greater Taipei area is at risk for gastrointestinal problems because of the unhealthy foods they consume at the end of the school day, according to the survey conducted by a Taipei medical university hospital, Shuang Ho.
Some 40 percent of parents would not start paying attention to their children's diets until the students develop gastrointestinal problems, the poll found.

Yeh Tzu-chen, a family medicine doctor at Shuang Ho Hospital, said more than 60 percent of the snacks that Taiwanese students favor, such as fried chicken, French fries and pearl milk tea, are high calorie foods and tend to cause acute gastroenteritis in children. In addition, Yeh said, the pearl milk tea and similar drinks sold by street vendors are usually unsanitary.
Many local students suffer from gastrointestinal diseases because their diets lack fiber and vitamins, Yeh said.

He cited the case of a female sixth-grade student who complained of abdominal pains and loss of appetite and was found by doctors at Shuang Ho Hospital to have chronic constipation. Her parents had taken her to the hospital on suspicion that she had intestinal tumors, Yeh said.
The girl recovered within a week after receiving treatment at the hospital and was put on a vegetable-based diet, he said.
It was a clear case how an unhealthy diet can seriously affect a child's physical wellbeing and learning abilities, Yeh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: China welcome to invest in public works open to international bidders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 21:15:38 (By Su Lung-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that both Chinese and foreign capital are welcome to take part in bidding for public construction projects that are open to international competition.

The premier made the remarks while fielding questions at a legislative session in which Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the ruling Kuomintang asked whether the government welcomes Chinese capital in BOT (build-operate-transfer) projects -- in which private contractors build and operate an infrastructure project for a certain period before transferring it to the government.

Lai noted that the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced June 30 the opening of 100 types of Taiwanese industries, ranging from manufacturing to the service and public construction industries, to Chinese investment.
But he said that less than NT$200 million from 15 Chinese businesses had been approved as of mid-October and questioned the poor results of such opening.
Wu said that if China is allowed to take part in bidding for every public construction project, it could affect the survival of domestic construction businesses.
But he also noted that as Taiwan became a member of the Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) of the World Trade Organization in mid-July, it is bound to follow relevant regulations.
"For this reason, the government will follow the regulations as they relate to international competition," he said.

The Public Construction Commission had said earlier that after Taiwan's GPA accession, it would open 16 percent of its government procurement opportunities -- estimated to be worth US$6 billion a year -- to GPA signatories.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Taiwan millionaires falls to 58,000: poll

TEXT.P: : The number of Taiwan citizens whose net assets exceeded US$1 million fell last year by 18 percent to 58,000, according to a survey released here today.

The survey by Merrill Lynch and Capgemini shows that there were 71,000 millionaires in Taiwan in 2007, and 66,000 in 2006. It attributes the decline to the global economic downturn, coupled with challenging equity and property markets.
In the Asia Pacific region, Japan and China together accounted for 71.9 percent of the total millionaire population and 65.8 percent of the region's wealth, at the end of 2008.
The number of millionaires in Japan last year was 1,366,000, down by 9.9 percent from the previous year, while in China the number was 364,000, down by 11.8 percent year-on-year.

The survey also shows that the wealthy in Hong Kong took the hardest hit in the region last year as a result of the global financial crisis, with the number of millionaires dropping by 61.3 percent to 37,000. The assets calculated in the survey include the value of private equity holdings, as well as all forms of publicly quoted equities, bonds, funds and cash deposits. It excluded collectibles, consumables and real estate used as primary residences.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to assume KMT chairmanship Oct. 17
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 21:30:31 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to assume the chairmanship of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Oct. 17 at the party's 18th national congress, during which Ma will perform the power of consent over the nomination of the party's vice chairman, KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said Tuesday.

Ma will make an inauguration speech during the conference in which he will appeal for party reform and solidarity, said Lee Chien-jung, chairman of the KMT's Culture and Communications Committee, adding that Ma will also drum up support for the party's nominees for year-end city and county chief elections.
The agenda for the conference was to be confirmed by the party's Central Standing Committee the following day, according to Lee.

The party congress, which will take place at the Sinjhuang Stadium in Taipei County, will begin with a changeover ceremony in which Ma will take over the chairmanship from his predecessor, Wu Poh-hsiung, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: After `minor mutiny,' Taiwanese fishing boat returns home
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 21:35:58 (By Tseng Yi-shuan and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat on which there was a "minor mutiny" while it was operating in the Pacific Ocean 10 days ago returned to Taiwan Tuesday.

Escorted by a Coast Guard Administration (CGA) vessel, the Yu Chun No. 166 arrived at Chichjn Harbor in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, where its Captain Shih Chin-hsing and Chief Engineer Tsai Ming-chih were reunited with their families.

Shih said that he and Tasi were threatened by two of the 10 Indonesian crewmen, who had armed themselves with knives, while their vessel was operating in waters some 1,600 km off the northeastern coast of Taiwan Oct. 2.
Shih and Tsai locked themselves in the wheelhouse and called their family via satellite phone for help, prompting the CGA to send a vessel to its rescue.
The captain turned the boat toward Japan's Ogasawara Islands -- some 1,000 km south of Tokyo -- and asked the Japanese government for permission to dock there.

Shih and Tsai decided to sail for home after the Japanese authorities allowed them only to moor 30 miles from the port out of concern by Japan's immigration authorities on how to handle the boat and is crew.

After meeting the vessel Oct. 9 when it was some 1,000 km east of Ouluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, four armed CGA officers boarded the vessel, freeing Shih and Tsai and subduing the suspected Indonesian crewmen.
The two suspects were later transferred to the relevant authorities for further investigation.

"We were lucky enough to be able to come home unharmed, unlike the cases in many other sea mutinies, although we did suffer a loss of NT$1 million as we caught no fish, " Shih said after meeting his wife and son.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMD president urges Taiwan to nurture tourism
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 22:19:31 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should develop and nurture its tourism industry, the head of a prestigious business school located in Lausanne, Switzerland said Tuesday.

John R. Wells, president of the International Institute for Management Development (IMD), made the remarks in a seminar in Taipei presided over by San Gee, deputy chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

Wells urged Taiwan to think about nurturing its service industry. Noting that the government does have plans to upgrade its service industry, such as the development of the tourism, medical and education sectors, he also said it should take stock of developments in other countries, adding that if Taiwan wants to develop its tourism, it could learn from the experience of Spain.
He also said that if the people of China, with its population of 1.3 billion, want to visit Taiwan, tourism revenues will be immense.

Taiwan Institute of Economic Research President David Hong said on the same occasion that Taiwan's economic growth in the past relied on the manufacturing industry and that while it still needs the manufacturing industry, its service industry is gradually on the rise.

He suggested that the government should attach greater importance to the service industry, "especially because most of the research and development funding is now used for the manufacturing industry, but in fact, should be focused more heavily on innovation and R&D in the service industry."
Wells earlier gave a speech on strengthening Taiwan's competitiveness in face of global challenges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to become `beacon of light for the world:' Holy See

TEXT.P: A Vatican official expressed confidence Monday in Rome that Taiwan will become "a beacon of light for the world" with its strong democratic traditions, spiritual civilization and tenacity, according to a statement released by the Republic of China Embassy to the Holy See.

Monsignor Gianfranco Ravasi, president of the Pontifical Council for Culture, made the remarks in a written address to a conference on the Catholic history of Taiwan. The speech was read by Ravasi's deputy, Monsignor Sanchez Del Toca, who attended the event on his behalf.

The conference was held by the Republic of China Embassy to the Holy See and the Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, or the Angelicum. It drew the participation of more than 150 scholars, Vatican officials, diplomats, priests and professors from the university.
In his opening remarks, ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Wang Yu-yuan noted that a free and democratic system is the cornerstone of religious freedom.
The fact that the Catholic church and 25 other religions are thriving in Taiwan is testament to the country's progress in democratic development, Wang said.

Although the number of Catholic followers accounts for less than 2 percent of Taiwan's population, the Catholic concepts of fairness and justice are deep- rooted in Taiwan through educational, medical and humanitarian programs promoted by the Catholic church, Wang went on.
He said humanitarianism, justice, charity, poverty reduction and the preservation of world peace are values commonly shared by Taiwan and the Holy See.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel laureate wants undisturbed life
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CAN) 10/13/09 22:50:42 (By Stanley Cheung and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The wife of the 2009 Nobel laureate in physics, Charles K. Kao, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, said Tuesday that her husband wanted to return to a quiet and undisturbed life and asked the media to respect his wishes.

In an open letter delivered through the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), of which Kao once served as president, Kao's wife said that since the announcement Oct. 6 that Kao had been awarded the Nobel prize, they had received messages from friends from all over the world.
"We are overwhelmed by the sea of congratulatory messages from so many people," the letter said.
"A Nobel laureate of Chinese ethnicity is a rare event and we understand the outpouring of happiness and pride for our people throughout the world wherever they live," the letter said.

"We would like to thank all who have expressed concern about his (Kao's) health. Unfortunately there is no cure at present for Alzheimer's. Charles shares this problem of coping with Alzheimer's with other eminent persons, Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher to name but two," it continued.

"He (Kao) is eminently proud of his past achievements and excited at becoming a Nobel laureate -- an unexpected award. The press and media have interviewed him and he is happy they have found all the facts they need. So he is more than ready to return to a quiet and undisturbed life now, and he asks that the media respect this, " the letter said.

Kao, 75, was named one of three winners of the 2009 Nobel Prize for Physics for his ground-breaking discoveries that led to the development of modern fiber- optic communication networks that transmit voice, video and high-speed Internet data around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan increases presence at Frankfurt Book Fair

TEXT.P: Taiwan will enjoy a greater presence at this year's Frankfurt Book Fair thanks to increased participation by official and private publications at the event, the Cabinet-level Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Tuesday.

A total of 1,630 print and digital publications from Taiwan, including 123 government publications, will be on display at the world's most prominent event of its kind, which will take place Oct. 14-18, RDEC officials said.
On the first three days, the fair is open to trade visitors only, while it will be open to the general public on the weekend of Oct. 17-18.

To forge a more robust image of Taiwan and tout its values in the international community, the government-run Taipei Book Fair Foundation (TBFF) invited a large numbers of public agencies to take part in the annual book fair.

Of the 123 official publications covering a wide range of topics such as tourism, culture, history, the arts, industrial development and general reading, 50 were put forward by the RDEC, 17 were selected by the National Palace Museum, nine were recommended by the National Museum of Taiwan Literature, and four each were selected by the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center and by the Taipei county government, the TBFF said.
The Frankfurt Book Fair is the world's largest trade fair for books, based on the number of publishing companies represented. It is held annually in mid- October in the German city of Frankfurt.
Representatives from book publishing and multimedia companies from all over the world attend the fair in order to negotiate international publishing rights and licensing fees.
The fair is expected to draw over 7,000 exhibitors from over 100 countries, with more than 286,000 visitors expected to attend, organizers said.

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat on which there was a "minor mutiny" while it was operating in the Pacific Ocean 10 days ago returned to Taiwan Tuesday.

Escorted by a Coast Guard Administration (CGA) vessel, the Yu Chun No. 166 arrived at Chichjn Harbor in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, where its Captain Shih Chin-hsing and Chief Engineer Tsai Ming-chih were reunited with their families.

Shih said that he and Tasi were threatened by two of the 10 Indonesian crewmen, who had armed themselves with knives, while their vessel was operating in waters some 1,600 km off the northeastern coast of Taiwan Oct. 2.
Shih and Tsai locked themselves in the wheelhouse and called their family via satellite phone for help, prompting the CGA to send a vessel to its rescue.
The captain turned the boat toward Japan's Ogasawara Islands -- some 1,000 km south of Tokyo -- and asked the Japanese government for permission to dock there.

Shih and Tsai decided to sail for home after the Japanese authorities allowed them only to moor 30 miles from the port out of concern by Japan's immigration authorities on how to handle the boat and is crew.

After meeting the vessel Oct. 9 when it was some 1,000 km east of Ouluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, four armed CGA officers boarded the vessel, freeing Shih and Tsai and subduing the suspected Indonesian crewmen.
The two suspects were later transferred to the relevant authorities for further investigation.

"We were lucky enough to be able to come home unharmed, unlike the cases in many other sea mutinies, although we did suffer a loss of NT$1 million as we caught no fish, " Shih said after meeting his wife and son.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMD president urges Taiwan to nurture tourism
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/09 22:19:31 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should develop and nurture its tourism industry, the head of a prestigious business school located in Lausanne, Switzerland said Tuesday.

John R. Wells, president of the International Institute for Management Development (IMD), made the remarks in a seminar in Taipei presided over by San Gee, deputy chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

Wells urged Taiwan to think about nurturing its service industry. Noting that the government does have plans to upgrade its service industry, such as the development of the tourism, medical and education sectors, he also said it should take stock of developments in other countries, adding that if Taiwan wants to develop its tourism, it could learn from the experience of Spain.
He also said that if the people of China, with its population of 1.3 billion, want to visit Taiwan, tourism revenues will be immense.

Taiwan Institute of Economic Research President David Hong said on the same occasion that Taiwan's economic growth in the past relied on the manufacturing industry and that while it still needs the manufacturing industry, its service industry is gradually on the rise.

He suggested that the government should attach greater importance to the service industry, "especially because most of the research and development funding is now used for the manufacturing industry, but in fact, should be focused more heavily on innovation and R&D in the service industry."
Wells earlier gave a speech on strengthening Taiwan's competitiveness in face of global challenges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to become `beacon of light for the world:' Holy See

TEXT.P: A Vatican official expressed confidence Monday in Rome that Taiwan will become "a beacon of light for the world" with its strong democratic traditions, spiritual civilization and tenacity, according to a statement released by the Republic of China Embassy to the Holy See.

Monsignor Gianfranco Ravasi, president of the Pontifical Council for Culture, made the remarks in a written address to a conference on the Catholic history of Taiwan. The speech was read by Ravasi's deputy, Monsignor Sanchez Del Toca, who attended the event on his behalf.

The conference was held by the Republic of China Embassy to the Holy See and the Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, or the Angelicum. It drew the participation of more than 150 scholars, Vatican officials, diplomats, priests and professors from the university.
In his opening remarks, ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Wang Yu-yuan noted that a free and democratic system is the cornerstone of religious freedom.
The fact that the Catholic church and 25 other religions are thriving in Taiwan is testament to the country's progress in democratic development, Wang said.

Although the number of Catholic followers accounts for less than 2 percent of Taiwan's population, the Catholic concepts of fairness and justice are deep- rooted in Taiwan through educational, medical and humanitarian programs promoted by the Catholic church, Wang went on.
He said humanitarianism, justice, charity, poverty reduction and the preservation of world peace are values commonly shared by Taiwan and the Holy See.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel laureate wants undisturbed life
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CAN) 10/13/09 22:50:42 (By Stanley Cheung and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The wife of the 2009 Nobel laureate in physics, Charles K. Kao, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, said Tuesday that her husband wanted to return to a quiet and undisturbed life and asked the media to respect his wishes.

In an open letter delivered through the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), of which Kao once served as president, Kao's wife said that since the announcement Oct. 6 that Kao had been awarded the Nobel prize, they had received messages from friends from all over the world.
"We are overwhelmed by the sea of congratulatory messages from so many people," the letter said.
"A Nobel laureate of Chinese ethnicity is a rare event and we understand the outpouring of happiness and pride for our people throughout the world wherever they live," the letter said.

"We would like to thank all who have expressed concern about his (Kao's) health. Unfortunately there is no cure at present for Alzheimer's. Charles shares this problem of coping with Alzheimer's with other eminent persons, Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher to name but two," it continued.

"He (Kao) is eminently proud of his past achievements and excited at becoming a Nobel laureate -- an unexpected award. The press and media have interviewed him and he is happy they have found all the facts they need. So he is more than ready to return to a quiet and undisturbed life now, and he asks that the media respect this, " the letter said.

Kao, 75, was named one of three winners of the 2009 Nobel Prize for Physics for his ground-breaking discoveries that led to the development of modern fiber- optic communication networks that transmit voice, video and high-speed Internet data around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan increases presence at Frankfurt Book Fair

TEXT.P: Taiwan will enjoy a greater presence at this year's Frankfurt Book Fair thanks to increased participation by official and private publications at the event, the Cabinet-level Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Tuesday.

A total of 1,630 print and digital publications from Taiwan, including 123 government publications, will be on display at the world's most prominent event of its kind, which will take place Oct. 14-18, RDEC officials said.
On the first three days, the fair is open to trade visitors only, while it will be open to the general public on the weekend of Oct. 17-18.

To forge a more robust image of Taiwan and tout its values in the international community, the government-run Taipei Book Fair Foundation (TBFF) invited a large numbers of public agencies to take part in the annual book fair.

Of the 123 official publications covering a wide range of topics such as tourism, culture, history, the arts, industrial development and general reading, 50 were put forward by the RDEC, 17 were selected by the National Palace Museum, nine were recommended by the National Museum of Taiwan Literature, and four each were selected by the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center and by the Taipei county government, the TBFF said.
The Frankfurt Book Fair is the world's largest trade fair for books, based on the number of publishing companies represented. It is held annually in mid- October in the German city of Frankfurt.
Representatives from book publishing and multimedia companies from all over the world attend the fair in order to negotiate international publishing rights and licensing fees.
The fair is expected to draw over 7,000 exhibitors from over 100 countries, with more than 286,000 visitors expected to attend, organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 14, or the 26th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese war.
1915: The Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of China government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk at Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Maj. Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society, " with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for the Republic of China membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
2000: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji says in Tokyo that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he adds that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that the accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small causes. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
As military villages fade, residents try to keep memories alive

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

Businessman Wang Rong-sheng recently returned to Taiwan during a break from running his company in China's Shandong province and accompanied his 85-year-old mother to Tainan City in southern Taiwan to visit the neighborhood they had called home since 1950.

What he came home to was a wrenching site, even if he knew what to expect. The 61-year-old Wang's old village of Shuei-jiao-she, a 45-hectare residential compound for Republic of China Air Force personnel and their dependents since 1948, had been razed.
Like many of its residents, Wang's father, an Air Force officer, and his family settled there after fleeing China following the communist victory in the Chinese civil war.

Memories of his family's Japanese-style home, the air raid shelter where he played hide-and-seek with his friends, and the stand where his mother would buy steamed buns for breakfast from a veteran from Henan province all welled up as Wang was overcome with emotion.

Wang's wife of 35 years could appreciate how her husband and his mother felt after seeing their home of nearly five decades turned into piles of debris as she also grew up in a village for military dependents, known in Taiwan as "juan cun, " that no longer exists.

Nostalgia is all many former residents of these "juan cun" have left as the villages fade into oblivion with the old soldiers passing away and the single story dwellings, many left over from the Japanese colonial era, being torn down to make way for urban development projects.

Roughly 600,000 armed forces personnel and their dependents from China settled in the juan cun -- mostly quickly erected shanty villages -- and the compounds were like miniature versions of China, with people from different Chinese provinces living next door to each other.

By 1982, fewer than 100,000 units in some 300 full-scale compounds were left nationwide. All that remains today are some 1,300 housing units on military village sites scattered around Taiwan, their obstinate residents holding out against having their houses torn down.

Even the Wangs moved out of Shuei-jiao-she in the late 1990s, in pursuit of modern comforts and new opportunities, but, as with many former juan cun residents, their village still exists vividly in their memories, and some former residents are pushing to preserve their culture in more than just their minds.

Yu Lih-hua, a professor at National University of Tainan who was raised in Shuei-jiao-she, and a group of Shuei-jiao-she activists have scrambled to save parts of the village since Tainan City began dismantling the compound in 2007.
"We Shuei-jiao-she people have lagged behind our counterparts in other juan cun around the country in the area of conservation, " Yu said.

As Shuei-jiao-she grew obsolete during this decade, the Tainan City government quickly moved to reclaim the 45-hectare site and earmarked some NT$200 million to clean up the village, build new roads and manage the land in a bid to turn it into an upscale residential area with a shopping mall.

But through the persuasive efforts of Yu and other activists to keep Shuei-jiao- she's memory alive, the city government left standing eight Japanese style residences, the village's elementary school and anumber of old trees, and these are being converted into a military village cultural park.
The old residences will become museums and an ecological park will highlight the site's century-old elm trees, decades-old mahogany trees and giant coconut trees.

A total of 23 juan cun have been preserved in similar ways around the country, and Yu says Shuei-jiao-she could be selected by the Ministry of Defense as one of up to 10 locations that will be developed into juan cun cultural preservation areas aimed at conserving the unique culture of these villages.

The Military Dependents' Service Department under the MND's General Political Warfare Bureau has asked local governments to submit their plans by next March to participate in the NT$400 million project.
"It is hoped that the juan cun culture conservation project will eventually create new tourism and cultural assets for the country, " said Lin Ching-fu, head of the MND department.
They are not the only ones trying to preserve juan cun tradition.

When Wang and his mother were touring their old village, which they moved out of in the late 1990s to pursue opportunities elsewhere, they were guided by Chu Rong-mei, who was also raised in Shuei-jiao-she and now teaches Japanese at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan.

She wrote a book called "Shuei-Jiao-She -- a Juan Cun in Memory" that was published in December 2008, and she said she forced herself to complete the project in two months, before an Asahi Shimbun crew visited Shuei-jiao-she to cover its history and current predicament as part of an in-depth report on Taiwan's juan cun and their culture.
"We could not let the Japanese outperform us in the effort to conserve our own unique but fading juan cun culture," Chu said.
During the Wangs' tour of the village, Chu took them to an open field where several individual Japanese residences were located before they were leveled in 2007.

The land that once was home to houses built by the Japanese military for its naval officers and their dependents before Japan's surrender in 1945 has ironically given way to even older historical relics.
It is now an archeological site after scores of ancient tombs were discovered there, some dating back to the Ming Dynasty (1368V 1644) and the Qing Dynasty (1644-1912).
The tombs, comprised of gravestones and wooden coffins with thick earthen and gravel shells, were unearthed after workers cleaned away the leveled buildings in April to make way for a new road.
Turning to another area of the now empty village, Chu identified a place where the homes of the first-generation pilots of the famous "Thunder Tiger" jet fighter squad were located.

The "Thunder Tiger" squad was a source of pride for Taiwan during the 1950s and 1960s. Some of the squad members were national heroes for downing China's MiG-15 and MiG-17 fighters during missions across the Taiwan Strait before the '60s.
The squad's exceptional flying skills were also shown off at National Day parades and overseas shows between 1952 and 1989.
This "Thunder Tiger" phenomenon was one of the "collective memories" of Shui- jiao-she and just one of the elements that made the village so unique, Yu says.

In the same vein as the village's celebration of the "Thunder Tiger" squad, the name of Tainan Air Force Elementary School, attended by almost all children raised in Shuei-jiao-she before the 1970s, was changed to Tainan Municipal Chihkai Elementary School in 1967 in memory of air force hero Chou Chih-kai.
Chou was conferred medals by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek during the early 1940s for downing six Japanese fighters. He was later killed in an air battle in Hubei province in 1943.

His mother, honored as "the Mother of the Air Force, " moved to Taiwan in 1949 and settled in Shuei-jiao-she, where she lived until passing away in the 1980s. She was once elected as a member of the Tainan City Council, with her supporters being mostly air force personnel and their dependents.

Those who grew up in Shuei-jiao-she all remember an open stadium village where many renowned movie stars from Taiwan and Hong Kong, even America, visited to meet their local fans and cheer up the military troops.
But perhaps as enduring as any memory are the basic tastes and smells derived from the variety of food representing all corners of China that appeared in the village.

Many dishes mixed the traditions of various Chinese provinces with culinary innovations born of necessity in a time of scarcity -- cooked dog meat sold by a veteran from Guangdong, cold noodles peddled by a veteran from Sichuan, and cured pork sold by veterans from Hunan.

Through the efforts of Yu, Chu, and many other activists and local governments, those memories will now be allowed to survive, enabling families like the Wangs to relive their old culture as the military villages fade away.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second wave of H1N1 outbreak emerging in Taiwan: CDC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 11:42:16 (By Chen Li-ting, Chen Ching-fang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) warned Wednesday that a second wave of the influenza A (H1N1) outbreak is emerging in Taiwan after the previous one peaked in early September.

According to CDC Director-General Steve Kuo, the H1N1 situation has been moderating over the past five weeks since the previous peak but a slight jump in the number of patients diagnosed with the new flu strain recently signals the beginning of the second wave.

Statistics released Wednesday by the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) show that there was one more patient hospitalized with the H1N1 flu strain than a day earlier, bringing to 355 the total number of such cases since the outbreak began.
While 16 of the patients remained in the hospital, 315 had recovered and been discharged, and 24 others had died, the CECC said.

Meanwhile, 442 classes in 294 schools around the country remained suspended because of H1N1 infections among students. The number of affected classes accounted for 0.29 percent of the total, according to the CECC.

Although epidemiologists have predicted that the second peak would appear in November, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said it is hard to predict when the peak will be and that the DOH will continue to monitor the situation closely.
To help the public prepare for the epidemic, the DOH will distribute 5 million masks in inventory to 100,000 low-income families beginning Nov. 1, Yaung said.

Also, the CECC is expected to make public details regarding its H1N1 vaccination program on Oct. 20, when the results of human clinical trials for the H1N1 vaccine produced by local vaccine manufacturer Adimmune Corp. are expected to be released, DOH Deputy Minister Chang Shen-chwen said.
While people under 10 years of age will probably have to receive two shots, those aged 10 years and older will likely need only one to be protected against the disease, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New envoy to Indonesia still under consideration: foreign minister

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang said Wednesday that the appointment of the new representative to Indonesia is being finalized, but he refused to confirm that former Vice Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia will be the one to take over the post.

"The appointment of the new envoy to Indonesia is in the final stages of the process but has yet to be finalized, " the foreign minister said during a budget review hearing in the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee.
He said many candidates were being considered and that an announcement would be made when the time is ripe.

Local daily the Liberty Times reported Wednesday that Hsia, who stepped down to take political responsibility for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) response to Typhoon Morakot, has been tapped to be the new envoy to Indonesia.

The appointment is in line with President Ma Ying-jeou administration's policy to focus on expanding contacts and exchanges with countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, in which Indonesia is a major player, the report said.
It added that Yang's ascension as foreign minister after serving as Taiwan's representative to Indonesia only added importance to the position.

Hsia tendered his resignation to take responsibility for the Foreign Ministry's instructions Aug. 11 to ask all its foreign offices to politely decline any offers of help from their host governments in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which swept though Taiwan Aug. 7-10, killing over 600 people.

He and former Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou later stepped down along with former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and the rest of his Cabinet, which resigned en masse last month, to assume political responsibility for what was called a slow and inadequate government response to the typhoon disaster.
Asked whether it would be "compensation" for Hsia if he were appointed as the envoy to Indonesia, Yang simply replied, "there is no such issue as compensation."

"Given Hsia's profound diplomatic experience and his excellent performance that is well recognized by our colleagues in the Foreign Ministry, he has plenty of opportunities to continue contributing to the development of foreign relations," Yang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan completes signature drive for bids to join U.N. agencies
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/14/09 13:39:37 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng, Y.F. Low, and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has concluded a signature drive for its bids to participate in two United Nations specialized agencies, but not all of the country's allies endorsed it, Taiwanese officials posted in the United States said Tuesday.

While 16 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies signed a position paper in support of its inclusion in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) , 15 signed another paper petition on Taiwan's participation in the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) , according to officials at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York.
The two documents are expected to be delivered respectively to the U.N. missions of UNFCCC signatories and ICAO member nations by Thursday, the officials said.

The allies that endorsed the UNFCCC bid are the Solomon Islands, Palau, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, the Marshall Islands, Belize, St. Lucia, the Gambia, Sao Tome and Principe, Nicaragua, Tuvalu, Nauru, Swaziland, El Salvador, Burkina Faso, Kiribati, and St. Christopher and Nevis.
These same allies also endorsed the ICAO bid except for Tuvalu, which is not an ICAO member.
The seven allies that did not sign either of the documents are Paraguay, Panama, Guatemala, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Honduras and the Holy See.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Henry Chen downplayed the lack of support from some of Taiwan's allies, saying that Taiwan only "welcomed" rather than pushed allies to endorse the petition.

The lack of outward support from certain allies does not mean, however, they would not support or speak on Taiwan's behalf at the meetings of the specialized agencies when the country's bid for participation is being considered, Chen said.

As the UNFCCC secretariat is located in Bonn, Germany, and the ICAO headquarters is in Montreal, Canada, Taiwan will also have its representative offices in these two countries help push the respective bids, TECO officials said.

They said promoting the UNFCCC bid ahead of the United Nations Climate Change Conference slated for Dec. 7-18 in Copenhagen will highlight the urgency and importance of Taiwan's meaningful participation in the convention.

Since 1993, Taiwan has been trying -- unsuccessfully, due to Beijing's objections -- to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation. In 2008, the country shifted its strategy to promoting a bid to "participate meaningfully in the activities of specialized U.N. agencies, " in line with President Ma Ying-jeou's diplomatic strategy that favors a moderate and pragmatic approach.

Following Taiwan's success in its bid to attend the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's decision-making arm -- as an observer for the first time in May this year, the government has recently announced that the UNFCCC and the ICAO will be the country's next targets for such "meaningful participation."
