DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday:
CHINA TIMES:
Grand justices should decide early on former president's request for constitutional interpretation

Former President Chen Shui-bian has requested a constitutional interpretation on the changing of the head of the panel of judges during his trial on corruption charges, with Chou Chan-chun giving way to Tsai Shou-hsun.

Such a request was unprecedented, and the direct reason behind the request is that Chen thinks there were irregularities in the changing of the panel's chief judge. Chou decided twice that Chen should not be detained, while Tsai has consistently maintained that Chen should be detained. Because the interpretation by the grand justices could affect the legitimacy of the court's decision in the trial, how they handle the request will become the focus of attention.

The deliberation process of the constitutional interpretation cases is usually not in the open, in contrast with the transparency of regular court cases, but due to the high-profile nature of the case, the grand justices should think deeply about the request and make a speedy decision.
LIBERTY TIMES:
Ma administration's next step will be to list Falun Gong as
evil cult

National Security Bureau Director-General Tsai Teh-sheng recently said that Falun Gong is not an evil cult, and its founder Li Hongzhi is not a terrorist, but it is not appropriate for him to visit Taiwan at this stage.

Li as well as Uighur rights activist Rebiya Kadeer are not allowed to come to Taiwan because of political sensitivity, with their visits potentially sabotaging warmer cross-strait relations, according to Tsai.
The so-called political sensitivities is in fact toeing the China line for fear of offending Beijing.
It is well known that China is the only country that stigmatizes the Falun Gong, smearing it as an evil cult.
China arrests and tortures Falun Gong practitioners. But Taiwan upholds religious freedom, and the Falun Gong is protected under the constitution of the Republic of China.
Today, the Ma administration kowtows to China and bans Li's entry. The public should not be too surprised when the administration obeys Beijing and declares the Falun Gong an evil cult.
l
UNITED DAILY NEWS: From Obama to Wei Jingsheng

U.S. president Barack Obama is the surprise winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, and the long-held expectations of such Chinese human right activists Wei Jingsheng and Hu Jia to win the prize fell through.
If the prize was to be awarded to the activists, Wei is certainly more qualified than Hu, who came out 30 years later and who received a higher education.

In comparison, at Wei's time, Mao Zedong had just died and China was a closed- door society after tumultuous 10-year Cultural Revolution. Wei's appeal for democracy was the most impressive cry from the grassroots level in the "Beijing Spring" movement.

Wei said in an article called "the Fifth Modernization: Democracy" that was posted on Beijing's Democracy Wall in 1978 that Deng Xiaoping, who crushed the 'Gang of Five,' (including Mao Zedong) should "give thanks to the outcries that catapulted him to power."

The calls were actually the voice of the people, and in Wei's view, the "Gang of Five" was not only defeated in 1976 through an internal struggle won by Deng and Ye Jianying but also because of that public voice.

Although Wei was then a 28-year-old electrician in a Beijing zoo and a senior high school graduate, his philosophy had tinges of Jean-Jacques Rousseau and John Locke, and he foresaw China's direction over the next 30 years,
Wei's political views may have been shared by many at China's grassroots level, but they would not or did not dare express them explicitly as Wei.
Though Beijing's leaders, such as Hu Jintao, cannot identify outwardly with Wei's, they should allow the people's "voice" to constantly reverberate in their minds.
APPLE DAILY: Ma administration has not delivered on promises

Three months after opening Taiwan to Chinese investment, only NT$189 million has entered Taiwan. The number of Chinese tourists arriving in Taiwan has also fallen far short of expectations since its opening last year.

But now the Ma administration is going to sign an MOU on financial supervisory cooperation and an economic cooperation framework agreement with China. That has caused great concern among workers, who fear that unemployment will rise even as businesses welcome the measures.
After the signing of the MOU, Chinese banks could set up branches in Taiwan, but China has no private banks, and they will serve political purposes after they come to Taiwan.

If the Chinese branches offer higher interest rates than local banks and draw a high volume of deposits, then lend the money to Chinese-invested enterprises in Taiwan that then buy important assets in Taiwan, how will the government grapple with such a scenario?
The misgivings about the ECFA run deeper. The Ma administration is thinking about mitigating the impact of Taiwan being marginalized after the ASEAN plus one (China) goes into effect next year.

But has China made any promises? If more local businesses flow out of Taiwan and go to China after the implementation of ASEAN plus one, and China's agricultural, service and manufacturing products flow into Taiwan, the products made with cheap labor could threaten the very survival of similar industries in Taiwan.

The Ma administration vows not to let in Chinese agricultural products and laborers, but this will run counter to the spirit of the WTO and the ECFA. The administration needs to assuage the public's misgivings about these questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 99.15 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 7,695.75.
The local bourse opened at 7,649.07 and fluctuated between 7,700.42 and 7,618.79 during the day's trading session.
A total of 5.23 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$148.03 billion (US$4.59 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues and textile stocks both moving up the most at 1.83 percent. Construction issues rose 1.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares increased 1.52 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 1.05 percent, cement stocks were up 0.84 percent, paper and pulp issues advanced 0.64 percent, and banking and financial shares rose 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,684 to 876, with 261 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$10.59 billion-worth of shares for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth cross-strait talks set for December in Taichung

TEXT.P: A fourth round of talks between the chief cross-Taiwan Strait negotiators of Taiwan and China will be held in December in the central city of Taichung, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Wednesday.

Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and China-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin last met in Nanjing in April, when they signed three agreements on the launch of regular cross-strait passenger flights, mutual judicial assistance and financial cooperation, as well as releasing a joint statement on a proposal to open Taiwan to Chinese investment.

The date and venue for the next Chiang-Chen talks were decided upon in a meeting held in Hangzhou a day earlier between SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian and his ARATS counterpart Zheng Lizhong, according to MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun.

In their upcoming meeting, the two officials are expected to sign four agreements regarding fishing labor cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, standards, inspection and certification for industrial products, and the avoidance of double taxation, Liu said.
Related officials from the two sides will meet soon to thresh out the details to be covered by the agreements, Liu added.

The SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies set up by Taiwan and China, respectively, to deal with cross-strait affairs and negotiations in the absence of official ties between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP urges regulator to check for Chinese capital in Nan Shan deal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 16:01:05 (By Fanny Liu and Wen Kuei-hsiang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday requested the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) to examine if the acquisition of Nan Shan Life Insurance Co. by a consortium led by a Hong Kong financial services firm was financed with capital from China.
The financial regulatory body should check if the ultimate beneficiary of the Nan Shan deal has any connection with China, according to DPP spokesman Chao Tien-lin.
"Regardless of whether it's financed by foreign capital or Hong Kong capital, the most important point is that there should be 'zero Chinese capital,'" Chao said at a press conference.

He stressed that if the government did not track down the ultimate beneficiaries in the deal, the "zero Chinese capital" principle might be nominally achieved, but Chinese investors could still be involved.
The transaction will be examined first by the Investment Commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and then sent to the FSC for final approval.
Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang would not comment on the issue Wednesday because the deal has yet to be sent to the Investment Commission.
An Investment Commission official added that the agency will carefully examine the deal after related documents are received.

US insurer American International Group Inc. (AIG) announced Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its 97.57 percent stake in its Taiwanese unit, Nan Shan Life, to a consortium comprising Hong Kong-based financial services firm Primus Financial Holdings and Hong Kong-listed investment firm China Strategic Holdings Limited for US$2.15 billion (NT$69.3 billion).

Robert Morse, chairman and co-CEO of Primus, denied at a press conference Tuesday that Chinese capital was involved in financing the acquisition, saying the funds came from institutional investors and wealthy families around the globe.

FSC Vice Chairwoman Lee Jih-chu said Tuesday that Primus has guaranteed that the Nan Shan deal was not funded by Chinese capital, but added that she has asked the company to provide documentation to prove the absence of Chinese interests in the deal.
According to local laws, companies with Chinese funding are not allowed to invest in Taiwan's financial institutions, including insurance companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peaceful transitions show democracy can work in Asia: legislator

TEXT.P: A ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator and member of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy's (TFD) board of directors, said at an international symposium Wednesday in Taipei that the two peaceful transitions of power in Taiwan prove that democracy works in Asia.

"The transitions of power in Taiwan -- it speaks for itself loud and clear our conviction that democracy can work in Asia, " John Chiang said at the Symposium on Democracy Building in Asia, which is being jointly held by U.S. think tank the Heritage Foundation, the nongovernmental TFD, and the Institute for National Policy Research (INPR).
Chiang was referring to the changes of government in Taiwan in both 2000 and 2008.
Taiwan's 2000 presidential election realized an unprecedented transition of power in the Republic of China's 90-year history, when the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ousted the long-ruling KMT.

In 2008 the KMT returned to power following landslide wins in both the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election, marking the second time Taiwan's electorate had put the opposition party in power in the country's history.

Edwin Feulner, president of the Heritage Foundation, echoed Chiang's views Wednesday, saying that while he was well aware of Taiwan's blemishes, he also knew how far Taiwan has come in terms of self governance, as the country has moved from authoritarianism to fighting communism, to a vigorous participatory democracy.
"The peaceful transfer of power has validated Taiwan's democratic experiment in the eyes of the world," Feulner said.
"Taiwan is better for having proved a democratic proposition through this repeated, peaceful transition of power from one political party to another," he added.

Speaking of building democracy in Asia, Chiang said it is an enormous and very difficult task to have democracy take root in Asia in a short period of time, given the continent's complexity, with its range of political and economic systems and great variety of cultural, linguistic and religious traditions and practices.

Describing the discussion of the development of democracy in Asia that is taking place in Taiwan as very appropriate, Feulner said that as unsettling as changes of government can be, they themselves have testified to the value of freedom.
"Whatever our peers in non-democracies may tell us, their own people want for the power to be free to choose, that is to change their governments," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong considering setting up office in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's chief executive announced Wednesday a series of measures to enhance the territory's relations with Taiwan, including a plan to set up an office there at an appropriate time.
Chief Executive Donald Tsang revealed the plan during his annual policy address to the Legislative Council Wednesday.
Tsang singled out Hong Kong's relations with Taiwan as one of the major topics in his address, which dealt mainly with economic issues.

"In response to the latest development in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, we will actively pursue economic, cultural, social and other exchanges with Taiwan in accordance with the Basic Law and Qian Qichen's Seven Principles," he said.
According to Tsang, the government will adopt the following strategies to develop its relations with Taiwan:

-- It will initiate bilateral business cooperation committees and establish a Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council to promote multi-faceted, multi-level exchanges with Taiwan.
Hong Kong will consider setting up a multi-functional office in Taiwan at an appropriate time and in an appropriate format to enhance high-level exchanges between the two sides.

--Hong Kong will foster economic cooperation with Taiwan, focusing particularly on trade services, and will commence discussions with Taiwan on arrangements for avoidance of double taxation, with a view to achieving progress and results.
--Hong Kong will play an active role in providing cross-strait yuan currency clearing services.

The government will seek to enable Hong Kong travel agents to operate in mainland China to sell tours to Taiwan, and will explore the further development of multi-destination tourism products -- including air and cruise packages -- among Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.
Tsang did not elaborate on the plan to set up the multi-functional office in Taiwan.

Currently, the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, which is financially supported by the government, has an office in Taipei but it deals only with trade matters and does not represent the Hong Kong government.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.060 to close at NT$32.242.
A total of US$908 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.312 and dropped to a low of NT$32.223.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar held on Kinmen to mark 60th anniversary of Guningtou battle

TEXT.P: A seminar was held on the outlying island of Kinmen Wednesday to mark the 60th anniversary of the battle of Guningtou, in which Kuomintang (KMT) forces fought off attacking Chinese communists to maintain control of the island.
Forty-one veterans of the battle were invited to attend the event, where they were paid tribute for their devotion to protecting the country.
The seminar was organized by the Kinmen National Park Administration and the Kinmen County Veterans Service Office.
Tseng Wei-hung, head of the park administration, noted that the battle of Guningtou was a crucial fight that helped Taiwan ward off the danger of being seized by the Chinese communists.

By analyzing and assessing the successes and failures of the battle, the seminar was aimed at providing lessons for people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and highlighting the value of peace, said Tseng.

The battle of Guningtou took place Oct. 25-27, 1949, when nearly 10,000 communist troops in 200 ships invaded the Taiwanese frontline stronghold of Kinmen, which lies just off the coast of China, as a prelude to seizing Taiwan.
In the ensuing fierce three-day battle, the invaders were utterly routed, losing nearly 4,000 soldiers, with another 5,200 captured.
The defeat brought a 10-year halt to Beijing's attempts to take Taiwan by force. In 1958, the communists began a protracted bombardment of Kinmen, but again failed to seize any part of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expected to relax ban on U.S. beef with precautions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 18:19:01 (By Yang Chu-min, Lee Chia-fe and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to re-open its doors soon to imports of U.S. bone-in beef, shredded beef, some beef offal and other beef products, after Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu made a public promise Wednesday that consumers' health will be safeguarded.
"No matter whether it is in my capacity as vice premier, or as chairman of the Consumer Protection Commission, I will not sacrifice consumers' rights and benefits," Chu said.

Chu made the promise while answering questions from Legislator Hou Tsai-feng of the ruling Kuomintang at the Legislative Yuan, who expressed concern after President Ma Ying-jeou said his administration had come close to a consensus with the United States on the beef issue.

It means the country is coming close to relaxing restrictions against imports of the controversial beef products from the U.S., which reported its first case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- in 2003, prompting its major Asian trade partners, including Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, to reject all its beef products.

Taiwan partially lifted the ban in April 2005 to allow imports of de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months old, but it reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, Taiwan once again agreed to allow U.S. beef imports, but only boneless beef from cattle under 30 months old, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any high-risk parts such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines.
Over the past year, the U.S. has never stopped trying to persuade Taiwan to open its doors more widely to its beef products, without regard for the safety concerns of local consumers.

At the Legislative Yuan, the vice premier said that the scale of Taiwan's relaxation of restrictions against U.S. beef imports will not be larger than those of South Korea, which he said imposes the most strict safety standards on U.S. beef among all the world's importers.
Chu said, however, that "if the restrictions are too tight, they might harm the bilateral economic and trade relations and the trust (between Taiwan and the U.S.) "
The government will demand that retailers sell U.S. beef in special sections to allow consumers to decide whether to purchase it or not, he added.

A day earlier, Ma told a visiting delegation of the Heritage Foundation, a Washington, D.C.-based think tank, headed by Chairman Edwin J. Feulner, that Taiwan and the U.S. have come close to a consensus on the beef issue.
Ma expressed hope that the problem will be resolved in "the foreseeable future."
Meanwhile, Minister of Health Yaung Chih-liang said imports will be restricted to bone-in and boneless beef without high-risk parts and from cattle aged under 30 months.
Asked when the restrictions will be relaxed, Yaung said "it should be near."

DOC.HEADLINE: Civil servants should not play online game at work: CPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 18:22:53 (By Fanny Liu and Li Ming-tsung)

TEXT.P: The Central Personnel Administration (CPA) said Wednesday that civil servants are not allowed to play the Facebook application Happy Farm, a popular free online game, during working hours.

CPA Chief Secretary Chang Nien-chung said such behavior violates the Civil Servants Law and the Civil Service Performance Evaluation Act, as civil servants are not permitted to attend to non-civil service matters during work hours.

Government organizations can decide upon methods of punishment, including oral or written warnings, or even sending severe cases to be reviewed by the Commission on Disciplinary Sanctions for Functionaries in accordance with the law, Chang said while responding to questions from reporters.

As the Happy Farm game has been gaining popularity among civil servants, Premier Wu Den-yih also said civil servants should focus more on performing public services, although he added that the government has not yet issued an order banning such behavior.
It would be unlikely to restrict such behavior if civil servants were to play in their non-working hours, he went on.
Some local governments have already taken measures to ban playing, with Kaohsiung county officials saying the game has been blocked by their firewall.

The Taipei city government has taken a more flexible approach by allowing the Facebook connection during lunch breaks while banning access during working hours, while the Taipei county government has blocked the game, a newspaper reported that day.
Happy Farm is currently the most popular online game in the nation, with some 3.3 million people playing it. There are some 16 million global users, according to the game's developer.

The game was designed by three Chinese men under the age of 30 in Shanghai in 2008 and sold to Facebook in April 2009. Players have to "raise crops and livestock, and can take part in cattle rustling and garden raids."

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade promoter sees more Chinese procurement from Taiwan next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 18:33:01 (By Chang Minga-kun and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The total value of goods China will procure from Taiwan next year is expected to exceed that of this year, although it will adopt a different procurement approach, China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT) Vice President Zhang Wei said Wednesday.

Following a thaw in cross-Taiwan Strait relations since President Ma Ying-jeou was inaugurated in May last year, the CCPIT has organized several procurement missions to Taiwan with an aggregate procurement value of over US$10 billion.

Zhang was in Taiwan as the head of a Chinese group that attended a cross-strait seminar on the management of finance corporations that opened earlier that day at the Taipei International Convention Center.

He said that from next year, China's procurement from Taiwan will be "normalized, " which means procurement will be made on a regular basis rather than sending procurement groups that each spend at least NT$1 billion.
"Moreover, the total value of China's procurements from Taiwan will increase year-on-year," he added.

Zhang, who concurrently serves as deputy head of several Chinese non- official organizations, including the Affiliate of International Chamber of Commerce in China, the Chinese Taxation Society, the China Finance Society and the China Law Society, said that " Taiwan is attractive to Chinese investors."

He made the remarks in response to comments on the limited size of Chinese investment in Taiwan after the government began allowing investment in certain areas from the other side of the strait in late June.
According to official statistics, Chinese investments totaled a mere NT$189 million as of the end of September, far lower than the general public's expectation.

"These enterprises need a `trial and accommodation' process before they can reach the decision on whether to invest in Taiwan, and we are here trying to figure out the right directions for would-be investors," Zhang said.
He said that with an excellent investment climate, Taiwan would be able to attract more Chinese investment in the future.
Zhang also said that China's economy is gaining momentum, with a predicted 8.5 percent growth this year, from which Taiwan and the rest of the world will benefit as a result.
He also noted that China's foreign trade is gradually recovering from the impact of the international economic crisis, evidenced by the shrinking rate of decrease in its trade volume.
According to China's latest official statistics, the country registered a total trade volume of US$1.557 trillion in the first nine moths of this year, down 20.9 percent from a year ago.
Zhang predicted that China foreign trade will fall by 20 percent for 2009, taking into account a possible global economic recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Issue of THRSC's handover period has to be addressed: vice minister

TEXT.P: Sooner of later the government will have to deal with a request by the debt- ridden Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) to extend the 35-year concession period to allow the company to reduce its mounting deficit, the vice minister of transportation said Wednesday.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Kuang-shih said an extension of the time when the THRSC is supposed to hand over the project to the government will help the company to deal with its depreciation and amortization issues in the face of its huge debts.
The THSRC board of directors appointed Ou Chin-de as the company's chairman last month -- a decision that was widely seen as a bid to help the corporation recover from its snowballing losses.

Since the system went into operation more than two years ago, the THSRC -- Taiwan's largest build-operate-transfer (BOT) project -- has incurred a deficit of NT$70.3 billion (US$2.18 billion) , mainly due to some NT$60 billion in high interest on its bank loans and depreciation and amortization costs that total over NT$40 billion.

The THSRC inked a contract with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) in July 1998 to build the high-speed rail on the BOT model, under which it agreed to operate the system for 35 years then hand it over to the government. The agreement also gives the THRSC the right to development of the railway stations for a period of 50 years.

The THSRC is expected to hold an extraordinary shareholders' meeting in November to elect new board directors and supervisors, which will pave the way for the government to play a leading role in steering the future course of the company.
Meanwhile, the government is trying to arrange a new deal between the bank syndicate and the company to obtain lower interest rates so that the company could better service its loans, Yeh said.

According to Yeh, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications also thinks that it is unreasonable that the contract sets the depreciation rate for the THSRC equipment and facilities at 26.5 years, because the service life of the company's rail equipment and construction is estimated at 100 years and 80 years, respectively.

Chiang Chin-shan, a representative from the Continental Engineering Corporation (CEC) who is on the board of directors, said that the contract would have to be revised to allow for an extension of the handover period.

In addition, Chiang said, unavoidable natural disasters should also be factored in. During the construction of the high speed rail project, work was suspended due to an earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999. He added that it makes sense to also extend the THRSC depreciation and amortization period.
The CEC is one of the THSRC's five original principal shareholders.
Meanwhile, Susan Chang, chairwoman of Bank of Taiwan, said Wednesday that the five major shareholders have refused to increase their investments, despite a legislative resolution asking them do so.
"The matter has been handed over to the MOTC, " Chang said, in response to Kuomintang Legislator Sun Ta-chien's questions about the banking syndicate loan to the THSRC.

The bank consortium arranging the syndicate loan is also asking the THSRC's five founding stakeholders to provide a joint liability guarantee for the new loan and to give a clear answer by the end of this month, banking sources said.
According to Chang, the five major shareholders have rejected the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lafayette slush fund still frozen in Swiss bank: top prosecutor

TEXT.P: A slush fund from the scandal-plagued Lafayette frigate deal struck between Taiwan and France in the early 1990s is still frozen in a Swiss bank account, Taiwan's top prosecutor said Wednesday.

State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming made the remarks while fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting after recent news reports said a Swiss federal court revoked earlier this month a 1996 court ruling that determined the French contractor paid kickbacks on the Lafayette deal in violation of its contract with Taiwan.
According to the news report, the Swiss court's about-face ruling might adversely affect Taiwan's chances of winning an international commercial arbitration that is still under way in Paris.

Taiwan has demanded the repayment of US$520 million in unlawful kickbacks from Thales -- the French company that sold six Lafayette frigates for US$2.5 billion to the country in 1991 under its previous name of Thomson-CSF.
Under Article 18 of the contract, the French contractor was prohibited from making any kind of commission payment.
In the arbitration petition, Taiwan is also demanding payment of 17 years' worth of interest on the money.

Over the ensuing years, the French contractor has insisted that it did not pay any commission to secure the deal, but the French government has refused to unveil any information about the money trail, citing the need to protect its defense security, which has made it difficult to resolve the case.
Local media reports said the latest Swiss court ruling seems to back the French claim and could eventually lead to Taiwan's loss in the arbitration process.

Responding to lawmakers' concerns about the prospects for the case, Chen said the Oct. 8 Swiss court ruling clearly states that all the Taiwan-related Lafayette slush fund will remain frozen in a Swiss bank account at Taiwan's request.
Chen was referring to US$495 million in unlawful kickbacks on the Lafayette deal paid to Andrew Wang, the middleman who was Thompson-CSF's agent in Taiwan.
Chen said the Swiss court writ will remain in place until after a Taiwanese court has made a final ruling on the Wang-related corruption case.

According to the Taiwanese investigation, Thompson-CSF paid the US$495 million to Wang and a further US$25 million to Alfred Sirven, a former vice chairman of the French oil firm Elf-Aquitaine. Sirven is alleged to have played the role of money launderer and allocator of the kickbacks.

Wang fled Taiwan in late 1993 following the death of Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng under suspicious circumstances. Yin is believed to have been poised to blow the whistle on colleagues who had allegedly received kickbacks from the Lafayette deal. Wang has been wanted by the Taiwanese authorities for Yin's murder since September 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau backs Kaohsiung's bid to attract Chinese tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct.14 (CNA) 10/14/09 20:48:38 (By Fanny Liu and Chen Shun-hsieh)

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau said Wednesday that it will fully support the promotion of Kaohsiung tourism in China, as the number of economic and trade groups from China to the southern Taiwan city has dropped recently.

Tourism Bureau Director Janice Seh-Jen Lai made the comment in response to a request by the Kaohsiung City government for the bureau to assist in promoting the city's tourism business in eastern China's Zhejiang province.
The occupancy rate at hotels in Kaohsiung City in September was about 50 percent, which was 10 percent lower than in the same period last year, Lai said.

Some 1,000 mainland Chinese tour groups visited Kaohsiung in September, close to the figure a year earlier, she said at legislative question-and-answer session. However, many economic and trade groups have canceled their reservations and the number of business visitors has dropped sharply, she added.

In the wake of the financial crisis, the outbreak of influenza A (H1N1), and Typhoon Morakot, the number of tourists from Japan and Korea has also dropped, contributing to the low occupancy rate at Kaohsiung hotels, Lai said.
According to the Tourism Bureau, during the first nine months of the year, the monthly average number of tourists from Japan was down 8 percent, and from Korea the drop was 39 percent.

According to some Kaohsiung tourism business executives, the decrease in the number of Chinese tourists to the city was caused by the city government's decision to invite Tibet's spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan to pray for victims of Typhoon Morakot, and the city's screening of a documentary on exiled Uigher activist Rebiya Kadeer.

China's Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council said Wednesday that the engagement of some interest groups in Kaohsiung with Tibet and Xinjiang separatist forces has jeopardized China's interests and turned off the Chinese people.
It is only natural for the Chinese people to show their displeasure, said the office's spokeswoman Fan Liqing at a press conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: No consensus yet on how to use China's relief donations: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 21:00:32 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not yet reached a consensus on how the money donated by China for Typhoon Morakot relief should be used, a senior cross-strait negotiator said Wednesday.

Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , made the remark after a visit to Hangzhou, China the previous day to discuss the date and venue for a new round of cross- strait talks on issues of mutual concern.

Kao said he exchanged views with his Chinese counterpart, Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , on the issue of the use of China's typhoon relief donations to Taiwan.
"But there is no consensus yet on the issue," Kao said.

According to Kao, China has remitted 150 million yuan (about NT$710.4 million) to Taiwan for reconstruction projects in the wake of the devastation wrought by Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan in August. The remaining amount that China has pledged in disaster aid to Taiwan will be remitted later, he added.
Kao said Zheng did not present a list of rehabilitation projects that China hopes Taiwan will fund with the donations.

But Zheng did mention that China looks forward to seeing its donations used to finance reconstruction of the Sijhou bridge in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, which will cost an estimated NT$500 million (US$15.53 million), Kao said.
China also expressed the hope that the names of its donors will be engraved on all new structures built with the funds, to highlight the goodwill between the people on both sides, he said.
In this regard, China took its cue from Taiwan, which donated huge sums after China's Sichuan Province was devastated by a deadly earthquake in May 2008, Kao noted.
At the time, Taiwan requested that the names of its donors be inscribed on the reconstruction projects that were to be built with its donations.

Kao said he had told Zheng that Taiwan's political situation is different from China's and that an overall assessment by the relevant central government agencies would be required to determine how the funds should be used.

According to an agreement reached at Tuesday's Kao-Zheng meeting, the fourth round of talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin will take place in the central Taiwan city of Taichung in December.

Chiang and Chen last met in Nanjing in April, when they signed three agreements on the launch of regular cross-strait passenger flights and mutual judicial assistance and financial cooperation. They also released a joint statement on a proposal to open Taiwan to Chinese investment.

In their upcoming meeting, the two officials are expected to sign four agreements regarding fishing labor cooperation; agricultural quarantine inspection; standards, inspection and certification for industrial products; and the avoidance of double taxation, Kao said.
Related officials from the two sides will meet soon to thresh out the details of the proposed agreements, he added.

The SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies set up by Taiwan and China, respectively, to deal with cross-strait affairs and negotiations in the absence of official ties between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health food or medicine, fate of Centrum to be decided by year end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 21:13:25 (By Flor Wang and Yang Shu-ming)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumers will soon get a clear answer on whether Centrum, a U.S. brand of vitamins, is food or medicine, Vice Premier Eric Li-luan Chu said Wednesday.

The reason why the product needs to be properly categorized is because currently it is considered a type of medication by the government, which allows retailers to sell it for much higher prices than it is sold in the United States, where it is considered a type of nutritional supplement.

"I personally regard Centrum as a health food, but will ask the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) to make a review and come up with a decision by the end of this year, " Chu said while responding to inquiries from lawmakers at a hearing in the Legislative Yuan.
Chu doubles as chairman of the Consumer Protection Commission under the Executive Yuan.
Taiwan's Department of Health has branded Centrum as a medicine for its high level of vitamins, Chu noted.

Ruling Kuomintang lawmakers, Lai Shyh-bao, Ho Tsai-feng and Lin Hung-chih, questioned why Centrum, which is categorized as a health food in the United States, is considered and sold as medicine in Taiwan's market.
By categorizing the product as a type of medicine, retailers in Taiwan can charge high prices.
According to Ho, prices of Centrum sold in the Taiwanese market vary greatly, ranging from NT$5.38 per tablet to NT$8.32 each.
In April, the price of one bottle of Centrum was about three times that in the United States, Lai said. Even now, it is double the U.S. price, he pointed out.
Centrum is extremely popular among Taiwanese people, with many traveling to the United States to bring it back to Taiwan as a gift for their friends or relatives.
On Oct. 12, the Taiwan High Court upheld a verdict by the Taipei District Court by acquitting a Taiwanese woman surnamed Hsieh of the crime of selling banned drugs.
Hsieh, who runs a drug store, was selling Centrum in the domestic market. She had asked her friends to bring back the vitamins from the United States.
The High Court acquitted her on the grounds that the reasons cited by the DOH for categorizing Centrum as a type of medication was inadequate.
Taipei prosecutors appealed Hsieh's case to the Taiwan High Court after the local court ruled Hsieh not guilty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reforms needed for Taiwans young democracy: experts

TEXT.P: Several experts from Taiwan said Wednesday in an international symposium that constitutional and legislative reforms are needed to improve the island's young democracy.

The experts were speaking at the "Legislative Optimization and Tools of Democracysymposium at the Symposium on Democracy Building in Asia, which is jointly held by the Heritage Foundation, a U.S. research and educational think tank, the non-government Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD), and the Institute for National Policy Research (INPR).

According to Shaw Yu-ming, chairman of the Taiwan Foreign Ministrys Coordination Council for North American Affairs, for years there have been debates about whether the Republic of China has a presidential system or Cabinet system, and after many constitutional reforms, Taiwan has ended up with a dual executive system.

This means that the country would have a presidential system if the presidents political party is the majority party in the national legislature, while it can become a Cabinet system if the presidents political party is the minority party in the legislature, he added.

Shaw said that because former President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) did not abide by this dual executive system during his term from 2000-2008, many problems occurred, such as the fact that even though then opposition Kuomintang held the majority in the legislature, it was not able to dominate the Cabinet.

Therefore, Shaw contended that to resolve these constitutional problems, two constitutional amendments are needed: First, in the presidential election, only when a candidate has received a simple majority of votesVthat means over 50 percentV can he or she be elected. Therefore, sometimes a second round of election is needed.
Second, in order to hold the executive branch accountable to the national legislature, the appointment of the premier has to be approved by the national legislature, Shaw added.

Joseph Wu, former Taiwan representative to the U.S. and a research fellow at National Chengchi University, said at the symposium that as a young democracy, a more important issue for Taiwan should be democratic consolidation.

According to Wu, while some political scientists argued that the most important rules of a democracy are being accepted and followed in Taiwan, the island is perhaps still struggling over how its democracy can be consolidated.
This is because there are still on-going debates on issues such as Taiwan's national identity, and whether Taiwan should have a presidential system or a parliamentary system, he added.
Former DPP legislator Hsiao Bi-khim said that the optimization of Taiwans legislative process is a very important element in the consolidation of Taiwans democracy.
Further strengthening and optimizing the role of the legislative branch in Taiwan does enhance the fundamental principle of checks and balances in a modern democracy,according to Hsiao.
Therefore, Hsiao contended that it is essential to revise the structure of the legislature, to increase accountability and checks and balances, and to improve the quality of legislation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Researcher hopes molecule vaccine can be marketed within 10 years
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 21:26:18 (By Lin Si-yu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: After announcing a discovery that the size of sugar molecules on the hemagglutinin (HA) protein on influenza viruses plays a decisive role in immune responses, Academia Sincia President Chi-Huey Wong said Wednesday it is hoped that human trials of the vaccine produced based on the findings can be completed within five years, and it can be marketed within 10 years.

Wong made the remarks while answering questions by lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan after a briefing on the 2010 working plans and budget of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top academic research institute.

During the session, many legislators expressed concern over Wong's disclosure that the findings of his team's vaccine research will be transferred to a U.S. company, founded by an alumnus of National Taiwan University, for development of the vaccine.

In response to their questions on why Taiwan cannot hold on to such a major research breakthrough, Wong said the findings cannot be transferred to a company that is incapable of developing the vaccine.
"We have also to consider how much we can get" from the company that succeeds in developing and producing a profitable product based on Academia Sinica's findings, he said.

Academia Sinica owns the intellectual property rights for the "molecule vaccine, " Wong noted, adding that the institute will be paid royalties and the amount will vary at different stages of the vaccine's development.
If sales of the vaccine reach US$1 billion, Academia Sinica could earn US$100 million, he added.
Wong further explained that it requires at least NT$10 billion to develop a new vaccine and he had determined that no Taiwanese company can afford that.
For those reasons he picked an international company which has agreed to open a branch in Taiwan to work on the development and manufacture of the vaccine, he said.
On Wednesday, Wong expressed optimism over the development of effective vaccines against seasonal flu and the new A(H1N1) virus based on his team's findings.
The findings have been published in the latest online issue of U.S.-based Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Holland envoy says he may remain in Taiwan after his tenure ends
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/14/09 22:49:46 ( By Chang Jung-hsiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Holland' s envoy to Taiwan, Menno Goedhart, said Wednesday that he may seek to stay in Taiwan after his term expires next year.

"I will seriously consider remaining in Taiwan following the expiration of my current term, because I have my fellow 'tribesmen' here," Goedhart said at a joint press conference with Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai to promote Holland Day activities.

Since he was named the representative of the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office in Taiwan seven years ago, Goedhart has toured almost every corner of Taiwan, and has become an "elder" of the Rukai people, one of the 10-odd aboriginal tribes of Taiwan.
Some citizens of Holland married local aborigines, mostly Rukais, during the country's colonial rule of Taiwan between 1624 and 1661.

Goedhart said he was the second foreigner to be awarded the honor of the "elder" title by the Rukai group in Shantimen township in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung. The first foreign elder in the Rukai tribe was also a Hollander, in the early 20th century.
Goedhart said he would choose to live in Tainan City, which has granted him honorary citizenship, once his wife agrees to stay in Taiwan instead of returning to Europe.
This year's Holland Day activities, the third consecutive event of its kind organized by the Tainan City Government, will kick off Oct. 17.

The event willl feature a bike tour of the area around the Chicano Tower on Oct. 17-18, and a "Shuwu" (tree-house) party and a rock-and-roll concert on Oct. 24-25, in which Holland's folk plays will be presented and traditional Dutch delicacies will be served.
The Chicano Tower, formerly called Fort of Provintia, was built in Tainan City by the Dutch in 1653 during their colonization of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan media executives to visit China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CAN) 10/14/09 22:51:56 (By Liu Cheng-ching & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: High-ranking executives of Taiwan's media outlets will visit China Oct. 28-Nov. 11 for discussions on ways and means of enhancing cross-strait media cooperation, Vice Secretary General Ma Shao-chang of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.

Headed by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, the 20-member group will visit Beijing and Shanxi Province to exchange views on journalistic exchanges with their mainland counterparts and Chinese officials in charge of the media.
Currently, Taiwan and China allow correspondents from their major media outlets to remain on assignment on the other side for a maximum of three months on a rotating basis.
However, there have been calls for a "normalization" of journalistic exchanges between Taiwan and China through the reciprocal establishment of media branches or offices on each side.

The Taiwan media delegation to China will include executives and senior journalists from SET TV, Formosa TV and the Liberty Times, which in the past were deemed as having embraced a pro-Taiwan independence stance.

The SEF is a semi-official agency in charge of handling cross-strait affairs through its counterpart, China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), in the absence of formal contact between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Web site created to encourage migration to eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A special Web site has been created to encourage migration to eastern Taiwan and to promote the lifestyles of health and sustainability (LOHAS) and recreation and health care service development in the region, an official said Wednesday.

The Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior took the initiative to create the Web site at http: //www.easthealthpark.com.tw/index.aspx to serve as an information service platform that will help attract more long and short stay vacationers to eastern Taiwan and encourage migration to the region, the official said.
The new information service is also part of a comprehensive eastern Taiwan sustainable development project launched by the government, the official explained.

In recent years, the official said, an increasing number of retirees and people who intend to launch new businesses in the LOHAS and recreation sectors have migrated to eastern Taiwan, mainly to Hualien City, Jian township, Taitung City and Luyeh township.
The new Web site will provide information about land development, housing sales and leases, in an effort to attract potential migrants, the official said.

Noting that eastern Taiwan boasts beautiful natural scenery and an expanse of plains, the official said the region is particularly suitable for development of LOHAS-related services and the recreation industry.

With this in mind, the official said, the deep-sea water industry, recreational farms, organic and non-toxic farming, and herbal and aromatic tree planting will be prioritized mainly in Hualien City and Hualien County's Jian, Shoufong, Yuli, Antong and Juisui townships, as well as Taitung County's Jhihben and Beinan and Taitung City.
Meanwhile, development of the health care service sector will focus on acupuncture and qigung, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 15, or the 27th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
70 B.C.: Virgil, Roman epic, didactic and pastoral poet, is born. His greatest work was the epic poem "Aeneid," which tells of the wanderings of Aeneas after the sack of Troy.
1821: The Central American Federation wins independence from Spain.
1925: During the warlord era in China, Sun Chuan-fang, superintendent of Chekiang Province, appoints himself as the commander in chief of a military alliance force of five provinces in central China to launch an expedition against Chang Tso-lin's army in Manchuria.
1928: The airship "Graf Zeppelin" lands in New Jersey after making its first transatlantic crossing from Germany.
1945: Pierre Laval, the French politician who led the Vichy government which collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II, is executed.
1946: Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering commits suicide by poisoning himself one day before his scheduled execution.
1950: The first popular elections of magistrates in Taiwan Province are held in Hualien and Taitung. There is a poor voter turnout and new elections are scheduled for Oct. 22.
1955: A single Republic of China air force Saber jet, piloted by Capt. Sun Szu- wen, shoots down one MiG-17 in a dogfight with 12 Chinese Communist MiG-17s north of Matsu.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the late president of Academia Sinica, is buried in a cemetery in Nankang.
1964: Nikita Khrushchev is replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, with Alexei Kosygin becoming prime minister.
1969: The biggest antiwar demonstration in U.S. history is staged as millions of Americans take part in organized rallies and marches to voice their disapproval over their country's continuing involvement in the Vietnam War.
1973: The Sino-Paraguayan Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Vietnamese political leader Le Duc Tho share the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the U.S.-North Vietnam cease-fire. But Le refuses it on the grounds that peace is not yet established in South Vietnam.
1973: Y.T. Wong, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, leaves for Los Angeles to attend a seminar on Sino-American trade.
1974: A 15-member national team leaves Taipei for Seoul to take part in the First Asian Taekwondo Championships.
1975: A martial arts contest is held in Tainan with 400 people from 11 countries attending.
1980: Lt. Gen. Armando Reyes Villa, defense minister of Bolivia, visits the ROC army headquarters and also the ROC navy headquarters.
1986: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang, presided over by KMT Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo, unanimously passes a resolution of political reform to institute the National Security Law during the period of Communist Rebellion and allow the formation of new political parties and organizations.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh, an Academia Sinica member, wins the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry. President Chiang Ching-kuo would send a letter of congratulations to Lee on Oct. 17.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes regulations governing the applications of local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: South African President F. W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela share the Nobel Peace Prize for their work toward ending apartheid and laying the foundations for democracy in South Africa.
1997: Steven Chu, a member of Academia Sinica and a professor at Stanford University, becomes one of the two co-winners of the Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China crashes while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan.
2000: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, urges the government to pay more attention to the nation's economic problems.
2001: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih arrive in Shanghai to attend a series of ministerial meetings under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated for Oct. 15-18.
2001: Gen. Chang Hsueh-liang, who briefly kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai- shek in 1936 at the peak of the Chinese civil war, dies in Hawaii at the age of 101.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man must examine his own heart and see that he has no cause for self-reproach, that he has no evil thought in his mind. Wherein the moral man is superior to other men consists even in that which is not seen by men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Holland envoy says he may remain in Taiwan after his tenure ends
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) 10/15/09 10:45:22 ( By Chang Jung-hsiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Holland' s envoy to Taiwan, Menno Goedhart, said Wednesday that he may seek to stay in Taiwan after his term expires next year.

"I will seriously consider remaining in Taiwan following the expiration of my current term, because I have my fellow 'tribesmen' here," Goedhart said at a joint press conference with Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai to promote Holland Day activities.

Since he was named the representative of the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office in Taiwan seven years ago, Goedhart has toured almost every corner of Taiwan, and has become an "elder" of the Rukai people, one of the 10-odd aboriginal tribes of Taiwan.
Some citizens of Holland married local aborigines, mostly Rukais, during the country's colonial rule of Taiwan between 1624 and 1661.

Goedhart said he was the second foreigner to be awarded the honor of the "elder" title by the Rukai group in Shantimen township in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung. The first foreign elder in the Rukai tribe was also a Hollander, in the early 20th century.
Goedhart said he would choose to live in Tainan City, which has granted him honorary citizenship, once his wife agrees to stay in Taiwan instead of returning to Europe.
This year's Holland Day activities, the third consecutive event of its kind organized by the Tainan City Government, will kick off Oct. 17.

The event willl feature a bike tour of the area around the Chicano Tower on Oct. 17-18, and a "Shuwu" (tree-house) party and a rock-and-roll concert on Oct. 24-25, in which Holland's folk plays will be presented and traditional Dutch delicacies will be served.
The Chicano Tower, formerly called Fort of Provintia, was built in Tainan City by the Dutch in 1653 during their colonization of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan media executives to visit China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CAN) 10/15/09 10:46:12 (By Liu Cheng-ching & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: High-ranking executives of Taiwan's media outlets will visit China Oct. 28-Nov. 11 for discussions on ways and means of enhancing cross-strait media cooperation, Vice Secretary General Ma Shao-chang of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.

Headed by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, the 20-member group will visit Beijing and Shanxi Province to exchange views on journalistic exchanges with their mainland counterparts and Chinese officials in charge of the media.
Currently, Taiwan and China allow correspondents from their major media outlets to remain on assignment on the other side for a maximum of three months on a rotating basis.
However, there have been calls for a "normalization" of journalistic exchanges between Taiwan and China through the reciprocal establishment of media branches or offices on each side.

The Taiwan media delegation to China will include executives and senior journalists from SET TV, Formosa TV and the Liberty Times, which in the past were deemed as having embraced a pro-Taiwan independence stance.

The SEF is a semi-official agency in charge of handling cross-strait affairs through its counterpart, China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), in the absence of formal contact between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Web site created to encourage migration to eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A special Web site has been created to encourage migration to eastern Taiwan and to promote the lifestyles of health and sustainability (LOHAS) and recreation and health care service development in the region, an official said Wednesday.

The Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior took the initiative to create the Web site at http: //www.easthealthpark.com.tw/index.aspx to serve as an information service platform that will help attract more long and short stay vacationers to eastern Taiwan and encourage migration to the region, the official said.
The new information service is also part of a comprehensive eastern Taiwan sustainable development project launched by the government, the official explained.

In recent years, the official said, an increasing number of retirees and people who intend to launch new businesses in the LOHAS and recreation sectors have migrated to eastern Taiwan, mainly to Hualien City, Jian township, Taitung City and Luyeh township.
The new Web site will provide information about land development, housing sales and leases, in an effort to attract potential migrants, the official said.

Noting that eastern Taiwan boasts beautiful natural scenery and an expanse of plains, the official said the region is particularly suitable for development of LOHAS-related services and the recreation industry.

With this in mind, the official said, the deep-sea water industry, recreational farms, organic and non-toxic farming, and herbal and aromatic tree planting will be prioritized mainly in Hualien City and Hualien County's Jian, Shoufong, Yuli, Antong and Juisui townships, as well as Taitung County's Jhihben and Beinan and Taitung City.
Meanwhile, development of the health care service sector will focus on acupuncture and qigung, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan sees huge influx of hot money: Central Bank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/09 11:47:59 (By Lin Yi-feng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) confirmed Wednesday that there has recently been a huge influx of hot money into the country that could have influenced the exchange rate of the New Taiwan dollar.

Speaking on the issue during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee, Central Bank Governor Perng Fai-nan told lawmakers that over the past month, NT$500 billion (US$15.52 billion) in inward remittances had not been used for stock investment but remained in transactional accounts held by foreign investors.

The reasonable balance in transactional accounts for stock investment is 3 percent of total remittances, or NT$100 billion in this case, Peng said, adding that the excess amount of NT$400 billion was "intended for currency speculation" according to the Central Bank's definition.
Since early September, the New Taiwan dollar has risen by more than NT$0.07, or 2.25 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier wants permanent houses for typhoon victims built by February
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/09 12:56:02 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Deng-yih gave a directive Wednesday for permanent homes to be constructed by next Lunar New year for families from Siaolin Village who were displaced by Typhoon Morakot in August.

Speaking during a meeting at the Executive Yuan on post-disaster reconstruction, Wu said Siaolin village residents, mostly aborigines, agreed to relocate further downhill and settle in permanent houses to be built in Shanlin township, Kaohsiung County, after their homes were destroyed by floods and mudslides during the storm.
Wu called for closer cooperation among the Executive Yuan, the Kaohsiung County government and charity organizations to complete the housing project by mid- February 2010.
The state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. will make available its 58-hectare Yuehmei farm in Shanlin township to accommodate 300 to 400 permanent houses for the dislocated aborigines.
Permanent houses for the displaced residents will also be built in the rural township of Wulipu near Siaolin Village.
The village was buried under tons of mud and about 400 residents presumed killed in mudslides trigged by Typhoon Morakot Aug. 8.

Wu also gave a directive for the construction of a museum and a memorial park within one year to commemorate typhoon victims and those who died during rescue operations and to preserve the cultural legacy and collective memories of Siaolin village.

The premier asked relevant agencies, including the Ministry of Justice, the National Police Agency and Public Construction Commission, to work as a team to jointly oversee that the housing program and other post-disaster reconstruction projects are implemented smoothly and transparently.
Meanwhile, he instructed the Council of Agriculture (COA) to come up with plans to help find mountain ranger jobs for aborigines who are unemployed as a result of the typhoon.
He also suggested that incentives, such as cash rewards, be offered to individuals and companies that contribute to forestation efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 24-day-old baby girl hospitalized with H1N1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/09 13:02:02 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A 24-day-old baby girl was recently hospitalized with influenza A(H1N1) , the youngest patient to be hospitalized in Taiwan with the new flu strain, health authorities said Thursday.

The newborn was diagnosed with the virus after she was taken to hospital Oct. 13 with symptoms that included a stuffy nose, fever, constant crying and agitation, according to Centers for Disease Control Deputy Director-General Chou Jih-haw.
The baby's fever was brought down after treatment and she is expected to recover fully in a few days, Chou said.
He said the infant could have been infected by her 14-month-old sister or 13 -year-old brother, both of whom had come down with flu-like symptoms.

Noting that infections among young children are usually transmitted from family members, Chou advised people to wash their hands before attending to children and suggested that people with flu-like symptoms avoid any contact with children.
The baby was among three new hospitalized H1N1 cases reported by the CDC Thursday, the other two being a 45-year-old woman and a 54-year-old man.
The total number of such cases since the outbreak began has reached 358, Chou said.

As of 4 p.m. Wednesday, 462 classes in 284 schools around the country remained closed because of H1N1 infections among the students. The number of affected classes accounted for 0.31 percent of the total, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan successfully traces buzzard migration route

TEXT.P: After about a year of research, Taiwanese raptor experts recently succeeded in tracing the migration patterns of the endangered grey-faced buzzard, the Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture said Thursday.

The research team, which was financed by the Forestry Bureau, released its findings that showed that grey-faced buzzards, an Asian bird of prey, usually stop over in Taiwan every October on their way south to winter in the Philippines.

The raptors, known scientifically as Butastur indicus, then fly north in the spring, making another stop in Taiwan before continuing on to the China-Russia border near China's Heilongjiang Province or North Korea to breed, the researchers found.
Between 15,000 and 35,000 grey-faced buzzards stop in Taiwan on the route each year, but prior to the latest research, little was known about their migration habits.

Keen to find out more about the birds' migration patterns, the research team, including researchers from Academia Sinica and the non-profit Raptor Research Group of Taiwan, tagged five adult buzzards caught in Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan and the Mt. Bagua National Scenic Area in the central county of Changhua in October 2008 and March of this year.
The five birds were dubbed Cape No. 1-5 and then released.

With the help of the satellite transmitters that were attached to the birds, the researchers were able to track the movements of Cape No. 1, No. 2 and No. 5 and trace precisely their previously mysterious migration routes.
The researchers found that as of Oct. 12, the three birds had already passed through Taiwan and two were en route to the Philippines for the winter, while one had already landed there.

Cape No. 1 was found to have traveled over 12,000 km in a broad circle covering the southern Philippines at the southernmost tip and Heilongjiang Province at the northernmost tip, with Taiwan as a midway stop and a mountainous area in China's northeastern Jilin Province as a rest stop for breeding in early June, according to the bureau.

Although Cape No. 1 arrived at its breeding ground later than Cape No. 2 and No. 5, it overtook the other two tagged birds and was the first to land in the Philippines after a year-long migratory flight.

It took refuge on a tiny island off China's Guangdong Province in March during the strong northeast monsoon, recovering its strength before heading further north around the end of May, the researchers were able to determine.
Meanwhile, Cape No. 2 and No. 5 also flew over 12,000 km in a migration circle, stopping at breeding grounds in a rural area of North Korea.
The researchers lost contact with Cape No. 3 and No. 4 somewhere over the ocean as the birds were flying north and their transmitters remained silent, according to the Forestry Bureau.
The recent findings -- the first migration data on grey-faced buzzards -- are a good scientific foundation for further migration research, the bureau officials said.

The grey-faced buzzard is listed in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES) and is also protected as a Rare and Valuable Species under Taiwan's Wildlife Conservation Act, according to the Forestry Bureau.

The adult grey-faced buzzard stands 41-46 cm, has a grey head, breast and neck, a white throat, a black moustache and mesial stripes, brown back and upper wings, and brown bars on white underparts and underwings. The juvenile is brown and mottled above, pale below with brown streaks, and has a broad white supercilium and brown face.

Generally, the southern migration areas of grey-faced buzzards are limited to Southeast Asia. In summer, they breed in eastern areas of Asia, including northern China, the Korean peninsula, an area southeast of the River Ussuri in Russia, and Japan. When autumn comes, they migrate south to southeastern China, Indochina, the Philippines, Borneo, the Celebes and New Guinea, although the migration routes are still not clear.

A few years ago, Japanese researchers were the first to implement satellite positioning technology to track buzzards. They tagged and released several of the raptors from the Japanese island of Ishigaki, hoping that they would fly south, but the birds headed north instead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma to preside over IDU annual meeting as chairman of KMT

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will preside over the 2010 annual meeting of the International Democratic Union's (IDU) Executive Committee, to be held in Taipei Oct. 31- Feb. 2, in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), according to KMT spokesman Lee Chien- jung.

Lee made the remarks Wednesday following a weekly party meeting, quoting a report by Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, who returned to Taiwan from the United Kingdom Oct. 11 after attending a Tory conference in Manchester from Oct. 5-8.
According to Lee, Chiang hailed the IDU as a platform from which the KMT can conduct a wide range of international exchanges with political parties of other countries.

President Ma, who will assume leadership of the KMT Oct. 17 at the party's 18th national congress, will preside over the IDU Executive Committee's annual meeting in his capacity as KMT chairman when its members meet in Taipei early next year, Lee quoted Chiang as saying.
This is not unusual, as former U.S. President George W. Bush attended the IDU annual meeting in the United States in 2005 while he was head of state, Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 14.65 points, or 0.19 percent, to close at 7,710.4.
The local bourse opened at 7,778.35 and fluctuated between 7,780.66 and 7,692.58 during the day's trading session.
A total of 6.03 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$164.56 billion (US$5.11 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.81 percent. Paper and pulp issues dropped 1.5 percent, textile stocks declined 1.28 percent, foodstuff issues were down 1.1 percent, and cement stocks decreased 0.68 percent.

Three other major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 0.51 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares increased 0.36 percent and machinery and electronics shares advanced 0.29 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,554 to 1,123, with 226 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$21.49 billion-worth of shares for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic pact may affect up to 80,000 workers: CLA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/09 16:01:14 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The signing of a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) could affect up to 80,000 Taiwanese workers in the worst-case scenario, the Council of Labor Affairs said Thursday.

The number includes workers who might lose their jobs, be sent on unpaid leave, or suffer pay cuts as a result of trade liberalization following the signing of the agreement, CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan told lawmakers during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's social welfare, health and environment committee.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs has earmarked NT$35 billion for subsidies to 3,740 businesses that are likely to be affected by the ECFA, and the CLA hopes that the affected workers will also be eligible to receive assistance, Wang said.
It will require an additional NT$10 billion to fund subsidies to workers, if they are to be given subsidies for up to six months, she said.
Wang said the CLA will fight for the rights of local workers and will continue to seek the Cabinet's support for the subsidy proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan develops first electro-thermal deep-sea diving suit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct.15, (CNA) 10/15/09 16:04:21 (By Chou Pin-chun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan, one of the world's largest suppliers of diving suits, has developed the first ever electro-thermal diving suit for deep, cold underwater environments, Taiwan Textile Research Institute(TTRI) said Thursday.
The market potential of this new product is estimated at NT$100 million (US$ 3.1 million), TTRI said.

The new electro-thermal diving suit is made from a special fiber, heated by batteries, and can sustain water pressure at 50 meters below the surface, which is a first, according to the institutes's Product Department Deputy Director Lee Chen-liang.

"At 30 meters, a diver encounters 4 atmospheres (atm) of pressure, so his diving suit should be able to withstand that pressure and also keep his body warm," Lee said, adding the suit's rechargeable batteries can last for three hours underwater.
He also explained that other thermal diving suits made in European countries are mostly for water surface sports and not for deep-sea diving.
TTRI has been in discussions with diving suits manufacturers on technology transfer, and mass production of the new diving suits is expected to begin by mid-2010, he said.
Taiwan is the world's largest manufacturer of diving suits, with an export volume of 4 million suits a year and an 80 percent global market share, according to TTRI.

TTRI also introduced a new anti-allergy fiber made from skullcap herb and chitin, which is a natural polymer. Another of its new products is a fiber-like health monitoring system that can record the heart rate of patients with sleep apnea syndrome.

The 2009 Textile International Forum and Exhibition is being held Oct.14 - 16 at the Taipei International Convention Center, with TTRI, Taiwan Textile Federation and local manufacturers displaying their products at 38 booths.
