DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI selected for U.S. R&D 100 Awards 2009
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/16/09 16:20:53 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's nonprofit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has recently been selected by U.S.-based R&D Magazine as a 2009 R&D 100 Award recipient for its STOBA lithium battery material.

The magazine honored the new generation battery technology for its ability to minimize the risk of internal short-circuits that lead to the common safety concern of "thermal runaway," a process that can cause batteries to overheat and even explode.

"The system begins with a polymer devised by ITRI that is blended into the battery. The polymer is responsible for the suppression of thermal heat, even in the case of puncture or other catastrophic damage," the magazine said.

Alex Peng, deputy director of ITRI's Material and Chemical Research Laboratories (MCL), said in an ITRI statement that the STOBA material is the only technology in the world that has fundamentally resolved the lithium battery safety issue.
"STOBA technology has already passed mandatory shorting and piercing experiments that are more stringent than the international safety standard," Peng said.
He will lead an MCL research team to the United States to receive the global technology award at a ceremony in Orlando, Florida, on Nov. 12.

MCL Director Jonq-min Liu said in the statement that while lithium batteries are the most important power source in today's electronic products, they remain the most unstable of electronic components.

In the past, safer lithium batteries were not required by manufacturers because there was simply no solution to the thermal runaway problem, but the safe STOBA material will help Taiwan's lithium battery industry stand out in the international arena, Liu said.

ITRI has applied for nine patents related to the STOBA technology, which not only resolves the safety problem, but also can extend a battery's high temperature recycling life by more than 20 percent, the ITRI statement said.
The Hsinchu-based research institute was named to the R&D 100 for the second year in a row, after being honored by the magazine in 2008 for its AC-LED technology.

Other recipients of the 2009 R&D 100 Awards, nicknamed by the Chicago Tribune the "Oscars of Invention, " include many big names from the United States, Japan, Canada and Russia, such as Intel, NASA, the U.S. Argonne National Laboratory, the Oak Ridge National Laboratory and the Los Alamos National Laboratory.
Aside from being honored by R&D Magazine, ITRI also recently received a Wall Street Journal Technology Innovation Award in the Consumer Electronics category for its paper-thin flexible loudspeaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close marginally higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 4.7 points, or 0.06 percent, to close at 7,715.1.
The local bourse opened at 7,712.03 and fluctuated between 7,738.04 and 7,691.39 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.21 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$117.94 billion (US$3.64 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down 0.69 percent and machinery and electronics shares dropping 0.25 percent.

Six other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.63 percent. Banking and financial shares advanced 1.33 percent, construction issues were up 1.22 percent, textile stocks rose 0.15 percent, cement stocks increased 0.12 percent, and foodstuff issues advanced 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,309 to 1,203, with 269 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$2.84 billion-worth of shares for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
UNITED DAILY NEWS:
The Frankfurt Book Fair green book tag at the Chinese pavilion is
unnecessary
On the Taiwanese books displayed at the Chinese pavilion at the ongoing Frankfurt Book Fair, an attached tag reads: "Content that violates the `one China' principle will not be recognized."
Such a move is unnecessary.

From the perspective of thawing cross-Taiwan Strait relations, it is a positive thing for the Chinese pavilion to display Taiwanese books. Most of the books on display have been screened and belong in the categories of art and decoration. Still they are marked with the "one China" tag. What a shoddy way to treat cultural creative works.
As an emerging power, China's "hard power" is being reckoned with. But its "soft power" still has great room for improvement, especially in the fields of human rights, democracy and freedom.

The tag should be removed to allow the expression of pluralistic views, which will show that China is open and progressive. But keeping the tag breaks any chance of China being seen in a positive light.
APPLE DAILY: A) Why aren't you angry?

Citizen Congress Watch and other civic groups staged a protest in front of the Legislative Yuan Wednesday over "runaway legislators" who claim their NT$11 million election subsidies but leave the legislature after serving for only around one year.

In the 21 months since the inauguration of the last legislature, seven ruling Kuomintang lawmakers have left. Of the seven, only two are legislators-at-large, while the vacancies of the remaining five will have to be filled through by- elections, which could cost the taxpayer over NT$100 million.

The absent lawmakers have had their elections invalidated because of vote- buying, but despite this, they will not have to pay back their election subsidies and after the by-elections, the new lawmakers will also be paid election subsides.
With such a law and such a government, people of Taiwan, why aren't you angry? (B) It takes two for a duet

Kaohsiung tour operators have complained that business is sluggish and blame the Kaohsiung city government for offending China by inviting the Dalai Lama to visit and by screening a documentary on Uighur political activist Rebiya Kadeer.

The tour operators say this is why China has asked tourists to shun Kaohsiung. Their claim is only partially correct. Global tourism has been badly affected by the global financial storm and the swine flu epidemic, as well as a spate of natural disasters. Taiwan is no exception.
This reminds us that China is by no means a country with a free economy and that its political hand often delves into the economic realm.

Beijing has not engaged in economic warfare only with Taiwan but also with the United States, Japan and Europe. However, they are big powers, and China dares not to be too severe toward them, contenting itself mainly with a bit of saber- rattling.

The situation with Taiwan is different, and China often uses businessmen to pressure officials. As long as those in Taiwan are prepared to sing a duet with Beijing, there is a high probability of China achieving its goal, which is why Beijing is keen to employ the tactic.
CHINA TIMES: Why has the DPP disappeared?
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) unveiled its first campaign ad Thursday to highlight its message that the party offers a guarantee of good governance.

In the ad, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and 14 DPP candidates for year-end local city and county chief elections are seen cleaning windows in a big cleanup operation. The ad pitches for cleanliness, diligence and love for the land -- the same spirit espoused by the party when it was inaugurated in 1986.
The DPP is hoping to raise its profile so that more people will contribute money to the party to finance the candidates in their costly campaigns.

In the past, the DPP has said that it wants to touch the hearts of the people, but after eight years of rule under former President Chen Shui-bian, its slogan of "the green in power will be a guarantee of good governance" has raised questions.
The DPP is anxious to rekindle awareness of the party in the eyes of the voters, but the question is: What made the DPP disappear in the first place?

If the DPP continues to condone its Taipei city councilor, Hung Chien-yi, and his attacks on the Taipei city government with fabricated news, while staying silent on the snowballing scandal involving the former president, the ad, even if all DPP candidates are cleaning their windows hard, will have a difficult time convincing voters that the party is sincere in upholding the value of integrity.
LIBERTY TIMES: Specter of police state hovering over Taiwan
Taipei City Councilor Hung Chien-yi and a Formosa TV (FTV) crew recently went to a Maokong Gondola station to film a video that they said showed the lax security of the station.

But the Taipei City government threatened to sue Hung for damaging public property and trespassing and one FTV reporter for theft. Hung then sued Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-pin and other city officials for aggregated libel.

As the two parties exchange fire, the Taipei Prosecutors Office moved swiftly to open an investigation. The National Communications Commission also notified FTV that it should answer questions within five days on the production process of the clip it filmed.
The swift response of the Taipei Prosecutors Office and the National Communications Commission is questionable.
Have the two treated similar or more serious cases according to the same criteria? Or are they stricter toward the opposition party but lax on the ruling Koumintang?
More and more people have seen the backpedaling of Taiwan's democracy, freedom and human rights over the past year under the Ma administration.
The incumbent mayor could not deal with the mess surrounding the Maokong Gondola left behind by Ma when he was Taipei mayor, so he tried to intimidate others by filing suit.

The public should be prepared that the specter of a police state -- which Mayor Ma's administration warned in 2004 would undermine the democratic system and freedom of expression that have been hard won -- is still hovering around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to improve disaster early warning network

TEXT.P: The government should strengthen Taiwan's broadband seismic network to improve its disaster monitoring and early warning functions, a local earth sciences researcher suggested Friday, saying that he has discovered the network can also be used to monitor landslides and mudflows.
Lin Cheng-horng, deputy director of the Institute of Earth Sciences of Academia Sinica, made the statement in a report on the use of the seismic network.
Lin said that his analysis of the data from the seismic network during Typhoon Morakot in early August revealed that huge landslides and debris flows could cause seismic waves.

For example, the energy released in the strong ground motion during the massive mudslides that destroyed the village of Siaolin in Kaohisung County in August was equivalent to that released by an earthquake measuring 4.6 on the Richter scale, Lin said. Seismic waves from an earthquake of this magnitude can be recorded as far away as Hokkaido in Japan, he said.
According to disaster observation data, at least 45 large scale landslide and debris flow events occurred within 24 hours after the onslaught of Typhoon Morakot Aug. 8, Lin noted.

The big difference between landslide- and earthquake-triggered ground motion lies in the vibration frequencies, he said. The frequency of landslide-induced ground motion would be one per 20 seconds, while that from earthquakes would be five vibrations per second, he added.
Strong ground vibrations caused by landslides or debris and mud flows could trigger other such events, creating a chain effect capable of bringing even worse disasters, Lin added.

Lin said he learned during Typhoon Morakot that the existing monitoring system can no longer fully provide early disaster warning because it can only monitor landslides and floods but cannot record information on events such as the formation of barrier lakes.
He urged the government to set up a multi-functional disaster early warning system by making good use of radar detectors and satellite equipment and expanding the broadband seismic network.

A total of US$1.18 billion changed hands during the day's trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: If allowed, Chinese tourists would choose to visit Kaohsiung: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 17:13:12 (By Lee Ming-chung & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: If Chinese tourists are allowed to choose freely where in Taiwan they would like to go for sightseeing, Kaohsiung City is one the places they would pick, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

The premier rejected as "inappropriate and non-representative of the full picture" a recent statement by China's Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council that Chinese tourists are boycotting Kaohsiung because some interest groups in the city are engaged with Tibet and Xinjiang separatist forces, which jeopardizes China's interests.
The office's spokeswoman Fan Liqing said earlier in the week that it is natural for the Chinese people to show their displeasure over this situation.
In response, Wu said if Chinese tourists are allowed to choose freely, Kaohsiung would be one of their choices of fun destinations in Taiwan that are known to have unique attractions.
Intervention in the travel agencies' tour plans shows disregard for the tourists' right to choose their travel itinerary, he said.
Taiwan will continue to uphold freedom, democracy and the law, he said.

He suggested that marketing is the key to drawing more tour groups and tourists, hinting that Kaohsiung City should embark on more aggressive marketing in China to introduce its tourist attractions to the people there.

Many economic and trade groups have canceled their hotel reservations in Kaohsiung over the past month and the number of business visitors from China to the southern city has also dropped sharply, Tourism Bureau Director Janice Seh- Jen Lai said.

Some Kaohsiung tourism business executives attributed the drop in the number of Chinese tourists to the city government's decision to invite Tibet's spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan to pray for Typhoon Morakot victims and to the city's screening of a documentary on exiled Uigher activist Rebiya Kadeer.
The Kaohsiung City government is run by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party which has been critical of President Ma Ying-jeou's cross-strait policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of centenarians in Taiwan increases to 1,223
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 17:37:18 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The number of centenarians in Taiwan has reached 1,223 as the life expectancy of the country's citizens continues to increase, according to a report released Friday by the Ministry of the Interior.
The number represents an increase of 148 persons compared with last year, when the centenarian population topped 1,000 for the first time to hit 1,075, the report said.
The results were obtained through an annual census conducted recently in preparation for the celebration of the Oct. 26 Double Ninth Festival that honors senior citizens.
All citizens born before Dec. 31, 1909 were counted.
The report showed that 1,135, or 92.8 percent, of the centenarians are between 100 and 104 years of age, with 84 of them in the 105-109 age group, and four at the 110-year mark or older.
The average age of the centenarians -- 853 women and 370 men -- is 101.48, a drop of 0.08 years from last year.
The oldest living centenarian this year is a 116-year-old woman in Kaohsiung City, who was the second-oldest last year. Last year the oldest was a 122-year- old, who has since passed away.
A 113-year-old man in Hualien County is the second-oldest this year, while in third spot is 112-year-old man in Yunlin County, and in fourth place a 110-year- old man in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI's paper-thin speaker wins Wall Street Journal award

TEXT.P: A paper-thin flexible loudspeaker, dubbed FleXpeaker, developed by Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , recently won the 2009 Wall Street Journal global Technology Innovation Award in the Consumer Electronics category.

FleXpeaker is an array of tiny, bendable speakers that can be combined to produce high-fidelity speaker systems of almost any size using standard printing, making it the world's thinnest, lightest and most flexible speaker.
It pioneers a new era in speakers and the electronic sound industry and allows consumer electronic products of the future to become even lighter and slimmer.
In a statement released Friday, the ITRI suggested that because the FleXpeaker is lightweight and consumes little power, it could be attractive for use in cell phones or in car sound systems.

Other possible applications include giant banners that could be used to deliver public-service announcements in train stations or advertising messages in shopping malls. It can also be incorporated into wearable clothing and consumer packaging, and can be cut with scissors into any shape.
"ITRI is seeking to license the technology or create a spinoff company to commercialize the product," the ITRI statement said.

Yi-jen Chan, general director of ITRI's Electronic & Optoelectronic Research Laboratories, who led the speaker project, traveled to San Francisco to receive the internationally acclaimed award Oct. 13.
At the award presentation ceremony, The Wall Street Journal news editor John M. Leger praised FleXpeaker as a revolutionary technology.
"The judges believe that this looks like a significant breakthrough in speaker design. They haven't seen anything like this before," Leger said.
The Wall Street Journal announced that the FleXpeaker had won the global Technology Innovation Award on Sept. 14, beating out high-profile companies such as HP, Livescribe and Motorola.

"To be recognized by an organization as prestigious and well- respected as The Wall Street Journal is a great honor, " Chan said. "I am very proud of our team that developed this groundbreaking technology and am pleased they earned such recognition."

In their ninth year, the 2009 Wall Street Journal Technology Innovation Awards received more than 500 entries spanning 12 categories, 180 of which were sent to a team of 16 judges from research institutes, venture capital firms, and experts and scholars from other reputed companies and organizations.
Judges were instructed to consider the technology's applications, commercialization and market potential in addition to its innovation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Many pregnant women exposed to secondhand smoke at home: poll

TEXT.P: Some 50 percent of Taiwan's pregnant women are exposed to secondhand smoke at home, according to the results of a survey on pregnant women released Friday.

Most pregnant women exposed to secondhand smoke in Taiwan face it at home, particularly at night, but others still must contend with secondhand smoke in the workplace, according to the survey, the largest of its kind in 20 years.

The survey, in which 2,346 pregnant women answered questionnaires and had their blood tested periodically, was conducted by National Taiwan University Hospital for the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH).

The blood tests found that pregnant women in Taiwan lack iron, folic acid, vitamin A and vitamin B in their diets, even in the initial stages of the their pregnancies, and the situation gets worse as the pregnancy progresses.

By the third trimester, many of the pregnant women had a 4 percent deficiency of folic acid, a 37 percent deficiency of vitamin B, and a 14 percent deficiency of vitamin B2. They also had major iron deficiencies, with some of the women in the trial having iron levels 50 percent lower than accepted standards.

The survey identified other flaws in the participants' diets. It found that local pregnant women ingest only 52 percent of the daily recommended amount of 7.4 mg of Vitamin E and only half of the 522 mg of calcium recommended per day.
The average amount of 4.9 c.c. of dietary fiber consumed every day by Taiwan's pregnant females also falls short of the recommended amount by between 17 percent and 32 percent.

As 60 percent of Taiwanese pregnant women also work and usually eat outside, Shaw Ning-sing, the National Taiwan University professor who was in charge of the survey, recommended they take fish oil and other mineral supplements to complement the nutrients they get from their diets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to be included in U.S. visa waiver program

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang said Friday that Taiwan and the United States are discussing the possibility of including Taiwan in a U.S. visa waiver program, but he gave no specific timetable.

Yang made the remarks in response to reporters' questions after attending an international seminar titled "Taipei-Washington-Beijing Relations under the Ma and Obama Administrations" that was held in Taipei by the non-government Foundation on Asia-Pacific Peace Studies and the Pacific Forum of the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a U.S. think tank.
"Both Taiwan and the U.S. understand the importance of the visa waiver program issue, which are already under discussion by the two sides. However, I cannot tell you a certain timetable," Yang said.

Asked whether Taiwan is concerned about U.S. President Barack Obama's visit to China scheduled for mid-November, the foreign minister said he is confident that Washington-Taipei relations will not be affected by the trip.
With the great improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Yang said at the international seminar, there are five facets of the new face of U.S.-Taiwan relations in the current context.

They include working on the inclusion of Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program, enhancement of bilateral security cooperation, economic and investment ties, and Taiwan's seeking of America's strong support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and International Civil Aviation Organization, according to Yang.

Moreover, it would be of mutual benefit to both Taipei and Washington to expand cooperation on issues of export control and counter-weapons proliferation, as the two sides have worked effectively together on the implementation of the container security initiative, which entails a system of checking for illegal goods shipping containers that leave Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan.

Speaking on the trilateral relations between the U.S., Taiwan and China, Chao Chun-shan, chairman of the Foundation on Asia-Pacific Peace Studies, said in his opening remarks that this is probably the first time since 1949 that the three parties had shared a path of mutual trust and cooperation.
If such a relationship continues to develop, there might be a chance for trilateral relations to reach a win-win-win situation, at which time Washington, Beijing and Taipei should seize the moment.

Ralph A. Cossa, president of the CSIS Pacific Forum, echoed Chao's view, saying that there is an opportunity to move things forward because the leaderships of all three are dedicated toward moving the relationship forward without a zero- sum mentality.
"The relations between the U.S., Taiwan and China are not and should not be a zero-sum game, and the U.S. very much wants good relations both with China and Taiwan," Cossa said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Organizer vows to stage bigger Taipei 101 fireworks show this year

TEXT.P: An even more spectacular light show and fireworks display will be staged this year at Taipei 101 during the New Year's Eve party, the vice chairman of the Taipei Financial Center Corp. (TFCC) that owns the tower said Tuesday.

Wei Ying-jiao made the comment after it was reported that the Tourism Bureau, the major sponsor of the Taipei 101 light show in the past two years, will not be able to sponsor the show this year because it has put a lot of its financial resources into boosting tourism business in areas hit by Typhoon Morakot.

Wei told reporters at an award ceremony for Taiwan's top 10 international brands that his group is very pleased with its investment in Taipei 101 and that "the New Year countdown party will absolutely not disappoint anyone."

Noting that the fireworks countdown is an important celebration that gives international exposure to Taiwan, Wei said that the TFCC will not only organize the event this year but also plans to make it bigger.

Asked about whether the name of his family's food and beverage business, Ting Hsin, will be displayed at the show, Wei said that his family prefers to keep a low-profile, therefore the show will not highlight any characters related to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER forecasts -3.72% GDP growth for Taiwan this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 18:43:28 (By Anita Pan, Cheng Yun-hsuan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) in its latest forecast Friday slightly adjusted downward Taiwan's economic growth this year from -3.56 percent to -3.72 percent.
The CIER said that the downward adjustment was made due to the "weaker-than expected" momentum of economic recovery seen in the second and third quarters of this year.
The CIER said that Taiwan's economy recorded a negative growth of 2.08 percent in the third quarter, but it should gain momentum to register a 5.31 growth in the fourth quarter.
Peng Su-ling, a CIER associated research fellow, attributed the optimistic outlook for the fourth quarter in Taiwan to the gradual stabilization of the global economic situation.

The CIER painted a gloomy picture of a 5.94 percent unemployment rate for Taiwan for the fourth quarter, and a 5.88 percent rate for the whole of 2009 based on what it said was a reluctance on the part of domestic enterprises to hire new workers.
However, the institution said the jobless rate will drop to 5.76 percent next year, when the economy is expected to grow by 4.65 percent.
The CIER also forecast growths of 1.91 percent and 8.16 percent, respectively, next year for Taiwan's private sector consumption and private sector investment.
Taiwan's commodity and services exports will increase by 9.72 percent and imports will grow by 8.47 percent in 2010, while the commodity price index (CPI) will climb 0.78 percent, it forecast.
However, an executive of the Citibank Taiwan said that the CIER's forecast of 4.65 percent GDP growth for next year is "too optimistic. "
Cheng Chen-mao, a Citibank vice president in charge of financial trading, said that although the global economy is beginning to show signs of recovery, "the crisis is not completely over".

He added that currently governments of the world, by implementing economic stimulus measures, are providing the biggest momentum for economic recovery, but whether or not the recovery would be sustained will depend in large on private investment.

Meanwhile, expressing concerns over the possible impact of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, Wang Lee-Rong, director of CIER's Center for Economic Forecasting, said that Taiwan workers who are rendered jobless by the ECFA should be transferred to those sectors that would benefit from the cross-strait agreement.

Negotiators from Taiwan and China are expected to discuss the ECFA issue when they meet in Taichung, central Taiwan in December for the next round of cross- strait talks, and are likely to ink the agreement some time next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diplomatic personnel to step up community outreach tours: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic personnel, particularly overseas mission chiefs and staff who are on home visits, will embark on community outreach tours to learn more about grassroots opinions, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday in a statement.

According to the statement, the ministry has come up with a comprehensive action plan in response to President Ma Ying-jeou's directive that diplomatic and national security personnel should have closer interaction with grassroots communities.

Ma gave the directive after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan in early August. At the time, diplomatic and national security authorities were criticized for initially turning down foreign offers of relief aid for typhoon victims.

During a post-typhoon review meeting, Ma said diplomatic and national security officials should be in more frequent contact or have greater interaction with grassroots people so that these officials can better represent domestic public opinions and situations in the countries to which they are posted.

Acting on Ma's instructions, the MOFA statement said, the ministry decided to arrange for overseas mission chiefs and staff to visit the regions hardest-hit by Typhoon Morakot whenever they return home on consultation visits.
"Through these kinds of outreach tours, diplomatic personnel are expected to acquire a better understanding of the local people's needs, "the statement said.

Overseas mission chiefs will also be required to meet with local government heads, particularly those in central, southern and eastern Taiwan and on outlying islands, before they depart to take up overseas posts or when they return on visits, in order to learn more about what kind of assistance is most needed to promote exports of local specialties and increase civilian exchanges.
Moreover, the statement said achievements in boosting bilateral trade and economic relations will become important criteria in evaluating the overall performance of overseas diplomatic missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top U.S. envoy to Taiwan confident of progress on big issues

TEXT.P: William Stanton, the top United States envoy to Taiwan, expressed confidence Friday in resolving or making progress on several important issues affecting Taiwan-U.S. relations, which he said would further enhance their already close ties.

According to Stanton, outstanding issues include resuming the long-halted Trade Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks, working on the inclusion of Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program, evaluating the provision of more security assistance to Taiwan, supporting Taiwan's participation in international organizations, and strengthening other areas of cooperation.
"Perhaps the most important vehicle we have for the trade agenda is the TIFA. That has been stalled over the beef issue, but it looks like it's resolved," Stanton said.

"We are looking to resuming the TIFA talks very soon. We hope before the end of the year to review new areas for progress on our trade agenda, " the envoy said in his speech at an international seminar in Taipei titled "Taipei-Washington- Beijing Relations under the Ma and Obama Administrations."
The TIFA talks, which are regularly held alternatively by Taiwan and the U.S., have been halted because of differences over Taiwan's continued restrictions on U.S. beef imports.

Another area in which the U.S. and Taiwan are looking to expand cooperation is law enforcement, said Stanton, who noted that the U.S. has been very encouraged by Taiwan's efforts in combatting human trafficking.
He thinks that over the long term, there is great hope that Taipei and Washington can ink an extradition agreement, which would serve mutual interests.

On the issue of including Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program, Stanton said Washington wants to make travel to the U.S. more secure and convenient for Taiwanese visitors and is encouraging Taiwan to strengthen its document security and how it issues its passports.

"We hope (to work) toward the goal of bringing Taiwan into the visa waiver program, which I certainly think is doable. I worked on the visa waiver program, which was a success in Korea, and I don't see why it can't be done here," Stanton said.

On Taiwan's international participation, the diplomat said Taiwan has plenty to offer to the international community, and he noted it hopes to join the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and International Civil Aviation Organization.
"We support Taiwan's meaningful participation in these and similar organizations, and will do what we can to help that happen, " he said.
Stanton said that the U.S. very much welcomes the improving relations between Taipei and Beijing but indicated that Taiwan needs to feel secure to continue that progress.
"Taiwan needs friends, and I can say with assurance that the U.S. will continue to be a dependable friend of Taiwan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. welcomes positive cross-strait developments: scholars

TEXT.P: Professor Bau Tzong-ho of National Taiwan University also suggested that the U.S. could play a more constructive role as a counterbalance, partner and deterrent.

Stressing the "one-China policy" that is observed by the U.S. government, CSIS Senior Advisor Michael J. Green maintained that the U.S. would likely play a background or supporting role in the process of developing cross-strait mutual trust.
Nevertheless, the U.S. should meet its commitments listed in the Taiwan Relations Act, he added.

The one-day seminar concluded Friday evening with a speech by William A. Stanton, Taipei office director of the American Institute in Taiwan. The top U.S. envoy spoke mainly on issues related to Washington and Taipei, such as including Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program and the resumption of the long- stalled Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. welcomes positive cross-strait developments: scholars

TEXT.P: American scholars attending a seminar on Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations said Friday in Taipei that the United States welcomed the positive development in relations between Taipei and Beijing and it is unlikely that Washington would play an intermediary role.

At the seminar, some 200 scholars from think tanks in the United States and Taiwan discussed the cross-strait factor in U.S. Asia policy and the U.S. role in building cross-strait mutual trust mechanisms. The seminar was jointly sponsored by the Foundation on Asia-Pacific Peace Studies (FAPPS) in Taipei and the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) in Washington, D.C.

Ralph A. Cossa, CSIS Pacific Forum president, said that the administration of President Barack Obama is "absolutely delighted that China and Taiwan are talking over and working out their problems between them."

Referring to the attitude of the U.S. government towards improved relations between Taipei and Beijing, and in response to a question by Professor George W. Tsai of the Chinese Culture University, Cossa said that the notion that the U.S. is worried about the two sides getting too close "is truly a minority point of view."

Cossa's view was echoed by Professor David M. Lampton of John Hopkins University, who said that most Americans would expect the cross-strait reconciliation to continue and would love to see the signing of a cross-strait peace agreement.

As confidence building is deemed vital to the progress of cross- strait relations, Professor Chen I-hsin of Tamkang University said, "Washington could play a multi-dimensional role in and after the process of cross-strait negotiations on the establishment of mutual trust mechanisms."

According to Chen, the U.S. can play the role of a facilitator by providing Taiwan with advice and suggestions, based on its own practical experience, when issues such as formal exchange programs, direct military-to-military exchanges and military liaison offices are discussed in the second track meetings.
Professor Bau Tzong-ho of National Taiwan University also suggested that the U.S. could play a more constructive role as a counterbalance, partner and deterrent.

Stressing the "one-China policy" that is observed by the U.S. government, CSIS Senior Advisor Michael J. Green maintained that the U.S. would likely play a background or supporting role in the process of developing cross-strait mutual trust.
Nevertheless, the U.S. should meet its commitments listed in the Taiwan Relations Act, he added.

The one-day seminar concluded Friday evening with a speech by William A. Stanton, Taipei office director of the American Institute in Taiwan. The top U.S. envoy spoke mainly on issues related to Washington and Taipei, such as including Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program and the resumption of the long- stalled Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Techniques to build Wang Yeh's boat may soon disappear
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 21:10:22 (By Kuo Chi-hsuan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: As the eight-day Donggang Wang Yeh Festival heads toward its climax Saturday when a multimillion Taiwan dollar boat is burned, a shipbuilding master worries that one day soon the art of building the deity's wooden vessel will be lost.

Young people today are not interested in learning how to put together the ceremonial boat, lamented 65-year-old Hsieh Chung-sheng while walking on a beach at Jhenhai Park to inspect the site where the highly anticipated triennial ritual of burning Wang Yeh's boat takes place.

The master craftsman said he began learning the skills needed to build wooden fishing boats when he was 16 and he was in his twenties when he was recruited by Donggang Township's Donglong Temple -- the center of Wang Yeh worship in southwestern Taiwan -- to work on the Wang Yeh vessel.

At the age of 48, he was promoted to head a team of more than 160 workers to make the craft that carries Wang Yeh on his pilmigrage around the town to help those who worship him eradicate disease and ward off evil.

As wooden fishing vessels have gradually been replaced by modern boats made of carbon fiber, the number of wooden boat craftsmen has also declined. Now there are only 100 members on his team, and they average 60 years old.

"We are a group of retired old men, " Hsieh says, and he is worried that a tradition that dates back more than 300 years, when Donglong Temple organized its first triennial Wang Yeh worshipping ceremony, could be without its main prop.

Wang Yeh's vessel, however, has not always been built completely with wood. In the early days, the ceremonial boat had a bamboo frame and paper body. It was not until 1973 that local residents had enough money to build a real boat, Hsieh recalls.
Wang Yeh's boat is actually modeled after an imperial boat in ancient China that was prevalent in the Fujian and Shantou areas.

"It wasn't as big as the one we build now, " Hsieh says, explaining that the boat's size in the first festival in Taiwan was about 11.4 meters by 1.7 meters and has expanded each time the ceremony has been held -- until 2009.

Wang Yeh's boat this year measures the same size it did in 2006 -- 13.8m long by 3.65m wide by 1.75m high -- because if it were made any bigger, it could not be carried through the streets of Donggang.
But its price tag of NT$6.6 million this year was about 10 percent higher than three years ago because of more expensive raw materials, Hsieh said.

On Friday, the colorful boat made of high quality Vietnamese juniper was pulled by people for a "sail" on the streets of the fishing port. The procession symbolizes the gods patrolling the Donggang area to expel evil spirits and plagues.

During the procession, the boat received offerings for Wang Yeh from local worshippers. It was brought back to the temple at around 6 p.m. and will be taken to Jhenhai Park at 2 a.m. Saturday for the burning ritual that ends the week-long festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer heads list of top 10 Taiwan Global Brands in 2009

TEXT.P: Computer vendor Acer Inc. was unveiled Friday as Taiwan's leading brand on a list of Taiwan's Top 10 Global Brands for the first time ever, with anti-virus software maker Trend Micro and computer maker AsusTek close behind.

Vice President Vincent Siew handed out awards to all of the companies on the top 10 list at Friday's awards ceremony, a component of the government's Branding Taiwan program created in 2003 aimed at building globally popular brands.

Acer headed the top 10 list with an estimated brand value of US$1.24 billion, thanks to its mergers with Gateway and Packard Bell in 2007 and its successful launch of netbook computers, according to officials from the event's co-sponsor, the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
Acer is Taiwan's largest vendor of laptop computers, and the world's second largest computer vendor after surpassing Dell in the third quarter of 2009.

Its product lineup includes desktops, laptops, personal digital assistants (PDAs), servers and storage, displays, peripherals, and e-business services for business, government, education, and home users.
Filling out the top 10 brand list were, in order, HTC, Master Kong, Want Want, Maxxis, Giant, Synnex and Zyxel.

Master Kong and Giant have made it into the top 10 every year since the list was created, even though it has been traditionally dominated by high-tech companies. Over the past seven years, Trend Micro has occupied the No. 1 spot five times.

But the continued presence of conventional businesses such as food processor Master Kong and bicycle maker Giant, along with rice snack maker Want Want was worth noting, according to global brand consultancy Interbrand.

The brand expert attributed Master Kong's listing to its prevailing market share in the Chinese market, which has spared the company from the adverse effects of the global economic crunch and helped its brand value appreciate by 19 percent in 2009 to US$916 million.
Want Want, which made the list for the first time, was estimated to have a brand value of US$421 million, while Giant had a brand value of US$262 million.

The combined value of this year's top 10 Taiwanese brands totaled US$7.326 billion, down 2.8 percent from 2008 due to the impact of the global financial crisis, TAITRA officials said. Each of the top four brands had brand values exceeding US$1.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't plans to provide NT$1b to promote creative industries

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) plans to subsidize NT$1 billion in discounts on student tickets for performances by local arts and cultural groups to help foster cultural and creative industries, a council official said Friday.
Fang Jy-Shiuh, director of the council's first department, said the government hoped the trial program would expand the demand for arts and cultural events.
A plan to offer tax incentives to encourage cultural consumption had originally been considered but was eventually scrapped after taking into account other potential consequences.

The government therefore decided to provide NT$1 billion a year for the subsidy program on a trial basis, Fang said in announcing the program at a seminar on the development of Taiwan's cultural and creative industries organized by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum.

Noting that the subsidy program falls under the provisions of the Cultural and Creative Industry Development Draft Act, Fang said that although the act has yet to be enacted, the CCA has begun mapping out the subsidy plan.
Fang also said that one of the CCA's main objectives is to help creative industries penetrate Chinese-speaking and international markets.
In the initial stage, the two sides can start by jointly holding large scale cultural and creative expositions and establishing a dialogue mechanism, she suggested.

She added that the CCA will work to promote industry cooperation between Taiwan and China in the areas of investment protection, intellectual property rights protection and joint ventures into international markets.

The cultural and creative industries of Taiwan and China complement each other, Fang contended, citing China's huge market, abundant capital, vast land and a sound cultural policy related to creative industries, and Taiwan's strong talent pool and its favorable and free environment to support the industry's development.

Kuo Su-chen, chief of a creative belly dance troupe and winner of the ninth Ahlan Wa Sahlan Belly Dance Festival in July 2008 in Egypt, said at the seminar that she believes the subsidy program will help expand arts and cultural consumption.

Kuo said that if performing groups are not famous enough, they usually find it difficult to sell tickets to their shows. She also suggested that the CCA should first provide a platform for performances to help boost performing groups' popularity.
Huang Ching-lung, president of Want Daily, one of the Taiwan-based China Times Group's publications, said no industry can afford to neglect the massive Chinese market.
Huang cited the contrasting experiences of two singers, Taiwan's top female Hoklo singer Chiang Huei and Hong Kong Jacky Cheung.

Both singers sold 1 million copies of their hit albums in their home markets, but Cheung's "Kiss Goodbye" sold 5 million copies in Chinese communities around the world, while Chiang failed to sell her album outside Taiwan.

Taiwan's cultural and creative industries encompass the visual arts, music and performing arts, cultural exhibitions and performance facilities, films, TV and broadcasting, publishing, advertising, and product design.

They also extend to fashion and architectural design, creative living, digital leisure and amusement industries, according to the definition by the center for promoting Taiwan's cultural and creative industries under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Progress in cross-strait ties expected ahead: U.S. academic

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot and other extraneous factors have combined to frustrate progress in relations across the Taiwan Strait recently but have not stifled positive momentum, and progress in cross-strait ties is expected to resume in the coming quarter, a U.S. scholar forecast in a recent report.

The online quarterly report, titled China-Taiwan Relations: Temporarily in the Doldrums, was authored by David G. Brown, a cross-strait affairs expert at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
According to Brown, it is largely extraneous developments, rather than policy changes, that have impeded progress in cross-strait ties in the July-September quarter.

"Typhoon Morakot consumed public and government attention on Taiwan for three weeks in August and then led to Cabinet changes affecting some of the senior officials handling cross-Strait economic issues," Brown wrote.

At the same time, Morakot occasioned two positive developments, Brown argued. First, Beijing was prompt and generous in providing financial and practical aid. Second, the U.S. also provided aid, which included the first deployment of U.S. military aircraft to Taiwan since 1979.

"This potentially sensitive action was handled discreetly, with Beijing portraying it as a humanitarian action, the U.S. planes leaving as soon as their humanitarian work was concluded, and neither Taipei nor Washington gave the action any broader significance, " Brown wrote.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's decision to invite the Dalai Lama to console Morakot victims presented a dilemma for Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou and for Beijing.
"In the end, both sides handled the issue in a way that delayed some minor cross-Strait events but did not significantly disrupt relations," Brown observed.
He predicted that progress in improving cross-strait relations should resume in the coming months.

Brown suggested, however, that the easy agreements were concluded in the first three meetings between top officials of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

More difficult issues involving the usual balancing of interests in bilateral trade negotiations have affected the pace of talks on both the memorandums of understanding (MOUs) covering banking, insurance and securities and the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Brown contended.

The financial MOUs, which were to have been completed in late June, are still pending. The financial regulatory systems to be defined in the MOUs must be in place before the two sides can reciprocally approve operations by financial services firms.
The MOUs are expected to be signed before the end of the year, Brown said, citing China's Taiwan Affairs Office.

Meanwhile, Brown pointed out that the fourth round of SEF-ARATS talks is scheduled to be held late this year and should result in additional agreements, possibly including ones on fisheries, agricultural product standards, product testing, double taxation and a discussion on ECFA.

On cross-strait economic ties, Brown said bilateral trade is beginning to recover from the precipitous decline caused by the global financial crisis and the first group of Chinese investments in Taiwan, although small, have been approved.

Citing tallies compiled by Taiwan's Investment Commission, the report said eight Chinese investments totaling US$769,000 were made during July and August with Fujia Newland Computers making the largest single investment.

With cross-strait relations proceeding constructively, the U.S. government's role is limited. Nevertheless, Brown said arms sales are one important exception that needs to be handled in a sophisticated way to support the long-term U.S. interest in a peaceful resolution of cross-strait issues.
"It is in the U.S. interest to support a government in Taiwan that is working constructively to consolidate a stable, peaceful cross-strait relationship," Brown argued.
Taipei is requesting arms so it can maintain a "credible deterrent position" from which to negotiate.

Furthermore, as the Ma administration is being criticized at home for not doing enough for Taiwan's defense, Brown wrote, the fact that there has been little concrete evidence of support for Taipei from the Obama administration is calling into question Ma's ability to successfully manage the all important U.S.-Taiwan relationship.

"With Beijing's deployments growing, there is a sound case for the U.S. to move ahead with the Blackhawk sale and to respond favorably to Taiwan's request for the F-16C/D aircraft, which are increasingly seen as a litmus test of U.S. support," Brown wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: Continuity in store for future U.S.-Taiwan-China relations: Paal

TEXT.P: Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan, said Friday in Taipei that "continuity" will characterize prospects for the short-term strategic paths of the United States, Taiwan and China.
The proposition was reinforced by last year's election of a Taiwan administration that seeks to eschew unnecessary friction with China and seek areas of cooperation with Beijing, according to Paal.
He said Taiwan has at least two and a half years to seek success with its approach, and Beijing still appears willing to cooperate, though always with a wary eye to the downside risks.

Paal, who is now vice president for studies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said at the seminar titled Taipei- Washington-Beijing Relations under the Ma and Obama Administratopms" that both China and the U.S. are also likely to continue their current tactics.

He said China's direction, economically and otherwise, appears to enjoy what passes for a consensus on the mainland, while the U.S., under the new Obama administration, is actively seeking to accentuate the positive with Beijing.
Obama has indentified the financial crisis, climate change, and non- proliferation as his key themes and has been seeking and initially obtaining Chinese cooperation in these areas, he added.
Paal also argued that Obama would undoubtedly like to see Taiwan shoulder an appropriate share of the burden of its own necessary defense.
"Indications are that his (Obama's) administration will assess Taiwan's requests with an eye to the actual situation rather than just the statements of China's leaders," Paal said.

"The friction that could result should be manageable within the broader positive context in U.S.-China relations, and in Taiwan's own efforts to avoid clumsily treading on sensitivities and to seek common interests," he added.

In the long term, Paal said whether the U.S., Taiwan, and China will change their strategic courses will depend on three factors that include the ability of the Ma Ying-jeou administration to demonstrate to Taiwan's voters that his policies are worth continuing.

The other two factors are China's avoidance of a domestic crisis, driven by factors such as a financial collapse, a failure to stimulate domestic consumption, or an embarrassing international setback; and America's readjustment of its economic trajectory from a capital importing to a capital exporting country, the downsizing of its international exposure to conflict, and fiscal responsibility, he added.

"These are significant threats, if now remote, to the positive sum game the triangular relationship has entered. The emergence of a significant change in any one of them will have a negative impact on the other two," Paal said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic crisis hurts Taiwan worse than South Korea: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 22:58:23 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The current global economic crisis has inflicted greater harm on Taiwan than South Korea, scholars at a Taipei forum said Friday.
According to a forecast by the Manila-based Asian Development Bank (ADB) in late September, Taiwan's economy is expected to contract 4.9 percent this year, compared to South Korea's 2 percent.

Chou Chi, director of the Economics Department of the Shih Hsin University, said that Taiwan outperformed South Korea in coping with the 1997 Asian financial crisis, but since then South Korea has adopted an economic development approach that has differed from Taiwan's and yielded a relatively satisfactory result.

For example, Taiwan's average real wage (salary) has remained relatively unchanged over the past 10 years and now accounts for only 60 percent of that of South Korea, in part because of the latter's rising productivity.

Echoing Chou, Hu Chung Ying, the vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, argued that Taiwan has put too much emphasis on the development of export-oriented high-tech industries, in sharp contrast to South Korea's more diverse policy of pushing shipbuilding, transportation, the automotive sector and high-tech industries as its development priorities.
Hu urged the government to seek to break the "bottleneck" by accelerating the development of the service sector over the next 10 years.

You Chi-tsung, the deputy director of the Industrial Technology Research Institute's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center, attributed Taiwan's lackluster performance to its relatively poor ability to create high value-added goods.

The decline in Taiwan's value-added rate from 27.8 percent in 1999 to 18.46 percent in 2008 stemmed in part from its industrial structure that was not geared to increasing incomes and the quality of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to find jobs for award-winning athletes

TEXT.P: Grilled on the difficulties Taiwanese gold medalists at international sports competitions are having finding jobs, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that the central government had an obligation to secure jobs for athletes placing in the top three of major sports events.
Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chih-hsiung, a silver medalist in taekwondo at the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens, raised the issue at a Legislative Yuan hearing Friday.

He said that in view of the problems faced by Taiwanese medal winners at this summer's Kaohsiung World Games and Taipei Deaflympics, the government should help outstanding athletes find ways to make a living.

Wu said he will direct the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council to come up with a plan to arrange for award-winning athletes in the recently concluded competitions to serve as coaches in table tennis, swimming, baseball and other relevant sports.
Major state-owned enterprises are also willing to financially support local baseball and basketball teams to hire medal-winning athletes to be their coaches, Wu said.
He also promised that the Executive Yuan would collaborate with local governments in helping outstanding athletes find jobs.
During the session, Huang also expressed concern that local students exercise too and eat too much.
Minister of Education Wu Ching-chi said his ministry has launched a "health campus" campaign to encourage students to exercise regularly and adequately while adopting a balanced diet.
"We will encourage local governments to suggest public schools in their districts to provide full vegetarian lunches once a week for their students," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese negotiator not to meet President Ma at upcoming talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 23:37:54 (By Lee Chia-fei, Liu Cheng-ching & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Chairman Chiang Pin-kung of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Friday that his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin. is not scheduled to meet President Ma Ying-jeou when he visits Taiwan for the coming round of talks in December.

Chen, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), paid a brief and awkward courtesy call to Ma at the Taipei Guest House last November, when he was in Taipei for the second round of cross-strait talks.
Chiang did not specify a reason why Chen and Ma will not meet.
Both SEF and ARATS are authorized by Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.
President Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Friday that a controversial economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will not be on the agenda of the fourth round of talks.

The topics of discussion will be cooperation on fishermen, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation, Ma said.

In a meeting with American scholars in Taiwan for a seminar on Taipei-Beijing- Washington relations, Ma reiterated that the government will secure the country's sovereignty and interests while seeking to improve relations with China.

Ma said that over the past year or so, the government has made great efforts to reduce hostility between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait with satisfactory results, including nine agreements signed in the past three rounds of talks between Taiwan and China.
Those pacts have made possible the establishment of air, trade and postal links between Taiwan and China, visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists, and cross-strait judicial assistance.

Defending his new diplomatic approach that seeks to avoid competition with China over diplomatic allies, Ma said that a climate of reconciliation has been made possible not only in the Taiwan Strait but also in the international arena.

Taiwan was able to be represented by a retired high-ranking official at last year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit meeting, and to take part in this year's World Health Assembly (WHA).

On the nation's future diplomatic operation agenda, Ma told the visiting scholars that the government will seek to take part in such international agencies that are deeply related to the safety of the nation and people but have no political significance, such as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese student volunteers share overseas service experiences

TEXT.P: Volunteer services in remote foreign countries have helped young students learn to overcome barriers with perseverance and to treat different cultures and ethnic groups with humility and sincerity, a National Tsinghua University spokesman said Friday.

Wang Chun-cheng, Tsinghua's deputy academic affairs chief who concurrently heads the extracurricular affairs section, made the remarks at a news conference in which a group of students shared their overseas service experiences during this past summer.
Wang said the university in northern Taiwan has organized overseas volunteer service programs for students for three consectuive years.
"This year we organized seven groups, who went to Nepal, Ghana, Indonesia's Aceh and Medan areas, Tanzania, and China's Qinghai province and Yinchuan in Ningxia province," Wang said.

The Nepal group stayed there for over two weeks, the longest stay of any group. The student volunteers lived in tents they erected on their own and went without running water and electricity. They helped with free medical services in an isolated mountain village that can be reached only on foot.
You Chun-wei, a graduate student who grew up in metropolitain Taipei, said it was an unforgettable experience to work and live in such a primitive environment.
You and his classmates also helped teach locals public health knowledge and establish a digitalized medical data system.
As most Tsinghua students focus their studies on engineering and science, volunteer groups to Tanzania and Ghana helped the communities they visited narrow the digital divide.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI's paper-thin speaker wins Wall Street Journal award

TEXT.P: A paper-thin flexible loudspeaker, dubbed FleXpeaker, developed by Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , recently won the 2009 Wall Street Journal global Technology Innovation Award in the Consumer Electronics category.

FleXpeaker is an array of tiny, bendable speakers that can be combined to produce high-fidelity speaker systems of almost any size using standard printing, making it the world's thinnest, lightest and most flexible speaker.
It pioneers a new era in speakers and the electronic sound industry and allows consumer electronic products of the future to become even lighter and slimmer.
In a statement released Friday, the ITRI suggested that because the FleXpeaker is lightweight and consumes little power, it could be attractive for use in cell phones or in car sound systems.

Other possible applications include giant banners that could be used to deliver public-service announcements in train stations or advertising messages in shopping malls. It can also be incorporated into wearable clothing and consumer packaging, and can be cut with scissors into any shape.
"ITRI is seeking to license the technology or create a spinoff company to commercialize the product," the ITRI statement said.

Yi-jen Chan, general director of ITRI's Electronic & Optoelectronic Research Laboratories, who led the speaker project, traveled to San Francisco to receive the internationally acclaimed award Oct. 13.
At the award presentation ceremony, The Wall Street Journal news editor John M. Leger praised FleXpeaker as a revolutionary technology.
"The judges believe that this looks like a significant breakthrough in speaker design. They haven't seen anything like this before," Leger said.
The Wall Street Journal announced that the FleXpeaker had won the global Technology Innovation Award on Sept. 14, beating out high-profile companies such as HP, Livescribe and Motorola.

"To be recognized by an organization as prestigious and well- respected as The Wall Street Journal is a great honor, " Chan said. "I am very proud of our team that developed this groundbreaking technology and am pleased they earned such recognition."

In their ninth year, the 2009 Wall Street Journal Technology Innovation Awards received more than 500 entries spanning 12 categories, 180 of which were sent to a team of 16 judges from research institutes, venture capital firms, and experts and scholars from other reputed companies and organizations.
Judges were instructed to consider the technology's applications, commercialization and market potential in addition to its innovation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Many pregnant women exposed to secondhand smoke at home: poll

TEXT.P: Some 50 percent of Taiwan's pregnant women are exposed to secondhand smoke at home, according to the results of a survey on pregnant women released Friday.

Most pregnant women exposed to secondhand smoke in Taiwan face it at home, particularly at night, but others still must contend with secondhand smoke in the workplace, according to the survey, the largest of its kind in 20 years.

The survey, in which 2,346 pregnant women answered questionnaires and had their blood tested periodically, was conducted by National Taiwan University Hospital for the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH).

The blood tests found that pregnant women in Taiwan lack iron, folic acid, vitamin A and vitamin B in their diets, even in the initial stages of the their pregnancies, and the situation gets worse as the pregnancy progresses.

By the third trimester, many of the pregnant women had a 4 percent deficiency of folic acid, a 37 percent deficiency of vitamin B, and a 14 percent deficiency of vitamin B2. They also had major iron deficiencies, with some of the women in the trial having iron levels 50 percent lower than accepted standards.

The survey identified other flaws in the participants' diets. It found that local pregnant women ingest only 52 percent of the daily recommended amount of 7.4 mg of Vitamin E and only half of the 522 mg of calcium recommended per day.
The average amount of 4.9 c.c. of dietary fiber consumed every day by Taiwan's pregnant females also falls short of the recommended amount by between 17 percent and 32 percent.

As 60 percent of Taiwanese pregnant women also work and usually eat outside, Shaw Ning-sing, the National Taiwan University professor who was in charge of the survey, recommended they take fish oil and other mineral supplements to complement the nutrients they get from their diets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to be included in U.S. visa waiver program

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang said Friday that Taiwan and the United States are discussing the possibility of including Taiwan in a U.S. visa waiver program, but he gave no specific timetable.

Yang made the remarks in response to reporters' questions after attending an international seminar titled "Taipei-Washington-Beijing Relations under the Ma and Obama Administrations" that was held in Taipei by the non-government Foundation on Asia-Pacific Peace Studies and the Pacific Forum of the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a U.S. think tank.
"Both Taiwan and the U.S. understand the importance of the visa waiver program issue, which are already under discussion by the two sides. However, I cannot tell you a certain timetable," Yang said.

Asked whether Taiwan is concerned about U.S. President Barack Obama's visit to China scheduled for mid-November, the foreign minister said he is confident that Washington-Taipei relations will not be affected by the trip.
With the great improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Yang said at the international seminar, there are five facets of the new face of U.S.-Taiwan relations in the current context.

They include working on the inclusion of Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program, enhancement of bilateral security cooperation, economic and investment ties, and Taiwan's seeking of America's strong support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and International Civil Aviation Organization, according to Yang.

Moreover, it would be of mutual benefit to both Taipei and Washington to expand cooperation on issues of export control and counter-weapons proliferation, as the two sides have worked effectively together on the implementation of the container security initiative, which entails a system of checking for illegal goods shipping containers that leave Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan.

Speaking on the trilateral relations between the U.S., Taiwan and China, Chao Chun-shan, chairman of the Foundation on Asia-Pacific Peace Studies, said in his opening remarks that this is probably the first time since 1949 that the three parties had shared a path of mutual trust and cooperation.
If such a relationship continues to develop, there might be a chance for trilateral relations to reach a win-win-win situation, at which time Washington, Beijing and Taipei should seize the moment.

Ralph A. Cossa, president of the CSIS Pacific Forum, echoed Chao's view, saying that there is an opportunity to move things forward because the leaderships of all three are dedicated toward moving the relationship forward without a zero- sum mentality.
"The relations between the U.S., Taiwan and China are not and should not be a zero-sum game, and the U.S. very much wants good relations both with China and Taiwan," Cossa said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Organizer vows to stage bigger Taipei 101 fireworks show this year

TEXT.P: An even more spectacular light show and fireworks display will be staged this year at Taipei 101 during the New Year's Eve party, the vice chairman of the Taipei Financial Center Corp. (TFCC) that owns the tower said Tuesday.

Wei Ying-jiao made the comment after it was reported that the Tourism Bureau, the major sponsor of the Taipei 101 light show in the past two years, will not be able to sponsor the show this year because it has put a lot of its financial resources into boosting tourism business in areas hit by Typhoon Morakot.

Wei told reporters at an award ceremony for Taiwan's top 10 international brands that his group is very pleased with its investment in Taipei 101 and that "the New Year countdown party will absolutely not disappoint anyone."

Noting that the fireworks countdown is an important celebration that gives international exposure to Taiwan, Wei said that the TFCC will not only organize the event this year but also plans to make it bigger.

Asked about whether the name of his family's food and beverage business, Ting Hsin, will be displayed at the show, Wei said that his family prefers to keep a low-profile, therefore the show will not highlight any characters related to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER forecasts -3.72% GDP growth for Taiwan this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 18:43:28 (By Anita Pan, Cheng Yun-hsuan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) in its latest forecast Friday slightly adjusted downward Taiwan's economic growth this year from -3.56 percent to -3.72 percent.
The CIER said that the downward adjustment was made due to the "weaker-than expected" momentum of economic recovery seen in the second and third quarters of this year.
The CIER said that Taiwan's economy recorded a negative growth of 2.08 percent in the third quarter, but it should gain momentum to register a 5.31 growth in the fourth quarter.
Peng Su-ling, a CIER associated research fellow, attributed the optimistic outlook for the fourth quarter in Taiwan to the gradual stabilization of the global economic situation.

The CIER painted a gloomy picture of a 5.94 percent unemployment rate for Taiwan for the fourth quarter, and a 5.88 percent rate for the whole of 2009 based on what it said was a reluctance on the part of domestic enterprises to hire new workers.
However, the institution said the jobless rate will drop to 5.76 percent next year, when the economy is expected to grow by 4.65 percent.
The CIER also forecast growths of 1.91 percent and 8.16 percent, respectively, next year for Taiwan's private sector consumption and private sector investment.
Taiwan's commodity and services exports will increase by 9.72 percent and imports will grow by 8.47 percent in 2010, while the commodity price index (CPI) will climb 0.78 percent, it forecast.
However, an executive of the Citibank Taiwan said that the CIER's forecast of 4.65 percent GDP growth for next year is "too optimistic. "
Cheng Chen-mao, a Citibank vice president in charge of financial trading, said that although the global economy is beginning to show signs of recovery, "the crisis is not completely over".

He added that currently governments of the world, by implementing economic stimulus measures, are providing the biggest momentum for economic recovery, but whether or not the recovery would be sustained will depend in large on private investment.

Meanwhile, expressing concerns over the possible impact of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, Wang Lee-Rong, director of CIER's Center for Economic Forecasting, said that Taiwan workers who are rendered jobless by the ECFA should be transferred to those sectors that would benefit from the cross-strait agreement.

Negotiators from Taiwan and China are expected to discuss the ECFA issue when they meet in Taichung, central Taiwan in December for the next round of cross- strait talks, and are likely to ink the agreement some time next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diplomatic personnel to step up community outreach tours: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic personnel, particularly overseas mission chiefs and staff who are on home visits, will embark on community outreach tours to learn more about grassroots opinions, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday in a statement.

According to the statement, the ministry has come up with a comprehensive action plan in response to President Ma Ying-jeou's directive that diplomatic and national security personnel should have closer interaction with grassroots communities.

Ma gave the directive after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan in early August. At the time, diplomatic and national security authorities were criticized for initially turning down foreign offers of relief aid for typhoon victims.

During a post-typhoon review meeting, Ma said diplomatic and national security officials should be in more frequent contact or have greater interaction with grassroots people so that these officials can better represent domestic public opinions and situations in the countries to which they are posted.

Acting on Ma's instructions, the MOFA statement said, the ministry decided to arrange for overseas mission chiefs and staff to visit the regions hardest-hit by Typhoon Morakot whenever they return home on consultation visits.
"Through these kinds of outreach tours, diplomatic personnel are expected to acquire a better understanding of the local people's needs, "the statement said.

Overseas mission chiefs will also be required to meet with local government heads, particularly those in central, southern and eastern Taiwan and on outlying islands, before they depart to take up overseas posts or when they return on visits, in order to learn more about what kind of assistance is most needed to promote exports of local specialties and increase civilian exchanges.
Moreover, the statement said achievements in boosting bilateral trade and economic relations will become important criteria in evaluating the overall performance of overseas diplomatic missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top U.S. envoy to Taiwan confident of progress on big issues

TEXT.P: William Stanton, the top United States envoy to Taiwan, expressed confidence Friday in resolving or making progress on several important issues affecting Taiwan-U.S. relations, which he said would further enhance their already close ties.

According to Stanton, outstanding issues include resuming the long-halted Trade Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks, working on the inclusion of Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program, evaluating the provision of more security assistance to Taiwan, supporting Taiwan's participation in international organizations, and strengthening other areas of cooperation.
"Perhaps the most important vehicle we have for the trade agenda is the TIFA. That has been stalled over the beef issue, but it looks like it's resolved," Stanton said.

"We are looking to resuming the TIFA talks very soon. We hope before the end of the year to review new areas for progress on our trade agenda, " the envoy said in his speech at an international seminar in Taipei titled "Taipei-Washington- Beijing Relations under the Ma and Obama Administrations."
The TIFA talks, which are regularly held alternatively by Taiwan and the U.S., have been halted because of differences over Taiwan's continued restrictions on U.S. beef imports.

Another area in which the U.S. and Taiwan are looking to expand cooperation is law enforcement, said Stanton, who noted that the U.S. has been very encouraged by Taiwan's efforts in combatting human trafficking.
He thinks that over the long term, there is great hope that Taipei and Washington can ink an extradition agreement, which would serve mutual interests.

On the issue of including Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program, Stanton said Washington wants to make travel to the U.S. more secure and convenient for Taiwanese visitors and is encouraging Taiwan to strengthen its document security and how it issues its passports.

"We hope (to work) toward the goal of bringing Taiwan into the visa waiver program, which I certainly think is doable. I worked on the visa waiver program, which was a success in Korea, and I don't see why it can't be done here," Stanton said.

On Taiwan's international participation, the diplomat said Taiwan has plenty to offer to the international community, and he noted it hopes to join the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and International Civil Aviation Organization.
"We support Taiwan's meaningful participation in these and similar organizations, and will do what we can to help that happen, " he said.
Stanton said that the U.S. very much welcomes the improving relations between Taipei and Beijing but indicated that Taiwan needs to feel secure to continue that progress.
"Taiwan needs friends, and I can say with assurance that the U.S. will continue to be a dependable friend of Taiwan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. welcomes positive cross-strait developments: scholars

TEXT.P: Professor Bau Tzong-ho of National Taiwan University also suggested that the U.S. could play a more constructive role as a counterbalance, partner and deterrent.

Stressing the "one-China policy" that is observed by the U.S. government, CSIS Senior Advisor Michael J. Green maintained that the U.S. would likely play a background or supporting role in the process of developing cross-strait mutual trust.
Nevertheless, the U.S. should meet its commitments listed in the Taiwan Relations Act, he added.

The one-day seminar concluded Friday evening with a speech by William A. Stanton, Taipei office director of the American Institute in Taiwan. The top U.S. envoy spoke mainly on issues related to Washington and Taipei, such as including Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program and the resumption of the long- stalled Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) negotiations.
