DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. welcomes positive cross-strait developments: scholars

TEXT.P: American scholars attending a seminar on Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations said Friday in Taipei that the United States welcomed the positive development in relations between Taipei and Beijing and it is unlikely that Washington would play an intermediary role.

At the seminar, some 200 scholars from think tanks in the United States and Taiwan discussed the cross-strait factor in U.S. Asia policy and the U.S. role in building cross-strait mutual trust mechanisms. The seminar was jointly sponsored by the Foundation on Asia-Pacific Peace Studies (FAPPS) in Taipei and the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) in Washington, D.C.

Ralph A. Cossa, CSIS Pacific Forum president, said that the administration of President Barack Obama is "absolutely delighted that China and Taiwan are talking over and working out their problems between them."

Referring to the attitude of the U.S. government towards improved relations between Taipei and Beijing, and in response to a question by Professor George W. Tsai of the Chinese Culture University, Cossa said that the notion that the U.S. is worried about the two sides getting too close "is truly a minority point of view."

Cossa's view was echoed by Professor David M. Lampton of John Hopkins University, who said that most Americans would expect the cross-strait reconciliation to continue and would love to see the signing of a cross-strait peace agreement.

As confidence building is deemed vital to the progress of cross- strait relations, Professor Chen I-hsin of Tamkang University said, "Washington could play a multi-dimensional role in and after the process of cross-strait negotiations on the establishment of mutual trust mechanisms."

According to Chen, the U.S. can play the role of a facilitator by providing Taiwan with advice and suggestions, based on its own practical experience, when issues such as formal exchange programs, direct military-to-military exchanges and military liaison offices are discussed in the second track meetings.
Professor Bau Tzong-ho of National Taiwan University also suggested that the U.S. could play a more constructive role as a counterbalance, partner and deterrent.

Stressing the "one-China policy" that is observed by the U.S. government, CSIS Senior Advisor Michael J. Green maintained that the U.S. would likely play a background or supporting role in the process of developing cross-strait mutual trust.
Nevertheless, the U.S. should meet its commitments listed in the Taiwan Relations Act, he added.

The one-day seminar concluded Friday evening with a speech by William A. Stanton, Taipei office director of the American Institute in Taiwan. The top U.S. envoy spoke mainly on issues related to Washington and Taipei, such as including Taiwan in the U.S. visa waiver program and the resumption of the long- stalled Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Techniques to build Wang Yeh's boat may soon disappear
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 21:10:22 (By Kuo Chi-hsuan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: As the eight-day Donggang Wang Yeh Festival heads toward its climax Saturday when a multimillion Taiwan dollar boat is burned, a shipbuilding master worries that one day soon the art of building the deity's wooden vessel will be lost.

Young people today are not interested in learning how to put together the ceremonial boat, lamented 65-year-old Hsieh Chung-sheng while walking on a beach at Jhenhai Park to inspect the site where the highly anticipated triennial ritual of burning Wang Yeh's boat takes place.

The master craftsman said he began learning the skills needed to build wooden fishing boats when he was 16 and he was in his twenties when he was recruited by Donggang Township's Donglong Temple -- the center of Wang Yeh worship in southwestern Taiwan -- to work on the Wang Yeh vessel.

At the age of 48, he was promoted to head a team of more than 160 workers to make the craft that carries Wang Yeh on his pilmigrage around the town to help those who worship him eradicate disease and ward off evil.

As wooden fishing vessels have gradually been replaced by modern boats made of carbon fiber, the number of wooden boat craftsmen has also declined. Now there are only 100 members on his team, and they average 60 years old.

"We are a group of retired old men, " Hsieh says, and he is worried that a tradition that dates back more than 300 years, when Donglong Temple organized its first triennial Wang Yeh worshipping ceremony, could be without its main prop.

Wang Yeh's vessel, however, has not always been built completely with wood. In the early days, the ceremonial boat had a bamboo frame and paper body. It was not until 1973 that local residents had enough money to build a real boat, Hsieh recalls.
Wang Yeh's boat is actually modeled after an imperial boat in ancient China that was prevalent in the Fujian and Shantou areas.

"It wasn't as big as the one we build now, " Hsieh says, explaining that the boat's size in the first festival in Taiwan was about 11.4 meters by 1.7 meters and has expanded each time the ceremony has been held -- until 2009.

Wang Yeh's boat this year measures the same size it did in 2006 -- 13.8m long by 3.65m wide by 1.75m high -- because if it were made any bigger, it could not be carried through the streets of Donggang.
But its price tag of NT$6.6 million this year was about 10 percent higher than three years ago because of more expensive raw materials, Hsieh said.

On Friday, the colorful boat made of high quality Vietnamese juniper was pulled by people for a "sail" on the streets of the fishing port. The procession symbolizes the gods patrolling the Donggang area to expel evil spirits and plagues.

During the procession, the boat received offerings for Wang Yeh from local worshippers. It was brought back to the temple at around 6 p.m. and will be taken to Jhenhai Park at 2 a.m. Saturday for the burning ritual that ends the week-long festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer heads list of top 10 Taiwan Global Brands in 2009

TEXT.P: Computer vendor Acer Inc. was unveiled Friday as Taiwan's leading brand on a list of Taiwan's Top 10 Global Brands for the first time ever, with anti-virus software maker Trend Micro and computer maker AsusTek close behind.

Vice President Vincent Siew handed out awards to all of the companies on the top 10 list at Friday's awards ceremony, a component of the government's Branding Taiwan program created in 2003 aimed at building globally popular brands.

Acer headed the top 10 list with an estimated brand value of US$1.24 billion, thanks to its mergers with Gateway and Packard Bell in 2007 and its successful launch of netbook computers, according to officials from the event's co-sponsor, the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
Acer is Taiwan's largest vendor of laptop computers, and the world's second largest computer vendor after surpassing Dell in the third quarter of 2009.

Its product lineup includes desktops, laptops, personal digital assistants (PDAs), servers and storage, displays, peripherals, and e-business services for business, government, education, and home users.
Filling out the top 10 brand list were, in order, HTC, Master Kong, Want Want, Maxxis, Giant, Synnex and Zyxel.

Master Kong and Giant have made it into the top 10 every year since the list was created, even though it has been traditionally dominated by high-tech companies. Over the past seven years, Trend Micro has occupied the No. 1 spot five times.

But the continued presence of conventional businesses such as food processor Master Kong and bicycle maker Giant, along with rice snack maker Want Want was worth noting, according to global brand consultancy Interbrand.

The brand expert attributed Master Kong's listing to its prevailing market share in the Chinese market, which has spared the company from the adverse effects of the global economic crunch and helped its brand value appreciate by 19 percent in 2009 to US$916 million.
Want Want, which made the list for the first time, was estimated to have a brand value of US$421 million, while Giant had a brand value of US$262 million.

The combined value of this year's top 10 Taiwanese brands totaled US$7.326 billion, down 2.8 percent from 2008 due to the impact of the global financial crisis, TAITRA officials said. Each of the top four brands had brand values exceeding US$1.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't plans to provide NT$1b to promote creative industries

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) plans to subsidize NT$1 billion in discounts on student tickets for performances by local arts and cultural groups to help foster cultural and creative industries, a council official said Friday.
Fang Jy-Shiuh, director of the council's first department, said the government hoped the trial program would expand the demand for arts and cultural events.
A plan to offer tax incentives to encourage cultural consumption had originally been considered but was eventually scrapped after taking into account other potential consequences.

The government therefore decided to provide NT$1 billion a year for the subsidy program on a trial basis, Fang said in announcing the program at a seminar on the development of Taiwan's cultural and creative industries organized by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum.

Noting that the subsidy program falls under the provisions of the Cultural and Creative Industry Development Draft Act, Fang said that although the act has yet to be enacted, the CCA has begun mapping out the subsidy plan.
Fang also said that one of the CCA's main objectives is to help creative industries penetrate Chinese-speaking and international markets.
In the initial stage, the two sides can start by jointly holding large scale cultural and creative expositions and establishing a dialogue mechanism, she suggested.

She added that the CCA will work to promote industry cooperation between Taiwan and China in the areas of investment protection, intellectual property rights protection and joint ventures into international markets.

The cultural and creative industries of Taiwan and China complement each other, Fang contended, citing China's huge market, abundant capital, vast land and a sound cultural policy related to creative industries, and Taiwan's strong talent pool and its favorable and free environment to support the industry's development.

Kuo Su-chen, chief of a creative belly dance troupe and winner of the ninth Ahlan Wa Sahlan Belly Dance Festival in July 2008 in Egypt, said at the seminar that she believes the subsidy program will help expand arts and cultural consumption.

Kuo said that if performing groups are not famous enough, they usually find it difficult to sell tickets to their shows. She also suggested that the CCA should first provide a platform for performances to help boost performing groups' popularity.
Huang Ching-lung, president of Want Daily, one of the Taiwan-based China Times Group's publications, said no industry can afford to neglect the massive Chinese market.
Huang cited the contrasting experiences of two singers, Taiwan's top female Hoklo singer Chiang Huei and Hong Kong Jacky Cheung.

Both singers sold 1 million copies of their hit albums in their home markets, but Cheung's "Kiss Goodbye" sold 5 million copies in Chinese communities around the world, while Chiang failed to sell her album outside Taiwan.

Taiwan's cultural and creative industries encompass the visual arts, music and performing arts, cultural exhibitions and performance facilities, films, TV and broadcasting, publishing, advertising, and product design.

They also extend to fashion and architectural design, creative living, digital leisure and amusement industries, according to the definition by the center for promoting Taiwan's cultural and creative industries under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Progress in cross-strait ties expected ahead: U.S. academic

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot and other extraneous factors have combined to frustrate progress in relations across the Taiwan Strait recently but have not stifled positive momentum, and progress in cross-strait ties is expected to resume in the coming quarter, a U.S. scholar forecast in a recent report.

The online quarterly report, titled China-Taiwan Relations: Temporarily in the Doldrums, was authored by David G. Brown, a cross-strait affairs expert at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
According to Brown, it is largely extraneous developments, rather than policy changes, that have impeded progress in cross-strait ties in the July-September quarter.

"Typhoon Morakot consumed public and government attention on Taiwan for three weeks in August and then led to Cabinet changes affecting some of the senior officials handling cross-Strait economic issues," Brown wrote.

At the same time, Morakot occasioned two positive developments, Brown argued. First, Beijing was prompt and generous in providing financial and practical aid. Second, the U.S. also provided aid, which included the first deployment of U.S. military aircraft to Taiwan since 1979.

"This potentially sensitive action was handled discreetly, with Beijing portraying it as a humanitarian action, the U.S. planes leaving as soon as their humanitarian work was concluded, and neither Taipei nor Washington gave the action any broader significance, " Brown wrote.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's decision to invite the Dalai Lama to console Morakot victims presented a dilemma for Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou and for Beijing.
"In the end, both sides handled the issue in a way that delayed some minor cross-Strait events but did not significantly disrupt relations," Brown observed.
He predicted that progress in improving cross-strait relations should resume in the coming months.

Brown suggested, however, that the easy agreements were concluded in the first three meetings between top officials of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

More difficult issues involving the usual balancing of interests in bilateral trade negotiations have affected the pace of talks on both the memorandums of understanding (MOUs) covering banking, insurance and securities and the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Brown contended.

The financial MOUs, which were to have been completed in late June, are still pending. The financial regulatory systems to be defined in the MOUs must be in place before the two sides can reciprocally approve operations by financial services firms.
The MOUs are expected to be signed before the end of the year, Brown said, citing China's Taiwan Affairs Office.

Meanwhile, Brown pointed out that the fourth round of SEF-ARATS talks is scheduled to be held late this year and should result in additional agreements, possibly including ones on fisheries, agricultural product standards, product testing, double taxation and a discussion on ECFA.

On cross-strait economic ties, Brown said bilateral trade is beginning to recover from the precipitous decline caused by the global financial crisis and the first group of Chinese investments in Taiwan, although small, have been approved.

Citing tallies compiled by Taiwan's Investment Commission, the report said eight Chinese investments totaling US$769,000 were made during July and August with Fujia Newland Computers making the largest single investment.

With cross-strait relations proceeding constructively, the U.S. government's role is limited. Nevertheless, Brown said arms sales are one important exception that needs to be handled in a sophisticated way to support the long-term U.S. interest in a peaceful resolution of cross-strait issues.
"It is in the U.S. interest to support a government in Taiwan that is working constructively to consolidate a stable, peaceful cross-strait relationship," Brown argued.
Taipei is requesting arms so it can maintain a "credible deterrent position" from which to negotiate.

Furthermore, as the Ma administration is being criticized at home for not doing enough for Taiwan's defense, Brown wrote, the fact that there has been little concrete evidence of support for Taipei from the Obama administration is calling into question Ma's ability to successfully manage the all important U.S.-Taiwan relationship.

"With Beijing's deployments growing, there is a sound case for the U.S. to move ahead with the Blackhawk sale and to respond favorably to Taiwan's request for the F-16C/D aircraft, which are increasingly seen as a litmus test of U.S. support," Brown wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: Continuity in store for future U.S.-Taiwan-China relations: Paal

TEXT.P: Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan, said Friday in Taipei that "continuity" will characterize prospects for the short-term strategic paths of the United States, Taiwan and China.
The proposition was reinforced by last year's election of a Taiwan administration that seeks to eschew unnecessary friction with China and seek areas of cooperation with Beijing, according to Paal.
He said Taiwan has at least two and a half years to seek success with its approach, and Beijing still appears willing to cooperate, though always with a wary eye to the downside risks.

Paal, who is now vice president for studies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said at the seminar titled Taipei- Washington-Beijing Relations under the Ma and Obama Administratopms" that both China and the U.S. are also likely to continue their current tactics.

He said China's direction, economically and otherwise, appears to enjoy what passes for a consensus on the mainland, while the U.S., under the new Obama administration, is actively seeking to accentuate the positive with Beijing.
Obama has indentified the financial crisis, climate change, and non- proliferation as his key themes and has been seeking and initially obtaining Chinese cooperation in these areas, he added.
Paal also argued that Obama would undoubtedly like to see Taiwan shoulder an appropriate share of the burden of its own necessary defense.
"Indications are that his (Obama's) administration will assess Taiwan's requests with an eye to the actual situation rather than just the statements of China's leaders," Paal said.

"The friction that could result should be manageable within the broader positive context in U.S.-China relations, and in Taiwan's own efforts to avoid clumsily treading on sensitivities and to seek common interests," he added.

In the long term, Paal said whether the U.S., Taiwan, and China will change their strategic courses will depend on three factors that include the ability of the Ma Ying-jeou administration to demonstrate to Taiwan's voters that his policies are worth continuing.

The other two factors are China's avoidance of a domestic crisis, driven by factors such as a financial collapse, a failure to stimulate domestic consumption, or an embarrassing international setback; and America's readjustment of its economic trajectory from a capital importing to a capital exporting country, the downsizing of its international exposure to conflict, and fiscal responsibility, he added.

"These are significant threats, if now remote, to the positive sum game the triangular relationship has entered. The emergence of a significant change in any one of them will have a negative impact on the other two," Paal said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic crisis hurts Taiwan worse than South Korea: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 22:58:23 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The current global economic crisis has inflicted greater harm on Taiwan than South Korea, scholars at a Taipei forum said Friday.
According to a forecast by the Manila-based Asian Development Bank (ADB) in late September, Taiwan's economy is expected to contract 4.9 percent this year, compared to South Korea's 2 percent.

Chou Chi, director of the Economics Department of the Shih Hsin University, said that Taiwan outperformed South Korea in coping with the 1997 Asian financial crisis, but since then South Korea has adopted an economic development approach that has differed from Taiwan's and yielded a relatively satisfactory result.

For example, Taiwan's average real wage (salary) has remained relatively unchanged over the past 10 years and now accounts for only 60 percent of that of South Korea, in part because of the latter's rising productivity.

Echoing Chou, Hu Chung Ying, the vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, argued that Taiwan has put too much emphasis on the development of export-oriented high-tech industries, in sharp contrast to South Korea's more diverse policy of pushing shipbuilding, transportation, the automotive sector and high-tech industries as its development priorities.
Hu urged the government to seek to break the "bottleneck" by accelerating the development of the service sector over the next 10 years.

You Chi-tsung, the deputy director of the Industrial Technology Research Institute's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center, attributed Taiwan's lackluster performance to its relatively poor ability to create high value-added goods.

The decline in Taiwan's value-added rate from 27.8 percent in 1999 to 18.46 percent in 2008 stemmed in part from its industrial structure that was not geared to increasing incomes and the quality of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to find jobs for award-winning athletes

TEXT.P: Grilled on the difficulties Taiwanese gold medalists at international sports competitions are having finding jobs, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that the central government had an obligation to secure jobs for athletes placing in the top three of major sports events.
Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chih-hsiung, a silver medalist in taekwondo at the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens, raised the issue at a Legislative Yuan hearing Friday.

He said that in view of the problems faced by Taiwanese medal winners at this summer's Kaohsiung World Games and Taipei Deaflympics, the government should help outstanding athletes find ways to make a living.

Wu said he will direct the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council to come up with a plan to arrange for award-winning athletes in the recently concluded competitions to serve as coaches in table tennis, swimming, baseball and other relevant sports.
Major state-owned enterprises are also willing to financially support local baseball and basketball teams to hire medal-winning athletes to be their coaches, Wu said.
He also promised that the Executive Yuan would collaborate with local governments in helping outstanding athletes find jobs.
During the session, Huang also expressed concern that local students exercise too and eat too much.
Minister of Education Wu Ching-chi said his ministry has launched a "health campus" campaign to encourage students to exercise regularly and adequately while adopting a balanced diet.
"We will encourage local governments to suggest public schools in their districts to provide full vegetarian lunches once a week for their students," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese negotiator not to meet President Ma at upcoming talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/09 23:37:54 (By Lee Chia-fei, Liu Cheng-ching & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Chairman Chiang Pin-kung of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Friday that his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin. is not scheduled to meet President Ma Ying-jeou when he visits Taiwan for the coming round of talks in December.

Chen, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), paid a brief and awkward courtesy call to Ma at the Taipei Guest House last November, when he was in Taipei for the second round of cross-strait talks.
Chiang did not specify a reason why Chen and Ma will not meet.
Both SEF and ARATS are authorized by Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.
President Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Friday that a controversial economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will not be on the agenda of the fourth round of talks.

The topics of discussion will be cooperation on fishermen, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation, Ma said.

In a meeting with American scholars in Taiwan for a seminar on Taipei-Beijing- Washington relations, Ma reiterated that the government will secure the country's sovereignty and interests while seeking to improve relations with China.

Ma said that over the past year or so, the government has made great efforts to reduce hostility between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait with satisfactory results, including nine agreements signed in the past three rounds of talks between Taiwan and China.
Those pacts have made possible the establishment of air, trade and postal links between Taiwan and China, visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists, and cross-strait judicial assistance.

Defending his new diplomatic approach that seeks to avoid competition with China over diplomatic allies, Ma said that a climate of reconciliation has been made possible not only in the Taiwan Strait but also in the international arena.

Taiwan was able to be represented by a retired high-ranking official at last year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit meeting, and to take part in this year's World Health Assembly (WHA).

On the nation's future diplomatic operation agenda, Ma told the visiting scholars that the government will seek to take part in such international agencies that are deeply related to the safety of the nation and people but have no political significance, such as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese student volunteers share overseas service experiences

TEXT.P: Volunteer services in remote foreign countries have helped young students learn to overcome barriers with perseverance and to treat different cultures and ethnic groups with humility and sincerity, a National Tsinghua University spokesman said Friday.

Wang Chun-cheng, Tsinghua's deputy academic affairs chief who concurrently heads the extracurricular affairs section, made the remarks at a news conference in which a group of students shared their overseas service experiences during this past summer.
Wang said the university in northern Taiwan has organized overseas volunteer service programs for students for three consectuive years.
"This year we organized seven groups, who went to Nepal, Ghana, Indonesia's Aceh and Medan areas, Tanzania, and China's Qinghai province and Yinchuan in Ningxia province," Wang said.

The Nepal group stayed there for over two weeks, the longest stay of any group. The student volunteers lived in tents they erected on their own and went without running water and electricity. They helped with free medical services in an isolated mountain village that can be reached only on foot.
You Chun-wei, a graduate student who grew up in metropolitain Taipei, said it was an unforgettable experience to work and live in such a primitive environment.
You and his classmates also helped teach locals public health knowledge and establish a digitalized medical data system.
As most Tsinghua students focus their studies on engineering and science, volunteer groups to Tanzania and Ghana helped the communities they visited narrow the digital divide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 17, or the 29th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge on Penghu (the Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is inaugurated in Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
2000: The Republic of China's Central News Agency enters into an agreement with France's Agency France-Press at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu says signifies Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.
2001: The two-day ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum begins in Shanghai with foreign ministers, trade ministers and representatives from the 21 member economies participating.
2001: The 2001 Taipei International Electronics Products Exhibition opens with 806 domestic and foreign manufacturers participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic crisis hurts Taiwan worse than South Korea: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/17/09 12:03:12 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The current global economic crisis has inflicted greater harm on Taiwan than South Korea, scholars at a Taipei forum said Friday.
According to a forecast by the Manila-based Asian Development Bank (ADB) in late September, Taiwan's economy is expected to contract 4.9 percent this year, compared to South Korea's 2 percent.

Chou Chi, director of the Economics Department of the Shih Hsin University, said that Taiwan outperformed South Korea in coping with the 1997 Asian financial crisis, but since then South Korea has adopted an economic development approach that has differed from Taiwan's and yielded a relatively satisfactory result.

For example, Taiwan's average real wage (salary) has remained relatively unchanged over the past 10 years and now accounts for only 60 percent of that of South Korea, in part because of the latter's rising productivity.

Echoing Chou, Hu Chung Ying, the vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, argued that Taiwan has put too much emphasis on the development of export-oriented high-tech industries, in sharp contrast to South Korea's more diverse policy of pushing shipbuilding, transportation, the automotive sector and high-tech industries as its development priorities.
Hu urged the government to seek to break the "bottleneck" by accelerating the development of the service sector over the next 10 years.

You Chi-tsung, the deputy director of the Industrial Technology Research Institute's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center, attributed Taiwan's lackluster performance to its relatively poor ability to create high value-added goods.

The decline in Taiwan's value-added rate from 27.8 percent in 1999 to 18.46 percent in 2008 stemmed in part from its industrial structure that was not geared to increasing incomes and the quality of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese negotiator not to meet President Ma at upcoming talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/17/09 12:04:23 (By Lee Chia-fei, Liu Cheng-ching & Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: Continuity in store for future U.S.-Taiwan-China relations: Paal

TEXT.P: Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan, said Friday in Taipei that "continuity" will characterize prospects for the short-term strategic paths of the United States, Taiwan and China.
The proposition was reinforced by last year's election of a Taiwan administration that seeks to eschew unnecessary friction with China and seek areas of cooperation with Beijing, according to Paal.
He said Taiwan has at least two and a half years to seek success with its approach, and Beijing still appears willing to cooperate, though always with a wary eye to the downside risks.

Paal, who is now vice president for studies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said at the seminar titled Taipei- Washington-Beijing Relations under the Ma and Obama Administratopms" that both China and the U.S. are also likely to continue their current tactics.

He said China's direction, economically and otherwise, appears to enjoy what passes for a consensus on the mainland, while the U.S., under the new Obama administration, is actively seeking to accentuate the positive with Beijing.
Obama has indentified the financial crisis, climate change, and non- proliferation as his key themes and has been seeking and initially obtaining Chinese cooperation in these areas, he added.
Paal also argued that Obama would undoubtedly like to see Taiwan shoulder an appropriate share of the burden of its own necessary defense.
"Indications are that his (Obama's) administration will assess Taiwan's requests with an eye to the actual situation rather than just the statements of China's leaders," Paal said.

"The friction that could result should be manageable within the broader positive context in U.S.-China relations, and in Taiwan's own efforts to avoid clumsily treading on sensitivities and to seek common interests," he added.

In the long term, Paal said whether the U.S., Taiwan, and China will change their strategic courses will depend on three factors that include the ability of the Ma Ying-jeou administration to demonstrate to Taiwan's voters that his policies are worth continuing.

The other two factors are China's avoidance of a domestic crisis, driven by factors such as a financial collapse, a failure to stimulate domestic consumption, or an embarrassing international setback; and America's readjustment of its economic trajectory from a capital importing to a capital exporting country, the downsizing of its international exposure to conflict, and fiscal responsibility, he added.

"These are significant threats, if now remote, to the positive sum game the triangular relationship has entered. The emergence of a significant change in any one of them will have a negative impact on the other two," Paal said.

TEXT.P: Volunteer services in remote foreign countries have helped young students learn to overcome barriers with perseverance and to treat different cultures and ethnic groups with humility and sincerity, a National Tsinghua University spokesman said Friday.
