DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/20/09 10:01:36 (By Lee Ming-tsung, Lin Yi-fong and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih assured the public Monday that a proposed energy tax will not be levied soon, saying that "it would be imposed sometime after 2011 at the earliest."

Wu made the comment after the Executive Yuan's Tax Reform Commission, convened by Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, met to discuss energy and environment tax proposals and eventually reached a consensus on pushing for an energy tax.

Wu said the energy tax, which would be assessed on the consumption of gasoline, diesel, kerosene, aviation fuel, fuel oil, and natural gas, is currently still on the drawing board, and that if it is imposed, there will be complementary measures to ease its sting.
"The fuel consumption fee and other taxes would be dropped, " the premier said.

Even if the energy tax is put in place, "it will be a long process, " Wu said, noting that the consensus reached at the meeting will be considered by related government agencies and then discussed at public hearings.
Amendments to existing laws would also have to be screened and approved by the legislature, he added.

Chu said participants in Monday's meeting could not reach a consensus on levying an environment tax, so the commission will first push for an energy tax on gasoline, based on the principle of not adding to the public's tax burden.
Meanwhile, the influential Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) said that without reasonable complementary measures, there could be an "exodus of businesses."
CNFI Chairman Preston Chen said the private sector is not opposed to the government's plan to levy an energy tax to conserve energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions.

But he urged the government to consider the country's industrial development and competitiveness, and especially the approach of its rivals such as China, Japan and South Korea, in its deliberations over an energy tax.
"That way, it will mitigate the measure's impact on industry and help maintain its competitiveness."
Chen voiced strong opposition to the environment tax, which would focus on taxing greenhouse gas emissions.

Citing a study conducted by the Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research, Chen said that even though the proposed carbon tax had been lowered from NT$2,000 per ton to NT$750 per ton, and projected revenues lowered from NT$800 billion to NT$435.1 billion, preliminary estimates show that manufacturers would be forced to bear an additional NT$100 billion in higher taxes and electricity bills.

Even the energy bill, he argued could have dire consequences because once it is imposed, businesses that use coal, fuel oil, and electricity will obviously suffer, and if they cannot pass on the extra costs in the face of international competition, their survival could be threatened.
State-run utility Taiwan Power Co. estimated that under the proposed energy tax plan, electricity costs would rise 40 percent over the next 10 years, to NT$3.54 per kwh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic aviation traffic continues downward spiral
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/20/09 10:03:31 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's domestic aviation passenger traffic volmue continued its steep decline last year mainly because of the expansion of high-speed railway services and the global economic slump, a civil aviation official said Monday.
The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) official made the remarks after legislators criticized southern Taiwan's Pingtung Airport as a white elephant because of its low utilization rate.

Except for flight routes linking Taiwan proper to its outlying islands, passenger volume on all domestic routes began to drop substantially in 1998 when National Freeway No. 3 was fully completed and opened to traffic.

The number of passengers slid further in 2003 over a SARS scare and the downward spiral became even more serious in 2007 when the high-speed railway was partially opened to traffic, the official said.
The expansion of high-speed rail services and the onset of the domestic economy slump amid a global downturn in 2008 further cut into passenger traffic.

According to CAA tallies, the 10 airports on Taiwan proper handled 40.21 million passengers in 2006 before the inauguration of the high-speed rail system. That total fell to 36.3 million in 2007 and to 31.47 million in 2008.

Noting that the high-speed railway has lured away many air passengers, the official said local carriers have successively suspended Taipei-Taichung, Taipei-Chiayi and Taipei-Tainan flight services and the number of flights on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route, previously one of the world's most traveled routes, has fallen to three round-trip flights per week.
In the first seven months of this year, passenger traffic volume handled by Taiwan proper's 10 airports totaled 17.2 million, a year-on-year decline of 11.6 percent.

Among them, only Chiayi Airport registered an increase in passenger traffic, handling 25.5 percent more passengers than a year earlier, while Pingtung Airport posted the biggest decrease, with passenger volumes falling 79 percent.

Passenger traffic also fell 56.7 percent at Hengchun Airport, 47.3 percent at Hualien Airport, 44.5 percent at Tainan Airport, 20.6 percent at Kaohsiung International Airport, 9.9 percent at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, 5.6 percent at Taipei Songshan Airport, 3.5 percent at Taichung Airport, and 2.2 percent at Taitung Airport.
Both Pingtung and Hengchun airports handle only three flights from and to Taipei each week, the lowest utilization rate among the 10 airports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 20, or the third day of the ninth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino- Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) says that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China is outdated and vows to replace it with a more aggressive approach.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: Former aboriginal affairs head now targets hairy crab aquaculture
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 12:06:03 (By Liu Chia-tai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The former head of Taiwan's aboriginal affairs has set his sights on raising hairy crabs in Hualien County after finding that the high quality water in the eastern county is ideal for the aquaculture industry.
"Hairy crab aquaculture will be more lucrative than farming, " Walis Pelin, former minister of the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP), said on Tuesday.

Pelin formed an aboriginal company together with some aquaculture experts after he stepped down from his post in 2007, and the firm established a model crab farm in Yuli Township, Hualien County, early this year.

Taiwan began hairy crab aquaculture around three years ago, mainly in western and southern Taiwan, but after inspecting Hualien's environment with aquaculture experts, Pelin believed the eastern county was a more viable location.
"The water quality in the Huatung Valley is good, and the environment is superb for the development of the aquaculture industry, especially hairy crab and sturgeon," he said.

"After we made sure of the superior water and environmental conditions, we did a cost analysis and found that demand was strong while the costs were low and the potential profits high. That's why we've decided to help indigenous peoples raise hairy crabs there," he said.
The hairy crab model farm covers about three hectares. The company initially released 150,000 fries, which have now grown to between three and four taels (one tael is about 37.5 grams.)
"The quality of the hairy crabs in Hualien will by no means be inferior to those raised in western Taiwan, mainly because we have clean water and zero pollution," Pelin said proudly.
His model farm is now developing a feed formula and various types of aquatic plants to boost survival rates and the weight of each crab.
"A hairy crab has to weigh over five taels to have better market value, " the former CIP chief said, confident that "the goal could be achieved in around eight or nine months."
He said the model farm will transfer aquaculture technology to local indigenous peoples and devise a cooperation and marketing strategy to help them develop hairy crab aquaculture farms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Book about Chinese civil war a big draw at Frankfurt Book Fair
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/20/09 12:40:40 (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born writer and University of Hong Kong professor Lung Ying-tai's latest book, titled "Wide Rivers and Seas, Untold Stories of 1949, " proved to be a big draw at the Frankfurt Book Fair Oct. 14-18.

Though China has banned all Internet articles and discussions on the book -- published by Taiwan's CommonWealth Magazine and Hong Kong's Cosmos Books in September -- Chinese publishers and exhibitors at the book fair scrambled to gain the rights to publish her book in their country.

Neue Zuercher Zeitung, a major daily newspaper in Switzerland, said in a commentary Monday that China should be positively surprised by the "small but attractive" Taiwan pavilion at the book fair, because visitors could realize that "people will have a future only when there is a past, and emotional debts from suppressed memories must be repaid."

That was the essence of Lung's book about how the Chinese communists defeated Chiang Kai-shek's Kuomintang troops in a civil war before declaring themselves the new rulers of China on Oct. 1, 1949, the commentary said.
It said Lung's speech on the book -- delivered at the book fair Oct. 15 and titled "Salute to the losers" -- was a touching one.

"China could learn from Taiwan, a small island, and the loneliness of Chinese dissident writers that true greatness comes from the willingness to face defeat and failure, instead of physical or economic magnificence," it said.

The German weekly Der Spiegel recently published a report filed by reporter Juergen Kremb from Taipei that gave a detailed account of Lung's new book, including why she wrote it and what she felt and discovered during her writing.

Kremb described the book, which Lung said will hopefully make people in China and Taiwan abandon long-held suspicions and prejudices of each other, as unarguably the most important book that has been written in the Chinese-language world in decades.
He said Lung has not been spooked by the Chinese authorities, who have sheltered its people from being influenced by the book.
"Only when you see your enemy's wounds, will you be able to put your gun down, " he quoted Lung as saying.

In addition to TV appearances and radio interviews in Germany during the book fair, Lung made the first of 10 blog reports launched by the Berlin-based daily Die Tageszeitung, called "the forgotten victims in China."

Lung's new book tells the story of the Chinese Civil War through the eyes of ordinary people whose lives were forever changed by the event, focusing on the many Chinese families that were broken apart by the fighting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military to be deployed before typhoon warning issued: Premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 13:53:49 (By Su Lung-chi and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With the approaching Typhoon Lupit expected to bring torrential rains to the northern half of Taiwan, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that military servicemen will be deployed to disaster-prone areas before the storm arrives.

Military servicemen will be mobilized and deployed to vulnerable areas 36 hours before a typhoon land warning is issued to get a better understanding of the situation and help residents stay calm, Wu said while responding to questions at the Legislative Yuan.

The premier also indicated that Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau will help the Philippines set up a weather station on the island of Luzon in the future so that it can more closely monitor the direction of typhoons in the region and enhance its ability to forecast storms' paths.

Wu had visited the weather bureau Monday morning to be briefed on the approaching storm. Weather bureau officials said he was the first premier ever to visit the bureau prior to a typhoon land warning being issued.

According to the weather bureau's latest forecast Tuesday, Typhoon Lupit has been downgraded to a medium-strength typhoon, but it could still bring extremely heavy rain to eastern and northeastern Taiwan and to mountainous areas in northern Taiwan on Thursday and Friday.
The typhoon was centered some 1,140 kilometers east-southeast of the southernmost tip of Taiwan as of 2 a.m. Tuesday and was moving in a westerly direction at 17 kph.
Forecasters said that downpours from Lupit's periphery and an intensifying northeast monsoon are expected to start dumping rain in eastern and northern parts of Taiwan on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promotes alternative energies

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday the administration has continued to push the development of renewable energies in a bid to cut consumption of fossil fuels and reduce Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions.

During a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, Wu said the government has promoted renewable energy development based on three principles -- offering incentives, allowing renewable energy producers to make profits, and ensuring social equality.

Wu was responding to a question from ruling Kuomintang Lee Ching-hua on whether the administration's plans to impose "green" taxes, including energy and carbon taxes, were conceived to raise tax revenues or to conserve energy and reduce green house gas emissions.

The legislator contended that if the KMT administration was an able government, it should provide renewable energy options for people to choose from rather than increasing or levying new taxes to reduce energy consumption.
Meanwhile, Wu reiterated that the government will not begin levying an energy tax without sound planning and said there is no timetable for the measure at present.

The premier said that although the proposed energy tax is commendable and has been implemented in several industrially advanced countries, the time is not ripe yet to adopt it in Taiwan, especially "when the domestic economy has just begun to bottom out from a year-long downturn and the people's lives are still difficult."
Wu assured the public on Monday that a proposed energy tax will not be levied soon.

He said the energy tax, which would be assessed on the consumption of gasoline, diesel, kerosene, aviation fuel, fuel oil, and natural gas, is still on the drawing board, and that if it is imposed, complementary measures will be adopted to ease its sting.
"The fuel consumption fee and other taxes would be dropped, " the premier said.
Amendments to existing laws would also have to be screened and approved by the legislature before the tax could be implemented, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close marginally higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 2.2 points, or 0.02 percent, to close at 7,753.52.
The local bourse opened at 7,808.03 and fluctuated between 7,811.92 and 7,753.52 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.47 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$125.12 billion (US$3.88 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 0.78 percent. Foodstuff issues declined 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks were down 0.45 percent, and banking and financial shares dropped 0.01 percent.

Four other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.28 percent. Textile stocks advanced 1 percent, cement stocks were up 0.95 percent, and machinery and electronics shares rose 0.31 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,401 to 1,120, with 248 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$5.21 billion-worth of shares for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma will not meet China leader unless Taiwan public approves: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct.20 (CNA) 10/20/09 16:41:27 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that President Ma Ying-jeou would meet Chinese Communist Party Chairman Hu Jintao only with the approval of the Taiwan public and in an environment of greater trust between the two sides.

President Ma's guiding principle in cross-Taiwan Strait policy is to safeguard national sovereignty and advance the people's welfare, therefore, such a meeting would only take place amid greater mutual goodwill and trust and if there is consensus among the Taiwan people, Wu said.

Asked by a legislator to explain on President Ma's statement Monday that he would not exclude the possibility of meeting with China's leaders, Wu said the government's cross-strait policies must be implemented at a steady pace over the long term, rather than being rushed or slowed down.

For example, Wu said, if the Taiwan government does not allow some enterprises to set up in China, they may lose their market share. However, enterprises that move to China too soon may lose their bases in Taiwan and hurt the Taiwan economy, he added.
Wu said he cannot project a timetable for any meeting between Ma and Hu, as both sides have to work to build greater trust and goodwill.
In addition, if there is no public consensus on the matter, it would be impossible to talk about a meeting between the two leaders any time soon, he stressed.

President Ma, who assumed chairmanship of his ruling Kuomintang (KMT) last Saturday, told Reuters in an interview Monday that he would not exclude the possibility of meeting Chinese leaders one day. "I won't exclude that possibility, but there's no timetable for that yet," Ma said.
Cross-strait ties, which were strained when the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party was in power from 2000 to 2008, have warmed up since President Ma took office in May 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2010 diary introduces historical figures
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 16:47:02 (By Chou Yung-chien & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Union of Taiwanese Teachers released a 2010 appointment diary on Tuesday that contains articles and photos highlighting significant events in Taiwan's history and people who contributed to Taiwan's democratic, medical and cultural development.

The organization's chairwoman Wu Li-hui said the diary showcases Taiwanese painter Chen Cheng-po (1895-1947), Japanese engineer Hatta Yoichi (1886-1942) , known for his contributions in hydraulic engineering during the Japanese colonial era, and Tu Tsung-ming (1893-1986), Taiwan's first Doctor of Medical Sciences (equivalent to a Ph.D.) and the first Taiwanese to hold a Ph.D. degree.

There are also articles introducing Taiwanese musician Teng Yu-hsien (1902-1944), who composed several well-known Taiwanese folk songs, and James Laidlaw Maxwell Sr. (1836-1921) from Scotland, the first Presbyterian missionary to come to Taiwan and the founder of the island's first western-style hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday:
Apple Daily:
Taiwan a hell for foreign workers

Five Vietnamese caregivers complained at a news conference that they were exploited and ill-treated by their bosses at a nursing home for the elderly where they were employed. They said they were forced to work overtime, were paid only a fraction of what they were promised and were locked in room.
This nursing home has really tarnished Taiwan's image as a country that puts a premium on human rights.
How can a nursing home that is cruel to its foreign workers be kind to the senior citizens in its care?
It is a shame that this has happened in Taiwan.
Liberty Times:
We do not understand what Chairman Ma is talking about

Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou told Reuters that Taiwan is ready to conclude a trade pact with China in hopes of diversifying Taiwan's export market so that it not focused entirely on Europe or the United States.
We really do not understand why Ma would make such remarks. Doesn't he know that China already absorbs 40 percent of Taiwan's exports.
Ma also said that he hopes Taiwan could treat China as a market for its products rather than a factory that manufactures its products for re-export. But is this something Taiwan can do unilaterally?
Based on his remarks, Ma must either be lying or is an idiot.
United Daily News:
Moving forward with cross-strait ties
It is now a well-established view that the disputes between Taiwan and China should be settled by peaceful means.
China has moved from denying the existence of the Republic of China to acknowledging its de-facto identity.
Now both sides should consider the next step, which is acknowledgement of the fact that there is only one China.
However, this one China should be neither the Republic of China nor the People's Republic of China, but something such as a confederate.
Political pundits may dismiss this idea as absurd but they should consider the next step because cross-strait relations cannot remain static forever.
China Times:
How can judiciary which cannot right its own wrongs right others' wrongs?
After an investigation, the Control Yuan has asked the Judicial Yuan to discipline Kinmen District Court president Chao Wen-yuan for sexually harassing female judges.
The Anti-corruption Office of the Judicial Yuan admitted afterward that it had looked into the case last year but found no evidence to support the complaints.
What a pity. The Control Yuan determined the complaints were true while the Judicial Yuan found a lack of evidence.
It seems that the judicial system adheres to the principle that people are innocent until proven guilty only when it probes its own people, motivated by a desire to keep skeletons in the closet.
But how can the justice system maintain its credibility and address the grievances of the people if it cannot address the grievances of its own workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not open fully to Chinese products: BOTF
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 17:04:56 (By Yang Su-min and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: In its negotiations with China on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Taiwan will maintain its stance of not fully opening its market to Chinese goods, despite Beijing's complaints about the restrictions, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOTF) Director-General Huang Chih-peng said Tuesday.

Huang made the remarks one day after China's Ministry of Commerce released a research report on the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait ECFA, which stated that Taiwan's current restrictions on cross-strait trade and investment are hampering the expansion of economic cooperation between the two sides and are unfavorable to the promotion of the ECFA.

Huang said he is not surprised at such reports because there are indeed more than 2,000 items that Taiwan has kept on its restricted list. They include 830 agricultural products and some industrial products, which will remain banned even after the signing of the ECFA, he said.

President Ma Ying-jeou has been pushing for the signing of the ECFA with China in an effort to reduce the impact on Taiwan of the new China-Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) free trade area.

Critics of the proposed pact, however, argue that it will undermine Taiwan's sovereignty and unleash a flood of cheap Chinese imports on the Taiwan market and spur an exodus of capital that will worsen Taiwan's already record high unemployment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Status of Taiwan's beloved goddess Matsu to be raised: premier

TEXT.P: Taiwan's most revered local goddess Matsu (or Mazu) will be given a higher standing as there are plans to designate a day in her honor and include her in National Day celebrations, Premier Wu Deng-yih said Tuesday.

During a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, Wu said he will ask the Ministry of the Interior to study whether the birthday of Matsu -- known as the guardian of fishermen and sailors and the most popular folk deity in Taiwan -- should be included as one of the memorial days in the country.
There are also plans to include the worshipping and culture surrounding the legendary maiden in National Day celebrations in 2011, Wu said.
Quoting President Ma Ying-jeou, Wu said Matsu worshipping originated from China and has been popular in Taiwan's grass-roots communities, particularly townships located near the sea.
It has been fully localized with a strong Taiwanese essence, Wu said.

He was responding to Non-Partisan Solidarity Union Legislator Yen Ching-piao who said that Matsu worshipping has been recently approved as an intangible heritage in need of urgent safeguarding by the UNESCO's intangible heritage committee.
Yen asked whether the government could consider listing Matsu's birthday, March 23 on the lunar calendar, as a memorial day in Taiwan.

Yen, currently chairman of the Taichung-based Jenn Lann Temple, which is one of the pivotal temples in Taiwan for worshipping Matsu, said Matsu worshipping and culture, stemming from fishing communities near China's southeastern coasts more than 1,000 years ago, has been spread around the world, with the number of followers exceeding hundreds of millions.
The annual procession to honor Matsu has been held for over a century in Taiwan and usually starts from Jenn Lann Temple, drawing thousands of followers.
Taiwanese Matsu followers have also regularly made pilgrimages to Meizhou Island of Fujian Province, which has for long been considered the "home" of Matsu.

According to legend, Matsu was a young woman who was born into a fisherman's family in Meizhou, in 960 AD (during the early Northern Song Dynasty). She was deified later for sacrificing her life to save her father and brothers.

Besides Taiwan, she is worshipped in areas of East Asia with a sea faring tradition, including eastern China, especially Zhejiang, Fujian, and Guangdong provinces, as well as in Hong Kong and neighboring areas in Southeast Asia, including Vietnam.
She is also worshipped in places where Chinese people immigrated, including Singapore, and Los Angeles.

Although she was initially believed to just bless the sea for fishermen, as time went by, people prayed to her for good health, a successful career or business, good harvests, and smooth relationships.

DOC.HEADLINE: Artwork loans to Japan will require legal protections: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 18:10:23 (By Lee Chu-hua & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be very pleased to exhibit National Palace Museum (NPM) artworks in Japan if the government there enacts anti-seizure legislation that would grant immunity to artworks from abroad, President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday.
Ma made the comment at the Presidential Office during a meeting with a group of Japanese parliamentarians from Japan's ruling Democratic Party and it major opposition Liberal Democratic Party.

According to the NPM, its collections are national assets protected by strict laws and regulations that allow for overseas exhibitions only in countries that adhere to international legal standards of protecting artworks on loan from abroad against forfeiture.
Many countries have enacted anti-seizure legislation to guarantee immunity for artworks and historic relics on loan from abroad for exhibitions.

Japan and Belgium have both expressed interest in borrowing NPM pieces for exhibitions, but the NPM has said that this would not be possible unless the two countries enact the relevant anti-seizure laws.
Meanwhile, in the meeting with the Japanese dietmen, President Ma reiterated that he will continue to work towards strengthening Taiwan-Japan ties.

Some of the achievements so far include the Taiwan-Japan talks in February on fishery disputes, the launch in June of working holiday tours, and the opening of Taiwan's new representative office in Sapporo, Japan, he noted.
The Taiwan government plans to open a cultural center in Tokyo to promote exchanges between the two sides, he added.
The president also expressed thanks for Japan's generous relief donations for Typhoon Morakot victims in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: H1N1 vaccination to be completed by next February
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 18:18:04 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Free vaccinations against swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1), will be kicked off nationwide on Nov. 1 and completed prior to the 2010 Chinese New Year's Day, which falls on Feb. 14, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) reported Tuesday.

A total of 12 million vials of the vaccine will be used up by that time, with children under the age of 9 receiving a two-dose vaccine to be sourced from the Swiss pharmaceutical firm Novartis and people aged above 9 receiving one dose, the CECC said.
The Novartis vaccine has been proven to be effective for the young and the old in Taiwan as over 70 percent of those tested produced antibodies against the A(H1N1) virus.

"If the vaccine developed by Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's sole human vaccine manufacturer, proves to have the same effectiveness, the Adimmune products will also be distributed in the upcoming vaccination drive, " said Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang.
Taiwan has placed orders with Novartis for a total of 5 million doses. The first batch of 370,000 vials are scheduled to arrive on Oct. 22.
"Some 4 million people are set to benefit from the vaccination drive when all the 5 million Novartis vaccine arrive, " Yaung said.

Meanwhile, according to Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Director-General Steve Kuo, the DOH has purchased a total of 10 million doses of vaccine against the A(H1N1) virus from Adimmune Corp. and delivery is expected to begin at the end of October.
Results of human trials of the Adimmune vaccine, which began on Sept. 23, are expected to be known as early as this week, he added.
The vaccine will be distributed in order of priority, starting with typhoon- affected victims, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, and pregnant women.

They will be followed by pre-school children, seriously ill patients, elementary, junior and senior high school students, individuals in the 19-24 age bracket and those over 25 at high risk of cardiopulmonary disease, healthy people in the 25-49 age bracket, and those between 50 and 64.

Statistics released by the CECC show that the total number of A(H1N1) hospitalized patients in Taiwan since the outbreak began had reached 388 as of late Monday. Of the total, 22 remain in the hospital, 342 have recovered and been discharged, and 24 others have died.

Meanwhile, a total of 536 classes in 316 schools around the country remain suspended because of H1N1 infections among students. The number of affected classes accounted for 0.36 percent of the total, according to the CECC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan would welcome visit by U.S. Cabinet member: foreign ministry

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it would welcome any visits to Taiwan by high level U.S. officials, including Secretary of Veteran Affairs Eric Shinseki, as such visits would serve to increase interaction between Taipei and Washington.
"The Foreign Ministry's stance is that it would be happy to have top-level U.S. officials visit Taiwan and exchange opinions," said James Chang, deputy spokesman of the MOFA.

Tseng Jing-ling, minister of Taiwan's Veteran Affairs Commission, said Monday in the Legislative Yuan that his commission has extended an invitation to Shinseki and that the earliest possible time for him to visit Taiwan would be next spring.

However, Christopher Kavanagh, press officer at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), told the Central News Agency that the AIT is not aware of the invitation and that "no decisions have been made for him (Shinseki) to travel to Taiwan."
There have also been media reports that Taiwan and the U.S. are negotiating on a visit to Taiwan by a high-level U.S. official, believed to be Shinseki.
If Shinseki does visit Taiwan, he will be the first Cabinet member from the U.S. to do so in nearly a decade, and this could signal significant strengthening of Taiwan-U.S. relations.
A visit in 2000 by former U.S. Secretary of Transportation Rodney Slater was the most recent by a U.S. Cabinet member.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan explains its designation for free-trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 19:57:08 (By Liu Cheng-ching & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will handle the issue of naming the economic cooperation agreement which the island hopes to sign with China, Mainland Affairs Council Deputy Chairman Liu Te-shun said Tuesday.
Liu gave the explanation in response to media inquiries about the difference in name given by Taiwan and mainland China for the pact, which Taiwan's government hopes to sign by next year.
Taiwan has called it an "economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) " while China has called it a "cross-strait economic cooperation agreement" without the word framework.
The debates on the designation arose after China's Ministry of Commerce used its name for the accord in the Chinese-language abstract of a research report it released on Monday on the planned accord.

According to Liu, Taiwan's economic affairs ministry is the authority on the subject since it has been promoting the agreement's signing and playing the role of pushing for informal communications with China on the matter.
And officials responsible for economic and trade affairs from the two sides will be the ones responsible for jointly working out the content of the planned agreement, Liu said.
According to an MOEA position paper, the cross-strait agreement, temporarily named ECFA, is a fundamental accord regulating economic cooperation activities between the two sides.

However, the word "framework" is used because the ECFA is only the guideline of a formal agreement, according to the MOEA. Because it must take the two sides a long time to complete the formal pact, the MOEA therefore has proposed signing the "framework agreement" first to resolve urgent problems, the paper said.
A formal agreement can not be decided without cross-strait talks, the paper noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges Japanese law on exhibition of national treasures

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Japan will need to iron out relevant legislation before a proposed exhibition on national treasures from the National Palace Museum (NPM) can take place in Japan.

Ma issued the call while receiving a group of dietmen of the ruling Democratic Party of Japan and the opposition Liberal Democratic Party during a meeting at the Presidential Office, in response to an earlier proposal put forward by Japanese parliamentarians.

"Should Japan be able to iron out such a special law or revise its current regulations to provide a safety guarantee to ensure that Taiwan's priceless national artifacts will be free from judicial seizure while out of the country, Taiwan will be very pleased to allow NPM treasures to be exhibited in Japan, " Ma said.

Prior to the 1990s, pieces from the NPM were rarely displayed in other countries, and loans of items to complement exhibitions in foreign museums were uncommon. The first time such a thing occurred was at the Galeries Nationales du Grand Palais in Paris in 1998.

Many countries are interested in borrowing pieces from the NPM to show in exhibitions in their museums and galleries, but this is only possible for countries in which laws on the guaranteed return of the pieces have been established, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said recently, adding that Taiwan has already enacted such a law.

Over the past decade, priceless NPM art works have been shown in Austria, France, Germany and the United States, which all have the relevant laws in place due to Taiwan's unique political status and concern that should such pieces leave Taiwan, Beijing might otherwise make an ownership claim on them.

To pave the way for an NPM exhibition to be staged in Berlin and Bonn in 2003, for example, Taiwan and Germany clinched an agreement in 2002 after arrangements had been made by both sides in 1998, shortly after the German parliament passed a law regarding the protection of foreign art objects during exhibitions in Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier says alternative Suhua freeway plan ready by March 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 20:05:38 (By Su Lung-chi and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that the Executive Yuan will complete a feasibility study on the construction of an alternative to the dangerous sections of the controversial Suhua freeway on Taiwan's east coast.
The alternative, which will be 20 kilometers long, is expected to be located farther from the planned coastal route of the proposed 86-k m Suhua freeway.
Environmentalists have said the construction of the Suhua freeway, which has 40 kilometers of tunnels, might be dangerous because of proximity to fault lines.

Considering that the substitute freeway could have sensitive geological factors, the government needs to evaluate the project cautiously and then decide whether to build the alternative, Wu said, while responding to questions at the Legislative Yuan.
Wu added that the alternative highway may cost up to tens of billions of Taiwan dollars, so therefore it should be assessed carefully.
However, the evaluation will not last more than two years and a feasibility study is expected to be ready by March 2010, according to Wu.

The disputed Suhua freeway was proposed more than a decade ago to connect eastern Taiwan's Yilan and Hualien counties. It would be a new means of transportation between Suao township and Hualien city, but due to environmental protection issues, this project has been temporarily suspended.
Environmentalists have raised strong objections against the project, saying it could destroy the scenic beauty, as well as flora, fauna and ecological balance of the area along the proposed route.
Proponents of the expressway have argued it will boost the economy of the region in eastern Taiwan, which is relatively undeveloped and consists mostly of farming communities.

Meanwhile, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said in Taoyuan on Tuesday that the construction of northern Taiwan's Wugu-Yangmei viaduct on Freeway No. 1 and the Taoyuan Aerotropolis will both begin in November.

Chu, a former magistrate of Taoyuan county, said the construction of the viaduct from Taipei county's Wugu to Taoyuan county's Yangmei was originally scheduled to take place by the end of 2010, but considering the frequent and heavy traffic jams on the freeway between Taoyuan and Taipei, he has been pushing for the construction to start earlier.
He also said construction of the blue line of Taoyuan international airport's Mass Rapid Transportation(MRT) connecting Gueishan township and Chungli city has been undergoing quickly and smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Removal of missiles will help to build cross-strait trust: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 20:08:10 (By Lee Shu-hua and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Any move by China to either dismantle or remove the missiles it has aimed at Taiwan will be helpful to the establishment of confidence building measures (CBMs) between the two sides, an official with the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday.

"Removal of the missiles by China would involve a sophisticated review of its military system and would be deemed a positive step towards building trust between Taiwan and China, " Lee Hsi-ming, an MND department chief said at a press conference at which Taiwan's 2009 national defense report was released.
President Ma Ying-jeou in an interview Monday with Reuters urged China to scrap the growing number of missiles it has aimed at Taiwan.
"(There are) more than 1,000 (missiles) and they haven't changed that. The number continues to go up. That is certainly a great concern for the people here," Ma told Reuters.

Responding to media questions about the number of missiles that are deployed mostly along China's southeastern coast opposite Taiwan, Colonel Kao Chung-pang of the MND's military information division said that his ministry "knows the exact number of missiles but it cannot make that information public." He did not elaborate further.

David G. Brown, a U.S. expert on China affairs, said in Comparative Connections, a quarterly published by the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), that the number of missiles has grown to 1,500.
Kao said the buildup of missiles is a long-term strategic policy for China and an issue of deep concern among Japan, the United States and other Western countries.
Lee said China will send a goodwill message by acting to either scrap or remove its missiles targeting Taiwan, which would be helpful to establishing cross- strait CBMs.

Saying that the MND will do its best to complete all necessary preparations for the cross-strait CBMs, Lee added that it is currently collecting and studying domestic and foreign reports on CBMs, especially those between China and its neighbors like Russia, India and Kazakhstan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon to lead promotion of Taipei's participation in Shanghai expo

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou will act as an ambassador to promote Taipei's participation in World Expo 2010 Shanghai, an official said Tuesday.

The business group is a sponsor of the Taipei Pavilion that the Taipei City Government will set up at the exhibition. The pavilion is expected to feature the city's ubiquitous wireless Internet access and its garbage and recycling policies.

According to Huang Nan-hui, a consultant of the Hon Hai Education Foundation, Gou decided to provide sponsorship for the city government's participation in the expo because the themes are consistent with Hon Hai's corporate values that emphasize environmental protection and energy conservation.

Gou will also take part in activities to be held by the city government as a warm-up to the exhibition. The activities will include a creativity competition to choose the smile, love letter, logo and image that best represent Taipei, Huang said.
Huang said Hon Hai has hired a renowned art consulting firm to help plan the Taipei Pavilion exhibition and has commissioned an excellent exhibition designer to build the pavilion.
To achieve the goals of environmental protection and energy conservation, the pavilion will be constructed in line with the "3R" principle of reduce, recycle and reuse, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC: Taiwan benefiting from dialogues with China
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 20:30:29 (By Cheng Chi-feng and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday that Taiwan has benefited from its "gradual" dialogues with China.
MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan made the remarks in a speech delivered to students at the National University of Kaohsiung.

For example, Lai said, the number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies has remained at 23 since President Ma Ying-jeou adopted his pragmatic "modus vivendi" approach to diplomacy by seeking not to compete with China over diplomatic allies.

This is in stark contrast to the record of former President Chen Shui-bian, who, during his eight years in office, launched an "all-out fight" against China in the diplomatic arena that resulted in Taiwan losing six of its diplomatic allies to its neighbor on the other side of the Taiwan Strait, according to Lai.

Taiwan has been able to secure its national sovereignty in its dealing with China, evidenced in the fact that neither Taiwan nor China deny either one's existence, which Lai said represents major progress from the past formula of "never recognizing each other's sovereignty."

"We are now able to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA) and other international organizations " without the need to obtain China's approval, as long as China does not actively oppose," Lai said.
In the three rounds of talks held between them since Ma was inaugurated in May last year, Taiwan and China have inked nine agreements to increase cross-strait exchanges.

On a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Lai said such an agreement is essential in order to secure Taiwan's global competitive edge in the face of the formation of free trade groupings among the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and other countries, including China.

Regarding the upcoming next round of cross-strait talks, scheduled to take place in December in Taichung, central Taiwan, Lai said the new round of negotiations will mainly focus on technical aspects related to agriculture, fishery and taxation issues.

Addressing students' concerns over a government plan to allow Taiwanese colleges and universities to recruit students from China, Lai said the incoming Chinese students could serve as a stimulus to help upgrade Taiwan's academic levels, and added that certain areas, such as medicine, will not be open to the Chinese students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Part of Berlin Wall to be inaugurated in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 21:37:49 (By Shih Hsin-yao and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A segment of the Berlin Wall that was presented to Taiwan in July will be inaugurated at the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) headquarters in Taipei Nov. 9, the 20th anniversary of the wall coming down, an official said Tuesday.

The inauguration ceremony will coincide with an exhibition on the themes of democracy and human rights that is being organized by the TFD, the 228 Memorial Foundation and the German Institute Taipei, said Liu Yen-chiu, director of the TFD's Domestic Affairs Department.
The foundation will decide later on how the wall segment is to be used, Liu said.

Karl-Heinz Schroeter, a county executive of Oberhavel, a district to the north of Berlin, promised to offer a segment of the Berlin Wall as a gift to Taipei's 228 Peace Memorial Park during a visit to Germany by 228 Memorial Foundation Chairman Chen Chin-huang in April.
The 3.5 meter-high wall segment was officially presented to Taiwan in a ceremony held in Oberhavel in July.
According to Liu, Chen has requested the TFD to help plan the use of the wall segment in light of the foundation's rich international networks.

Although Germany and Taiwan have no diplomatic relations, the gift is a token of Germany's recognition of Taiwan's democratic achievements and proof that democracy and human rights have no borders, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to lure back foreign investors

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) has suggested that Taiwan carry out overall tax reform and build a sound legal environment so as to lure European investors back to Taiwan, from where they could break into the Chinese market.
Such reform will create a better business climate and will also spur Taiwan to better develop its economy, the ECCT states in its 2009-2010 position papers which will be made public on Oct. 30.

In the annual report, the ECCT recommends that Taiwan slash customs rates and remove trade barriers to strike a balance in bilateral trade and commerce and effectively bolster such activity between Taiwan and the European Union (EU).

The report stresses the importance of EU-Taiwan cooperation and advocates the signing of a mutually beneficial agreement on Trade Enhancement Measures, similar to a free trade agreement, to create more business opportunities.

The ECCT also notes that Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization's Agreement on Government Procurement and the government's efforts to improve cross-Taiwan Strait political and economic ties are moves in the right direction.

This year, a total of 20 ECCT committees have produced position papers that offer suggestions to Taiwan on issues like building a more competitive taxation system, improving the legal system, upgrading infrastructure and offering incentives for green industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: First green industry expo will show Taiwanese innovations to world

TEXT.P: A Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) official said Tuesday that the first Taiwan International Green Industry Show (TiGiS) will serve as a first step to bring Taiwan's innovations to the global market.

Moses Yen, executive director of TAITRA's Exhibition Department, made the remarks at a press conference a day before the show's opening, saying that the exhibition will showcase Taiwan's green solutions and products under the themes of Clean Energy, Green Environment, Water Technology and Eco-life.
"Two messages we would like to convey are that green energy technologies are not unattainable or unaffordable," Yen said.

Organized by TAITRA and the Expo Union Corporation, the 2009 TiGiS is scheduled for Oct. 21-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center and will feature some 150 local and overseas exhibitors, including the American State Offices Association and the Japan External Trade Organization, which will introduce their countries' environmental protection efforts and results.

In order to raise public awareness of and interest in applying green products to their daily lives, a Green Tech Pavilion will be dedicated to innovations such as a carbon dioxide garment dry-cleaning machine, awater free urinal, eco- textiles and paper made from stone.

Also in line with the trend of eco-protection, the show will focus on Taiwanese companies producing fuel cell systems that use hydrogen as the fuel for stationary power generators that can provide virtually continuous electricity and heat with zero emissions of greenhouse gasses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Call for government to help develop fuel cell systems

TEXT.P: Two leading Taiwanese fuel cell companies said Tuesday that fuel cell manufacture is a future "star" green industry in which Taiwan should move now in order to take the lead.
They added that the government will have to play a significant role in providing more incentives and subsidies for the budding industry to develop.

Chung-hsin Electric and Machinery Manufacturing (CHEM) , a mechanical- electrical enterprise, and M-Field Energy Ltd., a manufacturer of back-up power systems, made the remarks ahead of the first Taiwan International Green Industry Show scheduled to open Oct. 21 with the aim of sharing Taiwan's innovations with the global market.

Company representatives told CNA that Taiwan should act now to retain the niche market of fuel cells while the country still enjoys the advantage of producing the products at a lower cost than Japan or Canada, which are also involved in the field.

"Without the government's support, both by investing in production and outlining a sensible subsidy scheme for consumers who opt for fuel cells, individual companies will be fighting a very difficult battle to open markets domestically and overseas, " said Mark Huang, marketing manager of M-Field.

M-Field manufactures MF-UTH-10 to be an eco-friendly solution to replace conventional diesel generators, as it consumes hydrogen from hydrogen cylinders to produce sustainable electricity and heat with water as the only byproduct.

Robert C. Wu, general director of CHEM's Renewable Energy R&D Center, also said the government plays a key role in the success of their product -- 1 kilowatt residential fuel cell combined heat and power (CHP) system that uses natural gas as its fuel source.

According to Wu, the CHEM fuel cell system operates at an efficiency rate of 75 percent-85 percent, compared to traditional power plants, which lose 65 percent of the generated power during transmission.

"The system is the best eco-friendly solution for residential use, as it produces 40 percent less, or 2.7 tons less carbon dioxide per year compared to that generated by conventional coal fired power plants and water heaters," Wu said.

He suggested that the Taiwanese government should model Japan's practice, in which people opting for fuel cell CHP systems pay 1 million yen (US$11,072) toward the cost of the machine, while the Japanese government provides 1.2 million yen in subsidies.
Each household using the fuel cells can then save 60,000 yen per year on electricity and heating, Wu said.
Noting that CHEM's fuel cell CHP systems will cost around the same as the Japanese ones, Wu said his company is looking to partner with Japan's Hitachi next year for production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County promotes leisure agriculture
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Central Taiwan, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 22:24:52 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government held a leisure agriculture tourism fair at the Fun Love Sculpture Park in Taichung City Oct. 17-18 to promote the county's many leisure farms.

According to Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, Changhua is a predominantly agricultural county that offers bright sunshine and pastoral fun, which are essential elements in the lifestyles of health and sustainability (LOHAS) that some modern people are pursuing.
Cho said Changhua is home to the largest number of leisure farms in Taiwan, and he invited the public to visit them to experience their various unique products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Waste water pollution problem in Changhua County greatly improved

TEXT.P: The quality of the irrigation water in Changhua County has been greatly improved since regular inspections of factory wastewater and severe penalties imposed by the authorities have forced electro-plating factories in the region to address their water pollution problems, according to an official of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

Chiang Chu-nung, an EPA inspector in central Taiwan, said that in recent years the EPA has conducted frequent inspections on the over 100 electro-plating factories in the county's coastal region, detecting heavy metals such as cadmium, chromium, nickel, zinc and copper in their wastewater.

Rice paddies and oyster farms polluted by heavy metals from factory wastewater caused major losses to the agricultural sector several years ago when consumers panicked over cadmium-contaminated rice and "green oysters" from the area.
Chiang said, however, that between 2004 and 2008, the qualification rate of irrigation water in the region rose from 33 percent to 73 percent.

Any factory reported to be violating the anti-water pollution regulations will be fined NT$60,000, and if no improvement is made within a certain period, will be fined another NT$60,000, according to Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT revokes memberships of two Central Standing Committee members
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 23:07:19 (By Lee Shu-hua and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: In a bid to demonstrate its determination to carry out party reforms, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) revoked Tuesday the eligibility of two vote-buying members to sit on its decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC).

Juan Kang-meng, chairman of the KMT's disciplinary committee, said Yang Chi- hsiung and Chiang Ta-lung will be removed from the election list of its CSC members because they were found to have distributed gifts to voters during an election of the CSC members Sunday.
The vacancies left by Yang and Chiang will be filled by alternates Lee Te-wei and Tsai Chin-lung.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who took over as the chairman of the ruling party over the weekend, asked in a party meeting earlier in the day for immediate and serious handling of the irregularities.

Juan said that in a meeting later that day, the 11 members of the 16-seat committee who attended the meeting unanimously approved a proposal to expel Yang and Chiang in accordance with party regulations.
Juan said that the committee will continue to investigate whether any other of its members have been involved in similar vote-buying.
Chiang, who denied vote-buying, expressed regret over what he described as "thoughtless" action by the party. Yang was not available for comment.

Also in line with the trend of eco-protection, the show will focus on Taiwanese companies producing fuel cell systems that use hydrogen as the fuel for stationary power generators that can provide virtually continuous electricity and heat with zero emissions of greenhouse gasses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Call for government to help develop fuel cell systems

TEXT.P: Two leading Taiwanese fuel cell companies said Tuesday that fuel cell manufacture is a future "star" green industry in which Taiwan should move now in order to take the lead.
They added that the government will have to play a significant role in providing more incentives and subsidies for the budding industry to develop.

Chung-hsin Electric and Machinery Manufacturing (CHEM) , a mechanical- electrical enterprise, and M-Field Energy Ltd., a manufacturer of back-up power systems, made the remarks ahead of the first Taiwan International Green Industry Show scheduled to open Oct. 21 with the aim of sharing Taiwan's innovations with the global market.

Company representatives told CNA that Taiwan should act now to retain the niche market of fuel cells while the country still enjoys the advantage of producing the products at a lower cost than Japan or Canada, which are also involved in the field.

"Without the government's support, both by investing in production and outlining a sensible subsidy scheme for consumers who opt for fuel cells, individual companies will be fighting a very difficult battle to open markets domestically and overseas, " said Mark Huang, marketing manager of M-Field.

M-Field manufactures MF-UTH-10 to be an eco-friendly solution to replace conventional diesel generators, as it consumes hydrogen from hydrogen cylinders to produce sustainable electricity and heat with water as the only byproduct.

Robert C. Wu, general director of CHEM's Renewable Energy R&D Center, also said the government plays a key role in the success of their product -- 1 kilowatt residential fuel cell combined heat and power (CHP) system that uses natural gas as its fuel source.

According to Wu, the CHEM fuel cell system operates at an efficiency rate of 75 percent-85 percent, compared to traditional power plants, which lose 65 percent of the generated power during transmission.

"The system is the best eco-friendly solution for residential use, as it produces 40 percent less, or 2.7 tons less carbon dioxide per year compared to that generated by conventional coal fired power plants and water heaters," Wu said.

He suggested that the Taiwanese government should model Japan's practice, in which people opting for fuel cell CHP systems pay 1 million yen (US$11,072) toward the cost of the machine, while the Japanese government provides 1.2 million yen in subsidies.
Each household using the fuel cells can then save 60,000 yen per year on electricity and heating, Wu said.
Noting that CHEM's fuel cell CHP systems will cost around the same as the Japanese ones, Wu said his company is looking to partner with Japan's Hitachi next year for production.

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government held a leisure agriculture tourism fair at the Fun Love Sculpture Park in Taichung City Oct. 17-18 to promote the county's many leisure farms.

According to Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, Changhua is a predominantly agricultural county that offers bright sunshine and pastoral fun, which are essential elements in the lifestyles of health and sustainability (LOHAS) that some modern people are pursuing.
Cho said Changhua is home to the largest number of leisure farms in Taiwan, and he invited the public to visit them to experience their various unique products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Waste water pollution problem in Changhua County greatly improved

TEXT.P: The quality of the irrigation water in Changhua County has been greatly improved since regular inspections of factory wastewater and severe penalties imposed by the authorities have forced electro-plating factories in the region to address their water pollution problems, according to an official of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

Chiang Chu-nung, an EPA inspector in central Taiwan, said that in recent years the EPA has conducted frequent inspections on the over 100 electro-plating factories in the county's coastal region, detecting heavy metals such as cadmium, chromium, nickel, zinc and copper in their wastewater.

Rice paddies and oyster farms polluted by heavy metals from factory wastewater caused major losses to the agricultural sector several years ago when consumers panicked over cadmium-contaminated rice and "green oysters" from the area.
Chiang said, however, that between 2004 and 2008, the qualification rate of irrigation water in the region rose from 33 percent to 73 percent.

Any factory reported to be violating the anti-water pollution regulations will be fined NT$60,000, and if no improvement is made within a certain period, will be fined another NT$60,000, according to Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT revokes memberships of two Central Standing Committee members
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/09 23:07:19 (By Lee Shu-hua and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: In a bid to demonstrate its determination to carry out party reforms, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) revoked Tuesday the eligibility of two vote-buying members to sit on its decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC).

Juan Kang-meng, chairman of the KMT's disciplinary committee, said Yang Chi- hsiung and Chiang Ta-lung will be removed from the election list of its CSC members because they were found to have distributed gifts to voters during an election of the CSC members Sunday.
The vacancies left by Yang and Chiang will be filled by alternates Lee Te-wei and Tsai Chin-lung.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who took over as the chairman of the ruling party over the weekend, asked in a party meeting earlier in the day for immediate and serious handling of the irregularities.

Juan said that in a meeting later that day, the 11 members of the 16-seat committee who attended the meeting unanimously approved a proposal to expel Yang and Chiang in accordance with party regulations.
Juan said that the committee will continue to investigate whether any other of its members have been involved in similar vote-buying.
Chiang, who denied vote-buying, expressed regret over what he described as "thoughtless" action by the party. Yang was not available for comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 21, or the fourth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition team are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and that also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award to the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, the Chinese communist's capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Communist Chinese forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1958: John Foster Dulles, U.S. secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to U.S. allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches the HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1973: The fifth general meeting of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations opens in Taipei with more than 400 delegates from 50 countries and areas participating.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation begins production.
1976: Ding Mou-shih, director general of the Government Information Office, returns from a week's visit to the Republic of Korea.
1979: Israeli Prime Minister Moshe Dayan resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from Gen. Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang is to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
1999: Far East Transport Corp. begins flight services between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia.
2000: Chinese Taipei's Chiang Chih-chung breaks the world record in men's Class 12 javelin with a throw of 57.228 meters to capture Taiwan's first gold medal at the Sydney Paralympics.
2001: Asia-Pacific leaders pledge to prevent "all forms of terrorist acts" and to strengthen cooperation to catch those who carry out such crimes in a joint statement after ending a two-day informal leadership summit in Shanghai.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Lupit to bring heavy rains despite missing Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 10:32:27 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Rains are expected in the northern and eastern parts of Taiwan beginning Wednesday night resulting from the peripheral effects of Typhoon Lupit, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
As of Wednesday morning, the storm was moving at 15 kph toward the northern region of the Philippines' Luzon Island, said CWB forecaster Tang Shun-jan.
Although Lupit will not hit Taiwan, its periphery will influence Taiwan's weather starting Wednesday evening, Tang said.
The typhoon's periphery, combined with the northeastern monsoon, will result in heavy rainfall in northern and eastern Taiwan over the next two days, he said.

In particular, Yilan County may experience torrential rain, defined as 24-hour rainfall exceeding 200 millimeters, and Hualien County could see extremely torrential rain, meaning rainfall exceeding 350 millimeters in 24 hours, Tang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority support stricter controls for Chinese banks: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 12:06:30 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Although most people are supportive of opening Taiwan's financial markets to China, they generally think that strict controls should be imposed on financial institutions from China, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
The survey was conducted Oct. 16-18 among 1,084 adults around Taiwan by the TVBS Poll Center for the MAC. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.
The results revealed that 56.1 percent of respondents are in favor of discussions between Taiwan and China on the issue of financial market liberalization.
However, 69.5 percent of respondents said Chinese financial institutions should be subject to stricter controls than those from other countries if they are allowed to set up operations in Taiwan.

Sixty percent of respondents think that the signing of cross-Taiwan Strait memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on financial regulation and supervision will help provide a sound environment for financial exchanges between the two sides.
Also, 53.2 percent of respondents believe the MOUs are favorable to the development of Taiwan's financial sector.

Financial authorities in Taiwan and China have engaged in months of negotiations to pave the way for the establishment of three MOUs for cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in the supervision and regulation of banking, insurance, and securities and futures.
MAC officials said recently that the two sides have achieved significant progress in their discussions, making it likely the agreements will be signed soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday:
LIBERTY TIMES: From Zhang Yuanyuan incident to President Ma's final identification
During a recent military parade in Beijing, a woman soldier named Zhang Yuanyuan said that "to devote myself to the motherland is my biggest wish."

Her words might not be a big deal. But she applied to become a permanent resident of Singapore a few years ago, which has offended Singaporeans because they were not happy to have someone who openly pledged allegiance to China to be a new immigrant.

There are many examples of people like Zhang in Taiwan. Some new immigrants came to Taiwan around 1949 when China was lost to the communists in a civil war. But even though they have lived in Taiwan for most of their lives, they do not treat earlier immigrants as their compatriots, instead identifying with the communist regime.

Zhang's remarks have raised the alarm in Singapore. But Taiwan has not shown the same alarm against the "my heart goes to the motherland" Ma administration. They voted for Ma Ying-jeou in the presidential election even though he still had not given a clear explanation of his possession of a U.S. green card.
Both Taiwan and Singapore are independent, sovereign states, but Singapore is clear on its national identification, while Taiwan is not, and this is why China is able to infiltrate and divide Taiwan.
UNITED DAILY NEWS: Does DPP dare say it doesn't want middle-ground voters?

The disgraced former President Chen Shui-bian asked while being detained who in the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) dares to say that he or she doesn't want ballots from pro-Chen voters, meaning the hard-core green and Taiwan-independence advocates.
But what the DPP should ask itself is "who in the party dares to say that he or she doesn't want ballots from middle-ground voters?"

Middle-ground voters have long been unhappy with the lack of self-examination within the DPP related to the corruption of Chen's aides and confidants and Chen's downgrading of Taiwan independence by contending in legal proceedings that Taiwan actually belongs to the United States.

In the runup to the 2012 presidential election, the DPP has to sort out its discourse on Taiwan independence. During that time, two major things will have taken place: closer cross-strait relations after the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement and the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Republic of China.
The ROC will have been in existence for a century by then, and Taiwan will have lifted martial law rule on the island for 23 years. Will the DPP still want Taiwan independence then?

The relationship between the DPP and Chen is one between the party and Taiwan independence. The relationship between the DPP and Taiwan independence will hinge on the party and the middle-ground voters. If the party wants to preserve the votes of those who support Chen, it cannot count on those in the middle to vote for the party in 2012.
CHINA TIMES:
Planning celebration of ROC's 100th anniversary

The government is reportedly forming an organizing committee for the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Republic of China. But we think the method and content of the celebration are more important.

China recently held a grand military parade to celebrate its 60th founding anniversary. The parade aimed to demonstrate China's status as a "world power" and in a sense reflect national emotions after hundreds of years of being suppressed by foreign powers.
If we use war memories or stances to interprete history, it is bound to evoke different views on such issues as cross-strait relations and unification vs. independence.
However, if we think from the perspective of the people, it will not be hard to forge consensus.
Since Taiwan is a mature democracy, we should organize the celebration based on the concept and perspective of "by the people."

The organizing committee should not dwell too much on power struggles or the transfer of power but rather concern itself with people's lives in delineating and recalling changes over the past 100 years.

Taking medical development as an example, we could contrast world and ROC timelines to track specific diseases, mortality rates, vaccine popularization and when Taiwan and China caught up to East Asian medical standards. The record will illustrate the ROC's progress in the world.
There are many other areas, such as the arts, literature, technology, agriculture, education, transportation, textiles and sports, where similar progress has been made over the past 100 years.
Focusing on the people will show the pluralistic facets of Taiwan and will invite people's enthusiastic participation in the celebrations rather than alienation from them.
APPLE DAILY: (A) Re-election of KMT Central Standing Committee members
Reports of vote-buying were rampant in the recent Kuomintang (KMT) Central Standing Committee election.
But in the end, the ruling party only invalidated the election of two Central Standing Committee members.
President Ma Ying-jeou has always touted his integrity, but despite his return to the helm of the party recently, its election culture is still corrupt.
The two were only stripped of their election victory but did not have their party rights suspended or their party memberships canceled.

Ma's integrity has been compromised. He should not be resigned to such lenient discipline. It would be better to have another election for Central Standing Committee members to serve as a warning to the party and improve Taiwan's election culture. (B) Fickle policy
The government announced Monday that it would levy an energy tax starting in 2011, resulting in a public outcry.

Due to the strong opposition, Premier Wu Den-yih changed his tone, saying there was no timetable for the levying of the tax and that it would wait until the economy recovered and people's lives improved.
Taiwan seems to be modern, but at its core retains the mind-set of a 19th century government that has no regard for the public's feelings.

Green policy involves many issues and requires careful and comprehensive planning as well as public awareness education. Has the government known or done anything about it? It would be better to invite experts from home and abroad to give government officials some cram courses on the issue.
