DOC.HEADLINE: After 5 bus mishaps, foundation calls for safety tracking system

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) should establish a traffic safety tracking system as soon as possible for passengers' well-being, the Consumers' Foundation urged Wednesday.

"Enacting such a system has become urgent after five tragic accidents involving large passenger buses took place in the past few weeks, " said Hsieh Tien-jen, the nongovernmental foundation's chairman.

Initial investigations of the accidents, which left a total of 12 people dead and 36 injured, showed that two were related to driver fatigue and two others were related to driver health, while the fifth resulted from mechanical failure.

With these mishaps still fresh in people's minds, Hsieh said the MOTC could no longer sit idly by and needed to create a safety tracking system that would not only include vehicle maintenance records but also bus drivers' health situations and working conditions.

Hsieh bemoaned the ministry's failure to take precautionary measures after four of the 17 tour buses inspected by the Cabinet-level Consumer Protection Commission in April failed to meet applicable standards.
"The 24 percent failure rate was alarmingly high, " Hsieh said, adding that the MOTC should have taken a cue from such a figure.
Speaking on the same occasion, Huang Yu-sheng, one of the foundation's policy advisers, said the MOTC should enhance information transparency on car rentals.

For instance, he said, operators should be required to provide the vehicle's roll-off date, maintenance records and accident history, and a list of its drivers and travel records from the previous two days.
"All relevant information should be included in car rental contracts," he added.
On the management of passenger buses, Huang said every bus and not just randomly selected vehicles should be inspected.
At present, operators are only required to make available representative vehicles for inspection, along with a document assuring that all other vehicles of the same model are of the same quality.
"The recent spate of accidents involving large buses has proved that this kind of quality control system has gaping black holes that should be plugged soon," Huang said.
He recommended, moreover, that provisional inspection stations should be set up at major tourist spots to facilitate roadside checks.
Wu Chia-cheng, the foundation's secretary-general, said the government should come up with legislation to restrict bus drivers' working hours.
He also suggested that consumers browse the Directorate General of Highway's Web site at www.thb.gov.tw to get more information about vehicles' conditions before renting a tour bus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records 25th death from H1N1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 14:56:22 (By Chen Li-ting, Lin Ssu-yu and and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Health authorities reported Wednesday that a 54-year-old man with underlying conditions has died from influenza A (H1N1), the 25th person in Taiwan to die from the virus.
The patient, a resident of Keelung City, had suffered from hepatitis and kidney disease, according to the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC).
CECC statistics showed that there were seven more patients hospitalized with the H1N1 flu strain than a day earlier, including four children between seven months and seven years old.
The total number of such cases since the outbreak began has reached 395.
While 25 of the patients remained in the hospital, 345 had recovered and been discharged, the CECC said.

As of 4 p.m. Tuesday, 639 classes in 367 schools around the country remained closed because of H1N1 infections among the students. The number of affected classes account for 0.42 percent of the total, according to the CECC.

Wang Chun-chuan, director-general of the Department of Physical Education under the Ministry of Education, said the number of class closures on Tuesday was the highest on record, which could be a sign that the H1N1 outbreak is escalating again after a lull in late September.

The Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health (DOH) recently warned that a second wave of the H1N1 outbreak is emerging in Taiwan and is likely to peak in November, after the previous wave peaked in early September.

In an effort to contain the spread of the new flu strain, the DOH is scheduled to launch a free nationwide inoculation program Nov. 1 that targets selected groups considered at risk of developing serious complications from H1N1 infections.

As the vaccines produced by local vaccine manufacturer Adimmune Corp. are not expected to hit the market until mid-November, vaccines supplied by the Swiss- based pharmaceutical firm Novartis will be used in the first weeks of the program.

Asked by lawmakers during a meeting of the legislature's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee about the performance of the locally produced vaccine, DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said the initial results of human clinical trials show that the Adimmune vaccine is not inferior to that made by Novartis.
Yaung said, however, that detailed results will only be made public after related data are reviewed by a pharmaceutical screening committee under the DOH.

According to Kang Chao-chou, chief of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, the committee is expected to meet Thursday night to review the results, after which the conclusions will be forwarded to the CECC for its reference.
However, a complete report on the protective effect and safety of the vaccine will only be available in mid-November, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals largely up in first nine months

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese nationals visiting Taiwan was largely up in the first nine months of this year, reflecting measures taken by the government last year to facilitate trips to Taiwan by Chinese travelers, National Immigration Agency (NIA) Director General Hsieh Li-kung said Wednesday.
A total of 426,782 Chinese nationals arrived in Taiwan between January and September, far surpassing the 89,256 who visited in the first nine months of 2008, the NIA reported.

Hsieh attributed the increase to several measures adopted by the government, including opening Taiwan's doors wider to Chinese tourists in mid-July last year and launching nonstop daily flights between Taiwan and China.

Speaking at a seminar on border control strategies being held at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Hsieh acknowledged, however, that the travel liberalization and more frequent cross-strait exchanges inevitably has had an impact on national security.

To learn from border control approaches adopted by advanced countries, experts and immigration officials from 22 countries, including Australia, Britain, Canada, Germany, and the Netherlands were invited by the NIA to give speeches on the topic at the seminar.

Speakers from Australia, Britain, Germany and the United States introduced how they were applying new technologies to step up border control efforts, while Canadian and Dutch officials focused on how to crack down on cross-border human trafficking and on their preventive efforts to wipe out document forgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City to film fish fry release to promote marine education

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government has commissioned a video of fish fry being released, to be distributed to students and faculty at schools around the city with the aim of promoting the concept of marine resource conservation, city officials said Wednesday.

As Kaohsiung is a major fishery base, over the past 20 years the city government has been releasing selected species of fry every year into the waters around the city, according to officials of the city's Marine Bureau.
This year, the coral reef areas of Chishan and neighboring regions were selected for the release of some 22,000 orange-spotted groupers, the officials said.

Weather and other conditions will be considered when deciding when to release the fish, the officials went on, adding that for two consecutive years, orange- spotted groupers have been selected for release because of their hardiness and high economic value.
Segments featuring researchers and experts instructing marine bureau officials in how to properly implement the release will also be included in the video.
Copies of the finished DVD will be distributed to 160,000 students and faculty at 139 elementary and high schools in the city, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 52.02 points, or 0.67 percent, to close at 7,701.5.
The local bourse opened at 7,751.75 and fluctuated between 7,774.4 and 7,675.61 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.62 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$124.62 billion (US$3.85 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.57 percent. Banking and financial shares declined 1.38 percent, foodstuff issues were down 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares dropped 0.64 percent, cement stocks fell 0.61 percent, textile stocks lost 0.12 percent, and plastics and chemicals shed 0.03 percent.
Construction shares, the other major stock category, gained ground, moving up 0.46 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,801 to 752, with 203 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$3.28 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Yat-sen doll a top gift choice of Chinese tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct.21 (CNA) 10/21/09 15:53:30 (By Lin Szu-yu and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Because China sees Dr. Sun Yat-sen as a great Chinese revolutionary and political leader, it is not surprising that items bearing his image at National Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall have become highly popular items, especially Sun Yat- sen dolls.

The 10-centimeter-tall figurine has been the most popular item among Chinese tourists at the facility's gift shop, said Cheng Nai-wen, the director of the memorial hall, following a legislative committee meeting.

Cheng estimated that the gift shop, which was reopened Oct. 5 after the hall contracted the Taiwan Handicraft Promotion Center to run it, could generate NT$2.76 million (US$85,235) annually in rights fees.

In addition to the Sun Yat-sen dolls, which sell for NT$300 each, Chinese tourists also like to buy documentary videos on the family of the late Kuomintang (KMT) leader Chiang Kai-shek, stamps, Taiwan dollar bills, commemorative coins and flags, Cheng said.
"Mainland tourists often get excited when they see the figurines, " said gift shop manager Christine Chu, "And usually they don't just buy one doll."

The souvenir shop also sells figurines of Chiang, his wife, and his son Chiang Ching-kuo, communist Chinese figures such as Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping, and more recent figures such as President Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President Vincent Siew, Chu added.
She also noted that the Sun Yat-sen stamp collection, sold exclusively at the memorial hall for NT$500, has been very popular among Chinese tourists since it was launched a year ago.

Cheng said the number of Chinese tourists visiting the facility has been steady in recent months at about 1,000 per day, down from the peak in April and May when 2,000-3,000 Chinese nationals visited the memorial hall.
Sun Yat-sen is frequently referred to as the Father of the Nation as he played an instrumental role in overthrowing the Qing Dynasty in 1911.
He was the first provisional president when the Republic of China (ROC) was founded in 1912 and later co-founded the Chinese Nationalist Party, or KMT, in which he served as its first leader.
Sun remains unique among 20th-century Chinese politicians for being widely revered in both China and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. state governor calls for cooperation on renewable energy

TEXT.P: Kansas Governor Mark Parkinson said Wednesday in Taipei that Taiwan and the United States should cooperate on renewable energy development, particularly in wind and solar power, as it would serve the interests of both countries.

Parkinson made the remarks in a meeting with local media after presiding over the opening ceremony of the first Taiwan International Green Industry Show, saying that he hoped his trip would create opportunities for Taiwan and Kansas to work on developing wind power, as both have significant wind resources.
"We are working toward developing wind power as a major source of electricity, so we are hopeful that we can develop some relationships there as well," Parkinson said.

Parkinson noted that wind power development in Kansas has grown significantly over the past decade from two megawatts to 1,000 megawatts today, constituting 10 percent of the state's 10,000 megawatts of electrical capacity.

The experience can serve as an example for Taiwan, which has a similar goal as Kansas in that it wants to have 10 percent of its power generated from renewable energy sources by 2010 and 20 percent by 2020, he said.
The U.S. governor also suggested that Taiwan's engineers and researchers should work on improving the storage of electricity, an area in which the U.S. is being left behind.
"If someone can make a breakthrough in battery storage, that will revolutionize the use of wind power, making it much more prominent across the world," Parkinson said.

Another area in which both sides can work is solar power, Parkinson went on, noting that the use of solar power is very limited in Kansas, while many Taiwanese companies have leading technologies in the area.

Parkinson said he is looking forward to doing business with Taiwanese companies seeking to supply solar panels to Kansas, as well as Taiwanese companies seeking to establish production facilities in the state.

Any company that employs more than 200 people and works on renewable energy is eligible for significant tax incentives in Kansas, an offer that would also apply to Taiwanese companies there, he added.

Scheduled to leave Taiwan Oct. 25, Parkinson is visiting the country to mark 20 years of sister state relations between Taiwan and Kansas and to introduce the green industry opportunities in his state.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.084 to close at NT$32.359.
A total of US$1.14 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.375 and fluctuated between NT$32.300 and NT$32.412.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH chief hails results of local vaccine human clinical trials

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang hailed Wednesday at the Legislative Yuan the mid-term results of human clinical testing of H1N1 vaccine produced by Adimmune Corp, Taiwan's sole human vaccine manufacturer.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the legislature's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee about the locally produced vaccine, Yaung said the Adimmune vaccine is in no way inferior to an H1N1 vaccine marketed by the Swiss-based pharmaceutical firm Novartis.

Stressing that the initial results have been good, Yaung said, however, that the final results will be made public in two days, after related data has been collated by a DOH pharmaceutical screening committee.

According to Kang Chao-chou, chief of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, the screening committee was scheduled to meet the following day to review the mid-term results. The relevant data will be published after being confirmed by the committee and conclusions will be submitted to the Centers for Disease Control for reference.
A complete report on the efficacy and safety of the Adimmune vaccine is expected to be available in mid-November, Kang said.

Meanwhile, Ho Mei-shiang, head of Adimmune's R&D department, told reporters that the immunity effect of the swine flu vaccine is marvelous, as had been expected, and she urged the public not to be worried about any ill-effects.

According to Ho, the immunity effect of foreign-made H1N1 vaccines can reach 70 percent, while the mid-term results of the Adimmune vaccine's adult clinical trials show that the local vaccine will not be any lower than that.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition to feature over 2,000 samples of Taiwanese alcoholic drinks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 17:46:24 (By Lee Hsi-chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Folklore Museum (TFM) in Taichung City, central Taiwan, will launch a unique exhibition Saturday, displaying more than 2,000 containers of locally produced alcoholic drinks, including the oldest liquor found in Taiwan so far.

The Taiwan Exposition of Alcoholic Drinks, to be held in celebration of the traditional Double Ninth Festival on the ninth day of the ninth lunar month, will trace the history of Taiwanese wine, liquor and beer, TFM Director Chu Chieh-yang said Wednesday.
The exhibits will include Pai Lu liquor produced in 1941 during the era of Japanese occupation. It is the oldest Taiwanese alcoholic drink that local collectors have found so far, Chu said.
Also on display will be a 1946 whiskey that was the first alcoholic drink to be distilled by the Taiwan Provincial Monopoly Bureau after the island was claimed by the Republic of China government.

The most expensive local alcoholic drink at the exhibition will be a premium Gaoliang liquor stored in a hand-painted porcelain jar, Chu said. It was brewed at the Chiayi Distillery of the state-run Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp and is valued at NT$200,000 (US$6,180) per bottle, he added.

More than 70 people have loaned their collections to the museum for the exhibition, which will showcase alcoholic drinks produced in the Japanese era, the period after the Republic of China government took over Taiwan in 1945, and the period after the monopoly on liquor was lifted in 2001.
The exhibition, which will run through Jan. 9, 2010, will include workshops on investment in and collection of Taiwanese alcoholic beverages.
During the Double Ninth Festival, it is customary for people to hike up a mountain and drink wine or liquor. It is also an occasion for honoring seniors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Denying access to Uighur activist not a democracy issue: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 17:56:08 (By Lee Chia-fei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government's recent decision to ban a planned visit by Uighur activist Rebiya Kadeer had nothing to do with the issue of whether Taiwan is a democratic country, a Presidential Office spokesman said Wednesday.
Taiwan was exercising its sovereignty by making such a decision based on its national interests, according to spokesman Wang Yu-chi.

Wang made the statement after Kadeer, in an interview conducted in Tokyo with the Taiwan-based Liberty Times, described the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou as "undemocratic" for turning down her proposed visit.
In September, Kadeer accepted an invitation for her to visit Taiwan in December, which was extended by several Taiwanese pro-independence groups.

Although Kadeer had not filed her visa application with the Taiwanese authorities, the Cabinet decided on Sept. 25 that she should not be permitted to visit on grounds that the World Uyghur Congress, of which Kadeer is president, alleging that the group is closely associated with a terrorist group.
Wang argued that it is unfair to call Taiwan "undemocratic" just because Kadeer was denied access to the country.

According to Wang, the fact that "The 10 Conditions of Love, " a documentary about the Kadeer's life, has been shown in Taiwan despite China's protest demonstrates that Kadeer's freedom of speech is being protected in Taiwan.
Also, the fact that Kadeer's criticism of the head of state and the government of Taiwan is allowed to be published in a local newspaper is evidence of Taiwan's democracy, he said.

He noted that not all individuals unwelcomed by China have been forbidden from visiting Taiwan. The Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, for example, was allowed entry despite Beijing's opposition, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shoe designer to share U.K. creative industry development experience

TEXT.P: World acclaimed shoe designer Jimmy Choo will speak at this year's Education U.K. Autumn Exhibition on his career in fashion and will share his experience of the creative industry development in the United Kingdom, the British Council Taipei said Wednesday.

According to a statement released by the council, Choo will host two seminars at the fair Oct. 24 and Oct. 25, with topics including why and how he built up his career as a shoe designer, advice for students who are inspired to work in design and fashion, and the experience of studying and living in the U.K.

Born in Penang, Malaysia into a family of shoemakers, Choo founded Jimmy Choo Ltd. in 1996 with Tamara Mellon, an editor for Vogue magazine, and become one of the world's most renowned shoe designers. Celebrity and royal patronage further boosted his image and in 2001, he sold his 50 percent stake in the company to concentrate on his exclusive Jimmy Choo Couture line.

In addition to Choo's seminars, the fair will also have a Creative U.K. area that will feature a mini-exhibition of the Jimmy Choo Couture shoe collection, classic Wedgewood tableware, and design works from U.K. alumni, according to the British Council statement.
"It is a great opportunity to enjoy the whole ranges of creativity from established U.K. brands, contemporary masterpieces to works from emerging designers," the statement said.

The Education U.K. Autumn Exhibition, which runs from Oct. 24-28, will also be held in Taichung and Kaohsiung, with representatives from British universities and schools taking part in the exhibition, according to the statement.

Visitors to the fair will not only have the chance to meet U.K. school delegates face-to-face and enjoy one-stop shopping for all the latest information about studying and living in Britain, but also a chance to win a Wedgewood tea set, a free trip to the U.K. and other prizes, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Press exchanges not on agenda of 4th round of cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 18:25:45 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The issue of press exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will not be on the agenda of an upcoming fourth round of cross-strait talks, but Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) officials said Wednesday that when the time is ripe, such discussions will be started.

The fourth round of talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is slated to take place in the central Taiwan city of Taichung sometime in the second half of December.

According to the SEF -- the semi-official intermediary body founded to deal with cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links -- Chiang has been authorized by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council to talk about four major issues: a safety check and quality certification system for agricultural products; moves to prevent double taxation; cooperation on fishery manpower affairs; and cooperation on the promotion of standard product quality checking and certification.
All of these are problems that have emerged in the course of the increasingly close trade and economic exchanges between the two sides, SEF officials said.

In the future and at an appropriate time, the two sides will also consider talks on the formation of a two-way investment guarantee agreement and a currency clearing mechanism, intellectual property rights protection, the establishment of a mechanism to handle economic and trade disputes, and cooperation and exchanges in the fields of media, culture and education, they added.

Addressing the issue of a widely anticipated proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, the officials said Chiang and Chen might bring the topic up during the Taichung talks, but will not sign an agreement at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's NSC chief accuses DPP legislative whip of slander
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 18:43:19 (By Lin Chang-shu & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: National Security Council (NSC) Secretary General Su Chi on Wednesday accused opposition Legislator Chai Trong-Rong of slander for alleging that Su had provided oceanographic data about Taiwan to China.

Lai Su-ju, Su's attorney, on Wednesday filed a complaint against Chai with the Taipei District Prosecutors Office. She said that Su will also launch a civil suit against Chai, asking Chai to pay NT$3 million in compensation, and to carry half-page notices of apology on the United Daily News, the China Times, the Liberty Times and the Apple Daily, for infringing upon Su's rights.

Chai, who is Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) whip at the Legislative Yuan, claimed several days ago that Su had been suspected of leaking national secrets by instructing the Ministry of the Interior to pass the oceanographic data on Taiwan to "its counterpart under China's State Council".

The DPP legislative caucus also said that it would not rule out the possibility of charging President Ma Ying-jeou, who concurrently serves as NSC chairman, of "offence of interference with relations with other states."
Presidential spokesman Wang Yu-chi on Oct. 19 rejected Chai's allegation as "totally groundless" and said the Presidential Office will consider filing a lawsuit against Chai.
The NSC in a press release Tuesday said that it will sue Chai for his untrue accusations unless he apologizes within 24 hours upon receiving a legal letter requesting rectification of a problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma vows to carry out KMT party reforms

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou vowed Wednesday to carry out a series of reforms to pursue the goals of "an excellent ruling party and a powerful and efficient government."
Ma made the remarks while chairing a meeting of the Kuomintang's decision-making Central Standing Committee, the first since he took over as chairman of the ruling party last weekend.
Saying the end of the KMT's national congress on Oct. 17 marked the beginning of "accelerated reforms," President Ma apprised party members of his expectations with regard to party reforms.
To achieve excellence, he said, the KMT must uphold justice, be clean and well- disciplined and always keep the people in mind.
He said that the KMT has to transform itself into an "action party" so as to enhance its cooperative relations with Premier Wu Den-yih's Cabinet, which Ma has described as an " action Cabinet."
"We should let public come to understand that the KMT is a party capable of self-reflection and of being responsible and is determined to push for reforms," Ma said.
During the meeting, Ma awarded certificates to CSC members and vice chairmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-built unmanned aerial vehicle completes maiden flight

TEXT.P: An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) developed by National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) successfully completed its maiden flight, which was a new milestone in Taiwan's progress in the field, academic sources said Wednesday.

The unmanned aircraft, dubbed Spoonbill UAV, successfully flew 92 kilometers from Taiwan proper to the outlying island of Penghu Tuesday on what was the first flight of its kind across the Taiwan Strait, NCKU said in a press statement.

NUKU President Michael M.C. Lai, also an Academia Sinica scholar, was quoted in the statement as saying that the unprecedented flight was not only an achievement for the university but was also "Taiwan's pride."
"It is also an important achievement in Asia, " Lai said, adding that NCKU's UAV technology is the "cream of Taiwan" and also the "best of Asia."
The NCKU research team arrived with the 30-kg aircraft early Wednesday morning at an airstrip it had constructed on a salt flat in Cigu, Tainan County in southwestern Taiwan to carry out the test.
The team then installed the antenna and activated the mainframe computer in preparation for the test.
The Spoonbill UAV took off at 9: 20 a.m. under manual remote control, flying at 100 kph at an altitude of 300 meters toward Penghu's Dongji island.
Ten minutes after takeoff it was beyond the team's field of vision and it switched to automatic control.
For about 30 minutes or so the team lost computer contact with the aircraft and there was some anxiety over the success of the test.

However, at around 10 a.m., the mainframe computer began receiving information from the aircraft again and the research team piloted the aircraft by remote control to a landing at 10: 17 a.m. on Dongji islet, completing the 52-minute historic flight.
The NCKU's Remotely Piloted Vehicle & Micro Satellite Research Laboratory (RMRL) built the Spoonbill UAV in April this year after 20 years of research and development.
The aircraft measures 2.2 meters long, 3.7 meters wide and 0.9 meter high.
In 2005, the team also completed a successful 16-km test flight of its Swan UAV from Donggang in Pingtung County to the offshore Siaoliuchiu. The vehicle was much smaller than the Spoonbill.

According to Hsiao, a complete UAV should operate with the use of two major systems -- on board systems and a ground station that allows researchers to control the aerial vehicle's movement and monitor the video images transmitted by the onboard camera.

Hsiao said an UAV developed by Australian researchers more than a decade ago was able to fly more than 1,000 kilometers, but the vehicle was not equipped with an automatic flight system, onboard camera, a video transmitter or GPS aviation system. "That vehicle lagged far behind the Spoonbill in terms of technology," he added.

The Spoonbill's onboard systems include wireless module for wireless data link between the aircraft and the ground control station (GCS) ; onboard surveillance camera that takes aerial videos/images; and video transmitter that transmit onboard video to the GCS in real time.
Hsiao said that 80 percent of the Spoonbill's parts and components were made in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese goddess Matsu's ascension to heaven celebrated

TEXT.P: Central Taiwan's Changhua County last week held a ceremony to celebrate the anniversary of the believed ascension to heaven of the island's beloved goddess Matsu, known as the protector of fishermen.

The ceremony was part of the 2009 Matsu round-Changhua County blessing procession organized by the county government to honor the widely-worshipped goddess, and to promote the development of cultural and tourism business in the county.
Eleven local Matsu temples joined the 12-day procession which took place from Oct. 5-16.

County Magistrate Cho Po-Yuan, who presided over the religious ceremony at the county's Fuhai Temple, expressed hope that the annual joint procession of Matsu statues enshrined at the temples, which was first held in 2008, will continue next year and in following years to become one of the county's cultural features.
He also reiterated the local government's determination to safeguard the rights and benefits of local fishermen, farmers and breeders of fish and livestock.

The religious event was attended by many folk arts performing troupes and groups of sedan carriers. Their festive performances and unique ways of guarding the goddess during the procession drew hundreds of spectators, county officials said.

According to legend, Matsu was born into a fisherman's family in Meizhou, southern China's Fujian province in 960 AD (during the early Northern Song Dynasty) . She was deified later for sacrificing her life to save her father and brothers, who were fishermen.

Although she was initially believed to just bless the sea for fishermen, as time went by, people prayed to her for good health, a successful career or business, good harvests, and smooth relationships.
The date of Matsu's ascension to heaven is said to be on the ninth day of the ninth lunar month, according to legend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will be firm on stance toward ECFA: economics minister

TEXT.P: Taiwan will stand firm when negotiating with China on a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) by seeking to exclude the import of Chinese labor, agricultural products and some industrial goods from the pact, Minister of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Shih Yen-shiang said Wednesday.

"We will do everything possible to prevent the imports of Chinese workers as well as China's 830 agricultural products and more than 1,000 industrial items from being included in the accord, " Shih said when responding to lawmakers' questions during a committee meeting of the Legislative Yuan.
Citing the latest statistics compiled by China's Ministry of Commerce, Legislator Su Chen-ching said China will benefit four times more than Taiwan if the two sides clinch such an agreement.
He accused the government of seeking to sign what he called "an unfair and humiliating pact."

But Shih refuted Su's argument, saying China's figures were assessed based on an assumption of a full market opening by Taiwan. Shih added that his ministry has worked out countermeasures to deal with the impact from China once an ECFA is signed.

According to the report by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, a Taiwan-China ECFA will help China realize a 0.63 percent increase in its GDP (gross domestic product) , or US$27 billion in value, while Taiwan will enjoy a 1.72 percent growth in GDP, worth about US$6.9 billion.

Critics of the economic agreement, which is similar to a free-trade agreement, have said it will flood Taiwan with cheaper Chinese products and threaten Taiwan's industries, putting many people out of work.

Proponents of the agreement, including President Ma Ying-jeou, have insisted the agreement is necessary in order to help Taiwan maintain its competitiveness, as China is planning to sign similar trade pacts with other countries in East and Southeast Asia, which would allow those countries to import items to China tariff-free.

In another matter, Shih reiterated that the government will not levy an energy tax unless the economy recovers, echoing Premier Wu Den-yih's remarks in response to a controversy arising from the planned tax.
Wu said a day earlier that there would be no timetable for the proposed tax, which is expected to double the price of gasoline products.

DOC.HEADLINE: University evaluation council launches college search engine

TEXT.P: The Higher Education Evaluation and Accreditation Council (HEEACT) of Taiwan on Wednesday launched a personalized college search engine "College Navigator in Taiwan, " which allows students to select the most suitable schools for them from a list of 69 four-year comprehensive colleges and universities.

HEEACT President C. Y. Chen announced the launch of the Web-based interactive process, which took the council two years to develop. Experts from Germany, France, the United States, Britain, Canada, and Spain, as well as Taiwanese academicians, contributed to the effort.
Chen said that the system uses a step by step process that allows users to pick schools using 11 criteria, 24 academic indicators and 16 general information data points.

The general information includes history, enrollment, number of programs and Web sites, student service, scholarships and tuition. The criteria cover academic survey, student selectivity, student demographics, faculty, library acquisitions, research output, teaching quality, international outlook and graduation rate.

Indicators reflect enrollment rate, proportion of graduate students, graduation rate, proportion of faculty members above the position of assistant professors, proportion of professors with advanced degrees, proportion of full-time faculty, faculty-student ratio, total expenditure per student, number of articles published, National Science Foundation grants per faculty, proportion of international students, proportion of international faculty and library expenditure per student.

Chen pointed out that all data was collected through academic surveys, government databases, and directly from the 69 institutions. Users can also select prospective schools by region, type, size and programs, according to Chen.

HEEACT was founded in 2005 under the initiative of the Ministry of Education (MOE). With an aim to conduct MOE commissioned higher education evaluation and accreditation, the council was formed with funding from all universities and colleges in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2010 Taiwan International Festival to wow audiences: organizers

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taiwan International Festival (TIF) will feature 15 productions from nine countries which aim to amaze enthusiasts of performing arts and music in Taiwan, the National Theater and Concert Hall (NTCH) said Wednesday,

A total of 45 performances will be featured, with performance companies coming from Spain, Denmark, Germany, France, Austria, Columbia, the United States and the United Kingdom, in addition to Taiwan.
Six of the programs will be world premieres while another six will be Asian premieres.

"You will be able to witness the avant-garde works from Europe and reinvented Taiwanese traditional art, as well as original productions that feature 'indigenous fashion' spirit," a statement on the NTCH's website said. "These wonderful works represent the integration of artists from Taiwan and all over the world."
This year's program aims to present the diverse cultures in Taiwan and countries around the world, while emphasizing environmental issues, such as global warming and pollution in the ocean.
Organizers said the 2010 TIF will try to broaden audience members' perspectives on the arts, by offering performances by innovative groups and artists.

World-famous composer Tan Dun will unveil "Crouching Tiger Double Concerto" a symphony orchestra version of his Oscar-winning score for the movie "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon". The orchestra version will feature both oriental and occidental instruments.

The concert will also feature Tan's first internet symphony "Eroica," a piece originally written for the YouTube network symphony project and performed by musicians from all over the world gathered by YouTube in New York.
His other piece "Earth Concerto-A Dialogue with Gustav Mahler" is considered unique for its combination of sounds created with organic objects and the ceramics from YiXin, China and Ying Ge, Taiwan.
Lin Hwai-min, the founder and director of Taiwan's internationally renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theater, will present his new work "Listening to the River," which was inspired by Taipei's Tamshui river.
Also on the program are performances by the Taiwanese performance group Xin Xin Nanguan, which will reinvent the emotional and poetic ancient Nanguan music with poems written in the Song Dynasty.

Taiwan-born Lin Mei Hong, the artistic director of Germany's Tanztheater des Staatstheaters Darmstadt dance troupe, will premiere her new work "Violett, Lila, PurPur," a combination of Taiwanese music and literature presented in dance theatre format.

The organizer has also arranged a few programs in line with the global trend of environmental protection and preservation of marine ecology, such as "Sirena a la Plancha", a dance about a story of impossible love involving a woman who transfigures into a mermaid in order to save the world but is caught by fishermen and later seduced by a giant. The dance is staged by Sol Pico, a modern dance company from Spain.

Other highlights include an avant-garde adaptation of Shakespeare's "Hamlet" by German director Thomas Ostermeier and French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj, and "Drum Beat, Heart Beat!, " a performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 1 by the National Symphony Orchestra, in collaboration with Taiwanese conductor Lu Shao- chia and Martin Grubinger, a percussionist from Austria.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT Central Standing Committee will meet around the island: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, announced Wednesday an unconventional move to have the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) hold meetings around the island as a strategy to mobilize grassroots support.
The president said that as the elections for city mayor and county magistrates are only about 40 days away, the KMT would demonstrate its flexibility as a "mobilized party."

He has instructed that the CSC hold meetings in five counties, namely Yilan and Hsinchu in the northern Taiwan, Nantou in the central region, and Chiayi and Pingtung in the south, in the coming weeks, to hear grassroots opinions and to lend support to the KMT candidates' campaigns.
The five counties were chosen because a tug of war is expected between the KMT candidates and their opponents there, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 22, 2009

TEXT.P: Institute in Taiwan, meets the press
Date and Time: 11:00 a.m., Thursday, Oct. 22, 2009
Place: American Culture Center, Taipei 2. Event: Report on unemployment rate
Date and Time: 4:00 p.m., Thursday, Oct. 22, 2009
Place: Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-profile Taiwanese media group to visit China

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with China will lead a high-profile Taiwanese media delegation to visit China Oct. 28, a Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) official said Wednesday.

"SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung will head the delegation of senior executives from 15 mainstream local media organizations on a five-day visit from Oct.28," said SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shao-chang.

The group will spend most of its time in Beijing, visiting China's major state- controlled media organs, such as China Central Television (CCTV), Xinhua News Agency and People's Daily, and meeting with their management personnel, Ma said.
The delegation will also hold informal meetings with China's State Council officials in charge of media affairs and with representatives of major Chinese news media.

Before wrapping up its visit, the group will travel to Shanxi to see historic and cultural relics there, particularly the renowned Pingyao Old City -- a well- preserved ancient city that has a grand city wall, residences and shops, and even government offices all in the style of the Ming (1368-1644) and Qing (1644-1911) dynasties. DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA can create over 105,000 job opportunities in Taiwan: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/09 23:21:55 ( By Chen Shun-hsieh, Yang Shu-min & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: In a best-case senario, the proposed cross-strait economic agreement would create 105,000 to 125,000 job opportunities in Taiwan, according to a report released Wednesday.

Prof. Lin Kuo-jung, director of International Trade at the Chihlee Institute of Technology that was commissioned by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to conduct the study, weighed the impact on Taiwan if the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is signed and if it is not.

Adopting the global trade analysis project (GTAP) model, Lin based his research on four scenarios -- the formation of a free trade grouping among the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and China, South Korea and Japan (ASEAN +three) without the ECFA; an ASEAN + three grouping with both Taiwan and China denied access to each other's agricultural markets; an ASEAN + three grouping with China opening its agricultural market and Taiwan's remaining closed; and an ASEAN + three grouping with both Taiwan and China adopting an open market policy.

Under the third scenario, which Lin described as the most favorable to Taiwan, the island's gross domestic product (GDP) would grow by 0.754 percent and the number of job opportunities would increase by 125,000, according to the report.
Among the various sectors, the services industry and the high-tech industry will benefit most from a cross-strait ECFA, the study showed.
However, if the ECFA is not signed, Taiwan will see its GDP drop by 0.179 percent and an additional 47,000 people would become jobless, the report stated.
In this case, the most serious loss of jobs would occur in the garment, metal and sports gear, and stationery and daily necessity industries, according to the report.
Under the second and fourth senarios, Taiwan would see a GDP growth of 0.7 percent and an increase of 100,000 job opportunities, the study showed.

Taiwan and China are expected to discuss the ECFA issue in the upcoming talks between the two sides in December before they formally ink such an agreement, which aims to liberalize cross-strait trade and exchanges.
The figures forecast by the CLA, however, were conservative compared to those in a similar research report unveiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) July 29.

The MOEA research, conducted by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER), put Taiwan's annual GDP growth at 1.72 percent and the increase in jobs at between 257,000 and 263,000 if the ECFA is signed.

Director Huang Zhi-peng of the MOEA's Foreign Trade Bureau, attributed the differences in the forecasts to the methods used by the Chihlee Institute of Technology and CIER to gauge the ECFA's impacts on Taiwan's economy.
CIER applied a dynamic GTAP model in its research, while the Chohlee institute adopted a static one, Huang said.
"If CIER had used the static method, it would have forecast an increase in job opportunities of around 130,000, a figure not far from that projected by the Chihlee institute," Huang explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2010 Taiwan International Festival to wow audiences: organizers

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taiwan International Festival (TIF) will feature 15 productions from nine countries which aim to amaze enthusiasts of performing arts and music in Taiwan, the National Theater and Concert Hall (NTCH) said Wednesday,

A total of 45 performances will be featured, with performance companies coming from Spain, Denmark, Germany, France, Austria, Columbia, the United States and the United Kingdom, in addition to Taiwan.
Six of the programs will be world premieres while another six will be Asian premieres.

"You will be able to witness the avant-garde works from Europe and reinvented Taiwanese traditional art, as well as original productions that feature 'indigenous fashion' spirit," a statement on the NTCH's website said. "These wonderful works represent the integration of artists from Taiwan and all over the world."
This year's program aims to present the diverse cultures in Taiwan and countries around the world, while emphasizing environmental issues, such as global warming and pollution in the ocean.
Organizers said the 2010 TIF will try to broaden audience members' perspectives on the arts, by offering performances by innovative groups and artists.

World-famous composer Tan Dun will unveil "Crouching Tiger Double Concerto" a symphony orchestra version of his Oscar-winning score for the movie "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon". The orchestra version will feature both oriental and occidental instruments.

The concert will also feature Tan's first internet symphony "Eroica," a piece originally written for the YouTube network symphony project and performed by musicians from all over the world gathered by YouTube in New York.
His other piece "Earth Concerto-A Dialogue with Gustav Mahler" is considered unique for its combination of sounds created with organic objects and the ceramics from YiXin, China and Ying Ge, Taiwan.
Lin Hwai-min, the founder and director of Taiwan's internationally renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theater, will present his new work "Listening to the River," which was inspired by Taipei's Tamshui river.
Also on the program are performances by the Taiwanese performance group Xin Xin Nanguan, which will reinvent the emotional and poetic ancient Nanguan music with poems written in the Song Dynasty.

Taiwan-born Lin Mei Hong, the artistic director of Germany's Tanztheater des Staatstheaters Darmstadt dance troupe, will premiere her new work "Violett, Lila, PurPur," a combination of Taiwanese music and literature presented in dance theatre format.

The organizer has also arranged a few programs in line with the global trend of environmental protection and preservation of marine ecology, such as "Sirena a la Plancha", a dance about a story of impossible love involving a woman who transfigures into a mermaid in order to save the world but is caught by fishermen and later seduced by a giant. The dance is staged by Sol Pico, a modern dance company from Spain.

Other highlights include an avant-garde adaptation of Shakespeare's "Hamlet" by German director Thomas Ostermeier and French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj, and "Drum Beat, Heart Beat!, " a performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 1 by the National Symphony Orchestra, in collaboration with Taiwanese conductor Lu Shao- chia and Martin Grubinger, a percussionist from Austria.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT Central Standing Committee will meet around the island: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, announced Wednesday an unconventional move to have the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) hold meetings around the island as a strategy to mobilize grassroots support.
The president said that as the elections for city mayor and county magistrates are only about 40 days away, the KMT would demonstrate its flexibility as a "mobilized party."

He has instructed that the CSC hold meetings in five counties, namely Yilan and Hsinchu in the northern Taiwan, Nantou in the central region, and Chiayi and Pingtung in the south, in the coming weeks, to hear grassroots opinions and to lend support to the KMT candidates' campaigns.
The five counties were chosen because a tug of war is expected between the KMT candidates and their opponents there, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 22, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek on Sept. 14 urged 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching being elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung being elected chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove the missiles.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and in 1962 had been sentenced to 42 years in prison, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Zedong successor.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. and injured more than 320 people.
2000: Industrial sources say that Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market.
2001: After years of preparations, a group of scholars, social workers and medical specialists form the "Taiwan Health Reform Foundation" to monitor the operations of the nation's medical system.
2001: Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), urges the public during a video shot for an ad to put their love of Taiwan into action by joining volunteer services.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor pushes for inclusion in trade talks with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 11:56:22 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Laborers must have a say in talks on a proposed cross-strait economic agreement, as it would impact most heavily on blue-collar workers in Taiwan, representatives of the country's labor sector insisted Thursday.

The heads of the Labor Rights Association and Taiwan Labor Front pushed for labor representatives to be included in talks on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, saying that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has not made enough of an effort to have labor represented in the negotiations.

Labor Rights Association CEO Wang Chuan-ping said the ECFA would have the greatest implications for workers, rather than for industries. However, no member of any labor group has been invited by the MOEA, the key planner on the Taiwan side, to take part in the meetings and seminars on the proposed agreement, she complained.
Even though some legislators have spoken out on behalf of domestic laborers regarding the ECFA implications, Wang said, "they hardly represent the voice of labor."
She accused the MOEA and the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) of providing empty, speculative data on the possible impact of the ECFA on laborers.
"Only the forecast that some workers may face salary cuts or end up jobless is thought to be accurate," she added.

Meanwhile, Sun You-lien, secretary-general of the Taiwan Labor Front, complained that several labor groups have contacted the MOEA and CLA for assessment reports and relevant data concerning the ECFA plan, but have been told that such information is classified.

Sun suggested that in addition to taking the "passive" approach of granting subsidies to workers and industries, the government should devise more "constructive" measures to help create employment for those laborers who will lose their jobs as a result of the ECFA.
For example, he said, the establishment of big nursing home communities around the country can help create a large number of long-term jobs for people in that field.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau chief to visit Jiangsu
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 12:43:09 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng, Kuo Mei-lan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau (KHB) Director-General Shieh Ming-hui is scheduled to leave for China Thursday to discuss a plan to establish a new shipping route to the port of Taicang.

Shieh will take part in a cross-Taiwan Strait port logistics forum to be held in Taicang, Jiangsu province and meet with Taicang officials to discuss possible cooperation plans between Kaohsiung and Taicang.
According to Shieh, the main purpose of the visit is to seek to expand cross- strait shipping routes and capacity now that there are direct transportation links between the two sides.
In the process, the port of Kaohsiung aims to become a cross-strait transshipment and logistics center, Shieh said.

Chen Chien-yu, chief of the KHB's Business Department, who was already in Taicang preparing for Shieh's visit, told the CNA that the proposed Kaohsiung- Taicang route is intended for small, short sea shipping vessels of around 1,000 tons.
The cargo shipped from Taicang to Kaohsiung can be transshipped to Southeast Asia, and even Europe and Americas in the future, Chen said.
Zhu Jiabao, an official at the Taicang Port Authority, expressed the hope that the two sides can finalize the details of the proposed route next month to facilitate its early launch.
Such a route is badly needed because the shipping lanes between Taicang and the Taiwan ports of Keelung and Taichung are near capacity, Zhu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Lupit slows down, prolonging rainfall impact on Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 14:34:57 (By Wang Shu-fen, Chen Shun-hsieh, Lu Tai-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Typhoon Lupit continues to slow down, which will prolong its influence on Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Thursday.

The typhoon's periphery, combined with the northeastern monsoon, brought rain to northern and eastern Taiwan Wednesday and the wet weather is expected to continue, although the storm is weakening, CWB meteorologists said.
The northern and eastern parts of the island are expected to continue to experience rain until Oct. 28, the bureau forecast.

At 11 a.m. Thursday, the storm was centered about 540 km east-southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanbi, moving at a speed of 9-5 kph in a west- southwesterly direction toward the northern region of Luzon Island in the Philippines, the forecasters said.
As the Pacific high pressure system dissipates and the storm continues to slow down, it could change course Friday or Saturday and move in a more northerly direction toward Taiwan, the bureau said.

If this happens, the CWB said, it will issue a sea warning against Lupit Friday, at the earliest. However, the weather bureau said it may not have to issue any warning if the storm continues to lose strength.

Meanwhile, the CWB forecast that temperatures islandwide will drop to an average low of 21 degrees Celsius Thursday, about 2 degrees lower than the average recorded the day before. The highs Thursday are forecast at 25 degrees in the north, 28 degrees in the east and 30 degrees in central and southern Taiwan.

In related news, officials in Lanyu, or Orchid Island, off Taiwan's eastern county of Taitung, closed schools and offices Thursday afternoon after hurricane-force winds whipped the island Thursday morning.
The winds are expected to strengthen in the next few days as Typhoon Lupit's periphery approaches the Bashi Channel and Taiwan, said Lanyu township chief Chou Kuei-kuang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Whiskered terns arrive in Tainan, expected to stay longer this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 14:42:42 (By Yang Szu-jui and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: As winter approaches, tens of thousands of whiskered terns have arrived in the southern county of Tainan, but the county government has decided not to host tern-watching activities this year in an effort to protect the birds, county officials said Thursday.

The birds' "sunset dance, " in which tens of thousands of black-bellied terns fly in flocks over the ocean at sunset, last year attracted thousands of weekend tourists to the rural township of Beimen.
However, the convergence of large numbers of tourists on the area caused the birds to leave sooner than usual.

Hung Yu-chih, a local guide who is familiar with the birds' migratory habits, said the whiskered terns, which normally would have stayed until April this year, left Tainan at the end of last December.

Last year, more than 10,000 people visited Tainan to watch whiskered terns, said Hung, who also runs a guesthouse in Beimen for bird lovers. "The noisy crowds of visitors seriously disturbed the terns," he said

The black-bellied terns -- small marsh terns with a slightly forked tail -- migrate to the coastal areas around Tainan and Chiayi County every winter. During their stay in the wetlands in Beimen near northern Tainan, they usually fly out to sea early in the morning and rest on the oyster racks then return to the wetlands at sunset.
Some bird watchers said that in addition to watching the unique "tornado-like" flight of the birds at sunset, they like to get up early to see them at dawn.
"It was amazing...they were flying so low that it seemed like they were just above our heads, " a bird watcher said, describing his experience.

Hung said he was worried that the whiskered terns, which left early last year, would not return this year. However, they began arriving in September and the numbers are expected to grow to a peak in November, he noted.

Although the first-ever tern-watching activity sponsored last year by the Tainan County government drew lots of tourists to the area, many of them criticized the lack of adequate facilities for bird watching.
This year, the Tainan County government will focus on educating bird watchers rather than on attracting visitors.
Even so, Hung is worried that the birds migratory pattern might be disturbed again.
"I really hope the bird watchers will keep their voices down, " said Hung, "I don't want to see the birds leaving early again."
