DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic pact not a zero-sum game: trade official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 15:32:30 (By Tang Pei-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will be a mutually beneficial move, rather than a zero- sum game, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Huang Chih-peng said Thursday.
Huang made the comment in response to concerns that the ECFA would be unfavorable to Taiwan because China would obviously benefit more from the agreement.

According to a report released recently by China's Ministry of Commerce, tariff reductions resulting from the ECFA are expected to boost China's gross domestic product (GDP) by 0.63 percentage points, or more than US$27 billion.

Meanwhile, a study commissioned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and conducted by Taiwan's Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research shows that the ECFA could push up Taiwan's GDP by 1.72 percentage points, or US$6.9 billion.
Huang said that while comparing the increase in GDP on the two sides, the public should realize that these are extra benefits that would be non-existent without the ECFA.

Gains for Taiwan will not mean losses for China or vice versa, he said, adding that Taiwan should go ahead and sign the agreement with China as long as it would bring more benefits than disadvantages.

DOC.HEADLINE: New investment in Chungkang processing zone exceeds NT$10 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 15:36:47 (By Chao Hung-chin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Chungkang Export Processing Zone in central Taiwan had attracted more than NT$10.335 billion (US$320.96 million) in new investment this year as of Oct.9, far exceeding the projected figure for the whole year, an official said Thursday.

"The government's aim was to attract NT$8.5 billion this year in new investment or capital increment by existing companies, " said Hsu Mao-hsin, director of the Chungkang branch of the Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Thanks to the government's promotional efforts, new investment in the Chungkang processing zone, located near the Taichung Harbor in Taichung county, had exceeded the original target as of Oct.9, Hsu added.

Up to Oct. 9 this year, 10 new ventures with a combined capital investment of NT$8.17 billion had been launched in the Chungkang processing zone, and five capital increase projects filed by existing companies with a total capital infusion of NT$2.158 billion had also been approved, Hsu said.
Accumulated investment in the zone topped NT$43.8 billion during the same period, with 58 companies setting up production facilities in the complex, Hsu said.
A total of 93.37 hectares of land in the zone, or 86.1 percent of the total, have been leased, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier orders early preparedness for Typhoon Lupit

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih on Thursday instructed relevant Cabinet agencies to take measures to prepare early against approaching Typhoon Lupit, saying that the more people prepare themselves, the less they will suffer.

Wu has asked the National Disaster Prevention and Protection Commission to maintain close contact with local governments for timely issuance of evacuation orders or pre-warning against flooding and mudslides as the typhoon approaches, according to Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin.

The premier also instructed the Ministry of National Defense to deploy troops and equipment beforehand to facilitate rescue preparedness, even if it is unclear whether the typhoon will hit Taiwan directly, Su said.

At 11 a.m. Thursday, the storm was centered about 540 km east- southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanbi, moving at a speed of 9-5 kph in a west- southwesterly direction toward the northern region of Luzon Island in the Philippines, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

The bureau has forecast that the typhoon, which combined with the northeastern monsoon, brought rain to northern and eastern Taiwan Wednesday, will continue to bring wet weather to Taiwan until next Tuesday.
Although the storm is weakening, CWB meteorologists said it could change course Friday or Saturday and move in a more northerly direction toward Taiwan.
The bureau may issue a sea warning against the typhoon on Friday at the earliest if the storm changes its course and moves toward Taiwan.
Northern and eastern parts of Taiwan are expected to be most affected by the heavy rains which the typhoon is expected to bring to Taiwan in the following days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 93.57 points, or 1.21 percent, to close at 7,607.93.
The local bourse opened at 7,692.75 and fluctuated between 7,710.82 and 7,577.89 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.86 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$139.04 billion (US$4.29 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.77 percent. Construction issues dropped 1.94 percent, banking and financial shares fell 1.71 percent, plastics and chemicals shares shed 1.44 percent, paper and pulp issues were down 1.25 percent, machinery and electronics shares lost 1.24 percent, textile stocks declined 0.43 percent, and foodstuff issues were down 0.08 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 2,141 to 591, with 126 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$13.01 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Underwater archaeology exhibition opens at Shihsanhang museum

TEXT.P: An exhibition that promises to offer a fascinating insight into the world of underwater archaeology and the history of ancient maritime links between Taiwan and China is being held at the Shihsanhang Museum of Archaeology in Bali, Taipei County until Dec. 13.

Under the theme Diving into History, the exhibition is composed of six divisions that feature a wide range of biological fossils from the Taiwan Strait that date back 40,000 years, an array of underwater cultural and historic assets, and a virtual underwater archaeological site, according to Lee Li-fang, a Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) official who is one of the organizers of the exhibition.

Other highlights include 20 artifacts retrieved from a sunken Chinese Qianlong period (1736-1796) vessel that was named General No. 1 after Penghu's General Islet where it was discovered by fishermen in 1994, Lee said.

According to unofficial statistics based on sunken ship records, there are an estimated 500 sunken vessels in the Taiwan Strait, said Ho Chuan-kun, director of the Department of Anthropology at the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung City, who is another exhibition organizer.
However, only about 10 sunken vessels have been located in a recent marine census conducted by the CCA, Ho added.
Because Taiwan lacks expertise in underwater archaeology, the CCA has sought international help in an effort to catch up with the more advanced countries in this field, according to Lee.

To this end, the CCA in 2007 signed a four-year cooperative memorandum of understanding (MOU) with France's Department of Underwater and Undersea Archaeological Research (DRASSM) for assistance in identifying and authenticating what was believed to be an ancient sunken vessel that was discovered during the dredging of Magong Harbor in Penghu, Lee said.
However, no wreckage was found during the underwater exploration of the site by local experts and seven DRASSM archaeologists, according to Lee.
Under the MOU, France will assist Taiwan with underwater archaeology projects and the two sides have jointly published two books on the topic, Lee added.
Taiwan has had marine links with China for 400 years and there are a number of sunken ships in the Taiwan Strait, said Wang Show-lai of the CCA's Headquarters Administration of Cultural Heritage.
The government should therefore seek to build underwater archaeology expertise in the country, Wang urged.

As historic heritage, artifacts and treasure recovered from sunken vessels are all considered as tourism resources, the government should set up a marine department or underwater archaeology agency to preserve these treasures, Lee suggested.
The Shihsanhang Museum of Archaeology, which was constructed at a cost of NT$380 million, is a major archaeology museum in Taiwan and an education center.
The museum was established with the aim of preserving and displaying artifacts unearthed at the Shihsanhang site.
Shihsanhang, which means "13 stores" in Chinese, was a port city that was known for extensive commerce and trade during the Qing dynasty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei's new MRT line suffers shutdown despite network upgrades
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 16:54:51 (By Sun Cheng-wu and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei's controversial new Muzha-Neihu MRT Line experienced a 47-minute shutdown Thursday after a network failure happened at its Jiannan station at 9:17 a.m.
It marked the first time that the 14.8-km Muzha-Neihu line had to suspend services since the system upgrades carried out by the Canadian contractor Bombardier were completed at the end of August.
According to the MRT management company Taipei Rapid Transit Corp.'s (TRTC) Vice President Chao Hsiung-fei, 34 trains were in operation when the halt in service happened.
Two trains were caught between stations and had to be manually driven into the stations. The entire line resumed normal operations at 10:04 a. m.

An initial investigation showed that the shut down might be caused by a network failure at the Jiannan Station, Chao said, adding that the effect of network optimization will be assessed further by the contractor Bombardier.

He also said Bombardier will propose another long term network optimization plan, in which another network system will be used to replace the existing one. The replacement network system will begin operation as early as January 2010.

Taipei's city government said in September that the system had become more stable after a series of upgrades, including ATM ( asynchronous transfer mode) network optimization, which confines problems to a specific section of the line or a single station when a signal fails, instead of grounding the whole system.

The new subway line, which combines the Muzha section that was built by French contractor Matra Co. in the 1990s and the new Neihu section built by Bombardier, has experienced eight major emergency shutdowns since its inauguration on July 4.
The subway management company suspended operations over two weekends in August to enable the contractor to fine tune the system's software and conduct tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.044 to close at NT$32.403.
A total of US$1.04 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.359 and fluctuated between NT$32.260 and NT$32.407.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former U.S. labor secretary to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Former U. S. Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao is expected to arrive in Taiwan on Oct. 25 for a five-day visit, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) source said Thursday.

The 56-year-old Taiwan-born Chao, the highest-ranking American official of Chinese descent in U.S. history, is expected to meet with President Ma Ying-jeou and visit her alma mater during her stay, said Chen Wen-yi, deputy director- general of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs.

At the invitation of National Taiwan University (NTU), Chao, who was the only Cabinet member to serve through two terms in the George W. Bush administration as of Jan. 20, 2009, is scheduled to deliver a speech at NTU and Fu Jen Catholic University, respectively.
Other ranking officials that Chao is expected to meet during the visit include Premier Wu Den-yih, Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang and Council of Labor Affairs Minister Wang Ju-hsuan.

Chao, who served as deputy transportation secretary under the administration of first President Bush, George H.W. Bush, went to the Taipei Private Tsai Hsing School before she emigrated to the United States at the age of 8 with her parents.
Chao was awarded an honorary doctorate degree in law by Fu Jen Catholic University in 1993. She is a former president of United Way, one of the largest charitable organizations in the United States.
In related news, according to Chen, Governor James Douglas of the U.S. state of Vermont is scheduled to lead a Vermont delegation to Taiwan on Oct. 29 for a short visit.
Douglas and his delegation will call on President Ma, in addition to visiting the Taipei Neihu Technology Park and the Nankang Software Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top U.S. envoy to Taiwan clarifies comments on ex-president's trial

TEXT.P: The top United States envoy to Taiwan on Thursday clarified his recent comments on the trial of former President Chen Shui-bian, saying that he has no intention of interfering in Taiwans internal affairs.

William Stanton, the director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents U.S. interests in the country in the absence of official ties, for the first time made public remarks about his comments on Chens trial in his Sept. 30 meeting with Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng.
His comments triggered criticisms from some legislators, local media and pundits, who accused him of interfering in Taiwans domestic matters.

In the course of the discussion of many issues, I just simply noted that there have been some people in the U.S. who commented about the trial of the former president and expressed concern,said Stanton, in response to a reporters question at his first official meeting with local media after taking office two months ago.
But it was not an extended discussion and I certainly didnt advocate any particular view on the issue,he added.
In his 31 years experience in foreign service, Stanton said, he has learnt that diplomats should never interfere with other countries internal affairs.

According to Stanton, Chens trial was not a principle topic during his introductory meeting with Wang, but rather they focused on discussing the issue of a Taiwan-U.S. extradition agreement and some bilateral training programs that Taiwanese judges and prosecutors have participated in, he added.

Both Chen and his wife Wu Shu-chen were sentenced on Sept. 11 by the Taipei District Court to life in prison, in addition to receiving fines of NT$200 million (US$6.13 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, on several counts of corruption, including embezzling from a presidential fund for state affairs, taking bribes from local businessmen and money laundering.
The Taiwan High Court ruled Oct. 9 that Chen, who has been detained since Dec. 30 last year, should remain in custody, on the grounds that he might abscond if released from detention.
Overseas scholars and legal experts have raised concerns about the case, with some saying Chen has been treated in an excessively harsh manner.

The court and prosecutors, however, have argued Chen should simply face justice for his crimes, while many Taiwanese people believe Chen should be punished if found guilty, and some see Chen's conviction as an improvement in Taiwan's justice system, as even a president can be convicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday:
United Daily News:

The Constitutional Court, at the request of ex-President Chen, confirmed the constitutionality of detention of suspects who were indicted for felony, but added an extra condition that there should also be reason to believe that the suspect might escape or coach witnesses to give false testimony.
We affirm the court's decision to uphold the detention of felony suspects although we do not see eye to eye with the court on condition it attached to detention.
However, we think this is an acceptable compromise as the court had to silence the criticisms from ex-President Chen and his followers.
China Times:
Prices of fuel and electricity should be raised but not be offset by cuts in other taxes
A tax-reforming panel under the Executive Yuan suggested on Oct. 19 the imposition of energy taxes to push up the prices of fuel and electricity by 35 percent to 57 percent over 10 years.
Finance minister said the expected hike in fuel and electricity prices would be offset by a reduction in other taxes, such as income tax and commodity tax.
We agree with the panel's view that the prices of fuel and electricity in Taiwan are too low in comparison with that of other countries and should be raised.

However, the unreasonable low prices are the results of the government's long- term policy aimed at boosting economic development. The problem can be settled by simply raising the prices which are under the government's control without having to resort to imposing new taxes.
Furthermore, the new taxes which would be indirect taxes in nature should not be offset by cuts in existing taxes, such as income tax, which is a kind of direct tax.
Liberty Times:
How could Ma try to replenish government coffers with new taxes?
The Ma administration is floating the idea of new energy taxes which will be imposed to replenish the government's empty coffers.

Taiwan posted a tax revenue shortfall of NT$200 billion in the first eight months of this year because of the sluggish economy and the squandering of the country's financial resources by Ma's administration.
In addition, Ma has failed to deliver on his campaign promise of boosting the country's economic growth to 6 percent per year, a failure that has contributed to the tax revenue shortfall.
It is a shame that the president is trying to fool the people and cover up his administration's bungling by imposing new taxes.
Apple Daily:
Modernization of Taiwan's military is becoming difficult
The obstacles to Taiwan's moderation of its military is increasing as the United States is more reluctant to sell arms to Taiwan for the purpose of pleasing Beijing.

Local pacifists have advocated the reduction of the defense budget in favor of budgets to improve people's livelihood, not to mention Beijing's opposition to arms sales by whichever country to Taiwan.
Last but not the least is the deteriorating morale of the armed forces, which undermine the country's war readiness.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.6-magnitude earthquake jolts central and southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 17:48:20 (By Chen Chi-feng and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.6 on the Richter scale struck central and southern Taiwan at 11: 36 a.m. Thursday, but no immediate damage was reported.
According to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , the epicenter of the earthquake was located 16 km south of central Taiwan's Chiayi City at a depth of 11 km.

Although the quake had a magnitude of only 1.0 in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) temporarily suspended its traffic service from Kaohsiung to Taichung City, as a precautionary measure.
According to the THSRC, the company canceled two trains after the quake struck, and stopped selling tickets for about 80 minutes. The ticket window resumed normal operations at 12:55 p.m.
The quake had an intensity of 2.0 in Chiayi City and Tainan City. Coincidentally, a quake measuring 6.4 affected Chiayi on the same day 10 years ago, with seven houses destroyed at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., Taiwan to seek 'gradual approach' to beef issue: envoy

TEXT.P: The United States and Taiwan have agreed to seek a gradual approach to resolving the long-running issue of Taiwan's restrictions on U.S. beef imports, William Stanton, the top U.S. envoy to Taiwan, said Thursday.
"I think the government is understandably concerned about sensitivities, people's concerns about beef, " Stanton said at his first official press conference since he took office two months ago.
Stanton said that the first step to strengthening economic and trade relations between Taiwan and the U.S. would be to "get over the hurdle of beef."
"I think there has been an interest in a gradual approach to the reopening of the market. We want, in the most cooperative, detailed and careful way, to roll out this decision," he added.

Asked why Taiwan and the U.S. have not yet sealed the deal after months of saying the issue is in final stages of discussion, Stanton said there has been an agreement in principle for quite a while, as U.S. beef has met all the criteria of international organizations that review beef safety.
In recent weeks the discussions have been largely procedural, rather than focused on the fundamental agreement, he added.

Taiwan is expected to reopen its market soon to imports of U.S. bone-in beef, according to recent statements by both President Ma Ying-jeou and Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu on the resolution of the issue.

Taiwan at present allows importations of boneless U.S. beef from cattle younger than 30 months, but the government is considering agreeing to a U.S. request to allow imports of U.S. beef from all cattle younger than 30 months , and some beef with bones, as long as the parts considered potentially risky are removed.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the Taiwan government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts, such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines.
Over the past three years, U.S. beef imports have been increasing year-on-year. In 2008, imports of U.S. beef to Taiwan amounted to a record US$136 million despite the restrictions on bone-in beef.
At present, the U.S. supplies around 32 percent of Taiwan's beef, with the rest coming mainly from New Zealand and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paiwan musicologist's passion breathes new life into tribal music

TEXT.P: Located in a remote mountainous village, the tiny Taiwu Elementary School in southern Taiwan might have only 44 students, but it has nevertheless gained international recognition through its 19-member choir that is dedicated to singing the traditional songs of the Paiwan tribe.

The choir, which is the brainchild and passion of choirmaster, schoolteacher and musicologist Camake Valaule, was formed to raise cultural awareness and preserve the musical heritage of the Paiwan, which with 86,000 people is the third most populous of Taiwan's 14 recognized indigenous tribes.
Taiwan's indigenous peoples have lived on the island for thousands of years, long before waves of Han settlers arrived from China.

Now, however, there are fewer than 500,000 indigenous people among Taiwan's population of 23 million, and modernization and assimilation into mainstream society has led to the disappearance or near disappearance of many aboriginal traditions, including their music.

Many indigenous people today are unaware of their musical legacy, a problem compounded in the Paiwan tribe by their lack of a written language, meaning that songs have had to be handed down verbally from one generation to the next.

But this is changing, thanks to the efforts of Camake and the school's choir, who have preserved many of the old and almost forgotten Paiwan tunes, garnering widespread attention for the Paiwan culture.

The children from the tribe's Taiwu and Jiasing settlements in the southernmost county of Pingtung first rose to prominence in 2003 when one of their songs captured first prize in a national aboriginal singing contest.

Three years later, in 2006, the Taiwu school choir was officially formed, and since then, the choir's mission of maintaining the tribe's musical heritage has drawn ever-increasing support and recognition.
In addition to having their songs included in various music recordings, the choir has also received numerous invitations to perform all over Taiwan.

This year, it traveled across the Taiwan Strait to Shanghai twice for cultural exchanges with Chinese minority ethnic groups, and in June, the group earned a rare opportunity to perform in Belgium, Luxembourg, France and Germany.
"The choir won great acclaim for its performances, " Camake recalled in a recent interview. "It is our adherence to tradition that distinguishes our choir from others."
Camake said the choir's rise to fame came as a bit of a surprise and was not part of his original plan.
"My principal aim was to collect and document our traditional songs so that our youngsters could learn about their ancestors' musical legacy and way of life," the 30-year-old teacher said.
Camake said the centuries-old ballads and songs presented by the choir can help Paiwan children take pride in their identity, an attitude that he believes is vital to success.
"We are a tribe known for our rich heritage of mythology and artistry. We love to sing and traditionally, music has imbued our everyday lives with color and meaning," he said with obvious pride.

For the Paiwan people, their songs are a means of expressing personal feelings and narrating the tribe's history or tales of a settlement, a clan or social class, Camake explained. In order to teach them to his choir, Camake first needed to record them being sung by Paiwan elders, who are known in the tribal language as vuvu.
Each song, whether a love ballad or a ritual chant, should be sung with strict adherence to certain tones, styles and traditions, he said.

Take the song titled Bulaqa -- a piece that is usually sung by the daughter of a chieftain in Jiasing settlement before her wedding ceremony. In the song, the bride not only thanks her parents, but also narrates glorious aspects of her family's history to inform the guests about her aristocratic bloodline.
Sikiqeci, meanwhile, is sung by a homecoming warrior or hunter to chronicle his clan's history and relate his acts of courage during his expedition.

As the Paiwan tribe has no written history -- all tribal knowledge and folklore is handed down orally -- Camake said it is not always easy to understand what the lyrics of many of the tribal songs mean.

With the patience and generous assistance of the Jiasing and Taiwu elders, Camake said, he has managed over the past six years to document and record more than 40 traditional songs, including love ballads, work songs, nursery rhymes, warrior chants and festive melodies.

However, he has also encountered some setbacks, as several clans with a relatively higher status are not disposed to sharing their exclusive ancient songs, a reluctance that Camake attributes to a "superiority complex."
"They do not like to hear non-noble tribesmen singing their clan's exclusive songs or to see those tunes disseminated outside their settlements," Camake said with a sigh.
Despite repeated lobbying, the Taiwu chieftain has not yet agreed to allow Camake to document the traditional songs that belong exclusively to his clan.
Another challenge lies in the fact that each Paiwan tribal settlement has its own singing style and rhythm pattern, Camake went on.
However, the young musicologist's strong sense of mission to preserve and pass on his tribe's history and culture spurs him to continue with his efforts to surmount the challenges he faces.

Over the years, he has traveled extensively around the isolated village, which sits on Beidawu Mountain at an elevation of 750 meters, visiting tribal elders to record their songs. When he returns home, he practices the songs he has recorded over and over again, a laborious process, but one that has produced rewarding results.

"Our choir members can now sing many ancient ballads that sadly, even their parents do not know, " he said. "This has led a number of these parents to reflect on their ignorance of their tribal musical heritage and to think about what they can do to save and protect our indigenous culture."
One of Camake's colleagues, Idis Chiu, who assists with teaching the choir the tribal language, described Paiwan music as lusty and brilliant, fully reflecting the tribe's vitality.
"Our music is closely related to each tribal settlement's natural environment and everyday life, and many of our tribal songs are richly melodious," she noted.
At first, Chiu recalled, some of the children were not particularly interested in the old songs because they were so different from the modern pop tunes they were more familiar with.
"But after training and performing away from the school, their interest began to grow and they are now enchanted with the music, " she said.

The school has also arranged for tribal elders to practice and perform with the children, Chiu went on, adding that some of the old vuvus have been moved to tears by the experience, as they never thought the almost-forgotten songs would come to life again and that they themselves would have the opportunity to play a role in their revival.

To better preserve and promote the ancient Paiwan songs, Camake said he has begun cataloguing the music he has documented all these years in preparation for asking friends familiar with musical theory to transcribe them into musical notation.

Camake said the 40-plus songs collected so far are just a beginning. "The next stage will focus on documenting the songs of festive rituals, as well as the tunes chanted by tribal shamans when communicating with the ancestral spirits, " he elaborated.

Moreover, he said, he will try again to communicate with the Taiwu chieftain in an effort to make him and his family understand that the purpose of documenting and recording his clan's ancient tunes is not to take them away but rather to save them for posterity.

"I'll continue to champion the cause of restoring and promoting our musical heritage, as we should not forget our culture and our traditions... and it is the young people who will have to carry on my work," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Clinic doctor investigated over swine flu death

TEXT.P: A doctor at a clinic in Sanchong City in Taipei County came under investigation by prosecutors Thursday after local health authorities accused him of dereliction of duty in a fatal case of influenza A(HINI).

Yang Yao-cheng, a department chief at the county's health bureau, said the case has been handed over to the Bianciao Prosecutors' Office for investigation into the Oct. 20 death of a 39-year-old female resident of Sanchong City.

According to Yang, the investigation was launched because the relatives of the woman accused the attending doctor, surnamed Tan, of failing to administer proper treatment to the woman after she tested positive for influenza A(H1N1) at the clinic Oct. 13.
She was diagnosed two days after she developed fever and a cough, but instead of being treated with anti-viral medication, she was given four bags of intravenous fluids on Tan's orders, Yang said.
The doctor claimed that the clinic had not been supplied with the anti-viral drug Tamiflu, he added.
Tan denied the accusation, and said that he suggested that the patient be transferred to another institution for better treatment.
But Yang said, the doctor did not issue a formal order until Oct. 15, when the women's condition began to worsen.
She was transferred to a hospital intensive care unit Oct. 16 after it was confirmed by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) that she had contracted the A(H1N1) virus.
The woman's husband also developed flu symptoms on Oct. 12, but he tested negative for influenza A(H1N1).
The woman's family members questioned why the doctor did not give her anti-viral medication, and they filed a complaint with the health bureau seeking compensation from the clinic.
The woman, who had no history of chronic diseases, died on Oct. 20 -- the 26th victim of influenza A(H1N1) in Taiwan.
The day before, the case of a 54-year-old man with underlying medical conditions was recorded as the 25th H1N1 fatality in the country.

According to the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, there have been a total of 401 hospitalized cases of H1N1 across Taiwan, and 25 patients are still in hospitals.

As of Wednesday afternoon, 646 classes in 351 schools around the country had remained closed because of H1N1 infections among the students. The number of affected classes account for 0.43 percent of the total, according to the CECC.
The CDC has recently warned that a second wave of H1N1 is looming in Taiwan and the outbreak is expected to peak in November, after an earlier peak in September.
Meanwhile, the DOH is scheduled to launch a free nationwide inoculation program from Nov. 1, targeting selected groups considered at risk of developing serious complications from H1N1 infections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry to consider proposal to mothball Mirage fighters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 18:34:40 (By Lee Chia-fei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Kao Hua-chu promised Thursday to consider a proposal to mothball the Air Force's Mirage fighter jets in light of their low performance and high maintenance costs.

Kao said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will carefully evaluate issues such as how to maintain the balance of combat capabilities across the Taiwan Strait, before making a decision on the matter.
In the meantime, the Air Force will work with the French manufacturer in an effort to fix the problems with the turbine blades of the jet engines so as to upgrade the aircraft's performance, he said.
The proposal to mothball the Mirage fighters was put forward by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.

According to Lin, the rupture of the engine turbine blades on Mirage 2000 fighters in May resulted in a drop of pilots' average flight hours to six hours that month, which was only 40 percent of the minimum 15 hours required by the MND.
Lin also pointed to the exorbitant costs involved in maintaining the Mirage fleet.

While the maintenance costs of the F-16 fighters and the Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF) are NT$160,000 and NT$250,000 per flight hour, respectively, it costs NT$800,000 per flight hour to maintain the Mirage jets, he said.
Also during the meeting, Kao denied an Apple Daily report that a F-5E aircraft was almost shot down by an F-16 fighter in a recent aerial gunnery training exercise.

Kao told lawmakers that fire from the F-16 fighter hit only the cable to which the aerial gunnery target on the F-5E jet was attached. The F-5E was serving as a towing aircraft in the training exercise, he added.
He said when the cable was hit, the F-16 fighter was 2,000 feet away from the towing aircraft, and it is untrue to say that the F-5E "was almost shot down."

DOC.HEADLINE: Legal protests will be allowed during next Taiwan-China talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 18:43:34 (By Lin Shen-hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Protests conducted legally will be allowed during the next round of talks between top negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China, which are scheduled to be held in Taichung City in December, Taiwan's top police officer said Thursday.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), is scheduled to meet with his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in December at a Taichung hotel yet to be finalized.

Speaking during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, Wang Cho-chiun, director- general of the National Police Agency, said not only will legal protests be allowed during the next Chiang-Chen talks, "the protesters will be seen and heard" as well.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator William Lai complained that the local police over-enforced their duties during the last Chiang-Chen meeting held in Taiwan. The meeting took place in Taipei in November 2008.
Lai accused the police of confiscating protesters' flags and of illegally entering a road-side store during their enforcement.

Thousands of police officers, including riot police, were mobilized in Taipei in early November 2008 during Chen's historic visit to Taiwan when the opposition party launched a series of protests against his visit.

Chen and Chiang sealed four agreements in Taipei then on the expansion of direct cross-strait flights, the launch of direct cross-strait shipping and postal services and the establishment of a reporting mechanism for food safety issues.

Meanwhile, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chi Kuo-tung suggested that in order to prevent undesirable accidents from occurring during the ARATS head's upcoming visit to Taichung, the Taiwan hosts should move the next Chiang-Chen meeting to western Taiwan's Yunlin County.
He suggested that the meeting be held at a Yunlin venue where there is only one way in and one way out.
"The police will be able to control the situation, even if thousands of protesters swamp the venue since there will only be one entry and exit," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should not be worried about U.S.-China summit: envoy

TEXT.P: Taiwan should not be concerned about the upcoming meeting between U.S. President Barack Obama and his Chinese counterpart Hu Jintao, as the two countries seeking a more cooperative relationship is in the interests of the world, the top U.S. envoy to Taiwan said Thursday.

A simple fact is that China is clearly one of the most important countries in the world. So its in everybodys interests, including Taiwan's as well, that the U.S. try to have a cooperative relationship with China,said William Stanton, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), at his first official meeting with local media after assuming office two months ago.

President Obama is scheduled to pay his first state visit to China on Nov. 15 after attending the Nov. 12-14 leaders summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Singapore. Some local Taiwanese media have raised concerns about whether Obamas trip will affect Washington-Taipei relations.

Noting that U.S. policies toward Taiwan under the Obama administration have not changed and are still based on the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), Stanton said although he believed the Taiwan issue would be raised during the meeting between Obama and Hu, the two will focus on discussing global issues, such as climate change and regional issues.

I dont think we can expect any surprises in that regard, Stanton said, adding that he has not heard any concerns about that meeting raised either by members of the government or by the opposition in Taiwan.

Under the Taiwan Relations Act, which was passed in 1979 after Washington established diplomatic relations with Beijing and severed formal diplomatic ties with Taipei, the U.S. is obliged to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan.

On the issue of Chinas growing military strength and influence in the region, Stanton said its no secret that the U.S. government has been taking note of Chinese military power in many of its own military assessments and reports, in which the U.S. does not agree with Chinas assessment of what potential international wars are, nor does it accept the definition of the economic zones.

Stanton, the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations, reiterated the U.S. commitment under the TRA to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons, but said that further arms sales is a matter that is still under review.
He, however, said that the U.S.-Taiwan military relationship should not be judged only on weapons sales, as there are other military exchanges and training programs between the two sides.

The U.S. Defense Department notified Congress on Oct. 3, 2008 of its approval of a US$6.46 billion arms package to Taiwan, which includes Apache attack helicopters, Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, Javelin anti-tank missiles and sea-launched Harpoon missiles, as well as an upgrade of the E-2T aircraft to the Hawkeye 2000 configuration, along with related support equipment.

However, the approved package does not include the diesel-electric submarines and Black Hawk helicopters that Taiwan is seeking. President Ma Ying-jeou has also reiterated his administration's desire to acquire U.S.-built F-16 C/Ds and other weapons on many public occasions.

Asked whether the U.S. could still carry out its commitments to Taiwan with a 30 -year-old TRA given the fact that both situations in the international arena and across the Taiwan Strait have changed dramatically, Stanton said that the TRA has served very well as the guideline for U.S. policy.
That document reflects U.S. interests and reflects U.S. values. Those dont change all that quickly. Interests and values are the bedrock of our relationship with Taiwan,Stanton said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan jobless rate drops slightly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 19:42:49 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jobless rate dropped to 6.04 percent in September, 0.09 percentage points down from a record high recorded in the previous month, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said Thursday.
However, the seasonally adjusted rate hit a record high of 6.09 percent, up from the 6.07 percent recorded in August, the agency said.
In September, the number of unemployed people totalled 661,000, down 11,000 from the previous month, when a record 6.13 percent was recorded, due mainly to new graduates flooding the job market.

According to the results of a survey released Thursday, some 48 percent of the people who lost their jobs over the past year did so involuntarily, and the unemployed were jobless for six months on average.

The results of the survey conducted Oct. 8-21 by the online human resources company 1111 Job Bank show that 21.34 percent of the unemployed were jobless for more than a year, 12.23 percent were jobless for two or three months, and 11.03 percent took one month to find a new job.

An executive in charge of public relations at 1111 Job Bank attributed the high ratio of long-term job seekers to their lack of ability, their slim competitive edge and their unrealistic expectations of their prospects.
The number of job applications sent out by each unemployed person averaged 81, for a total of just six interviews, according to the survey results.

Since July, the number of jobs has been increasing month by month , but with the influx of large numbers of new graduates into the job market, the unemployment situation has not improved much, according to the executive.
A total of 1,431 valid samples were collected for the survey, which had a margin of error of 2.24 percent and a confidence level of 95 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan must improve passport procedures for visa-free US entry: envoy

TEXT.P: William Stanton, director of the American Institute in Taiwan, said Thursday that further steps need to be taken by Taiwan for it to be included in a U.S. visa waiver program, including revising its procedure on issuing passports.

The most important factor probably would be in the case of how passports are issued here, as personal appearances are not always required to obtain a passport and that is a central criterion that has to be met,said Stanton, the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

Because there have been cases where adults and children, for example, who are not citizens of Taiwan, had been found with Taiwan passports. Our view is that if personal appearances are required, this would be a big step forward, Stanton added, describing the issue asthe initial largest hurdle.
Stanton made the remarks in response to a reporters question at his first press conference with local media after assuming office two months ago.

According to Stanton, other requirements, such as sharing information on stolen passports and criminal records, need to be resolved before Taiwan can be considered for the U.S. visa waiver program, under which citizens of member countries may travel to the U.S. visa free for up to 90 days for business or pleasure.
The criteria for the visa waiver program are determined by U.S. law so its not a political decision,Stanton said.

In order to improve its passport security, last December Taiwan became the 60th country in the world to begin issuingePassports, which contain a contactless chip and antenna embedded in its back cover, with the bearer's biographical data and facial image stored on the chip.

As to local media reports that Taiwan has invited U.S. Secretary of Veteran Affairs Eric Shinseki to visit Taiwan next year, Stanton said that he hasnt seen such an invitation in any government channels and that there has been no decision about a visit by anyone at this point, including General Shinseki.
He, however, welcomes visits to Taiwan by U.S. Cabinet-level officials, as U.S. policy allows such visits by Cabinet secretaries working in departments for technical and commercial agencies.
I certainly welcome visits in the future. There hasnt been one for a while so we will see,Stanton said.

If Shinseki does visit Taiwan, he will be the first incumbent Cabinet member from the U.S. to do so in nearly a decade, and this could signal significant strengthening of Taiwan-U.S. relations, according to some analysts.
A visit in 2000 by former U.S. Secretary of Transportation Rodney Slater was the most recent by a U.S. Cabinet member.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign envoys visit Kaohsiung township hit by Typhoon Morakot

TEXT.P: A fact-finding group of foreign envoys to Taiwan visited devastated Siaolin township in Kaohsiung County Thursday to gain an understanding of the post- typhoon recovery work being carried out there.

The foreign envoys from Australia, Austria, Belgium, the United Kingdom, France, Hungary, Malaysia, Switzerland and Thailand, who were there at the invitation of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), were briefed by Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing at County Hall before heading for the township, which was leveled by a mudslide triggered by Typhoon Morakot in early August.

The damage caused by the typhoon in parts of southern Taiwan's counties of Chiayi, Kaohsiung, and Pingtung and Taitung in eastern Taiwan was the worst in 50 years, with Siaolin township, which was totally wiped out, the hardest-hit area.
According to Yang, 575 Kaohsiung County residents were still missing and killed, while almost all roads and bridges in the county's mountainous areas were seriously damaged.

According to estimates by experts, some 300 million square meters of silt and rubble have been washed into rivers in the area, Yang said, adding that with cooperation between the central and local governments and private rescue and relief organizations, more than 6,000 refugees have been sheltered at temples and military barracks while they await the completion of their new houses built in safer areas.
At present, 132 prefabricated houses have been constructed to house some of them, while other permanent residences will be completed within six months, Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects U.S. to approve chopper deal before year-end

TEXT.P: The United States is expected to approve a Taiwanese Black Hawk helicopter procurement bid before either U.S. Thanksgiving Day in late November or Christmas, Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu predicted Thursday.

"The U.S. government is not likely to sanction any arms sales to Taiwan before President Barack Obama's visit to China in November, but after that, there may be a change in the U.S. attitude... and there may be good news on our Black Hawk deal, " Kao said during a Legislative Yuan Foreign and Defense Affairs Committee session.

Noting that the U.S. Congress is screening Taiwan's chopper procurement plan, Kao described the Ministry of National Defense (MND) as "cautiously optimistic" about the prospects of success for the deal.
On China's just-concluded National Day military parade, Kao said, the numbers and types of weaponry systems on display were far greater than documented in Beijing's annual defense white paper.

Against this backdrop, he went on, Taiwan cannot afford to relax in its combat preparedness, even though the possibility of an outbreak of war across the Taiwan Strait "has been less in the past two years than it has been in the five years prior to that."

As part of the government's efforts to beef up its disaster response capacity in the wake of Typhoon Morakot devastation, the MND is expected to assign 15 of the 60 Black Hawk helicopters it plans to purchase to the National Airborne Service Corps under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , and Kao said maintenance of these aircraft will be the responsibility of the MOI.

On concern raised by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Hung-liang that President Ma Ying-jeou might turn the country's armed forces into a "disaster relief army, " Kao said such worry is unwarranted.

"The primary portion of the military's 2010 budget of NT$300.1 billion will still go to defense and only NT$1.1 billion will be set aside for disaster response, " Kao said, adding that while Ma has instructed the military to make disaster response one of its core missions, it is not its only mission.
Meanwhile, Kao issued a clarification of recent speculation that Taiwan has closed its submarine procurement office in the United States.
"The speculation is groundless and the office remains in place, " he said.

Chiang Lung-an, the navy's chief of staff, said the office has two staff members responsible for the military's plan to purchase diesel-electric submarines, with one handling submarine-related affairs and the other dealing with administrative matters.
"The MND also has a special panel tasked with maintaining contact with the submarine procurement office in the United States, " Chiang added.
Taiwan has long been seeking to buy diesel-electric submarines, but the plan has never borne fruit because of complex technical and political issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: First batch of Novartis H1N1 vaccine arrives

TEXT.P: With a government inoculation program slated to kick off Nov. 1 to contain the spread of influenza A(H1N1), the first batch of the vaccine manufactured by the Swiss-based pharmaceutical firm Novartis arrived in Taiwan Thursday.

The first 370,000 doses of vaccine, part of the 5 million doses that Taiwan has purchased from Novartis, will be distributed over the next few days to appointed spots around the country where the public will be able to get shots, said officials of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH).
The 5 million doses of vaccine will help meet local demand for about 12 million doses.
The DOH will use the Novartis vaccine in the initial stages of the inoculation program, as locally produced vaccine will not be available until mid-November.

A day earlier, DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang hailed the mid-term results of human clinical testing of H1N1 vaccine produced by Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's sole human vaccine manufacturer, saying that the Adimmune vaccine is in no way inferior to H1N1 vaccine marketed by foreign firms.

According to Kang Chao-chou, chief of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, the relevant data on the mid-term results will be published only after being confirmed by a screening committee and conclusions will be submitted to the CDC.
A complete evaluation report on the efficacy and safety of the Adimmune vaccine is expected to be available in mid-November, Kang said.
Meanwhile, the number of deaths from influenza A(HIN1) had hit 26 in Taiwan as of Wednesday, with a 39-year-old woman from Taipei County listed as the latest victim.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 2009 newborns forecast to drop to new low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 21:32:04 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's birth rate has continued its downward trend, with the number of newborns expected to drop to a new low this year, an official of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.
Only 137,967 babies were born in Taiwan in the first nine months of this year, representing a 3.4 percent decline from the year-earlier level, the official said.
"Given this trend, the total number of this year's newborns could fall below 192,000, which would be a new low in the country's history, " the official added.
The number of newborns slid below the benchmark 200,000 for the first time in 2008, when only 198,733 babies were born.

According to MOI tallies, northern Taiwan's Hsinchu City boasted the highest crude birth rate of 9.4 births per 1,000 population for the January-September period, while the northern port city of Keelung recorded the lowest birth rate of 4.9.

Compared with the same period of last year, the offshore Kinmen and Lienchiang counties saw the largest growth in birth rate, both increasing 0.5 per 1,000 population, while the southern city of Chiayi posted the largest decline of 0.5 per 1,000.

In terms of maternal nationality, 91.2 percent of the newborns were delivered by Taiwanese nationals, 4.7 percent were born to women from China, Hong Kong and Macau and 4.1 percent were born to people from other countries.

Over the past six years, the MOI official said, the annual number of births to women from the three Chinese areas has remained almost the same, but the number of newborns delivered by spouses from elsewhere has been declining steadily.

In terms of marital status, 132,450 newborns, or 96 percent of the total, were born to married couples, while 5,489 or 3.98 percent were born out of wedlock, and 28, or 0.02 percent, were deserted babies or orphans.
Taitung County in eastern Taiwan had the highest number of illegitimate babies, followed by neighboring Hualien County and then Keelung City.
The number of babies born out of wedlock marked a 0.22 percent decrease from the 2008 level, but an increase of 1.06 percent from 1997, according to MOI tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legalization of gun ownership not considered: interior minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 21:34:34 (By Lin Kun-hsu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The government will not consider legalizing gun ownership by the country's citizens, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday.
Jiang said the disadvantages of allowing gun ownership outweigh the benefits and that the ministry will only consider allowing security guards to carry firearms.
He was responding to a call by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Yu Tien to allow law-abiding citizens to own handguns to protect themselves.

Yu claimed that gun smuggling is "quite common" in Taiwan, which he said not only enables gangsters and the wealthy to buy guns easily but also boosts the price of illegal firearms on the black market.
Possession of firearms by the general public would be a great deterrent for mob activity, he said.
In response, National Police Agency (NPA) Director-General Wang Cho-chiun pointed out that social order in Taiwan is not so bad that people need guns to protect themselves.
Meanwhile, Ye Yu-lan, an associate professor at Central Police University, expressed opposition to allowing legal ownership of firearms by citizens, including security guards.

Although there is still controversy over whether Taiwan's citizens should be allowed to bear arms for self defense, there are nonetheless more than 5,000 legally privately owned handguns in the country, according to statistics released that day by the NPA.
Of the total privately owned guns, 1,000 are for self-defense and 4,000 are used by aboriginal people for hunting, according to the agency.
The number of privately owned guns has been decreasing year on year because of strict domestic regulations on private ownership of firearms, an agency official added.

The Statute for Management of Self-Defense Firearms was originally enacted as many people brought guns with them when they retreated to Taiwan along with the Kuomintang government in 1949 after losing the Chinese civil war to the Communist Party of China.
Under the statute, people who own private arms are required to receive a regular inspection every two years as well as random inspections by the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO defends press freedom in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Under pressure from a marked fall in Taiwan's international press freedom ranking, the government will "clarify the matter" with the parties concerned and welcomes foreign nationals to visit Taiwan to explore the situation, a Government Information Office (GIO) official said Thursday.

Pedro Yuan, chief of the GIO's International Information Office, said the GIO will send a letter of clarification to the Paris-based Reporters Sans Frontieres (RSF), which placed Taiwan in 59th position in its 2009 report, down from 36th last year.
Government interference and attacks by protesters against reporters were cited by the RSF as the major reasons behind Taiwan's plunge in the ranking.
Denying government meddling in Taiwan's public or private media organizations, Yuan said the government fully understands the importance of press freedom as the cornerstone of a democratic society.
"Booming news media development is vivid proof of Taiwan's freedom of speech free from any form of interference," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record decline in January-August wages
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 22:29:11 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Wage earners experienced a record decline in their real incomes during the first eight months of 2009, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

The average monthly income of local employees between January and August fell by a record 6.79 percent year-on-year to NT$43,339, lower than the NT$43,388 posted in 2000, said Liu Tien-si, a DGBAS deputy department chief.
The average regular monthly wage also contracted during the same period by a record 2.52 percent to NT$35,678, according to Liu.
The average wage includes regular wages (salary and fixed monthly subsidies and bonuses) plus overtime, and other non- regular wages (performance bonuses, year- end bonuses and employee bonuses).

Real monthly income, which takes into account the impact of the consumer price index on wages, also fell by a record 6.11 percent to NT$41,640, slightly higher than the NT$41,206 recorded in 1996, Liu said.
Real regular monthly wages during the first eight months of this year dropped by 1.81 percent year-on-year to NT$34,279.

The number of employees in the manufacturing and service industries reached 6.33 million in August, the highest in the past seven months and representing an increase of 22,000 over the previous month, according to Liu.
For August alone, the regular monthly wage fell by NT$686, or 1.88 percent, to NT$35,879, which marked a decline rate of below 2 percent for the third consecutive month, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan may lift ban on U.S. bone-in beef from young cattle Friday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 22:35:07 (By Chen Li-ting and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will soon lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday.

"We will formally announce new market-opening measures before the end of this month or on Friday at the earliest, " Yaung said as bilateral negotiations on the long-running issue were entering their final stages.
U.S. bone-in beef to be allowed into Taiwan in the initial phase will include T-bone and rib steak, while beef offal will remain on the off-limits list, Yaung said.
"As for ground beef, the two sides are still in talks on this issue," the minister added.

Over the past three years, the United States has continued pushing Taiwan to open its market wider to U.S. beef and after many rounds of risk assessments and intensive bilateral negotiations, Taiwan has finally decided to gradually ease import restrictions on U.S. beef, Yaung explained.
For health considerations, Yaung went on, beef offal will remain off the import list in the initial stage.
Moreover, he went on, local importers will be required to produce Quality System Assessment (QSA) certificates issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

According to the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, the QSA program provides suppliers of agricultural products and services the opportunity to assure customers of their ability to provide consistent quality products or services.

"This assurance is based on meeting product requirements through a documented quality management system, " said Hsu Ching-hsin, a DOH food safety expert, who added that a QSA program will allow beef from U.S. cattle to be eligible to enter Taiwan and will certify through documentation, verification and traceability that the meat is from cattle less than 30 months of age.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines.
Over the past three years, U.S. beef imports have been increasing steadily. In 2008, imports of U.S. beef amounted to a record US$136 million, despite the ban on bone-in beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scientist wins international agriculture award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 23:12:21 (By Chang Jung-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A professor at National Cheng Kung University in southern Taiwan has won the 2009 prize in agricultural sciences presented by the Academy of Sciences for the Developing World (TWAS), a university spokesman said Thursday.

Yang Hui-lang won the prize for his outstanding achievements in the research and development of immunology, oral vaccines and prevention of viral infections in grouper aquaculture, the spokesman said.
TWAS is an international organization based in Trieste, Italy, that promotes scientific excellence for sustainable development in developing countries around the world.

The TWAS prizes are awarded to individual scientists in developing countries in recognition of outstanding contributions to knowledge in eight fields of science: biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics, agricultural sciences, earth sciences, engineering sciences and medical sciences.
Yang said he began to research aquaculture-related biomedical technology 10 years ago after seeing the problems of aquatic disease with which local aquaculturists were plagued.

"We started from scratch, " Yang said, adding that the NCKU organized a research team and established a laboratory and an experimental pond for development of biomedical technology for aquatic disease prevention, particularly in grouper breeding.
Yang will receive the TWAS award at the organization's conference slated for early next year. He will be awarded a prize money of US$15,000 and a plaque.

On China's just-concluded National Day military parade, Kao said, the numbers and types of weaponry systems on display were far greater than documented in Beijing's annual defense white paper.

Against this backdrop, he went on, Taiwan cannot afford to relax in its combat preparedness, even though the possibility of an outbreak of war across the Taiwan Strait "has been less in the past two years than it has been in the five years prior to that."

As part of the government's efforts to beef up its disaster response capacity in the wake of Typhoon Morakot devastation, the MND is expected to assign 15 of the 60 Black Hawk helicopters it plans to purchase to the National Airborne Service Corps under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , and Kao said maintenance of these aircraft will be the responsibility of the MOI.

On concern raised by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Hung-liang that President Ma Ying-jeou might turn the country's armed forces into a "disaster relief army, " Kao said such worry is unwarranted.

"The primary portion of the military's 2010 budget of NT$300.1 billion will still go to defense and only NT$1.1 billion will be set aside for disaster response, " Kao said, adding that while Ma has instructed the military to make disaster response one of its core missions, it is not its only mission.
Meanwhile, Kao issued a clarification of recent speculation that Taiwan has closed its submarine procurement office in the United States.
"The speculation is groundless and the office remains in place, " he said.

Chiang Lung-an, the navy's chief of staff, said the office has two staff members responsible for the military's plan to purchase diesel-electric submarines, with one handling submarine-related affairs and the other dealing with administrative matters.
"The MND also has a special panel tasked with maintaining contact with the submarine procurement office in the United States, " Chiang added.
Taiwan has long been seeking to buy diesel-electric submarines, but the plan has never borne fruit because of complex technical and political issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: First batch of Novartis H1N1 vaccine arrives

TEXT.P: With a government inoculation program slated to kick off Nov. 1 to contain the spread of influenza A(H1N1), the first batch of the vaccine manufactured by the Swiss-based pharmaceutical firm Novartis arrived in Taiwan Thursday.

The first 370,000 doses of vaccine, part of the 5 million doses that Taiwan has purchased from Novartis, will be distributed over the next few days to appointed spots around the country where the public will be able to get shots, said officials of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH).
The 5 million doses of vaccine will help meet local demand for about 12 million doses.
The DOH will use the Novartis vaccine in the initial stages of the inoculation program, as locally produced vaccine will not be available until mid-November.

A day earlier, DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang hailed the mid-term results of human clinical testing of H1N1 vaccine produced by Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's sole human vaccine manufacturer, saying that the Adimmune vaccine is in no way inferior to H1N1 vaccine marketed by foreign firms.

According to Kang Chao-chou, chief of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, the relevant data on the mid-term results will be published only after being confirmed by a screening committee and conclusions will be submitted to the CDC.
A complete evaluation report on the efficacy and safety of the Adimmune vaccine is expected to be available in mid-November, Kang said.
Meanwhile, the number of deaths from influenza A(HIN1) had hit 26 in Taiwan as of Wednesday, with a 39-year-old woman from Taipei County listed as the latest victim.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 2009 newborns forecast to drop to new low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 21:32:04 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's birth rate has continued its downward trend, with the number of newborns expected to drop to a new low this year, an official of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.
Only 137,967 babies were born in Taiwan in the first nine months of this year, representing a 3.4 percent decline from the year-earlier level, the official said.
"Given this trend, the total number of this year's newborns could fall below 192,000, which would be a new low in the country's history, " the official added.
The number of newborns slid below the benchmark 200,000 for the first time in 2008, when only 198,733 babies were born.

According to MOI tallies, northern Taiwan's Hsinchu City boasted the highest crude birth rate of 9.4 births per 1,000 population for the January-September period, while the northern port city of Keelung recorded the lowest birth rate of 4.9.

Compared with the same period of last year, the offshore Kinmen and Lienchiang counties saw the largest growth in birth rate, both increasing 0.5 per 1,000 population, while the southern city of Chiayi posted the largest decline of 0.5 per 1,000.

In terms of maternal nationality, 91.2 percent of the newborns were delivered by Taiwanese nationals, 4.7 percent were born to women from China, Hong Kong and Macau and 4.1 percent were born to people from other countries.

Over the past six years, the MOI official said, the annual number of births to women from the three Chinese areas has remained almost the same, but the number of newborns delivered by spouses from elsewhere has been declining steadily.

In terms of marital status, 132,450 newborns, or 96 percent of the total, were born to married couples, while 5,489 or 3.98 percent were born out of wedlock, and 28, or 0.02 percent, were deserted babies or orphans.
Taitung County in eastern Taiwan had the highest number of illegitimate babies, followed by neighboring Hualien County and then Keelung City.
The number of babies born out of wedlock marked a 0.22 percent decrease from the 2008 level, but an increase of 1.06 percent from 1997, according to MOI tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legalization of gun ownership not considered: interior minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 21:34:34 (By Lin Kun-hsu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The government will not consider legalizing gun ownership by the country's citizens, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday.
Jiang said the disadvantages of allowing gun ownership outweigh the benefits and that the ministry will only consider allowing security guards to carry firearms.
He was responding to a call by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Yu Tien to allow law-abiding citizens to own handguns to protect themselves.

Yu claimed that gun smuggling is "quite common" in Taiwan, which he said not only enables gangsters and the wealthy to buy guns easily but also boosts the price of illegal firearms on the black market.
Possession of firearms by the general public would be a great deterrent for mob activity, he said.
In response, National Police Agency (NPA) Director-General Wang Cho-chiun pointed out that social order in Taiwan is not so bad that people need guns to protect themselves.
Meanwhile, Ye Yu-lan, an associate professor at Central Police University, expressed opposition to allowing legal ownership of firearms by citizens, including security guards.

Although there is still controversy over whether Taiwan's citizens should be allowed to bear arms for self defense, there are nonetheless more than 5,000 legally privately owned handguns in the country, according to statistics released that day by the NPA.
Of the total privately owned guns, 1,000 are for self-defense and 4,000 are used by aboriginal people for hunting, according to the agency.
The number of privately owned guns has been decreasing year on year because of strict domestic regulations on private ownership of firearms, an agency official added.

The Statute for Management of Self-Defense Firearms was originally enacted as many people brought guns with them when they retreated to Taiwan along with the Kuomintang government in 1949 after losing the Chinese civil war to the Communist Party of China.
Under the statute, people who own private arms are required to receive a regular inspection every two years as well as random inspections by the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO defends press freedom in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Under pressure from a marked fall in Taiwan's international press freedom ranking, the government will "clarify the matter" with the parties concerned and welcomes foreign nationals to visit Taiwan to explore the situation, a Government Information Office (GIO) official said Thursday.

Pedro Yuan, chief of the GIO's International Information Office, said the GIO will send a letter of clarification to the Paris-based Reporters Sans Frontieres (RSF), which placed Taiwan in 59th position in its 2009 report, down from 36th last year.
Government interference and attacks by protesters against reporters were cited by the RSF as the major reasons behind Taiwan's plunge in the ranking.
Denying government meddling in Taiwan's public or private media organizations, Yuan said the government fully understands the importance of press freedom as the cornerstone of a democratic society.
"Booming news media development is vivid proof of Taiwan's freedom of speech free from any form of interference," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record decline in January-August wages
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 22:29:11 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Wage earners experienced a record decline in their real incomes during the first eight months of 2009, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

The average monthly income of local employees between January and August fell by a record 6.79 percent year-on-year to NT$43,339, lower than the NT$43,388 posted in 2000, said Liu Tien-si, a DGBAS deputy department chief.
The average regular monthly wage also contracted during the same period by a record 2.52 percent to NT$35,678, according to Liu.
The average wage includes regular wages (salary and fixed monthly subsidies and bonuses) plus overtime, and other non- regular wages (performance bonuses, year- end bonuses and employee bonuses).

Real monthly income, which takes into account the impact of the consumer price index on wages, also fell by a record 6.11 percent to NT$41,640, slightly higher than the NT$41,206 recorded in 1996, Liu said.
Real regular monthly wages during the first eight months of this year dropped by 1.81 percent year-on-year to NT$34,279.

The number of employees in the manufacturing and service industries reached 6.33 million in August, the highest in the past seven months and representing an increase of 22,000 over the previous month, according to Liu.
For August alone, the regular monthly wage fell by NT$686, or 1.88 percent, to NT$35,879, which marked a decline rate of below 2 percent for the third consecutive month, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan may lift ban on U.S. bone-in beef from young cattle Friday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 22:35:07 (By Chen Li-ting and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will soon lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday.

"We will formally announce new market-opening measures before the end of this month or on Friday at the earliest, " Yaung said as bilateral negotiations on the long-running issue were entering their final stages.
U.S. bone-in beef to be allowed into Taiwan in the initial phase will include T-bone and rib steak, while beef offal will remain on the off-limits list, Yaung said.
"As for ground beef, the two sides are still in talks on this issue," the minister added.

Over the past three years, the United States has continued pushing Taiwan to open its market wider to U.S. beef and after many rounds of risk assessments and intensive bilateral negotiations, Taiwan has finally decided to gradually ease import restrictions on U.S. beef, Yaung explained.
For health considerations, Yaung went on, beef offal will remain off the import list in the initial stage.
Moreover, he went on, local importers will be required to produce Quality System Assessment (QSA) certificates issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

According to the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, the QSA program provides suppliers of agricultural products and services the opportunity to assure customers of their ability to provide consistent quality products or services.

"This assurance is based on meeting product requirements through a documented quality management system, " said Hsu Ching-hsin, a DOH food safety expert, who added that a QSA program will allow beef from U.S. cattle to be eligible to enter Taiwan and will certify through documentation, verification and traceability that the meat is from cattle less than 30 months of age.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines.
Over the past three years, U.S. beef imports have been increasing steadily. In 2008, imports of U.S. beef amounted to a record US$136 million, despite the ban on bone-in beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scientist wins international agriculture award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/22/09 23:12:21 (By Chang Jung-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A professor at National Cheng Kung University in southern Taiwan has won the 2009 prize in agricultural sciences presented by the Academy of Sciences for the Developing World (TWAS), a university spokesman said Thursday.

Yang Hui-lang won the prize for his outstanding achievements in the research and development of immunology, oral vaccines and prevention of viral infections in grouper aquaculture, the spokesman said.
TWAS is an international organization based in Trieste, Italy, that promotes scientific excellence for sustainable development in developing countries around the world.

The TWAS prizes are awarded to individual scientists in developing countries in recognition of outstanding contributions to knowledge in eight fields of science: biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics, agricultural sciences, earth sciences, engineering sciences and medical sciences.
Yang said he began to research aquaculture-related biomedical technology 10 years ago after seeing the problems of aquatic disease with which local aquaculturists were plagued.

"We started from scratch, " Yang said, adding that the NCKU organized a research team and established a laboratory and an experimental pond for development of biomedical technology for aquatic disease prevention, particularly in grouper breeding.
Yang will receive the TWAS award at the organization's conference slated for early next year. He will be awarded a prize money of US$15,000 and a plaque.
