DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 23, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrives in Taipei at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agrees to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC) " rather than "communist China."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan agrees to lift ban on U.S. bone-in beef from young cattle
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/23/09 11:53:31 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan agreed to lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months Thursday by inking a protocol on Taiwan's new market-opening measures in Washington, D.C.
According to the protocol, the U.S. bone-in beef to be allowed into Taiwan in the initial phase will include T-bone and rib steak.
U.S. beef offal will remain on the off-limits list, while further talks will still be needed on imports of ground beef, according to the protocol.

Senior Media Affairs Liaison Nefeterius Akeli McPherson of the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) expressed welcome to Taiwan's decision to further open its market to U.S. beef based on scientific evidence and policies that are in line with World Organization of Animal Health (OIE) standards.

McPherson said U.S. beef exporters will follow a quality system assessment (QSA) program of the Department of Agriculture to ensure that U.S. beef entering Taiwan is from cattle less than 30 months of age and is certified through documentation, verification and traceability.
The OIE listed both the United States and Taiwan in 2007 as countries in which bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, are well under control.
It has continued to list cattle parts such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines, as "particularly risky" and these items remain on lists of export or import bans.
USTR officials said the United States will continue cooperating with Taiwan on pushing exports of beef and related products that are carried in the protocol.
The opening measures were expected to be announced by the Department of Health (DOH) in Taipei later.

Over the past three years, the United States has continued pushing Taiwan to open its market wider to U.S. beef and after many rounds of risk assessments and intensive bilateral negotiations, Taiwan finally decided to gradually ease import restrictions.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of mad cow disease was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.
In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts.
Since then, U.S. beef imports have been increasing steadily. In 2008, imports of U.S. beef amounted to a record US$136 million, despite the ban on bone-in beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., Taiwan may resume trade talks this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/09 15:09:44 (By Tang Pei-chun, Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S.-Taiwan Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks are expected to be resumed by the end of this year now that the issue of beef imports from the U.S. has been resolved, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Friday.
Taiwan's decision to further open its market to U.S. beef has paved the way for a resumption of the annual TIFA talks, which have been stalled since 2007, Shih said.
Taiwan agreed to lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months and inked a protocol on Taiwan's new market-opening measures in Washington, D.C. on Thursday.

Shih said he recently reported to Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu about the importance of renewing the TIFA talks and said that under the TIFA dialogue framework this time, Taiwan will seek to talk about e-commerce, product verification and other related issues.

Shih's remarks echoed those made by William Stanton, the top U.S. envoy to Taiwan, who said the previous day that the United States and Taiwan have agreed to seek a gradual approach to resolving the long-running issue of Taiwan's restrictions on U.S. beef imports.

Stanton said that as soon as the "hurdle of the beef" was cleared, the TIFA talks aimed at strengthening bilateral economic and trade relations between Taiwan and the U.S. could be resumed soon, hopefully before the end of this year.

The U.S. side, meanwhile, is expected to bring forward issues including pharmaceuticals, pricing of medical devices and ractopamine testing of U.S.-exported pork in the next round of TIFA talks, according to an official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Taiwan and the U.S. signed the TIFA in 1994 as a stepping stone to a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement. Under this framework, meetings were held once or twice a year since then until July 2007.

Senior Media Affairs Liaison Nefeterius Akeli McPherson of the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative expressed welcome that day to Taiwan's decision to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef from young cattle.
The latest development is conducive to a resumption of the TIFA talks, according to McPherson.
"We look forward to seeing both sides getting the opportunity to communicate, since there are so many trade issues to be settled, " she said.

Meanwhile, a Washington, D.C.-based Taiwanese official cast doubt on whether the new round of TIFA talks will take place this year, given that the U.S. government is running a tight schedule for the rest of this year, including an annual meeting of the China-U.S. Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade (JCCT) , a visit to China by President Barack Obama and the leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan names tourism representative to China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/09 15:44:03 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Yang Jui-tzung, deputy chief of the Executive Yuan's Third Directorate that is in charge tourism affairs, has been appointed Taiwan's first tourism representative to China, the Tourism Bureau announced Friday.
The appointment followed a consensus reached recently between the two sides to set up semi-official tourism offices in each other's countries for the first time in history.

Applications for the establishment of the proposed offices were filed respectively by the Taipei-based Taiwan Strait Tourism Association (TSTA) and China-based Cross-Strait Tourism Association (CSTA) Oct. 20 in Hong Kong.
According to a statement released by the Tourism Bureau, Yang's official title in his new position will be director of TSTA's Beijing office.
The agency's principal mission will be to promote Taiwan tourism among Chinese citizens, the bureau said.

Beijing has previously announced that Fan Guishan, a former department chief of China's National Tourism Administration who is currently vice secretary-general of the CSTA, will be its first tourism representative to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three Academia Sinica scholars elected to global organization
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/09 16:12:37 (By Kiu Kuang-yin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Three scholars from Taiwan's top academic research institute, Academia Sinica, were elected recently as members of the Academy of Sciences for the Developing World (TWAS) , the institute announced Friday.

One of the three new TWAS members is Li Wen-hsiung, director of the Biodiversity Research Center and professor at the University of Chicago's Department of Ecology and Evolution. He specializes in bioinformatics and the use of informatics tools and techniques to study the field of evolutionary biology.

Shen Che-kun, a distinguished research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Molecular Biology, was also elected as one of the TWAS members. His research focuses on the mammalian globin gene switch and genes that play roles in learning and memory in specific neurodegenerative diseases, according to Academia Sinica.

The third new member, Lih J. Chen, is the incumbent deputy minister of the National Science Council, whose major research interests are the synthesis and applications of low-dimensional nanomaterials, atomic scale structures and dynamic processes of advanced materials and the metallization of integrated circuit devices.
Meanwhile, four other Taiwanese scholars received TWAS awards, Academia Sinica said in its statement.
Yang Huey-lang, a distinguished professor at the Institute of Biotechnology and director of the Center of Biotechnology, National Cheng Kung University, was awarded the Agricultural Science Prize.

Chen Liang-gee, the deputy dean of the College of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science and a distinguished professor at the Graduate Institute of Electronics Engineering, National Taiwan University, received an Engineering Sciences award, while Academia Sinica scholar Wu Cheng-wen was awarded the TWAS Regional Prize.

Alex Ma, an assistant research fellow at Academia Sinica's Genomics Research Center, was elected as a 2009 TWAS Young Affiliate, an honor given each year to exceptional scientists under the age of 40.
Academia Sinica said the recognition reflects not only the scholars' personal academic achievements, but also their country's support for scientific research and assistance to developing nations.

TWAS is the world's leading academy for scientists from the developing world and an autonomous international organization. Its membership currently consists of more than 900 eminent scientists, more than 80 percent of whom live and work in developing countries.

Founded and based in 1983 in Trieste, Italy, the TWAS also sponsors a large number of research and training programs for scientists from the developing world. The main mission of the TWAS is to promote scientific excellence and capacity in developing countries for science-based sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Russian envoy conferred friendship medal

TEXT.P: Sergey Gubarev, Russia's top envoy to Taiwan, was conferred a diplomatic medal Friday in recognition of his contributions to promoting relations between Taiwan and Russia.

Gubarev, the representative of the Moscow-Taipei Coordination Commission on Economic and Cultural Cooperation in Taipei, is scheduled to leave Taiwan Nov. 7 after serving four years as the de facto Russian ambassador to Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

"During his four-year tenure, Representative Gubarev has done an excellent job of expanding Russia-Taiwan exchanges in such areas as the economy and trade, technology, arts and culture, " said Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang at the ceremony to confer Gubarev the Friendship Medal of Diplomacy.
"His dedication to this task has won him many friends from all walks of society in Taiwan, and especially from the ministry."
Describing Gubarev as an outstanding diplomat with a wealth of experience, Yang said he promoted various projects beneficial to bilateral relations.

They included arranging a visit to Taiwan last year by a delegation led by Anatoly Chubais, Russia's former first prime minister and CEO of the state-run nanotechnology company Rusnano, and a trip to Russia by Taiwan's vice minister of economic affairs to attend the first International Forum on Nanotechnologies, also last year.
The top Russian envoy to Taiwan said that during his tenure in Taiwan, he did his best to deepen the understanding between people in Taiwan and Russia.
"The best side of (my) Taiwanese life was the Taiwanese people, who are very friendly, cooperative, and open," according to Gubarev.
He said he found the diplomatic medal precious because he received it from people he loves.
"Thanks to the attitude of the Taiwanese people, the four years that I spent here in Taiwan (were) like one day for me," he said.
As to promoting direct flights between Taipei and Moscow, Gubarev said it's an ongoing effort by the two sides, but the main obstacles lie in the airlines rather than the governments.
According to the Moscow office, Vasily Dobrovolsky, the new Russian representative to Taiwan, is scheduled to arrive Nov. 16.
Dobrovolsky was a senior officer at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation and had served in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT welcomes Taiwan's decision to lift beef import restriction

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Friday welcomed Taiwan's decision to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months.
Taiwan and the U.S. inked a protocol in Washington on Thursday on Taiwan's new market-opening measure to allow imports of U.S. bone-in beef into Taiwan.

"We welcome the announcement of the new bilateral protocol on U.S. beef imports into Taiwan and Taiwan's publication of its amended import requirements for U.S. beef and products, which are science based and consistent with World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) guidelines," said AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges.

According to the protocol, in the initial phase, T-bone and rib steak will be allowed to enter Taiwan, while beef offal will remain on the banned list. The two sides will further discuss imports of ground beef in the future.

Over the past three years, the U.S. has prodded Taiwan to open its market wider to U.S. beef and after many rounds of risk assessments and intensive bilateral negotiations, Taiwan finally decided to gradually ease import restrictions.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of mad cow disease was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case emerged in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but they were restricted to boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts.
Since then, U.S. beef imports have steadily increased and totaled a record US$136 million in 2008, despite the ban on bone-in beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 41.35 points, or 0.54 percent, to close at 7,649.28.
The local bourse opened at 7,651.64 and fluctuated between 7,671.91 and 7,614.75 during the day's trading session.
A total of 3.94 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$117.23 billion (US$3.62 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 3.34 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 1.27 percent, foodstuff issues were up 0.98 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 0.96 percent, banking and financial shares increased 0.78 percent, construction issues were up 0.53 percent, cement stocks gained 0.51 percent, and machinery and electronics shares added 0.37 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,527 to 1,027, with 217 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$3.42 billion in shares for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. trade group urges resumption of U.S.-Taiwan trade talks

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) on Friday called on Taipei and Washington to resume the long-stalled Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks now that the controversial issue of Taiwan's restrictions on U.S. beef imports has been resolved.

In a statement issued Friday, AmCham welcomed the announcement that Taiwan and the United States have reached agreement on a protocol on the liberalization of imports of U.S. beef products into the Taiwan market.

"The protocol removes what had been a major irritant in the bilateral economic relationship. AmCham now urges the two governments to quickly schedule the long- delayed next round of TIFA talks, which should take place in Taipei," the AmCham said.

"TIFA talks have proven in the past to be a highly useful vehicle for the two sides to discuss trade and investment-related issues in detail, moving bilateral economic relations forward to the benefit of both economies," the statement added.

Shih Yen-shiang, Taiwan's minister of economic affairs, expressed confidence Thursday that Washington and Taipei will resume TIFA talks -- stalled since 2007 -- by the end of this year now that the beef issue has been resolved.
Taiwan agreed to lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months and inked a protocol on Taiwan's new market-opening measure in Washington D.C. on Thursday.

Shih's remarks echoed those made by William Stanton, the top U.S. envoy to Taiwan, who said Thursday that as soon as the "hurdle of the beef" was cleared, the TIFA talks, aimed at strengthening bilateral economic and trade relations between Taiwan and the U.S., could be resumed soon, hopefully before the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical team wins recognition in Paraguay
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct.22 (CNA) 10/23/09 17:14:37 (By Huang Kunag-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A medical team assembled by Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) has won acclaim in Paraguay for performing 15 artificial joint replacement procedures in the past week on Paraguayan patients.

At a news conference held Thursday to brief the media on the achievements of the Taiwanese medical team, Paraguay's Ministry of Public Health and Social Welfare said that the team also shared its expertise and experience with the medical staff at the hospital where it was working.
"Our medical personnel have learned much through this type of exchange, " said Ana Bordon, a department chief in charge of hospital affairs at the Paraguayan health ministry.

Bordon expressed gratitude on behalf of the Paraguayan government for the Taiwan team's professional and attentive care of the local patients, all of whom have been doing well since they had joint replacement surgery at National Itagua Hospital in Asuncion.

Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Huang Lien-shen, who was also at the news conference, presented 18 cases of pharmaceuticals and medical supplies to Paraguay's health ministry on behalf of the ICDF.

The ICDF medical team was composed of four orthopedic and cardiology specialists and two nurses. They arrived in Asuncion Oct. 13 and, in conjunction with Itaugua's medical staff, performed the 15 joint replacement surgeries in less than 10 days.
The ICDF is the Taiwan government's international aid arm under the supervision of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature considering bill to allow drinking of water on MRT trains

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan is screening a law amendment that seeks to allow passengers on the country's mass rapid transit (MRT) systems to drink water on the trains.

The draft amendment to the Mass Rapid Transit Law was presented Friday to the legislature's Transportation Committee, which will later move it to the legislative floor for approval, if it passes the first screening.

The bill was sponsored by 17 legislators, including Cheng Ru-fen of the ruling Kuomintang who noted that passengers on trains run by Taiwan Railway Administration and Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. are not banned from drinking water.

The no-drinking rule on the MRT, which its operators said was meant to ensure safety and cleanliness, is "unreasonable" Cheng said. The draft amendment does not seek to lift the ban on food or on all drinks on MRT trains, only on drinking water.
The bill also aims to ease the regulations against taking animals on MRT trains or into station zones without permission. It proposed that passengers be allowed to carry caged animals on the trains.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.005 to close at NT$32.398.
A total of US$752 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.403 and fluctuated between NT$32.387 and NT$32.420.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials on Friday:
Apple Daily:
No gag order
The Executive Yuan was criticized after a panel of experts commissioned by it to revamp the country's tax system recommended imposing energy taxes.

In the wake of the incident, President Ma Ying-jeou said in an interview with the Apple Daily that scholars commissioned by the government to offer advice on policy should be morally obliged to keep their suggestions confidential before the government has had a chance to consider them.
The president is wrong. What really matters is how the government makes its decisions, not stopping scholars from airing their opinions.
Actually, the public should be prepared for any new policy through a public debate, and only a public debate can convince the people to support the government's policy.
By gagging the scholars, the government will lose a valuable way to educate public opinion.
United Daily News:
Dismissing two vote-buyers is not enough
Although Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has dismissed two Central Standing Committee members-elect because of vote-buying, it is not enough to wipe out the practice altogether.
The Central Standing Committee is no long the policy-making body of the Kuomintang, and its members have no real political power.
But there are still many people vying for membership on the commission and even offering gifts to solicit votes, which is a kind of vote-buying.

If this corrupt practice is to be wiped out, it is not enough to dismiss only two members-elect. We urge Ma to get rid of all corrupt members-elect on the KMT Central Standing Committee to show the public that he is determined to clear the political arena of people who rig elections.
Liberty Times:
People should choose carefully in upcoming elections to avoid
being sold out
By assuming leadership of the ruling Kuomintang, Ma Ying-jeou has achieved what he called "complete governance" -- control of both the government and the ruling party.
He has tightened his control of the KMT by laying down rules that prevent party lawmakers from criticizing his administration.
Having muzzled his party's lawmakers, Ma will not only have absolute power but will also be completely unaccountable for whatever he does.

With Ma's growing power, the people's misery will also grow. How did the people end up in such a plight? It is because they were tricked by Ma into electing him as president and his party as the majority in the legislature.
In order to stop Ma from selling them out, the people should carefully choose who to vote for in the year-end elections.
China Times:
Why should children's potential be inspired by outside stimulus?
A local mental toughness-enhancing camp has been thrust into limelight in recent days for its practice of toughening children up by forcing them to eat fire.
The children were also reported to have been urged to walk on broken glass. What are these training programs for? To train the students to be acrobats or stuntmen?
Why do the parents of these children sign them up for such camps? The answer is because they are afraid that their children will be left behind on the starting line.
So it is the parents' desire to make their children more competitive against their peers that is to be blamed for their foolishness in putting their kids through such ridiculous training programs.

Parents should know that each child is unique and should not be compared with others, and that the most valuable gift they can give to their children is unconditional love that will inspire their children to fulfill their potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' Foundation blasts decision on U.S. bone-in beef
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/09 18:08:19 (By Tang Pei-chun, Hsieh Chia-chen, Su Lung-chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Consumers' Foundation condemned the government Friday for succumbing to "the United States' political and economic bullying" by agreeing Thursday to lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef.
Describing the decision as a "wrong policy" made at the cost of the health of Taiwanese consumers, foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said his group will not recognize or accept it.
Taiwan agreed to lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months and inked a protocol on Taiwan's new liberalized approach in Washington, D.C. on Thursday.
According to the protocol, the U.S. bone-in beef to be allowed into Taiwan in the initial phase will include T-bone and rib steak.

Beef considered to be contaminated by "specific risk materials" or from cattle over 30 months of age will remain on the banned list, while further talks will still be needed on ground beef imports, according to the protocol.

Expressing extreme regret over the government's decision, Hsieh said the foundation had tried to dissuade the government over the past five years from beginning talks with the U.S. on further opening the country's doors to U.S. beef before complementary measures were put in place.

The foundation has often advocated measures such as "batch by batch offshore inspection, " "meat tracking records, " and "warnings on labels" before Taiwan engaged in talks on the issue with Washington, Hsieh stressed.

He said no serious beef inspection system exists in the United States, and even China has barred the import of U.S. beef and beef products for fear of infection of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.
"On the other hand, Taiwan, which calls itself a human rights-upholding nation, has opened its doors so easily to U.S. beef," he lamented.

Consumers' Foundation Secretary-General Gaston Wu suspected that the decision was made rashly by people "upstairs, " as he discovered that relevant government agencies, such as the Department of Health, were not aware of what was happening.
Wu attributed the decision to the fact that Taiwan needs to beg to exist in the international community, thus creating opportunities for global political or economic bullies to exploit the country.
"Do innocent Taiwanese consumers need to swallow all of this simply because of the global political and economic bullying? " he questioned.
Meanwhile, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Friday that the government respects the decision and judgment made by the DOH on the opening.

According to the DOH, the signing of the protocol inked in Washington, D.C., Thursday means that local importers can apply for import permits for their first shipments of U.S. T-bone steak in mid-November at the earliest.

In related news, Kuomintang Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang expressed his hope Friday that U.S. bone-in beef will be allowed to enter Taiwan's market only after details of the opening agreement are made known to the public and after consumers' doubts on the meat and related products are dissipated.

Legislator Huang Sue-ying of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party criticized the move, arguing that Taiwan's existing restrictions on U.S. beef were not severe and in fact more lenient than those adopted in China, Australia, Japan and Singapore.
Huang said she suspected that the DOH had something to hide from consumers, without elaborating.
The United States has prodded Taiwan to open its market wider to U.S. beef over the past three years.

Taiwan first banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of mad cow disease surfaced in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.
In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but limited them to boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts.
Since then, U.S. beef imports have steadily increasing, amounting to a record high US$136 million in 2008, despite the ban on bone-in beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: Value of September export orders sets 11-month high

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan's export orders totaled US$30.84 billion for September, the highest amount in 11 months, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.
The figure is 3 percent lower than the year-earlier level and is the smallest year-on-year monthly decline since the global financial crisis broke out late last year.
The country's export orders in the first nine months were worth US$227.7 billion, down 18.01 percent from the same period in 2008, MOEA statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't respects DOH decision on U.S. beef imports: spokesman

TEXT.P: Amid some negative responses to Taiwan's imminent opening to U.S. bone-in beef, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Friday that the government respects the Department of Health's (DOH's) professional judgment on the matter.
Su made the remarks after Taiwan and the United States clinched a deal Thursday in Washington D. C. to lift a partial ban on U.S. beef imports.
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of U.S. boneless beef that contain no specified risk materials (SRMs) and from cattle younger than 30 months.

Under the terms of the new accord, U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef, intestines and processed beef that have not been contaminated with SRMs will also be allowed to enter Taiwan with effect from Nov. 10.

DOH Vice Minister Hsiao Mei-ling, and Hsu Tien-lai, chief of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture, said at a news conference Friday that the scope of Taiwan's opening to U.S. beef imports is on par with South Korea's.
Thirty other countries allow the importation of U.S. beef from cattle older than 30 months, Hsiao noted.
Only beef without SRMs, which include skulls, backbones, brain matter, and certain intestine parts and organs, will be allowed into Taiwan, he stressed.
To ensure the safety of U.S. bone-in beef, the DOH has twice sent experts to the United States, where they made on-the-spot risk assessment of the quality of the product, Hsu noted.
Hsu said he "believes" that U.S. beef is free from health risks, and its importation is not likely to cause contagious diseases in Taiwan's livestock industry or squeeze local producers.
"The move is not expected to impact on the local beef industry, given that the market for local and foreign beef is well segmented in Taiwan," Hsu said.
Taiwan produces some 6,000 metric tons of beef every year, far less than the imported amount of around 73,000 metric tons per year, he noted.
Meanwhile, DOH officials said that a Taiwanese importer may submit an application to import T-bone steaks from the United States as early as mid- November.

Taiwan first banned U.S. beef in 2003 after a case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the United States. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second mad cow case was detected in the United States.
In January 2006, Taiwan partially lifted the ban to allow U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar proposes "one China, two constitutions" formula
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/09 18:30:13 (By Chou Yung-chieh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A scholar on Friday proposed a "one China, two constitutions" formula for settling political disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"A peace agreement between Taiwan and China can be possible if both sides agree to adopt this formula," said Professor Huang Kuang-kuo of National Taiwan University, at a Taipei seminar on a possible cross-strait peace agreement.

Under the formula, the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China would each have their own constitution and exercise jurisdiction over their own territory, while upholding the one-China principle.
The territories would be recognized as the Chinese mainland for China, and Taiwan, Penghu Kinsmen, and Matsu for Taiwan.

Taiwan and China, as two equal political entities, would then be able to negotiate (on political issues) and thus contribute to building peaceful cross- strait relations, while Taiwan would gain greater participation in the international community, Huang suggested.

Professor Chang Yia-chung of National Taiwan University said that President Ma Ying-jeou's recent call for China to remove its missiles aimed at Taiwan before both sides can move to talk about a peace agreement is tantamount to "using the missiles issue to say 'no' to a peace agreement."
"It would not be a smart strategy," Chang commented.

He added that a cross-strait peace agreement is "an issue that Taiwan and China have to face sooner or later" since it involves the definition and content of "one China" and the political identities of Taiwan and China.

Since President Ma took office last year, Taiwan and China have signed nine agreements to increase cross-strait non-political exchanges, and Taiwan has been insisting on an "economics first and then politics" strategy in dealing with China.
Chang said that the idea of a cross-strait peace agreement has been "demonized" by the opposition camp, and the ruling Kuomintang "dare not mention it" for fear of repercussions in future elections.
Chairman Huang Kun-huei of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) has criticized the proposed cross-strait peace agreement as "a matter of capitulation".

Echoing Chang's view, senior journalist Nan Fang-shuo said that President Ma and his administration should not try to "shift the responsibility of a peace agreement onto the public, or even onto the United States and Japan", but instead, should deal with it seriously.

DOC.HEADLINE: High income earners to face higher health insurance premiums

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) unveiled Friday a draft plan to raise the income ceiling on which health insurance premiums are calculated, which is expected to affect more than 80,000 high income earners.

The plan, which is expected to boost the National Health Insurance system's annual revenue by NT$1.3 billion, is set to be implemented next year after it is approved by the Executive Yuan, according to Chu Tung-kuang, deputy convener of a DOH panel overseeing the insurance program.
Under the plan, the existing monthly ceiling of NT$131,700 will be raised to NT$212,000, and 13 new income tiers will be created.
That means, for example, that those making NT$212,000 or more per month will owe an additional NT$3,654 in premiums per month, based on the existing premium rate of 4.55 percent.

Because employees are only required to contribute 30 percent of the premium, they will only have to pay an additional NT$1,096 per month, while their employers, who contribute 60 percent, will have to pay an additional NT$2,192 per month per employee in this income group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister noncommittal about relaxation on Canadian beef imports
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct.23 (CNA) 10/23/09 19:47:27 (By Chen Ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang was noncommittal Friday about easing restrictions on Canadian beef imports after the department announced earlier in the day that imports of U.S. beef and beef products will be relaxed.

According to the latest DOH announcement, Taiwan will open its market to U.S. bone-in beef from cattle younger than 30 months under a protocol signed by the two countries in Washington, D.C., Thursday.

Yaung said the DOH will revise current regulations governing the importation of U.S. beef and beef products in terms of the newly sealed agreement on beef imports, and if all goes smoothly, the new regulations will be formally unveiled Nov. 10 at the earliest.
Since January 2006, Taiwan has only allowed the import of U.S. de-boned beef and beef products from cattle younger than 30 months.
In June 2007, Taiwan also opened its market to Canadian beef and beef products under the same conditions as those imposed on U.S. products.
Asked whether the new market-opening measures to U.S. beef will also be applicable to Canadian beef, Yaung said it will depend on bilateral negotiations in the future.
Yaung revealed that Canada's top representative to Taiwan paid him a visit Friday morning.
"We did touch on beef trade issues, but did not come to any conclusions in our discussion, " Yaung said, declining to disclose details of their conversation.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of mad cow disease surfaced in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.
In 2006, the DOH agreed to the resumption of beef imports, but limited them to boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months and produced by certified slaughterhouses, without any risky parts.
Since then, U.S. beef imports have steadily increased to a record high of US$136 million in 2008,, despite the ban on bone-in beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mid-term test report on locally-produced H1N1 vaccine released

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people may soon get shots of a locally-produced H1N1 vaccine, as a mid-term report on its initial effects in protecting people against the new flu virus was released Friday.

Chou Jih-haw, deputy director of the Centers for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), said Friday that based on a mid-term assessment of human clinical test results submitted by the vaccine maker Adimmune Corp. a day earlier, the DOH is leaning toward a very possible conclusion that adults will need only one dose of the vaccine produced by the company.
But Chou said that the DOH will only reach a conclusion later Friday, after a screening committee has reviewed all relevant data contained in the assessment report.

Adimmune is Taiwan's sole human vaccine manufacturer, and its human clinic tests about the efficacy and safety of its vaccine targeted at mainly adults aged over 18 years. Adimmune has claimed that its H1N1 vaccine has the ability to provide 70 percent immunity against the virus in men and women older than 18 years of age.
The dose of Adimmune vaccine for children younger than 9 years will be determined after test results on children are completed.
Meanwhile, the first batch of H1N1 vaccine produced by the Swiss-based pharmaceutical firm Novartis arrived in Taiwan Thursday.

The first 370,000 doses of the vaccine, part of the 5 million doses that Taiwan has purchased from Novartis, will be distributed over the next few days to designated spots around the country where the public will be able to get shots, DOH officials said.
The 5 million doses of vaccine will help meet local demand for about 12 million doses.
For children under the age of 9 years old, they have to receive two shots of the Novartis vaccine, DOH officials said, while others above that age only need one shot.
As of Wednesday afternoon, the number of deaths from influenza A(H1N1) has hit 26 in Taiwan, with a 39-year-old woman from Taipei County listed as the latest victim.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25 foreign officials attending ICDF workshop on agriculture

TEXT.P: A total of 25 officials from 21 countries around the world are taking part in a workshop in Taipei to learn from Taiwan's experience in developing agricultural enterprises, the organizer of the workshop said Friday.

The workshop is introducing Taiwan's current agricultural emphasis on balancing agricultural production, sustainable lifestyles and the environment, the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) , which is sponsoring the 13-day conference that opened Thursday, said in a statement.
Though Taiwan has amassed agricultural technology and experience, its agricultural sector has had to overcome major challenges to remain viable today.

Sustainable and creative agricultural policies and development were one of the key factors in Taiwan's strong economic performance over the past half century, but that progress was threatened when Taiwan joined the World Trade Organization in 2002, the statement said.

Admission to the world trade forced Taiwan to open its once restricted market to intense competition, and its limited natural resources and the small scale of its farms left local farmers poorly positioned to compete with cheaper imported agricultural goods.

To cope with the challenge, Taiwan has encouraged its farmers to streamline their operations by transforming themselves into "agricultural enterprises, " an approach that has achieved satisfactory results and is one the ICDF said can serve as a model for the world's developing countries.

Workship participants will have the opportunity to see this approach in action when they visit the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Corp., the Taichung Agricultural Research and Extension Station, the Hsinkang Farmers' Association in Chiayi County in central Taiwan, and several flower and botanical gardens around the island.

The ICDF has organized 15-20 workshops annually to help Taiwan's diplomatic allies and friendly countries train people in international trade, agriculture, fisheries, information technology, and community development over the past 15 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90 ordinary citizens experience life behind bars

TEXT.P: Many kinds of camps exist in Taiwan, but none had allowed ordinary citizens who have never committed a crime to get a taste of life behind bars until Friday, when a local prison opened its doors to those seeking a new experience.
The Taoyuan Women's Prison in northern Taiwan took the initiative to "imprison" 90 individuals for a few hours Friday, hoping to instill them with more accurate concepts of correctional facilities.
The people who registered for the unprecedented program came from around Taiwan and spanned various age groups and professions, prison administrators said.
One woman in her 70s, who was accompanied by her daughter and grandson, said she wanted to experience life behind bars because one of her family members used to be a prison warden.

Like convicts, the participants were required to pass through three heavily guarded iron gates, undergo health checks and have their mug shots taken soon after they arrived at 10 a.m. before being locked up.
Laughter rang out frequently as many participants said they felt funny about having their heights checked and mug shots taken under such circumstances.
They were then locked up in cells accommodating about 10-15 people for much of the rest of their stay, until 2 p.m. in the afternoon.

They did get a respite from their cells at noon when they were fed lunch. Just as with incarcerated criminals, who are required to give their serial numbers during roll calls held before each meal, the participants were also required to call out the numbers they had been given before eating.
Fear was the most common sensation experienced by members of the group, who felt uncomfortable being locked up in a guarded cell.

"I could not but feel paralyzed by fear and anxiety when I heard the heavy sound of the cell's iron gate closing, " said a young woman working at a university in central Taiwan who took part in the program with her boyfriend.
Cheng Mei-yu, head of the Taoyuan Women's Prison in Lungtan, Taoyuan County, said her facility is now holding 1,300-plus inmates, far exceeding its capacity of 1,000 prisoners.
"About 70-to-80 percent of our inmates were drug addicts or involved in drug trafficking, " Cheng said, adding that 12 of the prisoners are now pregnant.
Cheng said the program for noncriminals was designed to help the public obtain accurate information about the true conditions and functions of correctional facilities.
"Prisons are not as dark or humid as depicted in some motion pictures. But while prisons are well equipped, inmates are not allowed to have contact with the outside world," she said.

"Being in jail will truly inflict physical and psychological pain on inmates. We hope participants in today's event will let others know their feelings to help deter crime or serve an educational purpose."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-vice president Lien Chan ideal envoy for APEC: foreign minister

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Lien Chan, who serves as honorary chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, will be named for the second consecutive year as President Ma Ying- jeou's special envoy to the leaders summit of the 2009 Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, according to sources close to the president.

Foreign Minister Timothy Yang on Friday praised the former vice president as an ideal envoy to the summit. He said that Taiwan's envoy to the Nov. 12-14 APEC summit in Singapore has been decided and an official announcement will be made very soon.

In keeping with past practice, the Presidential Office will announce the name after it has formally notified the APEC summit's host country of the appointee via a special envoy who will return to Taiwan soon, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Monday.

Political observers said that Taiwan's choice of envoy to APEC this year will be seen a litmus test for cross-strait relations and a chance to strengthen Taiwan-U.S. relations, as he or she will have the opportunity to meet U.S. President Barack Obama and Chinese President Hu Jintao.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen authorities continue investigation of 'ghost' population

TEXT.P: Law enforcement authorities in the outlying Kinmen County on Friday found a household that has four times as many "ghost" residents as actual residents, as they crack down on people illegally registered there ahead of year-end elections.

Direct flights between Taiwan and China were not launched until 2008, prior to which travelers between the two countries had to transit in third countries or territories.

DOC.HEADLINE: Angry lawmakers demand DOH report on compromise over U.S. beef

TEXT.P: Angry about the government's decision to allow in U.S. bone-in beef, lawmakers across party lines demanded Friday that Department of Health (DOH) officials deliver a report on the issue to the Legislative Yuan on Oct. 26.

Lu Hsueh-chang, a whip of the governing Kuomintang's legislative caucus, said KMT legislators may reluctantly agree to imports of some types of bone-in beef from the United States but will not accept imports of beef offals, as the protocal with Washington seems to allow.

The DOH announced earlier Friday that Taiwan would expand market access for U.S. beef after officials of the two countries clinched an accord Thursday in Washington D. C. to lift a partial ban on U.S. beef imports.

Under the terms of the new accord, U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef, intestines, brains, spinal cords and processed beef from cattle younger than 30 months and that have not been contaminated with "specific risk materials" will be allowed to enter Taiwan starting Nov. 10.

Specific risk materials are defined in the protocal as the brain, skull, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cord, vertebral column and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months of age and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months that contain no specified risk materials (SRMs).

Lu blasted the DOH for failing to report in advance to relevant legislative committees on the issue, because "in compliance with a 2006 legislative resolution, the DOH is required to provide detailed reports about the importation of U.S. beef to the legislature."
Lu said he was extremely dissatisfied with the government's compromise on the issue and demanded that the DOH immediately halt all related operations.
"Otherwise, we will freeze the DOH's budget, " Lu said, after being briefed by DOH Deputy Minister Hsiao Mei-ling on the issue Friday afternoon at the KMT caucus office in the Legislative Yuan.

In response to Hsiao's efforts to convince Lu of the safety of U.S. beef, Lu said he felt ashamed by Hsiao's attitude and threatened to have those who defend the liberalization measure step down, including Premier Wu Den-yih and DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang.
For her part, Hsiao acknowledged that the DOH did not report to the legislature before announcing the promulgation of U.S beef imports from next month.
The legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party also called a news conference Friday afternoon, accusing the DOH of breaching the law by yielding to the United States.
The United States has been pressuring Taiwan to open its market wider to U.S. beef over the past three years.

Taiwan first banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of mad cow disease surfaced in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months, but the ban was reimposed two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the United States.
In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but limited them to boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA urges increases in exports to U.S., Europe
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) 10/23/09 23:43:38 (By Lin Yi-feng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Friday called for redoubled efforts to increase Taiwan' s exports to the United States and Europe, the nation' s second and third largest external markets, respectively.
The ministry made the call as it released a report on Taiwan's export orders for September, which recorded an 11-month high of US$30.837 billion.
The total was only 3 percent lower than in September 2008, the lowest year-on- year monthly decline in the 11 months since the global economic crisis broke out late last year.

China (including Hong Kong) remained the largest source of export orders received by Taiwan last month. Orders from China grew 9.44 percent from the same period a year earlier to US$8.262 billion and approached the historical high of US$8.74 billion registered in August of 2008.

Orders received from the United States totaled US$6.606 billion, a decrease of 10.6 percent from the same month last year, and orders from Europe amounted to US$5.708 billion, representing a year-on-year decline of 13.44 percent.

Orders from Japan and ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) countries rose from a year earlier. Japan placed orders for US$3.574 billion, a rise of 3.56 percent, and ASEAN countries ordered US$2.748 worth of goods, an increase of 8.79 percent.

Painting an optimistic picture for the final quarter of the year, MOEA statistics chief Huang Chi-shih said that an upturn in the global economic climate, the coming Christmas holidays and China's recently concluded "Oct. 1" National Day holidays were factors that could contribute to an increase in Taiwan's export orders in the fourth quarter.
Huang said, however, that there was still room for Taiwan to further explore U.S. and European markets since the island's September export orders from China were near their highest level ever.

Further breaking down the orders, the ministry said that electronics, information and communications technology (ICT) goods and precision instruments topped the list of export orders received by Taiwan in September.

September's orders for electronic products totaled US$7.716 billion, a slight decrease of 0.25 percent from the same month last year, while orders for ICT goods stood at US$7.695 billion, up 2.41 percent, and at US$3.061 billion for precision instruments, 11.84 percent higher than a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 24, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
2001: The Kaohsiung city government holds a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
2001: The 2001 Taipei Nuclear Insurance Pools Forum opens for a three-day discussion with 31 representatives from 21 national nuclear insurance pools around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."
