DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Rain to wane as Tropical Storm Lupit moves off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 12:32:07 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Rainy weather in northern and eastern Taiwan is expected to gradually wane over the next few days as Tropical Storm Lupit moves farther away, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecast Saturday.
As of Saturday morning, the storm was centered 420 km southeast of Eluanbi, Taiwan's southernmost tip, moving north-northeast at 7-11 kph, the CWB said.

Due to Lupit's peripheral effects and the northeast monsoon, showers were expected in northern, northeastern and eastern regions Saturday, the bureau said, adding that there is a chance of downpours in northern and northeastern parts.
However, the rainfall will moderate from Sunday, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax on investment-linked insurance may be imposed in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 14:14:29 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance is expected to promulgate a new measure to tax proceeds from investment-linked insurance products in late October or November to pave the way for its implementation next year, an official said Saturday.
According to the official, who declined to be named, the measure's impact on policy holders will be very minor.

Under the measure, earnings from unit-linked insurance products will be treated as taxable income. Gains of up to NT$270,000 will be tax-exempt under the existing exemption for interest income, but amounts beyond that will be subject to taxation.
In addition, proceeds from policies in which the policy holder and beneficiary are not the same person will be subject to a 10 percent gift tax on benefits of over NT$2.2 million.

The American Chamber of Commerce and the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei have expressed strong opposition to the policy, arguing that it will discourage consumer saving and damage Taiwan's insurance industry.

Despite their objections, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der told lawmakers recently that the tax will be imposed as planned because the policy was adopted by the Executive Yuan based on a resolution by the Tax Reform Committee under the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: British company to partner with local firm on developing wind power

TEXT.P: A leading British renewable energy development company is planning to enter a partnership with a Taiwanese firm to further develop wind power in Taiwan, according to a recent newsletter published by the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei.
SeaEnergy PLC and Taiwan Generations Corporation (TGC) will sign a memorandum of understanding Oct. 27 to jointly develop offshore windfarm projects in Taiwan, the newsletter said.

"This joint project by SeaEnergy and TGC will be the first offshore windfarm collaboration between the U.K. and Taiwan, which also demonstrates the international and local business support for the government's policy," the BTCO said.

The British representative office was referring to the passage of a long-awaited renewable energy development statute that cleared the legislative floor June 12. The legislation lays down a legal framework for encouraging investment in renewable energy production and offering incentives to local consumers who install renewable energy equipment.

In addition to permitting state-run Taiwan Power Co. to buy electricity generated by private renewable energy investors, the bill also authorizes the government to take measures to expedite the development of renewable energy technologies.
According to the BTCO, SeaEnergy is the only listed offshore wind energy company in the U.K. and an expert in the field.

TGC, which is a leading local offshore windfarm development company and one of Taiwan's few energy project development firms, has conducted nearly 5 years of feasibility studies for a Changhua offshore windfarm project and has already secured 11 permits and approval from the central government and the local authorities.

TGC is attempting to establish a platform for international players to bring in resources and successful development experience that can help Taiwan meet the goal of renewable energy development and win global recognition in the field.

According to the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , installed local wind power capacity in 2008 reached 358,000 kilowatts, making the country the world's 23rd-largest producer of wind power.

Under a new government policy to develop green energy, Taiwan aims to boost wind power capacity to 980,000 kilowatts by 2010, to 1.48 million kilowatts by 2015 and to 3 million kilowatts by 2025, the CEPD said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD to propose new program to boost employment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 15:50:31 (By Tang Pei-chun, Erin Ho and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday that the CEPD will propose a new program to continue boosting employment after an existing short-term employment program expires at the end of this year.

The ending of the 2009 employment program will affect 45,000 jobs, he said, adding, however, that the government will not rule out the possibility of making more public sector jobs available, CEPD Chairman Tsai Hsung-hsiung said in an interview with CNA.

"Although the economy has gradually started to recover, the overall jobless rate will remain high if these people are unable to get back into the job market, and the government has noted the significance of the problem," said Tsai, who took office Sept. 10.

Tsai said the CEPD will propose a new employment program after discussions with the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), which intends to increase the number of short-term employment opportunities or enhance existing employment and vocational training.
It might also consider creating more jobs in the public sector or assisting the private sector to cooperate with the government, Tsai went on.

However, the government is also concerned that some jobless people will become welfare-dependent, he continued, so that the CEPD will think the program through more carefully before proposing it to the Executive Yuan.

He said Taiwan's employment situation over the past five months has been improving, so that Taiwan might be able to avoid a situation in which market capital flows only into the local stock market or real estate market, which does not provide much help in generating new jobs.
"The government needs to expand private sector investment, which should become our target, " Tsai said.

Tsai said last month that Taiwan had passed through the darkest days of the economic downturn. With the launch of public construction projects designed to stimulate domestic demand, as well as post- flood restoration projects, more and more jobs will be on offer, he said in his first report to the Legislative Yuan.

Taiwan's jobless rate dropped to 6.04 percent in September, 0.09 percentage points down from a record high of 6.13 percent recorded in August. The number of unemployed people totalled 661,000 in September, down 11,000 from the previous month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-independence groups to protest proposed ECFA signing
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 16:42:20 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Pro-independence groups in southern Taiwan announced Saturday a plan to stage a demonstration in Taichung in December to express their opposition to the proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The organizations, led by the Southern Taiwan Society and Formosa News, said such an agreement must be blocked because it will seriously impact Taiwan's industrial sector and worsen the country's unemployment situation.

The demonstration will take place at the same time as a fourth round of talks between Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin, which will be held in the second half of December in the central city.

According to Formosa News President Chen Chi-mai, although the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has said the ECFA will benefit 700,000 people in Taiwan, another 1.6 million people will see their livelihoods threatened after the establishment of the pact.
Chen predicted that the agreement will bring more disadvantages than benefits and will make Taiwan's economic situation even worse.

Accusing the Ma administration of paying no attention to the voices against the ECFA, Chen said the groups will mobilize 1 million people to take part in the demonstration to display "the people's power."

The pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which fears the ECFA will undermine Taiwan's sovereignty, has requested that the government hold a referendum to allow the people to decide whether the agreement should be signed.
The request, however, has been refused.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor proud of city's garbage, recycling work
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 16:52:10 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Saturday that the city's garbage volume has dropped by 56.2 percent in the 10 years since a compulsory garbage classification system was enforced.
Hu made the remarks when he attended the inauguration of a kitchen leftovers processing zone at the city's garbage disposal facility.

The first city in the country to enforce classified garbage collection system -- in 1999 -- Taichung also started to encourage households to separate kitchen leftovers from their general garbage the following year.

In 2003, a factory was set up in the garbage disposal facility to process kitchen leftovers into fertilizer and chicken feed and today, with a subsidy of NT$50 million from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Executive Yuan, the city's environmental protection department has developed a special zone for managing kitchen leftovers that includes the processing factory, a chicken farm and an ecology park.
According to Hu, the city's garbage recycling rate has been raised from 8.9 percent in 1999 to 43.5 percent in 2009.

EPA statistics show that per capita daily garbage disposal in Taichung has continued to drop in the past five years and that at 0.367 kg per person per day, is the second-lowest among all cities and counties in the nation, behind only the outlying island county of Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese trade official to visit Taiwan with large buying delegation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 17:38:27 (By Tang Pei-chun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The secretary of the Jiangsu provincial committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC), who is also a member of the party's Central Committee, will lead a large purchasing delegation on a visit to Taiwan Nov. 9, one of the organizers said Saturday.

According to Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , Liang Baohua will be the highest-level communist Chinese official to have visited Taiwan -- the Central Committee of the CPC is the party's top decision-making body.

Political observers said Liang's visit signals that cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in the areas of economy and trade are back on track following the hiccup caused by the Kaohsiung city government's decision to invite Tibet's spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan and the city's screening of a documentary on exiled Uighur activist Rebiya Kadeer.
More than 1,000 businessmen from the eastern province will be in the delegation and are expected to spend more than US$1 billion, according to TAITRA.

The delegation, which will be divided into more than 10 groups, also includes some top management from around 50 well-known Jiangsu enterprises, including Sinopec Yangzi Petrochemical Company and China Resources' Suguo Supermarket -- one of China's top chainstores.
While in Taiwan, the delegation will engage in trade talks, visit a number of Taiwanese companies and attend seminars. Liang will also meet various politicians, TAITRA said.
Prior to Liang's visit, another two Chinese purchasing delegations, one from Sichuan Province and one from the city of Guangzhou, will arrive Nov. 2.

The Sichuan group, which consists of representatives of 35 companies from a major industrial center in central western China, and the 185-person Guangzhou group, will hold purchasing conferences and trade meetings Nov. 2 and Nov. 4, TAITRA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$25 billion needed to start nursing care insurance: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 18:23:48 (By Erin Ho, Tang Pei-chun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The government will need at least NT$25 billion in the initial stage if nursing care is to be included in the nation's universal health insurance coverage, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Tsai Hsung-hsiung said Saturday.
Tsai told CNA that the CEPD has prepared an evaluation report on nursing care insurance and that a draft of a nursing care bill will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan at the end of the year.

While the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan is working on a legal framework for nursing care insurance, the CEPD has studied the possible financial sources that would be needed to pay for the program, which is expected to be realized in 2011.
Tsai disclosed that the CEPD will suggest that the government, employers and employees share the cost of the insurance premiums, although the ratio of contributions has yet to be decided.

Like many developed countries, Taiwan is facing the problem of an aging population. CEPD statistics indicate that 22.5 percent of the population will be aged 65 and over by 2028, while the number of the disabled will have increased from 396,000 in 2008 to 811,000 by 2028.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transport minister wants more restoration of Alishan Highway
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 18:32:33 (By Chen Shun-hsie, Huang Kuo-fan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: With the road leading to one of Taiwan's most popular tourist attractions -- the Alishan Forest Recreation Area -- finally re-opened to small vehicles, the minister of transportation and communications said Saturday that he wants the highway further restored and open to medium-size buses by Nov. 20.

Mao Chi-kuo said he has demanded further repairs so that the highway can be used by 22-seater buses that can boost the tourist trade in the Alishan area, which fell victim to Typhoon Morakot that battered southern Taiwan with massive flooding and landslides in early August.

Earlier in the day, a ceremony was held at Chiayi County's Chukou village, the starting point of the Alishan Highway -- also known as Highway No. 18 -- to mark the road's re-opening after over eight weeks of restoration work.

Also that day, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications launched a free shuttle bus service on the highway, using nine- seater mini-vans running every 30 minutes to take tourists to the recreation area.

The buses will stop at the Chiayi Station of the High-Speed Railway, the Chiayi Railway Station, Xiding, Shizhao, Longtou and Fenchihu. Those who want to use the service will need to book at least three days in advance using the toll-free number 0800-210-589, the bureau said.
Asked when the highway will be re-opened to large coaches, Mao said only that "safety comes above all" and that large vehicles will not be allowed to use the road until it is safe to do so.

Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen has described the Alishan area as the county's most important economic lifeline. The road closure meant that tourists were unable to visit and even the transportation of agricultural products was affected, he said.
"Prices at the Fenchihu Hotel, which was once so popular it was difficult to get a room, are down 90 percent, " one traveler from Taichung surnamed Chen noted.
Chen drove to Fenchihu, a popular Alishan tourist destination, along with his wife and four friends Friday, the first day the road was opened.

Rooms were as cheap as NT$280 per night, according to Chen's wife. Besides, the condition of the road is very good and the landscape of Alishan is the same as it ever was -- "beyond perfect! " Chen said.
The re-opening of the road was not just good news for local tourists, but also those from China, who regard Alishan as one of the must-visit sightseeing spots in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT set to hold by-election for decision making body
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 18:55:11 (By Carfie Lee and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) looks set to hold a by-election for members of its Central Standing Committee (CSC) following a mass resignation of members of the party's policy-making body, KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said Saturday.
As of that day, 25 of the 32 elected CSC members had decided to step down over criticism that the Sept. 11 CSC election was marred by rampant vote-buying.

The party kicked two members out of the CSC Oct. 20 for their involvement in vote-buying during the election, but the move failed to stop mounting calls from party members for a new election of the CSC.

Outspoken KMT Legislator Chiu Yi took the initial decision to give up his CSC membership during a political talk show Oct. 22 to express his displeasure over what he described as "the evil precedent" in the CSC election in which many candidates were accused of having hosted banquets or distributed gifts in exchange for votes.
Chiu was followed by several reform-minded committee members who asked for a new CSC election in a bid to "re-build the KMT's image as a clean and reform- orientated party."
President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as KMT chairman, said Friday that he would be pleased to see other CSC members follow suit in a bid to improve the CSC's integrity.

After Ma's comments were spread by the party spokesman, more CSC members offered to relinquish their seats to signify their integrity and defend the party's reputation, making a new round of elections possible.
With the resignations, the CSC would have difficulty meeting the minimum number of members required to convene a meeting as stipulated under the nation's s Civic Organization Law.
Under the KMT charter, the CSC has 39 seats, 32 of which are elected by the party's Central Committee members and the remaining seven designated by the party chairman.

According to Lee, two other CSC members had expressed their desire to step down, while 13 of the 14 eligible alternatives had also agreed to renounce their rights to fill the vacancies left by the resigning members, making it possible that almost all of CSC's non-designated members will have to be decided upon through the by-election.
Lee said the KMT will convene an extraordinary CSC meeting Oct. 26 to decide how to go ahead with the by-election,

DOC.HEADLINE: Shoe designer outlines keys to success

TEXT.P: World acclaimed shoe designer Jimmy Choo shared his experience Saturday of building his couture shoe-making empire at the Education U.K. Autumn Exhibition in Taipei, saying that hard-work, devotion and gratitude are the keys to success.
"Young designers should never be afraid of challenges and hardship because hard- working, devoutness and being grateful are what make one successful," Choo said.
"Whatever you do, never wait until tomorrow. Finish your work today because success will not waiting for you tomorrow," he added.

Choo made the remarks at a forum on the sidelines of the Oct. 24-25 exhibition being organized by the British Council, an organization that promotes education, creative ideas and international cultural relations.

Born in Penang, Malaysia into a family of shoemakers, Choo founded Jimmy Choo Ltd. in 1996 with Tamara Mellon, an editor for Vogue magazine, and become one of the world's most renowned shoe designers.

Celebrity and royal patronage, such as that of Britain's late Princess Diana and U.S. First Lady Michelle Obama, further boosted his image and in 2001, he sold his 50 percent stake in the company to concentrate on his exclusive Jimmy Choo Couture line.

Recalling the time studying at London's Cordwainers Technical College, which is now part of the London College of Fashion, Choo said he had to work part-time to pay his tuition and that his career was not all smooth sailing after graduation.
There was a time when he had to make 50 pairs of US$10 shoes per week just to pay his expenses because his name was unknown, Choo said.
Today, his couture shoes cost at least 10 times than much and there is a long waiting list, he added.
In 1988, his creations were featured in a record eight pages in the August issue of Vogue magazine, bringing international recognition to his craftsmanship and designs.
"I never blame the gods or anyone else for my hardships. I work hard and am devoted to what I do because there is no shortcut to success," Choo said.
Standing in front of a mini-exhibition of his shoes, Choo said he was very happy to act as an education ambassador for the British Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese students to pay credit-based tuition fees: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 19:59:04 (By Lin Szu-yu and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Saturday that credit-based tuition fees for Chinese students studying at local public universities have been finalized at about NT$2,100 (US$65) per credit, which is 1.5 times that of the average NT$1,400 charged by private universities.
The credit fees were decided in a MOE meeting the previous day with representatives of local universities and colleges, Vice Minister of Education Lin Tsong-ming said in an interview with CNA.
Lin said the new tuition policy will not apply to Chinese students who have already enrolled in local universities.
He also said the MOE will respect student exchange programs signed between universities on either side of the Taiwan Strait and that the new tuition rule will not apply to such exchange students.
The new measures mean that tuition fees for Chinese students enrolling will now be closer to NT$80,000 per year, according to the MOE.

In the past, the MOE has allowed each college and university decide individually on the tuition fees for Chinese students, but it has questioned this practice as some local schools have enrolled Chinese students at only NT$47,500 per year.
Tuition fees at China's public universities vary from NT$23,700 to NT$47,500 per year, according to a report from the China Youth and Children Research Center.
The MOE also said it had no plans to revise the existing cap on the number of Chinese students allowed to enroll in local universities and colleges.
According to MOE statistics, there are around 300 Chinese students enrolled in local universities, much lower than the annual cap of 1,000 students.

DOC.HEADLINE: University head urges continuation of university development project
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 20:11:14 (By Lin Si-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) President Lee Si-chen expressed hope Saturday that the government will continue promoting a project to develop some of the nation's universities into some of the best in the world, the first five-year stage of which will expire at the end of 2010.

Thanks to the project, NTU recently achieved 95th place in the Higher Education league table of the London Times newspaper, up from 124th in 2008 and marking the first time a Taiwanese school has ranked among the world's top 100 universities on such a list.
Lee said he hopes the project will go on forever and that with funding, he believes NTU can become one of the world's top 50 or even top 10 universities.

He made the remarks at a ceremony to present the results of the five-year, NT$50 billion (US$1.54 billion) project aimed at boosting the quality of local academic institutions. Minister of Education Wu Ching-chi, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Chairman Morris Chang and Ministry of Education (MOE) Department of Higher Education Director Ho Cho-fey attended the event.
NTU's new ranking is seen as an encouraging result, as one of the project's goals is to cultivate top-level universities and research centers in global terms.

Under the program, the government has allocated NT$10 billion per year to subsidize applied universities and research institutes in efforts to improve their educational facilities and research quality.
In response to Lee's call, Wu promised that the plan will indeed continue and noted that it has the firm support of President Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 National Sports Game Open in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 22:07:33 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Nearly 10,000 athletes from 25 cities and counties are participating in the 2009 National Sports Game in Taichung, vying for medals in 35 events from Oct. 24-29.
President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih attended the opening ceremony Saturday evening at the stadium of the National Taiwan Sport University.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu welcomed all the participants and wished them enjoying the game in a festive mood.

The competitions of the five-day sports game include water sports, archery, track and field, badminton, baseball, basketball, bodybuilding, bowling, boxing, canoeing, billiards, cycling, fencing, soccer, golf, gymnastics, handball, hockey, judo, karate, rugby, shooting, softball, soft tennis, table tennis, taekwondo, tennis, volleyball, weightlifting, wrestling, martial art, sailing, rowing, equestrianism, and roller sports.

DOC.HEADLINE: University head urges continuation of university development project
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 20:11:14 (By Lin Si-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) President Lee Si-chen expressed hope Saturday that the government will continue promoting a project to develop some of the nation's universities into some of the best in the world, the first five-year stage of which will expire at the end of 2010.

Thanks to the project, NTU recently achieved 95th place in the Higher Education league table of the London Times newspaper, up from 124th in 2008 and marking the first time a Taiwanese school has ranked among the world's top 100 universities on such a list.
Lee said he hopes the project will go on forever and that with funding, he believes NTU can become one of the world's top 50 or even top 10 universities.

He made the remarks at a ceremony to present the results of the five-year, NT$50 billion (US$1.54 billion) project aimed at boosting the quality of local academic institutions. Minister of Education Wu Ching-chi, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Chairman Morris Chang and Ministry of Education (MOE) Department of Higher Education Director Ho Cho-fey attended the event.
NTU's new ranking is seen as an encouraging result, as one of the project's goals is to cultivate top-level universities and research centers in global terms.

Under the program, the government has allocated NT$10 billion per year to subsidize applied universities and research institutes in efforts to improve their educational facilities and research quality.
In response to Lee's call, Wu promised that the plan will indeed continue and noted that it has the firm support of President Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 National Sports Game Open in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/09 22:07:33 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Nearly 10,000 athletes from 25 cities and counties are participating in the 2009 National Sports Game in Taichung, vying for medals in 35 events from Oct. 24-29.
President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih attended the opening ceremony Saturday evening at the stadium of the National Taiwan Sport University.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu welcomed all the participants and wished them enjoying the game in a festive mood.

The competitions of the five-day sports game include water sports, archery, track and field, badminton, baseball, basketball, bodybuilding, bowling, boxing, canoeing, billiards, cycling, fencing, soccer, golf, gymnastics, handball, hockey, judo, karate, rugby, shooting, softball, soft tennis, table tennis, taekwondo, tennis, volleyball, weightlifting, wrestling, martial art, sailing, rowing, equestrianism, and roller sports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 25, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five- yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.
2001: Government agencies mobilizes over 1,000 military, medical, police and environmental protection personnel in their second joint exercise staged at a Taipei subway station to simulate possible responses against a chemical attack.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to sweep cross-strait hatred into history
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Taiwan, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:02:04 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou vowed Sunday on the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen to dissolve "the hatred" across the Taiwan Strait with the greatest sincerity so as to sweep killing into history and secure eternal peace between the two sides.

Addressing a ceremony to mark the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou -- in which Kuomintang troops repulsed an attempted invasion by Chinese communist forces of Kinmen in 1949 -- Ma said the battle rewrote modern Chinese history and ushered in an era in which Taiwan and China are separate and ruled by different governments.
The battle occurred soon after the ROC government relocated its seat from China to Taiwan after being defeated in the Chinese civil war in early 1949.

Some 10,000 Chinese communist troops made shore on Kinmen's Kuningtou beach on the night of Oct. 25, 1949 for a surprise attack, sparking a bitter conflict that lasted for three days. Some 7,000 People's Liberation Army soldiers were taken prisoner and around 3,000 were killed, while 1,200 ROC troops died.
"We should offer our gratitude to the ROC soldiers who sacrificed their lives in the battle to give Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu 60 years to develop in peace," Ma said.

He said the Battle of Kuningtou could easily be forgotten in comparison to other much more turbulent periods since the early 20th Century, when millions of people were killed in the Warlord Era, followed by the anti-Japanese war and the ensuing rise of the Chinese communists, but the battle represents an important and crucial page in modern Chinese history, as it changed the fate of both Taiwan and China.

It marked a watershed in modern Chinese history, as it allowed two political and economic entities with different ideologies to begin their differing experiments on either side of the Taiwan Strait, he continued.

Over the past 60 years, he went on, Taiwan first strived to exist in the conflict between the two facets of democracy and totalitarianism, and then endeavored to develop itself into a democratic economy amid competition among the United States, Japan and China.

By comparison, he noted, China has experienced a totally different 60 years, with the first three decades witnessing the most turbulent, distressing era in which many millions of people died, families were broken and societal core values collapsed.
"China experienced more trying, untold sufferings than Taiwan did in that period," he said.

However, in the most recent 30 years, China has continued conducting social and economic reforms via its unique "socialism with Chinese characteristics, " eventually leading to China's rise on the world stage, he said.

The president traveled to Kinmen to attend the ceremony in the company of Minister of National Defense Kao Hua-chu, National Security Council Secretary- General Su Chi and other high-ranking officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan formally enters international prosecutors organization
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:26:49 (By Chen Yi-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recently joined the International Association of Prosecutors (IAP) , the only global non-government organization of prosecutors, under the title of Chinese Taipei, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Sunday.

After twists and turns regarding its title, Taiwan was finally notified by IAP Secretary-General Henk Marquart Scholtz Oct. 20 that it had been admitted into the body as an organizational member under the name Chinese Taipei, the MOJ said.
The membership will allow Taiwan's MOJ and public prosecutors to share with other IAP members resources related to mutual judicial assistance and to host international IAP meetings.

The IAP was established by the United Nations in 1995 in Vienna due to rapid growth in transnational crime such as drug trafficking, money laundering and fraud. At present it has 130 organizational members and some 1,400 individual members representing more than 130 countries.
Due to China's obstruction, Taiwan had previously been represented in IAP meetings and activities by public prosecutors who are individual members.

Despite that setback, Taiwan has persistently pushed for organizational membership over the years by filing applications via organizations like the Prosecutors Association, Republic of China (Taiwan) and the Public Prosecutors Office for the Taiwan High Court, MOJ officials said.
In February, Taiwan's application to join IAP as an organizational member was included on the agenda of an IAP Executive Committee meeting.

Chang Chun-hui, a chief public prosecutor with the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office, along with several MOJ officials, attended the IAP 2009 annual meeting held in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev Sept. 6-10.
During the meeting, Chang was conferred by the IAP with a special achievement award for his long-term efforts in cracking down on human trafficking.

Members of the IAP Executive Committee told Chang and his colleagues at that time that Taiwan's prosecution system, with high-caliber public prosecutors, was established well enough to assume the responsibility of mutual judicial assistance, according to MOJ officials.

The IAP Executive Committee also told the Taiwanese delegates that China had expressed hope that the title Taiwan was using in its application -- the Prosecutors Association, ROC (Taiwan) -- could be changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy rain warning lifted as Tropical Storm Lupit moves off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:32:28 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted a heavy rain warning for northern and eastern parts of Taiwan Sunday as the outer system of Tropical Storm Lupit would no longer affect Taiwan as the storm moved farther away.
As of that morning, Lupit was more than 500 km from eastern Taiwan, and its effects had reduced significantly, according to CWB forecaster Luo Ya-yin.

Although showers were still expected in northeastern and northern Taiwan due to the northeast monsoon, the rainfall intensity and rainfall duration would decrease drastically, Luo said, adding that central and southern regions would see clear skies.
Northeastern and northern regions could experience cooler weather, with temperatures ranging from 22-26 degrees Celsius, he said.
The CWB retained its warnings for high tides and strong winds on the northern and eastern coasts and said the public should avoid seashore activities in those areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public projects expected to draw NT$60 billion in private investment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:32:44 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Seven government-led urban regeneration projects slated to be launched next year are expected to attract private investment of about NT$61.4 billion (US$1.89 billion) , Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) officials said Sunday.

The seven projects are part of 13 government-initiated construction projects with the aim of inviting private participation to develop government-owned land around the country, according to the officials.

The projects include one expected to attract private funding of NT$16 billion and covers an area of 5.7 hectares behind the Hsinchu Train Station, and one that could attract NT$17.8 billion at an old factory belonging to the Retired Servicemen Engineering Agency in Taipei County.
The CPA under the Ministry of the Interior is scheduled to begin officially inviting tenders for all seven projects in March 2010, according to the officials.

The agency has held two briefings since July on six other public construction projects slated for this year in various parts of the country, including two coveted land lots in downtown Taipei, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New bird species documented in Dongsha Marine National Park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:44:09 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: With temperatures getting cooler, large flocks of migrating birds have been seen flying over the Dongsha Marine National Park in the South China Sea, with 11 bird species having been documented there for the first time, officials said Sunday.
Conservation officials from the Marine National Park Headquarters and wildlife experts from the Kaohsiung City Wild Bird Society conducted a field survey on the Dongsha atoll earlier this month.

An official from the Ministry of the Interior's Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) , which is in charge of national park affairs, said the 11 species spotted for the first time included merlin, migratory quail, crested tern, plaintive cuckoo, Indian cuckoo, citrine wagtail, short-tailed bush warbler, Gray's grasshopper warbler, red-breasted flycatcher, paradise flycatcher and common rosefinch.
"These new additions have brought to 215 the number of bird species ever sighted and documented in the Dongsha Marine National Park," said a CPA official.

Since the beginning of autumn, the official said, a large number of migratory birds have passed or stopped over in the Dongsha Islands, including many endangered or protected species, such as Chinese goshawk, hair-crested drongo, chestnut-winged cuckoo, Indian cuckoo and ruddy kingfisher.
"The marine national park will continue stepping up conservation efforts and educational publicity to make the park a new wintering paradise for migratory birds," the official added.
Located 444 km southwest of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the Dongsha Islands, also known as the Pratas Islands, comprise Dongsha Island and two coral reefs.

The government made the area a marine national park in October 2007 as part of its efforts to better protect its rich marine resources and biodiversity. The park covers atolls and surrounding waters, with a total acreage of more than 350,000 hectares.
A national monument was erected on Dongsha Island June 30, 1989, as well as an adjacent structure to protect the monument May 18, 1993, to assert its sovereignty over the archipelago.
With an area three times that of Taipei City, the archipelago boasts the largest and most unspoiled group of atolls in the West Pacific.

The reefs surrounding the islands are also the best in Taiwan's territorial waters. Dongsha's coastal waters are known for their biodiversity, with 489 fish species and about 200 kinds of coral documented, as well as numerous other marine species.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transport minister vows to help build religious park on Matsu
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 18:14:12 (By Yu Hao and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will assist the Lienchiang county government to construct a religious park around a Matsu temple on the outlying island county to help boost local tourism, Transport Minister Mao Chi-kuo said Sunday.

Addressing a ceremony to mark Matsu's ascension to heaven and the unveiling of a statue of the goddess of the sea -- reported to be the world's tallest -- at the Tianhou Temple, Mao said the statue will not only become a new tourist destination for the island but would also give the local economy a shot in the arm.
He promised to help build the temple and surrounding area into a religious zone to attract more Matsu followers and help boost local tourism.
The Matsu statue measures 28.8 meters in height, according to administrator of the temple, who said the temple plans to apply for a Guinness World Record for the world's tallest Matsu statue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to hold Central Standing Committee by-election Nov. 14
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 19:32:17 (By Carfield Li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is scheduled to hold a by-election Nov. 14 for members of its Central Standing Committee (CSC) , as almost all elected members of the body have decided to resign, a party official in charge of election affairs said Sunday.

As of Sunday, the number of CSC members who had resigned or had expressed the desire to resign had increased to 29 amid criticism that the election for seats on the party's decision-making body was marred by rampant bribery, according to the official.
The KMT revoked the elected status of Yang Chi-hsiung and Chiang Da-lung Oct. 20 for giving gifts to party delegates to solicit for votes.

Outspoken Legislator Chiu Yi then took the initiative to tender his resignation to express his displeasure over what he called the bad precedent set by the just-concluded CSC election, in which many other hopefuls were also accused of hosting banquets or distributing gifts for votes.
The mass of resignations came after President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as KMT chairman, voiced support Oct. 23 for the resignation of CSC members to regain the integrity of the decision-making body.

The official confirmed that KMT Taipei City Councilor Li Keng Kuei-fang and KMT Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao, who had previously refused to resign, had said they would offer their resignations at a provisional CSC meeting slated for the following day.
Taipei County Council Speaker Chen Hsin-ching was the only one to stay firm in keeping his seat, a move apparently to prove his innocence.

The official also said that in an effort to improve election procedures and stem further incidents of vote buying, the KMT is considering shortening the polling time from eight hours to four hours and counting all the votes at a designated center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier denies vacillating on U.S. beef import policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 19:37:34 (By Lin Heng-li, Yang Su-min, Chen Li-ting and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday that the government has not vacillated on its policy toward U.S. beef imports and will ensure that the new market opening measures will not adversely impact local cattle raisers.

Wu made the remarks amid ferocious criticism from opponents about the government's decision to allow the entry of U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef, some offal and processed beef from cattle younger than 30 months and that have not been contaminated with "specific risk materials."

During an inspection tour of a post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction site in central Taiwan's Nantou County, Wu said the government has consistently factored in public health and the interests of local cattle raisers in its negotiations with the United States on beef trade issues.

In addition to following World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) regulations in deleting tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages from the permitted import list, Wu said the government has further imposed an import ban on brains, spinal cords, eyes and skulls.

"One of our top guidelines in U.S. beef trade negotiations has been that we will not relax restrictions beyond what have been applied in the U.S. proper, the European Union, Canada and South Korea, " Wu argued, adding that the government has not budged from this stance in the whole process.

Asked about his views on a plan by Yunlin County cattle farmers to stage a protest at the Executive Yuan against the new market-opening measures, Wu said he respects their right to express their opinions.
Nevertheless, he pointed out, locally produced beef only accounts for about 7 percent of annual domestic beef consumption, far lower than South Korea's 30 percent.

Against this backdrop, the premier went on, the government's decision to allow imports of U.S. bone-in beef should have even less of an impact on local cattle farmers than that experienced by their South Korean counterparts.
Wu further said the government will adopt measures to help tide local cattle farmers over the challenges they might encounter after U.S. bone-in beef is allowed to enter the local market next month.

The premier also took advantage of the occasion to clarify reports that he said during his tenure as a legislator that a decision to open the domestic market to U.S. bone-in beef should be approved by the Legislative Yuan.
"What I said at the time was that the executive branch should consult with the legislature before coming up with a decision on the beef trade," Wu argued.

The Department of Health (DOH) announced Oct. 23 that Taiwan would expand market access for U.S. beef after officials of the two countries clinched an accord the previous day in Washington, D.C. to lift a partial ban on U.S. beef imports.

Under the terms of the new accord, U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef, intestines, brains, spinal cords and processed beef from cattle younger than 30 months and that have not been contaminated with "specific risk materials" will be allowed to enter Taiwan starting Nov. 10.

Specific risk materials are defined in the protocol as the brain, skull, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cord, vertebral column and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months of age and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months that contain no specified risk materials.
The new market opening decision has since drawn flak from opposition parties and consumer rights activists.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said Sunday that President Ma Ying-jeou should be held accountable for the decision.
Citing a newspaper report, Tsai said it was Ma who made the decision under strong U.S. pressure to allow the expanded imports.
"Therefore, Ma owes the public a detailed explanation of the reasons behind his decision," Tsai said.
Meanwhile, Wu Jia-cheng, secretary-general of the non-government Consumers Foundation, said the decision will inflict permanent harm on Taiwan's environment and public health.
Moreover, he went on, the government has not been transparent in its decision- making process.

Claiming that the Presidential Office and the National Security Council had interfered with the DOH's professional judgment about the issue, Wu said this has violated the norms of a democratic country.
Wu said the Consumers Foundation is planning to collaborate with other civic groups in pushing the government to back off on its new market-opening stance in order to better protect public health.

Chen Shun-sheng, a Chang Gung University professor, said the government should seek to add a provision to the newly signed beef trade accord that will demand that the U.S. Department of Agriculture must offer damages or compensation if its Quality System Assessment certificates are proved to be untruthful or wrong.

DOC.HEADLINE: China ready for trade talks with Taiwan: Beijing official
DOC.DATELINE: Chengdu, China, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 19:41:19 (By Guo Mei-lan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: China is ready for trade talks with Taiwan and may broach the issue in forthcoming cross-Taiwan Strait talks later this year, Beijing's chief official in charge of Taiwan affairs said Sunday.

Wang Yi, chief of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, said Beijing hopes the two sides can exchange views on the issue in the fourth round of talks between China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , the two intermediary bodies in the absence of official ties.
Wang made the remarks at a seminar sponsored jointly by the Taipei-based Chung- Hua Institution for Economic Research and a think tank under the Taiwan Affairs Office.
"We are willing to negotiate with Taiwan on a trade pact and suggest the completion of studies by experts from both sides, " he said.
The seminar has drawn senior economic officials from Taiwan, including Deputy Economic Minister Hwang Jung-chiou, and Council for Economic Planning and Development Vice Minister San Gee.

ARATS President Chen Yun-lin and SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung are slated to meet in the central Taiwan city of Taichung on an as-yet unspecified date in December for the fourth round of cross-strait negotiations.

The trade pact, called an economic cooperation framework agreement, is designed to promote trade and economic cooperation between the two sides and the Taiwanese side hopes it will be concluded early next year.

It has stirred up controversy in Taiwan as its opponents are worried that the pact will undermine the country's sovereignty despite President Ma Ying-jeou's repeated assurances that it will not change the status quo across the strait in any way.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei hosts Indonesian culture festival to honor migrant workers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 20:06:52 (By Chen Hung-chin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government hosted an Indonesian culture festival at Daan Forest Park Sunday to honor migrant workers and new immigrants from Indonesia.
Hundreds of Indonesian workers, caregivers and spouses of local citizens decked out in folk costumes or stylish outfits attended the event held in the city's largest park.

Famous Indonesian pop signer Rossa and several Indonesian rock bands performed at the event to make the participants feel at home, said Tsai Pei-chen, head of the Foreign Workers Consultation Service Center under the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs.
The Indonesian pop vocalists also led the audience in performing traditional Indonesian dances "Barong" and "Poco-Poco."

Su Yin-guei, director of the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs, took part in a skit in which an Indonesia bride performed a body-cleansing ritual to symbolize wiping away bad luck and ushering in good fortune.

Hartutik, who uses only one name -- as is customary in Indonesia -- and who attended the event with the young son of her employer, said she was pleased to see the performances of traditional Indonesian singing and dancing.
Nurenih, who has been in Taipei for two years, said her employer offered her a day off from work Sunday so that she could attend the event.
"Seeing the large number of my compatriots and watching performance of traditional Indonesian dances and folk songs has helped relieve my homesickness," she added.
Taipei now has about 23,000 Indonesian workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait trade pact talks to proceed as scheduled: spokesman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 22:56:20 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will negotiate with China on the signing of a comprehensive trade agreement in a gradual manner, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Sunday.

He was responding to remarks made by China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs earlier the same day that Beijing is ready for talks with Taiwan on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), similar to a free trade agreement (FTA).

Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council of Cabinet, said at a an economic seminar held in Chengdu in southwestern China, that Beijing hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can begin ECFA-related talks within this year.
If both sides agree, Wang Yi said, the two sides can exchange views on relevant issues at the fourth rounds of high-level talks between the two intermediary bodies scheduled for December.
Wang Yi's statement marked the first official response from Chinese authorities to Taiwan's recent call for striking the ECFA deal as soon as possible.
In the first official comment on Wang Yi's statement, Wang Yu-chi said Taiwan will conduct ECFA-related talks with China at a pace as planned.

He also cited President Ma Ying-jeou's speech delivered Sunday at a ceremony commemorating the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou -- in which Kuomintang troops repulsed an attempted invasion by Chinese communist forces of Kinmen in 1949 -- to signify Taiwan's stance on cross-strait relations.

"Just like what President Ma said today in Kinmen that the Taiwan Strait should turn from a 'killing field' into a 'peace square, ' we look forward to seeing the two sides of Taiwan Strait resolve their issues or disputes through peaceful dialogue and negotiations, " said Wang Yu-chi.

Commenting on Wang Yi's remarks, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te- shun said the timing for formal launch of ECFA talks will depend on the results of informal talks between the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and China's Ministry of Commerce.
Officials from both sides have held three rounds of informal talks and a fourth round of informal talks is scheduled to take place later this month.
If all goes smooth, MOEA officials said recently, formal talks on the much- anticipated ECFA deal may get underway soon.

When Taiwan's top negotiator with China -- Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kun -- meets with his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, in Taichung in December, ECFA issues are expected to be formally discussed following Wang Yi's Sunday statement.

Taiwan's government has argued that an ECFA agreement with China should be signed as soon as possible to reduce the impact on Taiwanese businesses once economic integration of China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) comes into force next year.

After the China-ASEAN free trade agreement takes effect on Jan. 1, 2010, petrochemical products, textiles, automobile parts and machinery exports from ASEAN states to China will enjoy tariff-free treatment, which government officials said will seriously undermine the competitiveness of similar products from Taiwan.
But critics said signing an ECFA pact with China could hurt some of Taiwan's labor-intensive industries and even make Taiwan more reliant on China economically.

1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.
2001: Government agencies mobilizes over 1,000 military, medical, police and environmental protection personnel in their second joint exercise staged at a Taipei subway station to simulate possible responses against a chemical attack.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to sweep cross-strait hatred into history
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Taiwan, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:02:04 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou vowed Sunday on the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen to dissolve "the hatred" across the Taiwan Strait with the greatest sincerity so as to sweep killing into history and secure eternal peace between the two sides.

Addressing a ceremony to mark the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou -- in which Kuomintang troops repulsed an attempted invasion by Chinese communist forces of Kinmen in 1949 -- Ma said the battle rewrote modern Chinese history and ushered in an era in which Taiwan and China are separate and ruled by different governments.
The battle occurred soon after the ROC government relocated its seat from China to Taiwan after being defeated in the Chinese civil war in early 1949.

Some 10,000 Chinese communist troops made shore on Kinmen's Kuningtou beach on the night of Oct. 25, 1949 for a surprise attack, sparking a bitter conflict that lasted for three days. Some 7,000 People's Liberation Army soldiers were taken prisoner and around 3,000 were killed, while 1,200 ROC troops died.
"We should offer our gratitude to the ROC soldiers who sacrificed their lives in the battle to give Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu 60 years to develop in peace," Ma said.

He said the Battle of Kuningtou could easily be forgotten in comparison to other much more turbulent periods since the early 20th Century, when millions of people were killed in the Warlord Era, followed by the anti-Japanese war and the ensuing rise of the Chinese communists, but the battle represents an important and crucial page in modern Chinese history, as it changed the fate of both Taiwan and China.

It marked a watershed in modern Chinese history, as it allowed two political and economic entities with different ideologies to begin their differing experiments on either side of the Taiwan Strait, he continued.

Over the past 60 years, he went on, Taiwan first strived to exist in the conflict between the two facets of democracy and totalitarianism, and then endeavored to develop itself into a democratic economy amid competition among the United States, Japan and China.

By comparison, he noted, China has experienced a totally different 60 years, with the first three decades witnessing the most turbulent, distressing era in which many millions of people died, families were broken and societal core values collapsed.
"China experienced more trying, untold sufferings than Taiwan did in that period," he said.

However, in the most recent 30 years, China has continued conducting social and economic reforms via its unique "socialism with Chinese characteristics, " eventually leading to China's rise on the world stage, he said.

The president traveled to Kinmen to attend the ceremony in the company of Minister of National Defense Kao Hua-chu, National Security Council Secretary- General Su Chi and other high-ranking officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan formally enters international prosecutors organization
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:26:49 (By Chen Yi-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recently joined the International Association of Prosecutors (IAP) , the only global non-government organization of prosecutors, under the title of Chinese Taipei, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Sunday.

After twists and turns regarding its title, Taiwan was finally notified by IAP Secretary-General Henk Marquart Scholtz Oct. 20 that it had been admitted into the body as an organizational member under the name Chinese Taipei, the MOJ said.
The membership will allow Taiwan's MOJ and public prosecutors to share with other IAP members resources related to mutual judicial assistance and to host international IAP meetings.

The IAP was established by the United Nations in 1995 in Vienna due to rapid growth in transnational crime such as drug trafficking, money laundering and fraud. At present it has 130 organizational members and some 1,400 individual members representing more than 130 countries.
Due to China's obstruction, Taiwan had previously been represented in IAP meetings and activities by public prosecutors who are individual members.

Despite that setback, Taiwan has persistently pushed for organizational membership over the years by filing applications via organizations like the Prosecutors Association, Republic of China (Taiwan) and the Public Prosecutors Office for the Taiwan High Court, MOJ officials said.
In February, Taiwan's application to join IAP as an organizational member was included on the agenda of an IAP Executive Committee meeting.

Chang Chun-hui, a chief public prosecutor with the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office, along with several MOJ officials, attended the IAP 2009 annual meeting held in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev Sept. 6-10.
During the meeting, Chang was conferred by the IAP with a special achievement award for his long-term efforts in cracking down on human trafficking.

Members of the IAP Executive Committee told Chang and his colleagues at that time that Taiwan's prosecution system, with high-caliber public prosecutors, was established well enough to assume the responsibility of mutual judicial assistance, according to MOJ officials.

The IAP Executive Committee also told the Taiwanese delegates that China had expressed hope that the title Taiwan was using in its application -- the Prosecutors Association, ROC (Taiwan) -- could be changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Heavy rain warning lifted as Tropical Storm Lupit moves off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:32:28 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) lifted a heavy rain warning for northern and eastern parts of Taiwan Sunday as the outer system of Tropical Storm Lupit would no longer affect Taiwan as the storm moved farther away.
As of that morning, Lupit was more than 500 km from eastern Taiwan, and its effects had reduced significantly, according to CWB forecaster Luo Ya-yin.

Although showers were still expected in northeastern and northern Taiwan due to the northeast monsoon, the rainfall intensity and rainfall duration would decrease drastically, Luo said, adding that central and southern regions would see clear skies.
Northeastern and northern regions could experience cooler weather, with temperatures ranging from 22-26 degrees Celsius, he said.
The CWB retained its warnings for high tides and strong winds on the northern and eastern coasts and said the public should avoid seashore activities in those areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public projects expected to draw NT$60 billion in private investment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:32:44 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Seven government-led urban regeneration projects slated to be launched next year are expected to attract private investment of about NT$61.4 billion (US$1.89 billion) , Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) officials said Sunday.

The seven projects are part of 13 government-initiated construction projects with the aim of inviting private participation to develop government-owned land around the country, according to the officials.

The projects include one expected to attract private funding of NT$16 billion and covers an area of 5.7 hectares behind the Hsinchu Train Station, and one that could attract NT$17.8 billion at an old factory belonging to the Retired Servicemen Engineering Agency in Taipei County.
The CPA under the Ministry of the Interior is scheduled to begin officially inviting tenders for all seven projects in March 2010, according to the officials.

The agency has held two briefings since July on six other public construction projects slated for this year in various parts of the country, including two coveted land lots in downtown Taipei, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New bird species documented in Dongsha Marine National Park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) 10/25/09 16:44:09 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: With temperatures getting cooler, large flocks of migrating birds have been seen flying over the Dongsha Marine National Park in the South China Sea, with 11 bird species having been documented there for the first time, officials said Sunday.
Conservation officials from the Marine National Park Headquarters and wildlife experts from the Kaohsiung City Wild Bird Society conducted a field survey on the Dongsha atoll earlier this month.

An official from the Ministry of the Interior's Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) , which is in charge of national park affairs, said the 11 species spotted for the first time included merlin, migratory quail, crested tern, plaintive cuckoo, Indian cuckoo, citrine wagtail, short-tailed bush warbler, Gray's grasshopper warbler, red-breasted flycatcher, paradise flycatcher and common rosefinch.
"These new additions have brought to 215 the number of bird species ever sighted and documented in the Dongsha Marine National Park," said a CPA official.

Since the beginning of autumn, the official said, a large number of migratory birds have passed or stopped over in the Dongsha Islands, including many endangered or protected species, such as Chinese goshawk, hair-crested drongo, chestnut-winged cuckoo, Indian cuckoo and ruddy kingfisher.
"The marine national park will continue stepping up conservation efforts and educational publicity to make the park a new wintering paradise for migratory birds," the official added.
Located 444 km southwest of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the Dongsha Islands, also known as the Pratas Islands, comprise Dongsha Island and two coral reefs.

The government made the area a marine national park in October 2007 as part of its efforts to better protect its rich marine resources and biodiversity. The park covers atolls and surrounding waters, with a total acreage of more than 350,000 hectares.
A national monument was erected on Dongsha Island June 30, 1989, as well as an adjacent structure to protect the monument May 18, 1993, to assert its sovereignty over the archipelago.
With an area three times that of Taipei City, the archipelago boasts the largest and most unspoiled group of atolls in the West Pacific.

The reefs surrounding the islands are also the best in Taiwan's territorial waters. Dongsha's coastal waters are known for their biodiversity, with 489 fish species and about 200 kinds of coral documented, as well as numerous other marine species.
