DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulling ways to stop internal party election bribery
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 19:09:56 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will push for passage of a "political party law" to regulate internal party elections, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday in the wake of alleged rampant vote-buying during the ruling Kuomintang's recent election.

The minister made the declaration after President Ma Ying-jeou said in a recent interview with a local magazine "The Journalist" that he supports developing legislation for a political party law to incriminate those who commit vote- buying or bribery in elections for political party positions.

Before the enactment of a political party law, Ma said the government may also consider revising the existing Public Officials Election and Recall Law to regulate intraparty elections in order to prevent such elections from being tarnished by bribery or vote-buying.

The president further said in the interview that regardless of whether the new regulations will be integrated into the proposed Political Party Act or in the revised election and recall law, prison terms should be included as punitive measures for those who are convicted of vote-buying in elections for political party posts.

Ma, who doubles as chairman of the KMT, said that without clear legal regulations to incriminate those who commit vote-buying in elections inside political parties, his administration's lofty goals of political reform and elimination of official corruption cannot be realized.
Ma's statement came amid criticism that the latest elections for the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) was marred by rampant bribery.

Echoing Ma's call, some lawmakers have also proposed that elections for political party positions and party primaries for public office elections be put under regulations of the planned Political Party Act or the existing Public Officials Election and Recall Law.
Interior Minister Jiang noted that the Public Officials Election and Recall Law already stipulates that no bribery is allowed in party primaries for public office elections.

As to elections for political party chairmanship and other party posts, Jiang said, relevant regulations should be incorporated into the proposed Political Party Act which he said his ministry is still working on.

"Interior ministry officials are studying relevant legislation and legal revision issues and will keep close contact with legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties in the process, " Jiang said, adding that his ministry will endeavor to seek a social consensus on the anti-vote-buying cause.

Responding to complaints by opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislators at a legislative session later in the day that some police officers helped with vote canvassing before the KMT's Oct. 11 CSC elections, Jiang said such acts were not done during police officers' working hours.

"The proposed Political Party Act will strictly prohibit such acts and before the law is enacted, I will issue official letters to ask all ministry staff to refrain from being involved in any political party elections," Jiang added.

In an indication of its determination to wipe out corruption and establish clean politics, the KMT kicked two members from the CSC for their involvement in vote- buying during the election and all of the remaining members of the committee have decided to relinquish their CSC posts following Ma's open encouragement.

As a result, the KMT has decided to elect new CSC members on Nov. 14 and 75 hopefuls have registered their candidacy for the election. But only 73 of the hopefuls meet all requirements to run in the election, according to party sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Saint Vincent prime minister lauds firm friendship with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/29/09 19:48:12 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The friendship between Taiwan and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has become ever-stronger after many years of cooperation between the two countries, Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves said Wednesday.

Addressing the inauguration of a national library in the Caribbean country constructed using funds from Taiwan, Gonsalves said the biggest public library in the Caribbean region is the best testimony to the friendship between the two countries.

Gonsalves also expressed his thanks to Taiwan for its assistance with several other infrastructure projects, including the country's Youth Empowerment Service (YES) program, which has been rated as the best model program worthy of emulation by other countries in the region by the Inter-American Development Bank and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's (UNESCO's) Latin American regional office.
The program is geared toward the economic and personal skills and the social enhancement of unemployed young people.
Examination Yuan President John Kuan, who was visiting Saint Vincent and the Grenadines for the country's 30th anniversary of independence, also attended the ceremony.

Kuan said that assisting Taiwan's allies in strengthening the development of their human resources has been included in his government's white paper on foreign aid policy published in May and that the library's establishment marks the fulfillment of the principles covered in the white paper.
Kuan also said that Taiwan will stick to its promise to continue with bilateral cooperative programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to make Taiwan a leading new energy country

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih Thursday ordered the establishment of a new energy promotion committee in a bid to turn Taiwan into a leading country in the development of new energy.

The premier issued the instruction at a weekly Cabinet meeting after hearing a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) report on an action plan for the green energy industry, said Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin following the meeting.
Wu said that Taiwan, with a solid foundation paved by its powerful semiconductor industry, has a great advantage for developing green and other new energies.

However, the premier said there is still a great challenge for Taiwan if it wants to achieve the goal set for the country's new energy industry of attaining over NT$1 trillion (US$31.3 billion) in production value over the next six years, which currently stands at around NT$169 billion.

Wu said the new committee, to be headed by Minister Without Portfolio Liang Chi- yuan, should work toward excluding all the obstacles to make Taiwan a leading country in terms of new energy technology and new energy production.

The MOEA action plan lists sonar-optic, hydrogen and wind energy, ecological fuels, energy information and communication technology and electric vehicles as the major items for priority development, with the aim of "leading Taiwan's industry to transfer to areas with lower carbon emissions and high value."

The MOEA hopes that with breakthroughs in expertise, increased investment, enlarged exports and domestic demand, the production value of the new energy industry will have reached NT$1.15 trillion by 2015. (By Lee Ming-tsung and Bear Lee).

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier instructs Interior Ministry to set up `grandparents day'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 20:51:46 (By Lee Ming-chung and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih told the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Thursday to consider setting up a grandparents day as a "national holiday."

According to Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin, Premier Wu Den-yih asked the MOI at a Cabinet meeting to select a non-work day for a grandparents day so that it will not affect production and industrial development.
Wu said the day should be differentiated from the existing traditional Chong Yang festival for the elderly, which is celebrated on the ninth day of the ninth lunar month.
Education Minister Wu Ching-chi also said at the meeting that setting up such a day would not only help enhance family ethics but also help boost consumption and domestic demand, Su added.
In a move to enhance care for the elderly, the Executive Yuan approved in September a budget of NT$7.5 billion (US$230 million) for an elderly care program.

Under the program, the MOI plans to have implemented 63 projects by the end of 2011 to improve services to low-income elderly, strengthen the health care system and the "friendly environment" for the elderly, and encourage the elderly to participate in social activities.

The population of citizens aged 65 and above had reached over 2.4 million by the end of 2008 -- 10.43 percent of the overall population of the country -- according to the MOI. By 2025, Taiwan is expected to be classed as a "super-aged society, " by which time the population of senior citizens will have reached 4.81 million -- about 20 percent of the country's population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of classes shut down over swine flu shows sharp rise

TEXT.P: Although more and more classes around the country are being suspended amid the rapid spread of influenza A(H1N1) , the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) said Thursday that the guidelines regulating class closures will not be changed.

Based on the "325" guidelines published on Aug. 18, classes at kindergartens, primary schools, and junior and senior high schools, as well as cram schools and day-care centers, must be closed for five days to prevent cluster infections if any two students in the same class are diagnosed with H1N1 within three days, the CECC said in a press release.
Institutes or facilities caught failing to follow the guidelines will be subject to disciplinary action by local governments, the CECC said.

According to CECC statistics, a total of 919 classes at 439 schools nationwide had been closed as of the previous day, accounting for 0.67 percent of the total. To date, there have been 454 hospitalization cases of influenza A(H1N1), or swine flu, including 27 deaths and 33 people remaining in hospital.
As of Tuesday, 809 classes at 427 schools around the country had remained closed due to H1N1 infections among the students.

Meanwhile, the Pin-lin Elementary School in northern Taiwan's Taipei County announced that the whole school had been shut down for five days a day earlier, making it the second school to do so on the orders of the county's education bureau following the closure of the Pin-lin Junior High School.
Twenty eight of the 223 students at the Pin-lin Elementary School had been confirmed as having contracted H1N1.

The increased spread of swine flu among students has led to mounting pressure on parents, many of whom are having to take time off work to take care of their children, while teachers are also facing greater pressure to conduct make-up classes on holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's export reliance on China increasing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 21:01:56 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: With China leading the global economic recovery, two-way trade across the Taiwan Strait is regaining momentum steadily and Taiwan's export reliance on China has risen correspondingly, government sources said Thursday.

In August, Taiwan's exports to China reached US$6.09 billion, an 11-month high since the global financial crisis hit its peak last September, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said in a press statement.

Despite a rebound in shipments to China month-on-month, August's export amount still marked a 17.7 percent decline from the year-earlier level because of an export boom that ran until August 2008, the statement said, adding that the year-on-year export decrease for the month was the smallest in 11 months.

China's fast economic recovery has led to an increase in Taiwan's exports to China, the statement went on, adding that China accounted for 32 percent of Taiwan's total exports in August, the second-highest in cross-strait trade history. The highest rate was registered in September 2007, when the ratio hit 32.5 percent.

The BOFT statement further said that although Taiwan's overall exports to China showed negative growth in August, some key export items posted gains. For instance, IC chip sales marked a 15 percent increase compared with the previous month.
In August, Taiwan's trade surplus with China hit a 12-month high of US$3.93 billion, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU, Taiwan working hard on visa-free treatment: EU envoy

TEXT.P: The top European Union envoy to Taiwan said Thursday that the European Commission is working hard with the Taiwanese authorities to establish visa-free privileges for Taiwanese nationals entering the Schengen area, but added that there is no timetable on the issue.
Guy Ledoux, head of the Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office, told CNA that "we are working towards making a proposal before the end of the year, but whether it can be done I'm not sure."
He noted that the incumbent EU Commission's term will expire at the end of October, with a new commission coming into office in January.
"Before that, I don't know whether any new initiative will be made," Ledoux said.

Ledoux's remarks came in response to comments made by Charles Tannock, a member of the European Parliament (MEP) and chairman of a pro-Taiwan group in the European parliament, who said a day earlier in Taipei that he hopes Taiwanese people will be able to enter EU nations without a visa by early 2010.

Although Chiu Jong-jen, director-general of the department of European Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , said later that day that Taiwanese nationals are expected to be granted visa-free privileges at some point between April and June next year, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen pointed out that in fact there is no timetable for the issue, saying only that things are moving in a positive direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei travel fair to open with special offers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:31:28 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A wide range of special offers will be offered at the Taipei International Travel Fair (ITF) 2009 set to open at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday, as local tourism operators attempt to reverse the downturn in the sector due to the swine flu epidemic and the effects of Typhoon Morakot, an event organizer said Thursday.
This year, a record high of 1,206 booths will be set up by operators from 58 countries during the four-day fair, according to Stanley Chang-shou Yen.
Of the total, 256 booths will be promoting the World Expo 2010 Shanghai, Yen added.
The fair offers a good opportunity for visitors to hunt for bargains and get first-hand information and tips on travel in various countries, he added.

In recent years, individual tours have become an increasingly popular form of travel among young people worldwide, Yen noted, while encouraging those interested in planning this form of tourism to visit the fair to gather information for their travel plans.

Between last July and this July, the number of Taiwanese tourists visiting China reached about 4.75 million, more than half of a total of 8 million overseas visits made last year by Taiwanese people, Taiwan Visitors Association Chairman Chou Ching-hsiung said.

Between last July, when restrictions on visits to Taiwan by people from China were relaxed, and the end of September, Chinese people made more than 885,000 visits to Taiwan, making China Taiwan's second-biggest source of visitors, second only to Japan, according to statistics.
In addition, the number of Hong Kong tourists visiting Taiwan has reached 540,000 so far this year, up 15 percent year-on- year, according to Yen.

Backpackers form the largest group of visitors to Taiwan, who are attracted by the country's culture and natural scenery and the convenience of travel, according to Yen, who added that Taiwan therefore should promote its tourism attractions and expand its international tourist sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baseball players admit game-fixing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:37:28 (By Sunrise Huang, Oscar Wu, Sarah Lin and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Two professional baseball players of the Brother Elephants team admitted Thursday to being involved in game-fixing.
Wang Chin-li and Wu Pau-hsien made their confessions while being questioned by prosecutors of the Banciao District Prosecutors Office in Taipei County.

An investigation into professional baseball game-fixing had been snowballing over the past few days since nine players were summoned and eight named as defendants after questioning a day earlier. More players were summoned Thursday evening.
Wang and Wu were the only two detained for further questioning and were released early Thursday after confessing their involvement.

Among the eight defendants, six are members of the Brother Elephants, including Wang, Wu, Tsao Chin-hui, Liu Yu-chan, Li Hao-jen and Wang Chun-tai. Hsieh Chia- hsien of the Sinon Bulls and Chang Chih-chia of the La New Bears have also been implicated.

Brother Elephants manager Hung Jui-he suggested last year that the team would be disbanded if any players were proven to have engaged in game-fixing. With six players listed as defendants by prosecutors, the future of Brother Elephants is of grave concern of baseball fans, as Hung reiterated his comments after his players were summoned by prosecutors.

Minister of Sports Affairs Dai Hsia-ling also expressed concern about Hung's decision. Noting the team's contributions to Taiwan's professional baseball development, Dai called on Hung not to disband the team.
She pointed out that the Brother Elephants has been the country's most popular team, the future of Taiwan's professional baseball is closely related to the future of the Brother Elephants.

Meanwhile, Wayne Lee, secretary-general of the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , said that any players detained would be banned from playing and suspended from the payroll. The teams to which they belong will be left to decide on whether to terminate their contracts, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. beef import accord should be screened by legislature
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:42:43 (By Su Lung-chi, Chen Ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: If Taiwan's newly signed protocol with the United States on opening its market wider to U.S. beef from cattle younger than 30 months is an international treaty, it should be approved by the Legislative Yuan before it takes effect, a legislative official said Thursday.
Liu Han-ting, head of the Legislative Yuan's Organic Laws and Statutes Bureau, made the remarks while fielding questions at a legislative committee session.

During the session, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang said that as the new Taiwan-U.S. beef trade protocol is closely related to the people's rights and health, it should be screened by the legislature.

According to a previous ruling by the Council of Grand Justices, Liu said, written documents signed with a foreign country, regardless of its designation or name, should be screened by the legislature if its provisions are related to the people's rights or concern national interests and major affairs.
Even if the new protocol is merely an administrative accord, it should still be sent to the legislature, according to Liu.
"But so far, we have not yet received any document or notice from the executive branch," Liu added.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) announced Oct. 23 that Taiwan would expand market access for U.S. beef after officials of the two countries clinched an accord the previous day in Washington, D.C., to lift a partial ban on U.S. beef imports.

Under the terms of the new accord, U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef, intestines, brains, spinal cords and processed beef from cattle younger than 30 months that have not been contaminated with "specific risk materials" will be allowed to enter Taiwan starting Nov. 10.

Specific risk materials are defined in the protocol as brains, skulls, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cords, vertebral columns and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months of age and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months that contain no specified risk materials.
The new market-opening decision has since drawn flak from opposition parties, consumer rights activists, lawmakers and even city and county officials.

In the face of mounting criticism, Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that the government will see to it that U.S. beef offal and ground beef does not appear on Taiwan's market, but he did not elaborate on technical details.

DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang also said the same day that if U.S. beef offal and ground beef is shipped to Taiwan, his department will inspect each case to check whether the products are contaminated with any bacteria or viruses and said any products that fail the inspections will not be allowed to enter the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF head urges cross-strait talks on media exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:48:49 (By Chou Hui-ying, Liu Cheng-ching and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) proposed Thursday that cross-Taiwan Strait media exchanges be included on the agenda of talks between Taiwan and China next year.
Chiang Pin-kung, who was in Beijing as the head of a Taiwanese media delegation, made the call while meeting Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council.

Wang in return said that for the foreseeable future, cross-strait talks should remain focused on economic issues, but he added that issues related to news and cultural exchanges could be "gradually" included in the agenda of future talks.

The SEF and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , are semi-official intermediary bodies set up respectively by Taiwan and China to deal with cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.
The SEF and ARATS have held three rounds of talks over the past year or so and have reached nine agreements aimed at increasing cross-strait trade and economic exchanges.

A fourth round of talks will take place in December in Taichung, central Taiwan, when both sides are expected to sign four agreements regarding fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
The media delegation is comprised of executives from 15 Taiwanese news media outlets, as well as officials of the SEF and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Earlier in the day, the delegation visited the General Administration of Press and Publication, the Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily for exchanges of views on cross-strait news coverage.

The delegation also visited Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, ARATS President Chen Yunlin, and the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television (SARFT) soon after its arrival in Beijing the previous day.
The delegation was scheduled to visit the city of Shanxi Friday before returning to Taiwan Sunday.

In related news, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun urged China to consider reciprocal treatment for Taiwan's TV stations while asking Taiwan to allow programs of China Central Television (CCTV) to be broadcast in Taiwan.

Liu made the remarks in response to reports that MAC Vice Chairman Chao Chien- min, who is a member of the media delegation in his capacity as a SEF board director, said while meeting SARFT officials that CCTV will have no problem gaining a Taiwanese audience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Excellent university students should be retained: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:58:56 (By Carfie Li and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou instructed the education authorities Thursday to make efforts to retain Taiwan's excellent students in domestic colleges and universities.
Ma made the remarks while meeting a group of winners of the 2009 International Olympiad competitions in physics and mathematics at the Presidential Office.

He was referring to recent moves by the University of Hong Kong and the City University of Hong Kong to recruit Taiwanese students by offering a series of privileges including free tuition and dormitory accommodation, as well as subsidized living costs.
Saying that many other universities in France and the United States are following suit, Ma told the Ministry of Education to address the issue to prevent an exodus of Taiwan's best students.
"We are not opposed to studying abroad, but we just cannot let most of our excellent youngsters pursue studies in foreign countries," said Ma.

He added that despite budget constraints, the government still allocated NT$10 billion for 2010 to help domestic universities upgrade their academic levels in a bid to push them into the ranks of the world's top universities.

Although the investment is still far less than that made by the governments of Japan, South Korea and Singapore, it is still enough to prevent Taiwan's universities from lagging too far behind their foreign counterparts, according to Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to post quarantine officials in U.S. to ensure beef safety
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 23:04:54 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan's animal health inspection bureau said Thursday that the bureau will post officials in the United States to check the quality of U.S. beef and beef products that are to be delivered to Taiwan.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture came up with the decision after the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee passed a resolution earlier in the day that the quarantine bureau and the Cabinet-level Department of Health should post officials in the United States.

Those officials should carry out regular checks of slaughterhouses and other meat product facilities whose beef and beef products will be sold to Taiwan to ensure that their products are free from bacterial or viral contamination.

The bureau said in a press statement that one of its staff members already stationed in the United States is in fact a veterinarian who is qualified to check the quality of U.S. beef and related products before they are delivered to Taiwan.

If he finds that the meat processing plants do not meet the requirements set forth in the trade protocol signed by the two countries, the veterinarian is under instructions to report the case back to Taiwan, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier instructs Interior Ministry to set up `grandparents day'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 20:51:46 (By Lee Ming-chung and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih told the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Thursday to consider setting up a grandparents day as a "national holiday."

The population of citizens aged 65 and above had reached over 2.4 million by the end of 2008 -- 10.43 percent of the overall population of the country -- according to the MOI. By 2025, Taiwan is expected to be classed as a "super-aged society, " by which time the population of senior citizens will have reached 4.81 million -- about 20 percent of the country's population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of classes shut down over swine flu shows sharp rise

TEXT.P: Although more and more classes around the country are being suspended amid the rapid spread of influenza A(H1N1) , the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) said Thursday that the guidelines regulating class closures will not be changed.

Based on the "325" guidelines published on Aug. 18, classes at kindergartens, primary schools, and junior and senior high schools, as well as cram schools and day-care centers, must be closed for five days to prevent cluster infections if any two students in the same class are diagnosed with H1N1 within three days, the CECC said in a press release.
Institutes or facilities caught failing to follow the guidelines will be subject to disciplinary action by local governments, the CECC said.

According to CECC statistics, a total of 919 classes at 439 schools nationwide had been closed as of the previous day, accounting for 0.67 percent of the total. To date, there have been 454 hospitalization cases of influenza A(H1N1), or swine flu, including 27 deaths and 33 people remaining in hospital.
As of Tuesday, 809 classes at 427 schools around the country had remained closed due to H1N1 infections among the students.

Meanwhile, the Pin-lin Elementary School in northern Taiwan's Taipei County announced that the whole school had been shut down for five days a day earlier, making it the second school to do so on the orders of the county's education bureau following the closure of the Pin-lin Junior High School.
Twenty eight of the 223 students at the Pin-lin Elementary School had been confirmed as having contracted H1N1.

The increased spread of swine flu among students has led to mounting pressure on parents, many of whom are having to take time off work to take care of their children, while teachers are also facing greater pressure to conduct make-up classes on holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's export reliance on China increasing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 21:01:56 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: With China leading the global economic recovery, two-way trade across the Taiwan Strait is regaining momentum steadily and Taiwan's export reliance on China has risen correspondingly, government sources said Thursday.

In August, Taiwan's exports to China reached US$6.09 billion, an 11-month high since the global financial crisis hit its peak last September, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said in a press statement.

Despite a rebound in shipments to China month-on-month, August's export amount still marked a 17.7 percent decline from the year-earlier level because of an export boom that ran until August 2008, the statement said, adding that the year-on-year export decrease for the month was the smallest in 11 months.

China's fast economic recovery has led to an increase in Taiwan's exports to China, the statement went on, adding that China accounted for 32 percent of Taiwan's total exports in August, the second-highest in cross-strait trade history. The highest rate was registered in September 2007, when the ratio hit 32.5 percent.

The BOFT statement further said that although Taiwan's overall exports to China showed negative growth in August, some key export items posted gains. For instance, IC chip sales marked a 15 percent increase compared with the previous month.
In August, Taiwan's trade surplus with China hit a 12-month high of US$3.93 billion, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU, Taiwan working hard on visa-free treatment: EU envoy

TEXT.P: The top European Union envoy to Taiwan said Thursday that the European Commission is working hard with the Taiwanese authorities to establish visa-free privileges for Taiwanese nationals entering the Schengen area, but added that there is no timetable on the issue.
Guy Ledoux, head of the Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office, told CNA that "we are working towards making a proposal before the end of the year, but whether it can be done I'm not sure."
He noted that the incumbent EU Commission's term will expire at the end of October, with a new commission coming into office in January.
"Before that, I don't know whether any new initiative will be made," Ledoux said.

Ledoux's remarks came in response to comments made by Charles Tannock, a member of the European Parliament (MEP) and chairman of a pro-Taiwan group in the European parliament, who said a day earlier in Taipei that he hopes Taiwanese people will be able to enter EU nations without a visa by early 2010.

Although Chiu Jong-jen, director-general of the department of European Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , said later that day that Taiwanese nationals are expected to be granted visa-free privileges at some point between April and June next year, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen pointed out that in fact there is no timetable for the issue, saying only that things are moving in a positive direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei travel fair to open with special offers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:31:28 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A wide range of special offers will be offered at the Taipei International Travel Fair (ITF) 2009 set to open at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday, as local tourism operators attempt to reverse the downturn in the sector due to the swine flu epidemic and the effects of Typhoon Morakot, an event organizer said Thursday.
This year, a record high of 1,206 booths will be set up by operators from 58 countries during the four-day fair, according to Stanley Chang-shou Yen.
Of the total, 256 booths will be promoting the World Expo 2010 Shanghai, Yen added.
The fair offers a good opportunity for visitors to hunt for bargains and get first-hand information and tips on travel in various countries, he added.

In recent years, individual tours have become an increasingly popular form of travel among young people worldwide, Yen noted, while encouraging those interested in planning this form of tourism to visit the fair to gather information for their travel plans.

Between last July and this July, the number of Taiwanese tourists visiting China reached about 4.75 million, more than half of a total of 8 million overseas visits made last year by Taiwanese people, Taiwan Visitors Association Chairman Chou Ching-hsiung said.

Between last July, when restrictions on visits to Taiwan by people from China were relaxed, and the end of September, Chinese people made more than 885,000 visits to Taiwan, making China Taiwan's second-biggest source of visitors, second only to Japan, according to statistics.
In addition, the number of Hong Kong tourists visiting Taiwan has reached 540,000 so far this year, up 15 percent year-on- year, according to Yen.

Backpackers form the largest group of visitors to Taiwan, who are attracted by the country's culture and natural scenery and the convenience of travel, according to Yen, who added that Taiwan therefore should promote its tourism attractions and expand its international tourist sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baseball players admit game-fixing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:37:28 (By Sunrise Huang, Oscar Wu, Sarah Lin and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Two professional baseball players of the Brother Elephants team admitted Thursday to being involved in game-fixing.
Wang Chin-li and Wu Pau-hsien made their confessions while being questioned by prosecutors of the Banciao District Prosecutors Office in Taipei County.

An investigation into professional baseball game-fixing had been snowballing over the past few days since nine players were summoned and eight named as defendants after questioning a day earlier. More players were summoned Thursday evening.
Wang and Wu were the only two detained for further questioning and were released early Thursday after confessing their involvement.

Among the eight defendants, six are members of the Brother Elephants, including Wang, Wu, Tsao Chin-hui, Liu Yu-chan, Li Hao-jen and Wang Chun-tai. Hsieh Chia- hsien of the Sinon Bulls and Chang Chih-chia of the La New Bears have also been implicated.

Brother Elephants manager Hung Jui-he suggested last year that the team would be disbanded if any players were proven to have engaged in game-fixing. With six players listed as defendants by prosecutors, the future of Brother Elephants is of grave concern of baseball fans, as Hung reiterated his comments after his players were summoned by prosecutors.

Minister of Sports Affairs Dai Hsia-ling also expressed concern about Hung's decision. Noting the team's contributions to Taiwan's professional baseball development, Dai called on Hung not to disband the team.
She pointed out that the Brother Elephants has been the country's most popular team, the future of Taiwan's professional baseball is closely related to the future of the Brother Elephants.

Meanwhile, Wayne Lee, secretary-general of the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , said that any players detained would be banned from playing and suspended from the payroll. The teams to which they belong will be left to decide on whether to terminate their contracts, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. beef import accord should be screened by legislature
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:42:43 (By Su Lung-chi, Chen Ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: If Taiwan's newly signed protocol with the United States on opening its market wider to U.S. beef from cattle younger than 30 months is an international treaty, it should be approved by the Legislative Yuan before it takes effect, a legislative official said Thursday.
Liu Han-ting, head of the Legislative Yuan's Organic Laws and Statutes Bureau, made the remarks while fielding questions at a legislative committee session.

During the session, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang said that as the new Taiwan-U.S. beef trade protocol is closely related to the people's rights and health, it should be screened by the legislature.

According to a previous ruling by the Council of Grand Justices, Liu said, written documents signed with a foreign country, regardless of its designation or name, should be screened by the legislature if its provisions are related to the people's rights or concern national interests and major affairs.
Even if the new protocol is merely an administrative accord, it should still be sent to the legislature, according to Liu.
"But so far, we have not yet received any document or notice from the executive branch," Liu added.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) announced Oct. 23 that Taiwan would expand market access for U.S. beef after officials of the two countries clinched an accord the previous day in Washington, D.C., to lift a partial ban on U.S. beef imports.

Under the terms of the new accord, U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef, intestines, brains, spinal cords and processed beef from cattle younger than 30 months that have not been contaminated with "specific risk materials" will be allowed to enter Taiwan starting Nov. 10.

Specific risk materials are defined in the protocol as brains, skulls, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cords, vertebral columns and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months of age and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months that contain no specified risk materials.
The new market-opening decision has since drawn flak from opposition parties, consumer rights activists, lawmakers and even city and county officials.

In the face of mounting criticism, Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that the government will see to it that U.S. beef offal and ground beef does not appear on Taiwan's market, but he did not elaborate on technical details.

DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang also said the same day that if U.S. beef offal and ground beef is shipped to Taiwan, his department will inspect each case to check whether the products are contaminated with any bacteria or viruses and said any products that fail the inspections will not be allowed to enter the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF head urges cross-strait talks on media exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:48:49 (By Chou Hui-ying, Liu Cheng-ching and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) proposed Thursday that cross-Taiwan Strait media exchanges be included on the agenda of talks between Taiwan and China next year.
Chiang Pin-kung, who was in Beijing as the head of a Taiwanese media delegation, made the call while meeting Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council.

Wang in return said that for the foreseeable future, cross-strait talks should remain focused on economic issues, but he added that issues related to news and cultural exchanges could be "gradually" included in the agenda of future talks.

The SEF and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , are semi-official intermediary bodies set up respectively by Taiwan and China to deal with cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.
The SEF and ARATS have held three rounds of talks over the past year or so and have reached nine agreements aimed at increasing cross-strait trade and economic exchanges.

A fourth round of talks will take place in December in Taichung, central Taiwan, when both sides are expected to sign four agreements regarding fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
The media delegation is comprised of executives from 15 Taiwanese news media outlets, as well as officials of the SEF and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Earlier in the day, the delegation visited the General Administration of Press and Publication, the Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily for exchanges of views on cross-strait news coverage.

The delegation also visited Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, ARATS President Chen Yunlin, and the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television (SARFT) soon after its arrival in Beijing the previous day.
The delegation was scheduled to visit the city of Shanxi Friday before returning to Taiwan Sunday.

In related news, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun urged China to consider reciprocal treatment for Taiwan's TV stations while asking Taiwan to allow programs of China Central Television (CCTV) to be broadcast in Taiwan.

Liu made the remarks in response to reports that MAC Vice Chairman Chao Chien- min, who is a member of the media delegation in his capacity as a SEF board director, said while meeting SARFT officials that CCTV will have no problem gaining a Taiwanese audience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Excellent university students should be retained: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 22:58:56 (By Carfie Li and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou instructed the education authorities Thursday to make efforts to retain Taiwan's excellent students in domestic colleges and universities.
Ma made the remarks while meeting a group of winners of the 2009 International Olympiad competitions in physics and mathematics at the Presidential Office.

He was referring to recent moves by the University of Hong Kong and the City University of Hong Kong to recruit Taiwanese students by offering a series of privileges including free tuition and dormitory accommodation, as well as subsidized living costs.
Saying that many other universities in France and the United States are following suit, Ma told the Ministry of Education to address the issue to prevent an exodus of Taiwan's best students.
"We are not opposed to studying abroad, but we just cannot let most of our excellent youngsters pursue studies in foreign countries," said Ma.

He added that despite budget constraints, the government still allocated NT$10 billion for 2010 to help domestic universities upgrade their academic levels in a bid to push them into the ranks of the world's top universities.

Although the investment is still far less than that made by the governments of Japan, South Korea and Singapore, it is still enough to prevent Taiwan's universities from lagging too far behind their foreign counterparts, according to Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to post quarantine officials in U.S. to ensure beef safety
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/09 23:04:54 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan's animal health inspection bureau said Thursday that the bureau will post officials in the United States to check the quality of U.S. beef and beef products that are to be delivered to Taiwan.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture came up with the decision after the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee passed a resolution earlier in the day that the quarantine bureau and the Cabinet-level Department of Health should post officials in the United States.

Those officials should carry out regular checks of slaughterhouses and other meat product facilities whose beef and beef products will be sold to Taiwan to ensure that their products are free from bacterial or viral contamination.

The bureau said in a press statement that one of its staff members already stationed in the United States is in fact a veterinarian who is qualified to check the quality of U.S. beef and related products before they are delivered to Taiwan.

If he finds that the meat processing plants do not meet the requirements set forth in the trade protocol signed by the two countries, the veterinarian is under instructions to report the case back to Taiwan, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 30, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
2001: Microsoft Taiwan formally launches the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center, with thousands registered to try out the system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."
